wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: (noun neuter) the first letter of the Ateso alphabet

a vowel letter as in ‘arm’. a-1 prefix forming infinitive of ko-verbs: abaar (to knock off); aditakin (to dash away, run off very fast). a-2 prefix of adjectival and derivative nouns expressing past tense qualities. acobe Dr. Ecookit noi: Dr. Ecookit was very astute. ecobe clever; astute; wise. acobeu (derivative noun of ‘ecobe’) cleverness; astuteness; wisdom. a-3 prefix of feminine nouns singular and plural, and nouns of average size (neither too small nor too big in size): amoru: a stone, a pebble; aberu: a woman; akine: a she-goat a-4 prefix of feminine prepositional nouns: amot: in the pot; akokoroi: at, among the chicken; angor: among, towards women; adere: in or into the calabash; akongu: in (to) the eye. a-5 pronominal prefix of 1st person singular of ko-verbs in present tenses, and 3rd person singular and plural of past perfect tenses. akoto (eong) alosit Soroti: I want to go to Soroti, the word ‘eong’ – I, me - can be omitted without loss because the word “akoto” already implies ‘I want’. ko-verb - aime: to lick (with the tongue); 3rd person past perfect tense – ame: she/he/it has licked (with the tongue). aa! No! Do not! Stop it. aa! kolot ngina: No! go there. aabaat a crack in the mud. aabaran a rich man; a wealthy man.aabea nukitim dandruff. aabea nuka ilac: nits; eggs of lice. aabea nuka alos: badly ground grain. aabelan one who wounds someone’s head with a stick. aabenyan a guerrilla fighter; a rebel; a rogue; a lawless person, etc aabokan a spy, a tempter; a digger; one who digs. aabokan atesia: a professional grave-digger.aabolian a player; a jester; joker; sportsman or an athlete. aabuoron a robber; a confiscator.aabwaan a superintendent; a guard (of thing); a headman; one who builds fences or enclosures. aabwoan a sponsor; one who stands (bail, for election, etc).aacerit a star. aacer: a constellation; stars. aacoan a wise man; a wise person, a clever person.aacukut a blacksmith's bellows used for forging bells for dancing, or spears and axes; a blowpipe; the engine of a ferry boat.aadedengan a severe, savage or cruel person or animal.aadekan a patient; a sick or ill man.aademaran a robber; a plunderer.aadiekan a judge; a mediator; an arbitrator or arbiter. aadilon an early riser or traveller. amina eong aadilok: I like early risers. aadingiriran a fast runner; a fast cyclist. aadonyon a tailor; a dress-maker.aadotean an adulterer; a fornicator; a prostitute; a sex worker. aadukon a builder; an architect; a mason. aadyekan intercessor; adjudicator; separator; judge; arbiter; rescuer. aageretan one who massages, embrocates (sets a bone); masseur. aagogongon the strong, severe, hardy, difficult, strict one. aagolon a doorkeeper; a prison guard; a loser; a failure (in school).aagwelan a buyer; a purchaser. aajakunan a rescuer; a saviour; a redeemer; a liberator. aajalan iboro a generous, liberal, open-handed, big-hearted, charitable, or munificent person. aajaran a living person; the living. aajarak ka lukatwak: the living and the dead. aajean a potter; a person who moulds with clay, etc. aajenan an eyewitness; a martyr; one who knows; a deponent. aajengan a skinner; a person who removes the skin from a slaughtered animal. aajepan a wood cutter; a lumberman; a cheat; a trickster. aajion a fighter, combatant, boxer, wrestler, pugilist, rebel; a warrior, soldier. aakadakinan a depressed, sad, downhearted, or disgusted person. aakapiton a soldier in arms; a person in arms. aakinangan one who hears but does not answer. aakoran a distributor; a benefactor. aakorion a cultivator (a farmer who cultivates land); a planter; a grower of crops; a sedentary farmer; a peasant farmer.aakwenan one who laughs; a scoffer. aakwenaran one who ridicules; one who derides. aalakany a cooking pot having a wide aperture aalakunan a saviour; a redeemer. aalemunan one who removes something. aalemunan esolo: a taxpayer. aaleman epaaba: a cotton sorter or picker. aalemunan eluk: one who pays a fine for committing adultery or pays on behalf of an adulterer.aaliaton a creeper; a creeping thing (like a snake, worm). aaliliton a jealous or envious person. aalimonokinan a preacher, cleric, or reverend; an informer; announcer. aalimoron a reporter; a betrayer, traitor, rebel, turncoat, defector, or a deserter; an announcer, presenter, telecaster, or a broadcaster. aaliokon a liar; a hypocrite; a quack. aalokan a man who ensnares; a man who traps; a man who sets traps. aalokunan an adolescent male; one who traps or ensnares. aaloman an entrant; one who enters somewhere; an adulterer. aaloman aberu adulterer.aaloman kinga: a guard; a watchman; a witch. aalomaran one who enters; an entrant; a recruit; a newcomer. aaloton a pedestrian; a traveller; an explorer, voyager, trekker, a tourist; a passenger, or a commuter. aalumon a swimmer; a (scuba) diver. aalungan one who refuses something (in anger). aalyaton a creeping thing. aamamian the missing; absentee; the non-existent thing; imagination; phantom. kideikis loamamian: leave something for the absent one. edar ngolida amamiak: I waited for him in vain.aamejan a hunter; a seeker. aamejat a clever hunter or a person fond of hunting. aameran a sot; a drunkard; an alcoholic. aamimit a small bee. aamodan a cheat; a conman; fraudster; swindler; one who cheats. aamonyan one who weeps; one who cries; lachrymose. aamuriait a grape fruit from ekamuriei shrub, eaten ripe or as a vegetable seasoning when crushed raw. aangatan a robber, burglar, mugger, or a raider; a brigand, a bandit, or thug. aangibiriran a fast runner.aanyaman apese one who takes part of a girl’s dowry. aanyaman itunga a cannibal; a man-eater. engatuny lokanyaman itunga: a man-eating lion.aanyanar to examine, superintend, supervise, or inspect. aanyanaran a Protestant or Church of Uganda bishop; inspector; overseer. aanyet a mirror; something for seeing or for examining; the act or state of seeing or examining.aanyinyir sweat; perspiration. aanyit to keep in view. aanyun to see for oneself; to feel by touch; to meet or see each other. akoto aanyun ijo: I want to see you. aanyuni ber: I'll first see for myself. abu eong kaany ican: I had trouble or difficulty. aanyunet an example; a specimen; a model; a mirror; a sign; a miracle. aapegan one who denies; a protester; one who objects.aapeton a kicker; one who kicks. aapeton emopiira: a football player. emopiira lopetot: a ball for kicking; a football. aapikin to be near to, close to. aapikis kesi oiduka: they are nearing the shops. aapikinit to be approximate to, close to. aapikinit eong ikar akwatat luapolou: I am nearing a hundred years of age. aapiu (singular noun F) vicinity; nearness; propinquity. aapolon (a title of respect) a great person; a principal; an important person. aapu to be near; to be close to; to be imminent. (Conjugation: 1st person - aapie eong: I am near. iapie ijo: you are near (to me). kiapie iso: we are near. Imperative: koapu: come near (singular). koapuutu: come near (plural). koapie: be near (singular). koapiete: be near (plural).idunyasi kesi: they are near one another; they are neighbours. aapucon one who prepares a feast to reconcile with another; a peace-maker; a reconciler; an arbiter.aapupok: the audience. aapurokinan one who replies or answers back; a pleader; a lawyer; an intercessor. aapuron the intercessor; an arbiter; an advocate.koapuutu: come near, be near (plural). aaracor a plant, Labiate. aarakin1 to force or to compel; to kill elsewhere. aarakin bon: to commit suicide. aar bonik: to kill one another. aarakin2 to kill for someone else; to cause to do by force; to convince of guilt. aaran a murderer; a serial killer. aarar to despatch off, kill, or destroy; to kill off. lokaaran; ekaaran: a murderer. aarar: to abrade; to destroy (a court case) or to extinguish; to abrogate a legislation. aararet abrogation; scrapping; annulment; nullification; cancellation. aare two; a couple. aaremon one who spears; one who punctures. aaret (singular noun F) cow-dung; manure. (jocular) a huge mound of human faeces.aario (singular noun F) a slaughter; a killing; a murdering; a massacring; a slaying; a putting to death; the death sentence. aarotan a spy; a sleuth; a scout; a detective. aarotan iyemuto: a journalist. aarotan akiro: a spy or sleuth. aarucon a fitter; a plumber; a linkman. aarun1 to requisition. aarun2 to get by killing; to get after long pleading or begging; to raid; to extort or get by force, coercion, or threats. aaruwon a commander-in-chief of an army or any group. aasaan a woman servant. aasaan ateker: a family or clan caretaker; an attendant; a servant. aasaban a liar; fraudster; conman; a charlatan doctor; a witchdoctor; an impostor. aasabat a perennial or perpetual liar; a fraud; a charlatan; a dubious medicine man. aasean a voter; the electorate; a constituent; an elector. aasian one who escapes, i.e. an escapee; one who runs away; a fugitive; a deserter. aasioman a school-goer; a student (of reading).aasupon a tracker dog; a ferret dog; one who smells out (something hidden). aatacan one who pays up; a payer; a financier or sponsor. aatacan esolo: a taxpayer. aatacan iropito: a paymaster; a payroll officer. aatereunan a confessor (of bad doing); a rat (one who betrays a cause); a black leg; a sell-out. aatubon a judge; an arbiter; a cutter; a referee; an umpire; a magistrate; a butcher. aatubon akituk: a butcher of cows. aatubon imusaagon: a court judge. aatumunan a youth; a young girl of 14–16 years; an adolescent girl. aatupiton a follower; an attendant; a cohort; an aide; a servant; a henchman; a companion. aatupiton Yesu: Christ’s disciple. aatwan the mortal being; the dead one. aawean a man who sows; a broadcaster (of news or seeds). aawokon akipi a water-drawer; a person who fetches water. aawurian a parent. aawuton a castrator; an emasculator.aayeton a carver; one who chips away. aayuunan a rescuer; a saviour; a liberator; a redeemer. abaaba to strike, hit or beat (with a hard object on a hard surface) repeatedly. kinyek abaaba eong akakou k’ebela: stop conking my head with a stick. abaangat a crack in the dry mud. erit loeonit ileleba abaangan: dry mud in the kraal has a lot of cracks. abaango a species of wading bird resembling a duck; a green ibis. abaar to kill, to slay, to lynch an animal or person. ekotosi itunga abaar ekokolan: the mob wants to lynch a thief. abaasi a motor bus. abaati a corrugated iron or zinc sheet; a roof made of iron sheets; an iron or zinc-roofed house.ababairet a xylophone. ababairen nuimusugun: the glockenspiel (literally, the European xylophone). ababar (of beer, fruit) to begin to ferment or to ripen. abaikin to be overcome by shame; to be overwhelmed with shame, guilt, or vice; to be abashed. abaikis ejakait akiro: the chief is guilty of wrong doing. abaikis nges iponesio lueroko: she/he is steeped in vice. abaiki ngol emusaago: he was found guilty. abakaasa an envelope (i.e. a covering for a letter). abakas to call; to say. ebakai ai?: what is being said? what do they say? what do they call it? ebakas itunga: people say.... ebekoi: it is said. abala eong…: I say…; I am of the opinion that….; I think…; I was on the point of saying…. ibalas bo yesi ai?: what do you think?; what do you say? ebala esukaali pii: (the half-dissolved) sugar is (or feels) like jelly or syrup. ebalai: it is said; people say... nuebalai; nuabekoi; erwom: what is said; rumours.abala1 a plant; a root parasite of sorghum, Striga. abala2 to promise; to say; to repeat. nepe abala kalim akiro, kebapete akit: just as I was about to utter a word, I received a slap on the ear. to do; to sound like; to be imitating the stated sound, act, etc. ebala mwe mwe: it sparkles; it glitters. abalabala to talk at random; to talk nonsense. abalabalat a pennant wing; a nightjar (a nocturnal bird of the swift family with a harsh discordant cry). abalanana to keep promising; to keep saying; to keep repeating. abalang1 a plant, its ash used for salt, Vernonia cirnerea. abalang2 salt extracted from plant ash. aitokony abalang: (in a ceremony) to give food cooked with abalang to a woman who has recently given birth. aitale abalang: (of a person) to abstain from or go without eating salted food. abalar to promise. akiteng naebalare mamai ngesi na: this is the cow which was promised to uncle. abaliiga (a legendary character in Teso tales) a cheat; a conman; a fraud; a swindler. abangaan to become stupid, mute, foolish, deaf, or daft; to make a fool of oneself; to play the fool. abangaanar to become hysterical, stupid, deaf, foolish, silly, mad, etc. abangaanut (singular noun F) folly; stupidity; madness; dullness, etc. aikany abanganut: to endure (someone else’s) stupidity. abangacin a fat greenish-yellow grasshopper. abanganai a Flappet lark. abangit a female twin-child.abao a board; a chalk board; a wooden block; a timber. abar (collective noun F) riches; wealth; treasure.abaraapu a refrigerator; a fridge; an ice block; ice cream. abarak a pot for drinking or serving beer (an almost circular-shaped pot into which undiluted beer is decanted from the eli pot and hot water added). abarakakait a large pot with a small mouth. abaran a rich man; a wealthy man.ebareni papa epenek kede emweeso: daddy is shaving his beard with a razorblade.abarit to be rich in livestock, money, or non-crop items. abarun (of things) to become numerous, plentiful, abundant, or copious. abasang a pointed stick for digging or fighting; a cudgel; a dibble; a bludgeon.abasiisi a bonus; a baksheesh; an additional benefit. abatot a yam, Dioscorea.abaun to dissolve; to soak; to melt; to become wet. ebaunit do ekonipur elos bon: your back is now soaked with dirt. abean truth; certitude; certainty. akiro nuabeak: a maxim. abeanakin to do in turns or in shifts. abeanut (singular noun F) righteousness; virtue. abeanut to be truthful, just, or virtuous. abear (of a traveller) to turn towards; to lead to; to head towards. abebe antelope (a wild animal in the goat family with red lips). abebelei goats’ dung; rats’ dung.abebelei remains, remnants.abebenok a wing (of a bird, a fly, etc.); an aileron (of a fixed-wing plane). abeberiar to be ahead; to be there before others. luabeberikinos: the first people, animals, vehicles, etc to go. abeberikin alosit to set off on a journey first to be the first. abeei eggs; nits; spawn. abeet an egg (in general). abeet naka akokor: chicken egg. abeet naka emun: snake’s egg. abeeya badly ground grain; dandruff (in hair); scurf. abei a thorny tree in the ecomai family with edible fruit, Balanites orbicularis. abeikin to result in; to say the right thing by guessing; to tell the truth; to guess correctly. abeit1 truly; indeed. abeite cut mam ijo iswamat ngun?: indeed you did not do that (wrong)? abeit2 (singular noun F) the truth. enera eong abeit: I speak the truth. abeit3 to be authentic, true, just, actual; to be good, adequate to belong to. kibeitos yes akiro: it is your fault; you are at fault (plural). abeitok three-days-old millet or sorghum beer (brew) ready for drinking. abekar to take off a shell; to shell a nut; to remove a scab from a wound. abeket (disapprovingly, of a person) to have long nails; to have jiggers. abeketait an eggshell (after the bird has hatched). abeketet (disapprovingly, of a person) to be long-nailed. abekot a virgin (girl or woman). abekun (of something in an egg) to hatch out; to remove from the shell. abelanar to break up hard things one after another. abu epakasit kobelana amor kere: the porter cracked all the stones one after the other. abelar (of a person or an animal) to break through a fence, door, or an enclosure; (of thieves) to break into a house and steal; (of a traveller) to go through the bush (where there is no road). abelat a wound on the head (after one was struck with a stick or club on the head). abelat an arm ornament for dancers (made of carved wood). abelebel to hit or wound repeatedly on the head; to crush (nuts or grain) roughly. abelebelet a breadcrumb; a bit of amukeke (dry sliced potatoes); a tiny piece or remnant of bar soap; a piece of eggshell.abelekek a skull; a toe or finger nail; a piece of calabash or pot; a potshard; a tortoise shell. abelekek nakakou a skull. abelekek nak’ebokorit a finger-nail; a claw. abelerer to have big eyes. abelun (of cows, prisoners) to break out; to emerge from; to force oneself in or out towards the speaker. abeneniar to become simple, light or easy. abeneniar aswam: work has become easy (perhaps because more people have been drafted to do it). abeneniar abwokon: the burden has become light (less heavy). abenenu (singular noun F) lightness; ease; simplicity. ipimae emisaani abenenu arai alangiru naka ibore: the weights measure how light or heavy something is. abenenun (of something previously heavy) to become light (not heavy) or thin. abenot a cork or float. abenyan a rebel; an insurgent; a dissenter; a guerrilla fighter. abenyanu (singular noun F) rebellion; insurgency; mutiny; defiance. abenyanut to be mischievous, lawless, indifferent, harsh, or quarrelsome; to be truculent or confrontational. abenyu (singular noun F) guerrilla war; harshness; lawlessness; malevolence; cruelty; malice. aberakin1 coming first. aberakin2 to start something before someone else; to be before someone else; to take initiative. aberakina eong togo: I went into the house first (that is, before anyone else). aberakinet a self-start; an initiative; an early start. erai aberakinet nake: she/he took the initiative (literally, the initiative is hers/his). aberar to start or to be first; to be earlier. ikoku yen eberar osomero nges ekui ebela: the child who goes first (earlier) to school misses the cane.aberiang (of a person) to get excited or animated once. aberiangang (of a person) to be and remain excited. aberu woman (generally). naberu: yeniberu: female; feminine. aberun to start or to come first (towards the speaker). koberun ber ne: come this way before anyone else. aberut (collective noun F) a multitude or a crowd of women.aberyang (singular noun F) intellect; intelligence; excitement; stimulation.abeseeni a plastic basin (for bathing); a bath tub.abeun to speak out the truth; to say the right thing.
ekabaran aabarenon a barber; a man who cuts or shaves people’s hair
(of or relating to) yesterday or the previous day. ibian: yesterday

last night. bian kace: ngoon: the day before yesterday. akware nabian: yester night; last night. abiasit a live bullet; a cartridge.abicilaar to become narrow to make narrow. abicilil to be or have protruding narrow lips; to have a narrow mouth. ibicilil ngesi akituk: she/he is narrow-mouthed. ibicililas ngesi ipon: she/he has protruding lips. abiikin to pass wind for; to fart or to blow off for (a vulgar and indecent behaviour).abiira a plant whose fibre is used for thatching and the flowers are eaten as atigo or alilot in eboo vegetables, Hibiscus lunarfolices abiiwu a sling (for throwing a dart or a stone).abila a small traditional shrine; an altar; a (certain) tribe or race. abilakin to break for; to count for; to betray. abilakin abotet: to betray. abilakinio (singular noun F) judgement; reckoning; determination of someone’s fate. abilakinio abotet betrayal (of one by someone else); treachery (by the other party).abilar to deny; to refuse (used only of ekisil or opinion or accusation). abilar eong excepting me or counting me out. alemar eong: except me or count me out. abilet1 a hem; a fold; a break.abilet2 a list; a schedule; a rota. abiletait (of something breakable) a piece; a portion; a part; a morsel. abilianar to walk proudly; to swagger.abilibil to break into small pieces often; to infringe, violate, breach or contravene many times. abilibilio naka apedorosio: a violation of rights. abilibilibele a swift (bird). abiloi sticks for making a reed fence.abilot a flute; a bush with hollow stem, used as pop-gun, Stegano taenia araliacea; a reed-grass, Phragmetes mauritianus. abilun to bargain; to fix a price; to master something; to pull down a tree branch. abinin maize, sorghum or millet bran. abiokotar (disapprovingly, of toe- or finger-nails) to grow long. abiolos an ambulance.abir2 a plant used as medicine against beginning of leprosy (when rubbed on the body), Indigofera. abiro a club; a big stick used as a weapon (with or without head or knob); a life-preserver. akou nak’abiro: a knob of a club. abitakin (of people or animals) to huddle together with cold or fever.abitun (of white ants) to come out of a narrow passage. abitunun (of living things) to come one by one out of a narrow passage or outlet, door, or gate; to pull through a narrow opening one after another. abiules an ambulance.do bo...?; abo jo?; do bo jo?: what about you? why not you? abo nu?: how about these? aboboriot wood from ebobore used for cattle-troughs; an edible ebobore fruit. abocit a barren woman.aboga (singular noun F) amaranthus vegetable with green leaves, the stem of which is used to extract salt ash, Amaranthus spinosa.e. the rumen; the tripe. abok (a reference among friends) a tough woman; an iron lady.abokanakin to cover up; to bury. abokar to dig up slightly; to dig away a little. abokeboke (singular noun F) a plant from which salt is extracted, Asystasia gangetica abokenen to dig, tempt, etc repeatedly. aboketait temptation; lure; enticement; inducement. abokikin to dig down; to dig for someone. abokio (singular noun F) temptation, or being tempted. aboko a crown; a shell headdress; a mitre. aboko nak’ikukwa: crown of thorns. aponi kitanapai Yesu aboko nak’ikukwa: Jesus was worn a crown of thorns. abokony the lower jaw; the chin.abokonyony (an insult) to have big jaws. abokoror (singular noun F) prickly heat. ikaunit imukeru abokoror: a baby has a rash due to prickly heat. abokoyat an egg-shellakiseta: scrapings of potatoes (amukeke stuck at the bottom of the cooking pot). abokun to dig for oneself; to dig up; to dig out; to undermine; to tempt. abolet a race; a competition; a contest; a sports ground or stadium.abolia2 to play (games or football, etc); to jest; to joke (with akiro). aboliar akiro: to make a joke of something serious. aboliai eong: abolia eong: I am playing. eboliaete kesi emopiira: eboliasi kesi emopiira: they are playing football. aitumor abolia kimurwokini aswam: to spend time playing and forgetting one’s tasks. aboliaar to revel; to play away; to bamboozle. koboliaasi ngina: play over there. kilosi aboliaar Soroti: we are going to play at Soroti. abolibol a swelling as of pregnancy; a dew-lap (of animals such as cattle, horses, donkeys) abolobol to race; to compete. aboloc to peel off the bark or skin easily; to be flexible. abolokic a spoon. abolokin to race with (one another); to compete.abolokok the skull; an eggshell.abolor to run together; to agree; to be ready (to die, to promise). abolor toma atwanare: to be ready to die in a contest or duel. abolun to win; to race; to come racing. abomoror (of stomach) to be large or fat. abonan (in the Roman Catholic faith) a holy virgin.abong the evening. abongeresio the first stomach of a cow; the rumen (as a site for regurgitation).abongo a herb whose seeds are used as simsim. abongobong to keep returning, turning round (like a dog barking in different directions). abongokin to repeat, return; to answer; to reply. kobongok alimun nu nan ibala jo: repeat what you said earlier. kobongok ngesi ebe: answer him/her thus. abongokin kanuka: to be responsible for. ijo ibongokini kanuka iboroka luaoliosi: you will be responsible for my lost things. abongokinet an answer; a reply; a response; a reposte; a rejoinder. abongor to go back; to return to a place (away from the speaker); to retire. abongori eong nat ore: I am going back home later. abongun to come back; to return (towards the speaker). ibonguni wori?: when will you come back? inyo mam epedori abongun moi karaida moi kace? Bian: (a riddle) what cannot return tomorrow or the day after? Yesterday. abongut a bark cloth; the fibre of a bark tree; a blanket. abonot1 (singular noun F) meekness; mildness; humility. abonot2 to be meek, humble. aboogi a train wagon; a truck trailer. aboola (formerly) a 10-cents coin. aboolai: money aboole a cob (without maize) used as cork for bottles, etc. abooti a vote; a ballot paper. abor a place for goats outside the house; deep water. aboranakin to allot. abosanut (singular noun F) stinking; rotting easily; perishable; unpreserved. abosetait remains of a rotten thing. abosikin to become rotten for; to rot somewhere, to somebody. abosino a female child surviving after the death of other children born before her. abosus (singular noun F) foulness; rottenness; putrefaction. abosuun to become rotten for; to rot somewhere, to somebody. abotet treachery; a plot; a device. abilakin abotet: to betray. abotirir obesity; elephantiasis (of the scrotum).abu I have come, etc (abunere) (forms past tense of verbs). abu kiswama: she/he/it worked. abua a hole, a cave (for wild animals); a hiding place.aibiror ebuburia: to fall forwards. abubusia a water rat; a mink; a spotted-neck otter, Lutra maculicollis; a mink skin used as bracelet. enapit abubusia: she/he is wearing a mink-skin bracelet. abubut a banana fibre.abucelel to be red-lipped. abuikin to coerce, compel, force, or oblige; to slander to forget or slip the memory. abuikin itunganan akiro: to judge a man wrongly. kabuik: I forget. abuikin ekisil: to domineer. abukokin to pour into, down, on. abukokin akima: to take a basket of winnowed millet or sorghum, pour water into it and leave it for a certain number of days till the millet begins to germinate. abukor to pour away, empty out (away from speaker). abuku a book cover; a plough share (part of an ox-plough). abukuleru a species of edible termite. ikok luenyamio: edible termites. abukun to pour out (towards speaker). abukyoit eyelash or eyebrow. abulaayat a European woman; a word in a European language. abuleesut a girl slave; a maid servant. abulet opening of abscess or mouth of abscess. abulo to burst; to explode. abulo abeet: the egg has burst. abulo eboomu: the bomb has exploded. abulosi itunga: the crowd dispersed.abulo abus: the boil has burst. abulon (uncountable noun F) pus. abulor to burst open. abulor abus: to burst open a boil or an abcess. abulucaaret a bruise, scraping, a rubbing off. abulucar to bruise, scrape, or rub off (skin). abuluki a bugle.abulukuk nak’akou a skull. abulukuk nak’adere: a slightly broken calabash (almost intact).abulun to burst open. abulun amoitena: to disembowel. abulurur a swelling in the ear. abunakin akanin to fold hands. abunar eiyengane to hold in the breath. abunere1 (singular noun F) advent; the arrival. abunere2 to come. abunere kaneka: to emanate from me. abuni: I will come. kiponi: we will come. epote: they will come. abu: I have come. kipou: we have come. apotu: they have come. kiponi kinomai: we were beaten. adau eong abunere: I have already come. kidau iso aponere: we have already come. (note how abunere becomes aponere when the subject is plural) abunguret a lump; a loaf.
(singular noun F) the Coming (of Jesus Christ)

the advent. abunus the paunch; the fatty tissues of the stomach. abuonokin to hesitate; to be in doubt; to forget a point; to vacillate; to waver. abuonor to swell all over the body. abuor to rob, plunder, or confiscate. ebuonorete kesi iboro kitunga: they rob people’s things. apotu kobuosi: they robbed. abur (uncountable noun F) sleeping sickness disease of cattle, Nagana; Trypanosomiasis. aburaasi a (shoe or hair) brush. aburaasi naka amuk: shoe brush. aburaasi naka itim: a hair brush. aburacu a hook and eye; a fastener; a stud; a clasp. aburan to claim a debt; (of a baby) to begin to grow or become fat after delivery. abunit eong aburan emong: I have come to claim my bull (you owe me).aburanakin to cover for; to allot. abures (singular noun F) fatness, thickness; obesity.aburet a tool for tightening the skin of a drum. aburetait a wrapper, a cover; an envelope; a re-sowing. aburucaar to slip and fall; to slip and escape. aburucikin to slip off; to slip into. aburucun akiro to say what you did not intend to say; to let out a secret; to be inopportune or impolitic. elemuni koburuc ace: lest she/he reveal what was not intended. aburun to panic; to be in a bad way, state, trouble, bad plight. kaburunitos eong ican: I am horrified by poverty. ejai ibore yen kaburunit eong: there is something troubling me. aburututu a river frog. aburuun to become thicker. abus a boil; a carbuncle; an abscess or swelling. ebus: a very big abscess; a boil. aibul abus: to cut open an abscess. abuset abrasion. abuswa a big bowl.abutar to close mouth, to sulk; to be unobliging; to say nothing; to keep quiet; to be or look sullen, morose. kobuta!: shut up! abuton an eternal person. Lokasuban loabuton: God eternal. abutor to shed (rub) skin off; to bruise, abrade; (of a person’s skin) to become smooth and healthy-looking. abutosit snake’s skin (when it has been shed off); a slough; a peel. abutunge a bud; a sprout. abutur to swell, blister. abuturaar to go away with pursed lips; to go away angrily i.e. with sulky face. abuturur to look gloomy; to sulk; to show an angry face; to purse lips; to mooch or mope; to be swollen; to be bruised abutuun to begin to swell; (of abscess) to begin. abutuunet a swelling; an abscess; a pustule; a boil. abutuusit a rubber boot; a jungle boot; a boot. abuuba a bicycle pump.abuun (of dough) to swell, rise, ferment; to inflate; to puff. abuyior to overcome by force, great exertion; to bully; to rape; to rob. ikoto ijo abuyior eong: you want to rape or coerce me. erono abuyior apese: it is bad to rape a girl.abuyoor to force; to rape, bully; to dragoon. abwa a hole, cave (for wild animals); a hiding place.abwaikin: to settle down in a place; to make new home for someone else. abwaun: to come, settle near by. abwacit a barren woman; a lesbian. araus abwacit: (of a woman) to be barren or a lesbian. araun abwacit: (of a woman) to become sterile, barren or homosexual. abwakar akonye to charm the eyes by sprinkling poison on them. abwakat earrings. abwal a water-hole; a fountain; a pond; deep waters.abwalar to be taken or to take unawares and unprepared; to mislead somebody; to fall upon suddenly; to delay; to dally; to waste time; to be lazy; to be negligent. kidum ijo eong abwalara: you have found me unprepared. abu atwanare kobwalaa ngesi: death took her/him by surprise.abwang to break; to come or fall to bits; to crack.abwangar to run mad; to go wild, mad; to run amok; to run helter-skelter, become hysteric. abwanga adeka: the illness made him mad. to drive or make mad; to madden.abwangun to break out; to germinate (as of mushrooms, grey hair, small-pox). abwangun adeka kinga: (of sickness, etc) to appear. abwangun epuuru kakuwan Oluka kere: chicken-pox has broken out all over Oluka’s body. abwangut imaruk: big mushrooms have sprouted. abwaresikin to lasso or to get hold of quickly; to catch for somebody; to tie quickly on something. abwaresor to snatch away from speaker; to sweep away; to blow away chaff or dust. abwaresun: to lasso. abwaresunet the lasso or lassoing. abwaret to snatch away (as of hawk snatching a chick); to take suddenly and without asking; to snatch a meal; to fling a rope. abwas a fence round a kraal, homestead, etc; an enclosure. abwatakin to sprinkle on. abwatar to catch or snatch (hens, cows, etc). abwatar aberu kanuka etal: to lead or to introduce a girl (after conception of first child) to her parents’ home, being sprinkled with water as she enters the home. abwatar akipi: to shake off water. abwataror to be introduced with an offering of goat or anything. akoto akonikine abwataror amurake: I want your goat to make a present to my in-laws. abwatunio ore a traditional cleansing ceremony (involving sprinkling or smearing with water, cow-dung or raw millet porridge) performed at the entrance to the homestead before allowing in a long lost relative (presumed dead) or a daughter who gave birth to twins. abwaun1 to hide inside, surround, encircle (as fence). abwaun2 to hold; to contain water. ibwaunit erot akipi: the road is holding puddles of water. abwel a well; a spring of water.abwo (formerly) a tail ornament of animal skin worn by old women; a flap. abwoar to stand aside. kobwoa laije: stand over there.

May (literally, the month of uneasy hungry children).abwobwoot to loiter or stand idle. abwoenen to keep standing up. abwoenen kawai k’erot: to keep standing by the side of the road. abwoetait an easel

the standpoint; one’s opinion or position in a debate, an issue, etc abwoikin to stand up for; to guarantee; to sponsor, stand bail for; to be a godparent (to a child being baptised); to brave and face an attacker; to dare; to withstand. abwoikiniton a sponsor or guarantor; a godparent; a representative or delegate; one who stands and challenges another.abwonokin to doubt; to hesitate or vacillate.abworon a girl who refuses to marry or who refuses her husband.abwotar to emigrate; to go to another country. abwotun to immigrate from another country this way. abwoun to stand surety or bail; to refuse. abwou je: he has refused.abwounet a stop (sign); a fullstop; a stopping place; a station; a stage (for a bus or taxi). abwoyaar to calm down, relent, settle down, become clear (of water). ebwoyaaritos akip: the water has settled down (i.e. which was turbulent and dirty). abwoyaa akwap: the country has calmed (settled down). acaadula (of a woman) perennially having no food in the granary. aberu ngin acaadula: that woman has food insecurity (that is, her granary is always empty). acaago the Luffah plant, its fruit is used for making bathing sponges. acaanakin to give constant light; to keep on enlightening; to throw light on. ecaanakini akolong iboro kere: the sun constantly enlightens every object.acaapa a bandage; a patch; a tourniquet; a rag. acabakin to run quickly to something or someone (with long, light strides). abu ikapa kocabakin emir: a cat ran quickly (with long, light strides) after the rat. acabalalaun to run swiftly this way. acabar to run away quickly; to dash away. acabun to hurry towards speaker. kocabun lailo: come quickly this way.acak a light-green harmless arboreal snake, Chlorophis.kacakakin ngesi eong: she/he/it fell on me. acakanar to throw away (one after another); to squander; to abjure; to discard. acakar to fling away; to exile; to banish; to adjure. acakaret naka amoru: a stone’s throw. acakat a rain stone; white round pebbles found in akao.acakia a green harmless arboreal snake.acalaani a sewing machine; an instrument (like a curved knife) for weeding millet. acalaar to shout out, yell, scream; to cry out; to shriek.acalar to melt away (as of fat or butter); to dissolve or dilute (because it is thick). acamakin to permit; to acknowledge, allow, or sanction; to agree. kocamakinai eong abunere orekon: permit me to come to your home to be reconciled. acamakinet a permit; a consent; a sanction; an approval. abalua n’acamakinet: a written permit. acamanakin to show off.acamun to consent, assent, comply; to undertake; to agree, accept, abide, accede; to hit an object aimed at. acamu ngesi ebe asabi: she/he admitted that she/he lied. acamunos ngol ka okokuke: he is reconciled with his son. acamunet compliance; agreement; assent; admittance. acamunit to be willing; to want. anyarau eong Ocaatum ido ecamunit ngesi aupar ka eong: I have invited Ocaatum and he is willing to come with me. acany a foot deformity acquired in childhood; a painful incurable sore under the sole of foot; sole granuloma. ejai eong acany naepol noi: I have got a large incurable sore underneath my foot. acaun to become clear, light, bright, shining, etc. to shine; to be warm, be hot. ecaunit lolo akolong: the sun is bright today. acaunet a drought; a dry spell; sunshine. ace- (feminine adverbial prefix) some. acepaarit some day; occasionally. aceberu: another woman. acece (singular noun F) gravy; sauce; soup; consommé; broth. acedakin to spy upon; to inspect secretly; to take by surprise; to come upon suddenly or unnoticed; to confide a secret. icedanakin ijo eong apaarasia kere: you always take me by surprise, come upon me suddenly, unexpectedly. ejaas nuakoto eong acedakin ijo: I have something to tell you confidentially. acedanakin to whisper; to tell little secrets. ejaas kesi nuecedanakinete ipaupakec: they have secrets which they tell their companions. acedar to walk quietly away; to go away unobserved to take away stealthily (a mild form of stealing). ejai lokecedaa ekasigala kane: there is someone who furtively took my cigarette away. acedekanar to keep jumping along; to prance; to skip across. elosete apesur acedekanar kauno: the girls are going to have a skipping game. aceduna a secret. etogo loinerare nuceduna: a private room or office. einer nuceduna: to speak secrets. acedunun to eat daintily (little by little). acedunun inyamat: to eat food piecemeal. aceederuwa a mosquito net.aceerin nuka etuko ibusiak: the stripes of the zebra are beautiful. aceger (of a thin or slender person) to walk about naked. sirikiceger kakonye k’itunga: do not walk naked in public (that is, in front of people).acegerer to be thin. icegereras yesi: you are thin, emaciated. acegerikin to walk naked or in rags; to walk (as of a thin person). acekanut to be fertile; (of hair or weeds) to grow quickly. acel1 conflict; noise; cacophony; uproar. ingai eyaunit acela ne?: who is brings dispute here? acel2 to conflict; to shout; to quarrel. acel bian je akiring kia: the guy quarrelled the whole night for the meat. acelakin to dissent; to quarrel with. acelakinos ekiliokit k’aberuke: a man has quarrelled with his wife.acelanar to quarrel to be inimical. ecelanara itunga ngul: those people are not friends (that is, they are always quarrelling). acelanut the habit of shouting; making noise; boisterousness. kinyek acelanut: stop being cantankerous. acelar to shout; to scream.acelatun a ditch. acelenen to quarrel repeatedly; to nag. acelikite a species of bird, White-bellied florican. acelit a shell of a snail or any mollusc. toto k’acelit: toto k’acel: a snail; a snail shell. acen a niece on sister’s side. (note: on brother’s side these are called akoku: daughter).acereded (of men or animals) to be firm, refuse, struggle against abduction. acerededet: all out; doing the best you can. abu akiteng kocereded neakotor eong arikor nges: the cow struggled as I was dragging it away. acerit a star. acer: a constellation. aceritoit linear marks of a spilt liquid. ajaas Icodat acerito nuka akiyo: Icodat had furrows of tears on account of weeping often. ejaas ikoku acerito nuka akile: the child has marks of spilt milk on its body. acerokin to put stripes on; to make stripes on cheeks with tears, hence to weep. acerosit a stripe on stockings or on a zebra’s body. acetakin to brush lightly and hit something else; to rub or touch lightly in passing; (of a shot or of a missile) to graze (and always hitting another object). acetakin emal ikoku: the arrow grazed and hit the child. acetanar to keep slipping off (a tree).acetek to dance; to scuffle; to shuffle. Elisabet, kacetekata: Elizabeth, come let us dance. acibakin to drink a little for somebody else (usually for small babies, as a mother does, or birds teaching nestlings to take food). acibun to take a sip, drink or smoke little by little. akoto acibun apuru: I want to smoke cigarettes a little. acicing (used in infinitive and in 3rd person followed by an infinitive) to do or happen seldom or rarely. ecicing papaka abunenen ne: my father rarely comes here. acicing naka edou ngesi ayauni etengei: the scarcity of rain brought the famine. aiticicing: to cause to happen seldom or to do seldom. isiru kesi keticicingito eong alosit Bugondo: it is mosquitoes that make me go to Bugondo rarely. acidikik to have small breasts. icidikik aberu na: this woman has small breasts (that is, she is small-breasted). acigait a swelling on the ankle.acikait a swelling on the wrist.acikilikin akolodong toma akipi cikil: a tortoise dropped heavily into the water. acilakin to break into a house (after splitting the door or walls). acilanakin alelesia: to irrigate. acilar (of cloth) to tear off; to drain. acilar akipi: to drain away water. acilar akou (of person or animal) to break down, become mad, unmanageable, run off, go away quietly. acilet a tear (in cloth); a split (in the wall or wood); a passage (in a crowd). acilicil (of cloth) to tear to pieces; (of a stick) to split into splinters.aibil: to break (a promise, wood or command). aibwang: to break (glass or pottery). atiakin etogo: to break down a house. acilicilun to become torn to pieces; to rags. acilicilunos inapen kere: all the clothes are torn to rags. acilitoi to be unmanageable, not listen to anybody; to be cheeky, a rascal. acilun to break one’s way through (this way); to erupt; to irrigate. kocilun lailo: make your way towards me. acilun akipi: to irrigate (with water). acin faeces; excrement (of animals or birds); ordure. aiwu acin: to gas; to fart. acin kimirio: rat droppings or excreta; (figurative) rice grain.acingakin to place between prongs; to put between fork or between any narrow opening; to squeeze in between to place or press oneself into a narrow space. to be amongst, between. kocingakinos yesi da nepenen: you also squeeze yourselves in-between there. adum eong ikoku ecingakina kiding otunga: I found the child amongst the crowd. acingakina to be in between; to be in the middle of other things or people. acingar to pass, squeeze through a narrow opening, pass through difficulties. abu eong kacingaror akiro ngun: I got that case through with great difficulty. acingat a narrow place; a narrow passage.aiwu acin: to pass wind, blow off, or to fart. acipa name of grass used for making granaries or barns, Digitaria spp. acoa sense; wisdom; wit; knowledge; cleverness; skill; shrewdness; ability; dexterity; adroitness. aitub acoa: to decide; to make a decision. acoa na Iteso: Teso brew (called ajon). acoa nasubunet (singular noun F) instinct; intuition; gut feeling. acoanakin to be always careful. acobet a bird, a wax-bill. acobeu1 (uncountable noun F) acumen; intelligence; wit; sense; wisdom; cleverness; brains; astuteness; shrewdness. emamei ngesi acobeu: she/he has no brains.kocobeu, sirikoni nen: get wise, do not behave like that. acobok (of a girl) to have or to go about with developed breasts. ecoboki apese ngin: that girl flaunts her developed breasts. icobokokas ikisin: the breasts are developed. acocora the porridge-like waste product in the distillation of crude alcohol.acocorot a francolin-like bird. acodirir to be tall, long, high. acodocod to keep tempting, enticing. acodokokor1 a chestnut sparrow. acodokokor2 a vegetable. acodongong to be long legged, tall height, tallness. koyanga akonicodongong ngina: go away, please (literally, take away your imposing height). acodun to test, tempt; to try to challenge. aingisetaiti kon erai naka acodun: your question is a challenge. aswam ngin ecoduni akonicoa: that work tests your intelligence. apak nak’acodunio: the hour of trial or temptation. acodunet a trial, test, temptation. acodunio (singular noun F) temptation; enticement; inducement to do something morally wrong. acogorar to become awkward; to be cruciform. acoikin to avert; to see through; to beware of; to draw oneself away. acoiki ekokolan ngol akiro ngun: the thief has seen through the trap. kocoikis acoa naka ajokit: beware of the devil’s tricks. acoiki ngesi: she/he has withdrawn because she/he feels at fault.acoikinet foresight; wisdom; intention; certitude. acaadula emamei acoikinet: a woman with an oft empty granary has no foresight. acoikinit to note; to beware of; to draw oneself away. acoit to take care, look carefully, be aware. kocoite: be careful; beware. kocoitos!: (plural) beware!; know what is happening! aitocoit: to make, cause to be careful, to care. eswamat eong ngun komam acoit: I did that carelessly. acok1 sweet potatoes (native); Irish potatoes; potato or cassava tubers. acok k’Imusugun: Irish potatoes. acok2 ki-o to herd or to feed cattle or any other livestock; to follow (somebody or something) everywhere. acokicok (of eyes) to water. acokicokoto ikoku akonye: the eyes of the child are wet with tears to sprinkle water in order to lay the dust. acokit a sweet potato (native); Irish potato; potato or cassava tuber. acokit na Imusugun: an Irish potato. acokom to eat something nice, tasty (especially meat). acokonye a minx; a rude and daring girl (who looks you in the face); a curious woman. acoler ki-o to have a crown of hair standing up. acoliar to become thin; to become watery. acoliaros ajon nu: this beer has become thin, watery. acolib to point; to sharpen. kicolibikinai eong ekakalaamu: sharpen my pencil. acoman a traditional pad worn by women during menstruation.acomil to sit down sorrowfully, uncomfortably with watery eyes.edoteana. acomilil to be inquisitive; to have a piercing look; to brood or worry. inyo bo icomililar ijo kane?: why are you (singular) here brooding? acookonye a woman with lustful eyes.
a word in the Acholi language

an Acholi woman or native of Gulu, Kitgum or Pader districts of northern Uganda. Acoolin: the Acholi women; the Acholi language (one of the Luo dialects, the others being Langi of Lira and Apac, Alur of Nebbi, and Ethur of Kotido).acooro a cap, hat, helmet. acoricorot a drop of liquid. acoroi (collective noun F) (general name for) termites; a worker ant. acoto (uncountable noun F) cow’s urine.acoun to become careful, wise, prudent, cultured. acous to be wise, to be clever; cleverness; wisdom; to be cute, astute. acowe a wading bird, lily-trotter, Actophylornis. acualat meat removed from the hide or skin when pegging the hide/skin to dry (cooked and eaten). acuar to press out; to wring out, squeeze out. acuc juice pressed out from used beer or from the remains of beer (given to children to drink in the morning). acuducud to cause or make marks or spots (on head by a ringworm or bad shaving); to make spots on anything else; to spoil by witchcraft. icuducud ijo epaabaka: you have killed my cotton by witchcraft. acuduun to come here to practice witchcraft. kinyek acuduun lailo, kocudaa obukus ngina: do not come here to practice witchcraft, rather practice it there in your own home area. acugurikin to bend; to walk with stooped shoulders, with a stoop; to walk with round shoulders. ecugurikina ngesi kanuka aterot: she/he/it stoops due to the cold. acugurur to walk with a stoop. acuikin to squeeze for somebody else. kocuikinai eong emucuuga ngol: squeeze that orange for me. acukia a sunbird (a small bird believed to bring bad or good omen when it flies overhead to the left or to the right).acukudikin to arch. acukulet a bump or a dip or a hole in the road. ileleba acukulen orot lo: this road is very bumpy. acukulul to be bumpy, rutty, full of holes, ruts. icukulul erot: the road is bumpy. icukululos irotin: the roads are bumpy. acukumac a burning log or faggot. acukut a blacksmith's bellows (used for forging bells for dancing, or spears and axes); a blowpipe; the engine of a ferry boat.aculoit a bead (ornament). aculokin1 (of people) to mix in a crowd; to be in the middle of, mixed up with. adum eong ikoku eculokina kiding otunga: I found the child in the midst of the people.aculokin2 to make lukewarm (by adding cold water); to pacify by words or by mere presence. kolot ijo koculok itunga ngul: go and pacify those quarrelsome people (by showing yourself up or talking to them.) aculokin3 to interfere; to go and sit in the wrong place; to enter into a dispute uninvited. aculokinet a stain; a spot of dust. aculonokin to stain often; to stain repeatedly; to variegate (colours, hues). aculot1 a young hen; a pullet.aculucul to stripe; to stain repeatedly; to keep blemishing, be spotted. aculurikin ki-o to rest on top; to be on top to put on top. adum eong apupu iculurikina kuju atitipu: I found a hedge-hog on top of an anthill.acumulul to squat on haunches; to mooch, look sour; to sulk. lokapesenin edili acumululit okitui: the one with debts goes out very early to the bush and sits there on his haunches mooching about. acunakin to make an archway for somebody else to shrug shoulders.acunanakin to make an opening for water to run off; to make archway; (of water- passage or canal) to narrow out. acunar to pass through a narrow opening.acunasit a curvature; an arch. acunetait an archway; a lintel of door or window; a bend or curve. acunun to squeeze into to squeeze into a narrow opening.acupun to single out. kicupunit ijo eong bon aitaswam: you have picked me out to work often. acupun adekanakin: to be constantly ill. kacupunit eong adeka ngin: that disease always catches me (of all people). acupuno to be singular, peculiar, strange, eccentric. ecupuno ngesi noi: she/he is very strange; she/he is very peculiar. acur a head dress made of feathers. acuria (Ongino, Kumi) a ceremonial pot with two mouths.acurupar to taper down acurupiar to fold together; to fold to a point. acut a vulture, Neophron percnopterus.acuubu (in Pallisa, Tororo) common salt (sodium chloride).acuuma a ginnery; a flourmill; any machine or instrument. acuuma nairies alos: a flour mill. acuuma nailoset igoen: a cloth-washing or laundry machine.acuun to wring out; to press out, squeeze out. acuun akiyo: to weep (literally, to squeeze out tears). acuun akinyet kocok: to press oil from seeds. ajon nuecuitai: ajon nuecuu: beer which has been strained, pressed or squeezed. acuurut a woolly-necked stork; a black crake, Limnocorax. acwalat juice of potato or fruit. acwatai the porridge-like waste product in the distillation of crude alcohol.acwetar to glance off.acworet a plant that keeps bedbugs away, Pseudarthria hookeri. adaanakin1 to clap hands for someone (in a token of gladness or joy); to welcome; to clap hands at play. kodaanakis ejakait akanin: welcome the chief by clapping your hands. adaanakin2 to finish all for. kodaanak akonigogong nen: exhaust your strength there. adaanakin3 to give a report of; to give an account; to give an explanation. kodaanakinai nuiswamat ijo kangina: give me an account of what you did there. adaanakin4 (reciprocal verb) to beat one another often. itelepai lu edaanakinos apaarasia kere: these boys are always fighting or beating one another. adacakin to fall or throw oneself into danger; to endanger oneself to endanger another. sirikidacak eong toma akiro: don’t endanger me, that is, do not get me into that case. adacanar to spoil; to waste or squander. sirikidacanaa edia kwap: do not spill the vegetables on the floor. adacar to go to waste, do in vain; (of water) to pour over. adacaros isiriginika tai: my money has gone to waste. adacar kwap: to fall. elosi ngesi adacar: she/he/it is going to fall. to throw away thick matter to do in vain. idacanari ijo aikatakon: you fish in vain. adacun (of akiro, things) to drop in front of a person. adaduli a straw hat. arai kidolit adaduli, konap: if the hat fits, wear it. adae spoor, dust or mud on sole of foot. ailakilakar adae: to run away (literally, to shake off the dust on one's feet). adaet a mallet; a stick for threshing millet or beating house floor. adaikin1 to finish for; to tell the story or case. kadaikis akokoroi nu akakimai: these chickens have finished my millet. mam ijo idaikit atukot akiro kere: you have not told the gathering the whole story or all the facts. adaikin2 to thrash for someone; to lash for someone; to give a hiding. adaikin3 to be lost to. kadaikin eong ikakoku: my child is dead (literally, my child is lost to me). abu ngesi kodaikin toma akaninika: she/he died in my arms. kidaikinos oni iinonosiowok lukolo: our old customs are lost to us (i.e. they have died out). adairekita a female director; a manageress.edakas imongin: the bulls are grazing, feeding. edakas akituk: the cows are grazing. edaka akiteng: the cow is grazing. adakit akiteng: the cow has grazed. edakito akituk: the cows have grazed.adakai dregs; remnants of beer. adakakin1 to carry onto; to rear for, on or into; to entrust to, confer upon, give in custody. kanukinyo kidakakitor ijo eong ebela?: why do you want to beat me, that is, why do you carry the stick against me? kadakakit eong ijo ikakoku: I entrust my child to you, or give it to you for custody. adakakin2 to choose a leader; to elect, appoint; to lift up onto something. kidakakinio bo ijo ajakaanut wori?: when were you appointed to leadership? adakar to carry away to be confused; to be abashed; to have swollen head (with shame); to be proud, over bearing, carry head high; to be very hairy. adakar ijo akou: you are ashamed, or overcome with shame. edakara Apolo akou: Apolo is proud. adakar aberu ngin akou: that woman has a bushy head, full of hair. adakara to be arrogant; to brag. adaket a bier, a litter; a stretcher; a crane. adakiika a minute, sixty seconds.adakit to carry. edakit aberu ikoku: the woman is carrying a child. adakun to dismount; to bring hither. adakunos akile: the milk is boiling up (by cooking). adakun emugaati: the dough is risen. adakun eong akeju: my leg is swollen. adal a cape (of coat); lapel (of shirt or coat); a collar (of a dress). adalacar to fester; to ulcerate. adalacar ajimike: her/his wound has festered. adalaka (formerly) a variety of finger millet. adalarac an edible shrub, Oxygonum atriplicifolium. adalidal to be hanging down; to come down; to come near; to hang down low; to hang and swing; to dangle. emong lo edalidali abolibol: this bull has a dangling dewlap. edalidalete ikisin luka aberu: the woman's breasts are floppy. edalidalete aki: lop-eared. edalidali edou: the cloud is low (that is, it is threatening to rain). adam the brain; the cerebrum; the grey matter; wisdom; intellect. adamo (not used with liquids) to close or to fold or press together; (of a toothless person) to eat. edamoi ikoku emaido: the child (having no teeth) eats soft nuts. adamoikin (of book, cloth, skin, etc) to close, fold or press together; (of lips in pain) to compress. kodamoik emukule ngol: fold that skin.adamokok to be folded, flat; (of bag, breasts, football) to be empty. idamokokos imopiiran: the balls are empty. idamokokos ikisin: the breasts are flat, that is, there is no milk in the breasts. adangar to take once for all. koyanga acok ngupengun kodangaror: take those potatoes only and no more.adanyot a fruit of ekungur tree.edapadapat engatuny kauj: the lion is stalking our kraal. edapadapatai esaatikon: your shirt is patched all over. adapadapaar to move away stealthily; to edge away, off. adapadapat to keep on visiting someone bashfully (seeking favours). kanukinyo idapadapator ijo?: what are you after with your repeated visits? to look on longingly. edapadapat ikoku emugaati: the child looks longingly at the bread. to go stealthily; to be artful. edapadapatos kesi: they are artful or tricky in their movements. adapadapaun to try to regain favour in a roundabout way; to make overtures; to insinuate. edapadapauna aberu ngin abongokin k’okilenike: that woman is making overtures to return to her husband. to come stealthily. adapadapaunos: they are returning stealthily. adapakin to be hidden. adapakinos bo akinei ai?: where have the goats hidden themselves (i.e. where are they)? to put near something. ai bo idapakit ijo ikaboro?: where have you hidden my things? adapakina to be depending on (someone or something). adapalal flatness; evenness; smoothness. adapalanut flatness or evenness to be flat. adapao a porch; the eaves; a hiding place. adapenen to keep stalking someone or something; to continually repair by adding patches. kapas eong adapenen etogo lo: I am tired of repairing this house (or patching this house). adapet a patch (on cloth or anything). adapidap to catch (chickens) by stealth, side-stepping. adatat a newly cleared plot of ground; a new garden, field. adaun to be finished; to die. adaunos akipi: the water is finished. to finish; to accomplish, consummate; to complete, exterminate. kodau ber akoniswam: first finish your work. to be sufficient; to be enough. mam apeesan ngun edolete: that money is not sufficient. (adaun is also used to translate ‘after’, and ‘to be dead’). kidau aswamukon, kobu: after your work, come here; or, come here when you have finished your work. adaun papaka: my father is dead. adaunos eong akituk: my cows are finished or are dead. adauna absoluteness; absolutism. adaunet the end. idol ijo adaunet naka epelu: you have reached the end of the task.adea to crack; to make a crackling sound (as of a beam going to break). adeas akito kokuju togo: the rafters in the house are cracking. adeasit a (small) crack; a flaw, chink; a fault. adere na ileleba adeasia: this calabash is full of little cracks. adebe a tin; a metal can. adedea to keep cracking, sizzle (like sound heard when grass is burning).adedengan a severe, savage or cruel woman or animal. adedengiar to flare up; to go for; to molest. adedengiar ao kane: the bees are turning wild here. adedengiar ejakait: the boss has flared up. adedengikin to reprimand; to threaten; to be hard to; to be cruel or severe to; to treat harshly. kidedengikini moi ijo ejakait: the superior will reprimand you tomorrow. abu ekingok kadedengik eong: the dog made for me savagely. adedengu (singular noun F) severity; cruelty; barbarity. adedengun to become severe, cruel, harsh, etc. age ekingoko kon adedengun: your dog is getting fierce. adeet a plucking instrument; the place where the fruit was picked off. ejaas adeeta manaka, esubit bala ekokotai epaabaka: there are signs that my cotton has been plucked. adeikin to pluck vegetables or fruits for someone. kodeikinai eong da edia edis: pluck some vegetables for me too. adeka1 illness; disease; indisposition; epidemic; sickness; ailment. adeka naikopitoi: a contagious disease. adeka nakwana: the disease of these days (such as AIDS). adeka ya: that disease (known to you already). adeka2 to be ill, sick, ailing, unwell; to ail. adeka eong: I am ill. ideka ijo: you are ill. idekana ijo: you are always sick. adekakin to be ill, unwell, sick, etc of something; to go down with; to catch an illness. adekakin eong aola: I have a cough. aitedek: to tend a patient; to look after a patient, to nurse. adekanakin to be constantly ill, etc edekanakinos idwe: the children are always ill. adeke a variety of banana plant whose ripe fruit is boiled before being eaten.adekerer to be wasted, thin, emaciated. idekereras itunga etengei: the people are emaciated with famine. adekis a hospital; a dispensary; a health centre. adelonor to scream, to weep bitterly at intervals, like a woman whose husband or child has died. adelor to cry out, exclaim, shriek, howl, wail, etc; (usually of human beings, but also of animals) to ejaculate, yell. kanukinyo adeloriata itelepai?: why have the boys wailed? ademar to take by force; to rob or to plunder, extort, confiscate; to dispossess; to grab. apotu lukabuorok kademasi ekatogo: robbers plundered my house. ademececar to become too wet. adengelel to be anxious; to rejoice, be glad; to run for joy; to flirt, keep company with. adengelelooto idwe adumun akiring: the children are very glad to get meat. apotu idwe kodengelelooto alosit aiyeng: the children ran with joy when going on holiday. sirikidengelelok etelepat ngol: do not keep company with that boy (because he is bad). adengelelet to go or do with pleasure. edengelelet ngesi iswamai: she/he works with pleasure. adengelelokin to be glad, rejoice for something or on account of somebody. adengelelokit eong adumun egaali: I am glad (happy) that I got a bicycle. adengis a thing to pluck with; the place where a fruit has been plucked; the place where the esidengideng-worm has cut. adengokin to pluck for someone. kodengokinai eong emucuuga: pluck me an orange. adengor to pluck off, away. adengor etometomet: to tie off a wart. adengoret the place from which a fruit or cotton was plucked. aanyunit eong adengoreta: I have seen the marks left after the fruit was plucked. adengosit a scar left after beating or a swelling. adengun to pick off fruit; to knock off. adeor to gather (fruit, vegetables) and take away; to pluck, pick (for oneself) and take away; to run away very fast. adepar (used with the sense of aitelekaar) exceedingly; more than; better than; more, etc. beyond; further than. ibu ijo kokoko irwan akany ka adepar: you stole five times and more. adepar to overtake; to go past; to pass, surpass; to overlook, trespass; to miss; to omit; to be more than. adepar ekisil: to trespass; to go beyond the rules or the law. ideparit ijo erot: you have gone beyond the path. ejaas nges akituk nuedeparito akwatat: he has more than a hundred cows. sirikidepa ekisil lo: do not breach this law. adere a calabash; a half gourd, used for drawing water or beer; a bowl. aderecaar to slip away without waiting. aderecaar ekokolan: the thief ran off or away without being caught. aderecitoi to dash; to go with long jumps. aderit a sickness caused by eating the meat of ederit (bushbuck) owing to clan taboos forbidding it.kideronok akonikiro: speak the truth (straighten your words). aderut a twig used for making wicker baskets, doors or winnows (erite), Phyllanthus discoiceus. adeseikin to tell the truth; to repeat or say the same. ideseik ijo akiro nuakoto eong da alimun: you have said exactly what I wanted to say. adese ngesi Ateso: she/he is fluent in Ateso language. adeset a spark of fire; a splash of rain water, etc.adesiar1 to retort; to answer quickly and correctly (with akiro); to become familiar with. adesiar2 to beat or flog mercilessly; to hit point blank; to shoot on target. abu ngesi kodesia akokuke: she/he beat her/his daughter mercilessly. adesitoi1 alacrity; agility. adesitoi2 (of nervous person when called) to jump up quickly, be agile; (of a flea) to keep on jumping from one place to another; to be a quick and zealous worker. edesitoi etelepat je aswam: that boy is a quick and zealous worker. edesitoi etelepat lo neejai apese ngin: this boy is constantly going after that girl. adetakin to splash for somebody; to sprinkle, throw water on something, at some- body; to give a little. kanukinyo kidetakina ijo eong akipi?: why did you splash water on me? (of water or liquids) to fall on, to splash on, to drop on. adetakinos akipi oitaadaka: the water has splashed on my bed. adetanar to spill or boil over; to spark. edetanar akim: the fire is sparking. edetanaros akipi: the water is splashing off, i.e. boiling over. (of men or animals) to disperse. adetanaros itunga atipe: the people dispersed at once. adetar (of animal, birds) to throw off; to shake off from body like water or anything else after washing; to toss up.adetat a spot or a drop of water or liquids. adetekewait an edible berry from edetekewai tree. adetelel to flirt or make love to; to court. edetelelet etelepat neejai apese: the boy flirts with the girl. adetokin to grab at; to snatch away. kedetokinos ikokolak luko Owino ikeboro: the thieves from (Kampala’s) Owino market snatched away his belongings. adetor to jump up, spring up, stand to attention (used at a race when starting or at a parade to stand to attention). kodetor, kodetoros akerit: run, get off quickly. adetudetun to get up, rise at once, suddenly and run away. adetudetunos itelepai kimurokis iitaabonokec: the boys rose and ran off leaving their books behind. adetun1 to rise or get up at once; to rise very quickly or to wake up with a start; to choose one only; to select one by one. abu ngesi kodetun ekwenyuni: she/he woke up with a start. adetun2 to throw or to throw a little water at oneself. adeudeu a six-stringed arched harp.adeun to fall off from tree (as of fruit); to be plucked or picked. adeun epaaba epol noi lolo: much cotton has been picked today. adeunos imucuugai bon: the oranges have fallen off by themselves. adeyaar to throw at and hit; to answer to the point.mam ijo ijeni adeyaar, idyakenenei ijo duc: you do not aim well, you always miss the target. ideyaa ijo akiro: you have answered well (to the point); you have hit the point (in your answer). adi? F (interrogation) how many? angor adi?: how many women are they? adiakaret a mistake, fault, crime. adianakin akonye to keep aiming sharply, carefully, accurately with one eye closed; to keep looking through a narrow hole; to wink at. adiar to look through a narrow hole; to aim or peer away. adiar akongu kotoma apedot: to look at something through a pinhole. adidima a quarrelsome, noisy woman.adiding to be narrow. ediding ngesi aomisio: she/he is narrow-minded. ediding kesi aomisio: they are narrow-minded. aitididing: to make narrow, slender; to cause to shrink. adidinga a swelling in the neck; east coast fever in cattle.adidingaar to become narrow, slender; to shrink. adidingaar egoe lo: this dress does not fit. adidingikin to be too narrow for. kadidingikit eong epale lo: these trousers are so narrow for me. adidio a dragon fly. adieket a law court; a magistrate’s court.adigidigi a one-stringed tube fiddle played to accompany a human voice; an African violin.adiiga a sheep; an ewe.adiikin to look at carefully; to aim carefully; to look with one eye closed through a small hole. kodiik adebe ngin akongu, motoko ejai apedot: look carefully at that tin, perhaps there is a small hole. adiikinit akonye: to be shortsighted. adiikinit akongu: to be short-sighted (one eye); to slit one eye. adikam to eat thick porridge; to eat thick food. adilituun (of mushroom) to uproot; to eradicate. adilokin to start (doing something) early. alosi eong adilokin ainyam: I shall have an early breakfast. edilokinete akituk adak: the cattle will go to graze early. adilun to arrive or come early. adiluni moi tupuruc sek: I shall come (rise) very early tomorrow morning. adimasita a headmistress; a head teacher.edingas ebu ka ekingok: the hyena and the dog are enemies. adinga2 a disease of nose causing a very offensive smell; infection of septum in the nose; sinuses or sinusitis. adinganut1 to be aggressive; hostile. adinganut2 hostility; enmity; aggressiveness. adingiriar to run fast (away). kodingiriaros karai ikotos ayuun: run away fast if you want to save yourselves. adingirir to run fast, race along. edingiririt egaali lo noi: this bicycle cruises very fast. kodingirir oiduka: run quickly to the shop. adingiririkin to run fast to fetch something. kodingiririk ekileng kore: run quickly home and fetch a knife. adingirirun to run very fast this way. kodingirirunos lailo: run quickly this way. adingit a fiddle. adinyo a sheep given as present to father or mother-in-law; a hoe with long handle (used while standing). adiobore (indefinite pronoun F) anything; a scrap (of something). adiope diope F (numeral adverb, used with plural feminine nouns) one by one; one after another. angor adiope diope: one woman at a time. kolomanasi adiope diope: go in one by one. singly; one by one. kopotu adiope diope: come one by one, singly. adiopet F (numeral adjective) one. akiteng adiopet: one cow. akine adiopet: one she-goat. adiotai a little; some; a piece. koinakinai ajoola adiotai: give me a piece of cloth material. adiotitai a little; a bit. koinakinai acece adiotitai: give me just a little more soup. adipakin1 to crumble; to fall down on; to fall in (of house); (of a grave) to become depressed. adipakin etogoka: my house has sunk (or my house is ruined because my wife is dead). to crush; to raze. abu ekitoi kodipak ekatogo: a tree fell and crushed my house. adipakin2 to walk one behind another in procession or in Indian file. adipakinet a procession. adipalat a depression; a dip; a plain in a valley; a flood plain. adipanyany to be short, low (of house). adipar to go together (in Indian file); to accompany. kadiparos oni kere: let us go together (Indian file).adipidip to pummel; to beat repeatedly (with a fist or club); to knock heavily. adipiikin to get a glimpse of; to flash of; a momentary flash of. adipiikit eong engatuny, konye aolio: I got only a glimpse of a lion, but it has vanished. adipirir to keep behind someone.edipit ekingok papake: the dog usually follows its master. adipokin to beat with a fist at a certain place, at home or somewhere else in presence of someone; to beat for someone else. abu eong kadipok nges oreke toma: I dealt him a few blows at his very home. adipun to come together in company. kodipunos oreka: come together (Indian file) to my home.adiritit (of a tree or anything) to stand straight. adisaar to beat once on the back with a fist or club. adisamam to have large prominent buttocks. adisianar to dwindle away; to abate. adisiar to become smaller; to become childish. adisirikin ki-a to make a person look spruce (like a girl before her marriage); to fit nicely to be spruce. idisirikinos yesi: you are spruce. egoe lo mam kedisirikinit eong: this dress does not fit me. adisirir to look smart; to have a handsome appearance; to become stout and to be well built; to be spruce. idisirir etelepat ngol: that boy is smart in his appearance. adita a small basket.aditakin to dash out; to escape. aditakin ekokolan: the thief dashed off and escaped. aditeu1 smallness; infancy, childhood. aditeu2 to be small, humble, little, young; to be in childhood. edit ngesi: she/he/it is small or young. edisiak kesi: they are small or young. akoto kodit ijo: I want you to be small or humble. kodisiak: be small or humble. aitiditeun: to make smaller; to minimize.aditeun to become small; to decrease; to become humble. aditeut akituk kotoma aujokon: there are only a few cows left in your kraal. aditeu akuwanake kanuka adeka: he has become thin on account of disease. aditianut to be childish. aditidit to take big lumps of any solid food. editiditei ngesi atap: she/he takes food in big lumps. aditor to stretch oneself chest forward and arms out. aditot a valley. adiun to look at speaker through a narrow hole; to look in through a small hole (like keyhole). ingai ediunit akongu toma togoka?: who is peeping into my house? adoakin to snap a finger at (to call attention). kanukinyo kidoakinitor ijo eong ebokorit?: why did you snap your fingers at me (call my attention)? adoanakin to snap at repeatedly. kodoanak ekingok ngol ibokor kobu: snap your fingers to call that dog. adoanar to keep snapping; to smack repeatedly. kodoana ibokor kere: snap all the fingers. adoar to snap (fingers or to fire a gun). kodoa emuudu: fire the gun. adodanar to point constantly, repeatedly. adodar to point with lips or with index finger; to point away. edodarit emuudu laije: the gun is pointing the other way. adodikin to point out for; to show somebody. kododikinai erot: point out the road to me i.e. show me the way.adodoot to interfere. kinyek adodoot toma akiro numam eraas nukon: do not interfere in what is not your business. adodor (imperative verb) to be quick, easy; to hasten (doing something or becoming something) easy, easily, soon. edodor ngesi abunere: she/he/it is likely to come soon. adodoromunyel a quick cook; a woman who is quick to conceive again after birth or marriage. edodor aberu ngin: that woman conceives quickly. adodorot a species of water-bird, Grebe. adoelel to lie at ease; to be slender; to be emaciated. adoere to drop; to fall. adogoria a pot with two or three mouths (traditionally associated with rituals pertaining to the birth of twins – for example, it was used for burying the placenta of twins in the swamp; beer provided during the twin-dance was drank from it).adoikin to befall, fall upon; to happen to; to fall into. kadoikis eong akiro: I am in trouble. adokar1 (singular noun F) Ascension (Christ’s ascent to heaven on the fortieth day after the Resurrection). Apaaran na Adokar: Ascension Day. adokar2 to climb up or away from; to ascend; to embark (not to disembark). kodoka kuju togo: climb on the roof (of the house). adokarot acclivity. adoke a species of bird, White-crested lourie. adoket a ladder; steps; staircase; berth; landing site. adoketait a stepping-stone; a level; a rung of a ladder; a distinction; a rank; a scale; a class; a grade. eitaabo lo esiomio kadoketait nakokuju: this book is read at higher levels of study. adokikin to climb on, in, for, to. kodokik ao ngin: climb up for that honey. adokit to be aboard. adokit abaasi, agaali, edege, kice da: to be aboard a bus, train, aeroplane, etc. adokita a female doctor (who administers western medicine).adokokin to pick vegetables for somebody. ikakoku, kodokokinai eboo: my dear child, pluck some eboo vegetables for me. adokon a gift; something extra given by seller; a baksheesh. adokoriait a kind of berry. adokoror1 thinness; leanness. adokoror2 to be lean, thin, emaciated, wasted from disease.idokororas idwe lu: these children are emaciated (from starvation) adokun to climb down or come down, descend; to alight, dismount. kodokutu kere kokitoi: come down all of you from the tree. (note: to come down of birds or planes is adoun or adoore, but to disembark from a vehicle is adokun). adol a species of fresh water fish; elephant snout fish, Mormyrus. adolio to arrive (somewhere away from speaker) with something to deliver; to reach with. adolit to be ample; to be perfect, just enough, sufficient, holy; to be just; to be adequate, apt, or convenient. mam akiro kon edolitos: that is no answer; what you say is wrong. adolokin to call upon; to visit; to approach; to affect. alosi eong adolokin mamaika kocanike: I am going to call on my uncle in his difficulty (i.e. to condole with him). adolore to arrive; to reach; to be sufficient, enough, right, or correct; to occur, happen. abu kodolu: she/he/it arrived. apotu akiroke kodoloto: what she/he said was right or came to pass. adoli ore kon moi: I shall reach your home tomorrow. kodol kojokan: safe journey; bon voyage. adolun1 advent. adolun2 to arrive here; to arrive there where you are. adomelait dried up exudates from eyes due to conjunctivitis or inflammation of the conjunctiva of the eye. adomoc to approach somebody with dirty dripping hands or feet. sirikidomocun neka kakanin kon: do not come near me with dirty dripping hands. adomocaar to be full of perspiration; to drip with perspiration, perspiring, sweating very much. adomocaaros idwe akaulo abolia: the children drip with perspiration after playing. adomola a small container for liquids, such as a five-litre jerry can.abu je kodongak opaperoke: he betrayed his friend. adongakin2 to reserve food, keep for. sirikimurwok adongakin idwe inyamat: do not forget to reserve some food for the children. adonganakin to dole out for. adongar to take away food to somebody else; to reserve food for. adonge a barren female (person or animal).adongit to hold on to; to stick to opinion; to pinch; to be indelible; to hold with pincers; to be deep-rooted. idongit ijo akiro nuadaunos: you hold on to what is settled (against you). adongit to follow persistently. inyo bo idongitor ijo aupa ka eong?: why do you persist in following me (against my will)? adongodong to pinch all over the body; to have pinching or griping pain in the stomach (as after eating hard food like roasted maize or roasted cassava); to have the gripes. kadongodongoi eong akoik: I have griping pain in my stomach. adongun to pinch for oneself; to hold with pincers. adongun lukabong: to have supper or dinner. adongun lukapaaran: to have lunch (to be actually eating). adongunet pincers. adonyit a seam; a hem line; a line of stitching. adonyokin to mend clothes; to patch up; to mend for; to wrap something in. kodonyokinai ekapale: please, mend my trousers (for me). kodonyok apeesan ogoe: wrap the money in the cloth; or, sew the buttons on the dress. adoobe a small piece of cloth covering the female genitalia during menstruation; a tampon.adoobo a bucket; a pail. adoome a small piece of clothing covering the female genitalia during menstruation; a tampon.adoonokin to keep dropping on to; to keep putting into. to keep falling on or into. kadoonokis eong atiokisyo nuipu: many troubles keep on befalling me. adoor to go down; (of sun) to set; to dive, plunge into the water. adoo akolong: the sun has set.adoorakin to defame or slander somebody. abu ewadikan iyemuto kodoorak eminisita akiro: the news reporter defamed the minister. adoore to fall; to alight; (of plane) to land; (of bird, etc) to descend. ekoto edege adoore Soroti: the plane is about to land in Soroti. adoore boo: edou aitep lopeti: to rain incessantly. adoorian to complain; to lament; to bewail, grouse, grumble at; to squeal. adooriani eong ikakoku yen atwana: I lament over my dead child. inyo bo idoorianete yesi?: why are you mournful? adooro an artesian well; a protected water spring or well.adoosan (singular noun F) the smouldering of the fire; the glow.adopony to be nearly blind; to be one-eyed, eyelid permanently closed. edoponyi ngesi alosit: she/he walks like a half-blind person. adoponyoun (of a blind man) to come toward the speaker. adoponyoun etelepat neajai eong: the half-blind boy has come to me. adopudop whitish-grey. adorakin to give a second name, usually after 3-6 years. ekiror lodoret: a second name. adorodorot a lark. adoronyikin to vomit (of animals only). koyangaa ekonikingok ngina, kinyek adoronyikin idoronyike nen: take your dog away, so that it may not vomit here. adosa to break or crush (as of shell of groundnuts). sirikidosa abeei: do not drop these eggs (or do not burst the eggs by letting them fall). adosaar to break a thing by letting it fall; to burst as egg or cup or glass or husk of nuts. to break by falling; to burst. adosaaros abeei: the eggs are broken (by falling or otherwise). adosaikin to crush for somebody. adote a woman who has illicit intercourse constantly; a harlot; prostitute.adote to have illicit sexual intercourse once.edoteete kesi: they are having illicit intercourse. (note: matrimonial intercourse is aimorikikin - emorikikinos ngesi ka aberuke: he is having sexual union with his wife). adoteanar (of a man) to develop a strong passion for women. adoteanar ekesa ngol: that guy is becoming a womaniser. adoteanut1 to be in the habit of having illicit sex.adoteanut2 (singular noun F) inclination to illicit sexual intercourse. adotear to go somewhere to have illicit sexual intercourse. adoteu (singular noun F) adultery; fornication; lust; libido. adotor to fall off of hair, feathers, thorn, jiggers. adotoros ajul nuka ekokor: the feathers of the cock have fallen off. (of hair, feathers, thorns, etc) to fall off. adotun to extract; to take or pull or pick out this way.adoun (of rain or anything) to fall down, drop down this way. adoutu iitaabon kere kwap: all the books have fallen down. edounene edou apaarasia kere: it rains always. adoyaar to shout, fall out in anger against somebody (for sometime); to become thin; (of a swelling) go down; to hit. kanu bo kinyo idoyaaror ijo?: why have you grown thin? adoyaar edoi: to make a noise by snapping a rope to chase locusts or birds from ripening grain. elosi akabus adoyaar: my swelling is going down. adoyanar to crack a whip. edoyanarete idwe idoyan airengianara ikweny: children are cracking whips to drive away birds. adua sperms; semen humanum.adudu to stretch or disperse; to press outwardly; to make a passage through crowd; of birds or animals by gunshot or other way) to disperse. adudu akuwan: to stretch the body; to stretch oneself. adudung to overtake; to come upon, pursue closely. edudungit ekingok ipoo: the dog is in hot pursuit of the hare.aduduo thunder; explode or burst (of anything). apupi eong aduduo nakokuju: I hear thunder. adui a lair, a burrow, a pit, pitfall, a cave. aduikin to blow up (a house);
