to explode towards; to shoot (a bird); to blast (a rock). akoto aduikin amoru: I want to blast a rock. koduik ekweny ngol: shoot that bird. aduke abode, nest of rat; humble abode; homestead. aduketait a building; a structure; an edifice. adukit to inhabit, live in. edukit etoori okitoi ngol: an eagle lives in that tree. isubit ijo bala idukit oreka: it is as if you live with me (by always visiting me). edukit kwana eong aola atorob: I have an incurable cough (literally, a cough inhabits my chest). adukokin to build for someone, hence to marry a girl, a woman. ekoto ngesi adukokin akoku k’ejakait: he wants to marry the chief's daughter to marry in general; to get married. idukokin bo ijo wori?: when are you going to marry? to be married. adukokinos kesi: they are married. adukokino (singular noun F) a marriage; a wedding. adukokino kus ejokuna: yours is a good marriage. adukon a builder; an architect; a mason. erai ngesi loadukon: he is a builder or a mason. adukonor to leap, prance; to bounce (said of animals in general, but especially of little lambs).koloto kodukoosi ngina awai: go and build away from the old homestead. adukun to build for oneself. akoto eong adukun itogo idiokasilon: I want to build a little house for myself. aduli a hunting horn. adulusus to have fat falling buttocks. idulusus ijo: you have fat falling buttocks.adumakin to receive for someone; to procure for another; to find in or somewhere. ekoto kodumakin ijo toma aswamukon: you should be found at your work. adumak eong ngesi ore: I have found him/her at home. adumanakin1 to meet constantly in a certain place. nepene edumanakinos itunga: it is here that people meet each other. adumanakin2 to keep supplying; to give always. eong duc kadumanakini ijo inyamat: it is I who always supplies you with food. adumar to go and meet or join someone. alosi adumar papaka: I am going to join my father. adumari nges acepaarit: I shall join him/her some day. alot ngesi adumar aberu: he has gone to meet a woman (he has gone for a rendezvous with a woman). adumun to meet; to find; to receive; to accept; to earn, acquire, or obtain. inyo idumuni ijo karai kitwania aijar nakokuju?: what will you gain if you lose eternal life (heaven)? kadumakini ijo ai?: where shall I find you? adumunet a gain; a use; value; a profit; a receipt; a meeting place. atikit nadumunet aiboisit: admission ticket. adumunia to profit by; to gain by; to get by, etc. inyamat ejaas kanuka adumunia agogong: food is there for getting strength (to gain strength). adumunun to meet one another often; to meet often; to come together often to get often, receive or accept often. loiswamaenenei edumununei kotoma aswamuke: a worker will always receive benefit from his/her work. adunge1 edible termites and white ants for cooking.adunge2 (of fire only) to go out. adunge akim: the fire is out (extinguished). adungeor to be extinguished; (of fire) to go out. akim namam edungeori: the undying fire.adungokin to cut for someone. kadungoki eong ebiyat mana: the spear grass cut me while I was in the garden. adungor to curtail; to send evil away by sacrificing a lamb and leaving it in the wild for carion to eat. alosi eong adungor apesenikon: I am going to curtail your expenses.adungot a cut; a wound. epol adungot: the cut is big. adungudung to cut lightly in many places with a razorblade or knife; to cut (skin) often. adungudung okoku kon akan k’emweeso: your son has cut his hand with a razorblade. adungulul (of leg, arm, etc) to be short or maimed. adunguret a grass stump left after grass fire.adunyakin to work hard at; to persevere in; to do daily, go on with. kodunyakis aisisia apaarasia kere: continue learning everyday. kadunyakis aceswam: let us go on with other work. adunyanar to be or become zealous, industrious, etc. adunyanut1 persistence; perseverance.adunyanut2 to be persistent, obsessed, etc. edunyana, edunyaka: she/he is (they are) zealous. adunyar to come behind; to follow; to imitate, come after. edunyarit ikoku eipone kapapake: the child takes after its father’s habits. alosi eong ore, kodunya ijo: I am going home, you come after me. aduo to explode, as of gun or rocket or rocks. apupunit eong emuudu eduo: I have heard a gun go off. eduduo lolo akuj noi: it is thundering very much today. aduor to explode or detonate; to scatter away; to disperse or take flight. adupakin to fix; to plant (a pole, stick, spear in the ground); to put a nail, peg in the wall or ground; to plant (cassava, etc). kodupak esumaalit arwatat, akoto eong aikajakin ekagoe: fix a nail in the wall, I want to hang my clothes on. kodupak emeleku kageutu aicil epelu: put the plough into the ground and let us start the work. adur sexual intercourse in humans; copulation.adurar (of men) to go and have sexual intercourse elsewhere (not at home or near the speaker). adusa to throb; to beat (of anything heaving, falling). kodusa etuo ngol: churn the milk well (i.e. make the churn throb). edusai ekatau erono: ebala ekatau dus-dus: my heart beats irregularly (badly). adusaar (of anything) to fall forward or backwards. adusaar ikoku: the child fell over (from a high bed while asleep, or while learning to sit) to knock down. adusaun (of heart) to beat; to fall forward or backwards down; to pulsate. edusaunun ekatau: my heart beats quickly. adusaun epir akouka: the pole fell forward onto my head. adusukuk to be dumpy; (of something edible) to be very soft. adutakin to share with; to contribute to; to give to, endow somebody. kodutakinai eong da adipeesan: give me also a little money. Ikristayon icorakinitai adutanakin ekanisa apeesan kec: Christians are asked to contribute a tithe to the church. adutakinet a contribution; a portion; a gift; a tithe. mam ijo ilemunit adutakinetekon: you have not given in your contribution. adutanut1 liberality, generosity. mam ijo ijeni adutanut: generosity is unknown to you; or, you are not generous. adutanut2 to be liberal, generous. adutar to irrigate; to fill (tanks) with water; to distribute over there; to over fill. itunga luko Misiri edutanarete akipi toma omanikoriakec: the Egyptians irrigate their gardens. epakasit edutanari akipi ataagi: the porter fills the tank with water. to be overfull. inyo bo idutaritor ijo asaanit na?: why have you overfilled this plate? adutaros ataagin: the tanks are overfull, overflowing. aduuda (singular noun F) potato flour; atap from potato flour (tastes sweet if cooked without tamarind fruit). aduwet a catapult.adwal a woman’s apron made of skin; a woman’s plaited straps. adwalakaar to become flat; to droop (owing to lack of strength or energy); to become soft, flat (as of breast). adwalakaar atap: the millet bread is soft (poorly mingled, i.e. watery).adwalikidetok a plant, Cape- gooseberry. adwarakin to prophesy for someone; to predict or foretell what is to befall another. kodwarakinai eong atwanareka: foretell my death. adwarar to foretell; to predict, prophesy, divine. adwaret a prophecy, divination, a foretelling, a conjecture. adwareta nuka lokadwaran Isaia: the prophecies of the prophet Isaiah. adwaris (singular noun F) bitterness; pungency; acridity of things, words and heart; asperity. mam akoto adwaris naka etauke: I do not like his quick temper (the bitterness of his heart). adwarun1 (singular noun F) puberty; adolescence; (formerly) age-grade feast for youths reaching puberty – literally, the child has become sour.erai lolo na apaarit nakadwarun: today is the age-grade feast day.adwarun2 to grow stubborn; to be obstinate; to be refractory; to grow wild; to become bitter, serious. adwaru apese ngin: that girl has grown wild, stubborn i.e. she listens to nobody. adwaru ecooro kwana aiar akokoroi: the chicken disease (coccidiosis) constantly kills hens. adwaru apese: the girl has grown big (developed breasts or reached puberty). adwaruut akiro: there is trouble brewing. adwarus (singular noun F) bitterness; pungency; acridity of things and words and heart; asperity. mam akoto adwarus naka etauke: I do not like his quick temper (the bitterness of his heart). adwekelel (of food) to be flat to the taste. adwomakin to eat for or somewhere else. adwomaki ikoku edia orot: the child ate the vegetables it was carrying on the way. adwomar to finish eating all the vegetables. adwoma ikoku edia kere: the child has eaten all the vegetables. adyaka to trespass; to commit a fault; to sin. idyaka ijo: you have trespassed; you have erred. adyakalal to be soft (to touch). idyakalal alupot: the clay is soft (ot touch). adyakaret a fault, a mistake, a sin, an offence, a transgression, defect. adyekakin1 intercession; arbitration. adyekakin2 to reconcile; to propitiate; to intercede for; to pacify. koar akokor nadyekakinet itunga: slaughter a chicken for reconciling those quarrelling. to be reconciled, pacified; to give in, submit, calm down; to make peace; to intercede. adyekakinos ikulepek bonik: they are reconciled by themselves. adyekakinet reconciliation; propitiation; intercession; pacification. adyekar to separate combatants i.e. to take one away. kodyeka itunga kwi: go and separate those people. to be separated; to separate oneself. adyekun to pull (fighters) apart, save from; to guard; to come and rescue. kodyekunai eong kaneka lokasurupika: come and rescue me from my enemy. kodyekutu angor kinyekis aarakin: pull the fighting women apart, lest they kill each other. kodyek akitukukon, kinyek aisab: guard your tongue from telling lies. to be pulled apart, saved, extricated from danger. adyekun akituk: to guard one’s tongue. aedakin to peer through half-closed eyes; to warn by winks; to be intent on work. aedakin elacit: to play one a trick. alosi eong aedakin ngol elacit: I am going to conspire against him (play him a trick). iedakit lolo papaka aswam: my father is intent on working today. aedo a species of bird with a long neck, eats reptiles, and is a non-wading bird, Kori bustard. aejo a gem; a jewel. aekar to go far away; to depart; to be advanced; (of inanimate things) to have disappeared; to do well, become an important person. aekasi itunga ore: people have gone home. aekasi ikasirigin tai: my money has gone for nothing. aeka ekagoe: my dress is worn out. eekarit aberu: the woman is advanced in years i.e. she is aged. aeketet (of a man) having big, swollen testicles. aekun to come near; to approach; to accede. koekutu ne: come nearby. aisiekun: to make or force to come near, etc. aelekek (of a woman or girl) having half-grown breasts. aelo1 adultery; fornication; love affair; sexual intercourse. aelo2 (formerly) to be friends; to help in a friendly way; to be blood-brothers; (these days) to commit adultery or fornication. eeloete kesi noi: they are great friends: they are blood brothers. eelos kesi: they are lovers. aelokin1 (formerly) to become blood-brothers; (these days) to become lovers; to have an affair; to have sexual intercourse. neageata kesi aelokin, apotu komatata aokotokec: when they became blood-brothers they drank each other’s blood. kinyek aisud aelo, imina aikatun esilim: do not get involved in casual sexual intercourse, you may acquire HIV/AIDS. aelokin2 to have friendship with; to have sexual intercourse with (a man, woman, boy or girl). aelokinos apese ngin kede etelepat ngol: that girl and that boy are intimate friends. aelor to prompt; to move instinctively; to stir. aimony naka ikoku aelo totoke: the cry of the child has moved its mother instinctively. itaok eelorit totoke k’aruoke: the calf stirs the mother by its cry. aelut an edible round black fruit from ewelu or ekarukwei tree; a stick or leaf from ewelu tree, Vitex madiensis, Vitex doniana. aenanakin to tie up, bind (several things together) for somebody. koenanak akinei ngun nen: tether those goats there. aenanar to tie into separate parcels. koenana iitaaboi kamurengen: pack the books in separate parcels. aenar tie up and take away. aena lolo epakasit emuogo: the servant/porter has tied up and taken away cassava today i.e. has stolen cassava. aenet, aenetait a knot; a lace; a sash; a package; a parcel; something for tying. auno naenet: a rope for tying. aenikin to tie on, bind in or up; to fasten on or to. koenik auno omorosingike: tie the rope round her/his/its neck. koenik baa-ba: fasten it very tightly. aenun to bring something tied; to bring a parcel. inyo bo ienunit ijo?: what kind of parcel have you brought? aep an axe. ailikor aep: to become brave or do a brave act. Isiriamun lueduonorete iboomun atwakianakin ilikonorete aep: Muslims who commit suicide with bombs do brave acts. aerier to be transparent; to be thin (as of paper or glass or skin); (of belly of a kink lizard) to be so full that entrails are seen. aesikin to let go, set free; to make room or passage. koesikinai: let me go; set me free.aet noise made by cutting into slices or as of cutting stalks of grain. aetanunan a foster-mother; a step-mother; an adopted mother. aetokin to give a name or nickname. agaali a railway train; an ox-cart or an ox-wagon. agaali na apuru a railway train.agadigadi a wheelbarrow; a pushcart.agagar to put, squeeze, push, cram big things into small or narrow places or openings. sirikigagar asadukun togo loediding: do not try to cram big boxes into a small room. agagaraun to bring some bulky object into a narrow place. agagarikin to push or put a big thing into a small place or room; to squeeze through a small opening; to cram in. inyo bo igagarikinia ijo amotoka orot loediding?: why have you parked this big car on this path? mam eong apedori agagarikin eitaabo lo kere toma akouka: I cannot cram this whole book in my head. to push, place, cram, squeeze oneself into a narrow opening or place (not to fit). inyo bo igagarikinor ijo ne?: why have you squeezed yourself in here? agak a raven (completely dark without a white ‘collar’).e. the one with a white ring of feathers round its neck. agalapua (singular noun F) a camphor leaf or stick. agalibidin spectacles; goggles; specs; eyeglasses. agalon a gallon (a liquid measure in America). agangat aid; assistance. agangat nasodit: first aid; the help you give a sick or hurt person before a doctor comes. aigangakin itunganan: to help or assist someone; to come to someone's aid. agangarakou one with a big head; a fat-head. (a term of abuse) agar a fish with fins (in general).e pregnant or gestating. agaraki akiteng: the cow is near calving (i.e. the udder is big). (note: for pregnancy of a woman, use agorun). agaramikin to obstruct with. egaramikit eipyei ekitoi orot: lightning has felled a big tree onto the road. agaramikin emaase mana: a swarm of locusts has settled on the field. agaramikin emong kwap, agir anyoun: the bull has fallen down and will not get up. agariait a fish with fins (in general).kagarit eong epale lo: these shorts are too tight for me. egarit epeta ibokor: the ring is too small for the fingers. agasia rubbish; dirt; grime; filth; muck. agat to roar; to speak or shout simultaneously. egata akim biribir: the wild fire is roaring uncontrollably.agatun to speak or shout simultaneously, together. egatunete Isureta: ‘kotwana! Ibweny’: the thief-cursers shout together: ‘let him die!’ agear to start off (a journe, a meeting, or anything); to begin to make a start with. agear alosit: to start off on a journey. wori igeara ijo aswam?: when are you going to start work? ageero an artesian well.ageget a tilapia fish; ngege.araito ngun ejai egegetu: those fruits are astringent (cause constipation if eaten).agegit a bunch of grain kept in the smoky kitchen roof for seed.ageikin to make a start for someone else; to precede; to begin with. Tanganyika ageikini too naka Africa aipugaikin bon: Tanganyika preceded other East African countries in gaining self-rule. kogeikinai eong emukeeka keswama: start for me the mat and I shall go on weaving. agelakin to choose for; to sort out for, pick out for. kogelakinai eong ekamong: pick out my bull for me from your kraal. to be different; to differ; (of colour) to change. agelakinos akonikiro ka nuk’opaupakon: your statement differs from that of your companion.agelakina to be in contrast. agelanar to make a selection; to pick out what you want. kogelana ikoniboro kinyek lukos: pick what is yours and leave ours. agelar to pick out; to sort out; to choose and take away; to detach; to excommunicate; to isolate. kogela akituku kon kane: pick out and take away your cows from here. to be different; to differ; to be unlike. to separate; to settle difficulty outside court; to go one’s own way. egelas akituk ngun bonik: those cows separate and go to their own kraals. kogelas yesi ikulepek bon kore: settle your affairs amongst yourselves at home. agelegel to sort out; to group; to parcel out according to quality or price. kogelegel ikoniboro igwelanari: sort out your goods when selling. agelegela1 disparity; inequality; discrepancy; inconsistency. agelegela2 to be different, varied, etc. egelegela itunga: people differ. agelegeleun to be divided; (of a family or tribe) to live in different places. agelegeleunos kwana ikatunga: my people are now living in different places or countries. agelem to castrate, or to emasculate. agelem imongin: to castrate bulls.agelemaar to castrate or emasculate. agelemaar eitaabo: to expurgate a book. agelemio castration; emasculation.e. to be different from those guilty. agerasit a scar left after intentional cuts on the body; a small incision on the body; a tattoo; an engraving.
one of the Luo dialects, the others being Langi of Lira and Apac, Alur of Nebbi, and Ethur of Kotido

an English woman; an Anglican Christian woman. Igereesan ineras Agereesan: the English speak English. ageret to massage; to embrocate; to smoothen; to plane. egeresi ngesi akeju naingunyakina: she/he is massaging a dislocated foot. agerun to make bleed by incising; to tattoo; to cut tribal marks. agerun iburuo: to cut tribal marks. agerunet a cut, incision; an instrument used for tattooing or incising. agete a gazelle, Gazella granti. agetemem to have a distended belly. ageun1 the beginning; starting point; origin. ageun2 to start; to begin, originate. since; henceforth; from this point onwards. ageun lolo, mam bobo eong abuni orekon: from now on, I will not come to your home. to begin, start, originate. itungasinei apotu kogeutu ka Adam: all peoples originated from Adam. ageunet the beginning, the origin, cradle, cause. ijeni ijo ageunet naka itungasinei?: do you know the origin of man? agideudeu music.agietakin to catch (an animal) in a trap; to set a trap; to ensnare, to take away a prop. abu atukot kogietak ejakait kosi, kosodete airengiar: the council found our chief on the wrong and dismissed him. to go off by itself, as of a gun or a trap. abu emuudu kogietakin bon: the gun went off by itself. agietun to remove a prop, support; to pull away; to strike a match. karai kigietu ijo epir, ibiror etogo: if you take that support away, the house will fall. agigit a peg; a dowel; a tenterhook; a hanger. agiilo a borehole pump (named after a pioneer driller in Teso in the 1940s, S. Gill). agilaasi a glass thing in general; a glass pane or louvre. agilo the gap left after two incisor teeth have been intentionally removed from the lower jaw (as a fashion gimmick). agion (in the Catholic faith) a saint; a holy person; a perfect person.aitagior: to make holy, perfect, or saintly. agipakin akongu to keep looking at; to follow with the eyes so as not to lose sight of; to inspect closely, keep an eye on. loeswaman isaawan egipakit nginisuat akongu: a watch-maker inspects every part of the watch closely. kogipakite ikokuka akongu: keep an eye on my child. agipar to see someone or something from afar quickly, but not clearly; to catch sight of; to catch a glimpse of; to espy. kagiparit nan eong ijo ibuni: I espied you coming from afar. agipun to recognise from nearby; to spot or find a thing lost. agipunit eong ekapiiso: I found my needle. agiraar to wash, rub, rake away, clean up. kogiraasi erit koleleasi akipi: take away the mud so that the water may run off. agirait the natural lines or folds round a young person’s neck (often admired as signs of beauty in women); an armlet, bangle, wristlet, bracelet. agiria1 (of skin or wound) to peel off. agiria2 to take (vegetables served, rubbish with a rake) in great quantities; to take plenty; to stampede (of dancers or animals); to make thundering noise. agiriata idwe edia: children have taken vegetables in handfuls, big helpings. egiriaete kesi isirigin luipu: they get big pay cheques. agiria akeje: to make a thundering sound with feet, putting them down simultaneously in dancing; to stampede. agiriaar to rush away; to start off quickly; to make off. abu eong kaany engatuny kasodi agiriaar: I saw a lion and I ran away. agiriaar amuny kakuwan: (of skin by sun, chemicals, hot water, or fire) to be bleached or peeled off.agiriakin1 to gather (as of rubbish for burning); to rake together, scrape together (as of money, etc). kogirianakisi atunyeny kere akim: gather all that rubbish and burn it. to run to safety. agiriakin ikoku totoke: the child has run to its mother (for safety). agiriakin2 to run for one’s life; to rush after; to run after (as after a thief or animal after prey).agirianakin to rake up (as of rubbish for burning); to gather up; to mark out (as a day’s work or task). to collapse. kolot kogirianak agasia akim: go and gather up rubbish into fire. kigirianakinai eong ipelun: mark out my daily tasks; give me my job description. agiriaun1 influx; invasion; incursion; flowing down. agiriaun2 to be plentiful, abundant; to come in a crowd; to crowd together. agiriaunos itunga togo: people have rushed into the house. to bring many a crowd together; to catch many (as of fish); to gather a big crop of cotton; to harvest together. abu Acipa kogiriau agaria: Acipa caught a lot of fish. kagiriautu akimai: let us harvest all the millet together. agiriaun3 to start with a rush; to run, rush this way; to startle (as from sleep); to abound.agiriis (singular noun F) grease (thick lubricating oil for machinery). abu emakanika kisutak agiriis opiororo loegaalika: the mechanic put grease in the flywheel of my bicycle. agirikaca (singular noun F) horticulture; agriculture. agiris to chafe, abrade; to rub off; to bruise; to graze. egirisi amoru na akanika: this stone bruises my hand. agirisionor to graze, bruise, chafe. egirisionoro akouka: my head is bruised. agirisior to rub off; to erode; to bruise. akipi nuk’edou egirisionorete alup: the rain water erodes the soil.agirisioret a bruise, erosion, corrosion, attrition. agiro to roar; to thunder; rumble. egiro lolo edou noi: it is thundering violently today.agirokin1 (of rain, etc) to thunder; to threaten; (of a lion) to roar. agiroki edou: the rain is threatening, it is thundering. agiroki engatuny: the lion roars. agirokin2 (of a person) to refuse; to be difficult, abnegate, resist; to shout at; to be hard; (of disease, injury) to be painful to; to deny. abu eong kalot neejai ejakait, konye kagirok eong noi: I went to the chief but he was hard on me i.e. he shouted at me. to fall out with each other; to become enemies. agirokinos aberu k’okilenike: the wife has fallen out with her husband. agiron1 a girl who refuses to marry or who refuses her husband.agirun2 to thunder once; (of rain) to threaten. abu edou kogiru bian kokide: the rain thundered yesterday in the east (the rains are near). agisa to eat very much; to gormandise; to kill big animals or men (especially big or great men). abu esilim kogisa Iteso: AIDS killed important Iteso. agisaar to kill a big animal or man. agisaa bian Ojiirot etom: Ojiirot killed an elephant yesterday. agisakin to kill something big for somebody. kagisakit eong atwanare onaceka: death has taken away my big brother. kagisakit eong eloket ibaren: the Karimojong cattle rustler has plundered my livestock. agisakin akiru kwap: it rained very heavily. agisaun to bring big game home; to gather many or much (as of cotton, money or anything) to come in great quantities; to amount. agisaun edou: the rain came down in great torrents. agita a guitar (a musical instrument with six strings). agitakin1 to choke while somewhere. ai bo kigitakini ijo acokit?: from where did the potato choke you? agitakin2 to separate for, keep apart or back for. alosi eong agitakin ijo akonikituk: I shall keep your cows apart. agitakina to be in contrast, different, dissimilar. agitanar to sort out; to put separate; to divide in groups; to assort. kogitana igoen ilosi: sort out clothes as you wash.agitar to allocate; to put aside; to separate, detach, isolate. kogitasi itunga luedekas awai: isolate patients. to separate oneself; to go aside; to be different, not to be the same. egitara ibaren ngul, mam eraas luka: these cows are not mine, they are different. agitarit to have (something) separate, assorted; to have something one’s own. egitarit ngesi eketogo kwana: she/he has her/his own house nowadays. agitigit to classify, categorize, order, organise, catalogue, sort, or grade. agitun to put apart; to sever; to separate; to keep back for oneself. agitunit eong acok auni: I kept away three potatoes for myself. agius (in the Roman Catholic church) holiness; sanctity; sainthood; perfection. agogomit (singular noun F) a place which is practically treeless and has plenty of short grass; the savannah. agogong1 strength, power, force, might, potency, muscle, vigour; energy, life, oomph, vivacity, enthusiasm, liveliness; hardiness, power of endurance, resoluteness, toughness, stamina, durability, robustness; firmness, determination, steadfastness, resolve, decisiveness, control; backbone, moral fibre; severity, brutality, sternness, ruthlessness, strictness. emamei ngesi agogong: she/he has no strength or moral fibre. egogong baa-ba: it is very hard, difficult, etc agogong2 to be strong, energetic, etc. kogogong yesi da kotoma aswamukus: be hardworking in your jobs. agogongikin to be hard or difficult for. kagogongikit eong aswam ngin: that work is difficult for me. agogongor to become strong; to become hardened; to become energetic, difficult, strict, etc. agogongor lokadekan: the sick man has become strong. agogor to tire out; to wear out; to tax strength. kegogor eong aswam na: this work has tired me out.agogoriar to tire out; to wear out; tax strength. kegogoriasi eong aswamusinei ngun: those jobs have tired me out.agogorikin to tire out; to be tired for, on account of; to be awkward for. kigogorikitai ijo aidak epir ngol: they have given you to carry that heavy pole. agogwa (singular noun F) sexual intercourse (of people, not of animals) agol1 a urinary bladder; the pubic region; the lower abdomen. agol2 (singular noun F) uterus; womb.kirupak akan agola naka esaati: put your hand in the shirt pocket (and give me something). agoliam (of tall people) to walk. ai bo lolo igoliamete yesi?: where are you tall people going today? agolit a log for closing the gate of kraal. agolitomei (singular noun F) the north, i.e. the direction on one’s left when one faces the rising sun.agologolot a metallic bottle top; a species of fish, Synodontis victoriae. agolokin to stop; to shut up in; to lock in; to imprison; to block; to prevent from; to keep indoors (as of rain or other obstacle). abu ejakait kogolok nges: the chief put him in prison. kagoloki eong edou ne: the rain has stopped me from leaving here. to slam (the door). agolokin ekek: the door has slammed itself. agolokinos akiro: the case is finished (closed). agolokin ekaporoto: my throat is blocked. agolol to shut oneself up; to be in trouble, difficulties; to be prevented by. agoloro eong togo kanuka akurian: I have shut myself up in the house for fear. agoloritos eong aswamusinei ore: I am kept at home by all sorts of work. agolor to corner, prevent escape; to ambush, catch, shut out. kagolori eong ijo acepaarit: I will catch or ambush you one day. agolor aibobon: to be constipated.agolot a hollow in tree; a beehive; a confessional box (in a court of law or Roman Catholic church). agolun to shut, cut off; to put inside brackets, shut out or in; to prevent progress. agolu nges ekalitiini lailo: the quarantine has prevented him from leaving here. to be included, cut off this way (as of men or animals by water, etc). agongaar to lean against; (of sun or moon) to go down. agongaa akolong too: the sun has gone down (is leaning against the Western wall). to side together. agongakin1 to lean on, upon; to depend on. agongakinos akwapin too: countries are leaning on western capitalism. agongakin2 to lean something against, upon. kogongak egaali arwatat: lean your bicycle against the wall. agonganar to lean on one another; to understand one another; to rely on one another, help one another. kogonganaros bonik kotoma aswamukus: help one another in your work. agongot a species of fish; a bracelet; roots of weeds, or a kind of tree whose sticks make good building material. agongun to mark or stain oneself or one’s clothes leaning against something. ai bo kigongunia ijo etulia ngol?: where did you lean on to get that soot (on your back)? to fall back on to lean towards or against. agongunos akiro ngun newok: that case is turning (or leaning) against us. agoolu a millipede. agor angle; corner; bay. agoreik an angle; corner; a bay. agoromoit plaited grass for a belt (for tying firewood). agoror to take away with finger (from narrow container); to gouge out; to scoop out. kogoro ijo da akinyet koyanga: you also take a little butter with finger. agorun1 to scoop out, dig out. agorun2 to tire out; to make tired; (of women and animals) to be near bringing forth. kagorunit eong aswam na: this work has tired me out. agoru aberuka, ekoto aidoun: my wife is in advanced pregnancy and wants to give birth. agorunun to keep scooping out, digging out (as of mucus from nose). agougou a chameleon. egelanakin agougou: a chameleon changes its colour. agoyaar (of man, house, etc) to lean over somebody or something. agoyaar to lean over; to incline. egoyaara ipopongo lu: these cactus trees are leaning over. egoyaara ikoku yen iponesio neerono: this child’s manners are inclined to bad ways. agoyi to lean; to push aside with arms or shoulder by leaning aside against. agoyiikin to lean forward, on, over. sirikigoyiikin ikoku: do not lean forward on the baby. agugu1 bran; grain chaff. agugu2 a homestead sparrow (a bird). agugut1 the contents of a calabash fruit; the sponge-like substance found inside the anthill. agugut2 chaff of grain. agule1 at the back of the house. agule2 an enclosure; a backyard; a corner; a peninsula; a bay, gulf. agulit a large navel; an umbilical tumour; hernia.agumakini eong emal togo lo kotwana lokecwean: I shoot an arrow into my burnt house so that the arsonist may die. to shoot one another with arrows. agumakinos idwe: the children shot each other with bow and arrow (at play). agumar to dash away; to shoot past; to flash by. agumar egaali: the bicycle darted past. to send an arrow flying; to shoot off, eject. koguma emal kuju: shoot the arrow up into the sky. agumitoi to keep dashing about. inyo bo ibunitor ijo igumitoi kwangin?: wby do you come dashing along like that? agungurut (formerly) a 5-cent coin. aguosos (of a person) fat around the waist. agurai a very poisonous yellowish snake. agureeda a road grader tractor; a farm tractor.agurumikin ki-a to make round, barrel-like (as of pot or granary). kigurumik edula akoik: make the granary nicely round. agurumum to be fat-bellied. aguti umbilical hernia; a swollen navel.agutiaanar to have umbilical hernia. agutianut to have umbilical hernia; to have a big navel or a long umbilicus. aguuru a large, ugly kind of praying mantis.aguurut a brook; stream.aguurut a deep river; channel; waterfall; valley; ravine; turbulent current; cascade. aguurut a torrent or a waterfall; a dangerous stream. aguwom (of a fat man) to walk heavily; to waddle. agwaam ki-a to make rough; to roughen. apotu ikukwa kigwaamata akakuwan: the thorns made my skin rough. agwaamam to be rough-skinned; to be covered with dirt, rough. igwaamam ijo: you are rough-skinned. agwaamikin to beat with something very rough; to cut skin (like the scourging of Jesus Christ; to slander; to calumniate. kinyekinai agwaamikin eong numam enerit: do not slander me for what I did not say. agwaamu (of surface) roughness.agwaanya a bathing shelter; a urinal. agwaikin to get another into trouble. agwaiki ikoku papake akiro: the child has got its father in trouble. agwanga a woman prophet; a prophetess. agwaragwar to scratch often; to tear with claws. kagwaragwar eong ikapa: the cat has scratched. agwaramam (of skin) to be scaly, rough.agwarar to scratch slightly. agwara etoori ikoku ademar akekiring: the eagle scratched that child slightly in the process of snatching away meat. to give a sign by a scratch or pull; to take a person aside. agwararos kwi awai: they gave each other a sign to go aside. agware a species of bird; a laughing dove.agwaun akirot to commit a fault; to rouse to anger; to incite, excite, carp, calumniate; to attack. agwau lolo ejakait da akiro: the chief has also committed a crime this time, i.e. has also got in trouble. agwautu idwe ao: the children have roused the bees (into anger i.e. they have disturbed them). agwaunet calumny; aggression; attack; belligerence. agwaunun to keep slandering, provoking, calumniating, challenging. agweeret1 a broom made of twigs; a twig used as firewood; a cane for beating. agweeret2 a bush used for making brooms; small twigs of firewood. agwei a new crop of millet. aikony agwei: to taste first millet meal. koom emuron kobu aitokony itunga agwei: call the heathen priest to bless the first millet meal.(The heathen ceremony is as follows: the priest - emuron - takes the first morsel, after which the others do the same (take a morsel); the ladle with which the meal was stirred is placed above the doorway, for the children take the new meal next morning. Before the priest and the people partake of the food, he makes the sign of the cross on himself, smearing first himself and the people with the food and then throwing it in lumps to the four winds – north, east, south, and west). agweikin to coil for; to mould for, do pottery for, etc. kogweikinai amot: mould me a pot. agwel to buy; to purchase. kogwel egoe kaloto: buy the dress and let us go. agwelakin to buy for, at, in. ai bo kigwelakini ijo egoe lo?: from where did you buy this dress? agwelanar to trade; to barter. agwelanaran a merchant; a seller; a vendor; a trader; a dealer; a broker; a perpetual traitor; a serial betrayer. agwelanaret a marketplace; a bazaar; an auction.agwelar to sell; to betray. kogwelasi egaali ngol: sell that bicycle. agwelegwel to keep bribing or corrupting; to buy often. agwelun to buy for oneself; to redeem. igwelunit ijo nyo?: what did you buy? what favours are you trying to buy? agwetakin to fall or drop or go by removing support suddenly; (of match) to strike, to light; to dismiss, or to depose; to pull the trigger (of gun), to fire. sirikigwetak ekaicolong: do not remove my chair and let me fall. to fall; to be dismissed, deposed (of chiefs and the like); to go off (of a trap, trigger of gun, etc). agwetun to fall or drop or come down when the support is suddenly removed; (of match) to strike, to light. agwolom (of a hungry giant) to move about awkwardly (with an empty belly swaying). agwolomaar (of a hungry giant) to go away awkwardly (with an empty belly swaying). agwolomom (of a giant) to be haggard and hungry. agwolomun (of a hungry giant) to come awkwardly (with an empty belly swaying). agwotakin (Serere) to trouble people by immigration. inyo bo kigwotakiniata yesi iso?: why do you trouble us by your immigration?agwotasi itunga luipu okekwa je: many people have emigrated to the other side of the swamp.agwotun (Serere) to immigrate; to come near. kogwotutu lailo: migrate this way.agyel (Serere) to bribe; to buy; to favour. igyelit ijo ejakait ngesi ketelekaritor eong emusaago: you bribed the chief and that is why I lost the case. kingara ijo eong ido kogyelite je: you dislike me alone and favour him.ailip: to pray (ki); aiduk: to build (ko). ai? (interrogation) where? aiar to kill, murder, or abolish. kaar eong akure: I am thirsty. aarakin bon: to kill oneself; to commit suicide. aiar aswam: to dismiss from work. aiar etengei: to alleviate hunger. aiar akure: to quench thirst. aiar ekisil: to abrogate, abolish a law. aiar ajakaanut: to oust from power; to depose from chieftainship.aiba1 to get moist, wet. aiba2 (of night or new day) to become light. ebai akwap: it is dawn; it is very early. kolot ebai kide: go at dawn; go very early in the morning. abu ngesi kolot osapaali nepe ebai kide: she/he set off for a trip very early in the morning. aiba3 to hit; to tap with stick; to crack. aba ngesi akouka: she/he has conked my head. aibaaj ki-a to owe; to borrow money. kebaajiki eong aingadis isirigin imilionin ikany bon: the bank has lent me five million shillings only. aibaajikin ki-a to lend or let somebody borrow money. aibaajun ki-a to borrow or have a money loan. aibabakin1 ki-a to go begging for something. adol bodo ikerai luko Katakwi aibabakin: the internally displaced people of Katakwi are nearly begging for alms. aibabakin2 ki-a to give a little to a beggar. Isusan, kolot aibabakin emuduk isirigin akwatat: Susan, go and give the blind man a hundred shillings. aibabatoi ki-a to be destitute; to go about begging; to be in need; to be poor. ibabatoi ngesi ailipitoi inyamat: she/he goes about begging for food.aibaiba ki-a to pound something which is hard.aibak to slit, cut open an abscess with a scalpel or anything sharp. aibak abus: to open an abscess. aibakar ki-a (of many people together) to walk abreast.aibakibak ki-a to argue ineffectively; to talk nonsense in dispute; to crack (of potato heaps – a sign that big tubers are underneath). ibakibaki ijo tai: you talk nonsense; you are panicking for nothing, yet! ibakibakit acokit alup: the potato has cracked the soil. aibaliig ki-a to cheat a person out of his belongings; to defraud, swindle, con, dupe, or trick. aibam1 ki-a aibam aokot: (of a woman) to menstruate. aibam naman enangi: menorrhoea; continuous menstruation.aibam2 ki-a to plaster; to level off; to ram down (as of floor); to press into a lump (as of bread or atap). erai Okwi lokebaman itogoi: Okwi’s profession is plastering house floors. ebamakin ekume: the nostrils are blocked (unable to smell).aibames menstruation. aibamibam ki-a to beat earth repeatedly; to ram a grave or house repeatedly; to stamp down persistently. ejaas idwe aibamibam akwap eboliasi: children are stamping the ground as they play.kibana ber ijo igoen luinomitai: you first fold clothes that have been ironed. aibang ki-a to eat food with no vegetables or relishes. ibangi ngesi atap: she/he eats atap (millet or sorghum bread) without vegetables. aibany ki-a to press down (as of earth into a hole, etc); to trample down. mam akoto yes aibany amanaka: I do not want you to trample down my garden. (of tree, man or animal) to be short and stout. ibanyit etelepat ngol: that boy is short and stout. aibany kakeju ki-a to go far on foot. ilosi ijo k’egaali arai ibanyi k’akeju?: are you going by bicycle or on foot? aibanyakin kwap ki-a (reflective verb) to flop down; to be too weak to stand (only used for children learning to walk, or drunken/weak person). ebanyakin ikoku kwap: the child has flopped down (while trying to walk) to throw or press down. abu eong kebanyak nges kwap kiuta: I threw him down on his buttocks while wrestling. aibap ki-a to slap on the cheeks or ears; to smack; to strike at an angle. aibapakin akanin: to acclaim, welcome, applaud (by clapping hands). aibapar alup: to throw the gauntlet; to take up a challenge to a fight. aibapabap ki-a to slap cheeks or ears repeatedly; to clap hands.aibapasit a slap on the ear; a clap. aibar to become rich, wealthy, well to do (only used in infinitive). abarar, abaranar: (of cows, goats, chicken, etc) to become many; to become wealthy, well to do.aibat ki-a (of a person) to walk barefooted; to pad; to go on foot. aibat k’akeje: to move barefooted (without shoes); to foot (not to use a transport vehicle). aibatis ki-a to baptise. aibatis esirikaalet kede akim (ayangaar nges ojie): to baptise a soldier with fire (take him to the frontline). aibe1 (singular noun F) a gambling game with cashew nuts, a hole in the ground, more than one player contributing cashew nuts and apiku (a stone for hitting a nut outside the hole as chosen by the opponent – hitting that nut alone means you win all the nuts; hitting more than one means you fail and the chance goes to the opponent; nuts entering the hole belong to the person who threw them in; apiku entering the hole having nuts means that player will lose those nuts i.e. the nuts continue in play). aibe2 ki-a to crack a hard nut; to crack stones. aibe3 to be true.aibe4 to go to; to lead to. abeata kesi ai?: where have they gone? what has become of them? ebeit aswam: abaout to; just going to do something. aibebe ki-a to crack nuts or stones. aibebeloor ki-o to push, return earth into hole or grave; to fill up again; to turn (anything) upside down by pushing. aibebeun akiro ki-a to elicit information; to investigate. aibecokin abeit ki-o to say exactly what is meant; to do exactly what is wanted; to fit; to mimic or imitate exactly. aibeeleanut viciousness; quarrelsomeness; mischief. aibega ki-a to spy; to pry; to inquire secretly; to detect. aibeibe ki-a to crack a hard thing gently. aibeibe imaidoko: to crack cashew nuts. to beat rocks into small pieces. aibeibe amor komoru Abela: to crack rocks at Abela Rock quarry (in Katakwi town). aibek to hatch eggs; to remove a scab from a wound. aibekibek ki-a to gnaw at (figurative); to try to find out; to try to do or know what is above you or beyond you, what you do not know.aibel1 ki-a to crave for, hanker after; to desire ardently for food in general, especially for meat. aibel2 ki-a to cut up or split firewood. aibel3 ki-a to glean or dig up potatoes, cassava or anything from the ground. aibel4 to bash or crack the head with a stick; to break into small pieces. aibele ki-o to turn or change from side to side. kolot aibele acok kakim: go and turn potatoes in the fire. aibelear ki-a to tell a secret about someone; to expose somebody wrongdoing; to give someone away. aibeleikin akonye ki-o to look sternly at someone; to look daggers. inyo bo kibeleikinitor ijo eong akonye?: why do you look daggers at me? aibeleonor ki-o to turn about (as in sleeplessness); to keep turning round. aibeleor ki-o to turn; to translate languages (like Apuda has done here). aibeleun ki-o to turn something round or inside out (as of shirt); to turn back; to turn this way; to look or turn round; look behind; look this way. kibeleutu akituk lailo: turn cows this way. kibeleunos lailo (plural): turn this way. aibelianar ki-a to become greedy; to be greedy. aibelibel ki-o to roll about. ibelibelos idwe kotoma asinge: the children roll about in the sand. aibelibelo ki-o to roll oneself about; to keep rolling in bed from side to side. ibelibelos idegei luejie kokwamin: the jetfighter planes roll in the skies. aibeliikin ki-a to hanker after; to hunger after (meat). aibelokin1 ki-o to turn away; (of knee, ankle) to be twisted, sprained. ebelokin eong akung: my knee is sprained. aibelokin2 ki-o to turn something about; to turn upside down; to interpret; to translate. kibelok emukule ngol: turn that hide upside down. aibemakin ki-a to throw down on or somewhere to fall down on something. aibeniben ki-a to make thin; to slice thin. ebenen einer, konye aswam…: talking is easy, but working…. aibeny to start a quarrel or a dispute. aiber to be first; to come first. ikoto ijo aiber kotoma aingito: you like to be the first in the class examination. aiberuikin ki-a to be like a woman in actions; to be woman-like; (of a man) to be effeminate. iberuikit ekesa ngol: that guy is very effeminate.(an insult) aibesenen ki-a to be splitting often (as of wood, etc). aibeset an implement for splitting (such as a hatchet, an axe, a panga, etc).aibet ki-a to cut up; to split, saw, chop, chip. ibesi ngesi akito: she/he is splitting fire-wood. aibet akituk: to be ready to cry; to sulk. aisibet: to make to split, chop, saw, chip.aibetenen ki-a to be splitting often (as of wood, etc). aibetun akituk ki-a to screw up one’s face; to be at the point of crying; to sulk. aibi to pass out wind; to gas; to fart. aibic1 (singular noun F) a traditional Teso game for boys involving nuts being thrown into a small hole drilled on the ground at a distance of about four metres and a flat round stone called apiku used to aim at nuts that do not enter the hole. aibic2 ki-a to hit cashewnuts in a game of aibic. aibic imaidoko: to play the game of hitting cashewnuts.aibida ki-a to angle; to catch fish with a hook, i.e. with eibidas or eibidaet. aibielibiel ki-o to boil up; to effervesce; to bubble up. aibielonokin to turn back quickly and re-appear. ibielonokin aberu kotogo: the woman is busy in the house, i.e. going in and out. aibielor ki-o (of a woman from collecting water or a trip) to turn back quickly aibiikin ki-a to place (something somewhere).aibiiny ki-a to feel or to be unwell (not used often). aibiinyanakin ki-a to be often unwell. aibiinyikin ki-a to be or feel weak or unwell. aibil1 to break; to fold; (of anything) to transgress; to crease. aibil asuat: (of a husband and wife) to solemnise a marriage by breaking a piece of iron and each keeping their piece as a sign of faithfulness. abilakin abotet: to betray. abilakin akeje: (when sitting) to double up legs. abilakin ekia akeje: to put poison in foot prints. aibil ekisil: to break the law. aibil akeju: to fracture or break the leg. aibil akoit: a traditional Iteso/Karimojong ceremony of breaking the bone, to signify the end of animosities between the two peoples and the start of sharing (the thigh bone of an animal should be broken in half).aibil2 to make a list of; (of the bride’s relatives during marriage) to state the number of cows and goats to be paid as dowry; to count by heads or tickets. aibil akwes: to count heads. aibiler ki-o to be mad, delirious, mentally deficient. aibilerikin ki-a to become mad, delirious, mentally deficient. aibilerikinet (singular noun F) hysteria; hysterics; frenzy; madness; rage; fury. aibilinyaar ki-a to push back (the foreskin or prepuce); to plaster the wall with mud. aibina ki-a to gyrate the waist (like one dancing a kiganda dance). aibina kadodi: to dance to a kigisu circumcision dance. aibir ki-o to throw at; to hit; to pelt. aibiribir k’amor ki-o to throw stones at; to pelt. ekoto Angopu aibir Idengot k’ebela: Angopu wants to throw a stick at Idengot. aibirokin1 ki-a to throw at one another; to fall; to fall upon. abu Igella kibirokin kwap: Igella fell down. aibirokin2 ki-a to throw down. abu Ogweere kibirok Icumar kwap: Ogweere threw Icumar down. aimwany to break something (soft and powdery) into two. aimwany emuogo: to break a cassava tuber into two pieces. amwany to break suddenly. amwanyi etelepat akeju komopiira: the boy's leg has been broken in a football game. mwany broken completely aibironor ki-o to keep falling; to fall repeatedly. aibiror1 (singular noun F) a fall; a slip, fault, sin, transgression; failure. aibiror2 ki-o to fall; to fail; to commit a fault; to sin; to blunder. ebiror Odeke kotoma aingito: Odeke failed in his school exams. ebiror ikoku erono noi: the child has fallen badly. aibiror3 ki-o to throw away (anything). aibirun ki-o to lose a case; to fall forward, down this way. aibisaalikit (of body colour) jaundiced; yellowish. aibit1 ki-a to pluck leaves (of vegetables); to fish. aibit2 to come in or go out; (of ants or birds) to fly out; to swarm. ebisete ikong: the ants are swarming. aibit3 to leak or drip. ebisi ekume: the nose drips.aibitionor ki-o to become greedy, stingy, miserly. aibitionut (singular noun F) stinginess; longing; craving; greed, avarice; egoism. aibiun ki-a to notice, observe, spy out. aibobon ki-a to pass stool; to defecate; to empty one’s bowels; discharge the bowels.aibobonet the anus; the descending colon.aibogoikin ki-o (of milk) to curdle. ebogoikis akile: the milk has curdled. aiboi ki-o to sit, dwell, camp; to delay, wait, rest, dally; to be seated; to live in: aiboyenen: to dwell. itunganan iboyie k’inyamat: man lives on food. mam ijeni ebe inyamat iboyio itunganan?: don’t you know that man lives on food? edumunit ngesi agogong nakibois: (of a patient) she/he has got the strength to sit up. aiboibo ki-o to munch, gnaw, eat raw especially potatoes, cassava or raw mango fruit, sounding like bobo. aiboibo ikel: to gnash or grind one’s teeth. aiboikin ki-o to sit down on. kiboikin oicolong: sit on the chair. kiboikin kwap: sit down (on the ground). ai bo lolo iboitor ijo?: where did you stay (delay) this time? alosi aiboyior Serere: I am going to settle down in Serere.aibois an abode, a place, or a thing to sit on or settle in. abois naibecokino: the right place. aiboisio kere: everywhere; in every place. aiboisit dwelling place; address; home; resting place; abode; a chair. aiboisika: in my place; instead of me. ai bo iboyoo ijo?: what is your address? aijul neiboyoo: to change address. aibok1 to dig a hole for planting or for a grave; to cultivate. aibok acok: to heap potato mounds; (slang during the 1987 Teso insurgency) to dig one’s own grave before being killed. aibok ibilenga: to dig for mudfish. aibok2 to tempt; to ask in order to trap; to find out, or to spy. aibokiboka ki-a (of body or anything) to tremble. aiboko ki-o to catch flying ants and eat them; to light up with a torch. ebokoi eong ikong: I am catching and eating white ants. ibokoete kesi ikong: they light up torches to catch white ants. aibol to compete with; to race; to contest. aiboleikin ki-o to promise; to make a contract; to come to terms; to agree to.aibolony ki-a to circumcise.aibong to return, go back, or to retire; to reflect. aibongibong ki-a to make (cord or pot) too thick; to make thick (what should be thin); to wear a thick cord. inyo bo ibongibongia jo auno ngin?: why do you make that string so thick (too thick)? aiboonokin ki-o (of many) to sit. kiboonokinos ne: sit here (plural). aibos to rot, stink, putrefy, fester; to disintegrate. aibos tulutul: to become thoroughly rotten. aiboyior ki-o to stay away; to settle down somewhere. aibu1 ki-o to hammer; to knock (feet) against. aibu2 to swell, ferment. aibu3 to force; to coerce, compel; to slander. aibubu ki-o to hit; to knock, hammer. kibubu isumaalin okek: nail the door. aibubuakin ki-a to urge one on.aiburuburakin: to urge away. aibubukin ki-o to peg out., crucify; to hammer on or down; to nail. aibubulatoi ki-o to bustle or make noise with utensils. aibubulaun ki-o to appear noisily and suddenly to search out noisily. aibubuor ki-o to hammer away (as nail into wood.) aibubwanakin ki-a to dragoon. aibubwes (an implement for hammering, such as a mallet, a tack hammer; a sledge hammer, etc).aibucar ki-a to slip off; to go against; to say or do things that are not what someone wants. abucar asaanit ter kwap: the plate slipped and dropped down (broken). aibucaret a mistake; an error. aibuce a touch; a feel; a stroke or pat. aibuk1 ki-a to churn swing, rock, push to and fro; to shake, convulse. akile nuibukuk: churned milk. to waggle. aibuk2 to pour; to empty; to make water. aibukakin ki-a to churn for; (of heart) to palpitate. ibuka etauka: my heart palpitates. aibukaret a riddle or brainteaser; a puzzle, a poser; a cross-word puzzle; a conundrum. aibukubuk ki-a to heave, buffet, rock, swell (of waves), to shake much. aibul1 ki-a to take a little (especially of a liquid) from each container of anything to avoid overflow. aibul2 to incise and let out entrails or contents; to crack raw eggs. kobul ikwenyit: disembowel the bird. aibul abus: to incise an abscess. kobulok abeei oikopo: crack the eggs into a cup. aibular ki-a to catch up the overflow. kibulak ekamule adere: catch up the overflow of the beer in the calabash. aibuleikin ki-a to add beer to beer; to pour in more beer (to same container). aibulon ki-a (of a boil or abscess) to become ripe; to suppurate; to form pus. aibulu a species of destructive termite; an anthill or fat termites from which queen ants come. (From aibulu come fat flying ants called ikwaresia, which pair with slender ones called ingerepo - that fly in the morning from a different anthill called angerep - the result of this is that new anthills are formed of one kind or another). aibulubulun ki-a to overflow or bubble up (as of a well); (of a liquid) to gush out; to ooze out. aibulubulunun ki-a (of a liquid) to keep gushing out, to flow out, continually. aibululuikin ki-a to look blue or azure. aibun to have in the hand; to close in; to stop; to block; to gag a person; to fold (hands). kobun ikonikumes: block your nostrils. kobun akituk: close your lips. aibunga ki-a to beat or thrash; to give blows. kebungaata kesi eong: they have beaten me. aibungatait a thrashing; a beating; a blow. adumu aberu ngin aibungata nuipu: that woman has got many beatings. aibunget a cluster, a mass (of anything); a swarm (of bees); a thousand. einene (singular noun M) a swarm of migrant bees temporarily resting in a tree like a ball. aibupokin ki-o to throw down with a thud. aibur to re-sow (after failure of first sowing); to cover a drum with a skin; to seal; to wrap; to encase; to envelop.aibur abalua: to close the envelope. aibura ki-a to claim as a debt; to demand, press for; to dun. aiburakin ki-a to be uneasy, impatient, fidgety, on tenterhooks, on pins and needles to do something; to be anxious to begin action; to be eager, or keen. keburakit eong alosit: I must be off. aiburakinet anxiety; a worry; nervousness; fretfulness. aiburakinit to be anxious; to be impatient. aiburubur ki-a to be quick (in going or doing). kiburubur alosit: go quickly. aiburuburakin ki-a to urge away; to urge on. aiburuburar ki-a to urge away. aiburukuny ki-a (of mushrooms, flowers, leaves before opening out) to bud. aiburukunyun ki-a (of mushrooms or girls’ breasts starting out) to swell. aiburun ikisin ki-a (of a girl) to develop breasts at puberty. eburu ipese ikisin: the little girl has developed breasts. aiburututun ki-o to draw out water or ajon with a narrow-mouthed vessel, causing a low imitative sound. aibus1 ki-a (of weather) to be hot; to be warm. ibus lolo akwap: it is hot or warm today. ebusuu etogo lo: this room is neat and trim; this room is hot. . aibus2 ki-a to be fitting, apt; to suit, behove, befit; to be proper to, be fair to, convenient. aibusakin: to be fitting, befit, suitable to, expedient, proper, sufficient, becoming, or behove. aibus3 ki-o to throw down (object). aibusakinit to deserve; to be necessary, apt, pertinent, appropriate, suitable, or proper. aibuse (singular noun F) warmth; sweat; heat; perspiration.aibuses (singular noun F) glory; honour; esteem; fame. ainakin aibuses: to honour; to give honour to be honourable; to be glorious. ikoto jo aibuses: you want fame. aibusian ki-a to grub along, look for food. aibusibusitoi ki-o to gurgle. aibusokin ki-o to throw down (with a thud). ikoto kebusok kwap?: do you want me to throw you down? (in wrestling) to fall down. aibusor ki-o to throw down heavily; to slam. to fall down with a thud. aibusubusakin to become hot for someone. aibusun: to throw down with a thud to fall down heavily. aibusuun ki-a to look tidy, neat, trim, fitting. ebusuu eigoo lolo: the town looks neat and trim today.aibut1 ki-o to pull apart a limb or twig; to congest plants in sowing; to represent, take the place of. aibut2 (of a snake, chameleon, etc) to shed skin; to moult; to peel, to be blistered; to live long or forever; to be eternal. ebusi Lokasuban: God lives eternally. kobut kakwap: live long on earth. aibutokin ki-a to plunge oneself into (anything); to be stuck in mud. ebutokin itaok toma orit: the calf is immovably stuck in the mud. ebutokin ejakait toma omusaago: the chief is involved in a very serious case. aibutor ki-o disrupt, pull apart. aibutung ki-a to sprout; to form buds. aibutunget the shoot; the sprout; the bud (unopened). aibuubuar ki-a to urge on. aibuwanakin ki-a to collect and move things about; to shuffle; to pack. ingai ibuwanakin kotogo kalo?: who is shuffling in this house? inyo bo ibuwanakina ijo ikaboro kwangin?: why do you move my things about like that? aibuyakin ki-a to give many things not counted. aibwa1 ki-a to hide; to keep away, put aside; to abscond. aibwa ikinyom: to hide choice seeds (grain) completely. aibwa2 to fence in; to surround with a fence or hedge. aibwaadeikin ki-a to become a prostitute. aibwaanar ki-a to shout, scoff at, ridicule, or to jeer at. ibwaanario ngesi: she/he is an object of jeers and scoffs. aibwaar ki-a to send away with a curse. aibwabwaat ki-a to keep hiding things from public view; to keep concealing. aibwaciikin ki-a to become sterile; to be impotent. aibwaikin ki-a to lay down, place, put down. aibwaikin etau: to heed; to put one’s mind to; to take to heart. aibwaikin akanin kau: to put hands behind the back. aibwaikin akan: to sign a letter or any document. aibwait ki-a to be keeping concealed or in hiding; to hide. ibwait ijo ibore: you are hiding something. aibwakanar ki-a to swing, to vary (as of incense); to miss a thing one wants; to fan, wave a fan; to hit, catch, slap (as of hawk trying to catch a chick); to fail to catch, etc. abwaka etoori imiyot: the eagle missed the chick. akoto eong aibap ngesi konye kabwaka aibwakar: I wanted to hit her/him but I missed. ebwakanari esaseredooti elutaari: the priest incenses the altar. aibwakibwak ki-a to wave (with hand or anything); to flutter (with wings). aibwakibwak abebenoka: (of birds) to move wings up and down (sitting or standing); to flap wings. aibwakibwaket a fan (for blowing air about). aibwal1 ki-a to threaten rain. ebwal edou: ibwalete idowon: rain clouds are threatening to rain. ibwalete idowon karai ekotos aitep: the clouds put on ornaments if they want to bring rain. aibwal2 ki-a to wear feathers in hair or put on ornaments for feast; to adorn the head. ibwalete itunga elosete okosio: people ornament themselves as they go for dancing. aibwalukukun ki-a to hang over (as of hair over eyes); (of grass over path, branches of tree over road) hanging over. aibwalukun ki-a (of feathers) falling over eyes; (of branches of a tree) hanging over a path. aibwamaar ki-a to spear to death; to cause to drop senseless. aibwan ki-a to look after a bride in her new home. aibwanakin ki-a to fill a store; to put something in constantly, continuously. aibwanen ki-o to ride on horseback (or on any animal); to mount; to ride on cow. aibwang (of pottery) to break; (of anthill) to produce mushrooms.aibwangibwang imolokonyo luakiteng: to singe the hairs on the cow’s hooves (when preparing them for cooking). aibwany ki-a to gate-crash, intrude; to be a parasite. aibwany ajon: to gatecrash a beer party (of an uninvited person). aibwanyun ki-a to get by gate-crashing. aibwap ki-a to follow up; to trace; to track; to follow trail. aibwapakin: (of a boy after girl, a hunter after an animal, etc) to go after or follow somebody. aibwapar ki-a to track down (especially of girl going after boy.) aibwapit ki-a to keep going after; to seek, look for. aibwaret a shout; a holler; a bawl. apupi eong aibwaret: I hear a shout. aibwaribwar ki-a to walk fast. aibwat to sprinkle; to retreat and stand aloof; to see, look at from afar; to espy. abwasit: to keep at bay; to eschew. aibwel ki-o to bubble up. aibwelibwel ki-o to boil over or bubble over (of water or beer).aibwikin ki-o to hammer in or push in by force.aibwo to stand, stop, halt, stand up. aibwok ki-a to carry on the head; to transport. aibwoket a bier; the head (as a place for carrying). aibwokokin1 ki-a to throw oneself on; to attack in a rush.aibwokokin2 ki-a to carry for somebody. aibwokor ki-a to carry away. aisibwok, aibwolol ki-o to cry out; to wail; to moan; to squeal. aibwon ki-a (of new wife) to share everything with a co-wife. aibwong ki-a to exult, acclaim; to show outwardly the joy of having won the war or gained victory.aibwony ki-a to rip off a twig; to pull by jerks; to tug at a tree branch; to pull a rope as in tug-of-war; to strain, tweak. aibwony ajon: to suck beer ravenously. aibwonyar ki-a to pull or tear open (of a box that has been nailed); to disrupt; to pull away from speaker. aibwonyun ki-a to pull (towards speaker); to uproot. aibwor1 ki-o (of girl) to refuse to marry. ibworit apese ngin: ibworokit apese ngin ikiliok: that girl refused suitors.aibworar ki-a to be or to feel relieved (after illness); to give oneself a respite; to be free. alot ejakait ore aibworar: my husband went home to rest a little. aibworit ki-o to be fierce, raging, or cruel. ibworit ejakait: mister or the chief is in a rage. ibworitor ekingok akiring: the dog is fierce on account of the meat it stole. aibworo ki-o to bewail, weep, or cry over a stolen thing or a dead person. ibworoete kesi ikeceboro: they bewail, cry over their stolen belongings. aibworo or (often) aibworoenen: to bewail often; to weep for repeatedly. ibworos kesi ekecetunganan: they bewail their deceased male relative. aibworo aimony: to weep loudly; to cry out. aibworokin ki-o (of a man or an animal) to attack. aibworun ki-o (of smell) to become too strong; (of smell) to waft towards the speaker; (of dog) to come towards to attack. ebworunio lokapolon asaduku: the chief would not give the box; or, the stench of the big man in the coffin is too much (for the mourners). aibwos ki-a to pull, drag, heave; to jerk. aibwosit: to be pulling, hauling. aibwosar ki-a to drag out; to drag away; (of a crowd) to go somewhere; to pour off (a great quantity of liquid). ebwosaros akipi: the water has flowed (out of the pot or container). ebwosaros itunga toma okosio: many people have gone for the dance. ebwosaros ikong: the white ants have swarmed. aibwosun ki-a to pull or drag in; to drag towards oneself; to pour towards the speaker. aibwos ajon: to drink heavily (beer). aibwot ki-a to shake out (something thick out of a narrow vessel, like butter out of gourd, or sediment out of bottle); to throw out. kibwota atitot ngin: throw that salt ash sediment. aibwot to migrate; to move to another place; to change place of abode. aibwotun ki-a to take out (as yolk out of egg, butter out of gourd, as kernel out of fruit and cohesive matter in general). aibwotibwotun: to take out completely from. aica1 light; brightness; brilliance; transparency; lustre; clarity. Aica: a privately owned Ateso newspaper launched on June 7, 2003 (the proprietor was Hon. Grace Akello – the then state minister for Northern Uganda Reconstruction). aica naka akonye: the brightness of the eyes. aica2 ki-a to disapprove; to keep despising; to regard as wrong or useless; to criticise. icait ngesi aswamuka: she/he criticised my work. aica3 to give light to; to shine, be light; to be transparent; to be brilliant; to dazzle, be aglow. Nyakoi neecaa amoding: the north where the desert blisters. ecai akolong: the sun shines. aicaar ki-a to despise; to have a low opinion about; to animadvert; to blame. kecaasi eong itunga: people have developed a low opinion of me. acamun aicaario: to take the blame; to say that you are the person who did wrong.aicab to run quickly (with long, light strides). aicak1 ki-a to tread on; to trample down, press down; to to set foot, enter; to dare, attempt, try. aicak egaali: to ride a bicycle. aicak akimai: to trample down millet (in the granary, to compact it). mam bobo eong ecaki togokon: I will not set foot in your house again. mam eong ecaki alimun acekiro: I shall not try to say anything else. mam eong ecaki atwanare: I will not die. aicak emun ekori: to make a blunder; to get into trouble by being indiscrete (literally, to step on the snake’s tail). aicak2 to throw one after another. kocakata akito ngun kwap: throw those sticks down (one after another). aicakar ki-a to trample away; to tread on (like grass, etc when looking for something lost.) aicaket a foot-step; a sole of foot; a sole of boot; a shoe footprint.aicakicak ki-a to pound, mash things that are not dry.aicangicang: to pound anything dry or hard; to crush. aicakun akiro ki-a to get into trouble. aical to melt; to thin by adding yeast to beer; to liquefy (said of anything else, like adding water to something.) aicam to take possession of; to agree; to accept; to inherit, succeed, comply, abide. kinyekinai ber eong katwana, kocam konye ereka: wait till I die before you inherit my home. aican ki-a to pester; to annoy; to trouble; to ail. kecanete eong icuc: flies trouble me (pester me). aicana ki-a to be poor, troubled, afflicted. icanas isomero lu kere: all these students are poor. ecana eong: I am poor. icanasi kesi: they are poor. aicanakin ki-a to become poor. icanakinos bo yesi wori?: when did you become poor? wori bo kicanakinor ijo?: when did you become poor? aicang ki-a to pound dried potatoes or cassava.aicangicang ki-a to pound dried potatoes or cassava.aicania ki-a to pester with, annoy with; to vex with, etc. inyo bo kicania ijo eong?: why do you vex me (literally, with what do you vex or annoy me)? aicanican ki-a to lay waste; to spoil, to sin, to transgress; to waste. aicanicanet a sin, transgression; wastage.aicanicanun ki-a to become spoiled; to become wasted. ecanicanun akekuwan: his body is wasting. ecanicanunos iponesioke: her/his manners have become spoiled. aicanicanut (singular noun F) misfortune; bad luck. aicanio ki-a to be passive; to suffer tribulation. aicanuun ki-a to be rare, deficient, uncommon, infrequent. ecanuutu akipi nuelaete kotoma akwap: clean water is getting scarce in the world. aicap to hoe; to weed; to pluck a chicken or any bird. aicar to beat; to strike a person on any part of his body; to slog either with stick or hand; to lash. aicarakam ki-a (of milk) to curdle. icarakamitos akile: the milk is curdled.aicasetait a base of strength; a foundation to build on; a prop to lean on. aicasit ki-a to be supported; to be strong or well to do, energetic. kicasite kere aswam: be ready to work hard, i.e. be strong enough to work hard. icasit ekesa ngol: that man is well to do; that man is hardy. icasit ikoku karwatat: the child is supported by the wall (while learning to walk). aicat ki-a to stand firm or to grow strong; to convalesce or recover from sickness; (of maize) to ripen; to insist on an argument. ecat ekirididi lo: this maize has formed seed. aicatakin ki-a to lean on as a support (in getting up); to be constant and persevering. itwani etengei karai mam icatakinit aswam: you will die of hunger unless you keep working, i.e. work constantly. aicaticat ki-a to improve after illness. ecaticat ngesi: she/he/it is improving (healthwise). aicatun ki-a to be based on; to arise from; to build on; to steady oneself. icatunit etogo lo k’ingaroi: this house is built on stones. ai bo icatunitor aitubu kon ngin?: on what is your judgement based? aicawa ki-a to detract; to backbite or slander. aiceb to run quickly and lightly. aicebokin ki-a to frequent; to come often; to do or go often for something; to do constantly; to distress often; to beset often. ecebokis Ilok aingat Katakwi: cattle rustlers have frequented raiding Katakwi. inyo bo kicebokitor ijo eong?: why do you come to worry me all the time? kacebokit eong ajokit: the devil bedevils me with temptation. aicec ki-a (of a wound or sore) to fester or become bigger; to become septic. aicec nak’ajimi: blood poisoning; septicaemia; toxaemia. aiced to stalk, walk stealthily; to walk on tiptoe; to go unobserved to spy upon secretly. ecedete itelepai togo loka apesur: the boys walk stealthily to the girls’ house. ecedi ikapa neejai emir: the cat walks stealthily towards the rat. aicediced1 ki-a to hop gently; to skip. aicediced2 ki-a to prick lightly (as in tattooing or vaccinating). icedicedi edokita akan k’episo: the doctor pricks the arm with a needle.aicedicedun ki-a to follow somebody secretly; to stalk behind. kicedicedun ne: come stalking this way. aicegeg ki-o to stand with feet astride, legs apart; to stand for a long time. aiceger ki-a to plant or to put down a forked tree (or to hang things on the fork). aicegere a shelf; a fowl roost. aicegerikin ki-o to fall lightly (as of a cat falling down). abu ikapa kicegerikin omeesa: a cat fell lightly on the table. aicek (of weeds, of hair on body) to grow long; to grow quickly; to be overgrown; to be desolate; to fledge. ecekit Ocole atorob: the hair on Ocole’s chest is long; Ocole has a hairy chest. ecekit amisirika: my garden is overgrown with weeds. ecekit ere ngol: that home looks desolate (overgrown with grass). aicekicek ki-a to keep on raining a long time (used with edou: rain). ecekicek lolo edou: it has been raining incessantly today. aicel1 ki-a (of infection) to cause a swelling in the groin or pain in groin. aicel2 to scold at; to rave, sound hollow; to flare up; to use harsh language. aicelel ki-a to be conspicuous; to dominate; to be very big; (of big men, animals and things) to be visible from afar. etogo loicelelei: a high-rise building. iceleleete itogoi lu: these houses are prominent (high-rise). aicem ki-a to squeeze the stomach with the knees (this is done by women with the idea to procure an abortion or to relieve pain. A small girl kneels on her stomach and presses the woman's abdomen with her knees) aicemakin ki-a to touch or press lightly. aicer to have or leave stripes or lines or traces of a liquid. abu Icodat kocer akiyo: Icodat had furrows on her cheeks (formed by his tears). ecerit ikoku akile: the child has traces of milk on it (after drinking or sucking milk). aicerer ki-a (of a rider down the slope and on free gear) to move very fast, quickly. icererei epikipik: the motorcycle freewheels. (note: not used of human beings or animals) aicererear ki-a to move or ride fast away from speaker. aicerereun ki-o to move or ride fast towards speaker. ecerereun egaali neka: a bicycle came fast towards me. kicerereu lailo: move fast this way. aicet akwap to shuffle feet on the ground. aicib1 ki-a to plait (as a basket or mat); to weave rope into a net for fishing or hunting; to interlace; to braid, take a nip.aicib2 to sip, drink or smoke a little. kocib akipi kilikoria ekia: drink a little water to swallow the medicine. aicicik ki-a to bleach; (of a cloth in water) to lose colour. aicicikwa ki-a to change colour (in washing). aicicit akonye ki-o to lift head and look around; to be too curious.aicid ki-a to scrape (as of a pot); to wipe dry with finger (usually of plate of vegetables). aicidar ki-a to empty roughly; to wipe off thoroughly. kicidaa asaanit ngin: wipe that plate thoroughly clean (with your forefinger). aicigiciga ki-a to walk or run unsteadily (like one having sore joints). aicik1 exceedingly. ainyam aicik: to eat exceedingly. aimat ajon aicik: to drink beer excessively.aicik2 ki-a to press or squeeze. aicik akoik: (of women) to press the stomach to procure an abortion. aicik akan: to make fingerprints; to sign with thumb (as of one who cannot write); to swear not to do. aicik3 ki-a to warn the host (before a beer party takes place) of one’s coming, so that she/he can prepare; to invite somebody to pay a visit; to take preventive measures; to warn against (as hiding beer against undesirable visitors, or warn a girl against a bad boy). aicikakin1 ki-a to promise to pay a visit. aicikakin2 ki-a to surpass; to press on; to clamp; to keep down, hold down. erait epaaba kon noi aicikakin: your cotton surpasses all others in pods. kicikak apapulai ngun k’amoru: press those papers down with a stone. aicikakin akan: to sign with a thumb. icikakit ikapa emir kwap: the cat is holding down a rat.aiciket a stamp; an impression (object). aicikicik ki-a to press down; to exceed. aicikun ki-a to press down. aicikun akoik: to procure an abortion.aicil to split, break open; to tear. kobu nepe ecila kide: come at daybreak or come at dawn. aicil egoe: to tear a dress. aicil erot: to cut a road (through the bush); to make room through the crowd. aicil epelu: to take on a task (also used when starting to plough a furrow, shouting to oxen ‘aicil’: start and get on). aicing to make way through a narrow passage. kocing imor ngul: go (and squeeze yourself) between those mountains. aicip ki-a to weave; to plait (of nets and mats); to knit, intertwine.aicipakin ki-a to place child on mother’s back; to weave or plait for someone else. aicipar ki-a to sit with legs outstretched i.e. to be idle; to stretch legs; to rest. kapas eong aswam, alosi aicipar: I am tired of working, I am going to sit down (with legs outstretched). aicir ki-a to milk.aicirio ki-a (passive verb) to be milked; to be able to give milk. akiteng na mam ekoto aicirio: this cow does not want to be milked. aicirun ki-a to milk for oneself. akile nu nan pac ecirunio: fresh milk. aico to beware; to be mindful; to be cute, shrewd, careful; to be wise, clever; to be bashful, timid, shy. etelepat lo eco noi: this boy is very clever. eco ngesi noi: she/he/it is very timid, shy. sirikico: sirikiyong: do not be shy.aicoca ki-a to bring to bay, cause a fight for life. aicoce ki-a to hate everybody. aicoco ki-a to water flowers, crops, etc; to sprinkle water on flowers or anything as on floor before sweeping; to spill; to urinate voluntarily or otherwise as of men or children. ingai kicocoi akile togo: who has been spilling milk on the floor? aicocom ki-o to cause others to fight; to urge on into a fight; to exaggerate evil; to egg on; to instigate. icocomono etunganan lo: this man is fond of exaggerating mistakes of others. aicod1 ki-o to limp or walk on one leg. aicod2 to pierce slightly. abu ekukwai kocod akamopiira: a thorn pierced my tyre. aicodicod1 ki-o to run on one leg; to keep limping; to prick or pick repeatedly like a bird, or like a person pricking with a needle or anything pointed. kicodicodi ijo kwapekwangin: go on limping like that, go on trying (said of anybody trying hard to do a thing). aicodicod2 ki-o to walk or run on one leg. aicodokin: to limp on account of. ecodokin ngesi ejose: she/he has pretended to limp (in order to shirk work); she/he feigns limping. aicodor: to limp away. aicodo ki-o to limp, hobble; to go on one leg; to be paralysed; to wobble or to be a cripple. icodoi ngesi: she/he limps. aicoge ki-o to walk with a walking stick; to poke with a stick. aicoge alosit: to walk like a tall man. aicogeikin ki-a to prop; to strut, prop oneself up with the elbow or bent leg or stick. aicoger ki-a to make in an awkward shape; to make (a chain) roughly; to place poles as in the beginning of a building. aicogeun ki-a to be painful; to sting (of pain) in the stomach; to have a stinging pain in the stomach. kecogeunit eong ibore kotoma akoik: I have a stinging pain in the stomach. aicogiar1 ki-a to impugn; to pain very much; to prop up; to poke. aicogiar2 ki-a to tell off straight away; to attack at once; to assault as soon as a person appears. inyo bo kicogiara jo eong?: why did you tell me off like that? aicogoor kwap ki-o to raise and support; to stay. kicogoo asoto ngin: lift and support the top of that grain store (to take out the food).aicok ki-a to make (water) foul by stirring up dirt; to make foul, dirty. kinyek aicok akipi ngun: don’t dirty that water (i.e. do not stir up dirt in the water). aicoka ki-a (of fruit or grain) to ripen. icokaete akimai: the millet is seeding. aicokaikin ki-a to form seed or grain. ecokaikis imomwa: the sorghum is seeding. aicoki ki-o to herd, to feed cattle; to follow (somebody or something) everywhere. icokie ngol aberuke acok: he follows his wife everywhere (to prevent other men committing adultery with her). aicokicok ki-a to make wet; to drizzle continually; (of eyes) to be teary.icokicoki edou akwap: it drizzles. aicokun ki-a to be stirred as of water to dirty by stirring. ecokunos akipi: the water is foul. aicola ki-a (of potatoes, eyes) to be watery. icolaete akonye akiyo: the eyes flow with tears. aicolakin ki-a to be watery. ecolakis acok komanaka: the potatoes are becoming watery in my garden. aicole (of blood) to be watery, not quite red and healthy. aicoleikin ki-a (of blood, milk) to become watery (for). ecoleikis aokot kakuwan: the blood in the body has become watery. aicolia akeje ki-a not to walk in line or in step. icoliai ngesi akeje: she/he walks out of step. aicolia awoore: to sing out of tune. aicolia abolia: to play a bad game.aicolicol ki-a (of eyes, wound) to be teary, watery. aicolong ki-o to rest one’s head on a pillow; to be seated on a chair, etc; to subdue, subjugate. abu kadum ngesi icolongit amoru: I found him seated on a stone. aicolonget neck rest; head support or pillow.kicom akimai ngun: thresh that millet. aicom alup: to knead earth into mortar. aicoman ki-a (of a woman) to menstruate; to put on adoobe (rags worn by women during menstruation). aicome ki-a to spread lies and disaffection to cause a fight; to slander, or to cause a fight. icomei ngesi: icomeete kesi: she/he (they) slander her/him (them).asabakin. aicomeikin ki-a to tell, to spread lies about; to be dissatisfied with. aicomel ki-o to have an oval, pointed narrow head. aicop to put hot water in fresh ajon (traditional beer); to begin to do something intentionally; to start an action. aicop ajon: to place a pot of beer before guests.aicoper ki-o (of finger, ears, etc) to point upwards (of a new plant) to grow upwards; (of hair, etc) to point upwards; to point straight up. aicor ki-a to conspire; to arrange or settle privately, incite. icoras yesi aibunga eong: you are conspiring to beat me, i.e. you are inciting each other to beat me. aicor ki-a to exhort, urge, persuade, or induce; to warn or instigate. kecorit eong ijo sirikilot ore: I warn you not to go home.loicoritai: one who has been warned to keep a secret. aicor ekingok: to teach a dog to hunt. aicor imongin: to urge fighting bulls on.aicorakin ki-a to command, bid, or demand action; to give an order; to dictate; to advise. kecorakit eong ijo alosit: I order you to go. abu kecorak nges apaikin: I advised her/him to stop. aicorakinet a command; an injunction; a charge; a commission; an order; a mandate; a regulation; an edict; a counsel. ejai ijo aitodol aicorakinet naka ejakait: you have to obey the chief’s order. aicorakitoi ki-a to force to. mam eong akoto aicorakitoi: I do not want to be forced. aicorar1 ki-a to persuade oneself; to induce one another. ecoraros idwe toma aboliakec: children have induced one another to go and play. aicorar2 ki-a to win the heart or sympathy of somebody; to persuade to one’s side. abu Malinga kicora imukopin owaike: Malinga persuaded the commoners to side with him. aicoret counsel; instruction (from a teacher); advice. aingitun aicoret kaneejai itunganan: to ask for someone’s advice. aicori ki-a to fetch water (from the well). kicoriata akipi: fetch water (from the well). aicoricor ki-a to sprinkle; to scatter water over. kicoricor akipi toma akopit ngun: sprinkle water on that fibre. aicororikin1 ki-a (of animals) to be pregnant.aicororikin2 ki-a to pour on; to pour in drops i.e. slowly. kicororikit bian edou: it rained (a little) yesterday. aicorun ki-o to plot together while approaching here. ecorunos kesi aiar nges: they plotted to kill him. aicu to squeeze or press out liquid; to wring (as of clothes.) aicua ki-a (of meat) to exude liquid; to be juicy. aicucaun ki-a to drain off liquid in salt making. aicucuk ki-a (of a new cloth after first washing) to bleach, fade, change colour;
