to lose colour. egoe lo etapit aicucuk: this cloth often loses its colour in washing.aicucukwa ki-a (of cloth) to lose colour in washing; to be colour dirty.aicud to practice witchcraft for bad purpose.aipolia: to use anti-witchcraft means on the crops. aicuicuita ki-a to chirp or chirrup. aicuk ki-a to clean millet or sorghum by pounding it slightly in a mortar to remove chaff.aicuk ki-o to pump (as pumping water, air into bicycle or bellows for a forge); to walk like a lame man (as if one leg is short). aicuke ki-a to incite to fight. icukei ngesi itunga: she/he incites people.aicukeanut (singular noun F) incitement or being fond of intrigue. aicukokin ki-o to dance with bells tied to legs; to syncopate the musical instruments.aicukor ki-o to peddle (a bicycle) quickly away. kicukoo egaali oiduka: peddle the bicycle quickly to the shops. kicukoo akeje: run fast. aicukul ki-o to make holes or bumps, make bumpy. kinyek aicukul erot kwangin: do not make the road bumpy so. icukulete imotokan irotin: motor vehicles make the roads bumpy. aicukulikin ki-o to fall into a hole; to go over a bump. ecukulikinos itunga toma acukulen: people have fallen into the ditches. aicukun ki-o to peddle quickly this way (on a bicycle) or run very quickly (on foot). kicuku egaali lailo: peddle quickly this way. kicuku akeju lailo: run quickly this way. aicul1 ki-a to heap up; to dump, lump, congest, or agglomerate. aicul2 to mix hot and cold; to cool, or to mix sweet and sour; to mitigate or to palliate. kocul esupu lo, emwana noi: cool down this soup, it is too hot. aicul3 to stain, blemish, disgrace. enapit ngesi egoe loeculitoi neereng: she/he wears a red-striped garment. sirikicul erekon: do not disgrace your family. aiculakin ki-a to heap up for somebody; to cumber; to dump for to accumulate; to mount up. eculakinos agasia togokon: the rubbish has accumulated in your house. aicular ki-a (of anything) to heap up; to accumulate, mount up. ecularos apeseninikon: your debts have mounted. aiculat a heap; a pile; accumulation. aiculurikin ki-o to rest on top; to be on top to put on top. adum eong apupu iculurikina kuju atitipu: I found a hedge-hog on top of an anthill. aicum ki-a to stab; to pierce; to spear; to prick; to puncture. aicumio k’ikukwa: to be pierced with thorns. icumitai amopiiraka k’ikukwa: they have punctured my tyre with thorns. aicum epiiso: to inject or inoculate (with a needle). aicumun ebeele: (especially by double-dealing women at a dance) to start a fight (by courting two men). aicumakin1 acukumac ki-a to brand with fire. koyautu akituk kicumanakinai acukumac: bring the cattle to be branded. aicumakin2 akou ki-a to recline head on fingers or on the whole palm as a sign of sorrow.inyo bo lolo icumakinitor ijo akan amatenget, iomit anyoika?: why do you recline your head, what are you thinking about? aicumakin3 ki-a to pour in or on. kicumak akipi amot, kimwa bo oni ai?: pour a little water in the pot, after all how many are we? aicumakin ki-a to spear for someone or somewhere. kolot kicumakinai ebileng: go and spear a mudfish for me. aicumakin4 ki-o to spear oneself; to commit suicide by spearing or stabbing; to spear or stab for someone. aicumar ki-a to have an acute pain (anywhere). kecumarit eong ibore esyep: I have pain in my side. aicumet a fork; something for piercing or for spearing. aicumetait a wound from a stab. aicumul ki-a (of anything) to put into small heaps. aicumulikin ki-a (anything) to put into small heaps. aicun to bend as of bow or archway; to make horns of a bull meet each other like an arch. ecuni ngesi erute lok’ere: she/he is making an archway in front of her/his house. ecuni ngesi emong: she/he is making the bull’s horns narrower. aicun ekek: to make the entrance narrower. aicuny ki-a to dab; to mark or tick off with a writing instrument; to dip. mam ijo ijeni aicuny edia: you do not know how to dab vegetables (by dipping the food slightly in the sauce). aicunyanakin ki-a to keep dipping, as of a duck dipping its head into or under water; to keep dabbing on like one washing a wound or cleaning it; to dip lightly into the liquid. aicuny ebokorit toma akile: to dip the finger in the milk. aicup to pick out (from here and there); to gather; to single out. sirikicupucup, kolema kere: do not single out, take them all. aicur1 ki-o to leap with joy; to play or dance, jump about for joy; to jubilate, be gay; to rejoice, enjoy oneself; to effervesce. icuros apesur: the girls are playing, enjoying themselves. aicur2 ki-o to thresh in a mortar; to pound; to extract. kicur alos ejok: thresh the millet well. aicurun ki-o to come prancing about; to come running like a kid. itelepai, kicurunos lailo: boys, come playing this way. aicut ki-a to destroy or finish off one by one. adau egwang aicut imiyoi: the wild cat has finished off the chicks (snatching them one at a time).aicutakin ki-a to finish for somebody; to refuse to do again, make up one’s mind, not to do again; to resolve never to do again. akoto eong aicutakin aswamuke: I want to finish off his work. ecutakin eong abunenen orekon: I shall make up my mind never to visit you again.aicutar ki-a to finish off, to kill off well, deplete, despatch. aswam kere naiswamai ijo, ejok aicutar ngesi: whatever you do, finish it well. icuta ijo akonikiro?: is that all you have to say? aicuwa ki-a to be porous; (of a wound) to ooze. aicwal to cause to melt.ecwalata acok: the potatoes are watery (when cooked). aicwe ki-a to burn, set on fire, put fire to; to fire, ignite, light.aicween ki-a to mock; to ridicule. inyo bo kicweenia ijo eong?: why do you mock (ridicule) me? aicweikin ki-a to set fire to; to burn, fire, ignite.aicweis an incinerator. aicwenikin ki-a to ridicule; to mock. aicweyet ordeal by fire; an incinerator; a burner. aida1 ki-a to bury; to dig under. aida lukatwak: burial (of the dead). aida2 to lash, to whip, castigate; to beat the floor of a house (to level it); to scourge; to thrash millet, sorghum, etc. koda etogo: beat the floor of the house. aida k’ebela: to thrash; to drub. adaenenoo: to be beaten, to be allowed to be beaten. mam aberu adaeneno: a woman should not be beaten. aidaanakin ki-a to keep burying in, digging under (as of weeds). kidaanak ekoropot lo kwap: keep digging this weed (ekoropot) under. aidaanar ki-a to keep taking away; to keep pilfering. ejai ibore idaanari imiyoika kane: something keeps snatching my chicks. aidaar ki-a to pilfer, take away. edaa nan egwang akakokor: the wild cat took away my hen this morning. aidac1 akiro to throw out words; to speak at random; to talk nonsense; to talk foolishly. kinyek aidac einer: do not talk irresponsibly. aidac2 to throw thick matter (like mud or any semi-liquid matter) (not used of solids nor liquids); to throw bad things (dung, etc) at/on something hard. edaci ngesi alupot toma arwatat: she/he throws mud on the wall. aidadaar ki-a to take away secretly to abscond. aidadakin ki-a to give secretly (of poison or anything). aidadat ki-a to steal secretly.aidadaun ki-o to come secretly, stealthily (at night or during the day); to bring secretly. edadaunos ikokolak bian oreka: thieves came to my home secretly yesterday. aidaet a burial; a thing for burying; a shroud. aidaidaar ki-a a corruption of aidadaar: to take or steal secretly; to pilfer; to smuggle. aidaidaun ki-o a corruption of aidadaun: to come unnoticed, unaware; to come upon unnoticed. idaidaun atwanare aidaidaun: death comes without timing. idaidaunos ikokolak: thieves come secretly. aidaikin ki-a to bury in. idaikinio ngesi togoke: she/he will be buried in her/his house. aidak1 to carry; to rear a child. kodak ikoku kon kojokan: carry your child well. aidak2 to lift up; to carry in the hands or on the laps. edakit ngesi akou tai: she/he has no brains; she/he carries her/his head about for nothing.aidal ki-a (of a person) to milk straight into the mouth; to squirt from teat. idali etelepat akiteng: the boy milks from the udder direct to his mouth. aidam ki-a to walk with toes spread out; (of child) to toddle; (of old men or children) to totter; to hobble along. aidamidam ki-a to soak; to make thoroughly wet; to drench. abu edou kedamidam eong: I was thoroughly drenched by the rain.aidanga ki-a to cut or divide into big pieces. mam akoto ijo aidanga akakiring: I do not like you to cut my meat into very big chunks. aidangakin ki-a to cut a large piece (of meat, etc) for somebody else. aidangidang ki-a to undertake what one cannot do; to try the impossible; to make too thick; to make too big. kinyek aidangidang etogo naarai mam ipedori aiduk nges: do not attempt to build such a big house, because you cannot finish it. aidangun ki-a to cut a big piece for oneself. aidany1 ki-a to make hard by trampling; to trample down or on; to flatten out. kinyekis aidany akacok: do not trample down my potatoes to be flat. idanyito atenueik nuk’etekwa: the branches of the etekwa tree are flat (branch out like umbrella).aidany2 to kill or take many; to massacre; to kill a great number of; to slaughter; to ravage. edanyit ekodoi itunga kane: small-pox killed many people here. abu eloket kodany idwe luko Ngariam okaru 2001: the Karimojong cattle rustlers massacred the children of Ngariam in 2001. to live long; to finish food - eating all or nearly all; eat much. sirikidany atap: do not finish all the millet bread. aidany ikar swi: to live for many years. aidanyakin ki-o to squat down; (of a child) getting up and falling down, unable yet to walk. kidanyakinos nen: squat down there. aidanyany ki-a to be sitting down doing nothing. kanukinyo idanyanyaata yesi kane?: why are you sitting here idle? aidao (singular noun F) a funeral; a burial; interment.aidap to bypass; to go alongside; to put at the side of (as grass or anything at the side of house or road). kodap akituk ngun koreu kes lailo: go alongside those cows and lead them this way. aidapal ki-a to make flat; (of hilly or bumpy place) to flatten. aidar aijar (singular noun F) hygiene; safety; care for one’s life. aidar ki-a to wait for; to watch; to guard, keep or protect; to expect. idarete ikweny abeeikec: birds protect their eggs. aidarakin ki-a to watch for (in place of) someone; to mind for. kidarakinai eong ere: mind my home for me. aidarar ki-a to await somebody in order to let him/her do something, or in order to tell or send him somewhere immediately. edarit eong Omongin aingit acekiro: I am ready waiting for Omongin to ask him something. keker ngesi ngina aponi kidararai ainom: when she/he ran away she/he found them waiting ready to beat her/him. aidare ki-a to await; to wait for.kidareunoi: wait for me. (1st person: edarei eong. 2nd person plural: idareete. Imperative: kidare . aidareikin ki-o to wait a little for, have patience. kidareik, alosi aitac ijo: have a little patience, I am going to pay you. aidares a prison, waiting room or place; a dungeon; an ambush; a lying in wait; watching; guarding; waiting.kidareu akiro nukiponikito ijo: wait for what will befall you. aidario (singular noun F) conservation; protection; custody. aidaris a prison; a waiting room or place; a dungeon; an ambush; a lying in wait; watching; guarding; waiting.aidat1 ki-a to lie in ambush; to keep motionless. idasit ekokolan: the thief is lying in ambush. aidat2 to clear bush to make a garden; to make a new field.aidatakin ki-a to lie in ambush for someone; to remain silent; to refuse to answer.aidaudaun ki-a to raise (as of dust, etc). idaudau ijo apua: you raise the dust (by dancing). to rise, come up (as of dust, vapour, clouds, mist); to wave in the wind (as of feathers, banners, leaves, etc). edaudaun apua kokau k'emotoka: the dust has risen behind the motorcar. edaudaunos ajul nuk’ekweny kokwam: the bird has lovely soft feathers waving in the wind. aidaudawonokin to raise (dust, etc) continually to annoy somebody. kinyek aidau- dawonokin eong apua: stop raising the dust to annoy me. aidayo (singular noun F) a burial; interment.aide1 ki-a (said of anthill when it has holes everywhere for white ants to swarm). ideit atitipu na: this anthill has many little exits (akonye - eyes) for the white ants to swarm. (note: these little eyes or holes are made by termites just before white ants swarm). aide2 to pluck vegetables; to gather fruit; to pick cotton; to knock down fruits from the tree; to speak a language fluently. edei ngesi Ateso aide: she/he speaks Ateso fluently. edeete itunga epaaba: people are picking cotton. (of a hard object) to crack; to break slightly. adea eikopo: the cup has cracked. sirikide eikopo: do not crack the cup.aidec akou nak’emun: to crush the head of a snake to go on raining without stopping. abu bian edou kidec akware kiya: it rained the whole night yesterday. aidecakin ki-a to crush, to pound for; to step or stand on. kidecakinai eong emaido lo: crush, pound fine this groundnuts for me. edicaki amoru ekabokorit: a stone has crushed my toe. sirikidicak akejuka: do not step (or stand) on my foot. abu eong kedicak luk'asurupika: I crushed my enemies.aidecidec ki-a to keep on beating (as of fresh or wet sisal, etc). aidecidecaar ki-a to make, cut into pulp (as of groundnuts). aidede1 (singular noun F) eruption (as of wound or rinderpest). aidede2 ki-o to come out, into; (of a sore) to develop; to come to a head; (of a boil) to have pustules. aidedeun ki-a to appear to straighten out (folds of cloth or anything). kidedeu atorob: chest out! expose your chest. aidediar ki-o (of anything) to lie on the back, right side up, or face up.kidediar!: lie on your back!. kobuburiar: lie on your stomach! koper eidedia!: lie on your back to put on the back or right side up or face up; to turn face up. kidedia asaanit ngin: turn that plate up. aideerakin ki-a (of cattle or things or soldiers or boys) to put in a line. kideerak akituk elosete aimat: let the cows go to drink in a file. edeerikinos isirikaalei: the soldiers are lined up to go straight without deviating. edeeriki ngesi erot: she/he has gone straight ahead. aideerakin itim: to shave the head, leaving lines. aideerikin ki-a to carry a load on the head freely, not touching it. aideide ki-a to report; to tell on; to whisper, inform; to betray; to accuse. alosi eong aideide nukon kaneejai papaka: I am going to tell (on you to) my father.aideidea ki-a to whisper; to talk softly. aideideikin ki-a to whisper to someone’s ears. inyo bo nan ideideikini ijo ngesi?: what did you whisper into her/his ears? kideideikinai: whisper it to me.aideikin ki-a to leave something over or to someone else. kideikinai eong da ajon adis: leave a little beer for me too to be left over for someone. aidek1 ki-a (of a person) to click the tongue in disapproval. aidek2 (of a penis) to be erect. aidekar ki-a to refuse, disapprove, despise, show contempt by making a clicking sound with the tongue.aidekek ki-o to be sticking up; to protrude, stick out. idekekei akitoi kanen, kocoite: there is a protruding stick there, be careful. aidekereun ki-a to put one side up; to lift up eyelids. kidekereu abukio: look out (lift your eyelids). aidekeriar ki-a (of grass, etc) to bend upwards; (of tail of squirrel when running) to stick up; (of a piece of wood on the ground) sticking up. aidekerikin ki-o to dare to attack; (of a small person, etc) to hang onto. abu eong kedekerikin nges lokatuman: I beat him (though he is much bigger). edekerikinos luk’ocaalo kwi luk’otaun kotoma aboliasinei: those teams from up-country beat those from town in sports. abu Daudi kidekerikin Goliasi: David dared Goliath. aidekidek ki-a to stop a cow, etc with a click of the tongue; to call chickens by clicking the tongue. aidekidekun ki-a to click with tongue to halt; to make to go slowly or stand (used only of cattle when out of hand - to stop them, make them listen - usually when milking). aidel1 ki-a to impose on someone's kindness. idela ikoku kaneejai tataake: the child imposes on the kindness of a grand mother (confident, trusting in). aidel2 ki-a to show off; to swank with; to be ostentatious. ideli ekesa ngol itunga k'egaalike: he shows off with his bicycle. aidelanut to be fond of showing off proudly. aidelel ki-o to protrude; to be conspicuous; to be visible; to stand out; to be prominent, evident, exposed, pellucid, or tremendous. ideleleete akiro ngun: those things are very clear. idelelei ngesi noi kotoma ojako: she/he is very conspicuous amongst chiefs. idelelei Soroti kane: Soroti is very prominent from here. aidelun ki-a to persuade, advise, prevail on, or to influence. kidelu ekesa ngol ketegwel ngesi eong akiteng ngin: persuade that man to sell me that cow.aidem to confiscate; to rob; to plunder, snatch from. sirikidem iboro k’itunga: do not rob people of their things. sirikidem itunga iborokec: do not rob people of their possessions. aidemidem ki-a to make soft; to soak; to make damp; to drench. edemidem edou ekapale: the rain has soaked my pants. idemececas ikaperito: my beddings are very wet. aideng1 ki-o to cut round slightly (not to cut through). aideng2 to beat once but very hard. ikoku yenerono edengi nges papake: a bad child is severely beaten by his father. edengedengeete kwi imongin noi: those guys beat bulls very much. aideng3 to drink out in one go. aideng4 to pluck fruit or vegetables. edengi ngesi araito: she/he plucks fruits.aidenge ki-o to do alone, by oneself. edengei eong aiduk ekatogo: I have to build my house alone. idengeete yesi ikusinyamat?: are you eating by yourselves? aidengeria ki-a to produce fruit in great quantities. ikito ngul idengeriato noi: those trees are laden with fruit. aidengideng ki-o (of a ring) to cut a finger; to cut round something (such as a tree) and leave the middle uncut aidengokin ki-o to surround, go in front to stop running; to stay. kidengok ikokolak ngul: go round and intercept those thieves. aideny1 intention; a set purpose. aideny2 ki-a to prepare oneself, be prepared, be ready. idenyit ijo alosit: you are ready to go. aideny3 ki-a to have intentions of doing something good or bad; to intend, determine, premeditate. ejaas nuidenyit ijo kaneka: you are loath me. aidenyakin ki-a to have evil intentions against someone; to annoy somebody. kidenyakinit ijo eong apaarasia kere: it is always your intention to harm me.aidenyakinet determination. aidenyit ki-a to have a mind to; to be determined; aim at, intend. edenyit eong abunere orekon: I am determined to come to your home. aidep1 ki-a to pick, gather; (of animals or birds) to pick white ants or food. kolot aidep akito: go and gather firewood to talk a lot; to babble. idepi ikoku: the child talks a lot or has cried for a long time. aidep2 to exceed or go beyond; to tuck in or under. kidep aitiiba: tuck in the mosquito net. aidep ekek: fill the openings in or at the side of the door against mosquitoes. aidepidep ki-a to gossip, tell tales about, or spread rumours. aidepidepanut ki-a to be a tale-teller. aider1 ki-a to set a broken or fractured bone right; to solder a piece of iron; to poise, set, put up a pole for support. akoto aider ekatogo: I want to put a pole under the roof of my house (to support it). aider akoit: to set broken bones using splints or Plaster of Paris. aider2 ki-o to cross (a river) going along a fallen tree or rope. kider ekitoi kocoite ilatar: go gently along that tree (crossing a river) but do not fall (slip). aider3 ki-o to go straight along a path without deviating; to speak the truth; to go straight ahead. kidero cut ilosi: go straight ahead. etubi ejakait akiro ideritos: the chief settles cases justly. aiteder akiro: to justify; to settle justly; to make straight; to rectify matters. aideranakin ki-a to plant far apart; to spread out; to put in order, plant at regular distance. kideranak ikito irai: plant the trees far apart. to be far apart, scarce, to be few. ideranakina itunga oitela ngol: there are a few people in that parish. aideranakina ki-o (of plants) to be scanty, sparse, few, scarce, or patchy aiderer ki-o to be straight, direct; (of speech) to be clear; to be straight forward. idererei erot ngol: that road is straight. idererei einer kon: what you say is clear (you are not beating about the bush). aideriar ki-a to freewheel. aiderikin ki-a a corruption of aidarekin: to wait for somebody awhile. kiderik papa kon abunit: wait awhile for your father. aidet1 ki-a to fish with a hook; to wash clean or thoroughly; to look sharply at; to stare at. alosi eong aidet agaria: I am going to fish. kidet akaisuuka: wash my sheet well. aidesit icop: to stare or gaze without blinking (with eyes wide-open). idesit ngesi akonye: she/he looks very severely and sternly, i.e. she/he has a very stern and severe look. aidetakit akonye: to stare or gaze at. aidet2 ki-a to kill quickly; to despatch after having been nearly killed. apotu kesi kidetata emorotot eapie atwanare: they killed off the python when it was nearly dead. aidet3 to send particles (of anything) flying; to scatter sparks or tiny drops, splash, or to sprinkle; to tell off repeatedly. kinyek aidet akipi nuarokok ogoen: stop splashing dirty water on clothes. edesete idwe akipi: the children are splashing water. adetokin itunganan akiro: to tell off or scold someone. aidetar ki-a to bale out water (as in canoe or pool, etc); to purge. kideta akipi k’ataker: bale out the water from the canoe or boat; to wash very clean. aideukukin ki-a (of belly) to distend. aideun ki-a to leave some (not finish all). sirikidau ajon, kideu ace: do not finish all the beer, leave some to remain or to be left over. amat eong ajon, konye edeunos adis: I have drank beer, but there is a little left over. adaunos ajon: the beer is finished. edeunos ajon: there is beer left over. aideunet a remainder; remnant; remains; dregs. aidi1 the highest point (of anything); greatest height of tree or house or rock, etc; the apex.abu Daudi kodii Goliasi k’amoru: David aimed accurately at Goliath. aidia1 (of men, animals, ants, etc) to go many together. idiaete isuunyo: the black biting ants go out together.kidiaata akipi nuk’okicoi: drain away the water from the water hole. aidiaar ki-a to go many together. ai bo idiaaros yesi kere?: where are you all going (so many of you). apotu itunga kidiaaros neejai Yesu ipu: a big crowd accompanied Jesus. to take many (of living beings). ediaa ejakait itunga oreke: the chief has taken many people to his home. aidiakidiak ki-a to make soft (by wetting); to eat something soft and watery; (of a drenched person) to run.aidiakin ki-a to go in procession, in a line like ants (isuunyo). ediakis isuunyo amej: the black fighting ants are going in line to hunt. aidiakit ki-a to do wrong; to err. aidianakin ki-a (of living beings) to keep coming in crowds; to gather in crowds. idianakinete lolo akweny osamai ainyam ekutelek: the birds have gathered in the swamp to eat army worms. to keep coming or going in crowds.aidiar ki-a to drain, draw away people from their homes or to drain water from a hole or well; (of men, etc) to take away many. aswamusinei nuko Jinja idiaritos itunga ipu: the Jinja works have drawn many people. idiaritos itunga luka akwapisinei: they have drawn people from other countries. aidiare ki-o to go and look for vegetables (only used in infinitive). kolot adiare: go and look for vegetables. aidic1 ki-a to be always together; to suit each other, agree with each other. idicas Odong ka Opio: Odong and Opio are always together. akim mam idicas ka akipi: fire and water do not go together (do not agree). aidic2 ki-a to grind fine; to grind well, pulverise, triturate. koyautu alos naidicic: bring well ground millet. aidic3 ki-a to kill fleas with fingers; to crush (anything).aidicakin1 akeje ki-a to put heels or feet together like soldiers; to clamp; to measure by the feet (putting one before the other); to tread or step on somebody’s feet inadvertently; to grind fine; to press for. kidicakis akeje: put your heels together. aidicakin etau: to be brave. kidic alos na: grind this millet fine. idicak ijo ekabokorit: you have stepped on (crushed) my toe. aidicakin2 ki-o to be of the same mind; to be friends with. edicakinos do ikesa kwi: those guys are now close friends. aidicanar ki-o to keep going with a friend; to keep going together. ai bo idicanaros yesi duc?: where are you always going together? aidicanara ki-a to be in friendly relation; to be agreeable to each other. idicanara yesi noi: you are very friendly to each other. aidicar ki-o to go in company. edicaros Apuda ka Ikasangat apejo: Apuda and Ikasangat have gone together (in company) for a visit. aididia ki-a to whisper; to talk to oneself.aididianakin ki-a to whisper into another’s ear; to speak in a high, sharp tone as of women and children. aididior ki-o to conceal, delay to hide oneself; to be delayed; to stay away long. aidiece ki-a to do on purpose; to do intentionally.aidier ki-a to make a present of; to present with; to give away, distribute. idierit ngesi ikeboro kere, ecanuu do: she/he has given all her/his things away, and now she/he is poor. aidierakin ki-a to give as a present; to give away; to distribute; to lavish. kidierakinai eong da idis: give me also a few. aidii (of men, animals, ants, etc) to go many together in Indian file. idiiyaete imukunyo elosete: the black biting ants go out together Indian file.idikai ngesi ajon: she/he drinks much beer. kidikaata ajon: drink plenty of beer. (of anything) to be thick. aidikakin ki-a to suck; to drink in one draught; to bite. aidikes1 (singular noun F) density of a liquid; concentration; thickness. aidikes2 ki-o to be thick; to curdle. idikok akile nu: this milk is thick. aidikidik ki-a to frequent a place; to do frequently; to throb (of heart, etc). sirikidikidik itogoi lueroko: do not frequent bad houses to be frequent, constant. ebala eporotoka dikidik: my throat throbs. idikidiki etau loka ekakeran: the heart of a runner beats quickly. aidikior ki-o (of liquids) to become thick, stiff, coagulate. edikioros akile: the milk has become thick. aidikiun ki-o to curdle, congest; (of liquids) to become thick, dense; (of an activity) to intensify. aidil1 ki-a to put in more than necessary; to increase. kinyek aidil akito toma akim: do not put too many sticks into the fire (do not choke the fire). aidil2 to go early; to travel early in the morning. kodiloto moi yesi osomero: go to school early tomorrow. aidila ki-a to be many, plenty, abounding; to cook edila (wild pea leaves) vegetable. idilas akituk ko Teso: there are plenty of cattle in Teso. aidilakin ki-a to overdo, put many or much at once; to order to do too much. sirikidilak abalang odia: do not put too much salt ash into the vegetables. sirikidilak eong aswam: do not let me do too much: do not overwork me. (used with any verb, meaning: too or very much, i.e. to overdo; to do to excess; to overdose) aidilar1 ki-a to increase. kidila ekaropit: increase my pay to increase; to be added; (also) to fling. edilaros ikatunga: my people have increased. ibareneka mam idilara: my cattle have not increased. kidilakata kolo: what a crowd there was.aidilar2 ki-o to abound; to become many, plentiful, much. idilaros do inyamat ekaru lo: there is going to be plenty of food this year. (of anything) to drag away, pull away. aidiles abundance; plenty; cornucopia; plethora. aidilidilar ki-a to drag along, far away. edilidilasi ijaka ekokolan: the chiefs have dragged away a thief. aidiluun ki-a to become many, abundant, plentiful, increase. ediluutu akituk nuedekasi: the number of sick cows has increased. aidim1 ki-a to cut down bush or grass; to gather (of groundnuts); (of cashewnut fruit) to break off. kolot aidim amoni: go and cut the thicket. kolot aidim emaido: go and pluck groundnuts.aidim2 ki-a to pick, pluck, prune, gather, pluck. alosi eong aidim emaido: I am going to pluck groundnuts. aidim ekitoi: to prune a tree. (note: to pick of birds is atodunun). aidimakin ki-a to cut for or in some place. kolot aidimakin amoni ngina: go and cut the bush over there. aidimic ki-a to crush with foot or with a heavy object. idimicik ijo ekabokorit: you have crushed my toe (with your foot). aidimicikin ki-a to crush with foot or heavy body or stone. kidimicik imir ngin k’amoru: crush that little rat with a stone. aidimidim ki-a to cut short (especially vegetable plants); (of goat, sheep) to nibble at leaves or grass. kirengia ikalol ngin, idimidimi akimai: drive away that kid, it nibbles at the growing millet. aidimidimunun ki-a to pluck a few vegetables (for a short time). aidimokin ki-o (of movement) to stop suddenly. aidimun ki-a to cut a thicket or bush for oneself. akoto aidimun ikukwa ainakin akinei: I want to cut thorns for the goats. aidinga ki-a to drink much of water, beer, etc; to booze. idingaete kesi ajon: they drink much beer.aidingidinga ki-a to be too many. idingidingas itunga kokanisa, mam ipedori aiboikin kwap: there are too many people in church, you cannot sit down. aidiny1 ki-a to moan or blubber. apup eong eidiny loka idwe: I heard the sighing of the children. aidiny2 ki-a (in child birth, defecation) to bear down or push; to groan; to sigh. aidinyakin ki-a to refuse; to object (usually by a grunt); to help to strain; to help somebody to strain himself (accompanying him with groans). aidinyun ki-a (in child birth, defecation) to force out by constant pressure. aidio a peak; the highest point; greatest height of tree or house or rock, etc; the apex.aidior ki-o to disappear, vanish; to plunge (used with adverb dii di or duu du: entirely). edioros iboro ka dii di: my things have disappeared, vanished completely.aidip1 to follow closely. adip ikoku papake: the child is following closely behind its father. aidip2 to strike; to beat, box (with a fist or club); to punch; to contuse, belabour. kodip etau: beat your breast (for shame). inyo bo kidipio ijo eong?: why did you strike me with your fist? aidipidipar ki-o to go away together; to run off together. adipidiparos kwi Kampala: the guys ran off together to Kampala. aidipokin ki-o to stoop down; to hide. kodipokinos kwap, abu elope: stoop down and hide, the owner has come. aidir ki-a to go far away; (of a bird) to go upwards; (of roots) to bore deep; to dig a hole, straight down. idirit ijo iboki aipany: you dug the hole very deep. aidiririar akejen: to direct one’s foot-steps. aidiriakin1 ki-a to put straight on (like putting cigarettes behind the ear or in the mouth or pole on the roof, etc); to drive a spear straight into an animal or person. Kidiriak esigala akitikon: put that cigar behind your ear. aidiriakin alosit: to go straight away.aidiriakin2 ki-o to fall headlong. abu eong kediriakin toma aipany: I fell headlong into a hole. aidiricar ki-a to splash. kitor amotoka orot idiricanaros akipi: the water splashes when a car passes through puddles on the road. aidiridir ki-a (of bird) to hover; to pirouette; (of water) to spout. aidiridir nak’akipi: a maelstrom. aidirir1 ki-a (of liquids) to spout; (of blood, etc) to gush. idiririete akipi kotoma akongu: the water gushes from a spring. aidirir2 ki-a (of person) to stand upside down; (of any thing) to stand on head. idiririete ikomion: the tree stumps (after cutting trees) remain standing. idiririete iitaabon: the books are standing upside down. aidiririar ki-a to dig deep down. idiririaritos imirio aipany: the rats have dug their hole deep down. aidiririet a spout; a tap; a jet; a watering can; a syringe. aidiririun ki-o to gush out; to spout out. ediririunos akile k’okisin: the milk has squirted out from the breast. aidit to beat very much. sirikidit ikoku kwangin: do not beat the child thus. aidiya to go in a long file in procession; to progress. idiyaete lolo itunga osokooni l’Ocorimongin: there is a long procession of people going to Ocorimongin market today.aido1 to smack lips, snap fingers; to lick (sugar, salt, etc); to taste from open palm; to dip tongue into sugar, etc (in palm of hand). aido2 to drop; to fall. aido okela k’ebu: to be in wrong hands (literally, to fall on a hyena’s teeth). edoit ekanusu ne: my shilling has dropped here. aidoc ki-a to keep pricking or picking the same place; to sting in the same place. idocete akokoroi acok: the hens keep pecking at the potatoes in one spot. aidod to point at; to point out; to show. kanukinyo kidoditor ijo eong?: why do you point at me? aidodok (a general name for) a frog. aidodoka a plant, Solanum. aidoel a striped hyena, Hyena hyena. aidoido1 ki-a to get (gather) little by little; to get into a habit (of stealing or doing anything); to ask habitually for or be in the habit of doing something. loidoidoi mam inyekini aibar: he who gathers little by little is sure to get rich.aidoido2 ki-o to give a nice taste for; to give a taste of; to like; to like to; to be sweet to. kedoido eong esukaali: (the sugar gives me a nice taste) I like sugar. kedoidooto eong ajon: I like beer or I like the taste of beer. ibunit ijo kidoido aimat ajon: you have come here with the hope of drinking beer. aidoidoikin ki-o to taste well to; to be tasty to; to find tasty, nice. edoidoikis ikoku akile: the child has liked milk.aidoikin ki-o to place or put inside; to drop inside, put in the mouth to taste. kidoik akimai odula: put the millet into the granary. aidois maternity; labour ward; delivery room.aidok2 to climb up; (of animals) to mate. aidok3 to pick (teeth or bone); to gnaw at bone. adum eong ekingok edoki akoit: I found a dog picking a bone. adokis ikel: a tooth pick.aidokidok ki-o to take everything (that is there) away; to do in detail. sirikidokidokoo akwi k’acok kere: do not take away all the potato cuttings. aidokidokun akiro kere: to go into details. aidokio a pile, heap (of anything). aidokio akanin confirmation in to the Protestant church. aidokokin ki-o to place or put one on top of the other. kidokok amot okyala: put the pot on the hearth to be one on top of the other; to be stapled up one on top of the other; to overlap. edokokinos ikelake: her/his teeth are overlapping each other. aidokokin akan: to swear an oath; to put on hands conferring a sacrament (such as when corfirming young Christians). aidokokin aboko: to crown. akopiira naidokokinitai: double tier hat. aidokonokin akwi ki-a to put potato leaves on the heaps ready for planting. kidokonok ijo akwi kuju apanya, abuni eong aira: put the potato leaves ready, I shall come and plant them. aidokor ki-a to replant potato heaps after first potato leaves have dried up.aidokorian ki-a to be persistent, persevering; to keep in mind. kidokorian akiro ngun: keep that in mind. idokorianete kesi akiro: they keep it in mind. aidokorianut persistence; determination. aidokoriaun ki-a to investigate; to go in to find out. abu ejakait kidokoriau akiro kere: the chief investigated every case. aidokorikin ki-o to be persistent in; to be persevering; to insist in doing something, whatever obstacles in the way; to be keen on. kinyek aidokorikina akot egwelet egaali kikidioko isirigin: do not be so keen on buying a bicycle, when you have so little money. to persevere, go on, etc. idokorikina idwe abolia: the children are keen on playing. aidokosit a layer; stratum; a pleat; a hem. aidokudokun ki-o to bring away or out all that is there; to leave nothing behind; to remember everything; to call up past events good or bad; to detail, to rake up - hence to be spiteful. kinyek aidokudokunun nunan adaunos sek: do not rake up all these nasty things of the past. aidol1 ki-a to lie in misery or sickness; to lie in folds, doubled up with pain. idola lokadekan kotogo: sick person lies doubled up with pain in the house. aidol2 ki-a to coil (a rope); to fold (cloth). kidol auno ngin: coil that rope. aidol3 to arrive; to be enough; to be right, sufficient. mam etelepat lo edolit: this boy is not right. aitodol: to cause (make) to reach, etc; to complete, to fulfil. until; up to; hitherto. aitodol kwana: until (up to) now. aidolakin ki-a to fold up (cloth or body with pain). adeka nges idolakit ngesi: it is sickness that has kept him/her in bed. aidolakin akeju: to sit cross-legged. (of anything) to be folded up, shrivelled up. aidolar ki-a to coil away from speaker. aidolidol ki-a to fold many times round, like a bandage or a snake round a twig. aidolidola ki-a to droop; to be hanging down like a sick person or anything too weak to stand up. aidolo ki-o to lace or tie bundles of twigs on walls or roof of a traditional Teso hut. idoloi ngesi eketogo: she/he is tying struts on her/his hut, or is lacing up walls of her/his hut.aidomakin ki-a to plunge; to dip into; to dye. akoto aidomakin ekagoe toma akipi: I want to dip my dress in water. aidome ki-o to eat; to throw into the mouth and eat. idomei ikoku emaido: the child is throwing groundnuts one after another into the mouth and eating. aidon ki-a (of rain) to drizzle for a long time; (of rain, liquid) to drop, to leak; to drizzle. abu bian edou kidon kiya: it drizzled the whole night yesterday. aidonakin ki-a (of water or medicine) to drop on or into; (of a leak in something, water oozing) dropping from leak or rain. kidonakinai ekia akonyeka: drop some ointment into my eyes. idonanakinos akipi oitaadaka: the water keeps dripping on my bed. aidong1 ki-o to remain. edong ngesi ore: she/he has stayed at home.aidong2 ki-o to tap latex juice from a tree; to castrate animals. aidong ebule: to tap latex from ebule tree. aidong ekiliokit: to emasculate or castrate a male. aidong ikorwa: to castrate he-goats. aidong3 to pinch, nip, hold tight; to take food with fingers; to abide by. inyo bo kidongia ijo eong?: why did you pinch me? aidong ikoku iwos: to pinch a child on the buttocks. aidonga ki-a to leap into the air; to dance up and down. idongaete itelepai: the boys are dancing or leaping. aidonga ekirakira: to leap up and down in a cultural dance called ekirakira. aidonget the place where animals are castrated. aidongio castration. aidongis the scar left after castration. aidongit ki-o to remain behind; to pass time. aidongor ki-o to subjugate, subdue, humble by constant beating and telling off. edongori lolo eong epalikon: I am going to subdue your cheeky ways today. aidony1 ki-o to finish eating all the food; to finish all the drink (of beer and milk only). sirikidony akile kere: do not (finish) drink all the milk. edonyoto kwi inyamat bian: those men finished all the food yesterday. aidony2 ki-o to pound dried food (like potatoes or cassava). kidonyoto emuogo: pulverise that cassava.aidony3 to sew, knit; to mend clothes; to patch embroidery; to repair (anything). adonyoto apesur igoen: the girls sewed the clothes. aidoole anus; a bottom (of anything); arsehole. aidoonokin ki-o (as of food into throat, as of mother bird feeding young ones, or of letting a vessel down into a hole) to let down repeatedly.aidoor1 ki-o to rattle (like bicycle chains when free-wheeling); to gurgle; (of a person) to snore. ekonigaali idooroi noi: your bicycle rattles very much. idooroete akipi kodaraca: the water gushes under the bridge.aidoor2 ki-o to put something into the mouth unnoticed by another.to lessen or drop prices. to become less in price. edoor etiai loka acok: the price of sweet potatoes has plummeted. aidop1 ki-a to emaciate; to waste, dry up (by sickness, age, and of fruit by the sun). adau adeka aidop papaaka: illness has wasted my grand father's body or strength. abu akolong kidop imucuuga: the sun dried up the little orange plant. aidop2 ki-a to kill off (after wounding); to finish off food. aidop3 ki-o to become very hot; to be red hot; (of cigarettes, tobacco) to become ashes. idopit emukaro: the underground kiln is very hot. edop amiidika: my tobacco pipe is nearly out. edop ekasigala: my cigarette is nearly burned out. edop ekatau kanuka ican: akono ekatau: my heart is burned out with anger or sorrow.aidop4 (of a piece of grass, etc) to poke the eye. kadopit eong anyait akongu: a bit of grass has poked my eye. aidopakin ki-a to finish off for. aidopar ki-a to finish off, kill off. aso jo kidopaa ajon ngun: well, you finish that beer. aidopokin ki-a to become red-hot with or for (roasting). idopokit eupa acok: the fireplace is hot and ready for roasting potatoes. aidopor ki-o to be or to become emaciated, wasted, dried up (by sun); to fall in the grave, etc; to become ashes. edopo akakuwan kanuka adeka: my body is wasting through illness. aidopun ki-a to finish off (a thing by oneself). okwe, kinyekinai eong kedopu ajon ngun: please, let me finish that beer. aidor1 ki-o to put on the fire to boil; to cook (water or food).aidor2 ki-o to slander, detract, defame. inyo bo idoritor Abunyang?: why do you defame or slander Abunyang? sirikiyau akiro nuka edorit: do not malign others before me. aidoridor ki-a to gurgle. aidorokin (akipi) ki-o to put a water (pot) on fire; to boil (water for cooking, or for tea or food, etc); to heat. to be busy a long time. aidorokin iitaabon: to sit very long in one place reading for exams. edorokinos itunga oicolongo aipup imusaagon: people have been busy hearing long cases and are tired (said of any action lasting too long and tiring people). aidoror1 ki-a to gush; to gurgle; to rattle; to snore; to rush (of water fall). idororoete idwe: the children snore (in their sleep). idororoete igaalin luka Iteso: the Iteso bicycles rattle. idororoete akipi kotoma aguurut: the water roars into the waterfall. akoto ekia loka aidoror iporotoi: I want medicine for gurgling. aidoror2 ki-a to rattle, snore. ekonigaali idororoi noi: your bicycle rattles very much. idororoete akipi kodaraca: the water gushes under the bridge. aidosidos ki-a to treat carefully (as of eggs, glass cups and all fragile things). kidosidosata iboro ngul: treat those (very fragile) things carefully. aidosilaar ki-o to die a hidden death; to die alone in misery. adum eong obonipe kidosilaar: I found the hermit had died. adosilikin akakiteng okitwi: my cow died alone in the high grass. aidot to pluck a bird’s feathers; to pluck beards; to pick jiggers or thorns out of foot or anything. edosi etelepat epuusa: the boy is picking out a jigger. aidotidot ki-o to pluck out hair, feathers, beard one by one. edeke ngesi edosidosi iketim: sickness made his hair fall off. aidotor ki-o to take away; to remove (anything). kidoto jo epir: you pull out the pole (from the ground). kidotosi ber ejakait ngol, ekoto ecamusana: remove that manager, he takes bribes. edotoros imelekes: the hoes have come loose from the handles. aidoun ki-o to give birth to; to bear, bring forth a child. edou aberu ngin idwe luipu: that woman has brought forth (borne) many children. (note: to bear - of fruit: aira; of animals: auri) aidounio birth. ameun aidouniokon: since your birth; or, from the time of your birth. apaarit naka auriokon: your birthday.aidu1 ki-o to swim; to dive. edui etelepat ngol noi: that boy knows how to swim. aidu2 to fire a gun or rifle; to shoot; to blast or blow up. eduit ngesi emuudu: she/he fired a gun several times. aiduc ki-o to do for a long time, keep at it; to go on doing some work. akoto aiduc aswam na: I want to keep at this work. aiducokin ki-a to do everyday, continually, or many times; to persevere, do regularly. kiducok ailip: persist in asking (praying). aidudu ki-o to roast quickly in fire, keeping the thing to be roasted in hand or moving it to and fro in the fire - as of a cob maize, a potato, cassava, dried meat, a stick, etc aiduduar ki-a to raise clouds of dust. eduduasi amotokan apua: the cars have raised clouds of dust. to rise up as clouds of dust or as clouds, swarms of birds, flies. (note: of birds, men or living animals, use ediaros: to go or rise many together; to rise, of things like dust, mist or vapour: eduaros) aiduduor ki-o to hide completely; to take away secretly. eduduo mutan ikabore: somebody has hidden my thing completely. eduduor akakinei: my goats are lost altogether. aiduiduikin ki-a to roast for.aiduk to build; to erect, construct; to step-thatch. aidukul ki-a to hollow out anything. akoto eong aidukul ekitoi koraun ataker: I want to hollow out a tree to make a canoe. sirikidukul atap: do not hollow out the millet bread (bad manners). sirikidukulata akitukes: do not pout your lips. aidukulikin ki-a to hollow out for someone or something. kidukulikinai atuba: make a trough for me. aidukulikin akan: to hook fingers to make a hollow to hold water, etc. aidukulun ki-a to dig a hole, trench or ditch for protection; to make concave. alosi eong aidukulun ikai yen aperi: I am going to build a little hut for sleeping. aidukur ki-o to camp; to bivouac like scouts; to encamp or settle in. aidul ki-o to deepen (a hole). kidul aipany na: deepen this hole. aidulel ki-o to be convex, as of a rock or any other massive object; to lie in a big heap; to be very big; to stand out. idulelei emoru: the rock is convex. aiduleor ki-o to make a somersault, overturn. to overturn; to turn over as of a motor car; to capsize. aidules depth. aidules kwap na angolol: depth below sea level.aiduleun ki-o to raise one side up and overturn this way. kiduleutu emotoka kokau: raise the back of motor car. aidulokin ki-o to make deeper; to deepen for someone; to exaggerate. kidulok aipany: make the hole deeper. aidulokin akiro: to exaggerate a tale. aidulor ki-o to make deeper. aidum to find; to receive; to accept; to get; to gain; to procure. abu kadum ejakait ejai ore: I found my master at home. aidung to cut; to incise, lacerate, nick; to offend. adung eong ekileng: the knife has cut me. ikoto ijo aidung eong etauka kakirokon: you want to say something offensive (cutting my heart). idungi ijo akiro erono: you are using offensive language. aiduny1 ki-a to be near or close to; to be neighbours. aiduny2 ki-a to place near, close to; to put near. kiduny epaaba irai: plant cotton plants close to each other. aiduny3 to toil, labour, work hard, keep at, persevere, continue; to wear oneself out. kadunyata aswam: let us work hard. idunyit ijo ngun atitai, agir je akonikiro: you toil for nothing (wear yourself out for nothing), he will not listen.aidunyakin ki-a to cause to be near each other, be contiguous; (of anything) to put near, close together; to abut. erono aidunyakin ekine nepepe k’ebu: it is bad to put a goat near a hyena to be close together; to go together; to suit each other. ikapa k’emir mam idunyakinos: a cat and a rat cannot be together. aidunyet a neighbour; the one near. erai ngesi nakidunya ka eong: she is my neighbour. aidunyetait abutment. aiduokar ki-o to go back, return. kiduokaros ber, ibongunete moi: go home now and come back tomorrow (used in anger). aiduokun ki-o to return tomorrow; to come back to (used in anger). kiduokunos moi, emamei ber lolo apak: come back tomorrow, I have no time today. aiduopokin ki-o to be finished, as of air in tyre; to go flat, as stomach with hunger. eduopokin amopiira: the tyre has become flat (empty). aiduor ki-o to swim across; to sink, as of anything in the water. lomam ejeni aidu, elosi aiduor: he who cannot swim will sink. aiduor etau: to decide, intend, or propose. eduorit eong ekatau abongor ore: I made up my mind to go home for good.aidup to fix a handle (of a hoe or any tool). kodup akulep omeleku lo: fix a handle to this hoe. aidup akiro: to interfere in a dispute or case. sirikidup akirokos: do not meddle in our dispute. aidup emuudu: to load a gun. aidupaun ki-a to beat once with a resounding blow; to explode on. aidupaunun ki-a to shell heavily; to bombard heavily with cannon or grenades. edupaunun bian edege loka ajore Ilok: the army plane yesterday bombarded cattle rustlers. aidupokin1 akim ki-o to throw into the fire or dust or powder. iponesio kon lueroko kidupokinete ijo toma akim: your bad habits are going to put you in trouble. to fall into (the fire). edupokinos acok oupa: potatoes have fallen into the hot ashes. (note: to fall into liquid is ailumokin) aidupokin2 ki-a to cast, throw on to a heap of ash, etc. kidupok acokit okuruba: cast that potato into the heap of hot ashes. aidupokin3 ki-o to interfere in, meddle with. sirikidupokin akirokos: do not meddle in our dispute. aidupor ki-o to betray; to make a dupe of; to make somebody be fined for what is not his fault, as of a father being fined for his child's mistake; to pay fine for; to renege. kedupoo ikakoku: my child made me pay a fine; or, I am fined (imprisoned) for my child. edupo aola ekokolan: a cough betrayed the thief.aidupudup ki-o to pound into powder; to powder (by walking, grinding); to cause dust; to poke ashes looking for fire; to stir up the dust (as of birds or hens) to clean themselves of fleas; to clean grain by heating. aidupudupoor ki-o to destroy completely by fire, burn to ashes or decay by age to dust. abu akim kidupudupoo ekatogo: the fire burnt my house to ashes. edupudupoor ekatogo: my house burned down completely or has decayed altogether. aidupuk ki-o to cause to be well-ground or well-cultivated; to soften. kidupuk emanikor: cause the farmland to be properly ploughed. aidur (of a man) to have sexual intercourse with a woman; to screw (a woman). (note: this word only applies to the action of a man on the woman, joint action is adurakin).aidusor ki-o to fall on the back of head.aidut1 to give out to each; to serve food to many; to endow, bestow to each; to give things away; to divide (as of cake) to many; to dispense. ejeni ekepugan aidut ajakaanut: the ruler knows how to distribute his power or posts. aidut2 to pull out completely; to weed by pulling up; to uproot. edusi aberu eduan: the woman is pulling out the weed. aiduuda ki-a to beat; to pound or stamp like cassava or dried potatoes; to beat, pound a person. iduudaete angor acokokec: the women are pounding their dried potatoes. eduudata bian kwi ekokolan: those guys clobbered a thief yesterday.aiduun ki-o to swim this way. kiduun lailo: swim this way. aiduwa ki-a to raise dust, smoke, or mist. iduwai apua: the dust is rising. iduwai emotoka lo apuru: this motorcar is belching smoke (carbon). aiduwaunun ki-a to raise dust, smoke, or mist this way. iduwaununei ijo apua lailo: you are raising dust this way. aidwal ki-a to talk nonsense; to pester by nonsense; (of a child) to suck breasts that no longer has milk. aidwal atap: to stir millet porridge well. aidwalidwal ki-a to make a soft, weak meal (by adding much water); (of woman) to run with flat breasts. kidwalidwal atap kanyama kwangin: just make some soft meal and let us eat it as it is. idwalidwaluna akuwanake kanuka ican: she/he is weak on account of poverty or worries. aidwalidwalakin ki-a (of someone with no strength) to run (of porridge) to become soft, thin. kidwalidwalak ijo da: try to run even if you have no strength. aidwar to prophesy; to foretell; to predict; to divine; to guess. abu Yesu Kristo kodwar nuka amudiario naka Jerusalem: Jesus Christ prophesied the destruction of Jerusalem. aidweny to reap or to harvest sorghum; to finish off completely (by killing or eating). kadwenyata imomwa: let us reap sorghum. yen ewei aronusyo edwenyi ican kakuj: she/he who sows sins will reap sorrow in heaven.aidwetidwet akonye ki-a to wink repeatedly. aidwom to eat vegetables with atap; to drink millet/sorghum brew before water is added; to eat greedily; to speak inopportunely; to dip into something unclean or something clean but with unclean instrument.aidya ki-a to drain away (water from well or hole); (of many birds, clouds, people, animals) to rise or move together.aidyak to miss aim. to miss (the target); to fail to reach; to fail; to go astray; to make a mistake; to commit a fault. adyak eong airem etyang: I missed spearing (killing) an animal. inyo bo adyakit eong?: what have I done wrong? aidyakar ki-a to trespass; to sin; to make a mistake or commit a crime. aidyam ki-a to beat with a long soft stick. aidyas ki-a (of anything) to go on increasing. idyatas idwe kwana osomero eidyas: the number of pupils in the school is increasing daily. aidyasetait a storing place; a treasury, storeroom. aidyat ki-a to heap up; to store, save up, conglomerate. aidyat akiro: data collection or gathering. kinyek aidyat apesenin: do not let your debts pile (heap) up. akoto eong aidyat akimai odula: I want to store up millet in the granary. idyasitos kesi akiro nuipu toma odikisyonari: they have gathered many words in the dictionary. aidyatakin ki-a to compile for another; to gather for another; to collect for another. kidyatakinai eong akiro nuka Ateso: gather for me Ateso words. aidyatakinet a gathering; a collection; a compilation. edikisyonari erai aidyatakinet naka akiro: a dictionary is a collection of words (compilation). aidyatar ki-a to gather and send away; to collect with the intention to take away. abunit eong aidyatar isirigin kane: I have come to collect money and take it away. aidyatenen ki-a to keep storing up. aidyatun ki-o to mount up; to increase. edyatunos apeseninika: my debts have mounted. to gain, to collect for oneself. aidyatus (singular noun F) a gathering, collection (of anything, also of people). aidyek to intervene, adjudicate, separate combatants; to defend; to come to the rescue, alleviate, arbitrate. koinakinai akipi kadyekia akure: give me some water to alleviate my thirst. to mediate; to separate quarrelling persons; to reconcile, intercede.kodyek luejios kwi: separate those fighters. aidyel1 ki-a to lick (something dry). adum eong akingok idyeli asaanit: I found a bitch licking a plate.aidyel2 ki-a to lift between two or more persons; to carry as of a heavy load hanging down i.e. a dead body. inyo bo idyelitos yesi?: what load are you carrying between yourselves? aidyelar ki-a to carry away (between two or more people); to lick all off. aidyelit ki-o to be carrying together. idyelitos kesi epir: they are carrying a pole. aidyelun ki-a to carry a heavy load together this way. kidyelutu ne: carry it here. aidyeny to reap or to harvest sorghum.. kadyenyata imomwa: let us reap sorghum. yen ewei aronusyo edyenyi ican kakuj: she/he who sows sins will reap sorrow in heaven.aidyo the peak; apex; acme; highest point. aiga ki-a to protect or to shield; to guard (usually with the hand or arms) against harm or a beating or heat of the sun; to dodge; to catch (water or anything) with a vessel. toto igai idweke kinyekinai ainomonom: the mother protects her children from being beaten. aiga akiro: to refuse absolutely (by turning away one's face); to excuse oneself. aigaar1 ki-a to ward off; to parry. akoto eong aibel nes, konye kigaari do ngesi ebela: I wanted to beat his head but he parried the blow (or stick). aigaar akiro: to deny (usually with gesticulations). to guard or protect oneself; to deny or refuse. egaaros ngul kotoma akiro kanu ejenete kesi: they have denied the truth. aigaar2 ki-o to take sides with combatants; to become allies. apotu Italianin kigaaros owai loka Igirimanin kojie lokiareit lokakwapin: the Italians took sides with the Germans during World War II. aigaara protection; the lee side. aigaarakon: your protection or defence. aigaet self-defence; an alibi; an excuse; a justification. aigaga ki-a to catch something falling or thrown at; to hold. kigaga ikoku ekoto aibiror: catch the child, it is going to fall. aigagaikin akanin ki-a to hold out both hands (palm up) for begging; to guard the possession due to a son or anybody; to hold for somebody; to receive for somebody; to hold in trust for someone. igagakit aberu akanin ilipi: the woman stretches out her hands when she is begging or praying. abu okokuka lokegagakit eong kotwana: my son who supported me died. aigaganakin aimat: to drink one after another from the same vessel. to give to one another; to share (anything).aigagakin ki-a to hold out both hands (palm up) for begging; to guard the possession due to a son or anybody; to hold for somebody; to receive for somebody; to hold in trust for someone. aigagam ki-a (of cereal seeds) to begin to ripen. egagamata akimai: the millet is beginning to ripen. aigagaun ki-a to hold or to catch a fallen or thrown object or falling person. kigagau emopiira kojokan: catch the ball and hold it.aigaikin ki-a to shield; to protect; to guard from harm; to shade; to place something (stick, hand, etc) in between to prevent a blow, etc; to put out a vessel for catching rainwater or overflowing water to avoid a blow by shifting aside or guarding oneself against blow (by hand or anything); to shade oneself from the heat of the sun. aigal ki-a (of more than one) to work or do together; (of many) to share work; to gang up on or against someone or something. kegalata aswam na: let us do this work together. apotu kesi kegalata eong: they united to beat me. aigalaanut helpfulness; alliance to be helpful or supportive; to be allies. aigalakin ki-a to combine to help or work for somebody. kigalakinai aswam: join me in this work. kegalakinos aiduk ekanisa: let us build the church together. aigalal ki-a to skim off (like cream from milk); to strain; to filter. igalalai totoka imomwa: my mother is straining the sorghum for making beer. aigalal edia: to eat vegetables cooked in water only, with no flavouring or groundnut paste in. aigalalaar ki-a to skim off; to do superficially. aigalalaun ki-a to skim for oneself. aigalaleta dross. aigalar ki-a to combine for common action. kopotu kegalasi aswam tetere kidauni ngesi atipet: come let us work together to finish fast. aigali ki-o to fence off; to fence round; to bar; to close off. igalit ijo erot ngol?: did you close off that road? aigaligal ki-a to attempt a task too big for one person; to weed, clean (by oneself). egaligalit eong aswam ngin: this work is too big for me alone. mam eong bon apedori aigaligal akituk: I alone cannot manage to look after all those cows. kigaligala ijo amanaka aicap: you weed my garden by yourself. aigaligalakin ki-a to drive (fish into a net, goats into the pen, cattle into the kraal, etc) in by approaching with outstretched arms from side to side. aigalikin ki-o to defend; to prevent; to support; to block. kigalik amoru okek: put a stone in front of the door to prevent it from opening or closing. kigalikinai tetere mam ngesi kenomi eong: defend me lest she/he beats me. aisigalikin: to help; to assist; to shade. emamei etunganan lok’esigalikit eong aswam na: I have nobody to help me in my work. aigalionokin ki-o to put bars, obstacles, thorns around for protection. kigalionok ikukwa orot ngol tetere mam itunga edaunete araito: put thorns on that road so that people may not finish the fruits. aigalior ki-o to block a road, etc; to shade, to prevent someone from seeing; to push aside, out of the way; to block. kigaliorit ijo eong aanyun, kolot awai: you obstruct me from seeing, move aside. igaliorit ekitoi erot: the tree has blocked the road. kigalio ekitoi awai: push the tree aside.aigalisit a curtain, drape, blind, screen, shade, or shutter; a spare or stand-by thing. aigaliun ki-o to include or fence in.egalior je awai: they have excluded him, i.e. they have simply ignored him. aigalun ki-a to mob (a person); to pool together (of anything). kegalutu inyamat kanuka epucit: let us pool the food together for the feast. aigalun einer: to talk about a person present. inyo bo kigalunitotor?: why did they mob you?aigam ki-a to lie, tell falsehood. igami ekesa ngol: that man is lying.aigamakin ki-a to calumniate, lie; to perjure, fib, tell stories, be economical with the truth; to slander. sirikigamak eong akiro: do not calumniate me. aigamar ki-a to tell off straight away; to attack at once; to assault as soon as a person appears. inyo bo kigamaria ijo eong?: why did you tell me off like that? aiganan ki-a to sit on one’s buttocks with legs apart; to be the boss, i.e. sit and give orders for things to be done. aigang1 ki-a to support another or to ally; to plead, advocate for. igangas ngul etubete akakiro: they support one another in settling my case. aigang2 ki-a to make stand (as of a kiln, roof, etc) by using props; to build a brick kiln. kegangata emukaru: let us pile a brick kiln. aigang akito: to pile firewood ready to set fire on. aigangakin ki-a to give support to; to take sides with; to encourage; to be ally to. kigangakinai eong kotoma akiroka: side with me in my cause. to support one another, help one another, encourage one another; to be ally. kegangakinos kotoma aswamuwok: let us help one another in our work. aiganganar ki-a to keep on supporting (as of a sick person who is too weak to help herself/himself). kopaikisi yesi ne aiganganar lokadekan kinga: stay here to take the sick person out regularly. to support one another; to help one another; to side one with another (in a case). aiganget a defence, backing, a foundation, a support. aigangigang ki-a to be unable to do a work by oneself only. egangigangit eong aswam ngin elope bon: I am doing the work I cannot do by myself. aigangun ki-a to prop up, support; to stay. ebela iganguni akimat: the stick supports an old woman. igangunete ipirin etogo: the poles support the house. to lean against; to support oneself; to steady oneself. aigar1 ki-a to drive fish into a trap. igarete angor agaria aitiiban: the women drive the fish into the fishing net.aigar2 to be too big to fit; to be jammed; to be stuck. agarit eong ekek: I am too big to get through the door (or I cannot pass through this narrow door). aigarar ki-a to sit astride; to stretch out legs (while sitting). kiboikin ejok, sirigararai: sit decently, not with legs parted out aigasigas ki-a to be just alive; to be just breathing. eringa lokadekan igasigasi: the sick man is still breathing with difficulty. aigasiikin ki-a to become dirty, stained, or filthy. ikoku yen koleje alai egasiiki noi kwana: the child who used to be very clean is now very dirty. igasiikit ekonimoyo: your soul has become evil. aigat to curse thieves or debtors, as by the Isureta clan (clan of cursers) (the aggrieved people together with a suspected thief gather around an anthill where they burn a white chicken alive while the curser shouts, ‘mutan kotwana’ (let so-and-so die) and the people answer, ‘kotwana, ibweny-ibweny’ (let him/her die completely), then Isureta will block holes of the anthill with leaves of itulel and everyone runs off from the anthill without looking back. If the person cursed is the actual thief, he/she may begin to die within a few days unless he/she pays back what was stolen plus a fine of a cow to Isureta who will then unblock the holes of the anthill); to wish good health to the sick; to wish someone prosperity. aigatar ki-a to slip; to walk unsteadily, make a mistake. erot loerurut einakini itunganan aigatar: a slippery road causes a person to walk unsteadily.aigaun ki-a to be pregnant (early months). aigaun akiro: listen attentively, often with hand pulling the pinna (ear). kigautu akiro: listen attentively. aigaun akipi: to trap or catch water with hands or a vessel. ipu akipi nuigauna: much water was collected. aigaunet a receptacle for catching water; a tank; something for warding off attack; a defence; argument. ebela erai eigaunet: a stick is a defence weapon. nuinera ijo mam eraas aigaunet: what you say is no defence. aige to start to do something; to begin; to originate; to leave befor someone; to move in front of someone. koge ber aiduk etogo: begin first to build a house. first; to begin with. aige, kolot ber ainyam: to begin with (first of all), go and eat. aigel to sort out; to segregate; to pay a fine, to pay indemnity, damages; compensate, award. akoto eong aigel akakiro: I want to pay my fine. aigel asurup: to pay a fine for having murdered a person; to pacify the relations of murdered man, so that they do not take any vengeance on the murderer. aigen ki-a to eat alone or by oneself. erono aigen inyamat kiteete luce: it is bad to eat food alone while others look on. aigeng ki-a to trot, run slowly. koge aigeng, abu edou: start running slowly, the rain has come or it begins to rain. aigengigeng ki-a (of a short man or animal) to run; to run with short steps and slowly; to trot. aiger1 ki-o to measure or mark a plot; to mark. aiger2 to engrave, inscribe; to tattoo with tribal marks; to scarify; to write; to draw blood with small incisions so as to treat some disease when medicine is smeared on the cuts; to put stripes on pots, calabashes, or gourds. angor kesi egerete iburuo: only women do the tattooing. aigerosit an engraving; a mark (as of a house plan or that of a boundary). aigesiges ki-a to sweat, perspire profusely. kegesiges eong: I am sweating profusely. aitegesiges: to make to perspire profusely. itegesigesi aswam ngin: that work makes one sweat. aigesitoi ki-o to stagger; to try make an effort. kigesitoi ijo kwapekwangin: keep on trying; do not give up.igeta ngesi bala lokameran: she/he walks unsteadily like a drunken man. aiget2 ki-a to slice potatoes, cassava, bananas, etc. aigetanar ki-o to stagger; to try make an effort. igetanar ijo bala imera: you stagger as if you are drunk. aigetar ki-o to wobble, dodder, stumble backwards or sideways; to toddle; to lose your balance; to falter, make a mistake. apotu kesi kigetaros: they went staggering away or they made a mistake. aigetigeta ki-a to go or walk drunkenly, wobble, stagger, walk unsteadily, etc. igetigetas eong idwe kore kangina: my children at home are very weak, wobbling about. aigigin ki-a to eat much; to gormandise. aigik ki-a to keep punching or prodding in the stomach. inyo bo kigikia ijo eong?: why do you punch me in the stomach? aigikakin ki-a to punch a person in the ribs or stomach; to prod in any part of the body. kegikaki ngesi eong amarana: she/he punched me on the ribs. aigikaun ki-a to prod in the stomach; to punch. kegikau lolo ejakait eong kanuka esolo: the chief punched my stomach because of taxes. aigim ki-o to test, try, attempt, make an attempt. egim ikoku alosit: the child has tried to walk.aigimokin ki-o to find out; to experiment, try out, inspect. kolot kigimok ber erot: go and find out the way. aigimor ki-o to try, experience; to find out; to test. egimo eong etunganan ngol, konye mam bobo akoto nges: I tested that man, but I do not like him now to try, attempt. egimoros kesi auta, konye akuruokis: they tried to wrestle but failed. egimos akonyeka emong ngol: my eyes are pleased with that bull. aigip to peer up, distinguish at a distance; to notice; to recognise far off; to see far off. abu eong kagipa ijo ilwana: I recognised you at a distance. aigir1 ki-a to inscribe; to engrave; to write; to scratch into; to comb, mark out; to make lines.aigir2 to refuse, disclaim; to renounce; to deny, disown, or abnegate. to fail; to be unsuccessful. egirit akuwan: I am not feeling alright; my health is failing.aigirakin ki-a to engrave on; to write to; to mark out for someone else. akoto aigirakin ijo ebalua: I want to write to you. kigirakinai eong etogo: measure a house for me. aigiretait a line, a mark; a comb made of ox-rib; a writing, engraving. aigirigir1 ki-a to do script writing; to write like a child (illegibly), draw crooked lines. aigirigir2 ki-a to engrave often; to carve often; to write often, etc to be a carver; to be a writer or clerk, engraver. aigirigiret writing, writ, script, symbols, inscription, letters, text. aigirigireta: scriptures. aigisetait a splinter; a strip; a sliver; a shred; a fragment; a chip. aigit1 ki-a to clear the throat; to cough; to take off outer fibre of sugarcane; to strip off; to chip off. aigit2 to choke, obstruct, throttle, suffocate. agit ikoku acokit: the potato has choked the child. aigit3 to sort out, distinguish; to separate; to classify; to sever, put apart. aigitakin ki-a to splinter for; to strip off for, or peel for; to clear the throat (to attract somebody’s attention). egitakin akitoi obokoritika: a stick has splintered in my finger. kigitakinai eong ekaajo: peel the sugarcane for me. aigitar ki-a to clear throat; to cough. kigita eporoto kowou ekosio: clear your throat and sing a song.aigo akiro: to straighten out a case; to clear up using strong arguments. egoi etunganan ngol akiro kotoma atukot: he clinches the case by strong arguments in court.aigogo a nest for hens; a cavity, grave.aigogol ki-a to entangle; to trip up. sirikigogoloto lucetelepai ipesete emopiira: do not trip your fellow boys in the football game. aigogoleor ki-o to tackle, as in football; to cause to stagger, trip. inyo bo igogoleoro ijo nges?: why did you trip her/him? to stagger and fall. aigogwa ki-a (of people) to have sexual intercourse.aigoikin ki-o to grip tightly; to clamp; to clasp; to lock up; to lean on. kigoik ikusiboro togo: lock up your things in the house. aigol to shut, close; to lock; to prevent. kogol ekek: shut the door. egolit ngesi erotoka lokadumun aswam: she/he/it is preventing me from getting work. to be last. Okolimo egolit: Okolimo is the last (in class, in a sport). aigoligol ki-o to stir; to disturb (a liquid with stick. or spoon). kigoligol ber eles kagolot: first frighten out the squirrel from the tree hole with a stick. aigoligolokin ki-a to stir up; to poke in or at (with stick). kigoligolok etogo kere, tetere emir elomuni: poke round the things in the house so as to frighten out the rat. aigoligolun ki-o to cook quickly. kigoligol aditap kanyam: just cook a little food quickly and let me eat. aigong1 ki-a to walk infirmly, needing support; to loiter; to jog, saunter. aigong2 to lean something against or on, upon; to put against; to abut. kinyekisi aigong iboro arwatat: do not lean things against the wall. aigongakin ki-a to start running unsteadily (as an old man does). aigongigong ki-a (of a person who has no strength) to run. igongigongi ngesi bala emojong: she/he runs like an old man. kigongigong akwap, angatu edou: start running away, it is going to rain. aigongor ki-o to put things haphazardly (into room or box); to put things topsy-turvy. kinap iboro ejok, sirigongor kes aigongor: pack things neatly, do not just throw them anyhow. aigonon ki-o (of tree) to be heavily laden with fruit. aigooda ki-a to walk in an unnatural way (especially like a woman in advanced pregnancy); to be affected in manner of walking; to walk with affectation; to be proud, showy. igoodaete lolo itelepai kotoma agwelanaret: the boys are walking in an affected manner in the market. aigoodakin ki-a to show off for or somewhere. igoodakinete itelepai apesur: boys show off in the presence of girls. aigoonokin ki-o to repetitively hammer away or lock up. aigor1 (of pregnant woman) to be tired by hard work to tire out; to weary; to fatigue. aigor2 to get out with one’s finger (as dirt from ear, mouth or nose). aigore ki-a to put in a corner, aside, out of the way. kigoreata igaalin agule: put your bicycles aside. aigorear ki-a to tuck away; to hide inside. kigorea akituk, abu amuranikon: hide the cows, your father-in-law has come. to be hidden; to be put inside. kigorear, abu lokasurup: hide yourself, your enemy has come.aigoreikin ki-a to hide, put in a corner for; to drive into a corner (as cattle or men); to tuck away. kigoreik akituk awai kotubor amotoka: drive the cattle aside to let the car pass. aigorigor ki-a to keep poking at (mouth, nose or ear); (of worms) to dig a hole in a tree, etc; to explore, examine. sirikigorigor ekumekon: do not prod your nose. David Livingstone ngesi abu kigorigor Africa: David Livingstone explored Africa. aigorigora ki-a to be infirm, hoarse; to speak in a low tone; to grumble. egorigora eong, mam apedori alosit Kampala: I am too infirm, I cannot go to Kampala. aigorigorar ki-o to move quickly but unsteadily (as on a bicycle). aigorigorit ki-o to be weak from long illness. igorigorit ngol, sirikebuu: he is weak, do not let him come. aigorigorokin ki-a to poke at (in, etc) for someone else; to explore for. kigorigorokinoi eong akwap nako Karamoja: explore the Karimojong country for me. aigoror ki-o (of birds about to fly) to spread out wings to flex one’s arms ready to pounce at someone; to be fully fledged. aigu ki-a to knock the toe or foot against; to stumble the foot against.aiguanakin ki-a to keep stumbling. aigugunaar1 ki-a to be overloaded, overdressed, overburdened. ai bo igugunaaros yesi?: where are you going with your heavy loads?igugunai ejakait iketunga: the chief oppresses his people. kinyekisi aiguguna amotoka: do not overload the car. aigugunatoi ki-o to be carrying about a great load; to be overloaded, oppressed. aigugunaun ki-a to come heavily loaded; to be burdened to bring heavy load. kigugunaunos bo yesi kai?: where have you come from with such a heavy load? aiguikin ki-a (of foot or toe) to knock against; to stumble; to trip; to be scandalised. keguiki eong: I stumbled. aiguk ki-a to punch; to give a punch.kanukinyo kigukakinia ijo eong?: why did you hit me? ai bo kigukakinia ngesi ijo?: from where did he punch you? ai bo kigukakit ngesi ijo?: what part of your body did he hit you? aigul ki-a to speak a language as an expert at it; to know a language well. iguli ngol Aswairin noi: he is an expert at Kiswahili. aigulakin ki-a to address a person in a foreign language. aigulanakin ki-a to punch; to keep talking to people in a foreign language to punch or box one another. igulanakinos idwe: the children are boxing. aigular ki-a to interpret for people away from speaker. aigule ki-a to make an enclosure; to form a bay; to walk round an enclosure; to put things in the backyard. aigulear ki-a to put or take aside; to cut off the way. aigulugulaar ki-a to rattle, rumble (as of fluid in stomach). igulugula akakoik: my stomach is rumbling.aigulugul ikingok: to shake a pup after feeding on milk so that it may grow more quickly. aigulugulakin ki-a to build a little hut for goats or sheep; to rattle out words of a language unknown to the listeners. egulugulaki Emusugut Amusugun: the white man rattled out his English (to those who do not understand English) to speak to one another in foreign languages not understood. itunga luko Babel apotu kigulugulanakinos: the people of Babel spoke and did not understand one another. aigulun ki-a to interpret for an audience here. aigum to aim, to pierce or to shoot with an arrow; to sting. aigum akituk: to bleed cattle. agumun aokot: to draw blood. aigumugumitoi ki-o to sneak along. aigun ki-a to eat much.aigunuguna ki-a to struggle in vain; to show refusal by struggling. igunuguna apese na: this girl is refusing (by wriggling). aigur ki-o to stir, mix, or mash. aigur abeei: to beat eggs; to mix eggs well. aiguret a ladle; something for stirring. aigurokin ki-a to stir for; to stir once. aiguror ebalua: to write a sarcastic or sharp letter. aigurugur1 ki-a to run whilst carrying a load in front of one; to rattle (of stomach). kiguruguraros ka ikoku ore, abu edou: go home with the child, it is going to rain.aigurugur2 ki-o to keep stirring; to disturb; to stir or cook a little food by oneself; (of a burrow) to dig deep and with cellars. akoto aigurugur ikatap bon, kapas eong aitanyam luipu: I want to prepare a little food for myself, I am tired of feeding many. aiguruguro ki-o to mumble; to grumble; to speak in a low or deep tone; to whisper in a low deep tone. ejaas luiguruguros kotogo kaje: there are people murmuring in that room. aigurugurooro ki-o (of anthill or rat holes) to be dug deep with cellars. aigurumun ki-a to make a short and round-bellied granary or pot. aigurun1 ki-o (of things and speech or opinions) to get mixed up; to be in disorder. kanyoutu kane, egurunos akiro: let us go away, there is a mix-up here. aigurun2 ki-o to stir or mash for oneself; to stir this way; to stir feelings of people. kigurutu atap kedenyiata erot: mingle a little food for our journey. eguru ekesa ngol akiro nuedwarak: he has stirred up the feelings of people by sarcastic language. aigwa to provoke; to incite; to calumniate, slander, challenge. sirikigwa eong: do not provoke me. aigwaigwa ki-a (of skin) to have eczema; (of skin) to be rough, not smooth. igwaigwait akakuwan: I have eczema.aigwaka ki-a to have illicit sexual intercourse; to cohabit (of human beings only); to fornicate.aigwakakin ki-a to have sexual intercourse with somebody's wife. aigwar to scratch; to lacerate. kagwar eong ekukwai: the thorn has scratched me. aigwe (Serere) to coil; to fold round; to mould. kogwe aikit kibwokia akito: coil a head pad for carrying fire-wood. aigweny (Serere) to finish completely.aigwerakin ki-a to prune for or somewhere. kigwerakinai ekitoi ngol: prune that tree for me. aigwerar ki-a to make bare (as of a tree or plant by stripping off its leaves); to prune bare too much. to be bare, leafless. aigwet to remove support, seat, prop, etc and make fall; to keep switching on (as of electric lights, radios, etc). aigwiligwila ki-a to twinkle, sparkle, glimmer, gleam, flicker, or glow. aigwong ki-a to rejoice; to acclaim, applaud, exult; to applaud; to acclaim; to extol. abu ngesi kigwong kerem engatuny: she/he was exultant after spearing the lion.aigwongakin ki-a to rejoice on account of; to applaud; to exult. kigwongakisi emuu eberu: rejoice for the woman has given birth to twins.iiri ngesi inyamat: he/she is tasting the food. aiiranar ki-a to keep obeying or listening to (understand); to be intelligent. aiirar1 (singular noun F) understanding; cognition; obedience. aiirar2 ki-a to hear; to understand; to hearken; to listen. iirasi yesi?: do you hear? have you heard? aiires taste. ejai nges aiires naka ajon: she/he has a taste (for beer); a good judgement. aiires (for) tasting. ajon nukiires: beer for tasting. aija ki-a to accept, take from, collect, hand over, respond to call; to take and to give; to serve and to receive; to echo, give a present. kolot kija esolo: go and collect the tax. ejaan esolo: tax collector. ijaete imor: the mountains echo. aijaanakin ki-a to serve, keep handing over. akoto ijo aijaanakin eong: I want you to serve me. aijaar ki-a to accept; to receive from; to take away from. kijaa nges: take it. aijaar akiro: to reply; to echo. aijaar aikor: to take away for distribution. aijaaret an echo, reverberation, resonance, ricochet, or repetition. iremanakini ekingok aijaareteke: the dog is barking at its echo. aijadaanar ki-o to slouch, walk lazily. aijaet echo; reverberation; resonance. iremanakini ekingok aijaeteke: the dog barks at its echo. aijaikin ki-a to hand over to; to donate to; to serve to; to offer; to permit, give permission; to donate; to lend, concede; to impart, give or supply. kijaikinai ibore ngin: hand me that thing. akoto kijaik eong alosit ore: I want you to give me permission to go home. kijaik nges: give him. kijaikinai eong: give me. aijait ki-a to hold out arm for begging; to beg, implore, supplicate.ijaka ngesi kanuka aipas: she/he is staggering with tiredness. ajakit akure: to be thirsty. aijak2 to open with difficulty; to take off a thing stuck to something else (like taking off a stamp from a letter or open a lid of a box nailed down); to help deliver (a child or calf) at difficult birth. aijak akituk: to open the mouth when lips are parched with thirst or when jaws are swollen; to press down bottom jaw. ajakit akure: throat dried up, difficult to swallow, hence to be thirsty. ajakit eong itaok: I helped at the birth of calf by pulling it out. ajak ngesi akanin nuka lokatwan: she/he separated the clasped hands of a dead man. kajakit eong eibel loka akiring: I want to satisfy or to relieve the longing for meat. aijak anyakaeta: to be exhausted (with jaws hanging). aijakijak ki-a (of cats or dogs drinking) to lap up.aijakun ki-a to wear out, down; to exhaust, finish. kejakunit eong adeka: illness has weakened, worn me down, or finished me. aijal to give away freely, surrender, forsake, cede, leave to; to offer up, or sacrifice. ajalit eong akaijar kanuka akwapuka: I am risking my life for my country. aijalaanar ki-o to loiter, wait, hang around, linger, dally, skulk, dawdle, or loaf. aijalakin ki-a to be negligent about;
