to be sluggish in; to be careless with. ijalakin ijo kotoma akoniswam: you are negligent in your work regularly. ejalakinos itunga lu kaswamukec: these people are careless about their work. aitajalakin akoik: to relax the stomach (when tied too tight). aijalijala ki-a to be sluggish, negligent, careless; to do sluggishly, slovenly, lax; to have no zeal in work. ijalijalas kesi kotoma aswamusineikec: they are lazy or careless in their work. kejalijalit eong akuwan bala akoto adekakin: I feel weak as if about to fall sick. aijalionor ki-o to walk lazily, proudly, sluggishly. sirijalionor korot ilosi, kiwonyi atipet: do not walk so proudly on the road, be quick. aijam ki-a (of a fat man, slow walker, etc) to get off, start off; (of woollen blanket) to be soft. akoto eong aijam eringa akwap ecai: (I am a fat person) I want to start off before it is dark. aijamam ki-a to be at leisure, sit idle; to be idle, workless; to keep calm; to loaf; to vegetate. ijamamai ijo kaswamukon: you are at peace in your work. aijamijam1 ki-a to talk nicely; to get round a person, to persuade; to induce; to tempt; sirikijamijam eong, mam alosi aiyuun: do not tempt me, I shall not agree.aijamijam2 ki-o (of clouds) to lower. ejamijamun edou lo aicek lolo kia: this cloud is hovering low, it may rain the whole night. aijamijama ki-a (of soil after rain, or of a woollen blanket) to be soft. sirikijamijam eong, mam alosi aiyuun: do not tempt me, I shall not agree.aijamijamakin ki-a to neglect. ijamijamakit aberu ngin ikedwe: that woman is soft on her bad-mannered children.aijang ki-a to shake; to rock. kinyek aijang ekitoi: stop shaking the tree. aijangar ki-a to shake off; to awaken somebody by shaking them. aijangar akuwan: to take bodily exercise (by moving the body, shaking it, doing physical exercise). to be shaky; to be ill.to try something difficult. kolototo kijangaros aut kangina: go and try to wrestle over there. aijangaun ki-o to appear fastidious, finicky, faddy, or fussy; to come to a person with fastidious ways. aijangijang ki-a to shake repeatedly, agitate. ijangijangi ijo emeesa: you are shaking the table. aijangijanga ki-a to be unsteady; to tremble; to shake; to rock; to stagger; to be fastidious, difficult to please, squeamish. ijangijangas apapulai: the papers are shaking (in the wind). aijany ki-a to flourish; (of a family – ateker) to have many members; to grow out into many branches. ijanyit ekitoi ngol: that tree has many branches.aijar namam edaun: eternal life. aikul aijar: to enjoy or gratify oneself.aijar2 to be alive; to be healthy; to escape from danger; (of a female) to bring forth or deliver an offspring. ejarit ngesi: she/he is alive, healthy. ajar eong kotoma adeka: I have recovered from sickness. ajar akaberu ipese: my wife has delivered a baby girl.aijarijar ki-a to make loose; to slacken (a rope). aijarijara to be too loose, too slack, too big, not to fit. aijaun kia.to receive in the hands; to accept; to welcome a guest. aijaun ekosio: to sing the refrain of a song. aijaun akiro: to accept, believe. sirikijau akiro numam ijeni: do not believe any story that you are not sure of. aijaun akoik: to be pregnant. ajaun aberuka akoik: my wife is pregnant. aije to mould pots; to weave mats or baskets; to plait with grass; to weave; to make grass granary; to make round. kojeata amoti aare: mould two pots. kojeikinai edula: make me a granary of clay and grass. kojeasi ngesi ngina arai bo kojeutu ngesi ne: mould it over there or do it here. aijeburikin ki-o to be abandoned, derelict or relinquished. ireria lu kere ijeburikitos: all these homes are desolate. aijec1 (singular noun F) prolonged pain after childbirth; abortion through natural causes (not intentional); miscarriage.aijec2 ki-a (of women and animals) to abort; to speak the whole truth; to say all one knows, speak out. aberu ngin etapit aijec idwe: that woman is fond of aborting. abu ngesi kijece akiroke inera: she/he told the whole truth.aijecakin ki-a to abort for. akiteng ngin abu kijecak itaok idiope, kasodi eong agwelar nges: that cow aborted once, so I sold it. aijece ki-a to do on purpose; to do deliberately. aijeceikin ki-a to do on purpose; to do deliberately. aijecun ki-a to abort or miscarry (a pregnancy). aijek ki-o to rock; to hang up; to shake; to swing; to raise on high; to dangle; to depend. kijek ikonigoen arwatat: hang your clothes on the wall. ijeki emuron akae: the witchdoctor is shaking the rattle. kijekono ikoku motoko kinyek aimony: rock the child to and fro, perhaps it may stop crying.aijekeun1 ki-o to swing up and down. ejekeun akekoik kanuka etengei: his stomach swings up and down on account of hunger. ijekeunit enenwa akou kokitoi: the bat hangs head down from the tree. aijekeun2 ki-o to let down (as of a basket from a tree, or a bucket on a rope). aijekijeko ki-o a repetition of aijek: to swing, etc; to shake. kidol jo Kampala airabes ijekijekos imeederan: if you reach parliament in Kampala the flags flutter in the wind.aijekokin1 ki-o to be too short, too little, not long enough, not enough, not sufficient, insufficient. ejekokin auno na, mam edolit aitem etogo: this string is too short, it is not long enough to measure the house.aijekokin2 ki-o to hang up. kijekok etaala kuju: hang up the lamp.aijekoor ki-a to hang or to swing away. aijekor ki-o to be little or too little; to be short, insufficient. ejekoros inyamat kakoikika: my stomach is empty with too little food in it. aijel1 ki-a to lick (anything, like a dog does). ijeli ikapa akekuwan: the cat is licking its body.aijel2 ki-o to swing legs, when sitting on tree or table or high place; (of broken leg, cloth hung to dry) to swing in the wind.aijelel1 ki-o (Serere) to sleep on a bed. ejelelei eong kokuju oitaada: I am sleeping on the bed.aijelel2 ki-o to rain heavily but locally. ejelel edou ko Kapir: it rained heavily in Kapir. aijelelaar1 ki-o to glide or slide away (as of a snake). aijelelaar2 ki-a to hurl, launch, throw by force (as of a catapult, sling, etc). ijelelaanarete idwe ikojoi kotoma akabwaikec: the children hurl arrows with their bows. aijeleleikin ki-o to put on top of a shelve; to shelve (as of kitchen things, cups etc); to put on a table after cleaning. aijeleleun ki-o to glide this way, towards us. aijeliar ki-a to slide away; to slip away; to freewheel; to roll away; (of life) to ebb away; to be slowly flying. aijelijel ki-a (of food or drink) to be tasteless; to be fed up with. aijelijelikin ki-a to be tired of or fed up with; to have a disgust for somebody or something (used with etau: the heart). ijelijelit ekatau ekesa ngol: I cannot bear the sight of that guy. ejelijelakinos itunga lu itawonokec: these people cannot stand each other. aijem ki-a to taste with tongue once. kijem edia arai edolit amuunyu: taste the sauce if the salt is enough.aijemijem ki-a to taste with tongue more than once. kijemijem ecaai arai ejijim: taste the tea if it is sweet.aijen1 (singular noun F) knowledge; understanding; perception, or sense; cognition.kijeni ijo eong?: do you know me? ejeni ngesi aijen: she/he knows very well. aijen aberu: to have carnal knowledge of a woman. ejena ngesi noi: she/he is well-known, or is esteemed. aijeng to flay; to skin (as of an animal); to cut open by surgery; to slaughter; (of animals) to cut up or to skin; to operate upon.aijeny to clean with fingers (as of food from plate or ladle).kojep ekitoi: cut down the tree, fell the tree. aijep etunganan: to cheat a person out of his belongings; to defraud, swindle, con, dupe, or trick. ejepi ejakait ngol iketunga k’acoa: that chief cleverly defrauds (cons) his people.aijer1 ki-a to belch. aijer egwei: to belch from indigestion or constipation; to have an evil breath. aijer2 ki-a to twist (rope); to screw; to unwind; to twist words or statements, twist the neck, or to wring cloth. sirikijerak akakiro: do not twist my words. aijerun edoi: to twist a rope (for chasing birds or locusts).aijer3 (of anything) to spread out on ground to dry or for any other reason. kojera amukeke kooko: spread the sliced potatoes to dry. kojeras egoe kaany eong: spread or hold out the cloth, let me see. aijerakin ki-a to screw on or off; to twist together; to twist (words) for; to twist (neck) for; to wind (as of watch); to contort. kijerakinai eong auno: twist for me a rope. sirikijerak akakiro: do not twist my words. to squirm, writhe, twist, or struggle. aijerasit a screw, spiral marks of a saw or plane; unevenness. aijeruko ki-o to be unmanageable; to rebel against; to be rebellious; to walk proudly, slowly. sirijeruko kakonye kapapakon: do not be rebellious against your father. ijerukos itelepai lu: these boys are unmanageable. aijerukokin ki-o to rebel against.aijerun akonye ki-a to look sideways angrily at somebody. aijerun ki-a to belch. aijerun inyamat: to belch (due to satisfaction). aijes1 ki-a to slip or put down; to let down (as of price or like putting shillings on the table, millet into the granary, etc). kijes ikonisirigin omeesa: put your money on the table (i.e. letting them slip from hands). kijesasi ekusitiai kwap: lower your price. aijes eporoto ki-a to lower the voice, inflect the voice. aijes einer: to speak at a low tone; to modulate speech. aijes awoere: to sing in lower tones. aijes2 to be coloured thus. ejesi akonikiteng ai?: what colour is your cow? ejesi bee: it is red. ejesi cuc: it is black. ejesi kia: it is very white. ejesi pus: it is grey. ejesi naese: it is mottly grey. ejesi naongor: it is dark brown. aijesakin ki-a to slip, glide, go down, or to slope down. erot lo ijesakin kwap obuka: this road goes down to my village. aijesar ki-a to put down (as of price); to let down, abase a thing high up; to let slip down; to pour out. to glide, go, slip down (as one going down-hill, etc); to slip down, slide, decline. to go down; to diminish (as of water in river, as of people or anything); to slope down. aijesaret effusion; abasement; demeaning; degradation. aijesitoi ki-o to totter (like a child or drunken person).kijesu eporotokon: lower your voice. to diminish; to slope down, become smaller, slide down. to come down this way; to diminish; to descend; (of rain or water) influx.. ejesunos ikiliok ajesa: the men have come down into the valley. aijet to look like. ejesi kia: looks very white.ajiun to fight for; to try very hard to do something. ajiun apugan: to fight for self-governance. aiji to fight; to contend; to resist; to race, conflict. akoto aiji kajo kegaali: I want to race with you on the bicycle. ejiete kesi: they are fighting. ejiosi itelepai: the boys are fighting. ajiun apolou: to fight or struggle for one’s status (and win). aijiar ki-a to polish with fat or anything.aijie to coil (rope or carrying pad); to make round. ejieete angor aikita: the women coil the carrying pads. aijier to spread out to dry; to dry in the sun.kolot ber aijier acok: go and spread out to dry the potatoes (in the sun). aijiiko a spoon; a ladle.aijikakin ki-a to block up, close up (as of road, door, ear with cotton); to have constipation. ijikakit ngesi erot k’ikukwa: she/he has blocked the road with thorns. ijikakina erot: the road is blocked. ijikakina akit: the ear is blocked, she/he is deaf. ijikakina akoik: she/he has constipation. aijikar ki-a to absorb (as of liquids); to dry up through absorption. aijilil ki-a to strain; to distil; to filter (liquids); to sift. kijilil akipi kolema agasia: strain the water to remove the dirt.aijililaar ki-a to drain away. to disappear (as of water after rain); to infiltrate.aijililet a strainer; a sieve; a filter.aijililiar ki-a to drain away. to disappear (as of water after rain); to infiltrate.aijililikin ki-a to filter into or for; to instil. kijililik akipi amot na: filter the water into this pot. aijililikinet a sieve; a strainer.aijim ki-o to be cloudy, misty, no sunshine. ijimit lolo akwap: it is very cloudy, hazy, misty today. aijimiikin ki-a to develop into wounds or ulcers; to be covered with ulcers or sores; to be ulcerated. akakuwan kere ekoto aijimiikin: my whole body is going to become ulcerated (be covered with ulcers, sores). aijimijim ki-o (of weather) to be drizzling; to be cloudy; to be overcast; to spit a little (like a snake); to tremble with cold. ijimijimi emun aimul: the snake spits poison. ijimijimi edou akwap: it drizzles. ejimijimit eong akuwan aterot: I am not feeling well on account of the cold.aijimikin ki-a to hurt; to be sore. ijimikit akakuwan kanuka aterot: I feel very cold.aijimokin ki-o (of the sky) to be very cloudy or dark with rain; to spit a little. ijimokit Soroti, bala etepi edou: it is very dark over Soroti as if it is raining there. aijip to look at or inspect (a very small object like a jigger in one’s foot) carefully; to look sharp.aijipijip to keep looking sharply (at a small thing, like a jigger or small thing fallen on the ground); to go and look; to go and find out. aijir ki-a to drizzle; to cry or weep softly. aijirijir aimony: to weep softly. aijirijir awoore: to sing softly. kinyek akiru kijira, kolot: let the drizzle cease, and then go. aijiriar ki-o to relent; to go slowly; to freewheel.aijirijir ki-a to be drizzling; to sing softly; to mourn quietly. aijirijir eporoto: to croon. aijirijiriar ki-a to rain a little; to slacken (of rain or liquids); to boil away (as of liquids slowly boiling and evaporating away). ejirijiriasi akipi ngun, kodaka awai: that water is boiling away, take it from the fire and put it aside. aijirikin1 ki-a to sprinkle in drops (as of salt, dust, etc); to pour out a little. kijirik akipi eboga: sprinkle water on the vegetables. loibatisai ijirikini ngesi akipi oreet: he who baptises pours a little water on another’s forehead.aijirikin2 ki-o to refuse to leave a place. ejirikin ngesi togoke: she/he has refused to leave her/his house.aijo ki-o to pour without missing target (as of liquid); to let fall; to take to heart (of words). kolot aijo akipi amot: go and pour water into the pot. aijobira ki-a to go about aimlessly, pointlessly, uselessly, without direction or without purpose; to roam or wander about. aijodijod ki-a to try to persuade repeatedly; to try to prevail on; to misadvise; to hop on one leg. kijodijod ekesa ngol alosit ore: persuade that guy to go home.aijodo ki-o to persuade; to prevail on; to advise, adulate, pull wires.kejodoi eong jo alosit: I am persuading you to go.aijodoet flattery; sweet talk; smooth talk; sycophancy; adulation. aijogan ki-a to feel excited. aisijogan: to excite, enthuse, animate, motivate or agitate. aijoikin ki-o (of liquids) to pour into; (of things) to pour into; (of animals or people) to gather into. kijoik akile ocupa: pour milk into the bottle. kijoik akimai odula: put the millet into the granary. kijoik akituk auj: drive the cows into the kraal. to gather; to contain, hold much. ejoikinos akipi nuipu toma ataagi ngin: a great deal of water has gone into that tank.aijoja ki-a (of a few amongst many) to fight or beat; (of one against more than one) to fight roundabout, running in all directions. abu eong kejoja kokiding otunga luepu noi: I fought in the midst of many people. to change or to be changed about often. lukapolok ijojaete esisianakinan: the authorities shift the teacher about. aijoja atapen: to keep shifting the grinding stone from one hand to the other. aijoja akiro: to go from one to another, telling them a story or news. aijojakinit lailo laije: to dart here and there in vain. aijoja ikiliok: (of a cheating woman) to play one man against another; to double deal.aijojaanakin ki-a to gather crowd (of men, animals, fish, etc) together in one place; to drive together, rushing about. aijojaanakin ibaren luiramiramere: to drive livestock together in a sown millet field (to trample the seeds into the soil). aijojatoi ki-a to be astir. aijok ki-o to change from place to place. kapas eong aijokio ikar kere: I am tired of being transferred every year.aijokokin ki-o to change to another place; to transfer. ejokokit eong akakituk orekon: I have transferred my cows to your home. to exchange. kejokokinos oni akituk aare: let us exchange two cows. aijokor ki-o to change; to take to, remove to another place. kijoko eicolong lo ngina: shift this chair there. aijolakin ki-a to serve; to be a waiter to. akoto ijo kijolak eong kane ajai: I want you to serve me from where I am.aijolil ki-o to steal constantly, secretly. kidoido je aijolil iboro k’itunga: the habit of stealing people’s property is now engrained in him.aijolilis a crane or pulley for lifting loads. aijolior ki-o to lower carefully; steal quietly.aijoliun ki-o to lower carefully. aijom ki-a (of tree branches) to spread out; (of family) to spread out, to branch out, or to expand afar. ijomit emuria noi: the weeds have spread out very much. aijom alosit: to waddle; to walk slowly, heavily (like a fat person or animal). ijomijomi epege alosit: the pig waddles when walking.aijomoor ki-o to ensnare from somewhere; to persuade and lead away; to lead a person away into a trap; to deceive or ambush. ekoto ngesi aijomoor eong oreke: she/he wants to trick me into going to his home (to take me there to beat). aijomoun ki-o to ensnare from here; to persuade and lead this way; to lead a person this way into a trap; to decoy, deceive or ambush. akoto eong aijomoun ngesi oreka: I want to trick him to my home (to bring him here to harm). aijong ki-a to take some away or off; to cut off (as of cloth); to reduce number or quantity of anything; to diminish quantity or value or number; to cut pay. ijongit ijo akituk noi: you have diminished your cows very much. sirikijong ikasirigin lueropit, kiyatak: do not cut my pay, increase it. aijongakin ki-a to take away what is too much or too full too many (as of water out of too full vessel, as of too much money, food or of cows). kijongak akonikituk, epuata kauj: take some of your cows away, they are too many in the kraal. aijongar ki-o to diminish; to take out, away, abolish (laws); to stop (as of drinking or of a leak, etc). sirikiyatak ijo aijong ajon: do not take any more beer - stop drinking. ijongas ajon kotoma amot: the beer has diminished in the pot. ejongaros ikasirigin: my money has diminished. aijongijong akuwan ki-a to shake the body; to exercise or to work out or train; to do callisthenics or aerobics. aijonijon ki-a to beat up. aijono to be calm; to be at ease; (of temperature) to have cooled down; (of food) to have cooled down; (of an angry person) to have calmed; to be calm; (of adult people or children) to be at ease; (of hunger) to calm down; (of wounds) to get better or heal i.e. less painful. aijony ki-a to run (taking short steps) like a child; to run like short men do; to jog. aijonyijony ki-a to canter, run, gallop, trot, jog or sprint. aijool ki-o to throw down; (of things into a hole or water) to let down; to steal. kijool iboro ngul toma aipany naarai mam bobo ekotoi: throw those things into the hole because they are no longer wanted. ijoolie ekokolan iboro k’itunga: the thief steals people’s things.aijoolikin ki-o to put or let down a heavy load on to a lorry or anything; to put quietly aside; to put quietly into the pocket. kijoolikis emoru ngol toma amotoka: lift that big stone onto the lorry.aijoolis a crane for loading; a native pulley used to let heavy loads down or lift them from a deep hole. aijoolun ki-o to lower carefully. aijoor ki-o (of a receptacle) to contain; (of a container, vessel) to hold. etogo lo mam epedori aijoor itunga lu kere (naarai edite noi): this house will not hold all these people (because it is too small). amot ngin ijoorit acupai atomon: that pot holds ten bottles of liquid. aijop ki-o to make unequal (in size, length, height or number); to put unevenly; to make uneven; to make different. kijopoto icupai ienete: tie the bottles in alternation. aberu ngin ijopijopi aur: that woman alternates her children (produces boys and girls in alternation). aijopijopo disparity. ijopijopo etiai akakituk kanukon: there is disparity between the number of my cows and yours. aijopokin ki-o to be unequal (in size, quantity, height, number); to be different. ijopokino etaceka kalokon: my pay is different from yours. to make unequal. aijopor ki-o to make unequal; to shorten (of anything); to cut off (a piece); to diminish (of solid things and of numbers). kijoposi etiaikec: make their number unequal. to be unequal; to be less, have diminished, etc. aijor1 ki-a to catch as of fish or ants, locusts; to hunt. aijor agaria: to catch small fish.aijor aswam: to work always (literally, to crouch all the time working). aloto luce kere, eong bon ajori kane: others have all gone, I alone am sitting here on my haunches or left at home. aijore ki-o to hunt animals; to raid people; (of many) to steal or rustle. Ikaramoja ka Iturukana ijoreete itunga luce: the Karimojong and Turkana tribes raid other peoples. aijoreun ki-a to make prisoner; to catch slaves; to hunt or catch animals, small fish, locusts or ants. apotu kolo Imo kijoreoto Iteso: in the past the Baganda or foreigners made the Iteso their slaves. aijorijor ki-a to get fed up with; to catch repeatedly; to annoy; to dislike; to shun. ejorijori eong ekatau: I have angina pectoris (a heart disease which periodically causes pain in the chest); I feel like vomiting. aswam ngin ekoto aijorijor eong: I am getting fed up with that work. aijorijoronor ki-o to keep on visiting for the sake of food, begging food or anything else. sirijorijoronor oreke: do not annoy him with your frequent visits to his home. aijorojoronokin: to be in a hurry. aijorojorunun: to run this way. aijorijoror aswam: to work quickly ahead; to hurry to work. aijorijoror alosit: to run quickly. aijorijoroor ki-o to push one ahead; to force to do; to do quickly. ejorijoroo ejakait etunganan kanuka esolo: the chief has made a man run for his graduated tax (catching him and pushing him forward) to run quickly; to be on the point of doing; to hurry quickly. aijorim ki-a to take all; to catch all; to steal all men or animals or fish or anything. abu ekokolan kijorima ikaboro kere: a thief stole all my property. ijorimaete kesi akokoroi aiar: they kill chicken en masse. aijorimaar ki-a to take away all (people, animals and things); to kill all; to destroy, annihilate, obliterate or devastate all. adau akolong aijorimaar epaaba kere: the heat has destroyed all the cotton in the farm. to be all finished. ejorimaaros ikatunga kere atwakare: all my relatives are dead.aijorimaun ki-a to do a thing or an action altogether; to take all, catch all; to steal all, etc and bring. ejorimautu ijaka itunga kanuka esolo: the chiefs caught all the people for defaulting graduated tax. to be all in a certain state or condition. ejorimaun epaaba akonore: the cotton is all blossomed at once. ejorimaunos itunga ailip ebaga: all the people are attending Christmas prayers. aijoronor ki-o to seize, catch; to take away continually; to raid constantly. ejai egwang loijoronori ikamiyoi: there is a wild cat that keeps on taking away my chicks. aijose ki-o to pretend, feign; to act as if; to dissemble, dissimulate. ijosei ngesi iswamai: she/he pretends to work. ejotoi ngesi ejose: she/he pretends to sleep. epod ngesi ejose: she/he pretends to complain. aimony ejose: to pretend to weep/mourn/cry. adeka ejose: pretended sickness. aijoseikin ki-o to pretend; to feign; to sham. ijoseikinit ijo ajo: you are feigning sleep. aijoseonokin: to pretend/feign regularly. aijoseonut1 pretension; sham; charade. aijoseonut2 ki-o to pretend; to sham. aijot1 ki-a (of the sun or moon) to set; to go down. aijot eporoto: (of a nervous person about to make a speech) to clear the throat. elosi akolong aijot: the sun is about to set. aijot ore: to go home. kijota ber ekoniporoto: first clear your throat. aijot ebarenit: sharpen the razor. aijot2 to lean over aside (to let somebody else pass). aijot3 to shift from side to side. aijot iwos: to shift on one’s buttocks. ijosi ngesi iwos iboyei: she/he is shifting on her/his buttocks. aijotakin to sit on one buttock; to sit aside; (of anything) to lean over to put something aside (to let somebody pass) to sit on one buttock; to sit aside; (of anything) to lean overaijotar eporoto ki-a to cough slightly; to clear throat. aijotar aola: to cough slightly. aijoun ki-o to call hither; to gather here; to bring here. kijou itunga kwi lailo: call those people here. to lead this way; to come here. ejounos itunga kwi kere lailo: all the other people have gathered here. aiju ki-a to suck dry; to absorb; to hiss in anger or disapproval. eju akwap akipi kere: the earth or the soil has absorbed all the water. ijui ikoku ikisin katotoke: the child sucks the breast of its mother.aijuanar ki-o to deride, ridicule, scoff, disparage, mock, scorn, or disdain. aijuar1 ki-a to despise; to insult, jeer at; to refuse with insulting looks. engisit eong ngesi kosodi ngesi aijuar eong: I asked him but he jeered me. sirijuanari itunga: do not jeer people.aijuar2 ki-a to suck away; to absorb; to drain, evaporate; to finish completely. ejuasi alup akipi kere: the soil has absorbed all the water. to dry up; to be absorbed; to be despised. ejuaros akipi kere kanuka akolong: all water was evaporated by the sun. aijuarit ki-o to laugh at; to scorn, ridicule. ijuanaros itunga lu: these people are hissing in anger. ejua eong etau: I have disliked it. ijuarit ekatau akonikiro: I despise what you say. aijuet suction; absorption; assimilation. aijuijo ki-a to drizzle, feel miserable. kejuijuit eong akuwan: I feel miserable. ejuijuit eong etau: I feel doubtful about it. aijuikin ki-a to suck for a short time. kijuik ajon kolot: you suck a little beer and go. aijuju ki-a to drain off or to mop up; (of blotting paper) to absorb or suck; to kiss; to carry pollen; to drink up; to keep sucking (as of child, or as of bees sucking pollen or butterflies sucking flowers). aijuju inyamat: to digest or absorb food. ijujue acukia atur: the sunbird is sucking flowers.aijujuar inyamat: to digest or to absorb food. ijujue akoik inyamat: the stomach absorbs the digested food. ejujuasi ikapejok ajon: my visitors have finished all the beer. aijuk1 ki-a to push; to despatch; to send. kijuk ekagaali, kapas eong: push my bicycle, I am tired.aijuk2 to refuse (of anything). ajuk ikakoku abunere osomero: my child has refused to come to school.aijuk3 to paint, smear with ashes or clay, or contents of goat, sheep or cattle bowels as ordeal of the Iteso; (of a person or an animal) to become angry, furious, irate (like a bull goring an anthill with its horns in preparation for a fight). ejukete Iteso aberu naepotie ikijit: the Iteso smear a young Teso woman who is pregnant with contents of a cow’s stomach. aijuk akiria: to mark or tarnish with flour. ejukitai nges akiria: she/he is covered with flour dust (after grinding millet or cassava). aijukakin ki-a to send a thing to; to send on errand; to send for somebody; to actuate. kejukakit eong jo etelepat lo: I am sending you this boy. kejukakit eong ijo eitaabo lo: I have sent you this book. aijukanar ki-a to send often; to export and import. aijukar ki-a to send somewhere on an errand; to consign; to send away; to push forward; to despatch; to make visible, protruding, push forward. aijukar ko posita: to send by post. kijukasi: push off. akoto aijukar ijo Katakwi: I want to send you to Katakwi. to go away in crowds (as of people to market, of a swarm of locusts, etc). ejuka aberu akoik: that woman is clearly pregnant and is about to deliver (literally, pushes her stomach forward). aijukujuk ki-a to be too much for; to be unable to do or look after a work by oneself. kapas eong aijukujuk eduan: I am tired of weeding alone. ejukujukit eong idwe ngul kere: I am looking after all those children by myself. ejukujukit eong aswam ngin: I am doing all that work (and is too much for me). to be crowded together; to be near one another. ijukujukas itunga kokeresia: people are crowded in the cathedral.aijukujuka ki-a to be many. ijukujukas ikong: there are many white ants. aijukujukakin ki-o to be packed together or crowded; to be full of. ejukujukakinos ipejok oreka: my house is full of visitors. aijukun ki-a to send hither (of a big crowd); to import; to push this way. (of anything) to crowd together; to gather or be crowded together; to push one another; to exude. aijul ki-a to turn round; to alter (food, etc); (of place or clothes, manners or religion) to change; to interpret, convert, or to translate.aijul edini: to be converted to another religion or faith. akoto aijul inyamat luanyami, kapas eong ainyam alos: I want to have a change of food, I am tired of millet. aijulakin ki-a to translate for; to change about; to do alternatively (as fighting one and then another, doing this and then something else, change food about). ejulaki aberu ngin aur: that woman has altered her birth (that is, has borne a child of a different sex from the previous one). aijulanakin ki-o to be changeable, fickle, variable, unsettled, unpredictable, unreliable, unstable, unfixed, irregular, or undependable. aijular ki-a to lose free will; to be mad; to ask God for a favour; to put somewhere else.aijulir ki-a to witness or to testify in a law suit.aijulujul ki-a to change about; to turn about; to be reconverted; to interpret; to spread talk; (of crops) to rotate. aijulujuleta a rotation (as of crops). kibusakinit yes akor kaijulujuleta: it is necessary that you plant in rotation. aijulul ki-o to slope downwards, as of roof; to be stooped; to hang down upside-down. ijululei emenia kokuju okitoi: the bat hangs head downwards on the tree. ijululeete irotin: the roads slope downwards.aijulun ki-o to be converted; to be changed about; to be head first (in birth), head down (in falling).aijulunio (singular noun F) conversion (to the speaker’s side or viewpoint); adaptation; alteration; translation; renovation. aijunga ki-a to dress wounds; to give hot compression; to wash clothes without soap.aijungakin ki-a to dress wounds for; to give hot compression to, squeeze (cloth when washing); to make a dress with pleats. aijup to pick out (as of a jigger or thorns); to prick (as of little wounds); to scrutinize (a thing nearby or person far off); to pick potatoes or anything. ajupujup: to repeatedly pick or prick (as remnants of food in teeth); to find out.aijupujup ki-a to go and look, go and find out.aijupun to pick (as of teeth or food, especially of a hen or birds).aijur to lick; to sip, suck up, or to sniff up. ejurete akituk akipi: the cows drink water (from a nearly dry swamp). ejuri ngesi ecaai loemwana: she/he sips hot tea. aijur edoot: to lick salt clay. aijut to wipe clean (with finger or anything); to shave clean with razor; to clean the anus after defecating. aijut aidoole: to wipe the anus (after going to the toilet). aijuwanar ki-a to jeer; to despise, mock, deride; to scoff. inyo bo kijuwanara ijo eong?: why do you jeer at me? aijwaka ki-a (of a person with rotten teeth) to chew, suck dry tough meat or food. ijwakai emojong akekiring: the old man sucks the tough meat because he lacks teeth. aijwakar to suck meat dry, as of children or old men (note: for animals such as dogs or cats, use aijwakijwak: to lap milk, water, etc).ijwakijwaki ekingok akile: the dog is lapping milk.aijwala ki-a to make beer tasteless by adding too much water; to make soup tasteless by always boiling the same bone or meat again and again. ijwala ijo adakai ngin k’akipi: you spoil the beer by adding too much water. aijwalaar ki-a to make altogether insipid, as of soup. aijwalaikin ki-a to be insipid; to be tasteless, stale for. ijwalaikit emugaati lo: this bread is stale, tasteless. aijwalaun ki-a to despise, ridicule. aijwalaunit ki-a to be despising, ridiculing. aijwat to beat, give a thrashing, hitting. adum eong ejakait ejwasi etunganan: I found the chief beating a man (for not paying tax, perhaps).aijwatar ki-a to beat slightly (with small stick); to sweep a little; to clear throat (before speaking).aijwekijwek ki-a (of dogs and cats, etc) to lap liquids. ijwekijweki ikapa akile: the cat laps milk.aijweny (of anything) to finish eating completely.aika1 ki-a (of many together) to beat or hunt abreast for big and small animals; (of a man who has a case) to persecute. ikaete itelepai imirio: the boys are hunting rats. abu America kikaa Isiriamun kanuka asurokinio napaarasia 11/9/2001: America persecuted Muslims after the September 11, 2001 plane attack on the World Trade Centre in New York.aika2 ki-a to interfere; to cause trouble. ikaenenei ijo akiro apaarasia kere: you are always looking for trouble. aikaap (singular noun F) beginning of pregnancy in cows. aikaar1 ki-a to hunt away from home. alosi aikaar: I am going to hunt over there aikaar2 ki-o to walk abreast (many together); (of a tree or plants) to branch out; (of a family) to branch out; to be a big family, spread out. to walk abreast; to spread or branch out or ramify. ekaaros isirikaalei korot: the soldiers are walking abreast on the road. ekaar edou etepi: the rain is going in front like a broad screen. ekaaros ikito atenueik: the trees have branched out. ateker naka Oumo ekaar: Oumo’s clan (the founder of Kumi town) has spread out.aikaboikin ki-o to grasp; (as of football) to grip, to catch (when thrown at); to catch (as of a dog catching a piece of meat thrown in an open mouth). kikaboik emopiira: catch the ball. aikabub ki-o (of all seeds) to be fully swollen with water and ready to burst; to be fully grown. ekabubuutu imomwa: the sorghum seeds have swollen out (full of water, ready to burst). aikabubukin ki-o to be drowsy; to be heavy with sleep; to be fully grown. ekabubukinos akonyeka kanuka ajo: my eyes feel heavy with sleep. aikabubuun ki-o to be fully swollen, satiated with water, fully grown, quite ripe (as of maize seed or any fruit). aikac to intercept; to cut off, as of thief trying to escape; (of animals in hunting trying) to surround it and catch it; to leave a passage. yesi kere kokacata amotoka tetere mam kinangari: all of you leave a passage for the car lest it knock you down. aikac aswamusinei: to do many jobs or tasks concurrently. aikacikac ki-a to run fast. kikacikacata ore, abu edou: run home fast, rain is going to fall. aikacikacakin ki-a to run after or to run for. aikad to be wanting; to be lacking; to be missing; to be short; to be insufficient. kikadito jo iponesio lukajokak: you lack good manners. ekadit esukaali lo, kiyatak: this sugar is not enough, add more. aikade ki-o to hook down a high branch in order to pluck fruit.aikadeikin ki-o to hang up; to hook up or to take down by hook (of things high up). kikadeik ekakooti ngina: hang my coat there. aikadeun ki-o to take down with a hook (of anything too high to reach with the hand); to trip up (in football).ekadidikit eong inyamat akoik: I have half-filled my stomach. kikadidik epuko akiria: partially fill the sack with flour. aikadidio ki-o to be partly full; to be nearly full. amoti ngun ikadidios: those pots are nearly full. aikadidior ki-o (of anything) to fill partly. kikadidionosi amoti ngun k’akipi: fill those pots partly with water. ekadidionoros amoti nu akipi: there is less water in these pots than before. aikaika ki-a to rake off, take off with fingers (as of grass after slashing, as of rubbish after winnowing, as of groundnut shells after shelling). ikaikai ijo akiro inera, mam ilimunit nukabeit: you only touch the outside of the matter, you did not tell the essence of the case. aikaikaun ki-a to rake off, take from surface (leaving the bottom or the real thing, the essentials alone). aikaikaun akiro: to give the substance or the gist of a question or of a case. aikaikin ki-a to get the common knowledge of; to acquire knowledge, do in common; to make common that was not so; to get accustomed to; to spread news or anything, make common, spread out. sirikikaik akiro ngun otunga: do not spread that to the public. ekaikin ediiniwok akwapin kere: our religion has spread all over the world. kikaikis itunga alosit kigaalin k’ainap lomusugun: people have made it a common thing to travel on bicycles and to dress in European fashion.aikaj ki-a to hang up; (of house) to put up the roof. alosi aikaj atunuru: I am going to put up the roof. aikajakin ki-a to hang up on; to postpone or suspend (of a case). ekajakini eong ekakaaso arwatat: I am hanging my cassock on the wall. ekajakin ber emusaagokon: your case has been postponed for the moment. aikajakinet a peg on the wall (for hanging clothes on); a tenterhook.sirikikajanak aswamukon: do not procrastinate. aikaje ki-a to be mad, delirious, or insane; to become mad; to be mad; to run mad; to be insane.aikajeikin ki-o to have become mad on account of; to tend to become mad. ekajeiki etelepat ngol kanuka aisisia: that boy has become mad with studies.aikajet a peg for hanging things on.aikajikaj ki-a (of child) to babble; to stutter; to be not well ground. to grind roughly. ikajikaji etunganan ngol einer: that man stutters. ikajikajete kesi akimai iriete: they are not grinding the millet well.aikak to block up (said of a cow with very big udder about to bring forth or a man with a swollen scrotum or a big swelling). ekakit akiteng ngin ekot aur: that cow’s udder is very big (is blocking up her legs) it wants to bring forth. ekakit etunganan ngol abus: that man has a big abscess between his legs (he cannot walk well). ekakit ikoku aberu: the child has blocked the woman’s cervix (during labour). aikakoikin ki-a to become ice or icy; to freeze. aikal ki-a to speed up together; (of anything) to do quickly; to do together quickly. ikalete idwe inyamat enyamete: the children eat their food quickly (because they are many and food is little). kikalas aswam na kodaun atipet: hurry on together with the work so as to finish it soon. aikalar aswam: to do quickly together. ekalaros ajon: the beer has been finished (by many people).aikalal ki-a to cry loudly; to weep loudly; to shout, bawl. ikalalaete idwe aikalal, ido awoere mam ewoete: the children in the choir simply shout, they do not sing. aikalalanut (singular noun F) uproar, shouting, hubbub, noise, racket, hullabaloo, din, clamour, or tumult. aikalalanut ngin nakinyo?: what is all that hubbub about? aikalalat ki-a to shout; to quarrel, cry in alarm. inyo bo ikalalatotor ngul?: why do those people shout? aikalalator ki-o to extol; to praise loudly. aikalalikin ki-a to shout; to do in shouting, quarrelling; to raise the voice above others; to shout, sing or speak louder than others. sirikikalalak iwoi: do not sing louder than others. aikalam ki-a to make a jump; to jump over; to lift across; to pass over; to bounce. kikalam auno na: jump over this rope. mam eong apedori aikalam, naarai adeka eong akeju: I cannot skip, my leg is injured. kikalam iboro ngul juwai: lift these things across.aikalamar ki-a to bounce or to jump across; to lift across or over; to pass over.aikale ki-o to volley; to take up (a song) in a high tone; to raise the voice. ekaleu ngesi emopiira eroko kedolo kwap: she/he volleyed the ball before it reached the ground.aikaleikin ki-o to get stuck up high (in a tree or on a roof). ekaleikin emopiira amoni: the ball has remained hanging in the thicket. aikalekin ki-a to become a compound, ekal. aikalel ki-o to float or drift. emopiira ikalelo k’akipi: the ball floats on the water. aikaleleor ki-o to float down and away; to sail away. aikalelitoi ki-o (of anything) to float on or to; to be floating; to be afloat. aikalelo ki-o to float, drift, glide, hover, hang or soar. ataker ikalelo kokuju akipi: the canoe floats on the water. aikaler ki-o to be sleepless; to lie awake. abu eong kekaler akware kiya: I was awake all night.aikales ki-o to pretend not to hear; to snub (only used of not hearing). enera eong, kikalesi ijo aikales: I talk and you behave as if you do not hear.aikaleseun ki-o to come this way; to step this way. aikalesikin ki-o to disappoint; to ignore; to let one down. kekalesikinit ekesa ngol eong: that fellow disappointed me. aikalesoor ki-o to leave work undone, pass over undone. ikalesoonori ngesi aswam: she/he leaves the work undone. aikaleun ki-o (in Karamoja) to raise voice; to shout; to cry with loud voice; (of animals) to bay with loudly; to roar (used with eporoto). engatuny ikaleuni eporoto: the lion roars.aikam ki-a (of anything) to catch; to snare; to seize; to capture. aikam lukecor: to catch fish. aikam enyel: to corrode; to rust. aikam akiro: to take notes; to pay attention; to tape record.aikamakin1 ki-a to catch for; to take for somebody; to clip together. aikamakin2 ki-o to remain stuck; to agglutinate; to coagulate; to be entangled; to remain fixed. ikamakina epaaba toma ajimi: the cotton wool is stuck on the wound. ekamakin amotoka toma orit: the motorcar is stuck in the mud. aikamanar ki-a to catch one by one, keep catching and taking away; to echo. ikamanarete imor iporotoi: the rocks echo the sounds. aikamar ki-a to take away; to snatch away; to arrest. ekacudan ikamari akonye: the witch takes away the sight of people. aikamar akonye: to roll eyes; to look about aimlessly; to squint. abwakar akonye: to throw or sprinkle poisonous liquid or dust at someone’s eyes. aikamaraar ki-o to point down; to bend down and up (as of branches of tree, horns of cows - some pointing up and others bending down); (of speech) to be contradicting; (of eyes) to squint. ekamaraaros akusikiro: your statements are contradictory. aikamarikin ki-a (of a speaker) to alter a statement; (of branches of a tree) to hang or bend over; (of cows horns) to point in different directions - one horn up, one down, or crossing over each other. aikamesikin ki-o to look away from, avert eyes (as of a typist typing and at the same time looking at his/her copy); to keep an eye on. alosi eong atan, kikamesik ijo ekek: I am going to the well, keep an eye to the door.aikamisoor ki-o to refuse; to reject, leave undone. inyo bo ikamisooro ijo aswamukon?: why do you shirk your work? aikamisoor akiro: to refuse to believe.aikamun ki-a to catch (a thief or birds or animals); to capture, apprehend; (of blood or milk) to coagulate; to clutch. aikamun akiro: to understand; to know. aikamun akim: to catch fire; to go on fire. aikamun adeka: to contract some disease or sickness. aikamun erot: to start off on a journey or trip. aikamunio (singular noun F) a capture; detention; the arrest; apprehending aikamunit ki-a to be concerned or affected concerning; re; in relation to; to be applicable to. ikamunitos akiro nu ijo: this matter applies to you. aikamur ki-o (of any fruit, millet, etc) to begin to ripen; (of eyes) to fall asleep. ekamuroto akimai komanaka: the millet is ripening in my garden. ekamuroto akonyeka ajo: I am falling asleep. aikan ki-a to tempt; to entice; to allure, attract, invite, to induce (to good or evil). sirikikan nges toma aronusio: do not entice her/him to evil. aikanakin ki-a to entice; to tempt. sirikikanak nges akiro nuabu ngesi konger: do not tempt him to do what she/he refused. aikanar ki-a to entice; to go and do something good or bad. ijo ibu kikana nges alosit akoko: it is you who tempted her/him to go and steal.aikang ki-a to do roughly; to talk incoherently; to walk jerkily (like walking on hot or rough ground). aikangikang to grind very badly; to talk broken language. aikangikang alos: to grind millet for bread very badly. aikanikan ki-a to entreat, plead, implore, beg, pray, beseech, ask, or request; to pacify; to make clicking noise with the tongue; to talk one round or persuade. aikanikan akiteng: to entice a cow to give milk by making a clicking sound with tongue.aikanikanit ki-a to keep entreating; to pacify; to beseech. kanukinyo ikanikanitor ijo ikoku yenidela?: why do you plead with a fractious child?aikany ki-a to endure; to bear; to suffer. aikany etengei: to starve; to fast. aikany akure: suffer thirst; to be thirsty. aikany abangaanut: to be very stupid. aikany akolong: to endure the sun’s heat. aikany ican: to endure misery, poverty. aikany akiro: to be patient. aikanyakin ki-a to persevere; to endure for; to suffer for. kinger aikanyakin acok itwaniari ekal: if you do not persevere in herding you will not get married. aikanyakin ebela: to suffer the cane. aikanyanut1 (singular noun F) stubbornness; persistence; obstinacy. aikanyanut2 ki-a to be headstrong, obstinate, stubborn, or persistent. aikanyikin ki-a to do for the fifth time; to add one to four. ikanyik ijo lolo akoko: it is now the fifth time that you steal. kikanyik akituk kaloto iso: add one more cow to four and make it five and we go. aikap to equip; to hold a weapon ready to fight. to look very strong and healthy; to be in first pregnancy. aikap akiro: to have a speech ready; to be well prepared, equipped to speak. ekapit ngesi einer: she/he has her/his speech ready. ekapit akiteng ngin, edolit akwario: that cow looks very fit, ready for mounting (by the bulls) to make ready; to equip; to arm. kokapata imuudun, apotu Ilok: get your guns ready, cattle rustlers have approached. aikapeikin1 ki-a (of a beehive) to have honeycombs; (of skin) to become leathery. aikapeikin2 ki-o to do for the sixth time; to make six. aikapel ki-o to make white or spotted; to cause white patches. ikapelit ijo emaido ipeit: you made the groundnuts spotted by not roasting it well. aikar ki-a to fail in health, power, etc; to be too tired to get up; to rest after fruitless toil; to be fatigued; to founder, despondent; to be finished, no strength left, dying, fading away, declining. ekar emojong lo cut: this old man is truly tired. ekar epolon: the old man is now failing in health. ekar imojong: the old men are tired. aikarakin1 ki-a to be stumpy, small, dwarfed; to be stunted in growth. ekaraki ikoku yen, agir apoloor: this child is small and short, it has failed to grow. ekarakis kes, mam bobo ebongunete: they are defeated, they will not return. ekarakinos itunga lu ojie: they were all killed in battle. aikarakin2 ki-o to fail in something or somewhere; (of competing teams) to draw; (of a sick person, animal) to become tired and fall down for dead. ekaraki ngesi ne: she/he broke down here. ekaraki ngesi aswam na: she/he failed in this work.aikare ki-o (of women only) to scream; to shout for joy; to ululate. inyo bo ikareete yesi?: why are you ululating? aikareikin ki-o to shout with joy for somebody or in some place; to welcome loudly; to ululate. kikareikis imu: ululate to welcome the twins. (note: aikare is only done by women) aikareor1 edeke ki-o (in traditional ceremony) to lead sickness (edeke) away (food is boiled, mixed with blood and ashes in a little vessel, and taken to the swamp together with a hen or a goat that will be left there while people run back home without looking back. if one looks back, edeke will also return).aikareor2 ki-o to shout or scream away with joy while holding a spear, knife or stick. atingit eong akwara aikareo: I hold a spear while shouting for joy. ekareosi kesi ngina: they are screaming over there. aikareor3 ki-o (of women) to welcome men after a big game hunt or feast, leading them home; to welcome a big person or twins home. aikareso ki-o to sneeze. ikaresos: they sneeze. aikaresoor ki-o to sneeze away. aikaresoor akiro: to finish a case. aikaresoor adeka: to become well after sickness. aikaribuun ki-a to welcome in; to let in (a guest, visitor); to say ‘Karibu!’ aikarun ki-a to be overcome, come to a draw, deadlock; to be unable to do; to be too difficult for. kekaru eong aswam: the work has defeated me. to be a draw (in games); to be equally strong in fighting. ekarunos kesi kotoma autakec: they are equally strong in wrestling.aikasas ki-a to be tall, big and fat, as of an elephant. ikasasai Ikasangat: Ikasangat is tall and fat or is very big.aikasasaun ki-o to break out; (of a sickness) to become visible; (of a boy or girl) to become big. ekasasaun eong ekodoi kakuwan: small-pox has broken out on my body.aikaset a basket for catching ikole (catfish); a cutlass for slashing grass; a slasher. aikat ki-a to slash (as of grass); to hunt with sticks; to catch ibilenga (mud fish) in baskets. aikat akiro: to get into trouble. aikat inya: to slash grass.aikatakin ki-a to catch for or in some place; to try to do. to get oneself into trouble. ekatakin eong toma akiro: I got myself into trouble. aikatun adeka: to catch an infection (through irresponsible behaviour). aikatakinet a catch; a try or a trial. aikatakinet nasodit: the first catch; the first instance. aikatany ki-a to make an opening wide (of anything). kikatany ekek loka etogoka: make the door of my house wide.kikatanyik amot iswamai: make a wide mouth to the pot.aikatar ki-a to examine, inspect traps; to go and find out about a petition, etc. aikatar akopyo: to go very early (hence to beat the dew). aikaun1 emir ki-a (of many people) to chase a rat or any small animal with sticks. aikaun2 ki-a (of skin disease) to break out, to become visible.aikaun3 ki-a to encounter; to meet with or to come across. ekau eong emorotot korot: I encountered a python on the way. ekaunit eong akiro: I encountered trouble.aikawu ki-o to cook, boil maize or sorghum grain. aikawuikin ki-o to boil grain or any food for somebody quickly (without cooking properly). ikawuikini toto ikekoku inyamat: mother quickly cooks food for her child. aikawuor ki-o to cook food quickly (half done) for somebody away. aikawuun ki-o to preserve vegetables by drying; to preserve by boiling and drying (as of cow blood, or bean-leaves or meat by boiling a little and drying on fire or in sun). kinyamit iso eboo lokikauuno: we ate preserved eboo vegetables. aike1 ki-a to raise; to lift; to elevate. kikeata akanin: raise your hands.aike2 ki-o to scrape; to do a carpenter’s work; to chisel. aike3 akiria to fry or roast beer dough by turning it up to prevent from being singed or burnt at the bottom. aikear ki-a to raise up, lift up, elevate, make higher (as of a wall); to do better. aikear akanin: to raise hands up; to surrender, give up yourself. to be lifted, raised up, etc. kikeasi iporotoi: raise your voices. kikeasi akiro: speak louder. kikeasi aisisia: learn better, study better, or improve the education standards. aikeb to trim hair on forehead (by girls only). aikeb akiro: to speak nicely (literally, to trim one’s words). aikec ki-o to dance, boogie, or bop. aikecokin ki-o to dance for someone.aiked ki-o to brand (dry gourds and calabashes, or bulls and cows) with a red hot iron (considered to be beautiful marks); to decorate (utensils, cattle) with brand marks.aikedar ki-a to click the tongue with indignation.aikeike ki-o to cut an edge to (a board, a path, road or stone). ikeikei ngesi amor: she/he carves stones; she/he dresses stone. aikeikin ki-a to lift, elevate, or raise for someone; to put high up. kikeik ibore ngin: raise that thing. aikeis a woodwork, joinery or carpentry workshop.aikeit akonye ki-a to keep looking far. aikeit akou: to lift up the head to see. ikeit ekesa ngol akou apaarasia kere: that guy always raises his head (i.e. wants to see everything).aikeke ki-a to sift (anything); to winnow.aikekema ki-a (of a bird, especially a laying hen) to cackle. ikekemas akokoroi: the hens are cackling (a sign that they are laying eggs). aikekemo ki-o to chatter; to laugh loudly as of women or children. ikekemos angor emasete ajon: the women chatter and laugh when boozing. aikekemokin: to laugh at or for. kikekemokinoi kaloto: let us have a laugh, and then go off. aikekes a sieve, sifter, colander.aikekiar ki-a to disagree; to refuse. ikoto ijo aikekiar akakiro kere: you want to disagree with everything I say. aikemer ki-a to receive by chance; to receive unexpectedly; to be privileged; to be lucky. abu eong kekemer adumun ajakaanut: I was privileged to be appointed to a leadership position.aikemerikin ki-a to be lucky; to receive unexpectedly; to be fortunate. ekemerikit eong adumun aswam naejokuna: I was fortunate to get a good job.aiken ki-o to curse; to blaspheme. abu papa kiken ikokuke: the father cursed his child. sirikiken ekiror ka Lokasuban: do not blaspheme (the name of God).aikenetoit a curse; anathema; abomination. aikeng1 ki-o to walk with firm steps; to walk tight. emojong ngol ikengi alosit aikeng: that old man still walks firmly. aikeng2 ki-o to put upright; to make to stand erect. kikeng ijo ipirin: put the poles upright.aikengeng ki-a to remain firm; to stay put. aikengokin1 alosit ki-o to walk firmly to or for. ekengokis imakio lu alosit osokooni: these old veterans have walked firmly up to the marketplace. aikengokin2 ki-o to put upright; to set up (anything) somewhere or for somebody; to make (a house) strong. kikengok ikoku ngina: make the child sit over there (on its bottoms). ikengokit ijo ekonitogo: you have built a strong house. aikeniken ki-o to curse someone at heart by oneself without anybody hearing it. aikenitoit a curse mark; an anathema. etelepat ngol ejai aikenitoit nakolo kapapake: that boy has a curse of his father.aikeosit a carving; a work of art. aikenokin to curse one at a distance; to wish one going for a journey or to battle not to return (wishing that she/he may be killed far off). isapa lueyario kojie edaunitai aikenokin koreriakec: men who die in battle are already wished bad luck in their own homes. aikeny ki-a to strike; to hit. abu eong kekeny nges k’ebela: I struck him with a stick. aikeny akiro: to speak plainly; to speak loudly; to talk openly, clearly. okwe apese, kinyek aikeny akiro: oh girl, stop talking openly of others. aikenyakin ki-a to tell straightforwardly. kekenyakit eong ijo ebe ikokolana: I tell you frankly (plainly) that you are a thief. aikenyikeny ki-a to have throbbing pain; to have severe pain, gnawing pain. kekenyikenyi eong akit: I have a severe pain in my ear. aikenyikeny akiro: to open one’s mind, give one’s mind or opinion; to speak out boldly. aikenyun ki-a to speak openly; to speak frankly; to speak clearly, straightforwardly; to enunciate. aikeonokin ki-o to chisel off into proper shape; to cut off unevenness; to finish off a piece of carving. aikeonor ki-o to cut off unevenness; to finish off a piece of work, put finishing touch to a work of art.aikep1 ki-a to make a grinding stone rough by beating with a piece of iron when it is too smooth for grinding. aikep2 to cut; to pare; to cut rings in the bark of a tree; to circumcise. aikep abelekeka: to pare nails of hand or foot. aikep amuk: to shape or make shoes or sandals at the cobbler’s or shoe factory. aikep anapet: to cut and shape the skin for carrying the baby on the back. aikep akeju: to walk long distances.aiker to respect; to honour; to fear; to run in fear; to flee; to avoid. kokerite papakon: respect your father. aikerepikin ki-o to become mad; to become insane to be boisterous.aikereponut1 (singular noun F) tending to insanity, madness, or lunacy. aikereponut2 ki-o to be mad; to be a lunatic; to be insane. ikerepono ngesi: she/he is mad, or crazy. ikerepoko kesi: they are crazy. aikes1 ki-a to be firm; to be hard; to be obstinate; to insist; to be argumentative. eketa eong: I am insisting. iketasi kesi: they are obstinate, insisting. emina ngesi eikes egwelanari ikeboro: she/he sells her/his merchandise at high price i.e. allows little room for bargaining or haggling. iketa je cut: he insists absolutely (that I do it). aikes2 ki-o (of a tall person) to stalk like an ostrich; to stride as one with long legs. ikesikesi ekuulu akwap: the ostrich strides along.aikesa ki-a to speak loudly; to lift one’s voice. ikesai einer (ikesai akiro, ikesai eporoto): she/he speaks loudly.aikesaar ki-a to call away loudly; to emphasize. kolot kikesaa eporoto: go and shout out. aikesaun: to call out aloud. aikesakin1 overhead. kiboi bian iso aikesakin elap: we sat out last night till the moon was right above us. kiswama lolo iso aikesakin akolong cut: we worked till midday. aikesakin2 ki-a to give a heavy blow; to call for loudly. abu eong kekesak nges akit kakan: I slapped him hard on the ear. to work in the heat of the sun. etyono aikesakin toma akolong: it is hard to work in the hot sun. aikeses ki-a to stand upright, tall and big. aikeses aibwo: to stand up; to be standing out above others; to be perpendicular. ikesesei Elgon adepar imor kere: Mt. Elgon stands out above all other hills. aikesit ki-a to refuse; to say no; to decline, reject, snub, rebuff, turn down, or repudiate.aikesitor ki-o to refuse to let go; to raise price too high. ikesitotor imo lukane ikeceboro: the Baganda traders here sell their things at a very high price.aiket1 ki-a to pull tight; to stiffen as of rope or as strings of harps; to key up (guitar). aiket auno: to pull the rope tight; to drive a hard bargain. aiket akonye: to look into the face of, not to be shy; to be bold. kiket jo da akonye: you also look straight in people’s face, don’t be shy. aiket akuwan: to walk with full force or energy; to strain the body (as of a woman during childbirth). aiket2 to break down; to pull down (as of a house); to pullout (as new clothes from a box or as of firewood from a bundle). ekesete kesi ekecetogo: they are pulling down their house. aiketakin to pull tight; to hold tight; to become obstinate to become tight; to contract muscles of the body (as in a dying person). aiketakin ba: (of a person or something tied) to stay firm; to remain hard. aiketakin aki: to prick up one’s ears. aiketakin akanin: to hold arms rigid. aiketakin etau: to harden the heart or feelings towards. aiketar ki-a to pull tight; to tighten, stiffen, constrict. aikeun ki-a to raise up; to hoist; to uphold, support (of things and persons); to lift up (as of head). aikeun arwatat: to support a falling wall; to raise a wall (i.e. build it higher). aikeun akiro: to support a case, an argument. aikeun aswam: to work better and quicker. ekeun ekatau: I feel relieved. ikeu ijo ekatau: you have encouraged me. aikiar ki-a to lift up, push up, or extend; to boost, elevate, haul up, raise, or winch up.aikic ki-o to run while jumping like children. ikicete idwe lai kore: the children hurtle homewards.aikicokin ki-o to run for; to run after. kikicok aomare akim: run and fetch me some fire. aikid to kick; to punch with a fist; to beat with a stick. kocoite akiteng ngin ekidi itunga: be careful with that cow, lest it kicks people.aikidikid ki-a to tickle or titillate. kekidikidi ekulam, akoto alosit ailwat: the urine tickles me, I want to go for a short call. aikidingikin ki-o to reach the middle of; to reach halfway; to put in the middle; centralize. ekidingiki akolong akwap: the sun has reached midday; it is midday; it is equinox – the sun is overhead the equator. aikidiokikin ki-a to be too little, too few for; to be insufficient, short, inadequate, lacking, or unsatisfactory. kekidiokikis eong isirigin: I am short of money. aikidiokoor1 ki-o to become insufficient, short, inadequate, or little. aikidiokoor2 ki-o to become scanty, scarce, few, or rare. ekidiokooros akipi nuelaete kakwap: clean water has become scarce in the world. aikidiokun ki-o to be scarce, few, scanty, short (to speaker). ekidiokut eong acok: I am short of potatoes. aikidiokut (singular noun F) scarcity; fewness. aikij ki-a to stab; to suck (as of a calf punching the udder of its mother to force the milk to come). aikijakin ki-a to spear; to stab; to punch for somebody or some reason.aikil ki-a to long for; to desire; to crave for; to gravitate. ekila eong akiring: I long for meat. ikilas itelepai abolia: the boys crave for a game. aikila itim ki-a to comb hair thoroughly. ikilaete itelepai itimakec: the boys comb their hair well. aikila akimai: to clean millet (grain or crop) thoroughly. aikila edia: to prepare nice looking vegetables. aikilakin ki-o to long for; to desire; to crave for; to wish; to volunteer. ekilakin eong alosit ore: I now long to go home. ingai ikilakina aswam na?: who has volunteered for this work? aikilanar ki-a to writhe with pain. to suffer. aikilar ki-a to wish to someone something. inyo bo kikilatar yesi eong adumun?: what good thing do you wish me to get? aikilar alungar: to go away annoyed, disappointed. ekilar Takan alungar: Takan went away in annoyance. aikilikila ki-a to squirm with pain; to wriggle in or out; to try to escape from; to squirm in anger or pain; to become cruel or angry. ikilikila ekweny kakaninika: the bird is wriggling in my hands (trying to escape). aikilikila etengei: to complain of hunger. aikilikilakin ki-o to start wriggling in or out. aikilikilanar ki-o to throw oneself about; to cry bitterly; to like one another.aikilingikiling ki-a to tickle, amuse, entertain, delight, or please. aikiliokikin ki-a (of a woman) to be man-like; (of a man) to act as husband to (some woman); (of a woman) to be muscular or manly. kikiliokik ijo: (you) be manly. aikima ki-a to boil or make porridge.aikinga ki-a to go outside; to leave the room; to go to the places; to go for a ‘long call’.aikingan ki-a to go outside; to leave the room; to go to places; to defecate or have a ‘long call’.aikinganet the anus; the outing or sojourn.aisikingakin: to help (a child or sick person) to make a ‘long call’. ekinganiki etunganan oruteka: somebody defecated before my gate. kisikinganik ikoku: help the child to discharge its bowels (defecate). aikinganis the anus; a toilet; a latrine. aikingokikin ki-o to be like a dog; to behave like a dog; to be very poor. ikingokikit ngesi: she/he has become very poor, currish, or bitchy. aikipiikin ki-a to be watery, aqueous, dilute, or runny. aikir ki-o to jump; to skip up and down; to come down with a noise. ikirete kesi akwap: they are jumping up and down. aikirijim ki-a to germinate; to begin to grow (of seeds or mushroom). ekirijimata akimai: the millet has germinated. aikirikir1 ki-a to make or build artwork, craft, etc nicely. aikirikir2 ki-o to run noisily, stamping with feet. aikirikirokin ki-a to hurry, scurry, dash, hasten, or rush.aikirokin ki-o to fall down, put down with a thud or noise. ekirokinos itelepai kwap: the boys fell down with a thud. aikis1 ki-a to scrape (as of potatoes, cassava, or skin of anything); to rub; to rasp; to hack, vaccinate; to pare. aikis ekato: to vaccinate. emuron ikisi itunga ekato: the doctor vaccinates people. aikisar, aikisun: to scrape away, towards. aikisun: to jump this way (from a height). aikis2 ki-o to drop a sheaf of grass on its end or a child on its feet; to let fall (standing, not flat) of a pole. ikisonokini toto ikekoku: the mother bounces her child on her knee. aikisanar ki-a to scrape off, rub off; to rasp off; to pare away; to plane off; to comb out (as of bird cleaning itself); to preen; to delete.aikiset peelings; rind; scrap; the place or instrument for scraping. aikiseta nuk’acok: potato peelings. aikisetait instrument for scraping; a peeler of potatoes, etc; an adze. aikisikis ki-a to scrape (as of pencil, finger nails); to rub, scratch, graze, scuff, abrade, chafe, grate, or scour. akoto aikisikis ekabela kokwangu: I want to scrape my stick to make it white. aikisonokin ki-o to lift up and down, as of mother lifting and dropping her child in play. ikisonokini ngesi arukit okisu: she/he rams the pestle down into the mortar (when pounding grain).aikisor ki-o to fall from height; to jump down; to topple over. kikisor ijo kwap: (if) you jump down. to throw down (on its head or feet). aikisun ki-o to fall or jump down towards. aikit1 a carrying pad; a coil made of grass or cloth for carrying pots or gourds. aikit2 to scrape food out of a pot; to make scraping noise; to scrape. aikiya1 ki-a to propitiate; to pacify; to give a good example. toto ikiyai ikekoku kinyek aimony: the mother pacifies her child so that it may stop crying. ejok aikia luejios: it is good to make peace between people fighting.aikiya2 ki-a to persuade; to entice, draw by nice ways or means. akoto eong aikiya papaka kainak eong egaali: I want to persuade my father to give me a bicycle.aikiya3 ki-a to wait a long time, overnight. aikiyaar1 ki-a to do without stopping; to do all night. aikiyaar2 ki-a to go on begging; to keep on asking for something; to persevere asking; to keep on dancing all night. ekiyaasi bian itunga ngina ekosio: the people danced all night over there. alot ngesi aikiyaun ibore neejai opaperoke: she/he has gone to her/his friend to beg for something. aikiyaar3 ki-a to draw a person away; to entice one away; to attract, tempt, lure, allure, persuade, inveigle, beguile, or charm somebody. aikiyaikin ki-a to keep asking a favour for something. to be busy all night with something. lukacuuma naka epaaba ikiyaikinete aswam kuare: those in the ginnery work all night. kikiyaik ailip, idumuni: keep on asking (praying), you will receive. to pass the night. ai bo kikiyaikit ijo?: where were you last night? aikiyakiya ki-a to go begging; to soothe continually.aikiyaun ki-a to convince, sway, win over, influence, or persuade carefully; to get something out of somebody. abu eong kekiau nges akokor: I managed to get a chicken out of her/him. aiko1 to look for; to search; to find; to find out; to attempt.aiko2 to scratch; to itch as of jigger or scabies. ekoi ekingok akekuwan: the dog is scratching its body.ikobete itunga luelwaka agwelar emaido k’Ocorimongin: the people from afar flock to Ocorimongin market in Katakwi to sell their groundnuts. ai bo ikobar ijo?: where are you off to now again?aikob2 ki-a to transcribe; to copy.aikobakin ki-a to transcribe for; to copy for; to hand over to; to pass on to; to take to. kikobakinai eong eitaabo je: pass me that book. aikobar1 ki-a to go across to. ekobar Ejakait Apunyo okekwa je: Mr Apunyo has gone to the other side of the lake.aikobar2 ki-a to take away, hand to another, or pass on. kikobakisi etunganan ngol eitaabo lo: pass this book on to that man. aikobikob ki-a to hurry; to run (like a dog). ikobikobi ekingok apaarasia kere: the dog is always running. aikoc ki-o to gnaw at (a bone or anything hard). ikoci ekingok akojo: the dog gnaws at bones. ariebo na esilim kekoci akakuwan: this AIDS disease gnaws at my body. esilim erai ariebo naikoci: AIDS is a gnawing disease.aikocokin ki-o to clean the bone (cut off the meat from the bone) for somebody. aikocor ki-o to make bare, lay bare (as of field eaten by locusts or goats); to pick bare (as of dog and bone). ekocosi itunga ekaboo kere: people have plucked my eboo vegetables bare. aikocun ki-o to know well; to be clever at (of anything). ikocunit ijo Amusugun: you know English well.aikod to ask (somebody something); to lift (a thing) by a handle (like lifting a handbag). ejaas nuakoto aikod ijo: I want to ask you something. kokod adoobo ngin: lift that bucket. aikod loadekan arai ikoku: to lift or support a sick person or child by their arms. aikodakin ki-a (of plants only) to climb into, round, or creep round. aikodar ki-a to climb up as of a plant round a pole. aikode ki-o to hook down a high branch in order to pluck fruit.aikodeikin ki-o to hang up; to hook up or to take down by hook (of things high up). to remain hanging; to remain stuck on top.aikodeor ki-o to lift with a stick and carry away (as of dead snake). aikodeor emun: to lift away a snake with a stick. aikodeun ki-o to take down with a hook (of anything too high to reach with hand). aikodikod ki-a to climb, as of a plant round a pillar; to tie, entwine (a bed with ropes); to make a twine rope; to make a web (as of spider); to spread out on the ground, as of creeper plants like luffah and groundnuts, etc; to shoot out roots into the ground, as of creeper plants; to take root. atur ikodikodete epir: the flowers climb round a pole. aturot naikodikodi: a climbing flowering plant. aikodikod etunganan: to pester a man in order to make him angry; to nag a man. aikodil ki-a to keep throwing up and down as a cat with mouse or of mother playing with the child. aikodilaar ki-a to swing, take away; to cling, as of a child (catching it by the arm and slinging on the back, as women do). aikodomikin kwap ki-o (of a tall person) to fall down; (of a tall person) to sit or lie down exhausted. aikoikikin ki-a to be abdominal. ikoikikit adekakon: your sickness is abdominal (is in the abdomen). ekoikiki aberu na: this woman is pregnant.aikoj ki-a to spoil a work (one does not know); to trifle, dawdle.aikojakin ki-a to spoil a work for somebody; to dawdle at; to trifle at. ikojakinit ijo aswamuka: you have spoiled my work.aikojar ki-a to be trifling about. aikojikoj ki-a to trifle; to waste time doing a thing one does not know how to do; to dawdle. ikojikoji ijo aswam namam ijeni: you waste your time over a job you do not know how to do; you waste you time over a job you do not understand. aikojoikin ki-a to be bony, skinny, scrawny, lanky, lean, thin, emaciated, skeletal, or gaunt. ikojoikit akiring na: this meat is all bones. aikok to guard or protect; to hurry on forward; to be intent on; to do with a will; to insist; to receive with pleasure, gratitude; to mind, pay attention to; to take care of. kokok ijo ikakoku: protect my child. sirikikok eong, mam eong asii: do not guard, I will not run away. akokit eong adaun aswam na lolo: I intend to finish this job today. akokit eong ajenun Ateso: I am intent on learning Ateso. akokit eong aswam ngin: I pay attention to that work. akokit eong adumun ikonibaluan: I like to receive your letters. kokok aswamukon: pay attention to your work. aikokoor ki-o to finish off altogether, as of food, beer, etc; to deplete. ekokoosi kwi ajon kere: those fellows have finished all the beer. aikokor ki-o to roll along (as of a bicycle or a wheelbarrow, etc). aikokoroor ki-o to roll down or to roll away; to wheel along like bicycle or wheelbarrow to descend; to roll away by itself. aikokoruun ki-o to roll down this way (as a ball from roof). aikokoteonor ki-o to become nasty, spiteful, mean, vicious, malicious, cruel, horrible, malevolent, wicked. aikokoun ki-o to finish (the contents of something) completely. sirikikokou edula kere: do not empty the whole granary. aikol ki-o to nag; to irritate constantly; to blame repeatedly; to congest. aitokol: to contest (as of football).aitokokolit: to be always troublesome, quarrelsome, nagging, irritating, or rivalling. aikola alup ki-a to scrape ground with a hoe; to weed with a hoe; to beat with a thin stick or a whip. aikolaar eduan: to weed with a stick or hoe; to scratch away the weeds. aikoler ki-o to be sleepless. kekoler eong bian akware kiya: I was sleepless all night last night. ikolerit esirikaalet: the night watchman is alert. ikolerito akonyeka: my eyes are wakeful. aikolerit (singular noun F) insomnia; sleeplessness; wakefulness. aikolikol ki-a to have boils; to get boils, blisters, or sunburns. ikolikolit eong akan: I have blisters on my hand. aikolikolit (singular noun F) (a state of having) blisters; rashes; scalds. aikolikolun ki-a (of the skin) to break out into boils or blisters. aikoma ki-a to glide like a snake; (of animals, especially cattle) to walk in Indian file; to crawl; to make progress; to progress. ikomaete akituk odoot: the cattle walk in Indian file to the salt clay. aikomaikin ki-a to glide (like a snake); (of cattle) to go in Indian file to; to make progress in. ekomaiki emorotot togoke: the python has gone into its shelter. aikomo ki-o to howl; to wail (of a person or animal). lukangai ikomoete aimony kangina?: who are wailing over there? aikomoikin ki-o to howl at, wail for, shout for. aikomom ki-o to be very high, tall; to be outstanding. aikon ki-a to be like; to act towards; to look like; to do (has irregular conjugation) ikoni ai?: how is it? (plural) ikote yesi ai?: ikonete yesi ai?: what do you do? ikoni bo ai?: how is it? ekoni ijo akwap ai?: how did you find the weather? aikon ai? to do what? aikon nen: to be like that; to be thus. aikonakin ki-a to act towards; to behave towards; to do to. ikonakini ijo akoniberu ai?: what will you do to your wife? how did you act towards your wife? ikonakit ijo eong erono: you treated me badly. ekonakini eong kwangin: I do thus; so do I. ikonakini ngesi nen: she/he does thus. ikonakinete kesi kwangin: they do thus; so do they. ekonakini bo ikwaikini nen ai?: how comes it happened thus? ekonakini eong ai?: what shall I do? how shall I behave? how shall I go about it? to tackle; to treat. ikonakit ijo nges erono: you treated him badly. aikone ki-o (in Karamoja) to be friends; to make friends. aswam ekone: to make friendship. aikoneikin ki-o (in Karamoja) to become friends.kikonenen ne: keep doing it like this. aikong ki-o to hammer; to fasten; to knock (once); to tap. aikongikong1 ki-a to run (as of an old man or cow which is very thin). aikongikong2 ki-o to rap; to tap; to knock (as at door); to hammer. sirikiloma komam ber ikongikongit ekek: do not enter before knocking at the door. aikongokin ki-o to knock on; to hammer on; to make a strong rule or command for; to make strong. kikongok eloit lo kwap: hammer this peg down. kekongokit eong ijo ekisil, mam ibuni oreka: I absolutely forbid you to come to my home. ikongokit ijo etogo lo ne: you built this house very strongly here. aikongonor ki-o to beat hard with a hammer, one after another; to hammer hard; to loosen by hammering. aikony to bite; to sting; to be sufficiently salted. kakonyit eong ao: a bee stung me. ekonyit inyamat abalang: there is sufficient salt in the food (literally, the salt has bitten the food). aitokony aberu abalang: (a ceremony of) introducing a woman to taste salted food (after giving birth). kokony ebokoritika lokawasia: bite my last finger so that my absence may not hurt you (as a sign of goodbye). akonyokony eong akou: I have a splitting headache. aikoodo1 armed robbery; burglary. aikoodo2 ki-o to rob with the force of arms; to burgle. aikoowa leisure; pastime.aikoowa ki-a to be at leisure; to be at peace. ikoowai ijo eilat: you are walking at leisure. aikop1 ki-a to go from place to place; to be always on the move. aikop alosit: to be always going about; to go suddenly. to pass on things; to hand over (as at table). aikop2 to snatch; to seize quickly; to snap up. aikop alosit: to walk with quick steps. ekopi etoori imiyoi: the eagle snatches chicks. aikopa ki-a to borrow. aikopaar ki-a to lend out, pass on, devolve on. to move further on, spread; to go across; to jump; to go from one place to another (as of a monkey swinging from one branch to another). aikopaikin ki-a to lend to. ekopaikit eong Otim isirigin ilukumin ikany: I lent Otim five thousand shillings. aikopakin ki-a to hand on; to pass on. kikopakinai esukaali: pass the sugar on to me. aikopanakin ki-o to spread or to infect (as of disease). aikopaun ki-a to borrow for oneself. aikor to divide; to give away; to serve out (food), or dispense (medicine); to distribute, give out. kolot aikor inyamat: go and serve food. aikor apese: to hand a bride to her bridegroom at a marriage, wedding. cp aidut. aikorar ki-o to get on with difficulty; to scramble. abu eong bian kekorar osokooni: I trudged to the market yesterday. aikorikin ki-o to border on each other (of a plot, country or garden, etc). ekorikinos itunga lu: these people have become neighbours. ikorikino itunga lu: these people are neighbours. aikorikorit ki-a to drag along. aikorikor ikong: to force flying ants out by beating something hollow. aikorobe ki-o to gather people and align them near their work. aikorobeikin ki-a to put in a line; to align (as of men who are going to work or to be written down). kikorobeikis Imusugun ikecereria: the Europeans have built their houses in a line. aikorojong to remain stunned. abu ngesi kenom eong akou kekorojong eong: she/he stunned me with a blow on the head (literally, she/he hit me on the head and I remained stunned). aikoror ki-a to winnow; to pour down slowly and let the wind blow away the chaff in the falling; to pour down (water, etc) from a high place; to gargle; to freewheel on a bicycle or motorcar.aikororoun ki-o to freewheel down; to come down. aikoroun ki-o to tap with a stick; to hit a thing with a hard object; to make a noise with a stick. aikorounun: to keep tapping with a stick, (as of an anthill to force the flying ants to come out); to beat a hollow wood with a stick called agig.aikoru ki-o to border on; to be neighbours. ikoruos Ikaramoja ka Iteso: the Karimojong border on the land of the Iteso. ikoruos ijo ka nges: you two are neighbours. aikosi ki-o to dance (with or without bells). aikosi adeudeu: to dance to a harp. aikosikin ki-o to dance to a song. aikosos ki-o to be gigantic.aikot1 ki-a to duck down (to evade a blow); to clear grass; to trim; to slash (as of grass). kikot erot lo: slash the grass on either side of this road. ekosete idwe anya: the children are slashing the grass.aikot2 to brush off; to wave (goodbye); to flick away (flies or mosquitoes); to fan. aikot akopyo: to clear away the dew (with hand or stick). ekosi ngesi icuc: (she/he fans) she/he swats the flies. aikotar ki-a to clean; to beat (the dew away); to slash away. ikotanarete itelepai anya: the boys slash (cut) the grass. aikotel ki-o to prick up the ears; to raise the hat. aikoteloor ki-o to prick up ears like a dog or animal, when hearing strange noise or seeing a stranger. nekaanyunia etom eong, kikoteloori akike: when the elephant saw me, it pricked up its ears. aiku1 to escape, break loose; to get away with. akuata itunga kotuja: the prisoners escaped from the prison. abu ekapa kokoto aikamun emir konye abu koku: the cat wanted to catch a rat but it escaped. mam ekui: (it is) inevitable. aiku aitac esolo: to avoid paying tax (due to defects in the tax laws). aiku2 to pull out; to extract (a jigger or thorn). aiku ikukwa: to extract thorns from feet. aiku ipuusai: to extract jiggers (from feet, etc). aiku3 (of soap) to foam; (of beer or vegetables) to boil over; to cause foam; (of milk, carbonated drink or beer) to curdle, effervesce. aikuar ki-a (of rain) to slacken or to stop. ekua edou: the rain has diminished (slackened). aikuar akiro: to be free from worry; to be free from trouble; to be carefree. ekua akuwan akiro: I am free from trouble.ekuasi ipumu kakouke: her/his epileptic fits have ceased; her/his dizziness has gone.aikub to rush; to dash. aikuc ki-o to drill a hole; to make a hole in something; to start or kick off (a game, etc); to rub (soap). kikuc ajoroi ngin kanuka adumun akim: drill a hole in that ejoroi branch to make fire. aikuc asabuuni ogoen: to rub soap into clothes. aikuc ejie: to start a fight. aikuca ki-a to persevere; to persist; to overcome difficulties; to do in spite of difficulties.aikucaikin ki-a to do with difficulty for someone else; to solve somebody’s difficulties. kikucaikit oni Iteso eitaabo lo: we met with great difficulties in publishing this book for the Iteso. ikucanakinete luk’auriak ikecedwe esomero: parents endure hardships to have their children educated. aikucaun ki-a to acquire through difficulties; to do in spite of difficulties. kikucau akoniswam: do your work in spite of the difficulties. aikucokin ki-o to kick off (as of football); to start off (as in a game of cricket or aile). aikuconokin ki-a to take out (as pebbles in omweso or aileisit game); to rub on (as of soap on cloth); to keep starting off (in football); to start to kick off. aikucor ki-o to take out; to take out (as of pebbles from the aileisit game). aikucukucoor ki-o to make a hole; to penetrate; to bore a hole. ekucukucoosi icuc ajimi: the flies have eaten a hole into a sore. ekucukucoor ajimikon: your wound is getting deep. aikud1 ki-a to nag at; to bore, rebuke. aberu ikudi okilenike aitodol naekeria ngesi: the woman nags her husband until he runs away. aikud2 to bend to be warped; to be bent. aikud alosit: to turn a corner. aikud ebela: to bend a stick (to the shape required). aikud akudet: to turn a corner. aikudio annoyance; frustration; exasperation; anger; nuisance; irritation;
