harassment. aikudukuda ki-a to long for; to desire ardently; to titter, laugh quietly. ikudukuda ekatau ajenun akiro ngun: I long to know those issues. aikudukudo ki-o to whisper. lukangai ikudukudos kane?: who are whispering here?aikudukudokin ki-o to whisper to one another. aikujeor ki-o to sky or volley. aikujeor emopiira: to volley a football. aikujuikin ki-o to be like heaven; be heavenly. ikujuikit ekare: my home is like heaven. aikuk to make to kneel or bend the knee of somebody; to supplicate. sirikikuk idwe kinga: do not make the children kneel outside. aikukuj ki-a to tie (in general); to fold up (as of rope). aikukuj akiro: to talk illogically; to babble. ikukujai ijo akonikiro: there is no point in what you say: what you say is mere talk. aikukujakin ki-a to tie up roughly; to insert (tie) a knot; to involve, complicate. aikukujakin akiro: to petty talk.aikukujaun ki-o (of words) to be entangled; to be inextricable; to be illogical, pointless, or mixed up. to complicate (with akiro). aikukum ki-a (of thunder, train or plane) to make noise.aikukumaar ki-o to fall down and away (as of a tree or rock). aikukwaikin ki-a (of seeds when germinating) to become pointed; (of hedge or animal like porcupine) to be thorny. aikul to peel, pare, cut (to peel off bark). aikul aijar: to enjoy oneself; to indulge; to have a nice time. kokulata acok: peel potatoes. ekuli ngesi etwo: she/he pares (cuts even) the gourd.aikula ki-a to boil often; to beat up often. aikulaar ki-a to heat a liquid to boiling point; to beat up once. aikulecer ki-a to be undercooked; (of food) to be undone; (of a person) to be unable to sleep; (of a person) to be obstinate. ekulecerata acok: the potatoes are undone. ikulecerito akonye: the eyes are unable to sleep. aikum to bend forward. ekumete Iteso ekoriete: the Iteso bend forward while cultivating. aikumem ki-o to be prominent (as of a rock or fat-bodied person or animal or buttocks); to rise up from (as of a mountain); to stick up in the air (as of a house, tree). ekumem emoru: the mountain is prominent. aikumemet height; prominence. aikun ki-a to lament; to cry a long time; to bellow (as of cows or bulls going home in the evening); to howl (as of hyena); to roar (as of lion).aikuna1 ki-a to be misty, foggy, or hazy; to be constipated; to have indigestion. ekuna akoik: to be constipated. ikunai emoru ngol: it is foggy around that rock or mountain. aikuna2 ki-a to hoard up; to store up; to amass (things). lokebit emina aikuna iboro: a miser likes to hoard up things or property. aikunaikin ki-a to hoard up for; to store up for (somebody or somewhere); to have fixed deposit account. ikunaikit ngesi isirigin oposita: she/he has a fixed deposit in the Post Bank. aikung ki-o to knock (at the door). sirikimurwok aikungukung ekek ilosi aanyun lokapolon: do not forget to knock at the door when you go to an important man’s office or house.aikunget a rubber stamp; a coccyx (part of a skeleton; rudimentary tail.aikungokin ki-o to knock once only. ingai ekungoki ekakek?: who is there knocking at my door?aikungukung ki-o to knock repeatedly; to rap at the door (to call for someone to open).aikuny1 ki-a to shift slowly; to go step by step; to change place.aikuny2 ki-a (Protestant church) to take part in a holy communion sacrament; to partake of bread and wine (in church). aikunya ki-a to sit down waiting for food silently. aikunya inyamat: to wait for food; to beg silently for food.aikunyakin ki-a to move towards; to shift to; to go and receive holy communion. kikunyakisi ngina: shift that way. aikunyar ki-a to move away; to draw back. aikunyukunya ki-a to shift backwards and forwards; to fidget; to move forwards and backwards (as of people in a row or when suddenly meeting danger); to prepare for a journey; to shift about in a chair, as a sign of discomfort or uneasiness. abu eong kadum emun kasodi aikunyukunya: I met a snake and I fidgeted.kunyukuny backwards and forwards; first in one way, then in another. aikunyun ki-a to approach the speaker; to move this way; to shift this way. aikupa ki-a to dig out (as of groundnuts or potatoes left over in the garden); to find a way (for getting something). aikupa akwap tai: to look for in vain, to try in vain, to dig in vain (for potatoes, etc). aikupaikin ki-a to dig for, look for in vain. kikupaikinai edimaido: try to dig up some groundnuts for me. aikur1 to slide a foot forward or backward. ekurete apesur: the girls slide feet forwards and backwards in edonga dance. ekuri ekosobwan karai ekoto asurokin etunganan: the buffalo stamps and scratches the earth before attacking a person. aikur2 to catch fish with a hook; to roll away, as of cricket ball; to hit (as of tennis ball); to angle. aikur3 to dig out (potatoes, cassava, groundnuts) using stick or hoe; to scold; to tell off continually; to rebuke, inveigh, or browbeat. ekurete angor acok: the women are digging out potatoes.aikura ki-a to do with difficulty; to face or meet difficulty. aikura akwap: to try and dig hard soil. aikuraar (of hair) to shave off in one go; to finish ploughing a plot in one day. aikuraikin ki-a to obtain a thing with difficulty for somebody. aikurakin ki-a aikurakin enyure kibelai: to start the game of cricket.aikuraun ki-a to do with difficulty; to fight one’s way through; to persevere; to obtain with difficulty; to gain; to merit; to hammer out. abu ngesi kikurau ajakaanut aikuraun: she/he obtained a chieftainship (with difficulty) against a lot of opposition. kikurau akoniswam: do your work even though difficult. aikureanar ki-a to begin to be often thirsty. aikureanut ki-a to be continually thirsty. aikurukur ki-o to scratch surface of soil after sowing seeds; to cover sown seed with earth; to scratch ground (like a hen looking for food); to cultivate lightly. aikuruny ki-o to roast or to melt fat from cows or fat of sheep’s tail. aikurunyikin ki-o to mix pasted groundnuts with fat – akuruny - for someone (as a delicacy for visitors). aikusa ki-a to dirty the floor with feet; to make a knife blunt. kinyek aikusa ekileng: do not make the knife blunt. ingai ikusai etogo lo?: who makes this house so dirty?aikusaar1 ki-a to be bumpy. ikusaara erot: the road is bumpy.aikusaar2 ki-a to make blunt (of a knife or spear); to trample down (make a path by constant walking over same spot). sirikikusaa ekakileng: do not blunt my knife. sirikikusaa ekatogo: do not dirty my house (or do not bring dust into my house). kinyekisi aikusaar amanaka aitaraun erot: do not walk over my plot and make a path through it.aikusanut1 cheek, naughtiness, playfulness, etc.aikusanut2 ki-a to be cheeky, naughty, fidgety, etc. aikut1 to blow; to blow the whistle. ekusi ekwam: the wind is blowing. ekusi ngesi alamaru: she/he (blows) plays the flute or clarinet. ekusi aica: the hot season wind (the harmattan) blows. ekusi ngesi epiriigi: she/he blows the whistle. aikut2 to burrow (a hole); to dig up by hand, (of animals) by paw; (of rats, etc) to make a hole; to refuse. ekusit emir ne: the rat has made a hole here. akut eong jik: I have refused altogether. aikuwaar akit ki-a to give a strong blow (or slap) on the ear. aikwa1 ki-a (of rainfall) to stop. ekwaa edou: it has stopped raining. aikwa2 ki-a to boil or cook partly; to boil a little. kikwaa akiring kinyek aibos: boil the meat a little so that it may not go bad. aikwa iporotoi: to warm the throat (by drinking something hot); to soothe with; to lubricate, or to moisten the throat. koinakinai ekia kekwaa iporotoi: give me some medicine to soothe my throat. aikwa3 ki-a to slap (the ears or face); to deal a blow; to hit with a stick. alosi eong aikwa ijo aki kakan: I am going to slap your ears (literally, to warm your ears). aikwaar1 ki-a to clear up; (of rain) to stop. ekwaa edou: is has stopped raining. aikwaar2 ki-a to give a blow. aikwac (of a cat, an eagle, etc) to scratch; to write. kakwac eong ekapa: the cat scratched me. akoto aikwac ebalua: I want to write a letter.aikwad ki-a to clamber, climb with difficulty. aikwaikin ki-a to behave to; to do to. ekwaikini eong ai?: what shall I do? how shall I behave? how shall I go about it? do bo nat eong aikwaikin ai?: what can I do? (a sign of helplessness) to tackle; to treat.aikwam to give a strong blow; to put or give or take too much of anything; to give too much; to put in too much. aikwam ajon: alcohol abuse. kinyek aikwam ajon: do not give too much beer. sirikikwam akipi akile: do not add too much water in the milk. aikwang ki-a to row a canoe; (of a weapon) to graze; to touch slightly (as of a weapon). ajeni eong aikwang ataker: I know how to row a boat. aikwangakin ki-a to row one over to; to row somebody across water in a boat; to graze; to touch slightly (as of weapon grazing, just missing its aim). akoto ijo aikwangakin eong okekwa je: I want you to row me across water. aikwangar ki-a to row away; to ferry across water. to traverse (a river in a boat); to cross over (in a boat). ipedori ijo aikwangar eong okekwa je?: can you row me to the other side? can you ferry me across water? ekwangaros idwe juwai: the children have crossed over in a canoe. aikwar to copulate (of animals only); to cover (seeds in the soil); (in politics) to usurp or take over someone’s powers and privileges. aikwar aloboi: to sow during dry season. ageata itunga aikwar amanatakec: the people have started to sow their plots. luedisiak kotoma aswam kes ekwaritos luapolok aitamameunit angosibib ka abilarit apedorosio kec: those lower in the power hierarchy are the ones who have usurped powers of the leaders, rendering them useless. aikwarun ki-a to return to consciousness by oneself; to revive oneself; to come to from hunger, after eating a little. kaarit eong etengei konye atap na ketakwaru eong: I was dead with hunger, but this food revived me. aikwat ki-a to follow up.aikwatar ki-a to take apart; to take away. to lose weight.aikwatikwataar ki-a to chase away; to take away. aikwaun ki-a to add more hot water; to finish beer; to warm up beer before finishing it. to be warmed up and then finished (of beer only). aikwec ki-o to walk with a forked stick (as support); to stumble along with a stick.aikwecar ki-o to walk away with a stick as support; to stumble away with a support (usually a two-forked stick). aikwel ki-a to like; to long for. ikwela ekatau adumun egaali: I long to get a bicycle.aikwelakin ki-o to like; to long for. ekwelakin eong alosit ore: I long to go home.kekwenyit eong yes kere: I warn you all. aikweny2 to be awake, not to sleep; to open eyes; to be sleepless; to see; to look out. akweny bian eong akware kia: I did not sleep the whole of last night. ekwenyi ngesi, mam emudukana: she/he sees, she/he is not blind. aikweny kia kia: to be awake the whole night. aikwenyar ki-a to warn (somebody or many), admonish, bespeak, apprise, caution. akoto aikwenyar ijo: I want to warn you. aikwenyun ki-o to be on one’s guard, be warned. kikwenyunos yesi ebunit etengei: be on your guard famine is likely. aikwer1 ki-a to stroke (a cat or animals); to caress; to make even or level. ekweri toto ikekoku: the mother caresses her child. aikwer aloboi: to smooth out, level the furrows (after ploughing).aikwer2 to scratch (like a hen); to spread out (as of millet in the yard), etc; to dry in the sun; to equalize. kolot aikwer akimai: go and spread out the millet to dry.aikwerakin ki-a to rake, smooth out (soil or anything). aikwerakin akiria: to spread roasted dough to dry. aikwerikwer: to keep turning the roasted dough with fingers.aikwerikwer ki-a to rake; to flatten; to smooth (the soil aloboi).aikwet akibiriiti: to strike a match. aikwetikwet to beckon (once or many times by hand). aikwic to strangle; to catch in or with a hooped rope; to choke; to throttle; to brace. abu eong kekwic atapeng k’auno: I choked a guinea-fowl with a string.aikwij ki-a to suck; to make a sucking noise (as of child or calf, etc sucking breasts). aikwijikwij: to repetitively make a sucking noise. aikwikwia ki-a to laugh quietly. aikwikwia akwena: to laugh (but not aloud). aikwit ki-a (in a bad sense) to cause ardent longing for; to give longing for; to cause ardent desire or strong feeling; to hanker after. aikwong ki-o to put topsy-turvy; to put higgledy-piggledy; to confuse, not to put in order. ikwongit ijo ikaboro: you have put my things in disorder. aikwongakin ki-o to put things disorderly; to put them higgledy-piggledy. aikwongolikin ki-o to throw down an old man, or a big pole; to place awkwardly. (of anything or thin) to fall down haphazardly; to roll, fall (into bed) in a mess. aikyen1 a curse.aikyen2 ki-o to curse. abu edeke kikyen Kain: God cursed Cain.ainakin etunganan aikyenetoit: to put a curse on somebody. abu Lokasuban koinak Kain aikyenetoit: God put a curse on Cain.abu papa kikyenok ikekoku atwanare: the father put a death curse on his child. aikyenor ki-o to curse one to. akoto aikyenoor ijo bukus: I curse you at your home. aikyonokin ki-o to make level, smooth (of floor, ground, board, etc).aila1 (singular noun F) avoidance; ostracism. aila2 (singular noun F) sanitation; hygiene; cleanliness. aila3 ki-a to wash; to rinse (cloth or anything); to throw water on. ilaete kesi igoen: they are rinsing clothes.aila4 to be clean; to be neat, or holy. elai eketogo: her/his house is clean or neat. aila5 to shun; to hate; to avoid, or forsake. kalait ngesi eong: she/he avoids me. inyo bo kilaitor ijo eong?: why do you shun me? aila6 to space (in planting trees or plants or letters in typing, in producing children, etc). ailaagan ki-a to compete; to contest; to bet. ailaakin ki-a to be irregular doing something; to space (leaving space in between when planting). ailaanakin ki-a to do irregularly; to do now and again. ilaanakini ijo aswam: you work irregularly (not everyday). to plant at irregular distances (as of cotton, etc); to spaceto slap the face or ear repeatedly. ilaanakit ijo epaaba irae: you have planted your cotton at irregular (unequal) distances. ailaanar ki-a to go irregularly; to do now and again. ilaanari ngesi ore: she/he goes home now and again (irregularly).ailaar1 ki-a to visit, travel, stroll; to take a stroll; to take a walk. kilaa oiduka: take a walk to the shop. ailaar2 ki-a to hit, slap on the ear; to deal a blow on the ear. kilaa ber nges akit: first give her/him a slap on the ear. ailaar3 ki-a to wash what is not so dirty; to rinse with water. kilaasi akusiwat: wash yourselves. ailab ki-a to tell a lie; to boast or brag; to give away secrets (in delirium or drunkenness or otherwise). ailab akipi: to use too much water, etc.ailabaikin ki-a to make too wide for, too big for; to level the house for someone. kilabaik ijo eong etogo ngol, mam apedori aiduk: you measured that house too big for me, I may not complete building it. ailabany ki-a to make a thing too wide, like a pot, trousers, suit. abu lokadonyon kilabanya ekapale: the tailor made my trousers too wide. ailabanyaar ki-a to make wide; to widen. ailabanyikin ki-a to make an opening too wide for. ilabanyikit ijo amot na: you made this pot too wide, too big. ailabar ki-a to widen an opening. ailabilab ki-a to chatter or to talk rapidly; to rattle out (words); to babble; to talk much; to prate, prattle or rant. ailabilab einer: to talk much and rapidly. ailabilab akipi: to draw a cup-full or bucket-full of water or other liquid; to take too much of water or other liquid. ailabilabanar ki-a (of previously taciturn person) to become talkative; to waste (especially liquids). elabilabanar etunganan ngol: that man has become very talkative. ailabilabanar akipi: to take or use too much water (as a bad habit). kilabilabanar akipi kere okale je: all the water was taken to the other house. ailabilabanut ki-a to be talkative. ailac to undress; to loosen screws, nuts or bolts, etc; to unfasten something tied tight; to comb, or untie unkempt or braided hair; to release, set free prisoners, etc jailed. kolac akinei: release or set free the goats. ailac igoen: to undress. ailada ki-a to plaster (a wall); to smear; to daub. ailada ekume: to clean the nose with bare hands (like children). ailada ekori: to keep sitting in the same place, not to go away (literally, to plaster one’s tail on the seat). ailadaar ki-a to plaster once. to go (and sit somewhere) waiting for beer or meat. eladaar ngesi neejai akiring: she/he has gone after meat. ailadaet plaster; a thing for plastering.ailadaikin ki-a to smear on; to plaster on or for somebody. ailadaikin ekia ajimi: to plaster medicine on a wound. ailagagam ki-a (of one who is old or sick) to become very thin, emaciated, or scraggy (with collar bones standing out). ilagagamit ikoku: the child is very thin, emaciated (with the clavicle bones protruding). ailagagamikin ki-a to become progressively very thin (with prominent collar bones). elagagamikit eong: I have become very thin (with protruding clavicles). ailagilag ki-a to make large, wide, big (of a house, a pot, or garden). ilagilagit ijo akonimana: you have made a big garden (plot). ailagilagaar ki-a to build a big house or make something big in some place away from speaker. kilagilagaa ekonitogo ngina: build your big house over there. ailagilagakin ki-a to make large, wide, big (of a house, a pot, or garden) for somebody. ilagilagakit ijo nges etogo loepol: you built her/him a big house. ailagoikin ki-o to curdle (of milk); to be dew-webbed; to be hazy (of eyes); to have dew-webs (as of grass overgrowing path and full of dew-webs). elagoikis akile: the milk has curdled. elagokis inya: the grass is full of dew-webs. ailaikin ki-a to wash slightly dirty utensils or clothes for somebody or somewhere; to rinse for. kilaikinai eong ikagoen: wash my clothes for me. ailaila1 ki-a to speak in a loud voice; to talk too loudly; to talk much and quickly, gabble. ilailai ekesa ngol bala loka ikerep: that guy gabbles like a madman. ilailai ikoku ngin: that child talks too much.ailaila2 ki-a to rinse (clothes, utensils, etc). ailaila imomwa: to rinse ash from the sorghum so that it germinates in preparation for beer making.ailair ki-a to swear; to vow; to take an oath.ailaj ki-a to slacken (rope); to loosen; to sag; to unscrew; to untie. akoto eong ailaj akine, iketakit auno: I want to loosen the goat, the rope is too tight on it. ailajilaj ki-a to slacken (rope); to untie, unscrew. ailajilaj akerit: to slacken pace. ailajilaj aswam: to work sluggishly.ailajilaj akuwan: to relax the body, relax muscles. ailajilaj epale: to undo trousers or shorts.ailajilajakin ki-a to loosen, slacken, etc for somebody. to be slack, loose (as of rope, a screw, etc). ailak to undo, unfold; to redeem a mortgaged item of property. ailak aberu: to divorce a woman, to separate. ailak auno: to undo an entangled string. ailak egoe arai apapula: to unfold a cloth or paper. ailak itim: to comb hair. ailak etunganan: to free a prisoner; to redeem; to free a man from debt or prison. ailak etogo: to take off grass from the hut. ailak egaali: to redeem a mortgaged bicycle; to take a bicycle to pieces. ailak etau: to soften the heart; to be appeased. ailakakin ki-a to shake off for somebody; to beat a mat for somebody or somewhere. kilakak ekonimukeeka ngina: go and shake your dusty mat over there. ailakar ki-a to shake off (as of water, dust, etc) from mat, feet, hand, or of dog shaking ears. to have become loose; to shake loose. alakanaros ipetai luka egaalika: the nuts of my bicycle have become loose. ailakilak ki-a to shake; to brandish; to agitate. kilakilak emukeeka ngol: shake that mat (to take out the dust). ailakilak ikur: (euphemism) to dance (literally, to shake off maggots). ailakilak akwara kikel: to become angry and daring (literally, to brandish a spear with the teeth). ailakilakun ki-a to loosen; to untie, undo; to select second hand clothes for oneself. to come loose. elakilakun adukokino kec: their marriage has come apart. ailakun ki-a to shake this way. kilaku emaido: shake off the earth from the groundnuts. to come loose; to become free. ailala ki-a to sound the alarm. kilalaata, abu ekokolan: sound the alarm, a thief has come.ailalakin ki-a to shout for help; to beat the alarm for something; to raise alarm, call attention. nepe kidoluni iso kilalakinete itunga: as soon as we arrived, people sounded the alarm.ailalarikin ki-o to be in a place where one is in view of everybody; to be bare and visible to all; to be outstanding, as of high tree or house.ailam1 ki-a to curse. kelamit eong ijo: I have cursed you. ailam ikoku: to make the child ill, by the sexual intercourse of father and its mother (Teso culture forbids sexual intercourse with a breast-feeding woman). irwa kane, yes lukilamitai: go away from me, you cursed ones. ailam2 ki-a to jump over; to hop over; to pass over. ailam kuju: high jump. ailam kwap: long jump. ailam erot: to go across the road; to pass a road.ailamalam ki-a to step across things (considered bad manners to step over food). ailamasit a curse; an anthema.ailamilam ki-a to clean sorghum from ashes when making beer. ailamilam imomwa: to clean sorghum germinated in ashes (in the preparation of ajon). ailamilam amuk: to throw sandals about in order to predict the future (especially by those embarking on a raiding mission). ailamilamaror ki-a (prepositional verb) to take through danger; to help to pass through (as of cows through quarantine regulations); to take through an adventurous journey; to smuggle through. ekoto ngesi ailamilamaror akituk Bugondo: she/he wants to smuggle cattle to Bugondo in Serere county, Soroti. ailamulamun ki-o to pass through danger; to get over difficulties. adeka koleje eong noi, konye elamulamun do: I was very ill recently, but I have got over it. elamulamun eong kotoma atwanare: I escaped death narrowly. ailamun1 to come across this way; to cross into the new year. elamunos akituk nuko Karamoja lailo, ayautu edeke: the Karamoja cows have come this way and have brought rinderpest. ailamun2 ki-a (of the moon) to rise. elamu elap: the moon has risen; it is new moon. elap loelamunan: the new moon. ailang ki-a to emit seminal fluid (of a man or animal). ailangakin to emit semen humanum; to have an ejaculation. ailangar ki-a to get hold of a very hot thing; to take away a very hot thing (like burning charcoal or very hot food) in bare hands. ailangilang ki-a to juggle with the hand; to toss about (as of one carrying hot charcoal or hot food); to burn (the hand holding a hot thing). elangilangi eong inyamat: I am carrying or eating very hot food. ailangilangaar ki-a to carry away (as of a hot charcoal or anything hot, juggling it in the hand). ailangilangakin ki-a to give something hot to somebody, like a hot piece of charcoal or hot food, juggling it in one’s hand; to pick hot food. kilangilangakinai eong atotolet: bring me a bit of glowing charcoal by hand. ailango ki-o to catch by opening the mouth, like a dog does food thrown at it; to catch with open hands; to catch in flight. ilangoi ekingok atap: the dog catches food in its open mouth. ailangoikin ki-o to catch an airborne object for somebody; to be like the Langi people or their language and culture. kilangoikinoi eong emopiira ngol: catch that football for me. ailangoor ki-o to catch in the mouth (like a dog catching food thrown at it); to catch by hand (as of a football); to catch in flight; to catch whilst running (like they catch handball at play). ailangoun ki-o to catch at this location. ailany ki-a to overtake; to be ahead of; to surpass in size or cleverness or speed. abu Olanya kilany Omer: Olanya surpassed Omer in running. abu ngesi kilany oni: (euphemism) she/he passed away; she/he left us - died. ailanyar ki-a to overtake; to keep ahead of somebody; to surpass. kilanyari ngesi ijo k’acoa: she/he is cleverer than you (will surpass you in cleverness). ailap ki-a to spill; to tip out (liquids). sirikilap akipi: do not spill water. ailapad ki-a (of a person or an animal) to move freely. ailapad korot: to move aimlessly. ailapadaanut ki-a to be free. ailapadaara freedom of action; liberty; lack of restrictions; free will; choice. ailapakin ki-a to pour a little on or into; to pour or spill on; to waste (liquids); to serve with (liquids). elapakit eong akipi akuwanaka kere: I spilled water all over my body. ailapanar ki-a to keep spilling, pouring out; to inundate; to flood. to keep flowing over; to be in flood. ailapar1 ki-a to flow over; to overflow. elaparos akipi kataagi: the water in the tank is flowing over. ailapar2 ki-a to spill (a little); to tip out (away). kilapa akonikipi ngina: spill your water that way. ailapilap ki-a to run or to lope. ilapilapi ngesi akwap atitai: she/he just goes about doing nothing (big as she/he is). ailapilapakin ki-a to run away. ai bo ilapilapakini ijo?: where do you lope to? ailapuk ki-a to exchange; to uproot stalks from the garden.elapunos akipi kotoma ocilet: the river has overflowed. ailar ki-a to space; to leave space between. ailar epaaba: to space the cotton seeds (not to plant too near to each other).ailarakin ki-a to throw down on the head or side; to bump somebody’s head on the ground. to fall on one’s head; to fall headlong. ailarar1 ki-a to be bare; to be clean; to be shining, as of a washed clean face; to have a broad forehead; to be visible from afar. ilararai Olege: (Olege sits in an open place) Olege is in the open. ilararai elap: the moon is visible (not covered by clouds). ailarar2 ki-a to throw down on the head (of a person or animal); to throw head first. abu eong kelarak emir kwap: I threw the rat head first on the ground. to fall head first or headlong. ailasia ki-a to hit the ground with; to throw down. akoto ailasia ijo akwap: I want to throw you down (literally, I want to hit the ground with you). ailasilas akituk ki-a to flatter, sweet-talk, or cajole. ailasilasakin ki-a to make nice, tasty, or nice looking. kilasilasakinai eong akima: make me some nice porridge. ailat to throw down hard one after another; to swing arms about. kolata ngul kwap: throw them down. ailat akanin: to swing the arms backwards and forwards. ailat akeje: to make long strides. ailatalatatoi ki-o to loaf, mooch or loiter about. ailatat ki-a to lie down spread-eagled and helpless (like a dead person or a drunk). apotu itunga kobilutu Akudo kojeera aibunga erono kokerete ajalakin ilatatai kanen koomitos ebe etwanit: a mob broke into jail and beat up Akudo severely, dispersing when they thought he had died. ailate1 ki-o to hunt with spears. ilateete Iteso kinga na ere: the Iteso often hunt with spears (and call it going for a stroll).ailate2 ki-o to visit, call on; to pay a visit; to travel, hike (wander about). ilato ngesi she/he is (they are) hiking.ailateor ki-o to go away on a visit or journey. ailateun ki-o to pay a visit here. ailaun ki-a to come to pay a visit. akoto ijo da ailaun neka: I want you too to pay me a visit.ailaunun ki-a to come and do irregularly, now and again. ilaununei ngesi lailo: she/he only comes here now and again. aile1 a large pot.aile2 a species of bird - Florican. aile3 (singular noun F) prickly hairs of a plant or shrub. aile4 ki-o to play the game of omweso (a pea game played on a hollowed out board with 32 holes, each player taking 8*2 holes on one side). aile5 to beat; to thrash; to strike; to castigate. aileb ki-a to talk too much; to talk too quickly. ailebileb ki-a to be talkative; to keep on talking, loquacious; to chatter; to talk nonsense or to moonshine.ailebilebanut fond of talking; talkative, garrulous, chatty, or loquacious. ailebilebitoi ki-a to go round chattering, talking nonsense. ailed1 ki-a to smear (oil, butter or anything on the body). iledete Iteso akecewat ka akinyet: the Iteso smear their bodies with fat. ailed2 ki-o to be occupied, busy, engaged in doing something. iledos itunga aimat ajon: people are busy drinking beer. ailedakin ki-a to smear on or over once; to soil with something; to stain. ejai lokiledaki akinyet opaleka: somebody has stained my trousers with oil. ailediled ki-a to smear all over (the body); ceremonial oiling of pregnant women. ailedokin ki-o to be busy doing something; to be engaged in anything, as of working, talking, dancing, fishing, etc. ailedokin ejie: a free fight. eledokinos itunga amat: the people are busy drinking. aileerikin ki-a to expose; to display or put in the open. aileg ki-a to clean (as of nails or teeth, table, pot, etc). ailegakin ki-a to clean for somebody or somewhere. ailegileg ki-a to clean properly (of anything); to rub clean (as of teeth, etc). ailegilegaar ki-a to rinse (a pot); to clean properly; to do spring-cleaning to have become quite well; to have completely recovered. aileicikin ki-o to become ashamed of, shy of; to become bashful. inyo bo kileicikitor ijo?: what are you ashamed of? aileiconor ki-o to become or be bashful, ashamed, shy, modest. aileiconut1 (singular noun F) bashfulness; shyness. aileiconut2 ki-o to be shy, bashful, modest, coy, timid, reserved, self-conscious, withdrawn, blushing. ileicono ngesi: she/he is shy, coy. ileicoko kesi: they are shy. aileikin ki-o to play the game of omweso for or at a certain place. aileor: to go away to play the omweso. aileun: to play the omweso game here. aileile ki-a to carve smooth. aileilear ki-a to go and tell. aileileikin ki-a to tell to; to carve or whittle for. kileileikinai akiro nukorekon: tell me the news from your home. aileileun ki-a to come and tell; to carve and bring. aileisit a board on which the pea-game (omweso) is played with 32 holes. ailej ki-a to make soft (by cooking); to walk like a sick or tired person; to drag one’s legs along. aileja ki-a to take away one by one; to dance (often with bells). kileja amor ngun: take those stones one by one. ailejaanar1 alosit ki-o to drag oneself along (like a lazy, a sick or drunken person). ilejaanaros kesi elosete: they drag themselves along. ailejaanar2 ki-a to keep taking away one big one after another; to keep felling big ones. kilejaana itelepai osomero: take those big boys to school one by one. ailejaar ki-a to faint; to fell a big thing. ailejaar ajo: to be fall fast asleep. ailejakin1 ki-a to dance (often with bells on a string tied to the legs).ailejakin2 ki-a to treat carelessly, be careless about; to lax about. sirikilejak ikoniboro eyangaarete ikokolak: do not be careless about your property, the thieves will steal them. ailejakin3 ki-o (of a big one) to be alone; to be by oneself. eong bon elejakina ore, emamei aberu: I am alone at home, there is no woman. ailejatoi ki-o to slouch about; (of a tall and big person) to walk lazily and awkwardly. ailejilej ki-a to make soft (as of meat or bread by cooking properly); to relax, loosen; to be sleepy; to be without strength; to be weak. ailejong a cloth or skin used to cover a child on the mother’s back to protect it from the sun.ailek1 akwes ki-o to throw the head back; to hold the head back (for communion or for pouring medicine in eye). ailek ikisin: to shake, to flap breasts when walking or running or grinding.ailek2 ki-a to waste, squander, fritter away, or to misuse. ailek3 to vomit; to be sick; to spew; to bring forth (only of a woman). ailek akiro: to say everything one knows. ailek aokot: to vomit blood. aberu ka Malinga abu koleku ikoku isapat: Malinga’s wife gave birth to a baby boy. aso ijo kolek akiro kere nuijeni: well then, tell us all you know about (this or that). ailekakin ki-a to waste on or for or at. kilekakini ijo okoku kon ikoniboro: your son is going to waste your things (for you). alot ngesi Kampala ailekakin ikeboro ngina: she/he went to Kampala to waste her/his things. ailekek ki-o to sit alone and idly. ailekilek ki-a to retch; to feel like vomiting; to spit out. kelekileki eong etau: I feel like vomiting to waste (things). ilekileki ijo ikoniboro atitai: you waste your things anyhow. ilekileki akokor abeei: the hen wastes her eggs (by not laying them in one place). to be disgusted with; to pall. kelekilekata eong akonikiro: I am disgusted with your affairs (of a girl) to shake breasts when walking.ailekoor akou ki-o to throw or hold the head backwards; to look up. kilekoo akou: hold your head back (to drop ointment in the eye, etc). ailekoor akou: to dally, stay behind. elekoorit bian eong akou kore: I dallied at home yesterday. ailel1 happiness; joy; cheerfulness. ailel2 to be pleased; to be happy; to rejoice. apaarit naka ailel: the day of joy; happy day; a feast day. ailele ki-o to sift groundnuts; to prepare nice vegetables; to make delicious groundnuts sauce. ileletoi edia lo: there is plenty of groundnuts sauce in these vegetables. aileleb ki-a to fill in; to replenish; to put facts or answers in the spaces that have been left for them. kileleb akipi amot: fill the water in the pot. aileleba ki-a to be full. ka aileleba in full; in detail. ileleba amoti: the pots are full. ailelebikin ki-o to fill up; to make something totally full; to add so as to make full. kilelebik ecaai oikopoka: fill the tea in my cup (it is not full). ailelebun ki-o to be full; to swell up. elelebun epikisit: my lower leg is swollen. elelebun eong: I am satisfied (satiated); I have had enough (food or drink).ailelebwa ki-a to swing round and round (as of children); to revolve; to do the merry-go-round. ailelebwaun ki-a to make dizzy, faint, giddy, woozy, wobbly, or light-headed. ailelebwaunet dizziness; vertigo; faintness; wooziness; giddiness.ailelekej ki-a (of people) to take part in the rain-dance; to dance round; (of birds) to circle or hover around. ilelekejaete itunga: the people are dancing the rain-dance. ailelekin emaido ki-o to make delicious sauce with groundnuts for someone. ailelem ki-a to bluster or be noisy. kinyekis ailelemat: stop making noise; stop shouting. ailelemakin ki-a to make a noise somewhere or for something. elelemakis idwe kosomero: the children in the school are noisy. ailelerikin ki-a to be bare, open in view of everybody.aileliamit limestone. aileliikin ki-o to become or be striped (of clothes or animals). ileliikit egoe lo: this cloth is striped. ailem1 ki-o to pour too much water into (milk, vegetables or beer, etc); to adulterate. sirikilem akipi toma akile: do not pour much water into the milk: do not adulterate the milk. ailem2 to pick; to take; to reap (cotton); to subtract. koloto ailem epaaba: go and pick cotton. ailem esolo: to pay tax. ailem epaaba: to pick cotton from the garden.ailemilem1 ki-a to adulterate by adding too much water to. ailemilem2 ki-o to float; to move, flow away on the water. ilemilemi ekwam ataker: the wind floats the canoe. ailemilemo ki-o to float on the water or on any liquid. ilemilemos idwe kotoma akipi: the children are floating in the water. ailemilemoor ki-o to wriggle away or about (as a tadpole or mosquito larvae, or children playing in the water). elemilemooros atakerin okekwa je: the canoes have floated away to the other side of the lake. ailenge ki-o to cut; to sever; (in tennis) to cut the ball (to hit it before it drops). ilengeete itelepai inya: the boys cut the grass (of the lawn). ailengoikin1 ki-o to cut off for; to slaughter for. kilengoikinoi akakokor: slaughter the hen for me. ailengokin2 ki-o to detach; to separate; to seclude; to put aside or apart by itself; to give one alone. kilengok emong bon: seclude the bull. to be or to be left by oneself, seclude oneself; to live in solitude. alengokin eong bon aswam: I am doing the work in isolation. ailengoor ki-o to cut off (the head); (in cricket or tennis) to cut the ball; to flay. ailengoor akou: to cut off the head. abu esirikaalet kilengoo Yokana Lokebatisan akekou: a soldier cut off the head of John the Baptist. aileny ki-a to cut (as of branches); to cut up; to break up (as of wood or bones which are too long). kileny akojo numam ilosikino amot: cut up the bones which are too long to go into the cooking pot.ailenyar ki-a to cut off (as of branches); to prune (a tree). ailenyasit a joint (as of wrist, elbow, knee, etc). ailenyeleny akiro ki-a to give someone a piece of one’s mind. ailenyet the wrist. ailep1 ki-a to sift; to sieve; to filter. kilep akiria ngun: sift that flour. ailep2 to spout out; to milk; to have diarrhoea. elepi ikoku noi: the child has intense diarrhoea. ailep aokot: to have dysentery. ape kolep akiteng: go and milk the cow. ailepaanut1 (singular noun F) impudence; cheek. ailepaanut2 ki-a to be cheeky; to be impudent. ailepaikin1 ki-a to be impudent; to become cheeky. ilepakit ikoku: that child has become cheeky. ailepakin2 ki-a to toss on; to lift on to. kilepak asaduku ngin omotoka: lift that box on to the motorcar. ailepanar kuju: to bounce up and down (as of a ball or a dancer). ailepanut a creeper or grass used for making granaries. ailepar ki-a to bounce (as of a ball or animal); to lift up; to bump about; to bounce. ailepar okekwa je: to run to the other side of the valley or lake; to rush over. ilepanar ngesi elosi: she/he has a bouncing gait; she/he gallops. ailepep ki-a to protrude; to project, stick up or out; to jut out. ilepepeete ikela kon kwape kaluka etom: your teeth protrude like those of an elephant. ailepet a sieve (for flour); a sift. ailepilep ki-a to sieve (as flour, sand); to toss up and down; to flay a person. ailepilep akwap: to run away. ailepun ki-a to lift up, hoist. to bounce up; to emerge; to come up. ailepun akiro: to make known (secrets). elepunos akiro: secrets have leaked out. ailer1 ki-a to tighten; to harden (as of floor or of rope). ailer2 ki-o to keep in the open; to be very visible; to follow the middle of the road. kiler erot ilosi Katakwi: follow the road going to Katakwi. kiler akito ngun ilosi okekwa je: walk on these two poles to cross over to the other side.ailer3 ki-o a corruption of ailore: to glitter or to dazzle. ailerakin1 ki-o to become hard, solid (of ground or anything). ailerakin2 kwap ki-a to throw down hard. ailerar ki-o to drop dead; (euphemism) to die; to become hard. eleraros alup: the ground has become very hard. elerar esimit: the cement has become very hard. ailerer ki-o to be visible; to be plain; to lie naked or bare (without covering); to be obvious; (of an explanation) to be clear. emoru Elgon ilererei tupuruc: Mt. Elgon is very visible in the morning. ailererikin1 ki-o to expose oneself; to put oneself in the open for everyone to see. ailererikin2 ki-a to put in sight; to put in the open for everyone to see; to expose. kilererik ekonitogo amukurat ngin: put your house on top of that hill, to make it visible. ailererikin esakarameetu: to expose the blessed sacrament. ailes ki-a to jump from one branch to another, like a monkey or a tree squirrel. ailesiles egaali: to jump (with one leg and then) on to the bicycle. ailes angabes: (of dancers) to dance like there are no bones on the waist. ailesakin ki-o to jump on (as on a bicycle). elesakin ngesi ogaali: she/he jumped on her/his bicycle. ailesar ki-o to jump away; to run off at a gallop; to gallop away like a donkey or a horse. aileseikin to stretch out (of mats, skins, cloth, etc) in the sun for someone.ailesikin ki-o to fit inside something; to suffice; to be sufficient for.ailetileta ki-a (of a drunken person) to be dizzy. iletileta lokameran: the drunkard is stupefied. ailetiletakin ki-a to become dizzy; to become drunk, tipsy, throw down (of many) to be drunk, dizzy, tipsy; to lie down side by side (of many people).aileya ki-a to do in turns; to do one after another. aili to pour out; to separate liquid from something unwanted; to sieve or filter. koli ecaai: pour out the tea. iboro lueliak: liquids. ailia to creep, or to crawl (of a snake, etc); (of a person) to be on all fours. eliai emun: the snake crawls. eliat etunganan loemera: the drunk man is on his hands and knees. ailiak ki-a to shake or nod the head (as of approval or when working). ailiak kokau: to straggle or lag behind. ailiak alosit: to go or to walk while shaking or nodding the head. ai bo iliaki ijo?: where are you going as if you are tired? ailiakakin ki-a to nod to; to approve by nodding to. ailiakakinet a nod; an approval by nodding. ailiakar ki-a to go away; to go to somewhere. ailiak ekosio: to dance nodding head (up and down). ailiaketait nape; back of neck. ailianet a flame (of fire). abu eong kaany ailianet naka akim: I saw a flame of fire. ailib1 to be chilly; to be draughty. elibi akakuwan: I feel chilly. ailib2 to sprout out leaves (as of burnt grass or seeds or trees); (of sick people) to recuperate. egoe eliba: green cloth. naliba: green. loliba, lulibaik. ailiba ki-a to skim liquids (especially water); to scoop water slowly (without stirring the dirt up from the bottom). elibai eong akipi kokicoi: I am skimming water from a shallow well. ailibaun ki-a to skim liquids (especially water) for oneself; to scoop water slowly (without stirring the dirt up from the bottom) for oneself. elibaununutu angor akipi kokicoi: the women have skimmed water for themselves from a shallow well. ailic ki-a to make (things and men) disappear. ejai yenilici ikaboro: someone is stealthily taking my things. ailicakin ki-o to disappear or to get lost somewhere (especially underwater). elicakin ataker ocor: the boat has sank in the lake. ailicar ki-a to make to disappear, or to cause to disappear to vanish; to disappear; to be absent; to hide away. elicaros ikatunga: my people have disappeared. elicar elap: the moon has hidden. ailid to take hold of; to hold fast, or tight; to clasp; to fasten tight; to grip; to brace. elidit eturuturut angabet: the hornet has a narrow waist. ailiil1 ki-a to swing round in a circle; to move round, swing, blow about; to move up and down. ekwam iiliili ikito: the wind swings trees. ailiil2 to be very big, grotesque, tremendously big, or colossal (said of anything); to be horrible; to be awe-inspiring, terrifying; to be very dirty; to be afraid to touch; to be very big (like an elephant). eiliili emoru Masaba: Mt. Elgon is an awe-inspiring mountain. eiliili etom: the elephant is massive. eiliili abangaanutuke: her/his ignorance is too much. eiliili ates: the corpse is horrible. ailiilar ki-a to swing away. ailiili a water bird – the sacred ibis. ailiilikin to cause fear to; to inspire awe; to make afraid, terrify. kailiiliki eong etom: the elephant scares me. ailiilior to become very big; to become awe-inspiring; to become very dirty (with akou, to become very proud, swollen-headed). ailiilit a wild duck. ailiilun ki-a to swing back; to bring back by force; to swing, shake tail. to come back in a hurry; to run back. ailij ki-a to prick with a thorn or nail (of finger); to pierce easily; to bite (something soft). elij lolo eong emuebe: I have enjoyed mango fruits today. ailijakin ki-a to bite at something succulent; to pierce easily; to prick. kelijaki bian eong ekukwai akeju: a thorn pierced my soft foot yesterday. ailijilij ki-a to prick, peck (like a hen at a boiled potato). ailijilijakin ki-a to pierce (the skin); to penetrate deep; to suck (as of calf or child sucking breast of mother). ailik ki-o to swallow; to gulp; to absorb. ailik eluwe: to swallow like a frog or one without teeth, like a child or like an old person; to devour. ailiketait an oesophagus; a gullet. ailikidianut1 meanness with food; stinginess, etc. ailikidianut2 ki-a to be greedy, stingy, etc. ailikidikin ki-a to covet; to long for, hanker after; to wish. to be covetous. elikidikit eong ekonigaali: I wish your bicycle was mine. to wish for; to desire. elikidikinos kesi aimat akecejon bonik: they want to drink their beer by themselves.ailikilik ki-a to tear out; to pull out by force; to drag out (as of a thing fixed, difficult to loosen or to get out). ailikilikun ki-a to pull out, drag out; to force out; to pinch nose or cheeks. ailikonor ki-o to swallow continually, morsel after morsel. ailikonut ki-o to swallow quickly or to swallow one morsel after another; to gobble up. ailikor ki-o to swallow; to swallow up (like a hole or river swallowing a man or object thrown into it); to agree; to hold (as of a canoe, ship or church). kiliko ekia lo: swallow this medicine. eliko eong akonikiro: I understand what you say. ilikorit ataker ngin itunga ipu: that canoe holds many people. ailila1 akiro ki-a to tell good news or stories; to tell jokes. ililai ngesi akiro: she/he tells interesting stories. elilai ngesi akiro nuka akwena: she/he was telling jokes. ailila2 ki-a to take a thing secretly; to abscond; to pilfer. eja luililaete ikaboro: there are people who take my things secretly.aililaar ki-a to take away secretly; to smooth off; to sweep clean; to perfect. to abscond; to hide.aililaikin akiro ki-a to tell good news to or somewhere. kililaikinai eong akiro nukorekon: tell me some good news from your home. ailili1 a species of wading bird of the duck family; a small wild duck. ailili2 to envy; to be jealous of; to covet. kalilit eong ijo kanuka Ateso: I am envious of you because of Ateso. alili eong ekonigaali: I am envying your bicycle. aililia ki-a to purify pure. aililiam1 ki-a to become hard; to be clean. aililiam2 ki-a to be hard; (of something polished) to shine (like a clear moon).aililiang2 the biceps and triceps; the muscle of the upper arm. aililiget the umbilical cord; origin; beginning; element. aililiget nak’emaido the string or roots of the groundnuts after the plucking. aililiget nak’etaget: a flower of plantain. aililing1 (singular noun F) silence; hush; peace. aililing2 ki-a to be silent, calm, quiet, not resounding when tapped; to be in retreat or seclusion. inyukutan luililingete: consonants. aisililing: to silence, soothe; to make to keep quiet. aliling ejose: to refuse to answer, to act deaf; to feign deafness. aililing tii ti: to be very quiet, absolutely silent. aililinganut1 (singular noun F) silence; taciturnity. aililinganut2 ki-a to be often silent. aililingikin ki-a to keep or be silent to one asking a question - not to answer somebody. inyo bo kilingikinia ijo eong?: why do not answer me? aililingun ki-a to become silent; to become quiet. aililyam ki-a to be very hard; to shine (like the moon or star); to be polished like a diamond. ailim1 ki-a (of rain) to fall. ilimit edou epol: it rained very much.ailim2 to say; to speak out; to tell. karai ejaas nuikoto, kolim: if there is anything you want, speak out. aitilim: to make to say; to cause to speak. ailimakin ki-a (of rain) to fall on; to rain once; to inebriate. ilimakinit ca ngol edou: it seems it rained on him, he appears tipsy or drunk.ailimakinet a spot or freckle; a stain; a drizzle (of rain). ailimanakin ki-a to make spots; to freckle to have spots; to be freckled or have freckles. ailimanar ki-o to begin to rain (a few drops); to drizzle here and there. ilimanar edou: it is beginning to rain. ailimilim ki-a (of rain) to drizzle; (of dirt) to make spots on; to fleck; to mottle. ailing to be first; to be early there; to go there early. koling osomero: be early to school; be early at school. ailingiling ki-a to adorn; to decorate. ailingokin atap ki-a to cook badly; to serve half-cooked or raw millet bread. ipoi ngesi elingo: she/he cooks badly (because she/he does not allow water for mingling bread to boil, or she/he over-boils it).ailiok1 to tell lies. iliokit ijo akiro: you have told lies.ailiok2 to set on edge (of teeth); to make blunt (especially a cutting edge of a knife or an axe). ailiok ekileng: to make a knife blunt. ailiok ikel: to set teeth on edge. elioki emuebe ikel: a mango fruit sets teeth on edge. amoru elioki ekileng: a stone blunts a knife (by trying to cut a stone).ailiokan a withy; a pliable branch or twig. ailip1 prayer. ailip naka atupuruc: morning prayer; matins. ailip naka atibong: evening prayer; vespers. ailip2 ki-a (of a boil) to swell. ailip3 ki-a to ask; to beseech; to beg; to pray. ejai ibore yenikelipit eong ijo: there is something I asked from you. ailip aswam: to ask for work; to apply for employment. ailipanar ki-a to beg and take away often. to become a beggar. ailipanut1 begging often; asking persistently; petitioning often. ailipanut2 ki-a to be fond of asking; to be a beggar. ailipasit an asking prayer; a petition; a request. ailipesit head of sore; head of swelling. ailipilip ki-a to beg repeatedly; to pray continually; to beg from many people. ailipilipaar ki-a to grow a swelling. ailipilipitoi ki-a to go begging. ailipilipun ki-o (of a boil) to swell; to come to a head. elipilipunos abusioka: my boils have swollen. ailipun1 ki-a (of a swelling) to come up; to swell up. ailipun2 ki-a to ask for oneself. ailipun inyamat: to beg for food. ailir1 ki-a to stamp hard (as of floor, gravel, cement, etc); to fix properly, securely; to press together, compress. akituk ilirete auryanet: the cows trample down their resting or milking ground. kilirata epir lo: fix this pole properly. ailir2 ki-o to run fast (as of a guinea fowl or a quail); to roll down; to go rolling fast, as of a ball or wheel. iliri atapeng kokwap: the guinea fowl runs fast in the ground. iliri emopiira: the ball rolls fast. ailirakin ki-a to mingle just enough atap for a few people. akoto ber eong ailirakin ecokok atap adis: I want to first mingle a little atap for herdsmen. ailiret a lump of atap used to clean up the remnants of groundnut paste on the grindstone or mortar, afterwards eaten by the children. ailirilir ki-a to harden by rolling; to make hard (of soil, ground, food). akoto alirilir atap kanyam: I want to let the food get solid, then I may eat. ilirilirete akituk akamana: the cows are compacting the soil in my garden (by trampling). ailirilirakin ki-a to make hard by rolling or trampling; to stamp (floor); to cook food solid (by adding enough flour, etc).ailirira ki-a to stand or to be dumbfounded, stupefied, stunned. ailirokin ki-a to fix securely, immovably; to run fast to. ilirokina akwara kwap: the spear is fixed immovably in the ground. ailisin ki-a to be foggy, misty. ilisinat lolo akwap: it is very foggy today. ailisinakin ki-a to look or be like mist or fog. elisinaki edou: the cloud looks like fog. ailit1 a nest for hens to lay eggs in; a cavity; a grave.ailit2 chain of iron; spiral rings worn round lower arm and leg. ailit3 iboro ki-o to measure unequally; to distribute unevenly, unjustly. ilisit ijo ipirin luk’etogo erono: you have cut the poles of the house badly (too long). kinyek ailit akeje kingaren: do not out-walk me, do not walk so quickly. ailit akiro: to tell lies. ailit akeje: to out-walk or out-run somebody. ailit4 (of plants or trees) to be barren. alit ekitoi lo: this tree is (these trees are) barren. ailiya to shine (of sun or lamp, etc); to dazzle, or coruscate. iliyai elap kware: the moon shines at night. ailo1 ki-a to excel; to surpass, overcome; to go against; to lose (a case). keloata eong akiro: I lost the case. keloit eong aswam ngin: that work defeats me.ailo2 to dry; to air, spread out in the sun. koya egoe lo ailo: take this cloth to dry in the sun. ailo akanin: to spread out hands (palms up) as sign of denial or in gesticulating when preaching. ailobo ki-o to dig deep; to plough with oxen another time. iloboete Iteso akecemanat: the Iteso plough their plots twice before sowing. ailobokin ki-o to dig in; to plant (seeds, etc). ailobokin emaido kwap: to dig in the groundnuts. ailoboor ki-o to plough or to dig up a field once; to dig or plough the grass under. ailoboor amana: to plough a garden without planting anything in it. ailoboor inya: to plough in the weeds in the garden for mulch. ailobwa ki-a to tie (a person or an animal) with a rope; to put behind bars. ilobwatai ikokolak kojeera Luzira: thieves are being held behind bars in Luzira prison. ejai ilobwatai: to be under arrest; to be a prisoner of the police or soldiers. ailoc ki-o to take from one place to another; to alter; to interpret, transfer. ailociloc ki-o to change about or alter often. ailocokin1 (singular noun F) transfiguration; (chemistry) sublimation. ailocokin2 ki-o to interpret; to translate; to change place for; to change manners; to dress in other clothes; to alter; to disguise. kilocok iponesiokon: change your manners. to be transfigured; to change appearance; to become something else. elocokin etelepat: that boy has changed. abu Yesu kilocokin kakonye ka ikiyakia: Jesus was transfigured before his apostles. elocokin Onyait araun esirikaalet: Onyait has become a soldier. ailoconokin ki-o to fluctuate. ailoconor ki-o to change often; to keep changing; to exchange (as of money, cows, places, anything). iloconorio ngesi irwan ipu: she/he is transferred often. iloconor aberu ngin ikar kere: that woman changes husbands every year.ailocor ki-o to transport; to transfer (to another place); to change; to appoint to another place. ailod ki-a to go or travel to many places; to roam or wander about.kilodak atipe omorosing: tie a string of beads round your neck. ailodar ki-a to encircle; to surround (in hunting, etc); to go behind a house, granary, etc; to make the round of. luamejak egeete ber ailodar amonieik: the hunters first surround the thickets.ailodilod ki-a to coil round; to go round and round. ilodilodi emun ekitoi: the snake is coiling round a tree. ailodilodakin to coil round something; to twine itself round somebody or something. emun ilodilodakin elope okitoi: the snake coils itself round a tree. ailodo ki-o to beat; to lash (a person, animal, etc). abu esirikaalet kilodo etunganan k’eiboko: the soldier lashed a man with a whip. ailog ki-a to search; to explore; to reconnoitre. akoto ailog ekonitogo: I want to search your house. irotin luilogas: a labyrinth of roads. ailogilog etau: to examine one’s conscience.ailoga ki-a to charm, bewitch with herbs, etc.ailogakin ki-a to brandish a stick (in a dance) (of different things) to get mixed up. elogakinos akituk kotoma auj: the cows are mixed up in the cowshed or kraal. ailogar ki-a to brandish a stick; to travel to many places. ailogar akwap: to go round visiting places; to travel about. ailogilog ki-a to search repeatedly; to explore. ailogilog akiro: to investigate a case, examine, question.ailoilo1 ki-o to eat like a toothless person; to chew food with difficulty (especially shifting food from side to side).ailoilo2 ki-o to speak very loudly; to speak in a loud voice.ailoilo3 ki-o to cut up in lumps; to crush with a hammer into big lumps (said of stones, cassava, etc). ailoiloikin: to cut up in lumps for somebody. ailok1 ki-a to redeem (cows, cattle); to pay for looking after cattle. iloki ngesi akituk: she/he redeems her/his cattle. ailok2 ki-o to loosen, unfasten; to shake loose (a peg or pole or anything fixed); to persuade; to shake somebody in their plan; to get somebody round. ailok3 to trap; to ensnare (of man or animal); to bait. alokit eong emir: I have set a trap for the rat. ailok4 to knock out or to remove lower teeth. alosi eong ailok ikel: I am going to have my lower incisors knocked out. ailoka ki-a to transfer (liquids, etc) from one container or place to another. kilokaa esisianakinan ngol aibois ace: transfer that teacher to another place. ailokaikin ki-a to change or put somewhere else; to paint in a different colour. kilokaik akiria toma amot: shift the flour into the pot. akoto ailokaikin arwatat na eceraagi: I want to paint this wall another colour. ailokar ki-a to change colour; to change into; to repeat in other words; to transfer; to take or put somewhere else. akoto ailokar akituk nenice: I want to take my cows somewhere else. to fade. elokaros igoen ka: my clothes have faded. ailokaun ki-a to change to this side to be changed to this side. ailokilok ki-o to keep shaking (anything); to loosen. ailokilokoor ki-o to loosen by shaking. ailokokin ki-o to redeem for somebody; to pay for looking after something. ailokony ki-a to go in the opposite direction; to ignore; to exchange things; to pass without greeting; to mix up, barter (with other things), put in disorder; to boycott. okwe kobongokinai akiro, kinyek ailokony: please answer me and stop ignoring me. ailokonyikin ki-a to confuse; to dislocate; to put in disorder; to entangle a rope; to tie crosswise. ailokonyikin akiro: to spoil a discussion (by interfering or by illogical statement). to be entangled (of rope or case); to pass each other; to be intricate; (of teeth) to grow over one another. elokonyikinos ikekel: her/his teeth have grown over each other. ailokonyikin akeje: to cross legs. kilokonyikis akanin kus: cross your arms. ailokor ki-o to buy back; to return.ailokun1 ki-o to bring back; to return. akoto ailokun ikaboro luabu eong kainak ijo aidar: I want to get back my property that I gave you to look after.ailokun2 ki-o to talk round; to shake somebody in his opinion; to convince; to persuade. ailoli ki-a to keep moving a thing about. ilolie ngesi ikeboro: she/he moves her/his things about. ailoli akuwan: to move oneself about; to be restless. ailoli akonye: to roll eyes; to be curious; to look right and left. ailolio: to be driven from pillar to post. ailoli akiro: to tell-tale; to newsmonger. ailoli iselio: to be alarmed (as of a thief caught suddenly); to tremble or quake or be in a panic. elolitoi eong kotoma aswam: I am fussy in my work.ailolianut1 (singular noun F) cheek, nerve, gall, effrontery, chutzpah; playfulness, mischievousness; fuss, to-do, bother, excitement. ailolianut2 ki-a to be cheeky, playful, fussy, frivolous, etc ailoliar ki-a to take away (anything) immediately. kilolia akinei ngun ore je: take away those goats quickly to the other home. ailoliikin ki-a to move one’s things about. eloliikis ikatunga awatekec: my people are fussing around. ailolit1 iselio ki-a to be fussy; to hurry about different works, hurry up work. ailolit2 ki-a to keep moving something. kinyek ailolit akonye: do not be so curious (literally, do not keep moving your eyes). ailolitoi ki-o to be fussy; to fidget; to be restless. ailoloar ki-a to rinse away; to cleanse off; to wash out; to flush out. kiloloa amot ngin: cleanse or rinse out that pot. ailoloaret ablution; rinsing; bathing. ailolog ki-a to search; to find out; to be looking for. ilologaete lolo ipolisin itogoi: the police are searching houses today. ailologaar ki-a to take away (after searching); to steal; to rifle. ejai yenikilologaa akabalang: somebody has taken my salt ash away. ailologakin ki-a to search for; to search in a certain place. kolot kilologak ikoku esukaali kotogo: go and search for some sugar in the house for the child. ailologaun ki-a to bring all (after searching); to steal and bring; to mop up; to gather all. elologaun abenyak ko Teso: all rebels have been arrested in Teso. ailolom ki-o to be noisy; to make noise. ailolomonut ki-o to be in the habit of speaking in a loud voice; to be cantankerous, boisterous, raucous. elolomono eong, ilolomoko yesi: I, you are boisterous, noisy, loudspeaking. ailolomot ki-o to speak in a loud voice; to shout. sirilolomotos: do not shout.ailolony ki-a to be exhausted; to be very tired. ilolonyit kesi: they are exhausted (literally, it tires them). ailoloun ki-a to wash out, purify, or rinse out. kilolou eikopo lo: rinse out this cup. ailom1 aberu to commit adultery. ikamunitai Otwao elomit aberu: Otwao was caught in adultery. ailom2 to come out (of seeds or person, etc); to come in; to enter a newly built house. akoto eong ailom togoka: I want to enter (start staying in) my new house. age ekapaaba ailom: my cotton has come up. aitolom akiro: to cause trouble, to utter. ailong ki-a to wash (the body); to bathe. mam ijo ilongit: you have not bathed. ilongarit ijo ainyinyir: you are sweating all over (literally, you are bathed in sweat). (note: ailot is used when washing hands, feet or any single part of the body is implied). ailongakin ki-a to take a bath somewhere or to wash somewhere or in front of somebody. ailongakin ates: to bathe someone (who did not attend the funeral) at the graveside. ailonget a bathtub; a bathroom or shelter. ailongilong ki-a to shake or to disturb; to harass or agitate. kelongilongi eong amotoka na: this motorcar shakes me.ailongilonga ki-a to shake. ilongilongas ikito kanuka ekwam: the trees shake with the wind.ailongilongaar ki-o to be shaken about; to shake; to tremble. elongilongaaros akwi kanuka ekwam: the leaves shake in the wind. to shake a thing so that it may fall away from speaker.ailongilongun ki-a to shake a thing so that it may fall towards the speaker. to shake this way; to be shaken; to be upset; to feel shaky, feel sick. elongilongun adeka kanu kelongilongia amotoka: I feel sick with the shaking of a car. elongulongun ekatau kanuka ican: I feel upset on account of troubles; to be worried.ailony to miss the mark; to miss an appointment to a job; to pass over. ajakaanut abu kelony eong: leadership passed me by; I did not get the job. kilonya ijo akiro: you are unlucky. ailood ki-a (of a politician) to go round campaigning for votes; to canvass; to electioneer; to drum up support.ailop to deliver a child. ailop emong: to castrate a bull. ailop emaido: to draw or pull groundnuts by fingers.ailopa ki-a to tell tales; to accuse; to report on (somebody). kilopai ijo eong apaarasia kere: you report on me always. ailopa itunganan: to accuse someone; to report on somebody. ilopai ngesi eong ebe akokot ekekalaamu: she/he accuses me that I stole her/his pencil.ailopakin1 ki-a to be or become the owner of; to own; to accuse each other. ekot Omayo ailopakin emeesa: Omayo wishes to own the table. ailopakin2 ki-a to put through (as of a rope through a loop); to make a loop. ailopilop ki-o (of a man with big genitals) to run (lope). ailopilopaar ki-a to loop (as of a web). ailopilopoor ki-o (of males with big genitals) to run away awkwardly. elopilopoor etelepat: the boy ran away awkwardly (this word is used only of a man or male animals, not of women). ailopuk ki-a to change; to exchange; to turn the soil; to loosen the ground; to change the soil by turning it with a hoe. ailopuk ekiror: to get a another name (as of baptism). ailopuk akiro: to discuss issues; to alter a statement. ailopuk ki-a to exchange; to uproot stalks from the garden. ailor1 ki-o to close firmly. kilor erute, ekotos akituk alomun: close the entrance to the kraal well, the cows want to break out. kilor epiding kikukwa: close off the path with thorns. ailor2 ki-o to know a language very well; to speak clearly; to speak distinctly, i.e. to be articulate. ilori ngesi Ateso ailor: she/he speaks Ateso distinctly. ailor3 ki-o to leave space between; to space. kilor ikito irae: space trees when planting. ailor4 ki-o to make hard. kilor epuko: stamp the sack hard (with millet, etc). ailor akoik: to eat too much (literally, to make the stomach hard). ailore ki-o to blind (of the sun); to shine brightly; to shine into one’s face; to dazzle; to reflect the sunlight onto. iloreit akolong eong: the sun blinds or dazzles me. ailorilor ki-o to space; to make clear (as of floor or field, etc). ailorilor alaro: to clear the compound of weeds, etc. ailorilor akou: to shave clean or cut hair very low; to keep rapping on the head with an object.ailoronokin ki-o to leave spaces in between (as of rafters, etc). ailoror ki-o to be very hard; to be steady. iloror epeta lo: this screw is very hard. iloror kesi kotoma aswam: they are very steady in their work.ailoroun ki-o to strike on the head with a stick. iloroununei ngesi iso: she/he keeps rapping our heads. ailosikin ki-o to fit inside something; to be contained in; to be sufficient; to go into, be congruent. mam egaago lo ilosikin itunga kere: this shed cannot accommodate all people. ailot ki-a to wash (part of the body); to wash clothes or anything. ailot akanin: to wash hands. (note: ailong is to bathe or wash the whole body of a person). ailot igoen: to wash clothes. ailoloar igoen: to rinse clothes. ailotakin ki-a to wash for somebody; to wash (dirt) into something. sirikilotak ekonilos togo lo: do not wash off your dirt in this room. ailotar ki-a to wash off; to wash clean. kolot ailotar igoeneka: go and wash my clothes. ailotun ki-a to wash clean. ilotunit aberu ikoku: the woman brought forth a clean child. ailu to change into enemy; to attack. ailub ki-a to fill up; to fill to the brim. kilub amoti ngun k’akipi: fill those pots with water.ailubakin ki-a to fill up for, into, somewhere; to fill something with. kilubak amoti akipi: fill the pots with water.ailubulubaar ki-a to replete; to fill up to the top, to the brim.ailuc to make a feast or rite to atone for the wrong done; to palliate or pacify the gods; to lessen pain; to mitigate. ailud ki-a to block up holes with clay or cement; to stop a leak; to solder.ailudakin ki-a to block up somewhere for somebody; to solder or stop a leak. kiludak emina toma amotika: solder my cooking pot (literally, stick latex of gum on my pot). ailudar ki-a to block up completely; to stop what is inside from coming out. ailudar akiro: to keep a secret. ailugokin ki-a to bend (as of a bow or stick, etc on striking its target). to be bent, crooked.ailugokinet a curvature, crook, turn, corner; a bend, a twist. ailuj ki-a to eat soft fruit or food; to suck. iluji ikoku etaget: the child eats bananas. ailujakin ki-a to take a good bite of something soft. kilujak atap: take a big mouthful of millet bread. ailujar ki-a to eat and finish something soft. abu ngesi kiluja acokit kere: she/he finished off the whole potato. ailuk1 ki-a to leave marks of food outside of mouth or on fingers. ilukit ikoku inyamat kakanin: the child has marks of food on its hands (before washing them). ailuk2 (of an attacker) to encircle (the enemy); to surround; to catch fish by hand (to encircle fish); to weave a basket. ailuk etuo: to cut off the top of a gourd. ailuk adere: to cut a gourd in two, to make calabashes. ailuk3 to leave patches uncultivated. iluki ijo inya icapi: you leave unweeded spots in the garden. ailukum ki-a to make something round; to make a circle. kilukumu edula: make the granary round.ailukumun ki-a to make rounded; to be in a circle; to sit round. ilukumunos itunga emasete ajon: people sit round the beer pot as they drink (sit in a circle). ailul ki-a to surround; to fly round; to stand round in need of something. ekoto ao ailulu etuo lo: the bees want to swarm around this gourd.ailulu1 ki-a to crowd together in one spot (as of flies on wound, of men, animals, birds, etc). iluluete icuc ajimi: the flies swarm the wound. ailulu2 ki-a to smooth; to make smooth; to plane. ailulu abaoi: to plane boards. ailulu3 ki-o to raise an alarm or shout a warning (by repeating aloud the lu lu lu, keeping fingers on lips). inyo bo iluluoto yesi?: why do you sound the alarm? iluluete kesi atitai: they alarm for nothing.ailuluar1 ki-a to cover up altogether; to fill to the brim; to surround. kilulua amot: fill the pot. to be covered. eluluar etuja: the granary is full. eluluaros akonye: the eyes are puffy. ailuluar2 ki-a to plane off; to smooth; to fill up a hole. ailuluikin ki-o to raise an alarm; to beat the alarm. keluluikisi kanuka ekokolan: let us make an alarm on account of the thief. ailulukin ki-a (of many) to swarm round meat, food, or beer. adum eong itunga ilulukina ajon: I found people sitting round the beer pot. ailulum ki-a to stir a liquid and make it dirty. alosi ailulum: I am going for a plunge. to wet one’s bed. ilulumaete idwe aperitikec: the little children wet their beds. ailulumaar ki-o to go groping in the dark; to go out in the dark; to swim away. ailulumaikin ki-a to soil the bed; to plunge or swim somewhere. alosi ailulumaikin osamai: I am going to plunge in the swamp. elulumaiki ikoku ebilaangitike: the child has wetted its blanket. ailuluonut1 the habit of making alarm. ailuluonut2 ki-o to be in the habit of sounding or beating alarm. ailuluor ki-o to beat the alarm while going away. ailulut ki-a (of bees, flies, etc) to go and fly round something. ilulut ao amolig: the bees are flying round the beehive. ailuluun ki-o to shout towards this way; to call by alarming. kiluluu ijo itunga: shout for the people. (of many together) to come around. ailum to swim in the water; to submerge; to go under (liquid); to sink. elumi etelepat kotoma akipi: the boy swims in the water. ailumokin ki-a to plunge into liquid; to walk (in the mud). kilumok igoen toma akipi: soak the clothes in the water. ailumulum ki-a to keep secret; to keep hidden (of anything). ejaas akiro nuilumulumit ijo kotaukon: there is something in your heart which you are hiding.ailumulumaar ki-o to become obscure; to get lost. elumulumaaros akiro nuk’lteso nukolo sek kasonya: the old history of the Iteso has become obscure. to hide away; to cover up (as of a hole or a secret). ailumulumakin ki-a to hide for somebody. inyo bo kilumulumakitor ijo eong akakiteng?: why do you hide my cow away.Ailung1 (singular noun F) Lent (the time from Ash Wednesday to Easter Sunday, kept as a fast in remembrance of Christ’s fast in the wilderness); fasting. ailung2 ki-a to make into round lumps (as of clay, etc). ilungulungete luadukok elupe: the builders of a traditional hut make lumps of clay. ailung3 to refuse out of anger or spite; to abhor or abominate; to fast (go without food for religious reasons). alung ngesi inyamataka: she/he refused to eat my food (because she/he is angry). ailungakin ki-a to make lumps for somebody (like a mother making lumps of food for her child). ailungulung ki-a to make food or clay into round lumps or balls. ailungulung akiro: to harbour feelings of revenge; to harbour evil thoughts about someone. ailungulung akan: to clench the fist. ailungulungitoi akerit: (of a stumpy person) to run. ailungurikin ki-a to make round (of anything); to collect, bring together in a body; to keep for absent person. ailungurikin akiro: to gather evidence. ailuny ki-a to take off (as crust of a wound); to abrade; to take off (as of skin); to take off (feathers of chicken); to take somebody’s place (in their absence and without their knowledge); to replace someone. akoto ijo ailuny aiboisitika: I want you to replace me. ailuny alosit: to go straight on.ailunyar ki-a to abrade, etc. ailunyaret abrasion; a scratch. ailunyasit abrasion. ailunyuluny ki-a to bruise all over; to scratch all over. abu egaali kelunyuluny eong: the bicycle bruised me all over.ailupud ki-a to swell (as of ant hill being built); (of things) to cover with clay before being eaten by ants. ilupudi atitipu akonyeke: the anthill’s ‘eyes’ are being covered up by termites. ailupudaar ki-a to drip away; to be covered; to be dirty (of nose). elupudaaros ikumesike: her/his nostrils are dirty. to cover up (only of ants covering things, filling exits). elupudaasi ikok akonye nuka atitipu: the termites have covered the exits of the anthill (after white ants have swarmed). ailupudun ki-a to protrude; to drip (as of dirty nose or wound); to swell (as of a growing anthill). ailupur ki-a to push out (like a man’s distended or swollen testicles). ailupurun ki-o to ooze out (as of resin); to come this way with something swollen. ailur1 ki-a to be overcome by sleep; to doze. kelurete eong ajo: I am sleepy. ailur2 ki-a to harden; to make or stamp (of floor); to make smooth. ailur3 to bend the head; to look down; to bow down; to droop. elurete akimai kwap: the millet is drooping in the field (due to the sun’s heat). ailurakin ki-a to fall asleep; to fall, settle (on a chair, etc); to harden (the floor or anything) for somebody or somewhere. elurakin ngesi oicolong: she/he has fallen asleep on the chair. elurakin emaase mana: the locusts have settled on the crops. to become hard, smooth. ailuranar ki-a to doze; to be sleepy, or drowsy. ailuror ki-o to let fall down (as of child) on hard ground to fall down (of child or anything). kiluror ikoku kwap: the little child fell down. ailuruluraar ki-a to be very hard and smooth (like cement or stone). to make very hard (as of a floor). ailurulurakin: to make hard. ailurun ki-o to be exhausted, jaded; to be drooping (like a tree full of fruit); (of a dying person) to let her/his head droop down (of blood) to coagulate. ailusar ki-o to fall asleep quickly; to faint or have coma. abu eong kelusar naarai kapasit: I fell asleep at once because I was tired. ailusaret a concussion. ailut ki-a to overfill the mouth with food, adding more before swallowing the first; to gorge food. sirilusi acok ailut: do not gorge potatoes greedily. ailutulut: to eat greedily. ailutakin ki-a to attack somebody in a crowd; to go to a place together with one aim. ailutar1 ki-a to gorge; to eat too quickly, without masticating food. ailutar akituk: to close lips (in anger); to pout. ailutar2 ki-o to go away in a crowd for something. elutaros itunga toma akiring: the whole crowd have gone after meat. ailuterun ki-o to protrude; to bulge out. eluterunos akonyeke kanuka ajon: her/his eyes are bulging out on account of beer.ailutun ki-a (prepositional verb) to come together for something. inyo bo ilutunotor yesi ne?: why have you gathered here? ailwaritoi ki-o to try and find some living, earn a living; to carry on work without strength; to be struggling on; to be destitute. elwaritoi eong aswam karaida emamei agogong: I must work, though I have no strength.ailwat ki-a to urinate; to piss; to pass out water.ailwek ki-a to breed; to bring forth many children (said of father as well as mother); to have many children; to be the mother or father of many children. ailwer ki-a to prune (a tree, etc); to clear by burning. ailwicar ki-o to disappear, get lost (in a cloud, in the cloud of dust, out of sight).ailwom ki-a to dip fingers or hand into thick liquids or soft unpleasant things. ailwomakin ki-a to dip something somewhere unpleasant; to fall into sin. kilwomak igoen toma akipi: dip the clothes in the water. elwomakin eong toma akiro: I got into trouble. ailworakin ki-a to fall upon somebody or something exhausted to fall, to drop dead tired. ailworar ki-a to tire out. kelwora eong aswam na: this job has tired me out. ailworaun ki-o to become weak by sickness; to be dead tired; to be inert.ailya to climb; to creep (of plants); to crawl (of children or snake).ailyak ki-a to nod (head). ailyak akor: to work with a hoe, with the head moving in rhythm up and down. ailyakakin akou to walk nodding; to shake up and down, nodding (like a cow wearing a bell round the neck); to start walking on again or working on. elyakakis akituk akwes: cows are just walking, and not grazing anymore. kelyakakis alosit: let us move on again (after resting).ailyok to set teeth on edge (after eating sour or bitter things).aima2 to worship God; to praise or cheer a team vocally; to flatter by calling pet-names. aima ikiroria: to give names. koma imwatok ngul ikiroria: name those twins.aimac akiro to dodge answering issues at hand by deliberately introducing new topics for discussion. aimad ki-a to press or massage an aching part of the body. aimad ajimi: to apply poultice (i.e. bandage, heating pad, cold press, ice pack, or wrapping) on a wound; to dress a wound. aimadakin ki-a to press or dab on (like mud, clay, paint, poultice). aimaderikin ki-o to hold fast onto; to hang on to, cling to; to stick on to (like plaster on wound, etc or like a dog to an animal in a fight or at football). emaderikin ekingok amor: the dog has clung onto the antelope.aimading ki-a to kill; to harm; to hurt; to injure, be cruel to. sirikimading ikakoku: do not injure or hurt my child. aimadingikin: to deprive of; to do injury to; to hurt, do harm to. sirikimadingik ajakaanutuka: do not harm my chieftainship. kemadingikinos ikaboro lu: these things are lost to me. aimag ki-a to struggle; to fight (by boxing each other). akoto eong eimag ka nges: I want to fight with him. aimager ki-a to dawdle, be slow, walk lazily. aimages ki-a to pretend, feign. aimagesikin: to feign to somebody. sirikimagesik adeka: do not pretend to be sick.aimagimag ki-a to make crooked; to spoil to go unsteadily on the bicycle. imagimaga ijo kogaali: you ride precariously on the bicycle. aimagimag akiro: to speak awkwardly; to talk at random. aimagimagit: to make crooked habitually.aimago ki-o to work for beer or money; to do something for a long period of time. imagoete lolo kesi manaka: they are working in my garden for beer today.ajai kolo etunganan Akajikaj loabakai Amaguli naarai emagulul: there was once a man called Amaguli in Akajikaj because he was knock-kneed. aimagulikin ki-o to bend, cause to be crooked, or to bend for. kimagulik akabwa: bend the bow.aimaikin ki-a to warm a little near fire or in the sun; to warm up. aimaikin akima: to make porridge (for somebody). aimaima ki-a to implore; to persuade, entice; to do slowly and carefully.aimaima aswam: to work slowly and carefully. aimaima akiro: to talk gently and carefully. aimajek ki-a to give a stringent, bitter feeling. egeget emaidokoit, imajeki akituk: the cashew-nut fruit is astringent in the mouth. aimak ki-a to stick things to (like stamp on envelope); to close; to press together. aimakakin1 ki-a to stand aghast; to be perplexed. emakakin nges akituk: she/he was tongue-tied. aimakakin2 ki-a to attack; to stick, fasten, paste on, adhere; to rest on, press against, or fix. kimakak asitaapu ngin abakaasa: stick this stamp on the envelope. aimakanakin to keep sticking to (as of food to teeth); to get blocked; to stay too long in one place; to be overdue. aimala1 ki-a to covet (with the eyes); to long for. imalai ekingok akiring: the dog looks longingly at the meat. aimala2 ki-a to greet, praise; to welcome, commend, or to thank. kimala lukore: greet your home people.aimalalanut ki-a to be cheeky or disrespectful. aimalaya ki-a to be a prostitute; to roam about like a harlot; to be a nomad or a nomadic. isirigin eraas imalayan: money circulates (literally, money goes round like prostitutes). aimalecikin ki-o to dislocate; to overlap (as of teeth); to entwine. imalecikino ikelake: her/his teeth are overlapping. adum eong nges iboyei kimalecikite akejeke: I found her/him sitting with legs crossed.aiman1 ki-a to be enemies, show hostilities; to threaten each other. imanas Ilok ka lteso: the Karimojong and the Iteso threaten each other, are enemies. aiman2 ki-a to point at; to threaten by pointing at somebody; to warn by pointing with finger; to defy. aiman3 to roam about, wander about; to go round. to go round something or somebody; to go round fighting. koman etogo: go round the house. aimanar kau ki-a to put behind; to hide something behind one’s back. inyo bo ngin imanarit ijo kau?: what is it you are hiding behind your back? aimanar akanin kau: to hold hands behind the back. aimanasit a menace; a danger, threat. aimaneikin ki-o to hang on; to clasp. to hold or clasp or hang oneself onto something, like a bat on a tree or a child on the mother’s back.aimanerikin ki-a to put arms round the neck (as of a child with its mother). to hold arms round the neck.aimang ki-a to blow over, knock down, knock over many; to kill many successively. kidau aimang itunga kitironikin konye araun amulookolet: after killing many people then you repent and get saved. (used with plural objects) aimangakin ki-a to knock one over; to kill by knocking somebody down. aimangingia to have a stiff neck; to walk or do as one with a stiff neck, act proud; to be proud; to be obstinate. aimangingiar ki-a to walk with a stiff neck; to have a stiff neck; to be proud. aimaniman ki-a to inspect; to go round visiting. sirikimaniman akwap atitai: do not simply go round visiting. to meander; to go this way and that. aimanit ki-a to threaten somebody; to bully; to persecute (continually). aimany (of a man) to marry, pay dowry, or to become engaged; to espouse. ekoto ngesi aimany: he wants to get married. nuka emanyit: marital; matrimonial; conjugal. aimanyimany ki-a to tease or rub a skin to make it supple;
