to tan. aimanyimany akapet: to tan leather. aimar1 (singular noun F) arithmetics; mathematics. nuka aimar: mathematical. lumam imaras: lumam imarunos: a very big number, uncountable. aimar2 ki-a to count, or calculate; to reckon, compute. mam ijo ijeni aimar: you do not know how to count. aimar itunga: to take a census; to take a head count. aimar akeje: (of the police) to take measurements in a scene of a traffic accident to determine who is on the wrong. aimarakin ki-a to count, or calculate for somebody; to reckon, compute for. aimarakin isirigin: to compute costs for someone. aimarakin igaraaman: to detail or compute expenses for someone to pay. aimaramar ki-a to keep counting or reckoning. aimaramar apesenin: to list debts or liabilities one has.aimarananut stubbornness; pig-headedness.aimarananut ki-a to be stubborn or pig-headed. aimaranar ki-a to count up various things; to count up in little portions. aimaret a thing to count with; a counter; a calculator.aimarun ki-a to count for oneself; to bring too few instead of sufficient; to single out. kanukinyo imaruna ijo acok adis?: why do you just bring a handful of potatoes? koyau ibukito iuni lumaruna: bring three single baskets. aimasakin ki-a to throw at; to stone somebody. aimasakin engarot: to throw a stone at. aimat to drink; to aim; to absorb; to smoke (cigarettes). aimat etaba: to smoke tobacco. aimat amiidi: to smoke a pipe. aimat aokot: to suck blood; to drink blood. aimat akiro: to pay attention; to listen carefully in order to report; to bear trouble. aimatengaun ki-a to slap on the temples (amatenget); to give a blow on the temple. aimatumatun ki-a to become stupid; to become deaf.aimaumaun ki-a to placate, mollify, appease, calm, soothe, pacify, or conciliate and bring or get. aimaun1 ki-a to warm up food; to warm anything for oneself. kimau akima kamatata: make a little porridge for ourselves to drink. to warm oneself; to be entirely worn out or dead tired. abongutu lukeswamak imauna: the workers returned dead tired. aimaun ideteta: to tune small drums by warming near fire or in the sun. aimaun akima: to prepare or make porridge. aimaun2 ki-o to become warm; to become very tired or weak, languid. emaun eong: I feel warm, very tired, or very weak. aitamanaun: aitamwanaun: to make warm. aime1 to drive forward or away; to move (cattle, prisoners); to start from. amear akituk: to take cows to one’s father-in-law. aime2 to lick with tongue. aimec to shelter; to take refuge. komecata edou: take shelter from the rain. alosi amecakin ngina: I am going to shelter over there. aimeda ki-a to give a little extra; to give baksheesh; to add. adumun ameda: to make a little profit. kimedakinai idikapun: give me a little money. aimedakin ki-a to give a little extra to; to give baksheesh to; to add to. elosio aimedakin itemwan ice obuku Usuk: they will add sub-counties to Usuk county. aimedaun ki-a to get a little extra; to benefit from; to get a profit. imedaunenei ijo kaneejaas lukican: you profit from the poor. aimedaunit kaneejai: to benefit from; to be helped by something. aimedel ki-o to hold or show something tempting, but without giving it (like one showing a bone to a dog and not giving it); to tantalize; to give a present and take it back again soon after. inyo bo kimedelio ijo ekingok kakoit?: why do you tantalise the dog with a bone? aimeime ki-o to plane wood; to make flat, smoothen (an object); to mould or polish earthenware. kimeime abao ngin: plane that board. imeimei ngesi amot: she/he is moulding the clay pot. aimeleked ki-o to toss food into the mouth. aimelekedoor ki-o to finish off little food without waiting for others. aimen to disobey, contravene; to despise; to rebel against, sniff at; to win (as in football); to consider (something given) too small or too little. aimen ekisil: to break the law. aimer1 to fail to get; to escape one; to loose opportunity; to miss. kamerata eong ajon: (the beer missed me) I failed to get beer. kimer ijo ajakaanut: you just lost your chance to become a chief. (note here that, the object becomes subject). aimer2 to stain; to blemish. sirikimer ekagoe k’ebwiino: do not stain my cloth with ink. aimi to be rich in, to abound in crops; to have plenty; to treasure. emiit ngesi akimai: she/he has plenty of millet. imii ijo akimai: you will have a good crop of millet. aimicakin ki-a to put very close together. aimicakin akeje: to put feet closely together like a soldier standing to attention.aimid to pull finger out of mouth with a click (whilst eating); to lick fingers; to prick with the pointed end of a spear. aimidic ki-a to finish off many; to crush repeatedly between two hard things. aimidic apiyai: to misappropriate funds (perhaps corruptly). aimidiol ki-a (of eyes) to be runny or exuding; (of fruit) to discharge juice. imidiolitos akonye bala acok: the eyes are runny like sweet potatoes that have just been dug up. aimidiolikin ki-a (only of eyes) to be full with eye discharge. emidiolikis akonikonye: your eyes are full of discharge. aimidol ki-a (of a person’s body, clothes, etc) to become sticky, dirty, gluey (like glue, etc).aimidolit ki-a (of a person’s body, clothes, etc) to be sticky, dirty, gluey (like glue, etc).aimiimiit ki-a to pamper (as of child); to use sparingly (of cloth, etc); to nibble, play with (food). imiimiit ijo ikoku ngin: you pamper (spare the rod on) that child. aimiimiit akiring: to nibble at meat. sirikimiimii ebela: do not spare the rod. aimik ki-a to forbid to do; to refuse to give or to do; to hinder; to prevent from; to deny somebody something. ngai kimikit ijo abunere?: who prevented you from coming here? aimikar ki-a to forbid someone; to refuse to do or to give; to hinder from doing; to prevent; to deny somebody something. aimikar Iteso apedor naka aimorikikin: to deny the Iteso the right to unite. aimiketait hindrance; obstacle; encumbrance. aimil ki-a to shine; to flash. aimilia ki-a to flash, coruscate (as of lightning); to shine as of torch. imilia epaaba komanaka: the cotton is shining white in my garden. aimiliaun ki-a to spark; to flash (as fire from electric wire or lightning); to twinkle. aimima ki-a to entice; to draw into a snare; to ensnare. imimai ijo ikasirigin: you are trying to get money out of me (under false pretence). imimai ajokit itunga aimima: the devil draws the people by deceit. aimimaar: to draw away deceitfully.aimimit a small bee that picks wax from ears. aimin1 ki-a to have illicit sexual intercourse.aimin2 to bear (underground fruit or tubers); (of termites) to swarm; (of animals or men) to escape; to do intentionally; to go and do. eminito lolo acok ekaru lo: the sweet potatoes have done very well this year. eminete acok kotoma olapio iuni: sweet potatoes bear within three months. aimina ki-a (of anything) to be sticky, gummy, viscous, gluey (like glue, etc).aiminaikin1 ki-a to adhere to; to stick to; to cling to, be faithful to. aiminaikin2 ki-a to stick to; to adhere or cleave to; to paste on, glue onto; to affix to, agglutinate. kiminaik asitaapu kuju abakaasa: put a stamp on the envelope. aiminganar ki-o to object to or refuse by shaking head or shoulders.aimingiminga ki-a to object by shaking head or shoulders; to be peevish. imingiminga ijo bala ateran: you act peevish like a bride. aiminimin ki-a to handle; to touch repeatedly; to fondle; to play with; to fiddle with things, rub oneself when cold; to finger. aiminiminit ki-o to pamper, coddle, caress, etc. aiminiminitoi ki-a to go about feeling or touching everything; to fiddle with. siriminiminitoi: do not go about fiddling with things. aimo to seek for; to search for; to go and look for; to probe. kimoete moi eong kopas: you will look for me tomorrow and get tired (not find me). amoot eong etogo loperot: I am looking for accommodation. aimoc to converse; to talk; to joke; to have a pleasant chat; to have a sham fight. kimoca bian iso: we had a pleasant time yesterday. aimod1 ki-a to stain; to sow in the wet season.aimod2 to cheat; to overcharge, or to deceive; to fool; to cozen. aimodimod ki-a to sow in the wet season; to smear with dirt; to make dirty; to begrime. aimodol ki-a to make thick (only of vegetables). imodolaete kesi edia: they thicken the vegetables. aimodolaun ki-a to prepare nice thick vegetables; to dirty one’s body or clothes (said of thick substances dirtying or sticking to one’s clothes or body – not said of persons as subjects) to become thick or stained or dirty. aimodumodun ki-a to make something thick (like porridge or vegetables). kimodumod ber edia: first make the vegetables thick and tasty. to become thick, stained or dirty. aimojimoj ki-a to do badly, roughly; to botch. adukio naka isomeroi luimojumojuna: the building of substandard schools. aimok to turn inwards (cloth, etc). aimok akituk: to turn or press lips inwards. aimok adoobe: to put on adoobe, a tampon (passing it between legs and fastening it); to girdle. amokor ekori: to bend the tail inwards (between legs as of a subdued dog). aimokodanut ki-a to be fastidious, peevish, fractious, or testy. aimokorakin ki-a to become a trickster, a cheat, con artist or a fraud. aimoligikin ki-a to become or look like a beehive. aimom1 at dead of night, i.e. the part of night when there is dead silence. aimom2 short sleep; a nap; a siesta. aikamun aimom: to sleep soundly; to be fast asleep but for a short time; (noun) a nap. ajo nuka aimom: a short heavy sleep. aimomit a small insect found in old dry meat or fish; a small moth. aimomo ki-o to begin to ripen. emomooto imomwa: the sorghum has begun to ripen. aimomoet (singular noun F) (time of) ripening. apak nak’imomoet: the time of ripening. aimomot ki-o to be half ripe; to be yellowish. aimomoun to begin to ripen. aimon ki-o to be satiated; to be full of food; to have had enough; to be satisfied; to refrigerate; to cool. imokos idwe acok: the children have had enough sweet potatoes. emono eong (I am satisfied), imono ijo (you – singular – are sated), kimoko iso (we – exclusive – are satisfied). aimongimong ki-a to cake together; to catch; to congeal (of milk or blood); to go into seed as of millet, etc (when fingers or ears close in); to clot; (of hair) to be curly, fuzzy; to curdle; to coagulate. aimongong ki-o to sit down doing nothing. adum eong nges imongongoi kore bon: I found her/him sitting alone at home doing nothing. aimongoria ki-a to have little swellings all over the body. imongoriat akakuwan: my body has swellings all over aimongoriat1 (of the body) to have swellings or pimples. aimongoriat2 a pimple; a blackhead; acne; a swelling. aimonikin ki-o to be satisfied; to have had (or eaten) enough; to be convinced; to be pregnant. emonikin emopiira: the football is inflated. aimonikin: to be drunk. imonikin ijo, kolot ore: you have had enough beer, go home. aimonis a refrigerator; fridge. aimono ki-o to store for the future. imonoete itunga akimai: people store millet for famine times. aimonokin ki-o to make a food store; to store something for somebody. aimony1 to ooze out (as water or juice from potatoes or wounded tree or plant). emonyi acokit: the potato oozes sap.aimony2 to weep; to cry; to complain; to wail, to be ringing (of alarm clock); to weep or cry for. aimony akiyo: to shed tears. aimony naka etau: to crave or long for. emonyi eong etau alosit ore: I long to go home. mam ajeni nuemonyia ngesi: I don’t know why he/she weeps. mam ajeni nuemonyere: I don’t know why there is weeping. aimor1 to partake of together; to do together; to share. aimor aswam: to work together. Aimor nakalaunan: (in the Protestant church) Holy Communion. komorata atap: share the bread (from millet). aimor angor: (of men) to share women; to have a free-for-all affair. aimor2 to offend; to abuse; to scold; to insult; to curse; to revile; to call names; to berate.aimori ki-a to intermingle; to mix up; to take too many, join together; to add; to shuffle in; to blend. imoriei ijo agaria aimori: you take fish two by two instead of one by one. kimoriata asinge kalup: mix clay and sand.aimorianakin ki-a (of married people) to make love often. aimorikikin1 ki-a to be mixed together; to be joined, or united; to fellowship or congregate; to have sexual intercourse in marriage. aimorikikin2 ki-a to append; to mix together; to join together; to unite or to cooperate; to add (in arithmetic); to ally, compose, or connect. aimorikikinet sign of addition; plus sign; addition; connection; combination. aimorimor ki-a to combine or to amalgamate. aimoriun1 ki-a to uproot food crops; to bring along together. imoriu ijo eduan kede akimai da: you have pulled out the millet with the weeds. aimoriun2 ki-o to come together. emoriunos akimai kede eduan: the millet and weeds have been uprooted together. aimot to drag, push further; to pour in with force. aimu1 ki-a to spit; to bring forth twins. aimu2 ki-a to long for; to hanker after; to crave for; to desire. imuit ngesi aanyun eong: she/he longs to see me. kemuit eong akiring: I crave for meat. aimue naka ere: homesickness. aimuanar ki-o to start raining; to drizzle; to spit often or repeatedly. sirikimuanar kokeresia: do not spit in the cathedral. emuanar akuj: it is drizzling. to despise often; to scorn often. imuanari ijo akaswam duc: you always despise my work. aimuar ki-a to spit at; to eject; to despise; to scorn; to defy; to disapprove. emua eong akoniswam: I have despised your work. aimuarit ki-o to despise; to defy; to dare one laugh; to scorn; to disparage or disdain. kemuarit eong ijo mam ipedori aswam na: I defy you to do this work. aimuc ki-a to cover completely (as of a hole or crack) (note: for other things, use airap) aimucakin ki-a to fill up gaps; to plaster up cracks or holes in pot or wall, etc; to patch up. to close up, fill up by itself; to close; (of a wound) to heal up. emucakin akolong: the sun is overcast. aimucar ki-a to close a hole; to fill up a hole or crack. to close up by itself, be filled up by itself; to heal up; to become covered, overcast (of sun). emucaros eong akonye: my eyes are closed up (by sickness). aimucumucakin ki-o to cover oneself in well; to wrap up. karai ideka eimidi, kimucumucakin: if you have a cold, cover yourself well. aimud to gather into a store; to scoop up with hands (of solids only, like sand). aimud isirigin: to earn much money. aimudumudaar ki-a to tuck in; to cover somebody or something completely, as of a mother covering her child against cold or to sleep. to cover oneself completely to sleep or on account of cold. aimudumudanar ki-o to smile without breaking into a laugh. aimudumudia ki-o to smile broadly without showing teeth. aimue (singular noun F) a longing, craving; ardent desire for something. aimue naka ere: nostalgia; homesickness; longing. aimugogol ki-a (of road or soil or anything) to become uneven or rough. aimugogolit ki-o (of road or of hard soil) to be rough, uneven, pitted; (of a person) to be stupid. aimugole ki-o to be under training to become a nun; to undergo instruction as a bride or groom, etc. itunga luebeit aiwen epeta eloseneneete aimugole okanisa: couples who are about to wed go for instruction in church. aimuikin ki-a to spit at/on/in. aimuit ki-o to excite one; to give longing for; to cause ardent desire or strong feeling.kemuitos eong ajon: I long for beer. kemuit eong ikakoku: I long for my child.aimuj ki-a to eat; to relish; to eat vegetables; to eat (in general); to dine. alosi eong aimuj: I am going to take my food, to dine. aisumuj: to cause to eat; to feed. aimuj einer: to mumble (speak indistinctly like one without teeth). imuji ngesi Ateso inera: she/he speaks Ateso indistinctly. aimujio (passive infinitive of aimuj) to be eaten; edible. ibore yen mam imujio: a thing which is not edible. aimujejel ki-a (of food served) to be insufficient, not to be enough; to be short of. aimujumuj ki-a to rinse the mouth or clean the mouth after eating or after sleep in the morning; to lick round teeth with the tongue. aimujumujaar akituk: to rinse the mouth with water. kimujumujaa ber akituk kobu do ainyam: first rinse your mouth and then come to eat. imujumuji ngesi Amusugun inera: she/he mumbles English (speaks indistinctly). aimujuro1 (singular noun F) a frown; a scowl. aimujuro2 ki-o to frown; to look very cross; to scowl; to yawn after awaking; (of animals) to prepare to fight.aimujuronut1 (singular noun F) frowning; glowering.aimujuronut2 ki-o to frown, scowl often. aimuk1 ki-o (of the evening) to grow dark; (of vegetation) to overgrow. imuki akwap: it is getting dark. emuk akwap: it has grown dark; it is dark. aimuk2 ki-o to cover with something. aimuk akonye: to cover face. kimuk edula naarai abu edou: cover up the granary because it is going to rain. aimuk3 to take many at a time, as of a lorry or train; to scoop with hand or basin or anything; to gather a rubbish heap or other loose objects onto or into a container. komuk akimai k’odula: scoop the millet from the granary.aimuke1 ki-a to nurse; to treat medically; to take away a spell of witchcraft; to medicate. emukei eong, imukeete kesi: I/they treat. amukean: amukyan: therapy; treatment; medication.aimuke2 ki-a to try; to attempt; to face difficulties; to do with difficulty. kimukeata aisisia Amusugun: try to learn English. aimuke einer: to stammer, stutter.aimukear ki-a to finish with difficulty; to force away, send away by force. emukea eong nges togo: I have forced her/him to go in the house. to force oneself away; to drag oneself away. abu eong kemukear kore: I dragged myself from home. aimukeikin ki-a to try for someone or somewhere; to nurse for; to cure. aimukeikin ekia: to force somebody (animal or child) to swallow medicine. kimukeikinai ikokuka: try to cure my child for me. aimukemuket ki-o to try or attempt repeatedly. aimukeo (singular noun F) therapy; treatment; medication. aimukerikin ki-a to behave like a baby; to act like a baby. aimukes a treatment centre; clinic; sickbay; dispensary; health centre; hospital.aimuket (singular noun F) an effort; evening, nightfall, sunset. aimuket naka akwap: twilight; dusk. aimuket ki-a to try; to make an effort; to do with difficulty; to attempt; to endeavour. imuketos kesi aisisia Amusugun: they are trying to learn English. aimukeun ki-a to get with difficulty; to cure. emukeuni eong Amusugun aimukeun: I learnt English with difficulty. to be cured; to come with difficulty. aimukokin1 ki-a to become dark; to become evening. emukoki akwap: it has become dark; it is evening. kobu imukokit akwap: come in the evening. aimukokin2 ki-o to tuck in; to cover up (with something). aimukokin akonye: to cover the face; to blindfold. to cover oneself; to tuck oneself in; to bow (the head) in reverence; to bow head in order to evade a blow. aimukor ki-o to cover up somebody or something; to play one a trick. kimuko nges kebilaangit: cover her/him with a blanket. to be covered; to be asleep or to go to sleep; to delay; to become uncivilised. alosi eong aimukor: I am going to sleep or to bed. emukoros itunga lu: these people have become uncivilised. aimukos a cover (sheet, shawl, etc). aimukun ki-o to bring something covered (like food brought from afar) to cover oneself coming this way; to take shelter. kimukun lailo: take shelter here. aimula saliva; spittle; dribble; sputum. aimulat (singular noun F) phlegm; excess or unhealthy saliva. aimuleny ki-a to curtail, limit, restrain, hold back, cut back; to curb, rein in, shorten. aimuliamuliatoi ki-o to grope in the dark; to wriggle like a snake; to play like a small child or like a leper trying to hold things without fingers. aimulukujaar ki-a to swallow quickly, with noise in the throat. komulukujaa ekia ngol: swallow that medicine quickly. to be swallowed. aimululuar to shave closely or bare; to pick off or bite off completely. aimulumul ki-a to suck a sweet (like grown ups) or finger (like children); to make wet by keeping in the mouth; to smother with saliva, like a python does its prey before swallowing whole; to bite or nibble at (as one without teeth). aimumuor1 ki-o to do the old-time dance; to sacrifice for rain (cooking special food); to grow into seed; to begin to ripen. imumuorete itunga edou: people sacrifice for rain.aimumuor2 ki-o to disagree (by turning head away); to despise. emumoros kwi kiirasi nuka aswam: they shook their heads when told to work (despising the work as too difficult or too easy). aimumutaun ki-a (of babies only) to pass bad air.aimung ki-a to salute; to bow head; to shake the head; to nod. aimung akou: to shake the head (in agreement or when walking). aimungakin akou: to bow to; to agree; to salute (lifting hand and bowing head). aimunganar to shake head repeatedly to move or shake the head (as of one falling asleep); to doze off to sleep. imunganar ikoku: the child is dozing off to sleep. aimungar ki-a to give a slight push on the head (as a warning or out of anger). aimungumung akou ki-a to shake the head repeatedly (a sign of refusal or disagreement or displeasure). aimunon ki-a to conceal; to hide; to keep secret; to hush up. imunonit ijo ajon kotogokon: you are hiding beer in your house. imunonit ijo akiro nuka abeit: you are hiding the truth. aimunonikin ki-a to hide something for somebody. kimunonikit ijo eong nuka abeit: you have hidden the truth for me. aimunonit ki-o to be hiding; to be concealing something. aimunumuno ki-a to smile. aimununikin ki-a to commit onanism (sexual intercourse where the penis is withdrawn from the vagina before ejaculation); to masturbate. aimuny to break (of law, leg or arm, club, stick).aimur to cover; to seal; to bury; to bind (as of food). aimur akiria: to bury beer-dough (in preparing beer). aimur kede alup: to cover with soil (to ferment). aimur akituk (euphemism) to be dead and buried. abu eong kadum nges kemur akituk: I found her/him dead and buried. abu kadum kes kemurata akitukes: I found them dead and buried.aimurie akwena ki-a to smile without showing one’s teeth; to beam. aimuruj ki-a to disturb sediment (in water, tea, coffee, beer, etc); to contaminate (of liquids, not of cloth). aimuruj akiro: to poison the words; to explain wrongly.sirikimurujau ajon: do not disturb the beer. emurujaunos aomisioka: I am at a loss of what to say; I am nonplussed. emurujaunos ajon: the beer has been stirred. aimurumur to cover completely.aimurumura akwena ki-a to smile slightly. aimurumuraar to cover up completely (like a trap).aimurumuranar ki-o to smile continually; to have a quiet laugh. kimurumuranar: keep on smiling. aimurumuria ki-a to be smiling. imurumuria ngesi: imurumuriasi kesi: she/he is (they are) smiling. aimurwokin ki-a to forget; to neglect. kimurwok ijo aswamukon: you have neglected your work. aimurwonor ki-o to become forgetful. aimurwonut1 forgetfulness; oblivion; neglect; negligence; inattention; amnesia. aimurwonut2 ki-o to be forgetful; to be inclined to forget; to neglect; to be inattentive. aimusik ki-a to inherit; to succeed to a chieftainship or property. aimusoor ki-o to sit down brooding in silence; to muse. emusoosi kesi: they sit down musing, i.e. silently or quietly.aimusung ki-a to injure or to disable; to harm (of anything); to damage. imusung ijo ekagaali: you have damaged my bicycle. apotu kesi kimusungata akakeju: they injured my leg. aimusunganakin ki-a to hurt, harm, damage repeatedly for to hurt one another; to damage one another. aimusungikin ki-a to do harm to or somewhere or for somebody. to injure one another or oneself. emusungikinos idwe: the children have hurt one another. aimut to be or become dark, dim; to be overgrown. emusi akwap: it is dark. emusi etogo: it is dark in the house. aimutumuta ki-a to disagree by shaking the head or shrugging shoulders, with the mouth pouted. aimutunoor ki-o to bargain; to sell. emutunoo ngesi egaalike: she/he has sold her/his bicycle. emutono akonilaro: your compound is overgrown. aimutunun ki-o to buy or bargain for oneself. aimutur ki-o to be nearly ripe; to be fat (as of head, cheek). aimutut ki-o to it down brooding in silence; to be alone; to sit idle. abu eong kadum nges imututei bon kore: I found her/him alone sitting silently at home. aimuun ki-a to bear twins; to spit out. imuunit akaberu: my wife has brought forth twins. aimwad akonye ki-a to wink or blink with the eyes (as of half blind man). aimwadimwadun ki-a to come with blinking eyes. aimwaneikin ki-o to become greedy, etc for. aimwaneit ki-o to have the habit of greediness, gluttony, etc aimwaneonut ki-a to be inclined to being greedy. aimwang to despise; to contemn, affront, override, or defy. amwangit Katoda: to disrespect God; impiety, wickedness, or transgression. aimwangar ki-a to deflect, turn aside, ward off; to repel, redirect, sidetrack, avert; to prevent, draw away. aimwar akonye ki-a to blink eyes; to look fierce, look daggers. inyo bo imwaria ijo akonye?: why do you look so fierce? aimwat1 to degenerate (of crops); (of crops) to be a failure; to fail to get seeds. amwatata imumwa: the sorghum crop has failed. amwat epaaba lo: this cotton crop is a failure. aimwat2 to brush; to rub off; to wipe off. amwasi eong akaninika: I am wiping my hands. emwasi ngesi akonyeke: she/he is wiping her/his eyes. aimwaus ki-a to amount to; to be so many; to number. ijeni ijo aimwausukec?: do you know their number? imwaas kesi ikany: they are five. imwa ai?: imwaas ai?: how many?aimwolimwol ki-o to eat without teeth; to wash silks. aimyed to strangle; to throttle; to choke. kamyed eong akiring: the meat has choked me. abu auno komyed nges: the rope strangled her/him. aimyel1 ki-a to lick, put out tongue. imyeli ekingok asaanit: the dog is licking the plate. abu akim kimyela etogo: the fire licked the house.aimyel2 ki-a to long for; to hanker after; to desire ardently; to have proclivity. emyela eong alosit ore: I long to go home. imyela etauka: I desire, long for. imyela ijo ekagaali, mam idumuni be: you would like to get my bicycle, but you will not get it. aimyelakin ki-o to desire; to wish for, get a craving for. emyelakin eong ajon: I got a craving for beer. aimyelar angajep ki-a to pull out the tongue (to lick the lips or to ridicule someone). aimyelimyel ki-a to eat a little. to be insufficient for. emyelimyeli eong ikatap kane: I am eating my little food here. kemyelimyelata eong inyamat lu: this food is not sufficient for me. kopotu kemyelimyelata idia yen: come and let us share this little food. aimyelun angajep ki-a to pull out the tongue (to lick the lips or to ridicule someone). aina to be used to; to frequent; to be accustomed to. ana ngesi ne: she/he frequents this place. inai rwaru ijo ne: you will get used to this place in future. ainac ki-a to avoid; to make a detour; to dodge; to evade. kinac emun: avoid the snake. enac edou ne: the rain has gone past here. ainac aitac esolo: tax evasion (literally, to avoid or evade paying tax). to pass each other; to avoid each other. enacakinos amotokan: the cars have passed each other. ainace (singular noun F) moisture; moistness; humidity. ainak to suck (breast or anything). ainak akwena: to laugh heartily. ainak ajo: to sleep soundly, deeply. ainak epii: to suck a beer tube (to drink beer). ainak ekisin: to suckle the breast. ainakin to give to or for; to cause to present; to offer; to cause (with infinitive); to actuate, induce; to reward. ikoto ijo ainakin eong adeka: you want me to catch your disease (or you want to infect me with your disease). ainakinet a gift; a present; a prize; a contribution.inami ijo akiro: you are a good joker. ainam2 ki-a to cover; to patch (as of wound, tyre, tube, etc); to mend (a puncture). akoto ijo ainam akamopiira: I want you to mend my tyre. ainamakin ki-a to mend; to affix; to patch, put on, stick things together. ainamakin akiro: to tickle one’s fancy; to crack a joke for. kinamak ijo eong akiro: you have told me a joke. ainamanut1 to have the habit of cracking jokes; to be good or clever at cracking jokes. ainamanut2 (singular noun F) cleverness at joking. ainaminam1 ki-a to chat; to talk. abuni eong kenaminamata korekon: I am coming to have a chat with you at your home. ainaminam2 ki-a to press (as plaster on the wound); to press into position. ainaminamakin ki-o to come in crowds; to come quickly. enaminamakin emaase mana: the locusts has come down on the field in swarms. ainaminamun ki-o to come in great numbers or swarms. enaminamun emaase: the locusts have come in swarms. ainanakin1 to give continually, keep on giving. ainanakin2 to do in turns; to do in shifts. koinanakinos idarete: watch in turns.ainang1 to cease; to culminate; to stop; to end; to fade away. aijar namam enangi: eternal life. aitodol ainang nepe ekot: until it meets its wishes.ainang2 to punch; to give a blow with a fist; to box. kanang ngesi eong: she/he gave me a blow with her/his fist. ainap1 ki-a to put in order, one on top of the other; to pile up; to fold. ainap ainyam: to partake of every dish; to eat on steadily. ainap2 ki-a to strike or to give a heavy blow with the hand or stick. abu ngesi kenap eong k’ebela: she/he beat me with a stick. ainap3 to put on clothes; to wear clothes, shoes, ring, etc; to don (clothes), array. ainapaar ki-o to become polite; to be humble; to be gentle, well mannered. enapaaros Iteso: the Iteso have become polite. ainapaara ki-a to be polite, humble, gentle, or calm. inapaara ikonidwe: your children are polite, well mannered. ainapakin1 (singular noun F) a calm; quietness; peace. epol ainapakin kane: there is a lot of peace here. ainapakin2 ki-a to knock (somebody) down with a thud; to smack one down. enapaki ngesi oupake kwap: she/he threw her/his friend down. to fall down heavily. ainapakin3 ki-o to put in order; to calm down; to reconcile. to be at peace; to be quiet; to be peaceful; to be quiet (of wind or storm or sea). enapakinos itunga kere: everybody is quiet. ainapanap ki-a to beat repeatedly. ainapap ki-a to be well folded; to be orderly, i.e. order. ainapasit a layer; stratum, section, level. ainar to take to; to bring to, take away; to give to someone absent. ainarinar ki-a to cause to shake; to cause to tremble; to cause to vibrate. ainarur ki-o to swell (as a result of a beating or a bite). ainarurut: to be swollen. ainat to sit motionless (as a cat watching a mouse); to take one by one. enasi ekapa keanyu emir: the cat sits motionless when it sees a rat. ainatakin ki-o to feign or pretend death; to sit without moving; to lie down motionless like a cat or snake ambushing its prey.kinyek aine iboro ngul kere toma asaduku na nacici: do not cram all those things into this small box. eneete idwe akiro keyapuu aingito: children cram when examinations are near. ainebineb ki-a to saturate, drench, inundate, soak, flood. aineine ki-a to tire out sitting on, leaning on or hanging onto a person or animal. kineinei ijo eong kapasit: you lean on me when I am already tired. ineineete idwe itak: the children tire out the calves (by riding on them).aineke ki-o to desire; to wish for, long for, crave for; to need (of good or bad things). enekei eong aimat ajon: I have a strong craving for beer.eneket eong aibunga ijo: I long to beat you. ainekokin etau ki-o to set or put one’s mind or heart on (getting) something. enekokit eong ekatau agwel amotoka: I have set my mind on buying a motorcar. ainem adokar to go quickly up; to climb (a tree by stepping). aineminem ki-a to hasten off. kineminemata alosit oiduka: hasten to the shops. aineminem akwap: to run very fast; to walk quickly. ainene ki-o to hang up (things)aineneikin1 ki-o to cling onto; to hang oneself, i.e. to commit suicide by hanging; to adhere. eneneikin ikoku omorosing loka totoke: the child is clinging to its mother’s neck. aineneikin2 kwap to hang down. aineniat ki-a to hang and rest on mother’s back. ineniat ikoku totoke: the child hangs and rests on its mother’s back. aineno ki-o to be hanging; to depend. inyo ineno kanen?: what is hanging there? ainenokin ki-o to hang something on something else. kinenok egoe lo kuju auno: hang this cloth on the rope. ainep ki-a to be alight; to be on fire. enepu akim: the fire is alight, burning. ainepun ki-a to be alight; to be glowing; to catch fire; to be on fire; to be clever; to be hot, have fever. enepu etogo: the house is on fire. inepunit ikoku ngin kotoma atukot: that child is proving hot (clever) in class. ainer1 ki-a to speak; to talk; to converse; to utter. enera eong: I am speaking. enerata kesi: they have spoken. enera ngesi: she/he spoke. inerit ngesi: she/he has spoken; she/he has said. einer atitai: to talk at random, talk nonsense; to rave. ainer2 ki-a to spite; to backbite; to talk behind one’s back. kenera ngesi eong: she/he is backbiting me. mam alosi einer ijo: I won’t talk about you. ainer3 to claim; to choose beforehand; to select, or engage. anerit eong emong ngol: I have chosen that bull over there before hand. aineraar ki-a to talk in the way of; to speak like. ineraarit ngesi Serere: she/he talks like they talk in Serere: she/he speaks the dialect of Serere. ainerakin ki-o to talk to; to discuss; to reason together, accost. kenerakinos ber nuka akirot kangin: let us first discuss that issue. aineranakin ki-o to talk to oneself or to one another; to talk to each other. aineranut1 (singular noun F) loquacity; garrulousness; talkativeness. aineranut2 ki-a to be eloquent; to be talkative, loquacious, communicative. ainerun1 peace talks; dialogue; negotiations; parley; consultations; conspiracy. ainerun2 ki-a to come to an agreement; to discuss; to consider; to conspire; to plan. kenerutu ber: let us first come to an agreement. to be settled. enerunos akiro ngun: that question is settled or has been discussed. aines (singular noun F) thinness of body; emaciation; skinniness; slenderness; slimness. ainesu1 boorishness; rudeness; crudeness; vulgarity; stinginess; bad manners; gluttony; gourmand; greed or selfishness. ejai nges ainesu: she/he is uncouth. ainesu2 (singular noun F) half-cooked food; underdone food; unripe fruit. ainet to put too much into (not of liquids); to bring in great quantities; to give a heavy blow with a club or fist on the body (but not on the face).ainet atap: to serve a big heap of atap. konetu alupot: make a big heap of mud or mortar. angesi nat eong ijo: I may clobber you later . ainga to open (as of door or mouth). kongaa ekek: open the door. kongaa akituk: open the mouth. aingac ki-a to walk with a straddling gait (as of a person with genital ulcer); to walk proudly; to strut (like a baboon); to walk with difficulty, with legs astride (on account of abscess, syphilis, etc). aingacac ki-a to stand astride; to bestride. aingacac ecelet: to quarrel for a long time. ingacacaete ikiliok ejiosi: the men stand astride when fighting. aingada ki-a to keep in custody; to store away; to preserve or to put away; to conserve. ingadai ngesi anyunyura kitoni ainyangar: she/he keeps anger until revenge is done. aingadaar ki-o to budge or to move away; to stow away; to cache. aingadakin ki-a to keep for somebody; to store up for somebody; to put away for somebody; to reserve. aingadakin ates: to bury the dead; to inter (literally, to put the corpse out of reach). to hide oneself; to abscond. kolot kingadakin, abu amuran: go and hide yourself, your mother-in-law is coming.aingadakinet a place to store or keep things safely; a bank; a cache; the keeping of things. aingadas a corruption of aingadis: a storehouse; a bank. aingadis a storehouse; a bank. aingainga ki-a to entreat; to beseech; to pray; to soothe; to pacify; to quieten (as of a crying child); to implore; to disarm. kingainga ikoku: pacify the child; quieten the child. aingaingait ki-a to keep entreating; to beseech; to petition; to implore, or adjure. kengaingait eong ijo: I beseech you. aingaingaitoi ki-a to keep on beseeching, imploring or pleading. aingaingaun ki-a to persuade (to come); to entice; to entreat; to get by imploring. aingakakin ki-a to light upon, come upon unexpectedly. aingala ki-a to deceive or to beguile; to lead astray; to lie to; to bamboozle.ingalae: you lie. ingalaete ijo: they deceive you. siringalai: do not deceive. aingalaar ki-a to take one away by deceit; to entice away. to be deceived; to be taken in. aingalakin ki-a to tell or teach the wrong thing; to deceive; to take somebody in. aingalakin ekia: to poison. aingalakin eidada: aingalakin ecudet: to poison. aingalakin elweera: to give somebody consumption phthisis (tuberculosis). aingalangal ki-a to cheat, mislead, or tell lies to repeatedly; to elude often. aingalangalakin ki-a to take away by deceit; to take somebody’s food (or anything) by false pretence. aingalanut1 (singular noun F) deceit; deceitfulness; hypocrisy. aingalanut2 ki-a to be fond of lying, deceiving. ingalana ngesi: she/he is fond of deceiving. aingalaun ki-a to allure; to get a thing by deceit. aingalaun ajo: to coax sleep (by sleeping-draught or singing a lullaby). aingamingam ki-a to do quickly; to run or walk fast. aingamingam akeje: to run quickly. aingamingamakin ki-o to run quickly after; to rush at (used for many running together). engamingamakinos itunga omaido: people are rushing for groundnuts. aingany to probe; to examine carefully, look for carefully; to turn things over, looking for something. anganyakin akonye: to stare at. abu ngesi kanganyak eong akonye: she/he stared at me. ainganyosoor ki-o to fall down and reveal the behinds; (of a destitute) to die shamefully or miserably. eyapie ngesi ainganyosoor: she/he is nearly dying a miserable death. aingar ki-a to give assistance to many; to help many. aingarakin to help, abet, assist, aid, support, benefit, or be advantageous. kingarakinai: help us (me). aingarakinia: to be used for someone or something. aingarakin itunganan: to help someone; to come to someone's aid. to help one another; to be helped. kingaranakinos: help one another; support each other. aingarakinet help, assistance; auxiliary; asset; backing up. ipupuuto aigarakineta: there are several advantages. aingarar ki-a to stand out, be visible (as of pimples on the body or people far off, etc); to be on the alert (of many); to be ready to do together. aingarar: watching for something to happen; to be on alert. aigarar aiboi: (of a woman) to sit with legs apart, sit indecently. itunga kwi ingararaete kangina, lukai?: where are those people over there from? ingararaete ikok ekotos ejie: the ants (the soldiers of the anthill) are on the alert (ready to fight). aingaren ki-o to be or go in front, lead the way, precede. aingarenikit: to be in front of; to be better than another in work, etc. aingarenikin ki-o to guide; to lead; to precede. aingarenikinet leadership; management; headship. aingaringar ki-a to gang up for; to do in turns. kengaringarata acok: let us herd in turns. aingaringarun ki-a to have in common, have shares in, do in common. kengarungarutu etogo lo: let us share in building this house. aingat to plunder; to rob; to raid; to rustle; to pillage, or loot. apotu Ilok kongatata akituk nuka Iteso: the Karimojong raided the cows of the Iteso.aingeb ki-a to nibble. aingebingeb ki-a to be nibbling. ingebingebi akine ekapaaba: the goat is nibbling at my cotton. ingebingebi ikoku akiring: the child nibbles at the meat.aingecel ki-o to overlap (used with plural object). ingeceli ijo abaoi: you are overlapping the boards. aingecelikin ki-o to place in an overlapping position. to be overlapping each other. ingecelikino ikonikel: your teeth are overlapping. ainged (of rope or thread) to break; to snap. ainged epaperone: to break off friendship.aingedinged ki-a to walk as one who has pain in the lower back or waist or loin. aingejingeja ki-a to jabber; to stammer; to stutter.aingek ki-a to waddle (like a fat duck); (of cow or other animal) to have a big udder; to walk with legs far apart; to come quickly across anything looked for. ingeki ngesi alosit: she/he waddles. ingekit akiteng: the cow has a very big udder. aingekingek ki-a to find many together. aingekingek acok: to find many potatoes in one heap. aingekun ki-a to find quickly and bring a thing looked for. engeku eong ikasirigin luaolioritos: I soon found my lost money. aingel to break (as piece of pot or crockery). ingel ijo akasaanit: you broke off a piece of my plate. engeli ngesi atap enyami: she/he takes food in big lumps: she/he is a glutton.aingem ki-a to touch with the tongue; to taste; to take a little with the tongue (used for solid things like simsim, salt, sugar).kengemingemi eong akoik: I have pains in my stomach. aingemingem akwap: to run. aingemingem etau: to hurt one’s heart. kengemingemete eong akiro ngun etau: those words pain me, hurt me, are biting my heart. aingeny ki-a to be busy with; to be occupied with; to work hard; to be busy at. eingeny amat: to drink very much. ingenyas kesi ejie: they are busy fighting. aingenyakin amat to be having a big beer party. eingeny ejie: to be in a hot fight, fighting furiously.aingenyar ki-a to fight for, about, with or somewhere. ikaboro ingenyatar yesi: you are fighting for my property. aingenyun to take a little (of anything). aingepes ki-a (of door) to put ajar; to put in an overlapping position (so that it may fall). aingepes akiro: to hide the exact truth. aingepesikin ki-a to put in an overlapping position; to beat slightly; to overlap a little. ainger1 to cut the top of plants above the roots; to mow; to shave hair. ainger itim (akou): to cut hair. ainger anya: to cut grass for thatching. ainger akiro: to tell only part of the truth. ainger2 to refuse or to renounce; to deny or to decline; to withhold; to object; to disagree. anger ngesi: she/he refused. engerit ngesi: she/he is refusing or she/he refuses. angeroto kesi: they have refused. engerit ngesi: she/he is obstinate. aingereteny ki-a to be thin so that lower ribs stand out. ainges to do suddenly; to do all of a sudden; to attack by surprise. sirikinges alosit: do not go all of a sudden. ainget to finish (of work or holiday); to end. anget eong akaswam: I have finished my task (work). aingi to show teeth; to bare teeth; to grin; (of cotton) to show white, to blossom; (of growing tooth) to appear; to pull a sneering face. engii epaaba komisiri: the cotton is blossoming white in the garden. aingic to examine closely; to spy on; to look at carefully; to diagnose; to scrutinize; to search, inquire about matters; to examine (a case); to explore; to cross-examine; to canvas. aingil ki-a to pain; to give a biting, sharp pain. aingilakin ki-o to feel sudden sharp pain (usually in the knee or joint). aingilar to cause sharp pain. kengila eong ibore kosyep: something is pricking my side.to feel pricking pain in the side. aingim to pare; to cut into small pieces (of anything). kongim apapulai ngun: shred those papers; cut those papers into small pieces. aingim akiring: to cut meat into small pieces. aingim akonye: to slit the eyes; to blink; to twinkle.ainginimikin ki-a to hold insufficiently, lightly; to place something so that it can easily fall or break. inginimikinit ijo ikakoku, elosi aibiror: you hold my child very precariously, it will fall.ainginy ki-a (of beans, vegetables or potatoes) to mash; to crush; (of eyes) to rub; to eat a lot (of anything); to be gluttonous. ainginy einer: to talk behind one’s back; to slander; to spoil somebody’s name. ainginy acok: to eat potatoes by oneself or alone. ainginyakin ki-a to rub for, somewhere; to rub in; to mix in; to add in, put in. kinginyak emaido odia: mix groundnuts in the vegetables. ainginyanut1 gluttony; fondness of backbiting, etc. ainginyanut2 ki-a to be fond of backbiting, eating too much, etc. ainginyar ki-a to crush (by foot or car or heavy thing); to smash, annihilate; to eat all. abu amotoka kinginya ekingok: the motorcar crushed a dog. ainginyinginy ki-a to rub (like rubbing tobacco between hands). ainginyinginy ekume: to rub the nose. aingisenen ki-a to ask often; to keep asking, inquiring. aingiset a question mark; a question; a quiz; a query. aingisio (singular noun F) a questioning; an examination; a test; an inquiry. aingit ki-a to ask, enquire, request; to question; to examine; to give an examination. eong engisi: I ask; I am asking. yes ingisete: you are the ones going to ask. kingit (imperative) inquire; make an inquiry. kogeata ber aingit: first make an inquiry. aingitanar ki-a to keep asking; to keep questioning, make an inquiry; to inquire. to ask one another; to debate. kengitanasi: let us make an inquiry. kingitanaros: ask one another. aingitar ki-a to ask for and take away; (at school) to pass somebody into another class. to be passed or to pass; to get permission for. engitaros idwe ikany toma atukot naikanyet: five children have passed into the fifth class. aingitingit ki-a to interrogate; to quiz; to cross-examine; to grill. aingito (singular noun F) a school examination; a questioning; a test; an inquiry; a quiz. aingitun ki-a to ask for; to inquire about. aingitun ibore: to ask for something; to say that you want someone to give you something. aingitunun ki-a to keep asking for information; to keep inquiring. aingo1 to get annoyed; to become angry. ikoto ijo aingo: you want to become angry, offended (without reason). aingo2 to stir food (as of atap); to mix and mash together; to knead. engoi aberu aketap: the woman mingles and mashes her atap. aingo ekori: to walk like a lion or dog, i.e. sway or twist the buttocks proudly.aingob to drink something thick (making a sucking noise). aingob akima: to drink thick porridge. aingobel1 (singular noun F) a desire; a lust; a craving; a longing. aingobel2 ki-o to covet; to desire; to lust after; to crave for; to long for (good or bad). aingobelikin ki-o to desire for someone; to wish for. ingobelikit toto ikekoku inyamat: the mother wants food for her child. aingobelonor ki-o to become covetous; to become lusty. ingobelonor kwana ijo: you have become covetous, lusty. aingobelonut ki-o to be inclined; to be covetous, have a longing for; to be fond of; to be lusty. aingobingob ki-o to eat hurriedly, quickly; to gobble down.. aingod ki-o to diminish, take from. aingodol ki-o to tantalise; to make dips or potholes (as of motorcars on road). sirikingodol eong kakonikiring: do not tantalise me with your meat. aingodonor ki-o to take from. iboro kon mam ingodonorio: nothing will be taken from you. aingodor ki-o to minimise, shorten. aingodor aibuses: to discredit, abase. aingol a wooden spoon for mingling or stirring food; a paddle for rowing; an oar.ingomingomi ngesi inyamatake: she/he gobbles up her/his food. aingomingomoor ki-o to finish solid food quickly (not used of drinks). to be finished. kingomingomooros nan acok sek: the potatoes have been gobbled up sometime ago. aingong ki-a to diminish (anything), make little; to decrease, make less; to lessen, cut off a piece. kageutu aingong erot: let us start (shorten) our journey (by going on). ileleba edula, kingongu: the granary is full, spill off some of its contents. aingongakin ki-a to separate; to take from for somebody; to give a part to. kingongakinai eong da adikimai: give me also some millet from your full granary. to become less; to decrease. aingongar ki-a to take off a part; to diminish or to abate. kingonga ipakasin ice: take away some of the porters. to decrease; to diminish; to abate; to be half full. engongaros akimai kotoma odula: the millet has decreased in the granary. engongaros amoti: the pots are only half full.aingoninia ki-a to have a high opinion of oneself; to go very slowly (when told to do something); to swagger, disdain. ingoninia ngesi: she/he is haughty. . aingop to hide oneself; to be hidden; to be a mystery. aingop duu du: to be completely hidden, obscure; to be lost. engopit akirot ngin: that is a mystery. angop ikabore: my thing is lost. aitongop ki-a to hide.aingor ki-a to take off a little; to decrease amount of; to leave half full; to lessen; to make insufficient. ingori ijo akimai: you are reducing the millet.aingorakin ki-a to bring something half full; to bring part of the quantity required. aingorar ki-a to lessen; to decrease the amount; to take off the superfluous; to diminish. to be lessened; to be insufficient. engoraros akipi: the water has decreased. aingorianut1 (singular noun F) fondness for women; womanising. aingorianut2 ki-a to be fond of women. aingoror ki-a to roar (of airplane); to snore (of someone sleeping soundly); to growl, make a rumbling noise (as of dog, person, engine, aeroplane, thunder, etc); to wheeze (of an asthmatic). ingororoi edege: the aeroplane is roaring. aingororoun ki-o to come rushing towards; to come full speed towards. engororoun amotoka neajai eong: the motorcar has come full speed towards me. aingotiloor ki-o to cut off a big piece of something.aingotol ki-o to disfigure; to spoil (used with plural object). kinyek aingotol akamoti: do not disfigure or spoil my pots. aingotolikin ki-o to disfigure for or somewhere (as by a deep scar, etc) to be disfigured. engotolikinos nges akonye: her/his face is disfigured. aingu ki-o to smell something by putting the nose to it. kingu asabuunyu na: smell this soap.aingub to cut off a piece, break off a piece.ainguc ki-o to make a knot. ainguit ki-o to keep on smelling; to have smelled. inguit ekesa ngol amot: he is not sober (literally, he has smelled the beer pot). aingul to cut. kongul akiring na: cut this meat.ainguleny ki-a to cut up into small pieces; to make too short; to cripple; to curtail. ainguleteny ki-a to be cut off; to be short (after cutting off a piece). aingungu ki-o to smell; to go smelling (as of a dog, etc). ingungui ekingok epejonon: the dog is giving the visitor a sniffing. aingunguya ki-a to corrode; (of wood) to rot and fall off easily.ainguny ki-a to sprain, twist. ainguny ekume: to turn up or screw up one’s nose; to dislike; to disdain by turning up one’s nose. abu eong kanyarau nges ainyam, kosodi ngesi ainguny ekume: she/he turned up her/his nose when I called her/him to eat. aingunyakin ki-a to sprain one’s ankle or wrist; to dislocate. to be sprained; to turn the body suddenly as by surprise at hearing or seeing. engunyakin eong akung: my knee is sprained ainguonor ki-o to go about smelling (like a dog).ainguor ki-o to sniff up; to smell. enguo ekingok egwang: the dog smelled the wild cat.aingur to be stained, painted or spotted; to be irate, angry, or furious; (of a bull) to prepare for a fight by raising dust. aingur alup: to die (literally, to bite the dust). engurit ngesi alup: (she/he was stained by earth) she/he is very angry. angur kolo papaka alup sek: my father died long ago (literally, he was stained with earth long ago). aitungur: to stain anything. ainguruj ki-a (of liquids only) to contaminate; to spoil; to make dirty or foul; to mix up; to jumble. sirikinguruja akipi: do not dirty the water by stirring.aingurujaun ki-a (only of liquids through stirring) to spoil; to make dirty; to contaminate. ingurujau jo akipi: you have contaminated the water by stirring it. to be contaminated, spoiled (of liquids only).aingurungura1 einer ki-a to talk through the nose. aingurungura2 ki-a to grumble, rumble, to murmur. ainguun ki-o to smell something (not necessarily by putting nose to it). enguu eong ajon: I smell beer. aures: to smell after something. iur jo ajon: you smell after beer.aingwal1 ki-a to set out in fine colours; to emblazon. ingwalal: flamboyant. aingwal2 to become lame; to become crippled, disabled. engwali ngesi: she/he will be crippled. engwalit ngesi: she/he is a cripple. aingwar akonye ki-a to look fiercely; to glare; to glower; to look at angrily. aini to dent; to make potholes (as in the road), push inwards (making dents); to press inward, indent. ainia ki-a to push aside, away (with plural objects); to pull down (something aloft, such as tree branches) (only of things). kinia atenueik ngun: pull those branches lower or aside. ainiaar ki-a to push or pull out of.the way; to pull or push aside (of things that are flexible but do not move, and not of people). kiniaa atenueik ngun: push those branches away. to recline; to yield, give way, go aside; to fall to one side, heel or lean over; to keel. kiniaar awai katubor eong: lean aside and I pass. eniaar ngesi koicolongoke: she/he is reclining on her/his chair.ainiaga ki-a (of anything weak or soft) to swing or sway to and fro. ainiagaanar ki-o to bend or move from one side to another (as of one climbing a swaying tree or on an unstable bicycle); to oscillate. ainiagaar to push aside; to fall or bend to one side, as one falling asleep. ainiaginiaga ki-a to waggle. ainiaikin ki-a to push or pull down for. kiniaik akinei ngun atenueik konyamata akwii: push or pull down the branches for those goats to eat the leaves. ainiaun ki-a to bend this way; to bend down towards oneself. to become weak; to become tired; to become powerless; to become exhausted. ajioto ikokoroi eniaunos: the cocks have fought until they are exhausted. ainic ki-a to put close together; to weave close together; to plait nicely. kinic abwas ngin: put the poles of that fence close together. ainicanakin ki-a to fill up gaps in anything; to put closely together, to compact. ainicakin akeje: to stand to attention or put feet closely together. to be close together. ainiem to be long in doing; to stalk; to walk on tiptoe. iniemi ijo ilosi: you move silently on tiptoe.ainieminiemakin ki-a to stalk very fast (as of stalking on an animal or a thief); to go stealthily and quickly after. enieminiemakin ekapa emir: the cat has gone stealthily (quickly) after the rat.ainiep ki-a (of a squirrel, a person, monkey) to go or jump or climb from branch to branch or from tree to tree. ainiginiga ki-a to quiver; to object (by shaking head or shoulders); to show unwillingness (often feigned, as of a bride); to do as if objecting. iniginiga ateran bala mam ekoto alosit: the bride feigns not to want to go (to her new home). ainik ki-a to suck; to drink.ainikakin ki-a to suck somebody or something. kenikaki eong esirut: a mosquito bit me. ainim ki-a to sew nicely or well; to weave nicely or well; to plate nicely or well; to darn nicely. inim ijo ekasaati: you have sewn my shirt well. ainimakin ki-a to sew, plait, darn finely for somebody. ainiminim akwap ki-a to race, to run fast with short paces. iniminimete itelepai akwap: the boys are racing. ainiminimun ki-a to race this way with short paces. ainimun ki-a to plait, to darn for oneself. akoto ainimun ekasaati: I want to sew my own shirt nicely. aining ki-o to judge the weight of things by lifting or the strength of a person by wrestling; to balance (a weight on something); to test, assess, or put on trial; to try. ening eong epuko lo, elangir tii ti: I tried to lift this sack load, it is too heavy.ainingining ki-a to carry a heavy weight. mam eong apedori ainingining epuko ngol: I cannot carry such a heavy bag or sack load. ainingokin1 ki-a to weigh for; to judge weight for. to wrestle with. akoto eong ainingokin kajo: I want to wrestle with you (I want to try your weight or strength).ainingokin2 ki-o (reciprocal verb) to wrestle with one another; to wrestle often. ainingor ki-o to lift up; to try; to try weight (of anything). kiningo asaduku na: try the weight of this box. ainip to give a disgusting feeling; to satiate (as of honey or fat or butter). kanipit eong akinyet: fatty or oily food satiates me fast.ainir (of fatty food, honey and butter) to give a nauseating feeling. kanir eong esik: honey gives me a nauseating feeling (after eating too much of it).ainira ki-a (of an object or surface being cleaned) to be oily. aino to dent; to press in. ainoino ki-a to keep pressing; to test by pressing; to find out by pressing or feeling. ainoinoikin ki-a to test by feeling or pressing (as of food to know if it is done) for somebody; (as of fruit) to see if ripe. ainok1 combustion. ainok2 ki-a to kindle; to burn; to set alight; to put on fire (as of small things). kinok akim: light the fire. inoki ijo akito numam eraas nukon: you burn the firewood which is not yours. ainok iiriir: to blaze. to be aflame or afire ainok3 to be ablaze; to be on fire; to be alight. enoki akim: the fire is burning. ainok4 to follow closely; to press in upon (as on enemy or on animal in hunting); to harass; to rage. enoki ejie ko Bulaya: the war is raging in Europe. ainokaar ki-a to beat, slap, to deal a heavy blow (with the hand or club). kenokaasi kesi eong k’ebela: they gave me a resounding blow with a stick. ainokokin ki-a to kindle; to light; to burn, put on fire; to inflame. kinokok etaala: light the lamp. kinokok akim: kindle or stir the fire. (note: to mean to burn a house or a bush, use aicweikin or aicwe). ainokokin akit: to give a heavy blow on the ear; to warm somebody’s ears. ainokokin ecelet: to intensify a quarrel. ainokos ki-a to begin to fester; to swell (after a hurt or bruise); to become painful. enokosa akakan: my hand is swollen. ainom1 ki-a to beat; to strike. ainom epaasi: to iron clothes. ainom ejenunet loka emusalaba: to make the sign of the cross. ainom aput: to take a photo; to picture; to draw a picture. ainom isigira (or epiki): to gamble. ainom epuoso: to drink in one go. ainom akwap: to go far away. ainom awaragat: to narrate a parable. ainom atapuraita: to type. ainom amatapaalin: to make bricks. ainom etogo: to measure a house, etc. ainom ates esimit: to cement a grave. ainom eitaabo: to print a book. ainom emong: to pay a fine or dowry with a bull. ainom esimu: to make a telephone call. ainom epiiso: to inject; to inoculate. ainom eraagi: to paint. ainom2 to be burned; to burn; to be on fire. anom erekosi: our home is on fire. enomete ikitwo: the bushes are on fire. ainomakin ki-a to drive into; to beat for or into; to hammer. ainomakin esumaalit: to drive a nail into. ainomakin awaragan: to teach in parables; to tell somebody a parable. ainomakin ejenunet loka emusalaba: to make a sing of the cross for or on. kinomak ikoku ejenunet loka emusalaba: teach the child to make the sign of the cross. ainomakin esulut: to salute somebody. ainomar1 ki-a to beat off; to strike off; to beat away; (in tennis) to serve, service. kinoma akituk ngina: drive the cows that way. ainomar2 ki-a to imagine; to forecast; to photograph. kinomaa Teso naebarit, kijamamai, kongalei: imagine a rich Teso, peaceful and healthy. ainomar iputo yenididi: to take a snapshot or passport-size photograph. ainomonom ki-a to lash (as tall grass lashing face); to give a beating. ainomonom akwap: to travel a long way; to make a long journey. ainong ki-a to be hopeless, downhearted, dejected; to flinch, baulk, recoil, cringe; (of scrotum) to shrink due to cold or fear. abu ngesi kobong ore inongit: she/he went home dejected. ainot1 ki-a to flock together; to be in a big crowd, in swarms. inosito itelepai aipet emopiira: there is a big crowd of boys on the football field. ainot2 ki-a to sweep clean (as of room, etc). ainotakin ki-a to put together in one place; to put too many together; to congest. inatakina itunga toma okooti: there is a big crowd of people at the court. to crowd together; to swarm together, flock together. enotakinos itunga toma okooti: there is a big crowd of people at the court. ainotar ki-a to take too many of (food, men, clothes, etc). ai bo inotarete yesi inyamat ngul kere?: where are you taking all that food to? to go in crowds, swarms. ainotun1 ki-a to bring in crowds, in swarms, too many of. to come in crowds, in swarms. enotunos itunga osokooni: crowds of people have come to the market. ainotun2 ki-o to clean out thoroughly. kinotu ekatogo: clean my room thoroughly. ainu1 ki-a to overpower by weight; to overcome by weight; to weigh down on. kenuut eong ajo: I am overpowered or overcome by sleep.ainu2 ki-a to press, kiss, press against. inui toto ikedwe: the mother kisses her children. ainu3 ki-o to hammer; to pound; to give a hammering. alosi eong ainu emuogo: I am going to pound cassava. ainuakin ki-a to be too heavy to lift. kenuaki eong asaduku ngin: that box is too heavy for me (to lift or to carry). ainuar ki-a to bend down by weight. enua emucuuga atenu: the weight of the oranges bent the branch. to bend down by itself (of things); to droop (head as of plant in the sun or of man with heavy load); to stoop. ainuit ki-a to bear the burden of; to resist pressure. inuit ijo akou: you have a big head (an insult). ainuk to cover over; to fill in a hole; to bury (only of covering with earth). ainuk aipany: to fill a hole. ainukusa ki-a to sleep a long time; to sleep too long; to sleep in. inukusat lolo ngesi: she/he slept long today. ainukusanut ki-a to have the habit of sleeping too long; to be sleeping too long. ainumunum ki-a to feast; to celebrate (marriage, harvest or any other occasion). ainumunum ekaru loitetet: to celebrate the new year anniversary. kenumunumata apaarit naka auriokon: let us celebrate your birthday. ainun to bring and give; to bring, fetch for somebody here. koinunai eicolong: bring me a chair or seat.ainup to believe, follow what is said; to be obedient; to be amenable; to listen to. idwe enupete akiro nuka lukauriakakec: children listen to what their parents say. ainut ki-a (only of things) to make smooth; to make nice (as of a pot or a table, etc). inusi ngesi amoti: she/he makes the clay pots nice and smooth. ainuun ki-a to encumber; to make difficult. ainwak ki-a to light up (as with a lamp or torch); to illuminate; to x-ray; to scan with a radar or telescope. ainwak itunganan: to x-ray a person. ainwakakin ki-a to enlighten; to illuminate; to make light for somebody; to show the way by lamp or torch. kinwakakinai eong erot: show me the way (by light or torch). ainwaket an x-ray machine; a flashlight; a radar. ainwakitor (relative prepositional verb) to light up with. etabaasa loenwakitor eong etogo: the lamp with which I light up the room. ainwok to block a hole or anything; to stop a leakage. konwok erot lo: block up this path. ainwok aki: to block or close up one’s ears; to put fingers in ears; to turn a deaf ear to. ainwom ki-o to eat like a toothless person; to bite ineffectively (like biting rubber).ainya to widen; to enlarge; to stretch, open out, push aside, make a passage. ainya akoik: to widen the stomach; to expand the belly (as by over-eating or pregnancy). ainya ejungula: to become rich. ainyabuk ki-o to grind again. kinyabuk akiria: grind the flour again. ainyabuk akiro: to be illogical in talking; to talk illogically. inyabuki ijo einer: you talk without any sense (illogically).ainyabukoor ki-o to grind again for or somewhere away to be ground fine. enyabukooros akiria: the flour is ground fine. ainyaga ki-a to rob; to take by force; to raid; to plunder; to rob and take away by force; to cheat in buying and selling. ainyagaar ki-a to rob and take away by force.ainyaiyo ki-o (with negative connotations) to be fastidious; to be particular (about anything). ainyaiyonor ki-o (with negative connotations) to become fastidious. ainyaiyonut (singular noun F) fastidiousness; meticulousness; carefulness; neatness; preciseness; fussiness. ainyak ki-a to give back; to return (used with plural objects). kinyak ikaboro: return my things. ainyak ekume: to sniff up. ainyak akwap kau: to retard national or world progress.ainyakakin ki-a to give something back to; to replace; to return to; to answer; to retaliate; to reply. kinyakakinai akiro: give me (send me) an answer. ainyakakinet an answer; a reply; a response.ainyakanakin atap to repeatedly bite off a piece of food and dip it every time in the same vegetable dish (considered bad manners in Teso). ainyakar ki-a to take back to; to restore; return to; to make a restitution. to become taken back, returned, restored, released. enyakaros itunga kere: all the people were sent back, released. ainyakinyak ki-a to make rags or smithereens. inyakinyakaarit eboomu etunganan akeju: a bomb has totally shattered a man’s leg. ainyakun ki-a to bring something back; to return, or restitute; to recall; to lower; to decrease, reduce; to reply. alosi eong ainyakun eropiti kon kwap: I am going to reduce your wages. ainyal ki-a to mix (anything); to mingle, amalgamate, concoct. ainyalakin ki-a to mix up; to put or mix together; to adulterate. kinyalak akile ocaai: mix milk in the tea. to be mixed; to be adulterated. ainyales yeast; leaven; malt. ainyalinyal ki-a to mix up; to confuse; to mix many things, concoct. sirikinyalinyal ikoniboro ka luka: do not mix your things with mine. ainyalio (singular noun F) admixture; a combination; a mix; a blend; an assortment; a concoction; a fusion; a jumble; a muddle. ainyam1 ki-a to accompany; to escort; to guide. kinyamata kes: escort them. ainyam2 to eat; to consume (of solids); to take possession of. anyam etengei: to be hungry. kanyam eong etengei: I am hungry (literally, hunger has eaten me). ainyam eul: to become cheeky (literally, to eat impudence). anyam ngesi eul: she/he has refused, or she/he is cheeky. ainyam eropit: to receive pay. anyam emusaago: to lose a case; to get into a case. anyam (nes) ecor: she/he was drowned. anyam nges akim: she/he was burnt. ainyam ekia: to be poisoned. ainyam etau: to worry one, make angry. kanyamata eong akiro ngun etau: that made me very angry. anyam nges akwap: she/he was buried; she/he died. enyami ngesi akwap: she/he runs very fast. anyam lowok akwap: she/he lost the case. ainyam ajakaanut: to be elected into leadership. enyami ibore yen isirigin: this thing is expensive. ainyam edus: to eat without working. ainyam kepali: to cheat. ainyam apese: (of girl’s relative) to get part of her dowry. ainyam k’akou kice: to live on somebody else; to be a parasite or a hanger on. ainyam eding: ainyam ekolo: to be enemies; to be at loggerheads. anyam erot ikaboro: I lost my things on the way. ainyam kokwap: to undermine; to plot against. ainyam iboro: not to pay back. enyami ngesi ekulukulu (enyapedo): she/he lives on the dole or lives on begging. aipet ainyam: to eat from everywhere or at every house; to partake of every meal. ainyamakin ki-a to escort or to accompany somebody on the way. kinyamakinai oreka: accompany me to my home. ainyamar ki-a to go with a friend (somewhere); to go as a guide; to accompany. ainyamun ki-a to accompany this way. to be accompanied; to accompany one another. enyamunos ipapero: friends have accompanied each other. ainyamur ki-o to hang on waiting for food or drink, etc; to be a tramp; to be a gatecrasher. inyamurei ngesi: she/he is a hanger on, etc. ainyang1 vengeance; revenge; retribution; reprisal; settling of scores; retaliation. ainyang2 ki-a to avenge; to take vengeance; to give tit for tat; to hit back, take revenge, or to retaliate. ainyangakin ki-a to take revenge for; to retaliate for. alosi eong ainyangakin ikakoku: I am going to take revenge for my child. to be spiteful, revengeful. ainyanganut to be vengeful, spiteful. ainyangar ki-a to hit back; to revenge, retaliate. (of food) to be very hot. inyangarit atap na: this food is very hot (literally, this atap has taken revenge). ainyanyisaun ki-o to be crumpled. ainyapal ki-a to command; to urge on (of a foreman) to be a headman or an overseer. ainyayi ki-o to be particular about; to be fussy, finicky, faddy, picky, choosy, pernickety, hard to please; to do as if one does not like; to pretend dislike; to dawdle. (not often used in simple form, usually used is ainyaiyo). inyayios idwe enyamete: the children are fastidious in their eating habits. ainyekikin ki-a to leave to; to abandon for; to leave with; to entrust, discontinue, omit. kinyekik inyamat ngul konyam ngesi da: leave her/him some food. ainyekikinia ki-a (prepositional verb) to leave with somebody; to entrust; to bequeath. ainyekin ki-a to leave, abnegate, let alone; to allow; to wait; to abandon, cease, or resign; to abstain, let off, or forsake (also used for the negative imperative: kinyek). kinyek ber alosit: do not go yet. kinyek kwangin: stop. kinyek nges kolot: allow her/it/him go; let her/it/him go. ainyekin ngun besides that. ainyekoonut1 (abstract noun F) jealousy; envy. ainyekoonut2 ki-o to be inclined to jealousy or envy ainyer ki-a to do badly, clear badly, shave badly, weed badly, sweep badly, etc (used with plural objects, or with often, always). inyeri ijo ekatogo apaarasia kere: you sweep my room always badly. ainyerinyer ki-a to do badly; to clean, sweep, weed, shave badly, etc. ainyerinyer akiro: to explain wrongly. ainyerinyer atap enyamio: to dirty the millet bread (by eating like birds pecking everywhere). inyerinyeri ngesi akemana: she/he cultivates only the top soil of her/his garden. ainyigolit a tonsil. ainyik ki-a to vex; to haze; to become gloomy to sob. sirikinyik lucetunga: do not vex other people. ainyikil ki-o to cause to look gloomy; to make gloomy (of face); to make dark (of weather); to make sombre. ainyikilikin ki-o to make somebody look gloomy. apotu akiro ngun kenyikilikis eong: what I heard made me gloomy. ainyikokin ki-a to persevere; to carry on, hold on, to become persistent; (of suffering, rainfall) to become worse; to be diligent; to go on, keep on with something; to harass, keep troubling. kenyikokit eong akou: the headache keeps troubling me. ainyikokinonut (singular noun F) perseverance; assiduity; determination; diligence; resoluteness. ainyil to tear off (as of meat, cloth, paper, etc). sirikinyil ekagoe: do not tear my cloth.ainyinyir1 sweat; perspiration. ainyinyir2 ki-a to perspire; to exude; to sweat; to be very busy at. inyinyirit ngesi aswam: she/he is hard at work, she/he is very busy. ainyinyir aokot: to be in agony (literally, to sweat blood). ainyo to stand up often; to rise often. ainyo ape: ainyo eku: to rise slowly. ainyogo ki-o to do again; to repeat; to go over again. ainyogo einer: to repeat what was said.ainyogokin ki-o to repeat to or for; to do again for. kinyogok: do it again (what was just done). ainyogokinet repetition; tautology. ainyogonokin ki-o to reiterate; to keep repeating. ainyogonyog ki-o to reiterate; to repeat often. ainyogoor ki-o to do again; to reconsider; to revise. kinyogoo amanakon: plough your field over again.ainyogoun ki-o to rake up; to dig up (as of old quarrel). ainyoiro ki-o to pull faces; to grimace. ainyong ki-a to knead, or mix clay, flour, dough with a little water to make a thick paste; to mix paste for beer. ainyong akiria nuka emugaati: to knead dough. ainyongakin ki-a to knead for; to mix for or somewhere. ainyongar ki-a to tire out; to exhaust through work; to weaken by finishing strength of. kenyongasi eong aroma: the blows have weakened me. ainyonyo ki-a to initiate a newly married woman into the clan by smearing her with ghee mixed with shavings of esas sticks in her mother-in-law’s house; to anoint or smear. ainyonyoanakin ki-a to smear on often; to anoint often with. ainyonyoet ointment; instrument for smearing. akinyet nakinyonyoet: oil for smearing or anointing. ainyonyoikin ki-a to anoint somebody or somewhere. ainyonyoikino naka lukadekak: extreme unction (before someone dies). ainyonyoikin akiro: to incriminate. ainyonyoikino (singular noun F) unction; annointing. ainyool ki-a to turn, twist; to pump (as of a borehole). ainyool amotoka: to drive a motorcar. ainyoolaet a steering wheel; a starter (of a motorcar); any instrument used for turning; a screw driver. ainyoolakin ki-a to turn once, as of door knob; to switch on, as of electric light; to twist. ainyopidaar ki-o to grind fine (of flour) to be ground fine. enyopidaaros akiria: the flour is ground fine.ainyor ki-a to mix; to combine; to add; to confuse, intermingle. ainyorakin ki-a to combine; to mix; to make a stew; to add together. ainyorakin akiro: to talk nonsense to be mixed, combined, added. enyorakinos inyamat: the food is mixed. ainyorinyor ki-a to mix up; to mix together; to combine; to add up (of anything).ainyudakin ki-a to put many together; to cram into. sirikinyudak ikito irae: do not plant so many trees close together. ainyudunyud ki-o to do slowly; to go slowly; to smoulder (of fire). inyudunyudi akim agugu: the fire is slowly burning the chaff. ainyudunyud ekitwi: to cultivate slowly, i.e. on account of bushes or high grass the cultivation goes slowly. ainyuk ki-a (intransitive verb to draw back; to recoil; to withdraw; to refrain; to refuse, be dismayed; to flinch; to retreat. enyuk emir ngol: that rat drew back (when it saw the cat).ainyul ki-a to pluck (a hen, or hair). kinyul akokor ngin: pluck that hen.aidot akokor. ainyum ki-a to be very compact. ainyumit ki-o to be very compact, hard, dense, pudgy. inyumit ekitoi lo: this is a very hard tree. ainyunyu ki-o to scrape together; to mop up (as of remnants of food or anything). ainyunyu aidoole: to clean the behind by rubbing it on the ground (as of a dog does). ainyunyuikin ki-o to contaminate (by smearing on); to make dirty; to stain; to sully; to implicate; to involve. abu kolo Adam kinyunyuik oni aronus: Adam implicated us all in his sin: soiled us all. ikoto ijo ainyunyuikin eong akirokon?: you want to implicate me in your case. to be implicated, contaminated. ainyunyus ki-a to crumple (of paper, cloth) in order to soften it. ainyuses (singular noun F) thickness (of dough, clay). ainyusor ki-o to become too thick (as of clay, dough). ainyut ki-a (of many) to huddle; to crowd or swarm around. ainyutunyutakin ki-o (of many) to huddle together; to crowd together. aipa1 ki-a to do one thing after another. aipa alosit: to be always on the move. aipa inyamat: to swallow food quickly; to gorge. aipa einer: to talk at random; to talk quickly. ipai ngesi einer: she/he talks quickly. aipa2 to go aside, give way; to swerve away; to branch off; to deviate. epai erot lo ai?: where does this road branch off to? ipaa ijo noi: you have made a big mistake. mam ngesi ekoto aipa: she/he does not want to deviate. aipaagis ki-a to rent; to hire. aipaagis emotoka: to hire a motorcar. aipaagis etogo: to rent a house. aipaagisaar ki-a to rent away; to hire out. aipaagisaar eiduka: to rent out a shop. aipaagisakin ki-a to rent for someone; to hire to. aipaagisakin apae etogo: to rent a house for a girlfriend. aipaanakin ki-a to keep doing, beating. abu ngesi kepaanak eong kakan: she/he kept on slapping me. aipaar ki-a to send after; to send away after another. aipac1 ki-a to make bare; to lay bare. aipac emukule: to scrape off fat or meat from a skin or hide. kipac emukule ngol: scrape that skin or hide. aipac2 to shell (groundnuts or beans); to peel (the bark of); to hull (coffee). kopacata emaido: shell the groundnuts. aipad ki-a to flatten; to increase in number or amount (the usual word is aipadar). aipadar ki-o to increase in number or quality (of anything). epadaros ikedwe: her/his children have increased in number. aipadipad ki-a to flatten out, as of pastry or dough or clay. aipado ki-o to ignore or do sluggishly; to show no morale in doing something; to console; to say condolences.aipaikin ki-a to do immediately; to do quickly (once); to give tit for tat at once; to take revenge at once. abu ngesi kipaik agaria: she/he cooked the fish at once. abu je kipaik adodikin nges emuudu: the other guy proceeded to aim a gun at him/her. aipak1 ki-a to bale out water; to clean or to wash (as of wound or sore, or as women do their genitals); aipak ajimi: to clean or wash a wound or sore. aipak ataker: to bale out water from a boat. aipak atan: to bale out dirty water from the well. aipak2 to break (as of cobs, cassava or potato tuber, etc); to pick maize cobs or break off a branch of a tree, etc kopak ekirididi: pick the maize cobs. (used only of things that grow together). aipak akiro: to say something big; to use high flowing language. aipakakin ki-a to pour water on; to bale water on something or for somebody. aipakar ki-a to splash, to bale away; to draw away by deceit; to clean a wound; to lure or decoy away. abu je kepaka eong okitui aibunga: she/he lured me away into the bush to beat. aipakas ki-a to labour for hire; to do work for daily or monthly pay.aipakipak ki-a to catch many fish (especially mudfish); to separate scum or dirt on top of water (when going to drink). kipakipak ber epiria ilosi aiwok akipi: first separate the moss (on top of water) before you fetch the water. aipal to give up; to part with something; to concede, sacrifice, give place to, or to forgive (a debt); to back out; to let go. aipal naka etau: not caring; indifference. aipali ki-o to be cheeky, arrogant, insolent, stubborn, obstinate. ipalie : she/he is (they are) arrogant, insolent, stubborn. aipaliikin ki-o to rebel against; to become cheeky; to be insolent to; to become obstinate; to become stubborn, arrogant. epaliiki etelepat ngol: that boy has become rebellious. aipalionor ki-o to become stubborn; to become cheeky, etc aipalionut1 (singular noun F) cheek; insolence; contumely; arrogance; obstinacy; stubbornness.aipalionut2 ki-o to be insolent, arrogant, stubborn, unruly, cheeky, obstinate, or insubordinate aipam ki-a to pommel; to compress; to press (as of food); to heap or press one upon another. ipami ngesi alupot arwatat: ipami ngesi arwatat: she/he presses the clay on the wall. to grow, to increase (of an anthill).aipang ki-a to hit (especially of cricket ball). aipang einyure: to hit the cricket ball. aipang(akin ice) akiro: to shift guilt on somebody else. to be implicated in a case. aipang aijar: to live a hard life or life full of difficulties; to just survive. aipangar ki-a to beat or push away, aside; to turn aside to turn or go or bounce away; to turn aside. aipangar aki: to turn a deaf ear to; to ignore. epangar emopiira awai: the ball bounced away, aside. aipanipan akiro ki-a to try to talk oneself out of a difficult situation. aipany a pit; a hole (in the ground); a pit latrine; a ditch; a trench. aibok aipany: to dig a hole or a pit; to put oneself in problems. alosit aipany: to go to the toilet. abokikin ice aipany: to set a trap against somebody; to plot against; to entrap.epapai eong: I am pouring cold water over. aipapa einer: to spread news, tell secrets; to tell tales. aipapaar ki-a to bathe a sick person; to waste water. aipapaar akipi: to waste water. aipapel ki-o to ignore; to pay no attention to; to disregard; to take no notice of. kepapel lolo je eong kopucit ke: the guy ignored me at his party.kipapero iso: we (exclusive of person spoken to) are friends. ipaperos kesi: they are friends. aipapero ki-o to be friends. aipaperonut ki-o to be friendly, sociable or affable. aipar to show what is white; to expose the white or shining part of something; to expose a white or shiny object. kipar igoen omuria: put the white clothes out on the grass. aipar akonye: to show the white part of the eye. aiparar ki-a to burst open (of flower or mushroom); to spread out (wings of birds or ears of elephant); to effloresce. ipararaete akweny koitolima: the birds spread out their wings on the river bank (shore). aiparaun ki-a a corruption of aiparun: to appear in the distance; to emerge and come this way. aiparun1 ki-a to appear in the distance; to emerge (with a glitter); to face this way from afar (with a flash). aiparun2 ki-o to infiltrate, penetrate, or permeate.aipas to be tired, weary, fatigued, or exhausted. kapas eong: I am tired. aipasipasakin ki-a to fill to the brim. ilot ijo aipasipasakin akipi amot tetere do ilapanaros: you went and filled the pot to the brim such that it now spills. aipat ki-a to heap up one on top of the other (as of dung or clay). ipasi akiteng aoret: the cow heaps up the cow dung.aipatat ki-o (of a big person) to lie or sit idle, do nothing;
