to lie or sit in a big heap; to be a big heap. ipatatai : she/he is (they are) sitting idle. inyo bo ipatataa ijo kane?: why are you sitting here idle? ipatataete igoen kotogoke: there is a big heap of clothes in her/his house. ipatatai ngesi kore: she/he lies idle at home – big as she/he is. ipatatai tai: dormant.aipatipat ki-a to keep heaping up (as of clay or cow dung). aipaun ki-a to bring at once; to bring immediately. to be brought at once; to come at once. kipaunos kesi: let them come at once. aipaun akoik: to miscarry. aipaun inyamat: to vomit immediately (after eating something). aipe1 to run away; to escape. kopeata yesi: you escape! you run away! aipe2 to toast; to roast over a fire; to scorch. kolot kope acokit: go and roast a potato. kope akiring: roast the meat. aipec ki-a to struggle; to try hard, contend, or scrimmage. ipecas itelepai ka Ateso: the boys are struggling with their Ateso lesson. aipecar ki-o to fight, have a skirmish. epecaros bian Kony ka ajore: the (Joseph) Kony rebels had a fight with the Uganda army yesterday. aipecipec ki-a to try repeatedly; to try hard; to try the impossible; to persevere; to struggle; to flounder. aiped1 ki-a (of sickness, worry) to tire one out; to worry to death; to make thin by worries or pain. keped ajimi na eong: this wound makes me thin, or worries me. aiped2 to pierce (someone or something); to puncture; to bore into something; to make or cause a leak (on a vessel); to give (a person or animal) an injection. epedi emuron itunga: the doctor injects people. aipedar ki-o to worry, make thin. kipedi ijo eong kakonikiro: you tire me out with your talk. to be thin through worries. epedar eong noi: worries have made me thin or I am worried very much. aipede ki-a to open (as of a book); to cut open (as of fish or anything). ipedee ngesi eitaabo: she/he opens the book.aipediar ki-a to open and clean (as of fish); to open a book wide; to stretch out. aipediar etau: to open one’s heart, to say everything one has to say. aipeg to oppose, or wrangle; to contradict or to dispute; to deny; to argue; to object; to disagree; to differ. apeg kotoma agwelet: to haggle, bargain, or negotiate in the market. aipejo ki-o to visit; to go visiting. ipejoi ngesi : she/he is (they are) visiting or holidaying. aipejokin ki-o to pay a visit to; to visit somebody or somewhere. aipejonokin ki-o to haunt; to keep on visiting. aipek ki-a to flap wings (as of a cock or birds on the ground). aipekesen ki-a to inspect a suspect’s premises; to examine a possible crime; (of the police) to investigate; (of a law enforcer) to search. apotu ipolisin kipekesenata ereka: the police personnel came to search my home. aipekipek ki-a to flap wings (as of a cock or birds on the ground). aipelakin ki-o to stand on edge; to be warped; to be in danger of falling; to be slanting, not straight. to put on edge; to warp, put in falling or wrong position. aipelipel ki-a to give a contemptuous sign with the finger, hand or knife (with anything). kepelipeli ngesi eong: she/he points at me with contempt. aipelor ki-o to pierce through; to poke; to impale or transfix. abu eong kecum etyang aipelor cut: I speared the animal right through its body. aipelun ki-o to pierce through this way; to puncture this way (of anything) to protrude, project, stick out. aipemipem ki-a to run away, especially of children slapping feet on the ground. aipen1 ki-a to sharpen (a panga, an axe, or a knife); to whet (a knife, a spear); (of birds) to clean the beaks. kipenata akusikwaras: sharpen your spears. aipen akwaras: to get ready for war or hunting (by whetting the spears). aipen2 (of underground crops like sweet potatoes or cassava) to bear fruit; to develop; (of white ants) to swarm. apenata acok: the potatoes have developed or have become big. apenata ikong: the white ants have swarmed. apenata abulon toma ajimi: the pus has developed in the wound.aipen3 to accrue; (of coins, children, etc) to amount, to number, be so many. apenata ikonidwe idi?: how many children do you have? or what is the number of your children? answer: apenata kesi iuni: they number three. kapena kaloto: let us get going.aipenakin ki-a to sharpen for. aipenakin akwara: to make or get ready to spear; to plot against. sirikilot ngina naarai kipenakitai ijo akwara: do not go there, for they have plotted against you. aipenet a grindstone for sharpening or whetting; an oilstone; a whetstone aipeny to start or initiate doing; to be the first to do. kopeny aswam: start work. aipepe ki-a to select (seeds); to select cultivation; to improve seeds. aipepe ikinyom: to select seeds; to improve cultivation; to breed purebred animals. aipepe akiro: to revive or renew a quarrel; to rake up an old quarrel. aipepeunet (singular noun F) a culturing; a revival; a renaissance. aiperen ki-o to defer; to postpone, send away empty-handed, put off, refuse to give. sirikiperen lokican: do not send a poor man away empty-handed. aiperikin ki-o to lay down on; to put to bed; to put to sleep (as of a child). aiperikin yenikadekan adekis: to admit a patient in hospital. aiperiper ki-a (of young birds, white ants) to flutter in small numbers. iperiperete ikong: the white ants are flying in small numbers.aipeseikin ki-o (of a baby girl) to reach marriage age; to become a girl. epeseiki do ikoku ngin: that child has become a big girl.aipesekin ki-a (of a boy, man or woman) to act or be like a girl; to be girlish; to behave like a girl. ipesekit etelepat ngol: that boy acts, behaves like a girl. aipet1 to spread out. aipet akapet: aipet ejamu: aipet aperit: to make a bed; to put the coverings neatly onto a bed. aipet edula: to make a platform for a granary. aipet akiro: to discuss; to talk things over; to go into details; to try to come to an agreement. aipet ainyam: to eat from every dish or at every house. aipet2 to kick. aipet emopiira: to play football. aipet erot: to stop on the way and not reach the expected destination. aipetet ki-o to sit or lie idle, doing nothing. ipetetei : she/he is (they are) sitting idle. inyo bo ipeteteo ijo kane?: why are you sitting (lying) here idle? aipetipet ki-a to put or spread out near one another, as of dry potatoes or beans or anything. aipetipeta ki-a to have convulsions; to writhe; (of an epileptic or dying person) to struggle. ipetipeta ngesi, ipetipetas kesi: she/he is (they are) writhing or convulsing. aipetipetakin ki-a to convulse; to writhe; to twist and turn. epetipetakin lokadekan, etakani eridaki: the patient has writhed, it seems he has died. aipi1 colloquial form of akipi: water. aipi2 ki-a to itch; to irritate (the body). kepii eong akakuwan: my body itches me. aipi naka akiyo: to look for trouble. kipiete jo akiyo: you are looking for trouble; you are looking for a cause to cry. kepiete eong akiro: I am anxious to speak. aipic ki-a (used only with plural objects) to knead with fingers; to crush; to press. aipic akoik: to procure abortion. angor nueroko ipicete akoikes: bad women procure abortion (i.e. by pressing their wombs). aipic esigala: to extinguish a cigarette by crushing it; to crush, destroy a cigarette.aipicar ki-a (used with singular object) to crush, squash, squeeze, compress, or to defeat. to be crushed, defeated, compressed, or squeezed. aipicipic ki-a to crush (into pulp); to rub or squeeze with fingers or hands (note: for bread, use ainyong); to keep pressing with hands. ipicipici ikoku ikisin katotoke: the child is squeezing its mother’s breasts. kipicipic egoe ngol ejok: rub that cloth in water well. aipid ki-a to hit slightly (anywhere); (of many things) to smack, strike; to slap often; to beat. ipidai esisianakinan idwe: the teacher smacks the children (at school). aipidaikin ki-a to smack or hit somewhere. aipiding ki-a to make a back entrance in a fence or an enclosure (of a home). epidingete kolo Iteso ikecereria: in the past the Iteso made a back entrance to their homes. aipidipid ki-a to grow very tall; to go far away, go on a long journey, travel far. ipidipidete Iteso Bulaya: the Iteso travel as far as Europe. aipidipidiar ki-o to go far away; to disappear. epidipidiaros kesi ngina: they have gone off far away. aipiipi ki-a (of a breeze) to stroke or caress the body; to blow gently. epiipii ekwam akakuwan: the breeze blew gently on my body. epiipii ekwam akipi: the breeze ripples the water, blows gently over the water, hence cooling the water. aipik ki-o to squirm; to wriggle; to try to get loose by wriggling. aipikakin ki-a to place somewhere on or in; to put somewhere on or in. (note: aipiikin is a corruption of aipikakin). kipikakis kes ngina: put them over there. aipikakin etau: to take to heart, put the mind to. kipikakis akiro nu otawonokus: take these words to heart. aipikipiko ki-o to squirm; to wriggle; to try to get loose; to have convulsions. ipikipiko ekweny: the bird is struggling to escape. aipikor ki-o to overpower; to surpass (one’s strength); to be too difficult for; to overcome; to conquer or defeat. aswam na kepiko eong: this work is too difficult for me. aipikoret a conquest; a takeover; an invasion; an occupation; a defeat; a subjugation; a downfall. aipilaar ki-a to enjoy or relish food as others watch. ipilai ngesi aketap: she/he relishes her/his food. epilaasi kesi akiring: they have enjoyed the meat.aipilil ki-o to make groundnut sauce or a relish with groundnuts or simsim. aipilitoi ki-o to run fast, go at full speed. aipima ki-a to measure; to weigh; to survey. ipimai epaaba: she/he (they weigh)s the cotton. aipima edou: to measure rain (using a rain gauge).aipinipin ki-a to pour out drop by drop (as of medicine in the eye). to leak slowly. aipiny ki-a to eat, overeat; to gorge; to cram with food (an insult); to dine. kolot kipiny akonitap: go and gorge your food. aipinyanut1 tendency to gorge or overeat. aipinyanut2 ki-a to be fond of gorging, eating ravenously to gorge, overeat.aipior to be finished. epioros ikasirigin: my money is finished completely. aipipa ki-a (of a woman) to pacify a man by using charms or tricks. aipir1 ki-a (of wood or dried potatoes) to be eaten by weevils; to rot; to crumble to dust. aipir2 ki-a to pierce (by drilling); to drill; to bore with drill. ipiri ngesi abao: she/he drills a hole in a board. aipiripir: to drill, etc. aipiripir akim: to twist a stick for making fire, i.e. to twist a splint. aipiripir alupot: to shape clay into a sausage. aipiripir akit: to poke into the ear. aipiripir edek: aipiripir emaagira: to crush cooked beans with emodu or eipiret (stirring stick). aisipir: to cause to pierce or bore. aipirakin ki-a to bore for. aipirakin akim: to make fire for. aipiric ki-a to keep crushing; to continue squashing or pressing out (as of juice). kipiric emucuuga lo: squash this orange. to be crushed, squashed, or pressed out.kipiricaa emuebe ngol: crush that mango. aipirionor ki-o to lope or take a long jump. aipiripir ki-a to drill; to bore a hole; to twist. aipiripirun ki-a to drill or bore this way. to bore its way through (this way). epiripirun akolong kodowon: the sun light has pierced its way through the clouds. aipiris ki-a to crush; to dissolve; to melt; to make soft. kinyek aipiris acok ipoi: do not cook the potatoes too soft.aipirisaar ki-a to crush; to dissolve; to soften; to squash to be dissolved; to be crushed; to decay; to soften; to sink (of heart); to be overdone. epirisaar ekatau aiirar ngun: my heart has sunk on hearing the sad news. aipirisakin ki-a to dissolve into. kipirisak abalang odia: dissolve the salt in the vegetables. to be dissolved. aipisakin ki-a to fill to the brim, absolutely full. kipisak akipi toma amot: fill the pot to the brim with water. ileleba amot pisi pis: the pot is absolutely full. to be absolutely full; to be complete)y full. episakinos akipi toma amot: the water has filled the pot completely: the pot is quite full of water. aipisio (singular noun F) breeding; rearing; nurturing. aipit1 ki-a to grow; to breed; to develop wealth (of living things); to rear. aipit apese: to refuse to give a girl in marriage (literally, to fatten a girl). aipit2 ki-a to tie (anything); to tie in a loop. ipisi ngesi akito: she/he is tying the firewood together, i.e. binding the firewood in a bundle. aipit amuk: to tie the shoe laces. aipit3 ki-o to grow long, high, or tall; to spread branches. ipisit ekitoi ngol: that tree has spread out its branches. aipitakin auno ki-a to tie on; to tie up; to lash. kipitak esibet auno: tie the prisoner up. loipitakitai auno: he who is tied up. aipitinakin ki-a to be spiteful to; to be inimical to; to hate; to show antipathy to. aipitinanut1 (singular noun F) maliciousness; ill-will. aipitinanut2 ki-a to be inclined to malice; to be ill-willed; to be malicious. aipitinat ki-o to have ill-will against; to be hostile to; to hate. kipitinatos kesi ijo: they do not like you. aipitipit ki-a to wind round; to coil, wrap, or twist round. aipiun ki-a to haunt, preoccupy, irk, trouble, disturb, or worry. aipiyoor ki-o to make thin; to tire out; to worry (by begging or any other way); to exhaust; to suck dry. kepiyoorit eong aswam na: this work exhausts me (or surpasses my strength). epiyoo ejakait imukopin: the chief has exploited the common people (by grabbing their things, for example). aipo1 ki-o to bake on fire; to cook; to boil. aipo2 to tear off (as of the bark from a branch); to strip off; to pull off skin (of an animal). aipo akopit: to pull off fibre. aipoc ki-a to go over soft muddy ground; to mash. aipoc erit: to walk in or on the mud or cow dung. aipoikin ki-o to cook for; to boil for; (of a woman) to marry to be married. ipoikino: (of a man) married (therefore they cook for him). aipoit to have cooked. ipoit ijo inyo?: what have you cooked? aipok1 ki-a to catch in a trap; to be ensnared. aunoi kere ipokitos: all the snares were successful in trapping something. aipok2 to take in big lumps (of food, etc); to give a big hard blow. aipok akiro: to tell a great secret; to speak indecently; to tell big lies. aipok atap: to take big lumps of millet bread. aipok akit: to hard on the ear.aipokakin1 ki-o to get caught in; to become ensnared. epokaki emir togo: the rat was ensnared in the house. aipokakin2 ki-o to get cramps (in the arm or legs); (of a vehicle) to get stuck (somewhere). epokakin eong akeju: I have cramps in my leg. aipokaun ki-a to slap heavily; to give a sound beating once. aipola ki-a to be bashful; to be ashamed (the usual word is aipolakin). aipolakin ki-a to be or become ashamed; to become bashful. aipolia ki-a to counter evil; to make an offering to counteract witchcraft; to disenchant. aipolia idwe: a traditional ceremony for praying for a barren woman to become fertile, or for a woman whose children die in infancy or are aborted. aipom a puff adder snake.aiponga ki-a to beat with a heavy object often; to thrash, wallop many times. kiponga ijo nges: you beat him. aipongaun ki-a to give a whack once; to thump once.aipoonokin ki-o to always cook for somebody. aipoore ki-o to cook; to boil. ipoi ngesi: she/he is cooking. epo: she/he has cooked. epooto kesi: they have cooked. aipooro ki-a (of eyes, wound) to be red. ipooro nges akonye: her/his eyes are red. aipopol ki-a to talk loudly; to be noisy, raucous. ipopolaete: they talk aloud; they are noisy. aipopolanut ki-a to be noisy, raucous, rowdy, etc aipopolat ki-ao to be noisy; to be talking aloud. ipopolat ngesi, ipopolato kesi: she/he is (they are) rowdy, cantankerous. aipopony ki-a to act rough. aipoponyatoi ki-a to move like a rhino in bushes. aipor to fly; to take to the air. eporete ikweny kede idegei: birds and aeroplanes fly. aiporo1 wet season. apaarasia nuka aiporo: the days of or the time of the wet season; springtime. aiporo2 ki-o to elope with. abu ngesi kiporo akaberu: he eloped with my wife. alot akaberu eporo: my wife has eloped, run away. eporo elopement. aiporor ki-o to pierce through. ecum eong ebileng aiporor: I speared the mudfish right through. aiposi ki-a to drive or run into the bush or far away; to chase, make to run (used with plural object). iposie ngesi akituk okitui: she/he chases the cows into the bush. aiposiaar ki-o (of living things) to run and get lost; to rush away or out. eposiaar mamaika: my uncle got mad and ran away. aiposikin ki-o to rush at; to do rashly. eposikin ekapa emir: the cat rushed at the rat. aiposipos akiro ki-a to talk a lot in anger; to complain or quarrel a lot. iposiposi ngesi akiro: she/he keeps on quarrelling. aipot1 ki-a to lash, beat up, thrash, drub, belabour, or bash. eposi eong, iposete kesi: I am beating, they are beating. aipot2 akiro ki-a to talk much, say much; to prate. aipot einer: to talk at random, be talkative. abu ngesi kipot akiro: she/he talked a lot. akiro nukipota tai: sheer nonsense, bunkum, hogwash. iposi ngesi aswam: she/he works hard: she/he toils.aipotor ki-o to lead away, astray; to cut off. abu ngesi kepoto eong: she/he led me astray (showed me the wrong road) (not used figuratively) to go wild or astray; (of a woman) to go after another man.aipoun ki-o to cook for oneself a little food. aipu1 to escape by breaking through the crowd, etc.aipu2 to butcher; to slaughter; to kill (of animals). kopuoto emong konyamata: slaughter a (healthy and non-problematic) bull and eat it. aipua akipi ki-a to pollute the water. aipuakar ki-o to become many or numerous.aipuar ki-o to increase in number; to become many; to abound. epuaros idwe kosomero: the children in school have increased in number. aipuc1 (singular noun F) peace; harmony. aipuc2 ki-a to seal, close completely; to cover completely; to block up; to plaster; to close hermetically; to hide (the truth). kipuc amot: seal the pot. ekoto ngesi aipuc akiroke: she/he wants to hide the real truth. aipuc edula: to build a big clay-and-grass granary. aipuc3 to have peace; to be peaceful. epuci, epucete: she/he is (they are) at peace. aipuc naka etau: composure; equanimity. aipucakin ki-a to lock up for; to fasten (a box); to plaster over (a hole). aipucakin edula: to build a granary for someone or for something. aipucakin erot: to close or block up the road. to be blocked up; to be fastened, locked, closed up, plastered. epucakinos eong iporotoi: my throat is blocked. aipucanakin ki-a to patch up cracks or holes often (not used of cloth). aipucet a thing for blocking a hole or crack. aipud1 ki-a to desire; to like. ipuda ngesi inyo?: what does she/he (they) desire? kwape ipudar ekisil: as required by the law. aswam kwape ipudatar ikisila: to do as the laws or rules require. aipud2 ki-o to bring out; to expose. kipud iboroka kinga: bring my belongings outside. aipud3 to go out very early. ipudoro lolo jo kinga sek: you went out early today. aipuda ki-a to tread on; to trample on repeatedly. ipudaete kesi akakimai: they are trampling on my millet. aipudaar ki-a to tread underfoot thoroughly; to trample on completely. aipudaar erot: to make a path (by constantly walking over the same ground). aipudakin ki-o to decide on; to desire; to want. aipudakin: to prefer; to want; to be attached to. epudakin ekatau alosit kwapekwana: I have decided to go immediately.aipudanar ki-o to desire each other; to love each other, be of one mind. aipudel ki-o to tantalize.aipudokin ki-a to expose; to show; to bring out for. kipudokinai iso atenus: bring out the drum for us (to dance). aipudor ki-o to take outside; to show; to expose. kipudosi iicolongo kinga: take the chairs outside. to go outside; to show oneself outside. aipudun ki-o to bring outside; to make to appear (of woman); to bring a baby outside from confinement in the house after being born; to reveal (a secret). to come out (as of secret); to appear. aipudunio (singular noun F) a traditional ceremony of bringing a baby outside from confinement in the house after being born; a ceremonial bringing of the corpse of the dead out of the house for burial. aipues1 (singular noun F) quantity; multitude; amount. aipues2 ki-a to be many; to be numerous; to abound; to be great in number. kipu iso, ipu yesi, ipu kesi: we, you, they are many or numerous.aipuga ki-a to rule; to dominate, or to control; to govern. ipugai nesi, ipugaete kesi: she/he rules, they rule.aipuk1 ki-a to give a slight blow under the chin. aipuk2 ki-o to fan (face or fire); to flap wings; to increase. aipuk isiru: to fan or drive away the mosquitoes. aipuk k’akokor: to fan twins (on new moon) or to fan sick person with a chicken (something like incensing). aipuk elutaari: to incense the altar. aipuk itunga: to fan people. aipuk akim: to fan the fire. aipukor itunganan: to fan a person; to bewitch a person. ipukoritai ijo: you are bewitched. aipuk3 to keep opening (as of book, box, etc); to keep uncovering (used with plural object). aipukakin ki-a to give a slight blow to; to chuck. kepukaki ngesi eong: she/he gave me a slight knock or blow. aipukanar ki-o to box on the jaws often; to chuck again and again. aipukaun ki-a to box or knock on the jaws once. aipuke (of melted fat or oil) to solidify. aipuket a fan (for stirring air); a blow pipe; a bellows. aipukupuk1 ki-o (of heart) to palpitate or to beat quickly; to throb. ipukupuko ekatau: my heart throbs. aipukupuk2 ki-o to keep fanning; to keep incensing, shaking. ipukupuki ngesi akim: she/he fans the fire. aipul ki-a to grow (as of anthill or wound); to ooze out (as of resin); to protrude (as of mucus of nose). ipulit ikoku ekume: the child has a dirty nose. ipulit ajimi: the wound is festering. ipulas ajon eipul: the beer is just bubbling over. aipulaar ki-a to reverse the motion of something; (of action, such as speech) to change into something else, such as a quarrel. aipulaar emopiira: to kick the ball backwards overhead. aipulaar acel: to raise a quarrel; to turn into a quarrel. to be turned into; to be changed into. epulaaros akiro: the conversation has changed (into a quarrel or to another topic). aipular ki-a (of termites) to cover things to be eaten (of a sore) to be covered by dirt. epulasi ikok ebela: the ants have covered up the stick (to eat it) to be covered by soil or dirt (through the action of ants or termites). aipule a navel; umbilicus.aipulupul ki-a to rise to the surface (like bubbles); to grow like an anthill. aipum ki-a to throw down with thuds (of anything heavy). aipumupum ki-a to strike (of lightning); to throw down many times or often. ipumupumit eipyei etunganan kanen: the lightning struck a man in that area. aipun ki-a (used with plural noun) to throw dust, flour, powder; to cover with dust, etc aipun itunga: to cover people with dust. aipunupun: to keep throwing dust, etc aipunakin ki-a to throw dust or powder or flour at somebody.aipunanar ki-a to keep throwing dust; to knock the earth off the grassroots after hoeing; to beat one right and left, and pushing them down. aipunar ki-a to knock over (as of a car knocking a person, an animal or a bag of flour); to hit something so that it falls over. aipung ki-o to place a thing slanting; to turn sideways, to tilt up to be slanting, tilted, turned sideways; (of ship) to list, to be lopsided. aimat ajon aipung: to drink beer and get drunk (literally, to drink up to the slanting position). aipungokin ki-o to put slanting for; to tilt over for; to make to lean over to lean over; to be slanting.aipungor ki-o to turn away from; to turn towards somebody or from somebody; to turn one’s back to (used with epura). aipunupun ki-o to soil (hands or body or anything) with dust, flour or powder.ipunupunete idwe alupok: the children are throwing dust about. aipunupuno ki-o to roll in the sand, ashes or dust like chicken; to play in the sand; to cover oneself with dust. ipunupunos idwe kotoma asinge: the children play (roll) in the sand. aipunyar ki-a to knock over. abu akiteng kipunya elepit: the cow knocked over the milking can.aipup to hear; to listen; to understand; to know; to feel. aipupuk ki-a to shake (as of cloth); to slap wings (as of cock starting to crow or of hen going to fight); to attack furiously (of cock or hen). ipupukat ekokor itunganan: the cock attacked a man. (figurative) to attack fiercely. ipupukatos ajokin itunga: evil spirits attacked people. aipupukatoi ki-o to writhe; (of a bird) to struggle to get away from a trap. aipupung ki-a to tie into a big knot so as to make it difficult to untie. aipupungakin ki-a to bundle up, tie together for. aipupus ki-a to trample upon or down; to walk on or over. apotu akituk kipupusata ekapaaba: the cattle trampled down my cotton. aipupuut ki-o to be rather many. ipupuuto itunga kangina: there are rather many people over there.aipur1 ki-a to sprinkle dust, sugar, salt, powder, etc on; to strew with dust, etc. aipur2 to intercede, mediate, or arbitrate; to speak in favour of; to pacify; to reconcile; to placate. aipurakin ki-a to sprinkle on, etc (of dust, etc but not of liquids).aipuri ki-o to smoke out; to fill with smoke. ipurie ngesi eketogo: she/he smokes out her/his house. epurie elulu: there is hullabaloo. aipuri emome: to smoke out flying ants. aipurikin1 ki-o to be busily engaged; to be occupied with any action. aipurikin amat: to be busily engaged in drinking; to have a beer party. aipurikin2 ki-o to smoke out. aipurikin ikumes: to blow smoke into nostrils; to revive (by blowing smoke into nostrils) to be smoky; to smell after smoke; to taste after smoke; to look brown with smoke. epurikitos acok: the potatoes have a smoky taste. epurikitos igoenekon: your clothes are dirty (brown) from the smoke. aipuripur ki-a to sprinkle powders or crystals on; to strew salt, sugar, etc aipuris ki-o to spear, spike or impale. aipuruj ki-a to disturb (liquids); to contaminate (liquids); to stir or make dirty (liquids only). aipurujaun akipi: to dirty the water by stirring; to adulterate. epurujaunos akipi: the water has been stirred dirty. aipurusoor ki-o to spear or impale through. aipuruun ki-a to drive out by smoke. aipuseronut (singular noun F) widowhood; losing one husband after another. aipuset a mop; a duster; a wipe. aipusor ki-o to throw down heavily with a thud; to let slip or fall to fall down with a thud; to slip.kiput emeesa: polish the table.aiput2 to be like; to become like, resemble. eputos aberu kikokuke: the mother looks like the child. epusit ngesi ngai?: eputos ngesi ka ngai?: whom does she/he resemble? aiputar ki-a to wipe out, polish, or expurgate. aiputiikin ki-a (of a child) to become stunted in growth. aipuwaun ki-o to become dusty; to become dusty (of water or liquids). epuwaunos akipi nu: this water has become dusty. aipwak to start something new; to annoy someone without reason; to tease. aipwak aswam: to create your own work (not what one was told to do). kopwak erot kane: make a new road here. aipwak akiro: to start another topic (of conversation). aipwak ere: to build a new home. aipwat to wipe, buff, polish. epwasi epolisit emuudu: the policeman is polishing the gun. apwata kesi: they have polished. aipwok ki-a to soil or dirty (solid objects) with. epwokata idwe ikagoen: the children have soiled my clothes. (note: aicok, aipuruj: to make liquids unclean or polluted). aipwokakin1 kwap ki-a to throw down carelessly so as dirty; to dump or plonk down. aipwokakin2 ki-o to become dirty, soiled somewhere. aipwokun ki-o to become dirty or soiled. aipwony ki-a to push back the foreskin. aipwonyar ki-a to pierce with something sharp (as with thorn or pointed object). kepwonya eong ekukwai akeju: a thorn pierced my foot. aipyalal akwap ki-a to run very fast; to take to one’s heels. ipyalalaete kesi akeju: they run very fast; they are taking to their heels. aipyalalaar ki-a to run away very fast; to race, to run off quickly. aipyang ki-a to fetch a little of (liquids only); to shake, move liquids in a container. aipyang akipi: to bring a little water. aipyangar ki-a to take away a little of (a liquid) in a big vessel (so that it sloshes from inside)to be taken away (of a small quantity of liquid). aipyangun akipi: to bring a little or too little water. aipye to sweep (the house or compound); to clean with a broom. kopyeata etogo: sweep the house.aipyed1 ki-a to bewitch (by night dance or by cries) to bewitch; to cast an evil eye on; to curse. ekacudan ipyedi itunga: the witch bewitches people. kipyedi bian kia: somebody bewitched us last night by dancing round our house.aipyed2 (singular noun F) bewitching; witchcraft. koyanga aipyeda kon ngina: go and do your witchcraft somewhere else. aipyed3 ki-a to do witchcraft; to practice witchcraft. alot ngesi aipyeda: she/he has gone to practice her/his witchcraft. koyanga aipyeda kon ngina: away with your witchcraft! aipyel ki-a to hanker after; to be addicted; to feel a craving for; to long for; to desire; to lust. kepyel eong akiring: I long for meat (note that akiring is the subject). ipyelit ngesi etelebision: she/he is a telly addict. ipyelit ngesi emopiira lopetot: she/he is a football addict.aipyer ki-a to warm oneself (near the fire or in the sun); to bask. ipyerete itelepai enyango: the boys warm themselves in the morning sun. aipyer akim: to warm oneself near the fire. aipyer akolong: to warm oneself in the sun. aipyet to winnow; to sift. epyesete angor akimai: the women are winnowing the millet. aipyetar to winnow away; to sift away. apyetar inyamat: to finish the food. to be winnowed; to be finished (of anything). apyetar aswam: the work is finished. apyetar akeje: kapyetasi akeje: let us go away.aira1 ki-a to plant; to transplant. irae ngesi epaaba: she/he plants cotton.aira2 (of a plant) to bear fruit; to be prolific. ekitoi ngol erae noi: that tree bears well. airab1 ki-a to discuss; to debate; to argue, discourse. iraba ngesi : she/he is (they are) discussing, debating, or taking part in a discussion. airab2 ki-a to plead for; to endeavour; to settle differences. airab asurup: to settle a feud, a quarrel. airab3 ki-a to sharpen (as knife, etc). irabi epuudit icuumanake: the carpenter sharpens her/his tools. airabes a place of discussion; a parliament; a courtroom. airabes nakapolon: high court; the national assembly.alosi eong airac akonijon: I am going to throw your beer outside. airac akiro: airac einer: to talk a lot; to say much, be talkative. airac isirigin: to pay too much; to pay through the nose. airac edia: to spill vegetables. airacirac ki-a to have too many irons in the fire, do too many things at once. iraciraci ijo aswamusinei, mam eong apedori: you bring so many jobs, I cannot manage them. airacirac edia: to spill vegetables on something. iraciracete idwe edia: the children are spilling vegetables. airacirac apesenin: to have many debts. airadad ki-a (of anything inactive) to be numerous or many together. iradadaete itunga koreka: there is a crowd of people in my home, just sitting. airadirad ki-a to produce in great numbers; to put many together or near each other (of anything); to do many things, works at once. kiradiradata apanya: dig the potato-heaps near one another. airadirad aswamusinei: to do many jobs at the same time. cp airacirac. airag ki-a to grind badly or coarsely; to husk (beans or peas). imare luiragag: crushed peas. airagirag ki-a to grind badly or coarsely; to husk (beans or peas). akiria nuiragiraga: meal flour poorly ground. airaikin ki-a to plant somewhere or for somebody; to transplant. airaj ki-a to tie loosely; to make loose (used with a plural object). irajit ijo akituk ngun: you have tied those cows too loosely. airajaj ki-a to sit idly (especially of a fat person). irajajai ngesi kore: she/he sits at home doing nothing. airajiraj ki-a to tie loosely (used with singular or plural object). airam to pulsate; to beat (a drum); to play a musical instrument; to thresh grain. erami ngesi atenus: she/he beats the drum. airam itunga: to call people together (in olden times by drum, but these days a person can move from home to home telling people to attend a gathering, or simply place a radio announcement). airam adeudeu: to play the harp (musical instrument). airam edongot: to ring the bell. aram naka etau: heartbeat, pulsation. airam erot: to beat road level. airam itunga origa: to call people away for a hunt. airam emome: a method of catching flying ants (emome) by beating a dry log with two small sticks (the ants mistake the sound drops and swarm up a tube which leads into a pot where they are trapped). airam imu: a traditional ceremony after the birth of twins, involving wearing ebomo, emuria and egwangira plants on the head and waist, dancing emidiiri, beer drinking and a lot of other observances. airamakin ki-a to interfere; to meddle; to rush at. airamam ki-a (of wound, eyes) to be very red, crimson. iramamaete akonye bala etukuri: your eyes are red as those of an owl. iramamai: it is red, crimson. iramamaete: they are red, crimson. airamiram ki-a to take out cattle to graze in the morning before milking them (believed to increase milk yield). airanga ki-a to become greedy, gluttonous (with food). airangaanut1 (singular noun F) gluttony; greed; ardour. airangaanut2 to be greedy, gluttonous, or given or inclined to greed. airangang ki-a to be red all over (of anything). ayaun esaati irangangai aokot bon: a shirt was brought red all over with blood. airany ki-a to ride (on an animal or vehicle). airanyakin ki-a to make to sit down to sit down.airanyar to ride away. airap to cover or wrap; to hide (by covering); to make dark (by covering); to envelope. airapakin kwap ki-o to duck or stoop suddenly. airar ki-a (used with plural object) to pick up; to levy. irarete idwe ingaroi: the children are picking up pebbles. airarun ki-a to find, discover or pick up; to select. airas to continue, carry on, go straight on, or do immediately. airat to abuse often; to revile often; to offend often; to insult. abu nges karat eong: she/he offended me, or abused me. aire1 ki-o to peer or stare at.aire2 (of many things) to push aside far apart. areikin: to push for or somewhere.aire3 to hate, detest, dislike, be spiteful, be hard on, or to have something against one. (the word more often used is areit). aireb1 akiro ki-a to say something hurting; to be sarcastic; to complain bitterly. irebi Austin Ejiet akiro iwadikai: Austin Ejiet writes sarcastically. airebireb einer: to talk quickly. aireb2 ki-a to mince (meat); to cut, nibble, cut up small (vegetables or hair with a knife or scissors).irebi aberu ecaboi: the woman is cutting up the ecaboi vegetable. airebireb akiring: to cut meat into small pieces. akiring nairebirebitai: minced meat.aireb3 ki-o (used with a plural object) to stop the progress or advance of; to bring to a standstill. aireb ibaren: to stop cattle (from going further). airebar ki-a to nibble away at. abu emir kirebaa auno: the rat nibbled the rope. airebireb ki-o to keep in check, persuade to stay, dissuade, curb, stop from going, keep preventing from going (of living beings only). airebokin ki-o to oppose; to stem, resist, stop one from going or doing; to stop progress; to intercept; to prevent, keep back (from going); to hinder, obstruct, rail. ejaas akiro nukerebokinitos eong: something prevents me (from going or doing). airebokinet hindrance; obstacle; barrier. airebonokin ki-o to obstruct constantly, keep refusing, keep putting obstacles in the way, keep preventing. kerebonokini ngesi eong akalosit: she/he keeps refusing to allow me to go. airebor ki-o (only of living beings) to push back, repulse, parry, ward off, deflect, circumvent. airebun ki-o to fetch back; to lead back, drive back (only of living beings). kirebutu akituk: drive the cattle back. aired ki-a to make or brew plenty of beer. airedakin ki-a to brew much beer for, or somewhere. ireded ajon kotogo: there is plenty of beer in the house. iredakit amuran iketunga ajon: the mother-in-law has made a lot of beer for her people. aireg ki-a to scrape (of anything); to clear ground of weeds; to clean (as of road, compound) by scraping the soil. airegegear (singular noun F) palsy; paralysis - adeka naka airegegear airegem ki-a to have dirty eyes. airegireg ki-a to scrape clear or scrape off (of ground or anything). aireikin ki-o to peep at; to look through; to examine. akoto aireikin asaduku ngin: I want to look into that box. aireire ki-a to canvass; to converse. airem1 ki-a (of a dog or fox) to bark; to be barking. irema ekingok: the dog barks. airem2 to push or shove. korem amotoka: push the car. airem3 to spear, stab, or transfix; to puncture; to thrust (spear) into; to gore. arem esumaalit amotoka: a nail punctured the motorcar tyre.airemaar ki-a to bark away; to bark in a distance. airemakin ki-a to bark, howl, woof at once. eremaki ekingok ekokolan: the dog has barked at the thief. airemanut ki-a (of a dog) to be a good barker. iremana ekingokoka: my dog is a good barker. airenge ki-a to beat, or to overcome (in a fight); to drive (motorcar or motorcycle); to discharge or sack. airengear ki-a to dismiss, excommunicate, expel, send away, chase away, drive away, or to depose. airengear kotoma akwap: to deport, extradite. kirengea ekingok ngol: chase that dog away. abu Okello Lutwa kirengia Milton Obote kokaru 1985: Okello Lutwa deposed Milton Obote in 1985. airengeenen ki-a to keep on dismissing; to dismiss often; to drive a car, be a driver. irengeenenei amotoka: she/he drives a car. airengeikin ki-a to drive for somebody; to chase away, to send away for, drive into. airengeikin ekiliokit: to send away a girl (who refuses) to her husband. airengeun ki-a to send, expel, or drive this way. kirengeutu akituk (lailo): drive the cattle this way. aireonokin ki-a to look at constantly, scrutinise repeatedly.aibwap: to go to look for. aireor akou ki-a to look out (as snake from a hole or a person out of a window). airep ki-a to run with short steps; to trot (as of animal). airepirep ki-a (of a short person) to trot; to trip. airepirep akeje: to walk, go at trotting pace. airepun ki-a to come running (slowly). airere ki-o to examine; to observe; to look at sharply; to enquire. inyo bo irerei ijo kanen?: what is there you are looking at so curiously, so closely?airereonokin ki-o to choose for; to select for. airereonut1 (singular noun F) inquisitiveness; fondness for research. airereonut2 ki-o to be fond of looking at, for, in; to be inquisitive. airereor ki-o to look round for something (lost). aires (singular noun F) beer for tasting. airet to give a heavy blow (with a stick or hand); to bang (doors); to belabour; to rattle. airet ikekia: to rattle doors. airet adere: to drink beer greedily from a calabash. airetakin ki-a to shout at, rebuke, scold, reprimand, or chide; to balk strongly, reproach, or warn; to dress down. abu ngesi kiretak eong kanuka aswamuka: she/he scolded me on account of my work. to be scolded, reproached, reprimanded. airetun ki-a to thunder (once). airi1 ki-a to pull, drag along; to draw (used with plural subject or object). airi anaaga: to ride a bicycle hard. iriete kesi edula: they are dragging the granary along. airi emusaago: to drag a case on (without coming to the conclusion or final judgement). airi2 ki-o to cross or put in one’s way; to bar the way. alosi eong aikam lukecor, ido mam akoto ijo airi eong: I am going to fish and I don’t want you to spoil my good luck (prevent me). airi3 ki-o to look or search for; to sponge for food. airi inyamat: to look for food. airiikin: to look for, go and find for somebody or somewhere. airiikin ajon: to have a long drag at a beer tube (to drink ravenously). airi4 to crack, split, or tear along seams. airi5 to be crooked, twisted (as of board, tree, manners, house, rows of cotton plants, or anything abnormal, but not of road). eriete ikoniponesio: your manners are crooked. eriete nges akeje: she/he is knock-kneed. eriete akiro: it is a contradictory statement. erie eketau: eriete akeomisio: she/he is corrupted in thought. eriitos akonye: she/he has a squint.airi6 to straighten, make straight (as of a crooked stick, board, etc or of a case in question); to stretch out. kori ebela: make that stick straight. airiac to split, fissure. airiad ki-a to shamble along, walk like one with weak knees, that is, awkwardly; to trudge. airiak ki-a to hurry to, assemble together, or run to. ai bo iriakete yesi?: where are you hurrying to? airiakanara (of two or more things being compared) to be equal (in size or age), or to be commensurate. eriakanara papa ka okoku: iriakas papa ka okoku: the father and son are the same size. iriakanara iponesio: (of manners, behaviour) congenial.airiakuun to have the same height; to reach the same height; to be equally big. eriakuut kesi: they are the same height or size. airiam1 ki-a to meet, come together, or to encounter. bia keriama oreka: come, let us meet at my home. airiam2 ki-a to be sufficient or enough to go round. inyamat lu mam elosete airiam itunga kere: this food will not be enough for all the people. airiamakin ki-a to join; to put together; to tie together; to surround; to converge; to link. kiriamak aunoi: join the (two) ropes. apotu kesi kiriamakis etogo: they joined the house. to meet, come together, collide, or to encounter. keriamakinos ka nges ngina: let us meet him there. airiamakinet a meeting (place); a collision; a rendezvous. airiamar to meet at a distant place. airiamet a junction; an angle; an abutment; the intersection. airiamun ki-o to get together; to meet at one place, converge, or to concur. airian1 (singular noun F) a blazing heat. airian2 (of fire) to be ablaze; (of body) to be very hot, feverish; to glow, be aflame, ablaze. eiriani akakuwan kanuka eimidi: I am feeling feverish. eiriani ekatogo: my house is ablaze. koanyu, eiriani etogo loka Aanyu: look, Aanyu’s house is ablaze. airianar ki-a to keep pulling, dragging away or out to be dying, gasp for breath; to sigh. kenyek eong nges irianar: I left him gasping. airiang ki-a to stagger; to sway like a sick or drunken person, walk unsteadily. airiangakin ki-o to stagger into or somewhere or against someone. airianganar ki-o to stagger against one another; to lurch; to keep swaying. airiangitoi ki-a to keep staggering (like a drunkard). airianikin to stir fire; to be ablaze; to glow on account of. airiapakin ki-o to be surprised, give a surprise, come upon suddenly. eriapakin ngesi keanyu eong: she/he was startled on seeing me. airiare ki-a to grind (only used in infinitive). alosi eong airiare: I am going to the flour mill. airiaun ki-a to make dizzy, giddy. keiriaunit eong etengei: hunger is dizzying me. airib to become dark; (of sky) to be overcast; (of weather) to be dull. airic to hold fast, hold tight; to observe law, or to follow advice; to heed, obey law, or keep a promise. koric iicorakinaka: keep my commandments. airid1 ki-a to tighten the noose, etc. airid2 ki-a (of a dying person or animal) to gasp airid3 to tuck in; squeeze, press between two bodies. airidakin1 take a dying breath. airidakin2 ki-a to tie for; to fasten to die to be tightened; to be properly fastened. airidid ki-a to gulp down noisily; to drink like cows. airie ki-a to grind (between two stones); to pulverise. airieb to ache, pain, or hurt; to be sore; to make sore. kariebi eong akou: my head aches (pains me). kariebi eong akan: my arm aches. kariebi eong etengei: I am hungry. airiec to pound, crush, squash, ravage; to kill in great numbers. erieci eong acok: I am crushing potatoes.airiecakin ki-a to crush, squash, pound for. eriecak eong ekabokorit: I crushed my finger. to be crushed, pounded, squashed.airieng to avoid for fear or surprise. airieny ki-a to dig up, root up, uproot; to clear the bush. airieny ariang: to clear away stubble from where millet was harvested. airieny erot: to clear the road of grass.airiet a grinding stone; a mill. airieun ki-a to grind a little for oneself to be ground. erieun alos edit: only a little flour was ground. airiga1 ki-a to hunt (especially wild game). airiga2 ki-a to rub, file (with an iron file); to sharpen with a metal file; to grate. airiga ikel: to grind teeth, gnash teeth. airiga ekia: to rub on medicine. airiga k’emusumeeni: to saw. airigaikin ki-a to hunt for or somewhere. airigakin ki-a to surround (as of hunters surrounding animals); to fence in; to rub for. airigasit a hunting ground. airigaun ki-a to hunt out from a place; to rub this way; to rub for someone. alosi eong airigaun tata epur: I am going to rub grandma’s back (as she bathes). airiget a gathering of elders for a discussion; (formerly) a cabinet or assembly; a meeting. airigiikin ki-a (of food, for want of water) to be burnt. erigiikis acok: the sweet potatoes have burnt (because all the water evaporated from the saucepan). airigionokin ki-o (of anything) to rub on, into. airigior ki-o to saw (once); to abrade. airigioret abrasive; sandpaper; metal file. airigirig (abawoi) ki-a to saw (timber). airiikin1 ki-a to have a long pull, to drag or pull for, or somewhere. airiikin ajon: to have a short, good pull at a beer tube; to have a good short drink. kiriik ber ajon kolot: have a good drink (of beer) before you go.airiikin2 ki-o to put across, tie crosswise, or put in the way of; to bend sideways. airiikin akonye: to squint. airiikin akeje: to tackle (in a football game); to trip a person. iriikit ngesi akonye: she/he squints.airiir2 (of depth) to be abysmal; to cause giddiness, dizziness; to be precipitous. aipany ngin eiriiri: that hole makes one dizzy (because it is very deep). airiiri ki-o to put crosswise; to put in the way, obstruct, intervene, prevent, spoil. iriirit ijo alositeka: you have spoiled my journey or my luck. airiirikin (of fire) to start blazing. airiirikin akim: to start a blazing fire. airiit ki-o to drag along; to tow; to trail. iriit eris ekekori kokwap: the leopard drags its tail on the ground. airiitoi ki-o to be elastic; to be creeping (as a snake); (of a person) to drag oneself along. airik1 ki-a to be last. eong eriki: I am the last. airik2 ki-a to finish; to end. kirik inyamat ngul: finish off that food. airik3 to lead with rope or stick or by hand (as of a blind person). loemudukana erikio k’ebela: a blind man is led by the stick. airika ki-a (of a child, calf, etc) to suck the last milk; to keep suckling. airikakin ki-a to finish, complete, consummate, end, or to accomplish to be finished, completed, or accomplished; to die. akoto airikakin aswam na: I want to finish this work. ikar lumam irikakinos: for ever and ever.airikakinet a limit; an end; a boundary; a border; a full-stop. airikar ki-a to exterminate; to finish off (eating, spending, etc); to complete; to deplete. to be finished off; to get finished. erikaros inyamat: the food is finished. airikirik1 ki-o to cut meat or anything into long strips. airikirik2 (of part of the body, due to reflex action) to quiver; to twitch; to tic. airim ki-o to go round; to spin or revolve round; to wander about; to roam about; to hover over. irimi kereka akwap na: note that the fortunes of this world change fast (literally, by the way this world revolves). irimi ijo airim: you just wander about. irimi elap akwap, ido bobo irimi akwap da akolong: the moon rotates round the earth, and the earth in turn revolves round the sun. airimirim ki-o to go round something; to wander about aimlessly; to hover round. airimokin ki-o to round up, or to surround; to tour; to enclose, or encircle (of anything). kirimok ekonitogo k’abwas: surround your house with a hedge or fence. to be surrounded, encircled, or rounded up. irimokini akwap akolong irwana tipe kangolikaru: the earth revolves round the sun once every year. airimor ki-o to go round something; to surround, or to encircle. airimor akwap: to round the country or world. to make an excursion or expedition. airing ki-a to become stout, fat, or muscular. iringit ekesa ngol: that man is very muscular.airinga ki-a to take, carry, or catch something big. iringaete angor ibilenga k’ocor: the women catch big mudfish in the lake. airingaar ki-a to take away something heavy or big; to throw away or fly away with something big. eringaa etori aculot: the kite has managed to snatch away a young hen. airiny to lose freshness; to droop (with heat of sun); to become thin (of body of a person). erinyit acokit na: this potato is shrivelled. airioc ki-a to split (as of wood); to husk (groundnuts); to shell nuts, etc. airiong to carry a load on the shoulder. inyo bo iriongit ijo?: what are you carrying on your shoulder? ariongar: to carry away on the shoulder. airioniar ki-o to become black, dark.airionokin ki-a to put or do crosswise; to put horizontally, put obstacles in the way. airionokin amisirin: to plough across the slope. airionokin akito togo: to put struts or rafters crossways or horizontally in the house. airionut1 (singular noun F) darkness; blackness. airionut2 ki-o to be black, dark. iryono akware na: it is very dark tonight. iryoko Iteso; Imusugun ekwangak: the Iteso are black people; Europeans are white. airior ki-o to go to search for; to go to look for. erio ngesi amerekekin akan ngin: she/he went that way looking for the sheep. airioronut1 to be talkative, inclined to talk much airioronut2 (singular noun F) talkativeness; chattering. airip1 ki-o to come slowly; to fall slowly (as of tree or anything). airipokin: to come or go slowly to. iripuneneete itunga luka Acowa okison loko Ocorimongin: the people from Acowa (in Kapelebyong county in Katakwi) come slowly (often sleeping on the way) to Ocorimongin cattle market in Usuk county. airip2 to follow, come to, go after, go together, or to go in a crowd.airip3 (of liquids) to sip a little; to draw a little water from a tap. korip adijon kolot: sip a little beer, and go on. aripokin: to sip somewhere or for something. airipun ki-o to come to a place in the evening (with the hope of sleeping). ai bo iripunito yesi?: where are you coming to this late? (implication: there is no room for you here). airiri ki-a to cut round; to cut into strips; to circumcise; to cut to shape. to walk along, go along the edge or along a wall; to go along a boundary or shore; to pass near. airirikin ki-a to put or place near. kiririk ekonitogo moru ngol: build your house near that rock. to be near; to border on; to be opposite. airirim ki-a to drive or lead a big herd of cattle or crowd of people; to round up cattle or people. airirior ki-a to sidle about; to walk past, but near (an object). airiritoi ki-a to go about searching for (anything) in a sly way; to look for (anything) surreptitiously. iriritoi ngesi ajonio: she/he goes surreptitiously looking for free beer.airitit ki-a to be sitting together in a crowd; to be crowded together (of men or anything); to be many. irititiete itunga kore ka ejakait: crowds of people are gathered at the chief’s home. airitokin ki-a to take away; to gather for, collect for or somewhere. airitor ki-o to take away one by one; to carry off one by one. airiun ki-a to allure; to attract, draw towards one, conduce; to pull this way; to suck to hand down; to flap (as of breasts). airiun ajon: to suck beer. airiunun: to pull repeatedly. iriuni: conductive (of an electric conductor). airiyar ki-a to drag away; to pull away, or up; to tug at, or draw away; to induce. to crawl away (as of a sick person); to pull oneself along. abu eong keriyar okelesia: I dragged myself to the cathedral. iriye nges adeka: she/he is dying slowly (the disease is dragging her/him along). airo1 to examine; to look at; to inspect; to oversee; to pore over. eroi ejakait iitaaboi luk’esolo: the chief is examining the tax revenue books. airo amuk: (of raiders) to consult the foreseer (who shuffles sandals) to find whether the raiding excursion will be a success.airo2 to make narrow or arched; to cause shrinkage. airoc to lasso; to trip, catch, tie up. airod to usurp; to appropriate, encroach, cheat, defraud. erodi ngesi itunga: she/he cheats people. airog ki-o to prod with a stick; to open a blockage (as when cleaning a pipe, etc); to hollow out (of boat); to bore holes in to have a sharp pain (anywhere). airogirog epopong: to hollow out the cactus (to make the long drum called emidiiri). airoga (of any living thing) to be dying by wasting or growing thin; to become infirm. airogor ki-o to spear through. airojim ki-a to massacre (or many); to slaughter (of living things); to finish off (of hens by a thief, or of animals by sickness); to destroy; to play havoc with. airojo ki-a to round up (people or animals); to gather together into a trap; to summon. airojoun akituk: to round up cattle. airojoun imirio: to drive rats out of their holes into snares. airok to adapt or copy; to acquire, collect. airok iponesio: to acquire habits. airok iraan: to collect plants. airom ki-a (of throat) to swell or be inflamed. airomar ki-a to become swollen or inflamed.airomirom ki-a to massacre, slaughter, or bite all over; to finish off. abu eris kiromirom akinei ipu: the leopard ate several goats.airong1 ki-a (of fruit) to become ripe; (of weather) to become dark or gloomy; to darken, or become sombre. erongit akwap: the weather is cloudy, gloomy. airong2 to carry with the mouth; to have sticking in the mouth (as of lump of meat or potato, or cigarette) without eating. koinakinai eong da akiring karong: give me also a piece of meat to stick in my mouth. airongakin ki-a (of weather) to become gloomy, dark, or sombre. airop to reward; to award; to pay wages; to recompense; to remunerate or give a present to. airop ikoku: to give a present to a child. aropakin: to pay out for someone else. airoromaara ki-a to be gigantic and very tall. iroromaara ngesi (kesi): she/he/it is (they are) very tall. airot1 ki-a to take two or more together; to do together; to have more than one; to hold two or more at one time. airosit angor: to have two or more wives. airot angor: polygamy; bigamy. airot2 to spy upon; to investigate; to detect, reconnoitre. erosete isirikaalei ere ngol: soldiers are spying on that home. airotakin ki-a to give two; to give double; to put, hold two together. kerotaki eong Eluga ipalei: the Indian trader gave me two pairs of trousers or pants. to be two together; to be in a pair or in two pairs. erotakinos kesi oicolong: they both sat on one chair. airouroun ki-o to become mouldy, dusty, or mildewy. airu1 ki-a to give animals (especially cattle, goats and sheep) water in a trough. airu2 to sound; to make a noise; to crow, or croak; to roar, low, or grunt. aru atenus: the drum has sounded. aru edongot: the bell has rang. eruos aki: the ears are ringing. eruo engatuny, eris, ekokor, emong: the lion roars, the leopard purrs, the cock crows, the bull lows (bellows). airu3 to spit at; to spit out (as of a snake or person). erui emun aimula: the snake spits its venom. airub to settle down (as of sediments); to begin to congeal; to calm down; (of wound) to heal up, join up; to freeze (of water); to remain intact. erubit edula: the granary or store is intact (nothing has been taken out). airuc1 ki-a to do again; to repeat. mam eruci bobo: I shall not do it again.airuc2 to join or mend ropes; to knot (rope). airucakin ki-a to do again; to repeat. airucuruc ki-a to do repeatedly, be redundant; to repeat. mam eong akoto airucuruc akiro: I do not want to repeat what I said. airud ki-a to polish, rub, or buff up. airudakin ki-a to rub on. kirud emeesa: polish the table. airudokin ki-o to prick intentionally with (as with a needle). airudud ki-o to pierce, push in or down (accidentally) (as with a needle or pin). abu ekukwai kirudud akakan: a thorn pierced my hand.airududokin ki-o to pierce, push in. airugag ki-a to encrust; to develop a hunch-back. airugu ki-o to grind a little flour noisily; to make a grinding sound. ingai irugui amoru ngin?: who is grinding there? airugurug: repetition of airugu. airuj to cause to contract; to hit with an arrow; to make narrower; to fold up; to cover over. eruji ngesi emir: she/he is shooting a rat (with an arrow). airuja ki-a to dream; to imagine; to think; to consider; to have a nightmare. aisuruja: to cause dreams; to give one a nightmare. airujakin ki-a to think about; to suspect; to forecast for. airujaruj ki-a to meditate, reflect, consider, or ponder over.airujasit a dream; a nightmare; an imagination; a thought; a sentance.airuk1 ki-o to sing, hum. aloto itunga eiruk: people have gone to dance.erukete angor emaido: the women pound groundnuts. airukaun1 ki-a to bombard with shells (grenades or cannons).irukumit akokor (abeei): the hen is sitting on the eggs. airukutaar ki-a to drive away, throw away, expel; to dismiss, force away (by shouting or beating).airum ajakaanut: to take over power or leadership. erum ngol atapon: he has contracted leprosy. erum nges adeka: she/he has caught a disease. erum nges etida: she/he has become hysterical. erumata nges ileic: she/he is ashamed or shy. erum nges asulyany: she/he is lucky, has a stroke of luck; she/he is fortunate. aisurum: to make to seize; to make to succeed; to make to inherit. aisurum ileic: to make ashamed or disgraced. aisurum adeka: to infect; to give disease; to convey disease. aiturumun: to hand over. airumiar ki-a to appropriate, seize, embezzle; to take possession of. airumit ki-a to possess; to hold, keep, or own; to reign over. irumitos esapat ileic: the boy is ashamed; the boy is shy. airumun ki-a to take possession of; to chase and be at par; to succeed to or to inherit; to take hold of. airumurum ki-a to handle (of anything). kinyek airumurum ikaboro: don’t handle my things.airung ki-o to rest; to have a rest. airungosit a resting place; a stopover. airuny ki-a to urge, incite, encourage; to impel, press; to stimulate, goad, drive to. ejeni etelepat ngol airuny imongin: that boy knows how to drive oxen. airunyakin ki-a to urge for, incite; to drive for, etc.airunyar ki-a to urge away; to jostle, propel, take away quickly; to expedite; to drive away; to cast, goad away, send away; (of a car) to accelerate; to drive fast; to hurry on; to spur. (of a car) to go fast; to accelerate. airunyar akeju: to run fast. airunyun akeju: to come quickly, bring quickly. erunyun amotoka kwap: the car free-wheeled down the hill at great speed. airunyitoi to rush about; to run about, be fussy. irunyitoi ngesi bala edaan akain: she/he rushes about like one who is going to bury a co-wife.airup ki-a to put inside; to insert, or tuck in. eja luirupete akanin oisawon: there are pick-pockets about. airupakin ki-a to insert, push in, stick in, thread through (as thread through eye of the needle or a ring through the nose of an animal). airupar ki-a to push or put through; to push in or tuck in. to wrestle. airupar akonye: to look through a hole. akoto eong airupar kajo: I want to wrestle with you. airupe ki-a to report; to disclose hidden crime; to tell on, tell tales about, be tale-bearer; to be a sneak, a tell-tale; to agitate. irupei ijo: you are an agitator (reporter). airupeanut ki-a to be fond or inclined to duplicity or double-standards.airupurup ki-a to push in or into (as of potato into fire).airuru ki-o to plunder, steal; to raid, rob; to burn quickly or for a short time; to burn something very quickly; to roast quickly. kiruruoto emaido ngol: quickly roast those groundnuts. airuruakin ki-a to eat a little; to sip a little; to snatch a little food; to have a snack.airurum ki-a to sound in a deep voice; to groan; to grumble, rumble, roar, growl, purr, thunder, murmur, or buzz. irurumai akuj: it thunders.e. make a high-pitched sound once. airurumakin ki-a to throw at (of anything), pelt with. airurumaun: to throw this way or down. to fall down from. airurwo ki-o to raid; to plunder; to pillage and ransack. airurwokin ki-o to help in a raid; to raid for; to plunder somewhere. airurwonut1 fondness of plundering, stealing, or robbing. airurwonut2 ki-o to be fond of or inclined to rob. airut1 ki-a to dismiss, expel, or send away; to discard, reject; (of a car driver) to drive fast. airut2 to uproot, pull up by the roots, or force out. karusi eong etengei: hunger is tugging at my entrails. airutakin ki-a to fling at or down (as of a stone); to drive towards somebody; to throw at; to throw down with a thud. airutar ki-a to drive away, throw away, expel; to dismiss, force away (by shouting or beating).ai bo iruturuteete itunga?: where are people running to? airwa to wear on shoulder (as of a blanket or sheet); to put (clothing) on over the shoulder. airwad to make dirty; to dirty. airwairwa ki-a to besprinkle; to bedew; to spray. airwairwa apua: to lay the dust by sprinkling water (of rain) to drizzle. airwait a drizzle.airwak ki-a to blink; (of eyes) to wink. airwak akonye: to blink eyes. airwakakin1 ki-a to blink at somebody or something. airwakakin2 to overlook. arwakak eong ekakalaamu: I overlooked my pencil (did not notice it, though it was there). airwakirwak ki-a to keep blinking eyes; to riddle with holes. airwana ki-a to multiply; to do multiplication. irwana atipet: once. irwana aare: twice; double. irwana akany: five times. irwana ipu: many times; often. kirwanaata 2 ka 2: multiply 2 by 2. airwang to bite painfully; to sting.airwap ki-a to give a hard blow; to box; to beat, club. airwap akit: to slap the ear.airwat ki-a to plaster (a wall). irwasi ngesi etogoke: she/he is plastering her/his house. airwatakin: to plaster on, throw mud on (the wall). airwet to pull off (as of button of shirt or anything); to snap at; to tear bits off something; to snatch, pull off, seize hastily. abu emir korwet emukule: the rat tore bits of the hide. kolot airwet anya: go and pull the grass (from the roof). arwetar: to pull away, snatch away, snap away; to disrupt. airwodorwod ki-o to prod in vain, prick in vain (as one looking for a jigger). airwoirwo ki-o to become mouldy; to become mildewy. airwopokin ki-o to become empty (of stomach or tyre).airyan to be on fire; to be ablaze.airyear ki-a to grind into bits or smithereens. airyoronut ki-o to be talkative; to be garrulous. ais (singular noun F) open uninhabited area; the wilderness or bushes. aisa1 a perfume (cologne, essence, incense, scent). aisa2 to have a nice smell; to be fragrant; to smell sweetly; to have a nice odour; to be odoriferous. eur ngesi saa: she/he smells nicely. aisa3 to nurse; to rear a child. aisa idwe: to rear or take care of children; to baby-sit. esae akokor ikemiyoi: the hen is feeding its chicks. aisab to exceed the measure; to give too much. aisab akiro: to tell a lie; to fib; to lie.aisac to forsake; to refrain from (sexual intercourse); to leave alone, desert, abandon, renounce, or reject; to avoid; to get fed up with. atemonon esacit okilenike: a woman who has just given birth refrains from sexual intercourse. asac akokor ngin akebeei kodula: that hen has abandoned its eggs in the granary. aisag ki-a to thrust thorns or pointed objects on or into; to treat roughly. aisagakin ki-a to give rough treatment. apotu isirikaalei kisagakis Yesu aboko naka ikukwa: the guards pressed the crown of thorns on Jesus’ head. aisagisag ki-a to tie loosely, slacken (as of something well-tied).aisagisagun ki-o to get loose; to slacken. aisak to reap, harvest, or cut millet or sorghum.aideng emaido: to harvest groundnuts. aikur acok arai emuogo: to harvest potatoes or cassava. aisal to be missing; to be absent from; to be left over; to play truant; to abide, remain, survive, or stay away. esalit ngesi ore: she/he remained at home.aisam ki-a to prickle, itch (like nettles), or to smart (the popular word used is aisamisam). aisamisam ki-a to prickle, itch (like nettles), or to smart; to eat sour vegetables (especially emalakang) without groundnut or simsim sauce. aisang to end, come to an end, terminate, or culminate; to cease, conclude, or close.aisany ki-a to tease or fluff (as of cotton)aisanyakin kwap ki-o (of a shabby, decrepit or ragged person) to fall down. aise1 to pick out or select; to choose; to sort out; to elect. aise epaaba: to sort cotton. aise ikur kobaale: to segregate; to be unfair; to be biased (literally, to pick out maggots from mushrooms). komam aise ikur kobaale: without discrimination or segregating; at random. aise2 to stretch out a skin to dry; to peg out a skin or hide. aise emukule: to peg out an animal skin or hide to dry.aiseer ki-a to cheat; to deceive. aiseer iboro igwelanari: (of a trader) to cheat buyers by underweight or not filling to capacity. aisej ki-a (used with plural object) to provoke into a quarrel or a fight (through bad acts or harsh words). aisej einer: to incite or provoke with bad language. aisejakin ki-a (used with singular or plural object) to provoke, vex, affront, aggravate, anger, annoy, chafe, or enrage by words or actions. aisejakin akiro: to provoke someone with harsh language. aisek to pick, select, choose, or take out of.aisekek ki-a to beg (like a dog – with paws up); to stand outside (like a beggar); to humble oneself. ibusakinit oni aisekek kakonye Edeke: we should humble ourselves before God (stand like beggars). aisekel ki-o to mock or ridicule (as by putting out tongue, telling off in public, or any other way). inyo bo kisekelio ijo eong?: why do you ridicule me?aisekelikin ki-o to disappoint; to refuse (with some boasting or bragging involved); to put to shame. kesekeliki ngesi eong: she/he said she/he could do without me, i.e. she/he has told me off.aisekelonut1 mockery; derisiveness; ridicule; contempt. aisekelonut2 to be fond of mocking or putting someone to shame. aisekelor ki-a to show off, mock at, grouse at, insult. isekelor ijo akonibar: you show off your riches. aisekisek ki-a to lash with the tongue; to browbeat; to tell off (a beggar); to mock (a beggar). ‘ekot Iteso kimurokis nuka aitaraun eong ekirigi kec karai mam kesi epedorete aitac eong,’ ebala je isekelo: the Iteso should forget the idea of making me a prime minister if they cannot pay for my services, he told them off. aisen to deal a heavy blow; to thump. aiseny to be or become thin; to lose weight; to grow thin or lean; to be emaciated; (of body) to wither or be meagre. aisi1 (of grain) to germinate; to sprout or take root. aisi2 to escape secretly; to run away; to disappear; to abscond. asiata ipakasin: the porters have run away. aisial ki-a to badger, harass, bother, hector, or harry; to pain, pester, scold, persecute, or to blister. kesial eong amusenu: the hoe blistered me.aisialar ki-a to blister. kesial eong aswam na: this work distresses me (or is painful).aisialasit a blister; an irritation, pique, displeasure, distress. aisiba ki-a (of Muslims) to fast or abstain from food; to do without food (for religious reasons). aisibak ki-a (causative verb) (to cause) to line up; to put in line, abreast. aisiboikin ki-a (causative verb) to seat; to cause to sit down. aisicakun akiro ki-a (causative verb) to get somebody into trouble; to bring trouble upon. aisicaset an anchor; a support; a prop. aisicasit ki-a (causative verb) to strengthen; to confirm. esicasit eong nuinera ngesi: I confirm (what she/he says) her/his statement. aisicat ki-a (causative verb) to educate; to confirm; to strengthen, fortify, or consolidate. aisidel ki-a to make, to cause to show off, etc; to display or tantalize to. aisidel akanin: to manicure. aisidelel ki-o (causative verb) to make conspicuous; to expose. aisididiar ki-a (causative verb) (of troops, an instrument, etc) to penetrate very deep into. aisidik ki-o (causative verb) to make to be thick; to thicken; to make matters worse; to intensify. aisidik akiro: to make matters worse. aisidik ki-o to make a person to drink much. aisidony ki-o to pound fine; (of cattle, goats, sheep, etc) to ruminate, chew the cud. akiteng isidonyi inyamat: the cow ruminates its food. aisidony emuogo: re-pound cassava, to grind fine. aisidoun ki-o to help a woman deliver. aisidounet maternity; labour ward; delivery room.aisieb epaaba: to cut away the old cotton stalks. aisiebanar ki-a to keep slashing off; to chop off much. aisiebunun atap ki-a to take big lumps of posho or bread. aisiec ki-a to exchange, barter; to give tit for tat; to pay in kind, barter. aisiej akiro ki-a to be rude, impolite; to use rough language.aisiejun akiro ki-a to speak sharply; to rant, storm, insult. akiro nukisiejuna: rough, impolite, insulting language. aisiep ki-a to go through high grass (where there is no path). auta eong aisiep: I am going through the high grass. isiepi ngesi kais: she/he walks through the tall grass. aisiepakin1 ki-a to put something in the high grass; to throw, build in the high grass. inyo bo isiepakinia ekonitogo nen?: why do you build your house there in the wilds? aisiepakin akonye: to look askance at. aisiepakin2 ki-o to fall into high grass; to drop in high grass. aisig ki-a to have a hiccup; to jam or wedge often. isigi ngesi noi: she/he has a terrible hiccup. aisigakin1 ki-a to shut door with rubbing noise. aisigakin2 ki-o to get stuck suddenly. esigakin emeleku okomyo: the plough got suddenly stuck in a tree stump. esigakin bian akosimotoka orit: our car got stuck in the mud yesterday. aisigakin kwap: to be grounded (of ship or car, unable to move). aisigakinet a hitch; a glitch; a minor malfunction; a setback. aisigal ki-a (causative verb) to help, assist, take part in, share (work); to give a helping hand. aisigalikin ki-a (causative verb) to assuage, alleviate, mitigate, lessen; to relieve, soothe, ease, palliate, or moderate; to help (in work). konyam idia yen kisigalikinor etengei: eat this little food to alleviate your hunger. kocakakinai idiodapaic kesigalikinor aterot: give me some old piece of cloth (rag) to lessen the cold. emamei yenikesigalikit eong aswam: there is nobody to give me a helping hand with my work. aisiganar to have a persistent hiccup. aisigar ki-a to have a hiccup (once only). aisigeg ki-a to cause, bring astringency or constipation. aisigir ki-a (causative verb) to cause to refuse, deny, object, etc; to cause to fail, to be unsuccessful, difficult. aisigira ki-a to move slowly, lazily (by intention); to be sluggish (in movement); to show unwillingness by slow movement. aisigirokin ki-a (causative verb) to make to resist, to be hard. aisigirokin elopet bon: to deny oneself. aisiguikin ki-a (causative verb) to scandalise; to make to stumble. aisiig ki-a to wager as a guarantee of payment; to mortgage. aisiigakin ki-a to mortgage to; to give as security for a debt (especially in gambling). aisiigaun ki-a to get as mortgage from; to receive as security for a debt (especially in gambling). aisiilior ki-o to make unconscious or put under anaesthetics. aisiiloor ki-o (causative verb) to cause to suffocate; to stun; to give anaesthetics to. aisiilooret anaesthesia. aisiinaun ki-a to make moist; dampen; make mouldy. aisiir ki-a (causative verb) to give to taste.alosi eong aisiir ijo ekabela: I am going to make you taste my cane (give you a beating). aisiiraar ki-a (causative verb) to inform, warn, acquaint; to let know; to notify; to cause to hear. aisiiraaret a message; a communiqué; a note, letter, missive; a memorandum; notation.aisiiria ki-a (causative verb) to make dizzy, giddy; to swing round, drive round; to make frivolous. kesiiriai eong esigala: smoking makes me giddy, dizzy. aisiiriar ki-a to spin round. aisiirikin ki-a (causative verb) to inform, communicate, let known, notify.aisiiraar aisiit1 (singular noun F) pains of prolonged childbirth; prolonged labour. aisiit2 ki-o to cause to need, desire or long for. aisiitikin ki-a (causative verb) to remind someone; to cause someone to remember; to prompt somebody. aisiitikin itunganan iponesio luajokak: to remind a person of good manners or etiquette. aisiitoor ki-a (causative verb) to remind of something in the past; to cause to reminisce. aisiitun ki-a (causative verb) to remind; to jog your memory. aisiiya ki-a to fizz; to fizzle; to steam food; to exhaust through working long. aisiiyakinet a crust of bread; a simmering.aisijenikin ikoku ki-a (causative verb) to humour a child; to pamper a child. aisijoga ki-a (causative verb) to excite, incite, provoke, urge on, kindle; to fluster, churn, agitate. aisijopijop ki-o (causative verb) to gradate, rank, or classify.aisik aki: to block ears; to play deaf. isikik ngol aki: he is deaf. aisik amopiira: to inflate a tyre. aisika ki-a to threaten, hesitate to slap; to feign a slap or a blow. abu ngesi kesikaa eong: she/he feigned to strike me. aisikaar ki-a to threaten or feign to beat; to hesitate. aisikaar alimun akiro: to refrain from saying anything. esikaasi kesi etelepat ngol: they threatened to beat that boy. aisikad ki-a (causative verb) to lessen, make less, or make insufficient. aisikadikin ki-a (causative verb) to make less for; to bargain; to pay less. aisikakin ki-a to stamp down (as of cotton in bag); to ram in, block, inflate. kisikak ekagaali: inflate the tyre of my bicycle. esikakit eong aola eporoto: I am hoarse from a cough to be blocked. esikakinos eong ikumes: my nose is blocked (due to flu). aisikamun ki-a (causative verb) to infect; to make to catch. aisikamun ileic: to make ashamed.aisiket a bicycle pump.aisikin ki-a to allow; to permit. aisikisik ki-a to press down very hard, pump up hard; to beat up with closed fists thoroughly. kisikisik akamopiira: pump my tyre hard. aisikun ki-a to press down; to hold back, halt.aisikwarun ki-a (causative verb) to revive someone else (from fainting or exhaustion). aisikweny ki-a (causative verb) to cause to warn; to cause to wake up; to cause to remain awake. aisil ki-a to whistle. aisilakin ki-a to forbid, stop from doing; to whistle at, catcall. kisilak idwe aponenen ne tai: forbid the children from coming here without reason. aisilar ki-a to consider bad; to abstain from; to stop doing; to resolve never to do a thing again; to be sorry for; to repent; to abominate. esila eong akaronusio: I am sorry for my sins. aisilel ki-a (causative verb) to make happy, gladden, animate, cheer up, console; to make a proper drain; to drain properly. kitelel aleles ejok: make a proper drain.aisiliil ki-a (causative verb) to cause to swing round.aisililing ki-a (causative verb) to hush; to silence, muffle, or suppress; to mute, stifle, or deaden. aisilit ki-a to make up one’s mind not to; to make a rule not to. esilit eong alosit ngina: I made up my mind never to go there. aisiloc ki-o to juggle; to tie crosswise. aisilok ki-o (causative verb) to help to redeem; to help to pay back; to cause to redeem. aisilokin1 ki-o to have in between; to hide in between, or on to disappear in or between things; to hide between. abu eong kesilok ekakalaamu toma onya: I threw my pencil into the high grass. esilokin akakwara toma okitwi: my pen dropped in the bush (and disappeared). aisilokin2 ocor ki-o to disappear in the water (to drown); to dive. aisilokony ki-a to cause entanglement; to cause confusion, disorder. aisilolony ki-a (causative verb) to disable; to disqualify. aisim ki-a to perspire, sweat, swelter. aisimaar ki-a to approve, agree, take fancy to; to like, be pleased with; to compliment, congratulate, extol, or eulogise. aisimaaret a compliment; a congratulation; an eulogy, commendation, endorsement, praise, tribute, homage, panegyric, or honour. aisimam ki-a to be a waiter or waitress; to serve at table or to wait upon (at table).aisimik ki-a (causative verb) to prevent; to cause to refuse; to ban. kesimik eong adeka ainyam: sickness prevents me from eating. aisiminun ki-o (causative verb) to lure, attract, entice, or seduce. aisimisim ki-a (of the body) to have goose flesh; to begin to perspire; to begin to sweat (beads of perspiration breaking out). aisimon ki-o (causative verb) to satisfy, assure, appease, or content. aisimonikin ki-a (causative verb) to satisfy with food or anything; to convince somebody; to satisfy, assure, appease, or content. kisimonik ijo eong: you have convinced me, satisfied me. aisimorikikin ki-a (causative verb) to reconcile, bring together or patch up in a relationship. aisinapikin ki-o (causative verb) to appease; to placate; to settle. aisinepun ki-a (causative verb) to kindle a fire; to start a fire; to set alight or ablaze; to fire up (a car), i.e. to accelerate. enepu einer: the conversation is getting hot; they are quarrelling. eneput akiro: matters are becoming serious. inepunit ejakait kore: the chief is raging at his home.aisiner ki-a (causative verb) to cause to talk; to seduce; to engage somebody; to betroth; to woo; to persuade. aisiner apese: to ask a girl for marriage or fornication; to court a girl; to betroth; to woo. aisinerikin ki-a (causative verb) to intercede for; to pray for; to seduce for somebody; to arrange for. aisinerikin apese: to seduce a girl for somebody. aisinga ki-a to deal blows; to thump (many times, often). kesinga bian ejakait eong: my husband thumped me up yesterday.aisingaren ki-o (causative verb) to push forward, cause to lead, promote, make one the leader. aisingaun ki-a to deal a heavy blow; to beat once only. aisingaunun ki-a to deal heavy blows; to thump many times, often. kesingaununit bian ejakait eong: my husband thumped me up yesterday. aisingoror ki-o to deprive; to cause loss of; to cause to miss. aisinokokin ki-a (causative verb) to cause to put on fire; to cause a fire. aisinye ki-o to become greedy, stingy, selfish. aisinyeonor ki-o to become greedy, stingy, selfish. aisinyeonut1 greed; voracity; selfishness; stinginess; avarice. aisinyeonut2 ki-o to be greedy, selfish, stingy, avaricious. aisinyikokin ki-a (causative verb) to encourage; to make persevere; to urge on, goad on; to prod or spur on; to cause to become worse (suffering, etc). esinyikoki emuudu Ikaramoja aingat: the gun has encouraged Karimojong to raid. aisiok ki-a to go early; to be early; to do early. kisiok atan: go early to the well. kisiok ore: go home early.aisiokun ki-a to come early; to wake up early.aisiol ki-o (of a person) to rape (criminal and forceful carnal knowledge); to force a woman to have sexual intercourse against her will. esiol esapat loka ikar 30 amojong naka ikar 52: a man of 30 rapes a woman aged 52. aisiom1 to read (a book, etc); to school. aisiom2 to talk behind someone’s back; to slander; to backbite; to disparage; to malign. aisioni ki-o to give, distribute to many; to forgive (one or many), pardon; to have pity on; to have mercy on, absolve. aisioni aronusio: to forgive sins. esionie eong luk’ican ikaboro: I distribute my things to the poor. kisionioi eong aronusyoka: forgive my sins.aisionikin ki-a to give to out of pity; to give alms; to donate, distribute to; to give, present to; to pardon or have mercy on. kisionikinai eong da idinyamat: give me also a little food.aisip to deal a blow; to put into the ground (as of poles); to erect, set up, put up. aisip epur: to give a heavy blow in the back; to hit somebody in the back. aisip etogo: to start a new house by putting in the poles; to build a foundation.aisipan ki-a to be many; to have a gathering; to meet together; to crowd together; to be in a crowd; to flock together. isipanitos ikweny: the birds flock together. isipanitos ijaka oreka: many chiefs have gathered at my house. aisipaper ki-o (causative verb) to befriend; to make a friend; to court, woo, allure, or attract. aisipej ki-a (causative verb) (of the host) to entertain visitors; to host visitors to a party. aisipej ipejok: to host visitors. aisipiran ki-a (causative verb) to go in crowds. isipiranitos itunga agwelanaret: a crowd of people went to the market. aisir1 ki-a to adorn, wear, or cover oneself with (not with cloth, but with ornaments); to decorate; to embellish. isirit nges imidaalin akuwan: she/he adorns herself/himself with medals. aisir2 ki-a to knead bread with a mingling stick (where a little more than enough flour was added); to press together; to trample, ram. ingai kebuni ameikin akituk aisir akamana?: who brought cows to trample my garden?aisirab ki-a (causative verb) to accuse; to summon to court; to make talk. aisirakin ki-a to make hard for;
