to stamp hard for; to trample for. aisirereng ki-a (causative verb) to bless; to make lucky; to wish luck to. aisiriam ki-a (causative verb) to go to meet (and say welcome or to help to carry luggage); to cause to meet; to cause to clash or comflict. aisiriamikin ki-a (causative verb) to cause to meet with, put together, about; to cause to surround; to surprise. abu eong kesiriamik ikokolak ejengete ekamong: I caught the thieves skinning my bull. aisiriamun ki-a (causative verb) to cause to come upon; to cause to encounter or to face. aisiric ki-a to spout; to spit or spew often. emoru loisirici ekuron kede akim: an active volcano. aisiricaar ki-a to spout away; to spit or spew through the teeth. aisiricikin ki-a to inject or ejaculate; to spit at somebody. aisiridikin ki-a (causative verb) to cause to die; to cause to expire. aisirieb ki-a (causative verb) to cause pain or sorrow; to hurt, inflict pain, or to cause to be painful. aisiriengun ki-a (causative verb) to startle or to frighten; to take aback; to discomfit; to excite, foment trouble, thrill.aisirim ki-o (causative verb) to cause to go round; to wind up (as of gramophone player); to whirl; to swing round. aisirimet something to turn with; a hinge; a spindle; a gyroscope; a handle of a gramophone. aisirimikin ki-o (causative verb) to turn round; to wind up (as of gramophone player); to whirl. aisirion ki-o (causative verb) to besmirch; to make black or dirty; to disapprove. aisisia1 (singular noun F) education; teaching and learning; enlightenment. aisisia2 ki-a to study; to learn; to imitate; to mimic. isisiai ngesi Agereesan: she/he is learning English. isisiaete idwe engwalas: the children are imitating the lame man. aisisiakin ki-a to show or try (not of things); to point out to; to teach once, acquaint with; to lecture. kisisiakinai eong ekosio ngol: teach me that song.aisisianakin ki-a to teach, coach, or instruct; to show often; to point out often; to preach; to educate. aisisiar ki-a (of road, braches) to split into two; (of road) to fork out; to junction, spread out (as of a tree branch). aisisias a school classroom; a lecture room.aisisiaun1 (singular noun F) edification; enlightenment. aisisiaun2 ki-a to learn for oneself; to learn something by asking or studying. adau eong aisisiaun Agereesan: I have learned or I have known English. aisita ki-a (causative verb) to hire; to employ labour.aisiwotokin ki-o (causative verb) to push further away (of anything); to push a little forward or aside. aisiya1 ki-a (of carbonated liquid) to fizz, bubble, or effervesce; (of bread, potato on fire) to fizzle; to frizzle. aisiya2 ki-a to bear patiently; to starve; to go a long time without food; to bear hunger bravely.aisiyal ki-a (causative verb) to entertain or amuse; to humour; to cause delight or pleasure to. aisiyala bon: to amuse yourself. aisiyalaet amusement; entertainment; recreation; fun. aisiyalamikin ki-a (causative verb) to gratify, congratulate, acclaim; to please; to humour; to thank; to cause delight or pleasure to. aisiyalongong ki-o (causative verb) to disquiet; to cause to worry; to grieve, make anxious, long for, etc. aisiyap ki-a (causative verb) to delay, defer. aisiyapaar ki-a (causative verb) to cause to slow up; to cause delay. aisiyekaar ki-a (causative verb) to make to go away; to remove, carry away; to disperse, push forward. aisiyengun ki-a (causative verb) to cause to retire from work; to relieve from tension; to suspend or lay off (from work); to give a holiday; to give a rest to; to cause to rest. aisiyuun ki-a (causative verb) to cause to believe; to persuade, entice; to cause to get saved, i.e. to cause to accept some Christian teaching or doctrine; to cause to accept jesus christ as a saviour. aisobwa ki-a to make use of the eisobwa (fishing basket) in fishing (moving it in and out of water). kesobwai eong akou: I have got a throbbing headache. aisod to begin, start, commence. kasodoto alosit: let us start off on our journey. aisogo ki-o to catch fish by repeatedly plunging down a bottomless basket (eisobwa) at random. isogoete ikiliok ibilenga: the men are catching catfish with iisobwan baskets. aisok ki-o to arrest progress; to halt; to desist from; to die out; to stop doing, going, leaving off; to discontinue. mam lolo edou esoki: the rain will not stop today. aisokisok ki-o to leap (as of a bull). aisokok ki-o to hold the hand ready to grasp something; to be on the point of catching. aisokor ki-o (of rain) to clear up; to cease raining (going to stop, leave off); (of white ants) to stop swarming. esoko edou: the rain has stopped. esokosi ikong aimin: the white ants have stopped flying out. aisokot ki-a to twist (rope, etc); to roll tobacco. aisokot etaba: to roll tobacco in leaves or paper for smoking. isokotaete amojongik esigala: the old women roll tobacco for smoking. aisolet a black-and-white weaverbird, Masked weaver. aisolimod ki-o (of a gap in the teeth) to be very wide. isolimodot angaarany: the gap (in the teeth) is very wide. aisom to dance; to jump up and down; to bounce. esomete itelepai edisiko: the boys are dancing disco music. aisongolaar ki-a to go somewhere in vain. aisongolanut ki-a to go or do in vain. aisoni ki-o (used with plural objects) to give as a present; to forgive, pardon, spare, or excuse. kisonioi aronusyoka: forgive my sins. kisonioi: forgive me. aisonikin ki-o to present to; to give to; to forgive. kisonikinai adikiring: give me a little meat. aisonio (singular noun F) forgiveness; pardon; amnesty; mercy; pity.aisonionut2 ki-o to be lenient, forgiving aisonyaikin ki-a (of behaviour or dress) to become ancient or outdated. aisonyaikit ki-a to be ancient or belonging to the far past; to be archaic or outdated. aisorir ki-o to desist from, cease doing, forbear. akoto eong ainom nges konye abu kesorir: I wanted to beat her/him, but I desisted. (note: not followed by infinitive of verb). aisorit1 a circular mark on the skin due to ringworm, eczema, or syphilis. aisorit2 a snake venom (poison). aisosolikin ki-o to overreach, surpass, outdo, or outsmart. aisosolo ki-o to try the impossible.aisosolonut1 (singular noun F) self-confidence; self-importance; pretentiousness. aisosolonut2 ki-o to be too daring, too self-reliant, too self-confident; to be too overbearing. aisoswa ki-a to pretend not to know; (of groundnut plants) to fail to bear seeds. isoswakit lolo emaido okaru lo: the groundnuts harvest is poor this year.aisoswakinet a snack; a bite of food. aisotoikin ki-o to look like the roof of a granary; to look like an umbrella; to look like a hat. aisu to hiss; to make a hissing sound, louder than aisiar. aisuar ki-a to hiss at; to fart away. aisub to make or to do; to create; to mould; to form, or to shape. aisub amoti: to mould pots. asubit bala: to pretend, behave like, or resemble; to look like. esubit ngesi bala etyang: she/he is like an animal. esubit bala nyo?: what does it look like? esubit ngesi bala ngai?: whom does she/he resemble (look like)? (the answer can only be followed by a noun, not a pronoun). emong losubet: the sacrificial bull. esubitai ka: it consists of; it is composed of. aisuburaar ki-a to bring trouble; to put in a fix; to urge someone away. aisuburiar ki-a to urge on; to force away; to command, impel, goad, compel, hurry on; to harass, importune to be urged on; to be commanded, impelled, compelled, hurried on, importuned. aisuburikin ki-a (causative verb) to make to hurry; to hasten; to push on; to goad on, urge forward; to force. esuburiki ejakait adeka kwapekwana: my husband has been taken ill just now. aisud1 ki-o to shove in (anything); to plunge a fishing spear in water (in the hope of spearing a fish). kisud acok toma akim: plunge sweet potatoes in the fire. aisud akiro: to speak nonsense. aisud agaria: to spear fish randomly. aisud2 to mix; to knead together; to intermingle. aisud akiria: to mix malt, yeast and water in the preparation of beer. aisud emaido: to mix groundnut paste and water in the preparation of sauce. aisude ki-o to push over; to upset, overturn, or upend. aisuded ki-o to stand on the head; to be upside-down (of objects); to bend down very low. isudedei amot: the pot is upside-down. isudedei amatapaalit: the brick is not horizontal, not spirit-levelled. aisudeor ki-o to upset; to tip, turn or push over to topple over; to fall down; to turn a somersault. aisudokin ki-a to push inside; to force into. isudokini lokatatan asuat akim: the blacksmith thrusts the iron into the fire to force oneself into or amongst; to intrude or gatecrash. aisudonokin ki-a to accuse falsely; to accuse at random (rightly or wrongly). aisudun ki-o to speak at random; to say something not to the point; to assert suddenly, unreasonably; to do accidentally. mam eong esudunit ngun: I am not saying this at random (without reason). aisuduny ki-a (causative verb) to put close together; to put near one another. aisudunyikin ki-a (causative verb) to put close together; to arrange. kisudunyinik itelepai: put the boys near each other. aisudup ki-o (causative verb) to reduce to powder; to pulverise or grind fine; to grind again.aisudupuk ki-o (causative verb to grind finer; to pulverise. kisudupuk akiria: grind the flour fine.aisudupukoor ki-o (causative verb to grind finer. kisudupukoo akiria: grind the flour fine.aisuguikin ki-a to scandalise; to make to stumble. aisuguikinet a stumbling block. aisugul ki-a (causative verb) (of a man) to flirt with a woman with no intention of marrying; to make love to; to court or woo. aisugulokin ki-a (causative verb) to make round (as of a pot); to make to bulge. kojie amot kisugulok akoik: make the pot round (bulge out) to make round or pregnant (a woman).aisuguranut1 (singular noun F) sluggishness; slowness; unwillingness; reluctance. aisuguranut2 ki-a to show unwillingness by slow movement; to be phlegmatic; to be slow; to be sluggish; to show reluctance aisujaar ki-a to take away; to take at random. aisuk1 to leap, jump, dance, or hop. aisuk2 (of body) to be bent up, stooped (as of an animal mounting another).aisuk3 to bend, fold, or crumple. aisukuny ki-a to push near; to put near; to draw near; to shift near; to move near. aisukunyaar ki-a to push away; to put away; to draw away; to shift away (from speaker); to remove; to take away (causative verb) to cause to move away; to move something or someone away. aisukunyikin ki-a to move near to; to push near to; to draw near to; to shift near to; to put near to; to promote to be move near to; to be removed. aisukunyikin akeju: to move away stretched legs. aisukunyun ki-a to welcome a visitor; to greet or receive a guest. aisukunyun ipejok: to welcome guests. aisukunyuun ki-a to pull near; to draw near; to shift this way (towards speaker); to bring near; to befriend. aisulyanyikin ki-a to be fortunate, lucky with; to be blessed with, prosperous in. kasulyanyiki eong adumun ijo kane: I am lucky to find you here. aisumun ki-a (causative verb) to promise; to pledge; to assure.aisumunet a promise; a pledge; an assurance.aisuny ki-a to hasten; to be quick; to hurry; to do quickly; to sniff up. aisuny ekume: to sniff up. aisunyakin ki-a to do quickly; to do something in a hurry; to prepare quickly. kisunyak atap kanyamata: cook some bread quickly so that we eat. aisunyar ki-a to do in a hurry; to do quickly; to hasten. kisunyas emaido ngol aipac: shell that groundnuts quickly. aso ekileng lo kisunyariata aijeng emong: here is a knife for you to hurry up skinning the bull. aisunyit ki-o to do hurriedly; to do quickly. isunyit ngesi ainyam bala ekingok: she/he eats quickly like a dog. mam idwe isunyito aikamun akiro: the pupils are slow in understanding. (imperative: kisunyite; plural kisunyitosi: hurry up). aisunyun ki-a to improvise (anything). aisup1 ki-a to woo; to flirt; to take a fancy to (a person); to cuddle. aisup2 (of a dog) to look for; to track down; to ferret out; to seek (by smell). esupi ekingok etyang: the dog is sniffing up the animal’s scent. aisupar ki-a to woo away, enamour, infatuate. sirikisupaa apese ngin: do not woo away that girl. to elope; to be enamoured with. aisupu ki-a (causative verb) to make many; to cause to be many. ekoto ikoku ngin aisupu akiro: that child wants to make many excuses. aisupun ki-a to attract; to allure (as boy and girl); to do amorously; to woo for oneself. aisur1 (of cereal plants) to flower; to grow seed; to begin to ripen (of cereals). aisur2 to attack, hit, and scatter; to put to flight. abu eong kasur ikokolak: I scattered the thieves. aisurit an orange weaverbird. aisurukuny ki-a (archaic) to approach closely; to come near; to follow closely.aisurukunyaar ki-a (archaic) to interrupt (any activity but not speech); cut short (any action but not of speech); to expedite; to hurry on; to make to hum. aisurum ki-a (causative verb) to infect; to shame. aisurum ileic: to embarrass; to make ashamed; to abash. aisurunyaar ki-a to exhort; to cause to go away. aisusu ki-o to defecate (to go to the urinal or toilet); to piss or urinate; to shit; to pass urine or stool. aisusua ki-a to disguise bitter medicine by drinking something sweet; to counteract bitterness. aisusuar ki-a to take away bad taste by eating something sweet; to remove ill-feelings from someone by giving them something pleasant.adum eong etogo isusumai: I found the house on fire or belching smoke. aisusuor ki-o to kill by physical attack. ebungaata kwi je aisusuor: they beat him to death. aisuswaar ki-a to take away bad taste by eating something sweet; to remove ill-feelings from someone by giving them something pleasant.kisut ekia akuwanakon: smear your body with medicine (embrocation). aisut agweeret: to cane someone; to give somebody a serious beating. aisut2 (of in-laws) to come and demand dowry; to claim. aisut apese: to partake of a girl’s dowry. aisutakin ki-a to rub on; to smear on or in; to paint. aisutakin agweeret: to cane; to beat. aisutar ki-a to wipe away or off; to rub off.aisuubus ki-a to trade; to buy and sell. aisuuka a shawl; a bedsheet. aisuulaar1 ki-a to fart or pass wind quietly. aisuulaar2 ki-a to overgrow weeds or bush. isuulaarit ekonire: your homestead is overgrown with bushes. aisuurikin ki-a (causative verb) to let somebody smell or sniff a thing.aisuwa ki-a (of fire) to smoke; (of smoke) to rise. aisuwa ki-a to emit thick smoke. isuwai eketogo: her/his house is belching smoke; her/his house is smoky.aisuwaikin ki-a to fart or pass wind, to blow smoke on somebody or something; to smoke out.aisuwakin etogo: to smoke out a house. aisuwakin atitipu: to smoke out an anthill. aiswag ki-a to rub clean; to rub bright; to polish metal; to scrub hard. aiswag ikel: to brush or clean the teeth. aiswag akuwan: to rub the body (with soap and sponge). aiswagar ki-a to scour or scrub; to clean; to polish a metal object to become clean; to be rubbed off; to be polished. aiswajakin ki-a to put anywhere carelessly; to put something in a dirty place; to dump; to put at random; to put topsy-turvy to commence blindly; to start blindly; to do unprepared; to do blindly (without thinking of the outcome). eswajakin ngol toma akiro: he got himself into trouble (blindly). aiswak to fail; to miss. mam eswaki abunere: she/he will not fail to come. aswakar k’akongu: to have a glimpse at.aiswal to hit or beat with something small but painful. aiswal akiro: to crack a joke; to tell a good joke. aiswal acin: to pass out very stinging wind; to fart terribly. aiswama ki-a to work; to act; to labour to do; to make, fabricate, fashion, or form. aiswama ibore: to go about something; to do something. aiswamakin ki-a to do for; to work for; to labour for; to serve; to make for; to act for. aiswamakin erono: to ill-treat or do bad to; to maltreat. aiswamakin ejok: to do good to; to do a good turn (to repay bad with good actions). aiswamar ki-a to surprise or catch on the wrong footing. eswamar ijo mam iswamat: you have been caught idling or having not worked. aiswamaroroi ki-o to get on with something; to go on doing something. aiswamas a workplace; workshop. aiswamaun ki-a to form, shape, fabricate, mould, fashion for oneself to form itself; to come into being; to shape oneself; to be done. mam iboro kere epedorete aiswamaun bonik: all things do not just happen by themselves (some are made or created). aiswamun ki-a (of a guest) to come suddenly and unexpectedly; to be impromptu; to do or say spontaneously or off the cuff. aiswap ki-a to thatch or cover with grass or with anything to be overgrown with weeds; to look angry or annoyed; (of weather) to be cloudy. aiswapit ki-a to be overgrown. iswapit erot: the footpath is overgrown. aiswec ki-a to exchange, barter; to give tit for tat; to pay in kind, barter.aisweiswe ki-a to drizzle; to spray or shower. aiswet to cut off a little; to strike lightly; to flick or snip. aiswiswiya ki-a to snuffle, snivel. aiswogo ki-o to fish with bottomless basket called eisobwa. aiswola ki-a to fart or pass wind or gas often. aiswolaar: to pass wind or fart once.aiswolol ki-o (of hole or door) to be wide open. aiswop ki-a to look angry; to frown; to be sulky; to be gloomy; to look serious. aisworiswor ki-o to do carelessly or hurriedly. aisya1 ki-a to do for the first time. isyae ngesi alosit naelwana: she/he is going for the first time on a long journey. aisya2 ki-a to make thin; to exhaust, emaciate, wear down (on account of work, worries, etc). isyaunit nges aswam ngin: that work exhausts her/him.aisyaar ki-a to wear down, exhaust, or make thin (with work or worry). aisyaj einer ki-a to retort, quip, or rebut. aisyar ki-a to scatter, disperse, spread, diffuse.aisyarakin akipi: to splash water. aisyarakin iyemuto: to broadcast news; to disseminate to be scattered, dispersed, diffused, dissolved, broadcast.esyarakinos Imusugun akwapin kere: the Europeans are scattered all over the world.esyararos ikakapun kere: all my money has been spent. aisisyarakin: to disperse, squander, waste.aisyaun2 ki-a to begin, start with, commence. esyaunit eong adeka: I feel unwell (i.e. the disease is starting me). to be started. esyaunos itogoi ngul adiopepaarit: those two houses were started on the same day.aisyaunet the beginning; an initiative.aisyepaikin ki-a to be fatty; to be full of fat; to be oily, greasy, fatty. isyepaikinit epege ngol: that pig has grown fat (is full of fat, has developed). isyepaikinit akonikituk: your lips are oily. aisyepokin ki-o to stand aside. aisyom a corruption of aisiom: to read; to backbite; to talk behind one’s back.kita akile: pour out the milk. aita alimonokin: to keep preaching to.aita2 ki-a to work for wages; to work for beer; to do communal work for reward; to dig or cultivate for beer. aita ajon: to work for beer. aitaany ki-a (causative verb) to cause to see; to make to realise. aitaany ican: to cause trouble or problems to. aitaanyikin ki-a (causative verb) to present to; to cause to see; to cause to experience. aitaanyikin ican: to cause to see trouble; to cause trouble to. aitaanyun ican: to cause trouble to. aitaanyun (causative verb) to cause to see, experience, etc; show; point out. aitaar ki-a (causative verb) to make one die; to cause to kill; to tire out. ketaar ngesi eong akwena: she/he makes me tired (die) with laughing. ketaarete eong idwe lu einer: these children will tire me with talking. kinyek aitaar eong etengei: do not let me die (here) of hunger (by delaying me). aitaar ki-a to drink off; to drink in great quantities; to quaff beer. aitab ki-a to walk with a stick; to totter; to dodder; to hobble; to waddle (as of an old person or an infant); to walk by holding a wall (as of a child learning to walk). aitaba ki-a (causative verb) to make soft, wet, loose (as of a tied nut by oiling it); to moisten.aitababa ki-a (causative verb) to make hard; to make difficult. aitabangaanar ki-a (causative verb) to make or cause to be stupid, deaf, foolish, silly, mad, etc.; to make a fool of someone aibangibang k’ekia: to drug a person; to craze.aitabar ki-a (causative verb) to enrich; to make rich or wealthy. aitabaun ki-a to make to dissolve; to make wet; to soak; to moisten; to dampen; to warm up (by adding water). aitabir ki-a to sacrifice; to offer sacrifice. aitac1 ki-a to dance with joy; to exult; to rejoice; to be glad; to jump for joy; to be pleased; to be full of beans. etac ngesi noi: she/he is very pleased. aitac2 to pay; to hire; to repay; to expiate or reward; to remunerate; to refund or disburse; to compensate. kotaci akusipesenin: pay your debts. iboro lutacet: things with which to pay or to return; compensation. aiku aitac esolo: to avoid paying tax. ainac aitac esolo: tax evasion. aitacaanakin ki-a (causative verb) to light up; to enlighten or educate; to please somebody. aitacaikin ki-a (causative verb) to illuminate; to make to shine (for someone); to explain something to someone. aitacamun ki-a (causative verb) to convince; to persuade; to cause to agree. aitacaun ki-a (causative verb) to enlighten (literally); to shine on; to make bright, light; to throw light on; to inform; to instruct. aitacaun akiro: to throw light on a subject. aitacaun etabaasa: to turn the lamp up (for better light); add fuel to fire. iboro kere etacaunos: everything is clear. aitad ki-a to plant (poles of house, etc); to loosely put poles in holes; to put poles in order. kitadataber etogo kopaarete aisik: first put the poles down and then ram the earth round them. aitada ki-a (causative verb) to moisten or to soak; to make wet; to make damp. itada ijo akiria nuekamule?: have you soaked the beer malt?ketadaikis ipejok eong ikanyamat: the visitors have made me finish my food (by cooking for them). aitadakin ki-a to build for somebody; to put up poles (of a house) for somebody or somewhere. aitadasit a frame or structure of something being built. aitadaun ki-a (causative verb) to cause to finish; to end. aitaditada ki-a (of teeth, poles, or anything) to be loose. aitagal ki-a to do carelessly; to put in the way; to place carelessly; not to cultivate or plough deep enough. itagali ijo ikaboro aitagal: you pack my things carelessly. aitagalikin ki-a to hold lightly (with hand); to cultivate lightly; to fasten lightly (as of a nut); not to plant deeply; to leave things about carelessly. aitagalikin akiro: to talk without seriousness or intention to do what one says to be left about carelessly in disorder. aitagior ki-a (causative verb) to beatify; to make holy or saintly. aitagitaga ki-a to be loose (especially of teeth); to toddle. aitagwaikin ki-a (causative verb) to enhance; to add; to increase; to cause. ikoto ijo aitagwaikin eong akiro: you want to cause or add me problems. aitaikin ki-a to do communal work for or somewhere; to pour out (liquids) for. aitajarun ki-a (causative verb) to save; to bring back to life; to revive; to give life or to rescue. ajaru ngesi kotoma kalukatwak: she/he rose from the dead aitak1 ki-a to break down (as of house); to remove plaster from a wall; to remove a scab from a wound; to copy verbatim. aitak etogo: to break down a house. aitak2 to beat; to slap on the ears; to copy; to take off (something fixed). akoto eong aitak ijo akit: I want to slap your ears. kotak akiro ngun: copy those words. aitak ajon: to have a long drink or drag of beer. aitakadanut (singular noun F) disappointment; frustration; disillusionment; cynicism. aitakadikin ki-a (causative verb) to annoy; to vex; to worry; to provoke; to disconcert; to displease; to gall. aitakadikinet annoyance; vexation; worry; trouble; to dig up the floor and level it. kitakitak kwap k’etogokon: dig up the floor of your room and make it level. etakitakata acok apanya: the potatoes have cracked the ground (hence they are ready to be harvested). aitakwang ki-a (causative verb) to bleach; to cheer up; to console; to enliven; to gratify; to comfort. aitalakaaret a gift; solace; a gratuity; relief; a consolation; an amenity. aitalakanut1 (singular noun F) consolation; compassion; condolence. aitalakanut2 ki-a to be consoled or condoled aitalakin ki-a to gamble; to stake money or anything in gambling; to bet. etalakinit eong isirigin elukumit, kinomasi: I stake one thousand shillings, win it; I gamble for one thousand shillings. aitalal ki-a (causative verb) to enlarge; not to partake of; to abstain from; to be taboo. italei ngesi akiring: she/he abstains from meat. etaleete kolo angor abeei: in the past, women used to abstain from eating eggs. kitalee iso ederit kateker kosi: our clan does not eat the meat of a bushbuck (it is believed to cause semi-albinism). aitaleor ki-o to begin to abstain from; to begin to be taboo; to become taboo. akoto eong aitaleor akiring: I want to stop eating meat. aitam to try; to essay; to strive; to attempt; to endeavour; to test; to dare; to perceive; to venture. aitam aswam: to have a go at; to try to do something. atam edou akwap: it rains very heavily or it rains cats and dogs. aitam nuipedori kere: to do your best; to do what you can; to try hard. aitamameun ki-a (causative verb) to abolish; to destroy; to abrogate; to repeal; to cancel; to annihilate. aitamameunet abolition; destruction; abrogation; annihilation. aitamasikin ki-a (causative verb) to cause to rust; to stain or daub; to cause to drink or to absorb. aitamat ki-a (causative verb) to cause to drink; to score a goal (in a game of soccer). aitamwal ki-a (causative verb) to deform; to disable; to impair; to cripple; to make lame.aitan ki-a to feed; to nourish; to rear (children). aitana ki-a (causative verb) to train; to teach; to accustom to; to acclimatise. aitanaikin ki-a (causative verb) to cause to be familiar, etc; to practice; to make accustomed to; to acquaint with; to make used to; to tame; to train. aitanaikin akuwan: to train the body; to do physical training; to take exercise. kitanaik ikonidwe ailip nepe elosete ainyam: teach your children to pray before meals. aitanak ki-a (causative verb) (of a mother) to suckle the young; to give breast milk to a child or the young one. aitanakikin ki-a (causative verb) (like a mother to a child) to suckle for; to give to suck. kitanakik ikoku ekisin: give the child the breast to suck; suckle the child. aitanakin ki-a to feed for somebody; to nurture for; to bring up for; to get food for; to rear for. aitanang1 as far as; until; upto. aitanang Soroti: upto Soroti. aitanang2 ki-a (causative verb) to abolish; to end; to stop; to abrogate. aitanap ki-a (causative verb) to dress somebody else; to adorn or bedeck; to decorate militarily. kitanapata ikusidwe: dress your children. aitanapakin ki-a (causative verb) to pacify; to placate; to mollify.aitanapikin ki-a (causative verb) to dress somebody else; to adorn or bedeck; to decorate militarily. aitang ki-a to perform rites or rituals on children to counter evil. aitangakin ki-a to smear children with a mixture of flour and water for ritual purposes; to perform religious rites. aitangaleun ki-o (causative verb) to heal or cure someone else; to make healthy or to cause to recover. aitangar ki-a to perform rites or rituals to bless the hoe (by throwing grain over it at the traditional shrine – abila) as a sign of the official beginning of the planting season. aitangwal ki-a (causative verb) to deform; to contort; to disable; to make lame or maimed. aitanun ki-a to bring up (to maturity); to adopt; to rear a child; to cater for. aitanun ikoki: to adopt or nurture an orphan. aitanyam ki-a (causative verb) to feed; to give food to; to entertain. aitanyam akiro: to incriminate. aitanyam akonye: to entertain the eyes; to view for pleasure; to admire. aitanyamenen ki-a (causative verb) to cater; to feed often or always; to nourish. aitanyany ki-a (causative verb) to extend; to widen; to enlarge. aitap1 (only used in future tense) to be common; to be usual; to be ordinary; to be customary; to be seen commonly, usually as a rule. (note: for present tense, use atapit. etapit ngesi alosit ore: she/he goes home as a rule). aitap2 to dip lightly; to touch lightly; to touch lightly with the hand; to mop; to dab; to lay (hand on shoulder or head). kotap edia aitap: just dip atap into the vegetables, do not scoop.aitapaar ki-a (causative verb) to lead astray; to mislead; to seduce a girl; to misguide; to cause to go astray; to misuse; to misappropriate funds. aitapaikin ki-a to leave over; to cause to stay; to arrest progress; to stop or halt (a vehicle); to detain; to delay. aitapaikinet a brake; a stop; an impediment; a barrier. aitapakas ki-a (causative verb) to employ for wages or salary. aitapal ki-a (causative verb) to cause to give up; to cause to let go, to concede; to dispense with. aitapalaar ki-a to stop; to cause to neglect; to cause to remain quiet. etapalaa aswam akaisisia: work has caused me to neglect my studies. aitapalikin ki-a (causative verb) to cause to give up; to cause to sacrifice to. to lose heart, lose courage, be disappointed; to despair. aitapapal ki-a (causative verb) to make wet; to moisten; to cause to be damp. aitapas ki-a (causative verb) to tire out; to make one fed up; to bother; to trouble; to cause trouble to; to worry, to make anxious. aitapasio boredom; bother; vexation; irritation; fuss. aitapatan ki-a (causative verb) to make easy; to pretend to be easy; to tame or facilitate. aitapoet (Biblical) a vision; an appearance; an apparition. aitar ki-a to marry off a girl and receive dowry in return; to engage; to wait for (as of boy waiting to marry his fiancée).aitarakin ki-a to wait for (as of boy waiting for girl to grow up and marry). aitarasikin ki-a (causative verb) to put (a thing) somewhere at once; to get direct from one place or use to another. aponi kitarasikinai isirikaalei luajore luenyakunio ko D.R. Congo were rushed straight to the Sudan to fight Joseph Kony’s Lord’s Resistance Army rebels. aitaraun ki-a (causative verb) to cause to become; to appoint. aitaraun itunganan adakai: to minimise someone (literally, to make someone beer dregs). aitare ki-o to wait for; to be waiting a long time for. kitareoi: wait for me; wait there for me.aitareun ki-o to wait here for; to abide.aitarwaun ki-a to excite; to cause to run this way suddenly. aitasac ki-a (causative verb) to cause to forsake; to cause to refrain from (sexual intercourse); to make to leave alone, desert, abandon, renounce, or reject; to cause to avoid. imukeru itasacit atemonon okilenike: it is the newly-born baby refraining the woman from sexual intercourse with her husband. etasac ebulolo akokor ngin akebeei kodula: the fleas have caused that hen to abandon its eggs in the granary. aitasal ki-a (causative verb) to cause to be absent or to remain; to hold up; to retain or to detain. aitasang (causative verb) to end; to abolish; to abrogate; to limit, cause to cease, bring to an end, stop, terminate.aitasionikin ki-o to humble oneself; to be sorry; to use, to make, to spend, etc; to employ; to conscript or draft labourers; to make use of; to apply, exercise, adopt, operate, or utilise. akirot ngin mam itwasamao: that word is not used. aitaswam isirigin: to spend money (in order to get something); to bribe with cash payment. aitaswam akanin anyamia: to use hands for eating (as opposed to using spoons and forks). itaswamai ngesi emotoka alosio Kampala: she/he uses a motorcar to go to Kampala. aitatakanun ki-a (causative verb) to put forward; to show off. etatakanu ngesi akemuk: she/he shows off her/his nice shoes to be showy; to show off; to be very prominent. atakanunos akemuk: her/his new shoes are very showy. aitataleor ki-o (causative verb) to cause to abstain from (a certain food); selfishness; egoism.ingai kitayai egwang akakokor?: who let the wild cat take away my chicken? aitayamakin ki-a (causative verb) to quieten down, pacify, conciliate, appease, or placate. aite ki-o to look at; to make cuts (as in ear); to dig along the edge (as of a path); to clip. aitebiteb aki: to cut edges of ears; to make cuts on the earlobe. aitebitebet an incision; a tattoo; earmark.aitebukin ki-o to become swollen up as a result of eating much (usually accompanied by belching); to observe at a distance; to see a thing or person far off; to look far into the future. to look far; to have a wide view. apedori eong aiteluor etaun loko Katakwi komoru Abela: I can see Katakwi town from Abela rock (in the distance). aitem ki-o to measure or weigh (to find height, weight, strength or depth); to arrange often; to adjust more than once; to repair many times; to be preparing; to put right always. kitemonok emeesa: lay out the table; prepare the table. aitemun ki-o to do again or to repeat; to reform. aitemun bobo: to start all over again.aiten1 ki-a to drink very much (of liquids); to put in a row; to line up to be lined up; to be in a line. aiteriboor ki-o to obstruct the view, stand in the light; to screen; to obstruct sight; to prevent from seeing; to shade. kiteriboorit ijo eong: you obstruct my view. aites ki-a to deliberate; to become like an Etesot or Atesot, or Teso land. aitete ki-a to repair; to renew or refresh; to make new; to rejuvenate. itetei ngesi etogoke: she/he is repairing (renewing) her/his house. aiteteg ki-a (causative verb) to tire out; to fatigue. aitetem ki-o to try; to test; to practice; to do physical exercise; to state the cause; to give an account of; to describe; to explain; to discuss; to plan. aitetem ekia: to prescribe medicine. aitetem akiro: to state a case; to discuss an issue. aitetemikin ki-o to advice; to give advice; to show how to do; to make to fit; to adapt to; to plan for; to comment; to explain to; to account for. kitetemikinoi epale: make these trousers or shorts to fit me. kodonyokinoi epale: make me a pair of trousers or shorts. aiteten ki-a (causative verb) to make straight; to make level; to straighten; to settle (a case in court); to correct or rectify; to put right side up. aiteten akiro: to straighten or clear a matter. etenete: alright. akoto aiteten akeju ore: I want to go homeward. aiteten aomisio: to disillusion; to disabuse, to clarify, to inform. aitetenaar ki-a (causative verb) to make straight or to straighten.aitetenit ki-a to keep in order; to keep steady; to keep straight.aiteteor akonye ki-o (causative verb) to direct eyes to; to look towards. kiteteo akonye orekon: look towards your home. aiteteor akeje ore: to go homeword. aitetes1 newness; freshness. aitetes2 ki-a to be new, recent, or fresh; to be young. kitetiak oni: we are young, new, or inexperienced.aiteteun ekiror: to be enrolled again; to start again.aiteteunio (singular noun F) renovation; reformation; renewal; rebirth. aitetianut (singular noun F) newness; renovation. aitetiar ki-o to become new, fresh, recent, or young. itetiar ijo: you have become young again. aiteun ki-o to look carefully before doing something; to be on the look out before acting. aiteunet a pattern; an example; a prototype; a model. aiti1 ki-o (intransitive verb to be late; to come late; to go late. aiti2 ki-o to be oily; to be greasy. asaanin ngun itiete: those plates are greasy.aitibitib ki-a to have biting pain; to prickle; to have pins and needles. ketibitibi eong eimidi: I have a prickly feeling (on account of fever). aitibong ki-a (causative verb) to make it evening; to do till nightfall; to become or be dusk. etibong akwap, mam eong apedori alosit ore: it is too late for me to go home. abonguni eong itibongi: I shall come back towards evening. to make to become evening, dark, dusk. sirikitibong akwap: do not make it evening (i.e. before you come back). aitican ki-a to afflict; to maltreat or mistreat; to cause misery, trouble to; to inflict misery, sadness, etc. to; to cause or make mischief on; to pester or disturb. aiticanet a punishment, penalty; an inconvenience, nuisance, bother; a disturbance.aiticanio (singular noun F) punishment; penalty; sentence.aitidic ki-a (causative verb) to cause to grind well (fine). aidic amuk: to walk on tip-toe. aitididior ki-o to cause to delay; to make smaller, to be long time after. mam itididior: she/he won’t be long; she/he will be coming shortly; do not delay. aitidil ki-o (causative verb) to make plentiful, make abundant; to cause to go or leave early in the morning. Edeke itidili inyamat kere: God gives abundance of all kinds of food. aitidisiar ki-a (causative verb) to diminish, lessen, extenuate, or abase; to allay; to minimise; to abate; to alleviate or assuage; to make smaller; to abbreviate, make less. kitidisia etogo: make the (plan of the) house smaller. aitiditeun ki-a (causative verb) to humble; to humiliate, make small, make little; to decrease (the size). aitidyak ki-a (causative verb) to mislead, or lead astray. aitidyakalal ki-a (causative verb) to make soft by cooking or adding too much water. aitielo ki-o to have intercourse with a woman or girl.aitieny ikorio: to show greed; to try to prevent; to show discontent. aitienyakin ki-a to bump up against (once only) to shake or rattle (as of bicycle). aitienyanakin ki-o to bump up and down (as of vehicle going over rough ground). aitienyaun ki-a to bump off; to shell with big guns; to bombard a little with artillery.aitigiris ki-o (causative verb) to cause bruises, chafes, etc. aitiiba a net (especially a mosquito or fishnet).aitiikin aidoun: to conceive after many years. itiik ijo abunere: you (singular) have come late. aitiin ki-a (causative verb) to cause to grow thin or emaciate; to cause food to be undone or fail to get ready. adeka na ketiin eong: this disease has made me thin (emaciated me). aitiina ki-a (causative verb) to make damp; to make moist; to moisten. aitiirian ki-a (causative verb) to make equal; to level; to compare; to equalise; to adjust; to contrast. aitiirianakin ki-a to be equal; to be level with; to be compared with; to be equal; to be adjusted; to make equal to; to make level; to compare with; to equalise to; to adjust to. aitiirianet analogy; comparison; parallel; resemblance. aitiit ki-o a corruption of aitingit: to hold or keep in the hand; to possess. aitiji ki-a (causative verb) to fight someone or something; to attack; to fight somebody or something. aitoji: to beat; (of insects, such as bees, wasps) to sting somebody. aitijijim ki-a (causative verb) to make tasty; to flavour; to spice; to season. aitijijimikin ki-a (causative verb) to make one pleased with. akoto aitijijimikin ijo aswam na: I want to make you pleased with this work. aitijon ki-a (causative verb) to cool something; to chill or or put in a fridge. aitik to hold up; to enchant; to press down; to push against; to jostle; to obstruct; to hypnotise; to fascinate. aitik eiyengane: to hold breath. aitik etau: to determine in one’s heart not to; to hold back oneself. aitik eibel: to be continent; to abstain from. aitikidiokor (causative verb) to reduce, decrease; to make less, fewer, etc aitikitik ki-o to prevent; to obstruct constantly. ipu kwana ikee luitikitiket eimidi: there are many drugs to prevent malaria fever these days. aitikitikio (singular noun F) prevention; deterrence; controlling. aitikitikun ki-a to prevent.aitikokin ki-o to prevent; to hinder; to dissuade; to ban; to obstruct. aitikun ki-o to prevent from going further; to stop from going further; (of cattle) to drive back. aitili ki-a (causative verb) to make watery; to dilute. aitilil ki-a (causative verb) to tantalise; to taunt; to make envious; to irritate. itilili ikoku ekapa: the child is teasing the tomcat.aitilitila ki-a to be loose; to be shaky; to be unsteady. itilitila emeesa ngol: that table is unsteady (it shakes). aitilon ki-o to be deep or abysmal. aitilor ki-o to delay somebody to be late; to linger; to delay.aitim ki-o to pardon or to forgive; to absolve; to spare; to have mercy on; to pity; to have pity on. kitimoi: have pity on me. aitima a valve (a tiny rubber that controls air pressure in a tyre). aitimaikin ki-a to look like a hair; to be hair-like. aitimatim ki-a to waver; to be fussy; to rush about. aitimatimatoi ki-o to mess or fuss about. aitimet compassion; sympathy; kindness. aitimilimil ki-a to cause to shine; to polish; to glisten or cause to glitter. aitimin ki-a (causative verb) to endear; to charm, captivate, or enamour. aitimio (singular noun F) forgiveness; pardon; amnesty; mercy; pity.aitimonor ki-o to forgive one another. aitimonut1 (singular noun F) leniency; mercy. aitimonut2 ki-o to be inclined to forgive; to be lenient to; to be merciful. aiting ki-a to hold; to take hold of; to catch hold of; to grasp. aiting akan: to shake hands or ask in marriage; to propose marriage. aiting akiro: to grasp (mentally); to understand. aitinga ki-a to persuade; to constrain; to force. aitingaar ki-a to take away by force or with difficulty; to persuade to go or to do; to go or do unwillingly. abu ketingaa nges alosit aswam: I persuaded (constrained, forced) her/him to go to work. aitingaikin ki-a to force; to begrudge; to persuade; to constrain; to convince; to hold for somebody. kitingakinai ekagaali: hold my bicycle for me. aitingaun ki-a to bring by force; to compel; to force out; to pull out forcibly; to extract by force, i.e. to coerce. aitingaun akiro: to say unwillingly; to say with difficulty to force somebody to speak. aitinget a handle; a forceps; a pincers; a quiver for arrows. aitingirikin ki-o (causative verb) to cause to endure; to frown on. aitingit to have hold of; to hold in custody; to contain; to be looking after somebody’s goods as guarantee. aitinitina ki-a to pretend to be coy; to turn head in pretended shyness. aitip ki-o to dip; (of food or vegetables) to take little by little. aitipipil ki-a (causative verb) to hurt; to cause to be painful. aitipitip ki-a (of rain) to drizzle.aitir to touch (many); to feel; to handle; to finger. aitiri ki-o (causative verb) to cross-cut; to cause to bend, twist or curve. aitirikin ki-a to do daily or continually; to do many times; to do constantly; to persevere. aitiriong ki-a (causative verb) to make someone carry a load on the shoulders. aponi kitiriongai Yesu emusalaba: Jesus was made to carry a cross. aitiripakin ki-a (causative verb) to make or cause to stand in a row; to line up. aitirir ki-a to be speechless, mute, confounded, or dumbfounded; to stand in a row. itiriraete: they are standing in rows. aitironikin ki-o to apologise; to own up; to be penitent; to say sorry; to ask for forgiveness. aitisi ki-a (causative verb) to let escape; to cause to escape, run off, run away; to rescue clandestinely. aitisil ki-a (causative verb) to humble, humiliate, disgrace; to put to shame, embarrass; to shame, degrade; to desert a village, i.e. leave without people. itisilitoi ejakait kajakaanut: the chief was degraded. aitisilaar ki-a (causative verb) to punish, censure; to chastise; to mortify; to penalise; to castigate. aitisilaario (singular noun F) punishment; penance; chastisement; penalty. aitisilaario naka aijaanakin ateker: community service. aitisiom ki-a (causative verb) to cause to read (a book, etc); to pay school fees for; to cause to study to educate (by sending to school to learn to read and write, etc). aitisis ki-o (causative verb) to burn (of food only); to parch or scorch. aitisyepaikin ki-a (causative verb) to cause to become fatty or oily; to fatten (an animal for slaughter).aititi1 ki-o to become oily or greasy. etitie akonikituk bala inyamit akinyet: your mouth is greasy as if you had eaten oil. aititi2 ki-o to stop from running away. emong etitie akituk: the bull was the one stopping the cows from running away.aititil ki-o to become very dirty (usually with soot or black dirt). ititilat ngesi: she/he/it is very grimy or full of dirt.aititimanut ki-a to be vacillating, fussy, hesitating, or unable to decide. aititing ki-a (causative verb) to hand over to; to cut tops of grain; to reap.aitobitob ki-a to bite all over; to munch; to nibble (as of a rabbit). aitobong ki-a (causative verb) to cause or force to return; to force to go back; to make a profit.aitobongun ki-o (causative verb) to reclaim; to cause to come back or return. aitobwo ki-a (causative verb) to accuse; to cause to stand; to prop or support. aitobwok ki-a to make to carry; to put on the head; to load a person or car. aitobwot ki-a (causative verb) to evacuate or relocate; to evict; to expel; to cause to shift homes or emigrate. aitobwotun ki-a (causative verb) to cause to immigrate to this place. aitoc ki-a (of leaves and branches of a cut plant)to regrow; to sprout out again. aitoco akonye ki-a to try to see everything to be curious; to look around. aitocoliar ki-a (causative verb) to make watery. itocolia ijo akile ngun: you have added water to that milk. aitocoun ki-a (causative verb) to make wise, shrewd or careful; to enlighten; to make clear to; to caution or warn. akirot ngin ibusakinit aitocoun ijo: this case ought to make you careful, wise, etc. aitocun ki-a (as of leaves and branches of a cut plant) to sprout out again. aitod to peck once; to strike (as a snake does). aitoditod ki-a to shamble; to totter (like one who is tired); to go slowly (as of a weak person). aitodo ki-o (causative verb) to lose or to drop; to let fall; to cause to fall. sirikitodo ikoku: don't let the child fall. aitodoikin ki-o (causative verb) to make to drop into or on; to drop into; to drip into; to let fall into or onto; to get someone into trouble or case. ibu ijo kitodoik eong toma akiro: you got me into trouble (case). aitodok ki-a (causative verb) to lift i.e. to help to climb up or down; to make to climb; to help to climb; to let climb. aitodokaar ki-a (causative verb) to lift up i.e. to help to climb away; to make to climb away; to help to climb away; to let climb away. aitodokun ki-a (causative verb) to lift down i.e. to help to climb down or force down; to make to climb down; to help to come down; to let climb down towards oneself. aitodol1 upto; until; till. eboi eong aitodol nges abongun: I have stayed until her/his return.aitodol2 ki-o (causative verb) to achieve; to effect; to fulfil or to uphold. etodol ngesi eipudake: she/he has achieved her/his ambition or desire. aitodolikin ki-o (causative verb) to attain; to cause to reach; to fulfil. etodolik eong akapeleikinet abitun eitaabo loka Ateso: I have achieved my aim of writing a book in Ateso. aitodolikinet an achievement; attainment. aitodolun ki-o (causative verb) to satisfy; to cause to arrive here; to make to arrive there where you are. aitoduun ki-o to show (us); to indicate (to us). aitogogong1 ki-o (causative verb) to endorse; to invigorate; to affirm; to fulfil; to confirm; to corroborate; to certify; to sanction; to ratify; to make good; to fortify. kitogogong aitumunetakon: fulfil your promise. aitogogong2 ki-o (causative verb) to strengthen; to harden; to encourage, insist, prove, or approve. kitigogongoto arwatat ngin: strengthen that wall. aitogogonget an affirmation; a ratification, etc. aitogogongoor ki-o (causative verb) to enforce; to impose; to inflict; to effect; to fulfil. aitoikin ki-o to put sideways; to put on its side; to turn sideways. aitoikin aki: to listen attentively. aitoilikin ki-o (causative verb) to look like a wraith or a ghost (spirit of the dead). aitoito ki-o to dig along a rope or a line; to trim a hedge; to cut off inequalities. aitoitois an instrument for digging, cutting off edges, or trimming (hedge or ditch); a dibble. aitojaar ki-a (causative verb) to hit hard on the head. aitojok ki-a (causative verb) to make good; to bless; to praise; to speak well of; to commend.aitojokaar ki-a (causative verb) to recommend; to appreciate; to approve; to commend; to compliment. abu Okello kitojokaa aikopakin Omoding polis kanu aswamisineike nuka aimokoraikit: Okello recommended handing Omoding to the police for his unbecoming acts. aitojokianakin ki-a to praise always; to approve always; to benefit always. aitojokiar ki-a (causative verb) to amend; to improve; to recommend; to ameliorate; to appreciate; to approve; to commend; to compliment; to make good, nice, right, etc. aitojokiara bon: to be complacent, smug, self-satisfied, docile, submissive, or apathetic. aitojonaar ki-o (of angry person, weather, or a hot thing) to calm down, let cool down, put at ease, or put at rest; to sooth. aitojongoor ki-o (causative verb) to prevent, abolish, cause to cease, or stop. aitojor ki-o (causative verb) to make to sit on haunches (as of holding a child when pissing or defecating). aitok to hem; to make a hem (as of mat or cloth, etc); to limit. kotok emukeeka lo: hem this mat. etokit aberu ngin akiro: that woman is strict (she cannot stand nonsense). aitoka ki-a to beat on the back many times; to strike the back many times; to gulp or guzzle. kinyek aitoka idwe: stop beating up the children. aitokaar to strike on the back once; to beat the back once; to drink greedily. ekoto ekamejan aitokaar etyang: the hunter wants to hit the animal to rush away quickly through the bush. aitokakin ki-a to explode in the direction of or towards. kinyek aitokanakin eong ekonimuudu: stop exploding your gun in my direction (towards me). aitokaun ki-a to strike; to hit; to beat (somebody or something) to rush blindly towards the speaker. aitokimaar ki-a to pour out completely. aitokimaaret effusion (a pouring or flowing out). aitokokol ki-o to be an enemy of; to rival; to underbid; to impinge on. inyo bo kitokokolitor ijo eong?: why do you rival me? aitokol ki-o to cause a quarrel; to cause enmity; to thwart; to contest; to rival; to outdo; to overbid (said of anything). itokolit ijo eong: you thwart me. ekolosi ngesi kapapake: she/he is at loggerheads with her/his father. aitokolit ki-o to accuse; to rival.aitokony1 atap a ceremony for blessing and giving food to women after childbirth. aitokony2 atap ki-a (causative verb) to let people partake of first fruits of harvest; to give a woman the offals (entrails of a cow) to eat after childbirth.aitokot ki-o (causative verb) to endear; to charm, captivate, enamour, or attract. aitola ki-a to dry meat or fish by smoking over fire. aitoliokokin ki-o to hesitate; to be in doubt. aitololoar ki-o to drink up completely (as of a drunkard). aitolom ki-a to cause many to enter; to employ or to take on new staff (for work); to engage new workforce. aitolomaar ki-a (causative verb) to cause to enter into, cause to go out or into; to put into. aitolomikin ki-a (causative verb) to enrol, register, or sign up. aitolomun ki-a (causative verb) to cause to come in or out; to cause a seed to germinate; to make successful. ijo ibu kitolom akiro nubian: you caused yesterday’s trouble. aitolomunet an edition (of a newspaper or a book); a production or print. aitolomuun ki-a (causative verb) to introduce or to lead into; to pass out people who have been on training. aitolony ki-a (causative verb) to cause to miss; to be passed over. aitolot ki-a (causative verb) to set in motion; to impel; to cause to move or to cause to walk. aitomonikin ki-a (causative verb) to do for the tenth time; to add in order to bring up to ten; to add to make ten. kitomonik ipakasin ngul: bring the number of those porters to ten. aitomony (causative verb) to make to weep; to cause to cry; to make to complain. aitomony akiyo: to cause to shed tears. etomony aingito esisiak: the exams caused the students to cry (because it was very hard). aiton ki-a (of liquids) to drop; to let drop. aiton abalang: to make salt from plant ash; to filter ashes for salt; to distil. itoni aberu abalang: the woman makes salt (from plant ashes). aitonakin ki-a (of liquids) to drop on; to let drip on (in); to put drops on (into). kitonakinai ekia akongu: put some drops of medicine in my eye. aitonanakin ki-o (of liquids) to fall in drops onto or into; to put in drops in. aitong ki-a to take too much; to exceed measure. aitongong ki-a to sit around doing nothing or to sit in anger; to sit mooching. aitonok ki-a (causative verb) to cause to burn; to cause a fire to be near; to be close to. aitononok ki-a (causative verb) to weaken, soften; to dilute, to add water to calm down; to mollify. kinyek aitononok ajon: do not make the beer weak (by adding too much water). aitonyoun ki-a (causative verb) to arouse or stir up; to awaken; to cause to stand up; to set in motion or to start off an engine; to expel somebody from a place; to cause to go away (of woman getting divorced). aitoodi ki-a (used with plural object) to show; to point out; to indicate. aitoodiar ki-a to show; to demonstrate; to proclaim; to display; to exhibit; (of the groom and his relatives) to get introduced in marriage to the future in-laws. aitoodiaret an example; to manifest oneself; to show oneself; to introduce oneself. aitooj ki-a (causative verb) to make tall, high, or long; to elongate. aitoojaar ki-a (causative verb) to extend; to lengthen; to elongate. aitoolikin ki-o to bewilder; to lose; to waste; to mix up (as of rope - not knowing where the end is); to mislead; to confuse, upset, or interfere with; to cause to get mixed up. aitoolior ki-o (causative verb) to lose; to waste; to make or colour dark brown. aitoonikin ki-o (causative verb) to drain (land, well); to finish something for someone. aitoos ki-a (causative verb) to accuse; to take to court; to cause to plead.aitopol ki-o to make big, proud, or important; to bring up or to rear; to dignify; to promote; to develop.aitopolo (singular noun F) pride; conceit; arrogance; superiority complex. aitopolonut1 self-importance; haughtiness; arrogance; conceit. aitopolonut2 ki-o to be proud; to be haughty or arrogant; to be inclined to be conceited; to be inclined to be proud. aitopoloor ki-o (causative verb) to make big, proud, or important; to bring up or to rear; to dignify; to promote; to magnify. to become big, proud, haughty, or arrogant. sirikitopoloor: do not become proud.aitopoloorit to celebrate or honour; to commemorate, observe or remember an event or an occasion. aitopolooro ki-o to be arrogant; to think much of oneself; to be conceited. aitopoloun to educate or adopt another’s child as one’s own; to bring up; to educate; to extol. aitor1 ki-a to trample down; to stamp hard (as of soil or contents of a bag). ingai kitori akamana?: who trampled down my garden? aitor2 ki-o to pass; to go by, past. aitor toma ationis naepol: to pass through great difficulties (hardships). kitor awai: go alongside; pass by one side. aitor3 to tie round (something). aitor akou: to tie a scarf or a band round the head (because one is feeling headache, in mourning, etc). aitoris a passport; a permit for passing somewhere. aitorit ki-a to be passing or to have passed somewhere; to go by; to have experienced some unpleasant things. aitoron ki-a (causative verb) to spoil, make bad, defile, chide, find fault with, deprecate; (of a girl) to jilt; to blame; to spoil; to disapprove; to aggravate; to mar; to abominate. aitoronaar ki-a (causative verb) to spoil, make bad, defile, blame, chide, find fault with, deprecate; to blame; to mar; to abominate. aitoronikin ki-o to apologise; to express regret; to be penitent; to own up; to repent, apologise, or admit guilt. aitoror ki-o to pick something along the way on a journey; to pass by and pick. aitorubeikin ki-o to look like a shadow. aitorun ki-o to bring something along on the way back. aitosom ki-a (causative verb) to cause to jump, bounce, or dance. aitosom etau: to surprise, astound, or to astonish.aitotolikin ki-o (causative verb) to disarrange; to disorganise; to interrupt; to upset; to thwart. to be deformed. aitotom ki-a to pour liquids down the throat in great quantities; to guzzle. aitotom ajon: to drink a great quantity of beer. aitotom akiyo: to shed a lot of tears. aitotomitoi ki-o (of flowing liquid) to gurgle, burble, or spurt. aitotwa ki-a to beat (as of carpet); to shake off dust (by beating); to shake out dust from a vessel. aitotwaar ki-a to shake out dust from cloth, carpet or vessel; to dust by beating out. aitub to cut; to amputate; to referee (at football); to arbitrate; to decide; to cancel acheque; to pass an examination. aitub akiro: aitub emusaago: to settle or judge a court case; to arbitrate. aitub acoa: to play a trick; to devise a plan. aitub etau: to hurt one's feelings; to say something derisive; to be sarcastic; to gibe at. ketub apak edit: after a short while. aituburuun ki-a (causative verb) to make anxious; to make disquiet; to molest. aitubus ki-a (causative verb) to decorate; to honour; to beautify; to bear or keep company; to entitle. bia aitubus eong: come and keep me company. epejonon itubusi akaika: a visitor is coming to stay in my house. aitubusian ki-a (causative verb) to enslave; to make to work like a slave; to engage; to take into service; to exploit. luitubusianitai : slaves. aitubusian itunganan: to take advantage of somebody and make him/her work like a slave; to exploit a person. aitubusikin ki-a (causative verb) to make better; to increase. kitubusikisi aboliakus: put more vim into your game and make it interesting. aitubuun ki-o (causative verb) to distend; to leaven; to cause to swell. aitud1 akonye to drop medicine into the eye.aitud2 ki-o to tie up or to knot. aitud3 (used with plural object) to plant in little groups. aitudeng ki-o (causative verb) to extinguish; to put out fire; to cool down. akim namam edungee: hell, eternal fire. aitudokin auno ki-a to make a knot; to insert a knot. aitudum ki-a to cause to receive, get, or procure. aitudumikin ki-a (causative verb) to cause to get for someone, etc. aitudumun ki-a to cause to receive, get, or procure. aitudupuk ki-o (causative verb to grind finer. kitudupuk akiria: grind the flour fine.aitujul ki-a (causative verb) to cause to change, modify, modulate, alter, vary, convert, or turn. aitujul ediini: to convert to another faith. aituk1 ki-a to tie hard; to bind much. kituk akiteng oloit: tie the cow onto the peg hard. aituk2 to fill the mouth with water (or other liquids); to hold something in the mouth. etukit nges akipi: she/he has her/his mouth full of water. aituk isinyok: to drink beer (ajon ekamule). aituk3 to gather; to assemble; to heap up; to collect. aituku1 ki-a (causative verb) to let escape; to rescue; to redeem; to save; to snatch away from danger. aituku2 ki-o (causative verb) to cause to froth or foam; to make to froth or foam. kituku asabuuni: make the soap foam or lather. aitukul ki-a (causative verb) to cause to peel or pare. aitukula ki-a (causative verb) to make to boil; to boil; to allow to evaporate. aitukulaun ki-a to cause to start boiling. aitukum ki-a (of anything) to cause to bend forward; to overturn many face first. aitukumikin ki-o (causative verb) to bend forward (as of head or anything); to adore; to bend for; to make a bow for; to empty by holding vessel upside-down. aitukumikin akipi amot: to pour out all the water into the pot by turning vessel upside-down. to bend oneself down (in reverence, worship, adoration). itukuminikinos itunga Lokasuban: people adore God by bending themselves. aitukumoor ki-o to upset, overturn, push down; (of a person) to fall down headlong; to topple down. (of liquid) to be spilt. etukumooros akile: the milk has been spilt, upset. aitukurian ki-a (causative verb) to frighten; to horrify; to discourage; to deter; to cow; to scare. aitukurwoor ki-o (causative verb) to cause to fail; to cause to give up (a task, a work); to disable. aitukurwoor etyang: to run down an animal to death. aitukusiar ki-a (causative verb) to cause to dry up a little; to make to heal (a wound). aitukutuk ki-a to tie up hard; to bind in a big knot. kitukutukata akaninike: tie up her/his hands. aitukuun ki-o (causative verb) to make to foam (by adding salt to vegetables or adding baking soda to dough, or stirring soap and water). aitule ki-o to blow (fire); to accelerate (a vehicle). itulei ngesi akim: she/he is blowing into the fire. aituleikin akim: to stir up or kindle the fire; to light up (by blowing). aituleor ki-o to blow away; to somersault or tumble. aitulum ki-o (causative verb) to throw; to force to dive; to force to submerge; to immerse. aituluor ki-o to alter; to convert; to change; to transform; to cause to change colour, manners, etc. aituluor inyamat kotoma akoik: to digest food in the stomach. aitulutul ki-o to pour out from a narrow container (as from a bottle or gourd). aitum to be fat; to be stout or thick; to swell. itumit ijo: you are stout and corpulent. aitumor ki-o to delay; to prevent; to divert; to distract; to detain. ketumo eong aswam: work has delayed me to dally; to delay; to linger; to trifle; to dawdle; to be distracted. itumor ijo korot: you have lingered on the way. aitumudak ki-o (causative verb) to make blind; to command to shut the eyes. amuton itumudaki itunganan: darkness makes one partially blind. aitumun ki-o (causative verb) to cause to hope; to promise; to pledge; to engage.aitumurakin ki-a (causative verb) to make to ripen or ferment by covering (usually in a pot to ripen); (of corpse) to cause to decay. etumurakis alup lokatwan: the earth has caused the corpse to decay. aitumurikin ki-a to take by surprise. abu eong ketumurik nges ekokoi ikaboro: I took her/him by surprise stealing my things. (used with singular or plural object) to surprise; to take unawares; to startle. abu atwanare naka totoka ketumurik eong: the death of my mother took me by surprise. aitumurwokin ki-o to cause to forget. aitumusumus ki-o (causative verb) to dim; to make dark; to do till evening. aitumusumusio naka akolong: eclipse of the sun aitun to embrace; to put hands round; to hug; to hold in two hands; to press to heart; to fondle.aitung ki-a (of a woman) to stunt the growth of children by conceiving before the child is weaned. aitungakin ki-a (of a woman) to stunt the growth of child before it is weaned by too early conception; to nip in the bud. aitungananikin ki-a to act or look like a person. aituny1 ekileng ki-o to make a knife blunt or dulled. aituny2 ki-a to knock against; to bump against; to clash with. aituny3 ki-o to stir up; to poke fire; to feed the fire. aitunyakin ki-a to push over, on, or somewhere; to knock or bump against something; to clash with one another. etunyakinos amotokan: the motorcars crashed or bumped against each other; the cars collided with each other. aitunyar to be in a hurry; to go away in a hurry. aitunyit ki-o to speed up; to urge on; to push ahead; to drive on (only of visible things). akoto eong aitunyit: I want to speed up (the motorcar). aitunyokin1 ki-a to add firewood (to a fire); to put on fire; to stir fire. aitunyokin2 ki-o (of knife or an axe) to make blunt on or somewhere. abu ngesi kitunyok ekileng amoru: she/he blunted her/his knife on a stone. aitunyonokin ki-a to keep the fire burning (by adding firewood). aitunyunyurikin ki-a (causative verb) to make angry with; to enrage; to annoy with; to provoke. aitup to follow; to imitate; to succeed (another as heir); to obey. atupi eong akonikiro: I shall do as you request. aitupuc ki-o to reconcile; to bring or make peace between; to reunite; to bring together. aitupurucikin ki-a to become or look like early morning. etupuruciki akwap: it is dawning. aitupuset similitude; likeness; a contrast; a model; an analogy. aituput ki-o (causative verb) to make like; to shape like; to imitate; to form like; to compare; to cause to resemble. aituputoor ki-o to copy; to compare; to make like; to imitate. aitur1 ki-a to pour into through a narrow neck. kitur akile otuo: pour the milk into the gourd. aitur2 ki-o to praise; to glorify; to exalt; to extol; to applaud. kituritete Edeke: praise God. aitur3 to cut into big pieces; to take (food) in big lumps. aiturakin ki-a to pour into (through a narrow neck).aituraun ki-a to butt; to bump; to ram against. aituret a praise; an applause; a funnel.ituritos itunga akecoa: people praise her/his wisdom. aituro ki-o to boast; to brag; to exult; to applaud or vainglory; to bluster; to bluff. aituroikin ki-o to flower; to bloom. aiturokin ki-o to recommend by praising; to be proud of to praise oneself; to boast; to brag; to glory; to vaunt; to bluster. aituronut1 (singular noun F) fondness for praising; tendency to praise; bragging. aituronut2 ki-o to be fond of praising; to be fond of exalting; to brag often. aiturur1 (singular noun F) sadness; grief; melancholy; sorrow. aiturur2 ki-o to grieve; to regret; to mope; to mooch; to fret; to be sad or sorry; to be downcast. to bemoan. aitururum ki-a (causative verb) to cause to groan; to spread rumour; to spread lies abroad. aiturutur ki-o (of wound on the leg) to be made worse by walking or dancing too much, etc. aitus ki-a to snort (as of pig, sheep, or goat); to sniff. aitusar ki-a (of a calf, lamb or kid) to suck the udder while making a snorting sound. aitusub ki-a (causative verb) to cause to be like; to cause to make. sirikitusub eong ebang: do not make me a fool. aitusuba ki-a (of oneself) to act like. siritusuba bala lokabaran: do not act like a rich man. aitusulianyar ki-a (causative verb) to bless; to wish good luck to. aitutu ki-o to beat (the ground) hard; to stamp down; to raise the level of floor. aitutub ki-o (causative verb) to transmit; to let pass; to cause to cut. aitutuk ki-o to make a vow; to vow; to promise; to insure; to pledge; an indenture.aitutuket a testament; a promise; a vow; a covenant; a pledge. Aitutuket Nakitetet: the New Testament. Aitutuket Namojong: the Old Testament. aitutukin ki-o to beat flat for; to stamp down for or somewhere; to shoot with a rifle. aitutukin aipany: to fill a hole (stamp down the earth of). aitutukokin ki-o (causative verb) to cause to gather or to assemble. aitutum ki-a (causative verb) to fatten (of a fireplace) to belch out smoke. aitutun ki-a (causative verb) to allow to take hold of; to cause to embrace. aitutupikin ki-a (causative verb) to cause to succeed each other; to allow to follow after; to bring close behind. aituturum ki-o to cause trouble to; to instigate to do bad; to incite; to influence negatively. aituturur ki-o (causative verb) to sadden; to make sad; to grieve. aituu ki-a to take many; to call many. aituuar ki-a to take away many. ai bo ituuari ijo idwe lu?: where are you taking all these children to? aituumokin ki-a (causative verb) to astonish; to flabbergast; to surprise; to amaze. aituur ki-o (causative verb) to cause to smell of; to cause to miss or omit. aituurianet a corruption of aituuryanet: abbreviation. aituurikin ki-o (causative verb) to allow somebody to smell something. aituuryan1 ki-a (causative verb) to shorten; to abbreviate; to cut short; to abridge; to condense. aituuryan2 ki-a to curdle (fresh milk by mixing with sour milk). aituuryanar ki-a (causative verb) to make shorter or lower; to become brief. aituuryanet an abbreviation; a brief; a summary. aituut ki-o to teach; to initiate into a craft (used with plural object). kituut itelepai aiwadik: teach the boys the rudiments of writing. aituutoor ki-o to instruct; to train; to initiate a person into anything; to tutor. aituuwaikin ki-a to call together; to put many together; to cram together. sirikituuwaik iboro ngul kere toma asaduku: don't cram all those things into the box. aituwuor ki-o (causative verb) to deflate or puncture. aitwa to thrash; to beat out (lumps of earth); to knock down (fruit) with a stick. aitwa aloboi: to clear lumps of earth from furrows (by beating them). aitwa araito: to knock down fruit (with stick). aitwa emaido: to shake uprooted groundnuts. aitwa akiro: to talk much. aitwal ki-a to mark in different colours anyhow; to stain, tinge; to paint roughly. aitwalitwal ki-a to cause to be speckled; to blemish; to stain; to cause to be spotted. ngai kitwalitwali ekagoe?: who has made these stains on my dress (cloth)? aitwam to talk at random. aitwap to walk blindly; to walk without caring where one treads.aitwar to dismiss; to send away; to say goodbye to; to release to go away. akoto aitwar ijo: I want to bid you farewell. ibore yenitwaret: a parting gift. aitwekenyun ki-o (causative verb) to awaken someone else; to rouse from sleep. ajotoi sek papa, konye adaun aitwekenyun: daddy was asleep earlier on, but he has been awoken.aitwel ki-o to stagger; to walk unsteadily (as if passing over potholes). etwelitoi ngesi emera ajon: she/he staggers when she/he is drunk. aitwelitoi ki-o to keep staggering along. aitwelor ki-o to stagger away; to go in a hurry. aitweny to make sparks; to make fire with a flint. aitweng ekori: to be greedy (literally, to spark the buttocks). atwenyun akibiriiti: to strike a match. atwenyun akiro: to spark trouble. aityak to divide; to share; to separate; to make a distinction; to distinguish. atwanare kityaki oni: it is only death that will do us part. kotyak kojokan: distinguish well. eraas kesi ipapero lumam etyakas: they are inseparable friends. aityangaikin ki-a to be, do or look like an animal; to be beast-like. aiwa1 akipi ki-a to ford a river; to wade across water; to scoop out water. aiwaar ecor: to wade through; to ford a river or lake. aiwa2 to joke; to jest; to tell a joke; to talk in a friendly fashion. aiwaca ki-a (of cow) to be in-calf. iwacas akituk ngun: those cows are in gestation. aiwacun ki-a (of cow) to conceive; (of udder) to swell. aiwad to scoop out something thick; to scrape off something thick with fingers or an instrument. aiwad esik: aiwad amolig: to take honey from the beehive. aiwad amolig: (slang) to have an illicit love affair. aiwad atap: to take big lumps of atap with fingers. aiwad aoret: to scoop cow-dung. aiwad atan: to clean a water well by taking away mud from the bottom. aiwad ecor: to dredge a river or a well. aiwadik ki-a to write, inscribe, scrawl, scribe or print; to record; to register. aiwadik ebaluwa: to write a letter.aiwadikaet a written permit; a written agreement; a document; endorsement. aiwadikakin ki-a to write to (somebody). aiwadikao (singular noun F) enrolment; registration. aiwadikaun ki-o to get oneself enrolled or registered; to give your name for a competition, examination, etc. aiwaikin ki-a to help someone to scoop out water; to bale out water from or for. aiwak1 (of cow’s udder) to be big with milk. aiwak2 (used with plural objects) to break off; to knock out; to take off (a big piece of something hard); to give a heavy blow. aiwal1 ki-a to begin to boil. ewalasi akipi: the water is beginning to boil. aiwal2 ki-a (used with plural object) to open wide; to take off; to uncover. aiwal akonye: to raise eyebrows; to open eyes wide. aiwal3 ki-a to separate something stuck; to make loose something stuck (as of stamp on envelope, etc). aiwalakin1 ki-a to open for; to uncover for; to dawn upon (in the literal sense); to do the whole night until dawn or until morning. aiwalakin2 ki-a to loosen or separate something stuck for somebody. aiwalar1 ki-a to be boiled. ewalasi akipi: the water has boiled. koyautu akipi nuiwalarito: bring boiling water. aiwalar2 ki-a to open out (of flowers, ear of grain) to blossom; (of day) to dawn. ewala akwap: it is morning (literally, the earth has burst open) (of crust on wound) to come off; to peel off. aiwalar3 ki-a to take off something stuck (as stamp, etc).aiwalaret nakakwap daybreak; dawn. aiwaliwal1 ki-a (of cloudy sky) to clear. ewaliwal akuj: the sky has cleared. aiwaliwal2 ki-a to cleanse surface of water before drawing water (of liquid on fire) to bubble; to boil. aiwaliwalaar ki-a (of the sky) to become clear or to become cloudless; to separate shelled groundnuts from the shells; to push away dirt on surface of water; to cleanse surface of water before drawing water. ewaliwalaar akuj: the sky has become clear. aiwalun ki-a to take off (as stamp off an envelope); to peel off (as of bandage); to shell to come off; (of something fixed) to come loose; (of skin) to peel off; to fall off.aiwan to wound; to lacerate; to rip open; (as of bull with horn) to gore. kawanit ngesi eong: she/he has wounded me. aiwanganut1 (singular noun F) greed (eating hot food). aiwanganut2 ki-a to be greedy (by eating hot food fast). aiwany to see.aiwar1 ki-a to go in front and block progress of; to cut off one running away; to intercept. aiwar2 ki-a to skim (as of milk, etc); to take off surface. aiwar3 to become evening; to grow dark. awar akwap: it is evening; it is dark. aiwar4 nak’akwap the evening or dusk. abuni eong kewar akwap: I shall come at sunset. aiwarag ki-a to speak about in parables; to talk about someone. aiwarag itunganan: to talk about someone in parables; to propound a riddle. sirikiwaragak eong: do not talk about me in parables. aiwaragatoi ki-a to keep telling untrue stories about someone. ejaas luiwaragatos lucetunga: there are people who go about telling untrue stories about others. aiwaragaun ki-a to hint; to take a hint from. aiwaragikin ki-a to tell a story, a fable, a parable to; to talk about someone. kiwaragik idwe akiro: tell the children a story. aiwarakin ki-a (of anything) to go round to intercept for; to skim for. aiwaranar ki-a to shave off often; to take off (many bad portions). aiwarar ki-a to slice off; to skim; to take off the top of anything. aiwasi ki-a to be at the end of a row or a queue; to be the last on one side; to be at the border or edge. ingai iwasie?: who is the winger (in football)? who is the last in the queue? aiwasit ki-o to stay alongside; to stay on the border; to remain at the side; to remain aloof. inyo bo iwasitor ijo?: why do you stay aloof (aside)? aiwasiwas ki-a to try to get away by sidling; to move away in fear or shyness; to go away in fear; to back away; to move away backwards. inyo bo iwasiwasia ijo?: why are you trying to get away?aiwaun ki-a to bring something by carrying it through the water to come through water. awaun edou: it is raining. aiwe to sow; to disseminate; to spread; to broadcast. aiweiwea1 (singular noun F) a whisper; a secret. nukaiweiwea: secrets. iweiweasi nunyoika?: what are you (plural) whispering about? inera ngesi nukaiweiwea: she/he is divulging or telling secrets. aiweiwea2 ki-a to whisper; to tell a secret. aiweiwear ki-a to talk in whispers about. kocoite ecudeteke loiweiweare: be careful or wary of her/his witchcraft people whisper about. aiweiweikin ki-a to whisper to someone. aiwek ki-a to shake; to cause to rattle.aiwek akaen: to shake the rattle (a gourd with pebbles in it, used in traditional ceremonies). aiwel ki-a to spatter; to scatter (as of hen searching for food in the soil). aiwelanar ki-a to scatter in all directions; to spill all over to be scattered in all directions; to be spilled all over. aiwelar ki-a to throw out things or liquids; to spill out or abolish; to scatter; to throw about. to come or fall into bits; to break into pieces. ewelaki ekwam akapapulai toma otogo kere: the wind has scattered my papers all over the house. to be scattered; to be dispersed or be spilled; to be thrown out. aiweliwel ki-a to scatter; to break into fragments; to disarrange; to shatter; to squander; to lay waste; to abolish. eweliwel ekwam etogo: the wind has blown down the house. iweliweli akokor alupok: the hen is scattering the dust. iweliweli ijo ikoniboro atitai: you squander your property or assets for nothing. aiweliwelun ki-a to fall to bits; to fall to pieces; to shatter; to break to pieces. aiwelun ki-a to scatter this way; to spill out (liquids or solids) this way; to peel off in the direction of the speaker. aiwenaiwen ekingok: to guard your tongue; to be cautious of what one says (literally, to tie the dog). aiweniwen ki-a to twine or tie round; to spool. aiweniwenakin ki-a to tie round something to tie oneself round. eweniwenakin anyunyura otauka: I am very angry (literally, anger has entangled itself round my heart). aiweriwer ki-a to go quickly through dry leaves; to rustle or to wear swishing clothes. kiweriwer ore: go home quickly. aiwet1 ki-a to sip (hot tea or something bitter, hot, etc). iwesete kesi ecaai: they are sipping tea. aiwet2 to peel (as of potatoes). aiwetar ki-a to finish off (as of tea, etc). aiwiny ki-a to whistle. iwinya ngesi she/he is (they are) whistling. aiwinyakin ki-a to whistle for; to call by whistle. aiwo1 ki-o to catch or trap dripping water or any liquid with some vessel. aiwo2 to leak; to drip. ewoete akipi: the water is dripping. ewoi etuo: the gourd is leaking. ewoi akai: the house (roof) is leaking. aiwo3 to sing a song or hymn; to talk often; to tell often. aiwo4 (used with plural object) to take down loads from the head. aiwod to scoop; to ladle out (as of vegetables or atap). aiwod atap: to serve food (specifically millet bread). aiwodiwod ki-o to poke something blunt into a hole many times; to hollow out. iwodiwodi ikoku ekume: the child is poking at its nostril (with its finger). aiwoikin ki-a (of cow’s udder) to be heavy with milk. ewoiki akiteng: the cow's udder is heavy with milk to keep, stop milk for. ewoiki akiteng akile: the cow has given up the milk (to the suckling calf). ewoikis ikisinake: her breasts are heavy with milk. aiwoiwo ki-o to progress slowly. aiwok to draw (liquids); to scoop (liquids or flour). alosi aiwok akipi: I am going to fetch water, i.e. I am going to the well. aiwok akiria: to scoop up flour. aiwokiwok ki-a to shake up and down (as of bottle, jerry-can or gourd). cp aijang: to shake vertically. aiwol ki-o to dig out; to dig up; to plough up; to lift up (a dress, etc) to expose. iwolete imongin akacok: the oxen are digging up my potatoes. aiwolongikin ki-o to undertake something sizable without any chance of success; to try something big. sirikiwolongikin numam ipedori: do not attempt what you cannot manage.aiwolor ki-o to uncover; to raise up and take away; (of wind) to throw off. abu ekwam kiwolo akasoto: the wind blew off the dome of my food store. to come off; to peel or fall off. aiwolun ki-a to lift up (roots and all); to dig up (stones or big things); to excavate to peel off; to come unstuck. ewolun eong amuny: my skin has peeled off. aiwolunet a lever or crowbar. aiwom to fetch; to go and fetch; to bring. kowom akipi: fetch water. aiwona ki-a (of child) to be delivered; (of female) to bring forth; (of female) to give birth to. ewona akaberu: my wife has been delivered, i.e. she has been helped to give birth.aiwonet ki-o to long for; to desire; to be passionate. ewonet eong alosit aiyeng: I long for a holiday.aiwong to yawn; to open (the mouth); to gape. aiwonga ki-a to take or carry big loads. iwongai ipese ngin ikiliok lutiok: that little girl prefers getting huge men. aiwongaar ki-a to take away a big thing to go as a big person among children. aiwongaikin ki-a to give something big to. aiwongatoi ki-o to go about carrying big things; to go about like a big man. ai bo iwongatoi ijo?: where are you going with your heavy load, or as big as you are? aiwongonut1 (singular noun F) self-conceit; vain-glory; presumption; bombast. aiwongonut2 ki-o to be opinionated, self-conceited; to be vainglorious; to be presumptuous; to boast, brag, vaunt aiwony ki-a (of moving on foot) to hurry; to be quick; to hasten; to get on. kiwonyete: hurry up (plural). aiwonyakin ki-a to hurry up to somebody or somewhere; to go quickly to do; to hasten to. kiwonyak atan: go quickly to the well. aiwonyanut1 (singular noun F) quickness; celerity; haste; alacrity; swiftness; speed. aiwonyanut2 ki-a to be fast, quick (in walking only, not in running).aiwoor akile ki-o (said of a cow) to keep back milk; to withhold milk. ewoo akiteng akile: the cow withheld its milk (has kept it back). aiwope ki-o to stretch for something; to try to reach or catch a high target; to aim at attaining an end; to aspire to. iwopet ngesi adumun ajakaanut: she/he aspires becoming a leader. iwopet ekatau: I long to. ewopei eong adolore Jinja: I am wishing I could reach Jinja. aiwopeor ki-o to grasp;
