to try to reach; to reach for something; to try to catch by stretching out the arm. kiwopeo akan: stretch out your arm and get or hit. aiwor1 ki-a to manure; to pour compost manure on land. aiwor2 (of soil or earth) to split; to crack; to fissure. eworitos acok ngun: those potato heaps have split (implying the roots are mature for harvest). aiwor3 to scoop out; to take out by handfuls. aiworiwor1 ki-a to smear with cow-dung; to plaster with cow-dung. kiworiwor ekatogo: smear my house with cow-dung. alup nuiworor: humus. aiworiwor2 ki-o (of wound) to fester. iworiwori akajimi: my wound has festered. aiworo ki-o to call out names; to call someone; to shout at; to invite to shout. aiworo eporoto: to shout; cry out. aiworokin ki-o to call for somebody; to shout for someone; to scoop up soil or earth and pour into (once). aworokin alup akonye: to scoop up soil and throw into someone’s eyes. aiworoor ki-o to call somebody away. adau Lokasuban aiworoor nges: the Creator has called her/him away (i.e. she/he is dead). aiworot ki-o to be calling somebody; to invite. aiworoun ki-o to call somebody to come; to summon or invite. kiworou etelepat: call the boy. aiwosa ki-a to accuse; to sue; to call to court; to go to court. iwosai ngesi: she/he has gone to court (to seek redress). aiwosakin ki-a to plead for somebody; to take up somebody's case; to take each other to court. aiwosis a toll gate; a revenue checkpoint. aiwot1 ki-o to be advanced in age; to become weak due to old age. ewotosi ngesi ikar: she/he is advanced in age. aiwot2 ki-o to shift; to go slowly; to move step by step; to fall slowly; to go slowly down; to grow slowly. iwosi etogo ngol: that house is slowly falling. aiwotor kau ki-o to move slowly backward. aiwotun ki-o to come forward step by step. aiwote ki-o to hire labourers; to be engaged for a wage or anything; to work for anything, even for food or beer. iwoteete kesi emaido: they work for groundnuts. iwotei ngesi akiro: she/he is looking for trouble. aiwoteun ki-o to deserve; to earn. akoto aiwoteun idisirigin: I want to earn a little money. aiwotokin ki-o to shift forward to; to advance; to gain ground. nepe kiwotoki akwap: when it was getting towards evening. aiwoun akipi ki-o to catch dripping water, etc. aiwowa ki-a to roast; to fry. iwowai ngesi ikong: she/he is frying white ants. aiwowaet a frying pan; a griddle; a grid-iron.aiwowaikin ki-a to fry in, for, or somewhere. aiwowas a frying pan; a griddle; a grid-iron.aiwu1 ki-o to empty liquids. aiwu2 to fart or pass wind; to gas or break wind. aiwuc1 ipon ki-a (used with plural objects or repeated action) to purse lips. iwuci ngesi ipon: she/he purses her/his lips. aiwuc2 ki-o to throw (things more than once); to fling. sirikiwuc iboro ngul kinga: do not throw those things outside. kiwuc amor ngun kinga: throw those stones outside. aiwucakin ipon ki-a to purse lips at somebody. aiwucar ki-a to purse lips. aiwucokin ki-a to throw in, at, or to. aiwucor ki-o (used with singular or plural object) to throw away; to fling away; to toss; to throw (a ball). kiwuco acokit na: throw away this potato. aiwucun ki-a to throw this way. aiwud ki-o to prod; to insert (a needle); to poke. iwudi ngesi eswam: she/he prods the rat-hole (to force the rat out). aiwudet a bicycle pump.aiwudokin ki-o to poke in (just once); to insert (a needle or any piercing instrument); to inject; to inoculate or vaccinate; to pump up. aiwuduka ki-a to show discontent, displeasure, or dissatisfaction; to complain; to sigh. koyanga ekoniropit, siriwudukai: take what you’ve earned and don't complain. aiwuduwud ki-o to poke repeatedly; to keep prodding; to look for a hole (by prodding). aiwuk to pull up or uproot heavy things. aiwuk ibilenga: to catch big mud-fish. aiwukek ki-o to be gigantic; to be outstanding; to be prominent (as of high tree or mountain). iwukekei emoru Masaba: Mt. Elgon is prominent. aiwukuukun ki-o to raise up a heavy or difficult thing (from the soil); to lift with difficulty; to pull up (something heavy from the soil) to rise from the dead; to rise with difficulty. aiwulakin ki-a to refuse to obey someone; to disobey. sirikiwulak papakon: don’t disobey your father to go on strike. ewulakinos ipakasin: the porters have gone on strike. aiwulanut1 disobedience; obstinacy; stubbornness. aiwulanut2 ki-a to be disobedient or insubordinate. aiwulor ki-o a corruption of aiwolor: to blow off open; to lift up and away (as of wind). abu ekwam kiwolo asoto: the wind blew the dome of the granary away. aiwum1 ki-a to begin to smell; to begin to rot or corrupt; to putrefy. ewum akiring na: this meat is beginning to smell. aiwum2 ki-a to give a beating to; deal blows to; to maul; to maltreat; to contuse.aiwum3 to wonder; to stand aghast; to be astonished or surprised (not often used in its simple form). aiwumun ki-o to fall heavily from a height. aiwumuumo ki-o to mutter; to confer together in low voices; to talk together in low tones. iwumuumos itunga kotogo: people are murmuring inside the house. aiwumuwumo ki-o (of bees) to drone; (of people) to murmur. aiwuni ki-o to make three; to make a third. aiwuniikin ki-o to make a third; to do for the third time; to make three for. aiwuny1 ki-o to push up; to pull up (of anything); to raise up; to lift up. aiwuny ekume: to pull up the nose. aiwunyokin ipon: to pull up the lips; to show with lips or to point to with lips. aiwuny2 to snort; to blow the nose; to sneeze. awunyar ekume: to blow out the nose; to dilate nostrils i.e. make them wider. aiwunyonor ki-o to keep lifting or raising up; to pout. awunyor ekume: to show contempt (by turning up nose or lips). aiwup1 to thread (beads, etc); to string. aiwup2 to satiate; to wear or fatigue. kawupit eong aswam na: this work has tired me out. kawupata eong ajon: I am sated by beer: I have had enough beer. kawup eong cut ainyam: I have really had my fill of food. aiwupaun ki-o to fall from a height. aiwur to go to bed hungry; to sleep hungry overnight.aiwurut aokot: to have dysentery. iwurusi ngesi: she/he has diarrhoea.aiwuruwuro ki-o to murmur; to mutter, rumble, etc. iwuruwuro akwap: the earth rumbles. inera ngesi kiwuruwuro: she/he speaks in a low tone. aiwut (used with plural object) to pull out (teeth, testes, or anything from ground, etc); to pull out of a hole or socket; to castrate. aiwut ikel: to pull out teeth. aiwut emong: to castrate a bull. aiwut etunganan: to take out power (by witchcraft). aiwuti1 ki-o to sigh. iwutiei ngesi: she/he sighs. iwutiete kesi: they are sighing. aiwuti2 ki-o to sob; to blubber. iwutie ikoku: the child sobs. aiwutionut1 (singular noun F) niggardliness; miserliness; stinginess; close-fistedness.aiwutionut2 ki-o to be niggardly; to be ungenerous aiwuwor ki-o to empty or drink out altogether. aiya to take away; to lead away; to rule; to govern. aiyaga to loosen or unfasten; to untie.aiyagiyag to loosen often; to make very loose. aiyaki ki-a to send on errands; to use; to commission. ai bo iyakie ijo etelepataka?: where are you sending my boy to? aiyakianut1 (singular noun F) obedience; submissiveness; service. aiyakianut2 ki-a to be obedient; to be dutiful or submissive aiyakiar ki-a to consign to; to send somebody; to despatch; to delegate; to commission.aiyakikin ki-a to send to or somewhere (on errand). aiyakitoi ki-a to serve; to minister to; to be obedient to; to be dutiful. ateker ekoto idwe luiyakiaka: the clan loves obedient children. aiyakitonut1 (singular noun F) utilitarianism; submissiveness. aiyakitonut2 ki-o to be useful, submissive, etc aiyakiun ki-a to send this way (on errand). aiyala ki-a to joke; to chat. aiyalaikin ki-a to tell a joke to; to joke to; to converse with. aiyalakin ki-o (Serere) to become negligent. aiyalama ki-a to be glad; to be pleased or jocose; to be grateful; to be delighted or happy. iyalamas kesi aanyun ijo: they are glad to see you. aswam naiyalamare: pleasant work. eyalama: I am glad; thank you.eyalamikinos kesi: they are grateful or thankful. aiyalamikinet compliment; a thank you; gratitude; amenity. aiyalanut1 (singular noun F) tendency to converse; chitchatting. aiyalanut2 ki-a to be fond of chatting; to be good at telling jokes aiyalaun ki-a to speak out (in jest). aiyalayalatoi ki-o to chatter; to jabber. aiyalongong ki-o to be anxious; to fret; to worry or to be worried; to be troubled about. iyalongongoi ijo atitai: you are worried for nothing. aiyalongongoet anxiety; worry; dread; melancholy; trepidation. aiyam ki-a (used with plural object) to take gently or carefully; to handle gently; to put carefully; to mollify; to do cautiously; to lift gently; to treat gently. kiyam ikaboro: treat my belongings (things) with care. aiyam akonye k'ajon: to wash the face of a young child with beer (a traditional ceremony practised on the child when 1-2 years old purportedly to prevent sickness). aiyamakin ki-a to calm down or become quiet, peaceful (as of anything disturbed or painful). aiyamakina ki-a to be at peace. aiyamakit ki-o to do carefully or gently; to take, carry, or treat carefully. kiyamakite asaduku na: treat this box carefully. aiyamam a corruption of aijamam: to be comfortable; to keep calm; to sit idly; to be gentle. ijamamaete kesi: they are comfortable. aiyamar ki-a to take away or to put away gently, quietly; to take wholesale (i.e. everything). to go away softly (without disturbing anyone). abu ngesi kiyamar: she/he went away quietly. aiyamitoi ki-o to walk or do things cautiously or carefully; to walk gently. aiyamiyam ki-a to persuade; to entreat; to beg gently; to soothe; to pamper; to placate; to please; to humour. aiyamun ki-a to bring gently or quietly. kiyamu amot ngin: bring that pot carefully to come quietly or gently. kiyamunos togo: come softly inside the house. aiyany to see; to look up; to visit; to inspect; to pay a visit; to guard. abuni aiyany ijo: I shall come to pay you a visit. aiyap ki-a to be slow; to hesitate; to go slowly; to delay or be late; to loiter; to lag behind. ibu ijo kiyap k’orot: you delayed on the way. aiyapakin ki-a to hit lightly (once only); to alleviate. aiyapar ki-a to slow down. kiyapaa amotoka: slow down the car i.e. reduce its speed to go last of all. aiyapepera ki-a to be humble; to be gentle, meek, mild; to be polite or merciful. iyapepera apese ngin: that girl is good and gentle. aiyapeperanut (singular noun F) courtesy; gentleness; humility; meekness, etc. aiyapeperikin ki-a to humble oneself for. aiyapiyap1 ki-a to do carefully, slowly, lazily; to go somewhere slowly. ilosi iyapiyapi: you go or do carefully, slowly.kiyapiyap ikoku naarai edit: beat the child lightly for it is young. aiyapo ki-o to swear or take an oath; to vow; to abjure. iyapoi ngesi : she/he is (they are) swearing. abu ngesi kiyapo ebe mam icaki ore: she/he swore never to go home again. aiyapoet abjuration, refusal; swearing.aiyapun1 ki-a to take a little off; to encroach slightly. aiyapun2 ki-o to come last of all (slowly); to come slowly this way. aiyapunun ki-a to eke out; to remove a little at a time; to be thrifty, economical. kiyapununei ikapunukon: be frugal, thrifty, or economical with your money (singular). aiyar to kill; to slaughter; to murder; to slay. eyari: she/he/it kills or is lethal, deadly. eyarete: they kill, they are fatal or deadly. aiyar luipu: to massacre. aiyar ebole: to break a promise; to breach a contract or a vow. aiyar etau: to disappoint; to break somebody’s heart.eyareiki nges aberu: he took a second wife. aberu naiyareikina the 2nd wife. aiyaror ki-o to beg sorrowfully. aiyarorotoi ki-o to keep on begging sorrowfully; to live on alms or by begging. inyo bo iyarorotoi ijo?: why do you go about begging? aiyasetait an appendix (in a book); an annex; an addition. aiyat ki-a to accrue; to increase; to augment; to add; to increase, by adding; to annex; to extend (power or riches); to say further; to give more. aiyatakin: to add to. aiyatun: to make bigger, greater. aiyat akiro: to exaggerate. iyatunitos ikoku ngin igoen: clothes make that child look bigger.aiyat aiyatakin ki-a to do again; to repeat; to add to; to increase; to augment; to extend (power or riches); to annex; to give more to; to proceed; to appeal (in court). kiyatak abeei auni: add three eggs. aiyatakinet an increase; the addition; the repetition; the increment. aiyatanakin ki-a to keep adding; to keep exaggerating; to do continually. iwuta ijo da aiyatanakin amuunyu (esukaali) akiro: you (singular) are also exaggerating the story. aiyaya1 agaria (singular noun F) a way or method of fishing. aiyaya2 agaria ki-a to fish. aiye1aiye2aiye3aiyecunaiyed (of eyes) to blink; to crush lice. aiyed akonye: to screw up eyes; (of eyes) to blink or twinkle. aiyedar ki-a to suck in the abdominal muscles; to work very hard; to be bent on finishing work; to have one’s whole mind on the work. iyedarit ikoku: the child has refused to eat. kiyeda adaun aswam kon lolo: work hard to finish your work today. aiyedar akoik: to pull in or to contract the stomach. aiyediyedo ki-o to be inactive, feel lazy (after overeating). aiyeduko ki-o (as of a sick person or dying animal) to be breathing slightly. iyeduko ngesi: she/he/it is breathing faintly. aiyek1 ki-a to postpone; to put off matters; to remove or to move out of reach. kiyeka ekonitogo ngina: build your house there (i.e. remove it from here). kinyek aiyek akiro: don’t postpone matters. kinyek aiyek emusaago: don’t postpone the case. aiyek2 ki-a to shake; to rattle (anything). aiyek akaen: to shake a rattle (a gourd with pebbles - as a charm by witchdoctors). aiyekakin1 ki-a to take further away. aiyekakin2 ki-a to reach something to somebody; to hand over to; to promote (in rank or level). kiyekakinai ekalaamu: reach me the pencil. aiyekanar ki-a to keep postponing. aiyekar ki-a to take away from here, remove, carry away; to alienate; to send or put further away. kiyeka ikoniboro acekwap: take your things elsewhere. eyeka ngesi etauke kaneka: she/he has alienated her/his affections from me. kiyeka eicolong ngina: put this chair over there. aiyeket a rattle; anything that makes a rattling noise. aiyekun ki-a to bring near. kiyekutu akinei ne: bring the goats near here. aiyel ki-a (Serere) to strew; to scatter.kiyelasi etogo: pull that house down. aiyelar2 ki-o (Serere) to disperse; to scatter; to break up (as of clouds, etc). eyelaros idowon: the clouds have dispersed. aiyeliyel ki-a (Serere) to scatter; to disperse.aiyem to make or cut a way through the bush or high grass. aiyem abwas: to break through the hedge or enclosure. aiyem ekitwi: to break through the bush; to cut through the bush. koyem ekitwi karai ikoto adumun inyamat: clear away the bush (make a new garden) if you want food. aiyem etogo: (formerly) to break open the roof of a house at twin dances when the uncle of twins cannot get in through the door. aiyen (Serere) to tie; to knot; to bind (as when making a roof or granary); to fasten; to bind (to a promise or to secrecy); to pack up; to bind (as of certain foods), cause constipation. aiyen baa ba: to tie firmly or tightly. aiyen ekingok: to say nothing about what you know. koyen iboro kon kolot: pack up and go. ejaas nuk’ayenitos eong angajep: I am bound to secrecy. emuogo ejeni aiyen akoik: cassava is good food for diarrhoea, that is, it binds the stomach. aiyen otuja: to imprison. eyenit lolo aberu etau: the woman has tied a rope round herself on account of pain. aiyen imugug: to die; to pass away.aiyeng2 ki-a to breathe. eroko ngesi iyenga: she/he/it is still breathing. iyengi ngesi: she/he/it is having a rest. iyenga ngesi: she/he/it is breathing . aiyeng3 ki-a to rest; to pause; to take a holiday. aloto idwe aiyeng: the children have gone on holiday. alosi aiyeng: I am going for a holiday. aiyengakin ki-a to breathe over; to pant; to take a holiday or a rest somewhere; to pause somewhere. aiyenganakin ki-o to pant; to gasp. aiyengar1 ki-a to breathe aside. kiyenga awai, erono eiyengane kon: breathe aside, your breath is bad. aiyengar2 ki-a to breathe in (inhale); to draw breath. aiyenganar apuru naemasiatar ice esigala: to passive smoke. aiyengun ki-a to relax; to breathe out (exhale); to pause; to give oneself a respite, retire from work. kiyengu ber (singular); kiyengutu ber (plural): have a rest (relax awhile). aiyengunet a comma; a resting-place or point; the interlude; a sigh; a rest. aiyeniyen ki-a (Serere) to tie round; to coil round; to entwine; to wind by coiling. aiyeniyen ausi akeju: to tie a bandage on the leg.eyeniyenaki ikalol auno bon: the kid has entangled itself with a rope. to tie several things together for someone. aiyepaiyer1aiyer2 to take or to cut a small piece of cloth or hair, meat; (of eyes) to close a little; to nibble at (like goats, etc). koyer akonye ikwenyi: close the eyes a little. koyerutu akiring itubete: cut the meat into small pieces. ayerun: cut towards. ayerar: cut away, off. ayerakin: to cut for someone. koyerakinai edimaido kape: give me some groundnuts to roast.aiyet1 ekiror to give a name; to nickname.aiyet2 ki-a to sip hot tea, soup, etc; to suck through teeth or from hand. iyesi ngesi ecaai apaarasia kere: she/he always sips tea. kinyaritai ijo aiyet ecaai lok'epucit: you have been invited to a tea party. aiyet3 to cut from the surface (as of meat); to slice; to cut from top; to carve. apupi bala eyesete akimai: I hear a noise as if they were harvesting millet.iyetanari ijo ijon idis idis aitodol amerikin: you will sip that beer till you get drunk. aiyetar ki-a to draw in (liquid); to sip, suck up; to make a sucking or a sipping noise. iyetarit lolo etunganan ngol: he has been sipping (beer) today; he is tipsy or drunk. sirikiyeta asupu: do not drink the soup. aiyetun ki-a to suck up (snuff, beer, tea, etc); to sip by oneself; to draw in smoke or one’s breath. aiyeyea1 whispers; secrets. aiyeyea2 ki-o to whisper; to speak softly; to do secretly.aiyi1 aokot (of blood) to flow; to bleed. eyiete aokot: the blood is flowing. eyiete ikumesika: my nose is bleeding. eyiete eong ikumes: I am bleeding through the nose: my nose is bleeding. aiyi2 ki-o to agree; to answer; to echo; to reply; to acknowledge one’s presence when called; to respond to a call. mam ijo iyii karai kinyaritai: you don’t answer when called. iyiete imor: the hills echo. aiyi3 ki-o to cool by fanning, stirring or blowing on. iyie ekwam amwanus: the wind lessens the heat. kiyi akima komat lokadekan: cool the porridge and let the sick man drink it. aiyiikin: to cool for. kiyiik ikoku akile: cool the milk for the child (to drink). aiyi4 to favour; to speak in favour of; to side with, protect, guard against; to separate fighters; to rescue. koyiata luejios ngul: separate those fighters. aitiyi: to cause, make to rescue, guard, etc. aiyiar to save from, rescue from, protect from, guard from. koyiarai kanekaronon: save me from evil. aiyiciic akonye ki-a to look around, be curious. aiyid1 ki-a (Serere) to wag; to shake the tail; to flirt. aiyid ekori: to wag the tail. iyidi ekingok ekori: the dog wags its tail. aiyid iselio: (of a very fussy person) to rush here and there. aiyid iselio bala nak'edaan akain: to be rushing about nervously like a wife going to a co-wife’s burial. aiyid2 ki-a to put away quickly; to hide quickly. eyidi ngol atap: he eats the food quickly. aiyidakin: to hide for. aiyidar: to hide away quickly. aiyid3 to be satiated, full up with food; to satiate. esik lok'ao kisunyari aiyid: honey is very satiating. aiyidiyid ekori ki-a (of a dog) to keep wagging the tail. aiyidiyidaar ki-o (of a person) to be very tall; (of hill, tree, etc) to be very high. emoru Masaba iyidiyidaara kuju: Mt. Elgon is very high. Odele iyidiyidaara noi: Odele is very tall. aiyiikin1 ki-a to allow by saying yes; to permit by saying yes. kiyiikis ngul alosit: let these people go free. eyiikitos: they allow. aiyiikin alosit: to set free. aiyiikin2 ki-o to acknowledge a call; to agree; to answer when called. eyiikis idwe iworotoi: the children have answered when called. aiyikinyiny ki-a to have big fat cheeks. iyikinyiny nges: she/he has fat cheeks. aiyil ki-a to swing things round. aiyil akuwan: to swing the body (being very busy or in dancing). aiyil iselio: to be alarmed. aiyilakin ki-a to return, go back at once or quickly; to rush back; to hide quickly. abu ngesi kobu kosodi aiyilakin ore: she/he came and went back home quickly. eyilakin emir kaike: the rat rushed back into its hole (on perceiving danger). aiyilar1 ki-a to run away, turn away quickly. abu ngesi kobu kosodi bobo aiyilar: she/he/it came and then turned away quickly. aiyilar2 ki-a to fling or throw away. kiyila ibore ngin kinga: throw that thing away. to turn away quickly. aiyilarar ki-a to be thin, emaciated, with a big head. aiyiligaar ki-a to swing and throw away. aiyililitoi ki-o to rush about; to dribble about (as with football); to wander about; to be restless. iyililitoi ikoku ngin: that child is restless. aiyilitoi ki-o to move about quickly, turn from place to place; to be fussy. aiyiliyil ki-a to swing the of body, arms or things round. iyiliyilete idwe akanin ekerete: the children swing their arms when running. aiyilonor ki-o to have palsy; to keep collapsing or becoming unconscious. aiyilor1 ki-o to faint; to be unconscious (from beer, sickness, etc); to get fits; to be epileptic. aiyilor etida: to be frenzied with dancing. iyilorit aberu etida: the woman is frenzied by the healing dance. aiyilor amat ajon: to be drunk and unconscious with beer drinking. aisiiloor: to cause to faint; to drown; to be under anaesthetics. aiyilor2 ki-o to knock or give a knock on; to hit or crack; to be stunned.aiyilun ki-a to hurry back this way, return at once. kiyilu emopiira atipet: be quick, kick the ball this way. eyilunos kesi naarai adumutu akiro kangina: they have returned at once because they got into trouble over there. aiyim ki-a (of anything) to press down.aicik. aiyin1 (of tuberous food, such as potatoes or cassava) to be underdone; to fail to get cooked properly. eyinitos acok: the potatoes are not completely boiled or roasted. ayinata, ayina acok: the potatoes are underdone. aiyin2 to waste; to wither away; to become thin, emaciated. aiyin ikoku ngin akuwan: that child has become thin. aiyin3 to give many things to; to give too many. aiyina ki-a to become moist, wet, damp, mouldy. iyinatos igoeneka: my clothes are damp, moist. elupe loiyinat: wet clay. aiyinaikin ki-a to be too moist, damp, mouldy for. keyinaikit eong etogo: this house is too damp for me. aiyinat ki-o (Serere) to be damp, humid; to be moist; to have moisture. iyinat ne: it is damp here. iyinatos itogoi luka Iteso: the houses of the Iteso are damp. iyinat ngol akan: he is rich, well to do. iyinatos ikagoen: my clothes are damp (singular: iyinat egoe: the dress is damp).aiying ki-o to look for something by thrusting a stick or spear where it is expected to be; to fish with spear, as for mudfish - spearing the mud at random. aiyingiying ekori: to sit uneasily. aiyingiying ekori ki-o to shake body as of one sitting restlessly; to sit restlessly. iyingiyingi ngesi ekori iboyie: she/he sits restlessly (literally, she/he sits shaking her/his tail). aiyingiying epii: to shake the drinking tube in the beer-pot (in order to clear it). aiyingokin to fish with spear for someone or somewhere. alosi aiyingokin ikakoku ebileng: I am going to catch a mud-fish (with a harpoon) for my child. aiyingor ki-o to feel with a stick or spear under water (as of one looking for fish or a rower of boat piercing the mud when rowing with a pole). aiyiniyina ki-a (Serere) to whimper; to cry softly.aiyiny1 ki-a to whistle. aiyiny2 ki-o a corruption of aiying: to fish with spear by spearing. aiyiny3 (used with plural object) to tell off; to ridicule. sirikiyiny itunga: don't tell off or ridicule people. aiyinyakin (used with singular or plural object) to tell off someone; to ridicule someone. aiyinyiyiny ki-a to feel cold; to feel itchy. keyinyiyinyi eong akuwan, akoto neemwana: I feel cold, I want a warm place. kakoto eong akuwan aipi naarai keyinyiyinyi: my body is itching, I want to scratch myself. aiyir ki-a to taste something. kiyir ber ajon: first taste the beer.aiyirakin: to taste for or somewhere; (of people) to taste each other (obscene). aiyiria1 ki-a to look all round, go round in circles, to be confused; to be giddy or dizzy.; (of earth) to turn round or revolve; (of head) to turn, be dizzy. iyiriai akou: she/he is confused. iyiriai emaase: the locusts fly round in circles. aiyiria akou: to be dizzy. iyiriai lo bala ebang: this man here is like a fool. iyiriai akwap: the earth revolves. akakou iyiriai: I am dizzy. aiyiria ajo: to be drunk with sleep; to be overcome with sleep. iyiriai ngol adeka: the sickness confuses him, causes him to roam about. aiyiria2 ki-a to wander about aimlessly; to roam about; to rove aiyiriar ki-a to cause to roam about; to confuse. aiyiriayir ki-a (of a person, wind or water) to whirl round; to be stupid. aiyiriyir1 ki-o to appear as a mirage; to be deep down; to be precipitous, abysmal; to have a big view. ejai ayiriyir kwap: there is a deep abyss below. kongolia ngina elwana ngina, eyiriyiri ecor: look over, there is the mirage of the lake far off. karai kibwo kane komoru Apesur, eyiriyiri Serere noi: if you stand here at Moru-Apesur rock, you have a good view of Serere. aiyiriyir2 ki-o to walk quickly; to walk fast. aiyiror ki-o to disappear utterly. amoot eong akabore, konye ayiror: I looked for that thing of mine, but it is lost completely. eyiroros ikaboro kakonye: my things got lost under my eyes.aiyisinit an armlet, bangle, wristlet made of iron; wire in general; brass bangle. aiyisit ki-o to be in want (of anything); to be in need of. apoloor etelepat, iyisit do aberu: the boy is big, he wants to marry. eyisit eong isirigin: I am in want of money. aiyisiyisonor ki-o to swing head from side to side to show dislike or disgust (at something bad). aiyisokin ki-o to sit in the middle of people; to sit in the centre of anything. kiyisokin ijo amotoka: sit in the middle of the car. aiyit1 akituk ki-a to pay dowry. iyisi ngesi akituk: he is paying the dowry. aiyit2 ki-a to flow, well up; to leak; to seep out, trickle down. eyisi ecor: the water wells up from the well. eyisi amot: the pot leaks. aiyit3 ki-o to remember; to keep in mind; to bring to mind, recall to mind; to recollect. aiyit4 ki-o to wish; to want; to like; to desire; to require, request. eyit ikoku ajo, koyangaasi: the child wants to sleep, take it away. iyisito idwe abolia: children want to play. aisiyit: to cause to want to. isiyit ekooti aitwar ngesi: the court requests that she/he should be set free. aiyit5 (Serere) to sharpen; to point (as of pencil or spear). eyisi ngesi ekekalaamu: she/he sharpens her/his pencil. koyit ekalaamu ngol: sharpen that pencil. eyisi ngesi ekalaamu: she/he sharpens the pencil. aiyitar akituk ki-a (Serere) to pay away bride price; to show cows for dowry to in-laws.aiyitokin ki-a to do, start work late (after others). aiyitokin apotuun: to be pregnant after years of barrenness. aiyitokin abunere: to come late. eyitokis idwe aponere osomero: the children are late for school. to call somebody for a job. keyitokinit lokapolon eong aceswam: the boss has given me another job. to remember, call to mind. aiyitokin apotuun: to be pregnant after years without bearing a child. aiyitor1 ki-o to invite somebody to go away; to call apart, away. emamei Opejo, iyitorit nges inacike: Opejo is not there, his sister called him away. to call one another for some reason. aiyitor2 ki-o to remember things or persons far off or left behind to become homesick. aiyitun ki-o to remember, recollect, keep in mind, bring to mind, or recall to mind; to call hither. kiyitutu akiro nuka atukot: remember what was said in the meeting. kolot kiyitu ngesi kobu atipet: go and call her/him to come at once. aiyitunet remembrance; commemoration; nostalgia. aiyiya1 ki-a (of a person, fire, wind) to calm down. aiyiya2 ki-a to plane, smooth; to make level. aiyiya akiro: to smooth, settle matters. kiyiya erot: level out the road. aiyiyaikin ki-a to level the floor or anything. aiyiyakin ki-a (of man when excited, of fire too hot, of wind or of liquids too hot) to calm down. to make level, even; to plane. adau edou aiyiyakin: the storm has calmed down. aiyiyakina ki-a to be flat, even; to remain quiet. kiyiyakin ijo: (you) be quiet. aiyiyi ki-o to cool by ladling up and down, or by blowing or fanning. kiyiyi akima: cool down the porridge. aiyiyo ki-a to console; to soothe (as of person in grief). aiyiyoit a variety of small fish.aiyodo ki-o (Serere) to get by flattery; to gatecrash. iyodoi ngesi esigala: she/he is trying to get a cigarette by flattery.aiyodoun ki-o (Serere) to take or get something for oneself by flattery.aiyogakin ki-a to greet for; to salute on behalf of; to thank for to greet one another. keyogakinos ber: let us first greet each other. aiyogiyog ki-a to loosen; to cause to be shaky. aiyogog1 ki-a (of a person) to be dressed or ornamented. iyogogoi aberu ngin noi: that woman is well-dressed or wears many ornaments. aiyogog2 ki-a (of a plant) to be laden with fruit. iyogogoi emucuuga: the orange-tree is laden with fruit. aiyokiyok ki-a to rattle; to tinkle (as of bells or coins in the pocket). iyokiyokas isirigin koisaoke: the money rattles in her/his pocket. aiyom ki-a to break to pieces; to crush with the feet (something dry); to smash to bits; (of a person) to wash the face. aiyomiyom ki-a to smash completely; to break completely. aiyong to fear; to stand in awe of; to be dismayed; to be afraid of; to revere; to dread. aiyoyo ki-o to encourage or urge on (so that she/he performs better); to praise or cheer.aiyu ki-a to agree; to allow; to suffer; to let; to tolerate. aiyud to satiate; to reduce a gap; to narrow. kayud eong emaido: I have eaten enough groundnuts (the groundnuts have sated me). aiyudakin epelu ki-a to lessen; to slacken a work; to decrease or diminish a task; to cut a task; to lighten a task. kiyudak ekapelu: lighten my task (work). aiyug ki-a to run while stooping with arms moving up and down. aiyug ikeperin: to shrug (move shoulders up and down, as a sign of helplessness or refusal). aiyuk ki-o to burn slightly (as with hot iron); to singe; to sear; to cauterise (as burning of rotten flesh with hot iron). aiyup1 (Serere) to weary; to wear out; to tire out; to fatigue. kayupit eong aswam na: this work has fatigued me.aiyup2 to string beads, fish, or bits of meat. aiyup atip: to string beads. aiyup agaria: to string fish. aiyup akiring: to string pieces of meat. aiyup ikel: to pick or clean teeth. aiyuun ki-a to believe; to agree to; to accede to; to abide by; to accept; to comply with. aiyuunanut1 (singular noun F) credulity; naivety; gullibility; submissiveness. aiyuunanut2 ki-a to be credulous, unsuspecting, gullible, or amenable aiyuunet approbation; belief; faith; conviction. aiyuunit (singular noun F) faith; belief; conviction; creed; doctrine; dogma; persuasion. emamei nges aiyuunit: she/he has no faith. ajaagi a jug; a jar; a flacon; a carafe. ajaanakin to be often present, attend at a meeting or at school. ejaanakin ngesi duc toma aisisias: she/he is always present in school: she/he attends. ajaanara to be related to, have relations (to be lovers); to be acquainted. kijaanara ngesi ka eong: we know each other. ajai, ijai or ejaas I am, you are, or they are present. ajaikin to be with; to have; to be present. ajaikinos itelepai osomero: the boys are at school.ajaikina to have; to be with. aberu ngin ejaikina k’akoik: that woman is having a pregnancy. ajakaanut chieftaincy; reign; kingdom; government; regime; rule; administration; management. ajakait a mistress; madam; mrs (used in addressing a woman).ajakakin to pull the mouth open, pull asunder. kojakak lokadekan ekia: open his mouth and pour medicine down the sick man’s throat. ajakar to drag; to tear off or tear open; to stop a calf or child from suckling (to wean). to tear oneself away; to drag oneself away. ajakar eong kane: I have torn, dragged myself away from here. ajakar ikoku: to wean a child from suckling. ajaket pincers, tongs, or forceps; a bridle.ajakilil to have thick, drooping, sagging, or flabby lips. ajakun to extricate, force open, tear open, tear off towards speaker; to save from. ajakun aunoi: to untie, undo, release the ropes. ajakun itunganan kotoma aunoi: to untie, release a person. ajakun akiro: to break silence. ajakun amisiri: to clean a plot of weeds by weeding properly. ajakun akituk: to restart conversation after silence. ajakus to be present; to have; to be with. ejok ajakus k’isirigin: it is good or necessary to have money.akoto ajakut k’idwe k’itunga: I want to be with people’s children. ajakut ka: to have.ajalakin to let; to allow; to suffer; to permit, laissez faire; to release; to forsake or surrender. ajalakin akuwan alelasia: to indulge oneself, spoil, treat, pamper, pander to. kojalak eenat ngol kolot: release that prisoner, let him go. ajalamuun to become warm; to be lukewarm. aitajalamuun: to warm up. akipi nuajalamak: lukewarm water. ajalijal to have one’s mouth watering; to dribble, drool, or slobber; to let saliva leave the mouth; to salivate (like a dog or child, old people); to let the tongue hang out. ekingok ejalijalete aimul: the dog salivates, slobbers - its mouth waters. ajamak to waddle; to walk like a fat goose or a fat man. ai bo ijamakete yesi?: where are you fat people waddling to? ajamat a quagmire, swamp, marsh, or bog. ajanit a broom made of grass; a grass used for sweeping, Sporobolus pyramidalis.
a Jopadhola woman (the Luo speakers of Tororo district)

a word in the Adhola language. Ajapadola: the Jopadhola women; the Adhola language. ajar (of rope, trousers or anything tight) to get loose; to become unfastened. ajarar to loosen (rope, trousers or anything tight). kojara auno naka akine: loosen the rope of the goat. ajararos ajon: the beer has become thin (not too thick, not too watery). ajararoroi to survive, subsist or to exist just in a needy state. ajarosikin (of trousers, cows, etc) to tie; to fasten.to be tied; to be tight. ajarotor to unfasten; to loosen, untie. kojaroto auno koloit: loosen the rope from the pole. ajarujarun ki-a to become loose, slack; to be loose, slacken. ajarujarun akoik kanuka etengei: the stomach has become slack with hunger. Ajarun1 (singular noun F) the Resurrection (Christ’s coming back to life three days after his death on the cross; or the coming back to life of all the dead at the Last Judgement). ajarun naka lukatwak: the resurrection of the dead. eketajaran: a saviour; rescuer; reviver. ajarun2 to come back to life; to resurrect; to revive. ajarun3 to spread out millet, groundnuts, etc. to dry.ajarun4 to loosen, disentangle, unfasten, slacken, widen. kojaru auno, eketaki itaok: loosen the rope, it is strangling the calf. ajarunet a new grain (literally, that which brings back life); new food; a new harvest meal.ajaus to be present; to exist; to attend at. ajai: I am present. ejaas: they are present. abu kajai: I was present. ajai eong togo: I am in the house. ejaas kesi togo: they are in the house. kojai Lokasuban mamakus: God be with you all. (note: when followed by an adjective or verb, ajaus is not translated). ajok: I am ok or good. ajaus ka: to have; to contain; to own; to be with; to possess; to be or to belong to. ejai eong aberu: I have a wife. kija eong ka aberu: I am with a wife. ejai eong etogo: I own a house . ejaas kesi k’angor: they have women; they are with women. ejaas kesi ka ekingok or ejai kesi ekingok: they have a dog.iboro luejaatar ngesi: her/his belongings. ejaas swii: they are plentiful; they are abundant. ajean a potter; a weaver; a mat-maker; a builder or maker of grass-and-mud barns. ajees military; relating to the armed forces. igoen lukajees: military clothes – army uniforms.to be round; (of a snake) to coil; to lie in folds or coils. adum eong emun ejeikit aikit toma amot: I found a snake coiled in a pot. to lie or stand or sit round something. ajeikinos ikiliok amot k’ajon: men have sat round the beer pot. ajejait a niece.acenika: my niece. Ocen and Acen are children of a sister. ajeje a honey-guide bird, Melichneutes robustus. ajele a ring-neck dove; a wild pigeon.ajeluukot a valley; a vale; a dale; a dell.ajen to be related; consanguine. itunga luejenas mam etiakas: people who are related do not separate. ajena affinity; kinship; blood relationship. ajenereita an electric power generator. ajengan a medical surgeon; a skinner or flayer of animals. ajengetait a surgical wound or scar; an incision; a suture. ajengio (singular noun F) a surgical operation; surgery. ajenikin to foresee, notice; to know by; to take to heart. ijenikini ijo biai ebe etepi lolo edou?: how did you know that it would rain today? kojenik akakiro: take my words to heart. aitejenikin: to inform, send a message. aitejenunet: a message, sign. ajenun1 cognition; discerning; comprehension. ajenun2 to get to know; to learn; to experience, fathom, comprehend. to know; to find out. mam ngesi epedori ejenun: she/he cannot know. to know one another; to be acquainted with one another. kijenun eong ka Oromait: Oromait and I have got acquainted. ajenun cut: certitude. ajenunet a sign; trademark; a mark; a token; a wonder; a miracle; an omen; a symbol; a musical note. ajenyar to finish off killing, or to finish off eating food. kojenya inyamat ngul kaloto: finish off that food and we go.ajepaanut (singular noun F) a habit of cutting; a habit of cheating; a habit of plotting. ajokit epol nges ajepaanut k’otunga: the devil is in the habit of cheating (plotting against) people. ajepakin to cut, fell a tree for somebody; to kill somebody on behalf of or by order of somebody. ajepar to cut away, lop off; to fell; to intrigue or plot against the life of somebody (by poison or otherwise). ejai loekoto ajepar aijarakon: somebody is plotting to kill you. ajepasit a cut; a gash; a wound. ajepejep to keep on cutting; to keep on cheating; (of heart) to keep throbbing; (of head) to keep paining; to pulsate. ajepunun to cut for oneself; to prune, clear a tree of its branches. ajepunun atap: to take very big lumps of food. ajepunun etunganan: to keep on cheating (or plotting against) a person. ajeret a lasso; a rope; a loop.ajesan down there; on the slope; in the valley. ajesat a valley; a slope; acclivity. ajesumot a valley; a vale; a gorge; a dale; a dell.ajetakin to pull the trigger of a gun; to fire (a gun); to light match (a pipe); to set fire (to grass); to start (a car or motor cycle); to fold (a chair).ajeun to make round; to mould with clay.ajiikin to fight for somebody; to race for. ajiikini eong Iteso akecepolou: I will fight for the honour of the Iteso. ejiikinit ngesi aijarake: she/he fights for her/his dear life. ajiis fighting place; arena; battle field; a fight. ajiis nasodit: the first fight or battle. ajijim1 (singular noun F) sweetness; taste; tastiness. ajijim2 to be sweet, tasty, or pleasant. iboro ngul kere ajijimata: all these things are sweet (tasty). ajijimikin to taste nice; to be tasty to; to be savoury. ajijimun to become sweet, tasty, nice to. ajikilil to have swollen or fat cheeks; to be or become cloudy, overcast; to be sulky, down-hearted, miserable. ijikilil nges eketau: she/he is sulky, down-hearted. ajikitu (singular noun F) deafness. ajimi a wound; an ulcer; a sore. ajingirir (of a bull or a man) thick-necked. ajingirir emorosing to be thick-necked. ajingiriki emong: the thick-necked bull is swaying its head as it walks. ajio war, conflict, combat, warfare, confrontation, hostilities; battle, encounter, skirmish, melee; fight, brawl, struggle.ajionut1 war-like; warring; fondness of fighting. ajionut2 to be war-like or fond of fighting ajior to fight for or about, contend for, race for (something). ejiosi ingokwo kanuka akojo: the dogs are fighting for bones. ajipakin to look at in the distance; to go and find out; to look into the distance.kojipa ngina karai ebunit ngesi: go and see (or find out) if she/he is coming.ejisakit etunganan ngol etogo (lopeti): that man has built a big house. ejisakitai ngesi ajakaanut: she/he has been given a big job or post.ajo1 sleep; rest. adeka naka ajo: sleeping sickness. ajo2 to sleep, nap, or to have a siesta (only used in infinitive). alosi ber ajo aimom: I am going to rest awhile.kojoik akiro ngun: find out about it, straighten that case. kojoik egoe omeesa: spread the cloth on the table. ajokak advantages; usefulness; the value or worth. mam eong adumunit ajokak kotoma aswam kangin: I have not found the value of that work.ajokianakin to approve of always; to agree to always; to benefit always to be good always; to be nice always; to be kind always; to be just always. ajokiar to become good; to become nice; to become just; to become right; to become cured; to become healed to amend. kojokiar k’otunga kere: become or be nice to everybody. akajimi mam ekoto ajokiar: my wound will not heal up. ajokikin to be good, nice, kind to, just for. kajokikitos eong ajon: beer is good for me. kijokikit ijo eong: you are kind to me. to benefit; to profit. aswam ngin mam epedori ajokikin eong: that work cannot benefit me. to approve of. mam kajokikini eong aswamukon: I cannot approve of your work. ajokikinet approval; endorsement; sanction; consent; say-so; support. ajokis goodness; kindness; benefit; usefulness; advantage. ajokit1 a blind worm (believed to be the residence of a demon); a small black snake without a visible head.ajokit2 the devil; Satan; a bad spirit; a demon. ajokokan benefactress; a generous woman. ajokot an ox yoke; a harness. ajokotau a kind-hearted woman; a donor.ajokus naka akuwan: angaleu: health. (note: kijokis in Ateso Atororo means ‘all’. akoto kes kijokis: I want them all). ajoliar to be insipid, tasteless (as food without salt, tea without sugar); (of conversation) to be untruthful, talk nonsense. ajoliaros akonikiro.ajon1 (uncountable noun F) beer; alcoholic drink; booze; brew.aita ajon: to work for beer. amuna ajon: to prepare or make beer, i.e. to brew beer. airedakin ajon: to make much beer. ireded (ajon) (of beer) much. ireded ajon kangina?: (of beer) is it brewed much over there? acuc (uncountable noun F) ‘ajon nuka adakai’ when it is nearly finished - watery and having lost ability to make one drunk. ajon nukadwarak brew with strong alcoholic content. ajon nuewiiny (singular noun F) sweet brew or gruel - one day old. ajon arasai beer that is a little bitter or alcoholic - two days old brew. ajon aperoi or ajon abeitok beer ready to drink - three days old brew. ajon aupaupan (uncountable noun F) brew that is better than ‘aperoi’ - four days old brew. ajon nuasosolok; ajon nuesosol; ajon nuesasamito beer that is overdue for drinking and has gone bad – bad smelling beer. ajon ekamule brew made for sale to the public (commercially) and is not very thick like that for own consumption. ajon ecuwat or ecuat sweetish beer which has been squeezed from the thick beer and sold commercially. adakai (singular noun F) dregs or leftovers of beer after drinking, consisting of particles of grain. emanit or epii a tube for sucking beer. ajon nuebabar bad beer not good for drinking (because it is insipid or astringent). esosol ajon nu: this beer is too old and smelly. aibwany ajon: to drink beer uninvited or by gate-crashing. aidika ajon ki-a to drink much beer. aibwony ajon: to drink beer ravenously or greedily with a beer tube– with the throat making a racket (noise). aidinga ajon: to drink much beer alone. asip germinated sorghum or millet ready to be ground into the flour that will be fermented and roasted for beer making. aicop ajon: to serve fresh or thick beer to drinkers in a pot or calabash. aimur akiria: to ferment flour (mixed with water into a thick paste, put into a big saucepan or clay pot or just wrapped in banana leaves and buried in the ground, for a period of five days or one week) for beer making. akeit a huge frying pan of clay or steel in which fermented dough (amurat) is roasted in the process of beer making. aberu nakamunan ajon a beer brewer or hostess serving beer. aidwom ajon: to eat thick beer without adding water. aike akiria: to fry the fermented dough. aical ajon: to put yeast (ainyales) into sweet thick one-day-old brew to cause fermentation and also to thin it (acalar). ainyales millet or sorghum germinated, dried and ground as yeast for beer making. ajon2 nukakebe tinned beer; tinned brew. ajon3 nukacupa bottled beer; bottled brew.adau atap ajonere: the millet bread has cooled. elosete inyamat ajokere: the food is getting cold. (note how ajonere becomes ajokere in plural) ajongo to stop, cease, or leave; to end. kojongo aimat ajon aipung: stop drinking beer excessively. ajongoikin to leave some for somebody else. kojongoikinoi eong da edicaai: leave me also some tea.ajongoor to stop; to prevent, abolish, forbid. ekotoi ajongoor itunga aimat ajon: they want to stop people from drinking beer. alosi eong ajongoor apero paran: I am going to stop taking my siesta.ajoniar1 (of fire, sun or hot liquids) to become less hot, cool down; (of weather) to calm down, to become calm; (of meat) to remain undone even though being cooked; (of men) to surrender after a fight, to be easy, to be impassive. kipas iso ejie, kikoto ajokiar: we are tired of war, we want a ceasefire. ajokiasi akipi: the water has cooled.ajoniar2 to be raw or not cooked sufficiently. ajoniar akiring na, kinyaka ngesi akim: this meat is not done, boil it again or put it back on fire. (note: the plural of ajoniar is ‘ajokiar’, and happens to be spelled the same as ajokiar: to become good) ajoniarit (of weather) to be calm; (of men) to be easy, impassive. ajonio beer (a sarcastic or abusive reference) ajonis (singular noun F) immaturity; rawness (both of food and of a person’s mental or physical development).ajono calm; calm down; restful; peaceful; cooled down. ajonore to concede; to become cool; (of angry person or animal) to cool down; to be unripe, raw, uncooked. ajono atap: the millet bread has become cold. ekotos inyamat ajokore: the food will be cold. aitojonaar: to allow to cool; to appease (an angry person or animal).ajoola a roll of cloth (new and uncut); a piece of cloth not yet cut and sewn into a dress or tablecloth. ajoora a penthouse; a chicken hut. ajore the military; the armed forces; the defence forces; militia; a territorial army; soldiers; an army (of men or fighting ants); a crowd; a raiding force; the Teso army. ajoris a perch; a place or something to squat on. ajorit to be perched on; to be squatting down. ajoroi a branch, twig, or leaf of ejoroi tree. ajorokin to squat down to work; to do something. ajorokin aiboi: to sit down to rest. ajorokin aswam: to get down to work. kojorok ijo aswamukon: you get down to work. adum eong nges ejorokit aimat: I found him seated to a good drink (perhaps at a wrong time or wrong place). ajosi an important dance in Soroti and Katakwi accompanied with a drum beat from one atenus (big drum) and four ideteta (small drums); a war drum. ajotakin (of moon or sun) to set, go down; to clear throat; to sink. ejotakinit akolong erono lolo: the sun set when it was still blazing hot today. ajotet naka akolong early afternoon, 2:00 pm to 3:00 pm.abuni eong toma apak nak’ajotet akolong (naka ajotakin kakolong: abuni kapak naka alomar k’akolong otuo: I shall come in the early afternoon, I shall come in the late afternoon or late in the afternoon or towards sunset. ajoto to sleep, rest awhile, have a siesta (only used in infinitive). alosi ber ajo aimom: I am going to rest awhile. ajotoet a place where to sleep; drool from the mouth during sleep. ekoto ngesi ajotoet, mam ekoto ace: she/he wants a sleeping place, she/he does not want anything else. ajotokin to sleep somewhere. kojotok ijo lolo oreka: sleep at my home tonight. to make to lean over, put on its side. to sit on one side, lean over, lie on side. ajotoor to go to sleep; to be asleep. ajotoor: ejotoi: she/he is asleep, sleeping . akoto ajotoor: akoto ajo: I want to go to sleep, or she/he had wanted to sleep. ajotooros: they have slept. ejotoete: they are asleep. ajototo a large wading bird, with grey and white feathers, long legs and along neck, Heron. ajoyiar (of a liquid) to cool down; to stretch (of anything, as of baby for rest or sleep; as of a mat - to pull straight); to straighten. kapas eong, akoto ajoyiar akuwan: I am tired, I want to stretch myself. kojoyiasi akanin: stand to attention. to rest, stretch oneself. ekeri emun ejoyiara akuwanake: a snake moves with its body stretched. ajoyiaros itelepai kotolim: the boys are resting in the shade. ajoyiar akiro: to straighten out a case.ajuket1 a brush or instrument for painting. ajuket2 colouring; painting. akoto ajuket naka emodi: I want paint for hair dressing. ajukokin1 to stain, smear with; to mark. kojukonok ngesi akuron: smear him with ashes. ajukokin2 to refuse to. ejukokit ngesi akonikiro: she/he refuses to accept your message.ajukujuk to stain with anything. ajukujukit eong ekakaaso kebuino: I stained my cassock with ink. ajulong hair on fingers or body.ajulongit hair on fingers or body.ajulot a feather; hair on the body (not on the head); eiderdown; fine feathers of birds. ajul nuk’openek a beard; moustache; sideburns. ajul nuk’oponoi: a moustache ajulut a species of bird, a male crimson-breasted shrike. ajungula a branch or a leaf of ejungula plant. ajupakin to pick out for somebody. ejupakini toto ilac kakou k’ikoku: the mother picks lice from the child’s head. ajurakin to lick off; to drink, sip off; to finish drinking liquid for. kojurakinai eong edia ngol: finish the vegetables for me. ajurar to suck up; to sip away; to lick clean; to finish off (cigarettes).ejurari ekapa akile: the cat licks off the milk (from the plate). ajuri1 a kind of vegetable or beans. ajuri2 a syphilitic scar on body (after the syphilitic wounds have healed). ajurung to hang head; to be despondent; to lose heart (as of one who is in trouble); to roam about (despondently or in despair); to wander about. ejurungi ngesi akwap bala ikerepikit kanuka atwanare k’aberuke: he roams about in despair about the death of his wife. ajurungikin to wince, flinch, cringe, recoil, grimace, or make a face. ajurungit to sit bent up, huddled up (on account of cold or rain). ejurungitos akokoroi kere kanuka aterot: the hens sit huddled together on account of the cold. ajurungung to grow despondent; to be despondent, hopeless, low, dejected, downhearted, downcast, unhappy, sad, or pessimistic. ejurungungit ngesi koreke: she/he sits at home full of pessimism about her/his future prospects. ajuruset a plane; sandpaper; an instrument for smoothing things like a pot or granary, or wall or board. ajurusiar to strip off (as of leaves); to make smooth; to plane, make even, polish wood (with sandpaper). to be slippery, smooth, even, polished; to slip; to slide down. ajurusikin to attack; to approach; to catch; to get hold of. ajurusikin ekapa emir: the cat has caught a rat. inyo bo kijurusikinor ijo eong?: why have you attacked me? ajurut to be slippery. ejurut erot: the road (path) is slippery to make smooth (as of board or wall or granary). ajurutaar to be slippery; to slip away, slip a bow knot. akoto ajurutaar (aisi): I want to slip away (to call my friend, etc).ajurutaar to slip (of feet or of things from hands); to miss; to escape, slip away. akoto ekapa aikamun emir, konye aburucaar emir: the cat wanted to catch a rat but it escaped.ajurutaaret a slippery place; a bow (tie a bow); a bow-knot (of shoes); a loop knot. kocoite erot ejaas ajurutaareta: be careful there are slippery spots on the road. ajurutun to strip off (as of leaves from a branch) to come outside for freedom; to slip towards to come; to go at once to speaker. kojurutunos yesi kere: clear out all of you and come this way. ajutor to sit with an angry face, fed up; to mope, sulk, brood, pine, or pout to clean the place where a child, a dog, cat has defecated; to clean away; to refuse altogether. ejutorit ngesi kore: she/he sits at home moping, mooching, or sulking. ajuto ngesi akonikiro: she/he has refused your request entirely.ajwatakin to beat once, give one light blow or stroke.ajwele a ring neck dove; a pigeon.kojweny asaanit: finish (the food on) the plate. adau aberu ya ajwenyar edia kosepuria: the other woman has finished off all her sauce from the pot (using her index finger to gather remnant of food and leaking the finger).akaadi a postcard; any hard piece of paper with one’s picture, etc for identification or containing other information; an immunisation card (given to mothers or prospective parents); a communal drinking, eating and dance party for young adults (especially in Katakwi during Christmas, New Year and Uhuru). akaalait a camel; a dromedary. akaale1 a serving spoon; a ladle; a scoop.akaam to break up the soil for cultivation with a hand hoe; to prepare the soil for early cultivation using a hand hoe; to munch dry food or tough fried meat; (of ruminants – cows and goats) to chew the cud. ekaamete Iteso aloboi: the Iteso prepare gardens for sowing. akaamar to go and prepare soil over there. akaami eong ne, kokaama ijo ngina: I prepare the field here and you over there. akaamikin to prepare soil for somebody or somewhere; to hoe crops. kokaamikinai amanaka: prepare my plot for sowing. ai bo ikaamikini ijo imarekon?: where are you going to break up the soil for sowing your peas? akaawa (singular noun F) coffee beverage.akabaka (any) queen or female hereditary ruler. akabakanut (singular noun F) a king’s reign; a kingship; monarchy; kingdom; sovereignty. akabeera a polythene paper bag. akabo1 a diaphragm. akabo2 to catch with hand or mouth; (as of a football) to catch it by hand or stop it with feet; (of a dog) to catch a piece of food thrown into its mouth.akabwa a bow (for shooting arrows).ekojo long arrow for shooting birds, etc. akacar to lead or drive a man or animal between two or more people, like a bull to the slaughter house. kokacasi emong lo aiyar: take this bull to be killed (lead it, with one man on each side). akadakin1 etau to be disgruntled with; to be sad or disgusted with; to be discouraged or regretful. akadakit eong: I am downhearted; I am sad, feel disgusted. kakadak eong etau: I feel downhearted. akadakin2 to be dismal; to be too few, too little, insufficient, or not enough. akadakinos ikasirigin: I have not got enough money. akadakinet anxiety; annoyance, irritation, infuriation, exasperation, bother, anger, frustration, displeasure. akadakit (singular noun F) melancholy; sad, depressed, downhearted, miserable, down, low, glum. akadapao a veranda; porch; terrace; balcony; loggia; portico.akadit to be lacking, insufficient; to be wanting, deficient, not enough. ekaditos etogo anya: the grass for the house is insufficient. ekadakina eong isirigin: I have inadequate funds. kakadit eong aswam na, akoto ace: this work is not enough or too small for me. akadot salty clay licked by cattle. akae a witchdoctor’s gourd containing pebbles; a rattle. akaguba a harlequin quail. akai a hut, a house, a cabin, a shelter, or a shed; a nest; a pen, a sty, a cage, a stall, or a paddock; a halo round the moon. akai naka ikwenyit: a bird’s nest. akai kadidi a grass, Sporobulus. akaideit a kind of vegetable marrow or edible gourd; (in Karamoja) a pumpkin. akain a co-wife; a fellow wife. akais- (numeral prefix) tens of. akais akany: tens of five; fifty. akais aare: tens of two; twenty. akais akany kaare: tens of five and two; seventy. akaje (singular noun F) madness; delirium, fever, hallucination, restlessness, confusion, frenzy, ecstasy, elation, insanity, or disorientation.akaka akiro: to talk rubbish or nonsense. ekakaete kesi anya: they are gathering grass (rubbish). akakaar1 to hasten away from; to run away in fright; to rush pell-mell in flight.akakaar eong akerit emun: I ran away in fright from a snake. akakaar2 to clean (a plot by taking away grass); to clear rubbish (from compound etc). akakaet a rake; an implement for gathering rubbish. akakakin to run suddenly after.akakanyaar to clear the throat. akakanyaar erokokonyit: to spit out phlegm. akakanyaar akiro: to show disgust for what is said. akakanyun akiro to spit out; to despise offensive language of others; to show disgust at bad language.akakas to walk with big long strides or steps; to hurry. ai bo lolo ikakasi ijo?: where are you off to, with your long steps? akako hailstone; ice; frost; a bead (resembling hailstone, but transparent). ikakoikit: icy; glacial; polar. akakot hailstone; ice; frost; a bead.

a woman native to parts of Arua district of Uganda west of the Nile; a word in the Kakwa language. Akakwa: the Kakwa language; the Kakwa women. akal a reedbuck, Redunca fulvorufula.akalaani a clerk; a secretary; amanuensis. akalabata a wooden sandal; a clog.akalanyanut (singular noun F) laziness, idleness, indolence, lethargy, sluggishness. akalas a grass torch; a flat-topped grinding stone.akalaya (formerly) a metallic utensil mostly used for carrying bathing water; a trough.
(title of) Her Worship the wife of Emorimor (the cultural leader of Iteso)

a queen consort of a reigning emorimor. akalol a young goat.erai amerekek ngin akambak: that sheep is a come-back, i.e. it got lost in the bushes of Teso while being driven away by rustlers.akamera a camera (a gadget for taking photographs). akamole a girl pretending to work. akamu the dry season; summer. akamuran a sister-in-law; a mother-in-law; the wife’s sister. akamurak: all female in-laws generally.akan a hand; an arm; a signature; a handwriting; a thieving habit. akoto aikwac akan: I want to write (to scratch the handwriting).etau k’akan: palm of the hand. toma akan: in the hand. akan k’etom: an elephant trunk. ejai ikoku ngin akan: that child is a thief.kolot akan ya: go to the other side. akan k’emeleku: the handle of a hoe or plough. eokitos akanin: to have nothing in the hands; to be empty-handed. abunit eong eokitos akanin: I have come empty-handed i.e. without money, poor at that time. akang F my friend; my dear; dear me. okwe akang konyou, nukon nupe inerai: my dear lady go away, it is you they are talking about. (akang used in a salutation or beginning a letter to a woman: Dear Madam). itunganan: my dear. akang atunganan ngin erono!: that wife of mine is bad news! akanga to speak openly; to speak straight out; to do deliberately; to do openly; to do purposely; to do knowingly. abu eong akanga ainyam akiring apaarit naikanyet: I ate meat on Friday deliberately. ibu kokanga akanga?: did you do it deliberately?akangaar to go or to do uninvited. akangaar ekesa ngol togoka atitai: he went into my house uninvited, uncalled for. akangaar ngesi aimat ecaai: she/he went off for tea (by herself/himself) uninvited. akangaikin to do deliberately; to tell deliberately, openly, in his face. alimokin akangaikin: to tell straight into somebody’s face; to tell deliberately. akangas1 accident, mishap, misfortune, disaster, calamity, catastrophe, mistake; hazard, danger, risk, peril, vulnerability. adumun akangas: to have or be involved in an accident. akangas naka amotoka: a car accident. earit akangas naka agaali itunga luipu ko Kachumbala: a train accident killed many people at Kachumbala.akangas2 the lower and bigger of the two traditional grinding stones.akangaun to come uninvited, uncalled for; to do without notice. inyo bo ikangaunor ijo ne?: why did you come here without notice? akansila a local administrative council female representative. akany five. ikany five (note: numerals follow masculine and feminine prefixes of nouns they refer). itogoi ikany: five houses. amor akany: five stones. idwe ikany: five children. akany kape: six. akany kaare: seven. akany kauni: eight. akany kaongon: nine.

akalel akambak a retrenched, laid off, or deserting army woman now living a civilian life in the village; a come-back; rustled or raided livestock that gets lost within Teso before reaching its destination (Karamoja)
a woman native of former Bugisu (the present day Mbale and Sironko districts)

a Mugisu woman or word in Lumasaba (the language of the Bagisu people). Akanyanga: the Lumasaba language.akanyeret a bracelet; a bangle; an armlet; a wristlet. akanyumit a wild simsim (not traditionally eaten by Iteso men) used as medicine for gallstones in the kidneys; a leaf or a stem of a simsim plant. akao a small seasonal swamp for communal grazing.akapakin to equip, prepare. to prepare oneself; to make immediate preparations, equip oneself. abu ejakait Ekapa komam eong akapakina: Mr. Ekapa has come when I am not prepared or ready. akapanakin to gather for oneself things necessary for; to gather equipment for (feast, fight, journey, etc). akapanakina to be prepared for; to be ready (for anything). ekapanakinos itunga alosit ojie: the people are prepared to go to war. akaparar to have large wide ears, stiff and pointed (not soft like of some people, or dogs, cows, cats, etc); (of new cloth) to be full of starch. ikapararas akike: her/his ears are long and stiff. ikaparar egoe lo, ekot ber ailosio: this cloth is stiff with starch, it needs washing first. akaparikin alosit to go along with long stiff ears (an insult). akaparikin kekegoe: she/he walks along with her/his stiff cloth (or stiff hide). akapet1 a cowhide or animal skin to sleep on; a honeycomb; a leather ball. ailangilang akapet: to play football; (slang) to have sexual intercourse. aipet akapet: to lay out the bed. akapet2 naka ao a honeycomb. akapilaar to take away bad luck. akapilanakin to bewitch; to bring ill luck to or for somebody. ikapilanakini ijo itunga: you bring bad luck to people. akapilanut (singular noun F) ill luck; evil. iyau jo akapilanut: you have brought ill luck. ekapilana ngesi: she/he brings ill luck. ekapilaka kesi: they bring ill luck. akapilaun to bring bad luck here. akapit to be ready with; to be prepared for; to be ready for eventualities; to be armed. akapit eong adita agwelakin emuogo: I am ready with a basket in case I have to buy cassava. akapul a navel; umbilicus.akarab to give imitative sound of running cows or horses (galloping, first with front and then hind legs). ekarabete akituk osamai: the cows are galloping to the swamp (to drink). akarac alosit to walk bow-legged. ikaracacas itulin: the hip bones are sticking out as of a deformed person. akaracac to be bowlegged; to stand or walk like a skeleton, bowlegged but erect. ikaracac ecom ebwoie: the baboon stands bow-legged. akarad to beat with a heavy object. apotu kesi kokaradata etyang k’abotei: they clobbered the animal with the clubs. akaradikin to lurch forward; to fall down; to fall on top of; to protect with one’s body. akaradikin emong kwap akurwoki aswam: the ox fell down unable to work. akarapan a nose ornament; ring for ear, lip, or tongue.ekarasete kesi ekokolan kotogo: they are spearing a thief in the house. akarasaar: to spear without releasing the hold on the spear. akarasun: to stab.akarasikin to spear with big spear or stab with big knife. akarasik eong emong: I speared a bull with a big spear.akarata a playing paper card. akarataasi a paper for rolling cigarettes.
a woman from Ikarebwok clan of Iteso.
a woman native to former Karamoja (the present day districts of Moroto, Kotido and Nakapiripirit)

a word in Ngakarimojong (the language of the Karimojong). Akarimojong: the Karimojong women; Ngakarimojong language. akarukwait round edible fruits (black when ripe) from eelu or ekarukwei tree, Vitex doniana. akarwait a drizzle of rain.akata a saucer (on which a tea cup is placed). akataasa a metallic or plastic tray.akatapan (in Karamoja) a small black termite.akatar to gallop; (of animals) to canter.akatarikin to fall down on hands and feet i.e. not fall down altogether; to canter, fall forward (as of a child). akatarikin ikoku kwap: the child has fallen forward on its knees. akatenak occasions; times. akatenak aare: twice.akauka: my back. akaulo1 after that; later on. kilosi konye oni akaulo naka ailong: we shall go later on after bathing.akayoit a small fish - pounded when dry and eaten in groundnut sauce, and famed for being a remedy for measles.akebat a trimmed forehead (especially of girls). akebe a tin can; a small metallic container or vessel. akebun to trim a little. akebun akiro: to talk nicely for a short time and then keep silent. akedekede (colour of cows or birds with many colours) banded; hooped; lined; striped.akediany the left hand; the left side. lokediany : the left one. akan nakokediany : the left hand; left side, on the left. akeero (singular noun F) a playground; a green park; an open space; a playing field; a recreational area; a theatre.akeju a root; a foot; a leg (of man, animal, or table, chair, etc); a pedal (of a cycle).akekesiar to be strong, obstinate, difficult, or hard. akekesiar akirot na: this is a difficult case. akekesikin to become strong for, difficult for, obstinate to. ekekesikit eketau akirot ngin: she/he finds this case difficult. akekesu (singular noun F) power; strength; trouble; swiftness.akele (rarely used) a man’s penis.akelesia the Roman Catholic church or the Catholic religion.akelyo a plant eaten as a vegetable and from which salt is made, Colosea argentea. akemer a birth mark; a skin mark on body of a leper; a syphilis mark on forehead; a freckle; white hair on a young person. akeo a vegetable, Gynandropsis pentaphyll.akep the jugular vein; a blood vein in the neck or on forehead; a blood vessel in neck or forehead. akepar to pare away; to circumcise. akepio (singular noun F) circumcision. akepun to cut for oneself. akeraar to run away; to take refuge somewhere. akeria to run off with. akeriata kesi ekabore: they have run off with my thing. akeria ngesi aberuka: he eloped with my wife. akerianut1 riches; wealth; treasures; affluence; prosperity. aiwot naka akerianut: economic development. apol naka akerianut: economic growth. iitaabon luka akerianut: business records. aibois naka akerianut: a business premises. akerianut2 to be rich, developmental or skillful. (ekeriana ngesi) ekeriaka kesi: (she/he is) they are developmetal, skillful, or rich. akeriar to run towards; to make off. abu ekokolan kokeriaa okekwa je: the thief ran off across the swamp to the next village/hill. akerikin to go and fetch quickly; to run to help or relieve somebody; to run to the rescue; to run after someone. kokerik akipi: run to fetch water; run for water. abu etunganan kakerik eong korot: somebody ran after me on the road. akerit1 (singular noun F) a flight; an escape (by running away); a getaway, or a departure; a trip, a journey, a voyage, or air travel; an athletic event (especially a race). akerit2 to be running; to be afraid; to honour.kokerite lukapolokokon: respect or honour your superiors. akerit kede egaalit: to move on bicycle. akerit kede emotoka: to drive a car. akeritor akiro: to telltale, rumourmonger, gossip, or to inform on.akerun to run this way; to come to the rescue. akesa a colleague; a member of an age group. akesa ngin: that woman over there. akesa kwa: those women over there. akesa na: this woman here. akesisianakinan a teacher; a schoolmaster; a professor. aketar to pull out, take away (as of a house, etc). aketekete (singular noun F) a distance. ajena naka ketekete: a distant relation i.e. no relation at all. aketun to pull out (anything) towards the speaker. akewat forefoot (of an animal); foreleg or front limb. akeyiar to melt; to be completely overcast; (of meat) to be very fatty; (of milk) to become watery; to rebuke, become nasty. adau akinyet akeyiar kotoma otwo: the butter has melted in the gourd. akeyiaros idowon: the sky is overcast.akibiriiti a match; stick of matches; a flare. akideit a bow harp from the east. akidiar to hurt; to pain (of a blow); to smart with laughter or coughing. kakidiarit eong aromait na: this blow hurts me. kakidiarit eong akwenekwenetoi na: this constant laughing pains me (hurts my sides). akididi ki-a to make small strips of leather or anything; to make a string for a harp, etc or to make bootlaces from a hide. akididiun: to cut a small strip from anything.
airwait, elimilim akasision (singular noun F) a billion
(in the Teso week) Wednesday.akidingot nak’ecor: etau lokecor: the middle of the lake.akido a green jumping frog found in swamps. akijaraijiiko: a spoon

a ladle akikerep ki-a to become mad; to go insane; to run mad.akikomo brass or copper (metal or bracelet). akikum a rubber stamp.akikunget a rubber stamp.ekilari ngesi alosit: she/he is walking bald-headed. akilarikin1 to walk or go bareheaded. kinyek akilarikin, ededeng akolong: do not walk bareheaded, it is too hot. akilarikin2 kwap ki-a to fall heavily with the head hitting the ground; to strike the ground with back of the head.akilauri a hurricane lamp glass. ejaatar etabaasa kede akilauri, konye itodooma emameotor akilauri: a hurricane lamp has a glass, but a candle does not. akile (uncountable noun F) milk; white latex; sap; juice. akile nuk’epopong: juice or latex from a cactus plant. akile nuk’eligoi: latex from eligoi hedge. akilekan a plant used for making salt. akiling the upper arm; biceps muscle.akim a fire; lighta flame; a blaze; a bonfire; a conflagration; an inferno; a gunfire. akim naka ekipyei: electricity. ailikor akim: to become angry (literally, to swallow fire). akima porridge or gruel made from finger millet or flour from any other grain; liquid volcanic lava; the porridge-like waste product in the distillation of crude alcohol (ewaragi or ejuge).aicom akimai: to thresh finger millet. atap: cooked millet bread. alos: millet or flour destined for eating as bread. akimai finger millet in the granary or store. aicom akimai: to thresh finger millet. alos: threshed finger millet destined for making flour for eating. airiar alos: to grind millet or sorghum to use for bread. akimait a grain or a plant of finger millet, Eleusin corocona. akimat an old woman; a crony; a million. akiminganar to become deaf; to be deaf. akiminganaros akaki: my ears have become deaf or no longer hear properly. akiminganut1 deafness; hard of hearing.akimingikin to be deaf to. akimingikis kesi akakiro: they have turned a deaf ear to what I say. akimirait a necklace or bracelet made of pieces of ostrich eggshell.akimul saliva; spittle; dribble; sputum.e. to pay no attention to one’s environment or the information it offers. kiriamun eong kikimingiok ekinangete oidukai: I met deaf people going to the shops. akinangang to be deaf; to hear and refuse to answer; to act as a deaf man. inyo bo ikinangangar ijo keworot?: why do you not answer when I call you?akinangikin alosit to go as of a deaf man; to act like a deaf person.akine a female goat; a she-goat.akinei a female goat; a she-goat.akingarenikinet leadership; management; headship.akingok a bitch; a female dog; a loose woman (i.e. a prostitute); a very poor woman (living a dog’s life – i.e. miserably). akingol1 a beige-coloured grasshopper. akingol2 a ladle; a paddle or oar (of canoe); a spoon.akinyang a small crocodile (whose anus is ground and powdered as a love potion); a pigmy crocodile.akiru: a young crocodile. akinyet fat; oil; butter; petrol; paraffin; grease. akinyet nak’ikanyum: simsim oil. akinyet nak’etaala: paraffin; kerosene oil. akinyet apeteloori: petrol. akinyet naapotik: grease. akinyet nak’akiteng: butter. akinyet nak’asyepai: cow fat or lard. akinyet nakajonon: uncooked (raw) fat. akipi (uncountable noun F) water; juice; liquid; amniotic fluid (in humans). aiyat akipi akuwan kayen edeka: to administer fluids intravenously to a patient. aiga akipi nuedou: to trap rain water. akiporo wet season.akiriat: a big heap of flour. eriata kesi akiriat: they have ground a lot of flour. ejukonokina ijo akiria: you are white (smothered) with flour. akiria nuka emuogo: cassava or tapioca flour. akiriap to roam about (looking for the road or anything else wanted). akiriap eong erot loka adumun ikaboro, kaoliki: I looked for the way to find my things in vain. akiriapikin to find by chance, by good luck. abu eong akiriapikin ajon: I got some beer by chance; I was lucky to get some beer.akiriapitoi to go about looking for something.akirib to stamp feet; to dance, stampede. akirib ekosio: to dance. akirib akeje: to stamp feet on the ground as in dance or military drill. akiribikin to walk together or dance together in step or in unison. akiriboor to walk away in step. akirididi the armpit; a maize stem, stalk or leaf. akirimait necklace of ostrich eggshell. akirimat bits of ostrich eggshell. akiring meat generally (beef, pork, lamb, mutton, chicken); flesh or tissue; muscles; fleshy part of fruit. ejijim akiring naka emuebe: the fleshy part of the mango is nice or a mango is sweet. akiring nak’akiteng: beef. akiring nak’amerekek: mutton; lamb. akiring nak’epege: pork. akiring nak’akokor: chicken. akiro words; affairs; cases; news; difficulty. akiro nyo? (greeting): what is the news? how are you? akiro nuamwakak: bitter, or hot, words; a difficult situation. akiro nukakwapin kanukokinga: international affairs. akirosinei list of words; words in general matters; affairs; news; difficulties; cases. akirot a word; an affair; a case; an incident. akiro: news; difficulty. akiro nukajokak: the good news. akiru1 a young crocodile. akiru2 (singular noun F) rain; precipitation; rainfall. etepi akiru: it is raining.akit the ear. ekit loka emeleku: the ear-like bit of a worn-out traditional hoe. ekit: a big ear as of an elephant. ikit yenika akimait: (plural) iki luka akimai: the earlike leaves of millet. akitegaet a poison trap; a poison snare; a trap. Akiteng1 a woman’s name. akiteng2 a cow.akituk: cows; cattle; a herd of cattle.akitimir (singular noun F) a vegetable, Oxigonum atriplicifolium. akitiyo a spade; a shovel. akito wood; timber; firewood. aijep akito: to fell or cut firewood. akitoi a piece of wood; a small stick; a cane. akito: firewood. arara akito: to gather or collect firewood. akitor to scoop out or away completely; to finish all; to scrape out. akituk1 mouth; lip; opening; language. akituk nak’amot: the mouth of the pot. akituk nak’ecilet: a river mouth. ejai ekesa ngol akituk: that man is a big liar (has a mouth); he is a tale-teller; he is sharp-tongued. Kolimokinai ikabore: karaida kemutono akwap, mam ipedori aolikin? Akituk: (a riddle) tell me a thing that you cannot miss even if it is very dark? A mouth. akituk2 cattle; cows. akitun to exhaust; to scrape out, when almost finished; to scoop out, finish all. akitun etau: to search the heart. akitun akipi: to scoop out (what is left of) water or liquid. akitunos ajon kio kiot: the beer is completely finished. akitun: to make a scraping noise as of drawing water from a drying well. akitun akipi: to draw water from a shallow well or nearly empty pot (making a scraping noise).akiyai firstborn girl.aimony akiyo: to shed tears. akiyot a leaf (of vegetation).akobo a divorcee (once) or a woman divorced several times. inyo bo ikotor ijo aimany akobo, kojaas apesur?: why do you want to marry a divorcee when there are other girls?akoboit a banknote; paper money or currency.akobokobot a cucumber fruit.akoc (a reference among friends) a tough woman; an iron lady.akodakin to fasten (as of buttons); to link or to join (things) together. akodakinit akanin: to be arm in arm; with your arm holding another person's arm. kokodanak apeesan nuk’epalekon: fasten the buttons of your trousers. akodanakin to make a chain; to fix here and there (as of a spider fixing or fastening its web). akodanakin aunoi: weaving rope (as for a bed frame). akodakin ibokor: to hook fingers. akodanakin irikoi: to join links of a chain. akodar to carry away with a handle as of bucket or light object. kokoda ijo ikatuo da ocor: take my little gourd with you to the well. kokoda ikimat adekis: take the little old woman to the hospital. (note: akodar goes with the idea of a little load) akodet a handle (of a cup, a bucket, etc). akodet nak’akiro: akodeta nuk’akiro: reasons for causing trouble, source of trouble. akodit to carry in the hand; to hold (as one goes along) as of a lamp. ekodit ngesi etabaasa: she/he carries the lamp. akodit adoteu: to love many at once. (note: to carry big objects is aibwokit, adakit; to carry small objects is akodit). akodol (of a tall person) to be exhausted and sagging; to go about exhausted and stooping. akodolikin to lie down or sit down exhausted; to fall down exhausted. ekodolikin emong kwap kanuka apasit: the (ploughing) ox fell down exhausted.akodomom to be round-shouldered (like old and tall people); to be tall and thin. akodun to lift up by handle; to pull up by a hook; to tempt; to pull up (as of suspenders, braces). akoeded to be slender, slim, slight, lean, trim, or willowy. ikoeded ngesi: she/he is slender, thin. ikoededos kesi: they are slender. akoik abdomen; womb; stomach; belly. ajaus k’akoik: epotie akoik: she is pregnant. arinyo akoik: the belly is wrinkled: to be hungry. arinyo akimat: the old woman is wrinkled or has wrinkles. akoikin to find for, look out for; to search for; to attempt for. kolot kokoik eong akiring k’osokooni: go and look for some meat for me in the market. kokoikinoi akwara ka naolio: go and find my lost spear. akoit a bone; a piece of skeleton. akojo bones; a skeleton. akojop an axe-handle.akokit to do frequently, regularly; to put one’s mind on, not to forget. akokit eong ailipasineika: I pray regularly, frequently, often. isirikaalei ekokitos iwenan: the soldiers guard the prisoners. akoko1 larceny; theft; robbery; stealing; burglary; shoplifting; thievery; pilferage. ekokoi ngesi: she/he steals. akoko tiritir: to steal everyday; perpetual thieving; kleptomania. akoko2 to steal; to thieve, pilfer. akokoar: to steal away; to take away; to steal and take away. akokolanut1 kleptomania; thieving. ekokolana ngesi: : she/he is (they are) fond of stealing. akokolanut2 to be a thief; to be fond of stealing.
Nakiuniet akidingot the middle; the core; the main part

a word in the language of the Kumam people of Kaberamaido and parts of Soroti district. Akokolemwo the language of the Kumam people of Kaberamaido and parts of Soroti district. akokor a hen; a fowl; a chicken; a female bird. akokore (of fruits) to ripen; (of water) to boil; (of brew) to ferment; (of food) to be done (only used in the plural, singular is akonore). akoko acok: the potatoes are done (well cooked). akoko akimai: the millet is ripe. akokoro a bicycle wheel. akokos alosit to go in a hurry; to hurry. abu ngesi kokokos alosit: she/he went off in a hurry (with heavy long strides).akokosan to be very old; to become very old.akokosanar to become old. akokosanut1 great age. akokosanut ke emik nges aswam: her/his old age has prevented her/him from working.akokosanut2 to become very old. akokosikin to hurry off on foot somewhere or for someone. kokokosik akeje aomare papakon, atwana toto: hurry off to call your father, mother is dead. akokoyo (uncountable noun F) tallow i.e. hard fat from sheep or cattle. akoku1 a female child; daughter.koany edweet ngol: look at that crowd of children. akoku2 kajokotau a girl of good-hearted mother.
