(a term complimenting a good girl).akokuke: akokukec: her/his or their daughter. akoku3 kapapaka my father’s daughter; my step-sister; my half sister (different mother).Akol1 a pet name for a cow with large white patches in a generally black body; a person’s name. akol2 to be at loggerheads; to be constantly in opposition; to rival; to quarrel. akoli a cup, gourd or a small calabash for drinking water. akolicic1 albinism.akolicic2 to have red or white spots on the body; to be half albino.akolilit cucumber fruit or plant.akolipan to be barren; (of women or animals) to become barren. akolipan akakiteng: my cow has become barren.akolipanut1 (in males) sterility; barrenness. akolipanut2 ki-a to be sterile; to be lazy; to be impotent. ikolipana ijo: you are impotent. akoloboc a fork (an eating implement with prongs).akolokin to quarrel about, dispute about. akolokinos itelepai kanuka inyamat: the boys are quarrelling about food. akolong the sun; a clock; daylight; the sun’s heat. ebala akolong ai? what is the time (what does the sun say)? akolongit the hour. ekolongit: the day. ekolongit: day. ekolongit lokadumunia: the day I meet you. ngol kolongit: every day. akolongisinei: days.akolonor ejakait kwana: the chief has become very difficult to deal with these days. akolor to be at loggerheads; to be enemies. ekolos papaka k’onaceka: my father and my brother are at loggerheads. akoloror (singular noun F) bald-headedness.akomolianut1 (singular noun F) pie-baldness; brown-spottedness; albinism. akomolianut2 to be pie-bald, coloured, spotted dark brown. ekomoliana akine: the goat has a dark brown colour or spots. egoe loekomoliana: a dirty-brown coloured cloth. akomot armlet. akompiuta a computer; a laptop; a personal computer (PC). acuuma naebakai akompiuta ejulaki eiswamae loka eyapeesi noi: a computer has revolutionized office work so much. akone (in Karamoja) a female lover. irai ijo akoneka: you are my friend.akong a knee or other joint.akung nak’ebokorit: finger-joint, or knuckle.akongoror to lose weight. akongu an eye; a spring (of a well). akongu nak’atitipu: an opening (hole) in an anthill. akongu nak’ekicoi: the spring of a well. akonore (of food) to be done; to be cooked; (of fruit or an abscess) to be ripe; (of food) to be ready. akoko inyamat: the food is ready (is cooked and can be eaten). akonyakin to clench or grit teeth, as of dying person. Okanya elosi atwanare naarai ekonyanakini do ikel: Okanya is going to die because he is now gritting his teeth. akonyar to bite off (away). akonyaret a mouthful (of food); a bite; a morsel. koinakinai adiopekonyaret naka atap: give me one mouthful of food or just a morsel. akonye eyes; faces. kakonyeka: in front of me; before me. kakonye: later on; in the future; before; in front of. kidareu kakonye: wait, you’ll see or get it later. akonyetait a bite; a sting. akonyokony (of body) to ache; to keep biting (as of fleas or anything). akonyokonyata eong iidep: fleas have bitten me. akonyun to bite off; to have a bad ache. kakonyununei eong akou: I have a constant headache. kakonyununei eong akoik: I have a constant stomach-ache. akoodakita a conductress; a woman who collects fares from passengers on a bus, taxi, etc.akoodom a condom; a thin rubber sheath worn on the penis during sexual intercourse, to prevent the release of sperm into the vagina and so avoid pregnancy, and to prevent the spread of disease.akoogo1 a chicken breed with bare necks; a hen without feathers round the neck. akoogo2 a percussion reed instrument or accompanied dance to its sound; a thumb piano. akoomat a bracelet; a plectrum of a percussion instrument called akoogo. akoonokin to be continually scratching or rubbing oneself; (of a bird) to preen feathers. akoor to scratch off. akoo ikoku akejimi: the child has scratched the scab on its wound. kokooroi epura, kepii: scratch my back, it itches. akopa a woman who has had several husbands.akopiira a hat – a cap, a trilby, a panama, or a sunhat.akopirot a large feather (of birds). akopirot nak’ekuulu: an ostrich feather. akopiton a bark fibre used as rope, string; a strip of bark. akopokin to dash at; to attack somebody suddenly; to snatch something away for somebody. akopokin ekapa emir: the cat has suddenly attacked a mouse or rat. akopor1 to wear a stiff skin or cloth (as unwashed khaki). akopor2 to snatch a thing away; to tell tales of other people. akopo etoori imiyot: the eagle snatched a chick away. to get up quickly and go away; to get off suddenly; to start suddenly. akoporikin to start off dressed in stiff cloth or skin. akoporor to become stiff; to become tough, dry, hard (as of a skin, dried meat, etc). akoposoor to hasten away; to hurry off. akoposun to snatch off, drag off, or away.akopun to snatch up, towards speaker; to seize. to start all of a sudden. akopun ngesi togo: she/he has come into the house suddenly. akopyot dew; fine drops of water from grass and trees; a court registration fee. ekitoi eisi akopyo: the tree rains dew-drops. atikor akopyo: to go very early. akor to cultivate (soil); to dig (in general); to farm. ekoriei ngesi akemisiri: she/he cultivates her/his garden.ailobo: to level out; to equalize the soil or plough the second time. aibok acok: to make little heaps for planting sweet potatoes. aiwe: to sow (seeds). aikurukur: to rake under the seed or cover the seed with earth by driving a herd of cattle through the sown field. aicap eduan: to weed. aisak: to harvest grain (such as millet, sorghum, rice). aikut emaido: to harvest groundnuts - to dig up groundnuts. aikur acok: to dig out sweet potatoes. ailem epaaba: to pick cotton. aipac emaido: to unhusk the groundnuts; to shell. akorakin to allot; to distribute to; to share out to; to divide for. kokorakinai eong da: give me also something. akoranakin to distribute often or to many persons. akorar to give something away; (of many) to finish quickly. akorar apese: (of in-laws) to hand a bride to her bridegroom at a marriage. akoras itunga inyamat kere: the people finished the food quickly. akorar ajon kosokooni: the beer has been finished in the market quickly. akorasit a serving; a portion; a share; a piece. akorasit naka inyamat: portion of food. akoraut a bush, Mimosa aspera. akoret a place where food is distributed; the hatches of a cafeteria; the instrument with which food is served. Akori1 a pet name for a white and brown flecked cow; a woman’s name. akori2 a woman or animal slow in conceiving; a female giraffe.akorikin to cultivate for someone. akorio (singular noun F) distribution; division; allotment; allocation. akorior to plough away or hoe away (weeds, etc).akorisit a plot (of food or cotton); a cultivated piece of land. akoro (singular noun F) (in Karamoja) hunger; starvation. kaar eong akoro: I am very hungry. kanyam eong akoro: I am starving. akoroc to bail water from a gravely well (making the above sound). akorococ to be uneven; to be rough (of road); to be hard (as of ground or soil); (with akou) to be stupid.ikorococos alup: the ground is hard, uneven. ikorococ eguudo: the road is uneven. akoroi1 self-sprouting potatoes (left in the ground and sprouting out).akoroi2 a branch of ekoroi bush, used to close the gate of a kraal or goat hut, or house; a piece of wood from the above bush used for a toe-holder of sandals and for a nose clip for an obstinate cow or bull. akoromit a species of bird also called lily-trotter bird.akorun to serve up. akorun inyamat: to serve up food.akorwa wooden or skin sandals; clogs.akorwoit a grey hair. akoset a fly swatter or whisk (made of cow- tail or of twigs); a fan. akoto aikot icuc kakosetait: I want to drive flies away with a fly-swatter.akosong a bone joint; thigh-bone or femur; joint of meat. akotar to chase away once with a fan or similar instrument; to swat (flies, etc) with a swatter. akote1 to like; to love; to need; to want; to wish. akoto eong inyamat: I want food. akoto eong: I want. ikoto ijo: you want. kikoto oni: we want (or need). ikotos yesi: you (plural) want. ekotos kesi: they want. ekoto ngesi: she/he wants. akote2 naejok (singular noun F) goodwill; wellwishes. kitoodikinai akonikote naejok: show me your goodwill. akote3 nakaronon (singular noun F) bad will; bad wishes. kikotor ijo eong erono: you have bad-will against me. akotonokin to love, like one another. kokotonokinos bonik: love one another. akotor1 to walk, to go with a thin body. ekotori (lokadekan) oiduka: the thin person goes to the shop. plural: ekotorete kesi: they go with thin bodies: they have thin bodies. akotor2 to wish to somebody something. akotor eong ijo aswam ace: I wish you to do another work. akotoraar (of a thin person or animal) to die. akotoraaros akakituk bian: my emaciated cows died yesterday. akotorikin (of a thin person or animal) to fall; to die somewhere. ekotorikin ekimat kwap: the thin old man fell down. akotorikinos akakituk osamai: my cows died in the swamp (from starvation); the cows in the swamp became so emaciated that they died. akotoror to be very thin; to be very small; to be tiny (of men and animals). akotoror ikoku ngin, edeka apaarasia kere: that child is very thin, it is always ill. akou1 head; top of; ruler; headman. ijo nges akou naka itunga kere: you are the head of all these people. akou k’amukat: point of shoe. egogong akou: stubborn, stupid. ejai ijo akou: you are proud. akou2 atapengo (singular noun F) a vegetable, Justicia insularia. akoun to look for; to find; to search for. kokoutu ibore yen aolio: find the thing which was lost.akoyior to go and look for; to go and find somewhere, over there; to attempt; to try to be going to. akoyiosi idwe ngul papakec: those children have gone to look for their father. akoyiosi akipi ayangaar eong: the water current was going to take me away. akoyokoyot uncooked beeswax tallow.
a Christian woman. akuar to extract (and throw away). akuare night. akubai a water beetle.akubany to stride away

to make big strides; to walk proudly. ikubanyi ijo bala isot: you stride away like a gentleman (like a proud man or boy).akube a small gourd for water and butter oil. akubitoi to rush round; to dash around. akubokin to dash at; to rush at, pounce on, jump at. akubokin ekapa emir: the cat has rushed, dashed at the rat. akubor to rush or dash out or away; to dart away. akubor ekokolan: the thief scurried away. akubun to rush into; to dash into. akubun ekingok togo: the dog rushed into the room. akucakin to hang; to strangle or to choke. to hang oneself. akudet a corner (of a road, street); angle. akudi to cough aloud; to laugh aloud; to double up with laughter or coughing. akudianar to cough persistently. akudo to sit bent or drawn up (like a man full of pain). ekudo ngesi kanuka amojongu: she/he stoops or hunches due to old age. akudoit churned sour milk and good or fresh milk mixed together (producing lumps). aleposi akudo idwe: the children got diarrhoea by drinking akudo. akudokin to fold (cloth, etc); to bend down or up (as of elbow or old person). ekudokina loaraman airam atenus: the drummer has bent to beat her/his drum. akudokin akeje: to bend the knees, draw up the legs. akudokin aswam: to put your back into work; to work hard at something.akudokinet a corner; a bend; a loop. akudolikin to bend double; to double up. akudud (singular noun F) agriculture, especially crop husbandry in its traditional form using a hand hoe.akudukud to wind (as of a road); to meander. ekudukudei erot lo noi: this road meanders very much. akudukudet wrinkles on the face or body. akudukudo to twist; to warp; to fold, crease. akudukud akolong emukule: the sun has warped the hide. to be twisted; to warp; to crease. ekudukudo apapula: the paper is creased (folded). ekudukudo irotin bala emun: the roads are twisting like a snake (are full of turns). akuet remnants of froth of milk; remnants of foam (after frothing or foaming). akuikin1 to escape from. to elude, escape, avoid, or dodge. kakuikis eong ityang kere kokitwi: all the animals escaped in the bush. akuikin2 to boil over on to or into; to bully; to hector; (of big person to small one) to domineer. akuikis akile akim: the milk has boiled over into the fire. sirikikuik ikoku: do not bully a little child. akuj (abstract noun F) sky; heaven; summit; to top of. (in Karamoja) God: Akuj. ejai toma akuj: she/he/it is in the sky; she/he/it is in heaven. akujup an axe-handle.akuk nuk’okwap: coal. akuko to be kneeling; to revere, worship. . kicorakitai oni akuko kakonye ka Edeke: we are obliged to kneel before God (to revere and worship God). akukokin to kneel down to; to kneel at or for. kokukokinos ngina: kneel down over there. akuku charcoal.akuk nukakwap: coal. akukum to bend forward, bow, stoop (as of one touching toes or ground). akukumikin to bend down for somebody or something. akukumit to be bending down. ekukumit ngesi iswamai: she/he works bending down. akukumit ilosi: to walk with a stoop.akukumor to bend down on hands and knees, also on hands and knees touching the ground with forehead (like Mohammedans).akukunya1 application; diligence; exertion.akukunya2 to be diligent, very busy, active, or restless; to exert oneself; to be in a hurry. ekukunya ngesi aswam: she/he works diligently.akukunyaar to hurry away; to go quickly to. kokukunyaaros aswam: hurry away (go off quickly) to your work.akukunyikinos itelepai aiwadik kojokan: the boys have exerted themselves in order to write nicely. akukunyor to become sweet to the smell; to become tasty. edia kon akukunyoor noi: your vegetables (have become) are spicy or nice smelling. akukur to be busy, active; to do quickly; to do zealously; to make an effort. ekukuri ngesi aipoore: she is busy cooking. Marita, Marita, ipu iboro lukiinakinete ijo akukura: Martha, Martha, many things will keep you busy. akukuranar to work hard and to work zealously; to do anything with heart and soul. akukuranut1 (singular noun F) zeal; perseverance; efficiency; diligence. ejai ngesi akukuranut toma aswamusinei ke: she/he is efficient in all she/he does.akukuranut2 to be busy, zealous, efficient. akukurikin to do one’s best for; to work hard for. akukurikin eong aiswamakin ikadwe: I do my best working for my children. akukuse a small grinding stone.akukusiar to go straight; to run quickly, without deviating, without stopping; to continue. kokukusia ijo alosit oiduka: go quickly to the shops.akukusikin to hasten; to do quickly; to rush at a work. akukusikinos kesi aitudeng akim: they rushed to extinguish fire. akukut charcoal; embers.ekulaete akipi: the water is boiling. ekulai edia: the vegetables are boiling up. akulaar to ferment; to boil over; to become red hot (of iron in fire). akulaasi akile: the milk has boiled over. akulaet resin of plants; dross of beer or boiling food; bubbles of liquid. akulaikin to boil or to bubble into; to rust, become rusty. ekagaali akulaiki kere: my bicycle has become rusty all over. akulaikisi akile akim: the milk has boiled over into the fire.akulaikinet burnt or black part of meat or food. ipoit ijo acok erono, ileleba akulakineta: you cooked the potatoes badly, they are burnt.akulakin to peel for someone; to pare for; to corrode.kekulaiki akiring: the meat is burned. akularar to be bald-headed; to grow bald. ekularaar ngesi: she/he has grown bald. akulaun to bubble up; to boil; to evaporate; (of iron in fire) to become red hot; to fizz. ekulaununete akipi k’atan: the water bubbles up in the well.akulep1 a handle of a knife, an axe, or a hoe; a haft or hilt of a sword. akulep2 to run or jump (like a frog); to leap; (of horse) to gallop; to abuse; to scold. ekulepete atyang akwap: the animals are leaping. akulep aberu okilenike: the wife scolded her husband.akulepikin to run off; to gallop; to leap away for or to. akulepoor to gallop or leap away (as of horses or animals or frogs). akuletait a peeling or flake (as potato or cassava-peels, etc) akuleut a prickly plant burnt for salt making. akuluma a clap trap or rat-trap (for catching rats); the gallows; a cover on a granary; a dangerous structure that may collapse anytime (possibly endangering its inhabitants). Akum k' Oumo (proper noun) the old name of Kumi. (literally, Akum of Oumo, Oumo being the founder) akuma a corruption of akima: porridge, millet, gruel. akumac a big edible tortoise or turtle found in aro (wilderness).
an Atesot woman, so called by the Karimojong

a Kumam woman (a native of Kaberamaido district) who speaks a language akin to Luo and Ateso. akumioit an edible fruit from ekum tree, from which Kumi derives its name. akumonokin to turn one’s behind on to (somebody) (considered bad manners). ekosio lok’akumonokin imu: an obscene dance for twins (where behinds are turned to one another).(note: bearing twins was considered aicud or ecudet, a form of wizardry) akumor to turn back away from. ekoto ngesi ereka kokumorite laije: she/he wants my home to be built facing this way (with the back looking, turned that way). kokumosi laije: turn your behinds that way. akumukiliok a heifer.kokum lailo: turn your backside this way. akung a knee or other joint.akung nak’ebokorit: finger-joint, or knuckle.akuosi akile kakim: the milk has boiled over into the fire (foams on to the fire). akur honeycomb with bee larvae. akuraru a leather scabbard for a spear blade; a leather sheath; a leather casing, a leather cover; a leather case for a weapon; a holster. akure (singular noun F) thirst; need for liquids. ajak akure: to be thirsty. kajak eong akure: I am thirsty (literally, thirst has made my jaws hang).akurian1 (singular noun F) fright; timidity; fear; cowardliness; sensitiveness; threat. akurian2 to be frightened; to be sensitive; to be afraid; to be timid; to be a coward, craven; to be ticklish, affright, diffident. ekuryana ngesi: she/he is cowardly, etc. ekuryaka kesi: they are timid, etc aitukurian: to frighten; to make afraid, timid, etc; to threaten. akurianaar to become afraid; to fear; to be scared, etc. akuriei a timid woman; a coward, etc akurokin to dig (potatoes, etc) for somebody or somewhere. akurub to munch, chew, masticate, crunch, chomp or grind with teeth. ekurubi apese emuogo loajonon: the girl is munching raw cassava. akurun1 to bring near with a hook or stick.akurun2 to call insulting names. inyo bo kikurunitor ijo kiworot?: why do you use those insulting names on me?akurungan (of old man) to be old but strong enough to marry; (of a man) to be virile at an old age; (of a man) to be active sexually or otherwise. amojong ngesi konye eroko ekurungani: he is old but still making love or wooing. akurunganut (singular noun F) (of men) making love in old age; virility; old age libido or nymphomania. akuruny (singular noun F) edible melted fat; lard from sheep’s tail.akurur to work diligently in the field for hours; to scratch somebody with thorns as of a cat scratching a person; to scrape fat and hair of a skin; to rake. akururaar (of hair) to shave off in one go; to finish ploughing a plot in one day. akurureet a rake.
ataok akumun to point your backside this way; to turn the backside this way
a name of a woman. akurwoit a corruption of akorwoit: a grey hair. akurwokin to fail to, not be able to manage

to be unable, too difficult for. kakurwokit eong aswam ngin: that work is too difficult for me.akurwoor to fail to do; to be or become impossible; to be unable; to be too difficult; to be too much for. kakurwo eong aswam ngin: that work is too much for me. akurwo aberu adeka: the illness has overcome the woman (she won’t live long or she will not survive it). akuset a burrow; a hole in the ground; instrument for burrowing or making a hole. akusiar to dry up a little (as of road, cloth, of body after washing, etc); to heal up; (of a wound) to dry up a little; to be delayed; to delay. akusia erot: the road has dried up a little. akusia akajimi: my wound has healed up a little. inyo bo ikusiarata yesi kangina?: why do you delay over there. akusia akwap: it is fairly dry. akuta a digging stick with a metal dibble (popular in Lango as a hoe).akutakin etwo: to ostracise. akutakinet a blast (with a horn or a flute); a gust of air; a flurry. akutapap to be very dirty (especially of fingers and toes). kekutapapa: they have become altogether dirty. akutapapaar to become dirty. akutapapaaros akaninika: my hands have become dirty. akutar to blow out (fire, etc); to blow away; to extinguish. akuta ekwam ataker okekwa je: the wind has blown the boat to the other side of the lake. kokuta etabaasa: blow out the lamp. akutor to dig out (as of groundnuts) or potato tubers from the fire. akutukanut1 truculence; aggressiveness; hot-temper. akutukanut2 to be quarrelsome; to be rude; to be hot-tempered, fretful, strict, unruly, harsh, aggressive. ikutukana ijo : you are hot-tempered, etc. akutun1 to blow this way. to summon by horn; to call by whistle or bugle. akutun2 to dig out of the fire (roasted potatoes); to dig out groundnuts or millet from the granary; to give a dig in the back with the fist or with a club. abu ngesi kokut akangabet: she/he hit me on the back. kolot kokut emaido: go and dig up groundnuts. akutunet a blast of wind; an exhumation. akuudian1 (singular noun F) trials or tests (of faith); tribulations; great suffering (like the biblical Job). akuudian2 to grieve too much (like the biblical Job); to mourn for long; to weep continually. ekuudiani aberu ikekoku yen atwani bian: the woman is grieving over her child who died yesterday.akuudianakin to keep mourning over; to keep grieving for someone or something. akuuguto a sift.akuun1 epali to become ill-mannered; to become obstreperous, or cheeky. ikuu ijo epali kwana: you have become cheeky these days. akuun2 to pick out (jiggers or thorns); to extract. akuun3 (of mouth or of soda or beer or soap) to foam; to boil up. akuu asabuunyu dau dau: the soap has foamed very much. akuwaar to escape in a certain direction (away from speaker). akuaasi ngina: they escaped in that direction. akuwamikin to make rough. to become rough. akuwan the body; a cadaver or corpse. adeka naka akuwan: body malais. akuwan naka aberu (euphemism) the female genitalia; a woman’s body; (polite reference to) the woman’s private parts. akuwan naka ekiliokit the male body; the male genitals; (polite reference to) the man’s private parts (the penis, the testes and all). akuwe a hydrocele (lymphatic filariasis transmitted by a culex mosquito); enlarged testicles (i.e. elephantiasis of the testes).kokuyum emugaati: eat soft (fresh) bread. kokuyum asinge: walk on the sand. akuyumikin to go on loose sand or on soft soil. to break a dry thing once (like a pot, biscuit or a granary). kokuyumik edula k'ebela: break up that granary with a cane. akuyumoor (of a dry and floury thing) to become soft or loose (like a biscuit). akuyumooros alup: the dry soil has become soft (loose). akuyumum (of cake or boiled potatoes) to be soft; (of soil or sand) loose. ikuyumum emugaati lo: this bread is soft (fresh). akwacakin ebalua to write or scribble a letter to somebody or someone. akwacakwac to scratch all over. abu egereger kakwacakwac eong noi: the monitor lizard scratched me all over. akwacar to claw away. akwacet a scratch; a graze; a grate. akwacun to scratch (this side); to write. akwadar to go about with a weak thin body. aanyu eong lokadekan ikwadar adekis: I saw the sick man struggling (stumbling) to the hospital. akwadarar to waste away (from illness); to become emaciated. akwadarikin to straggle (as of a sick person or animal); to stumble along. akwalikwal midriff; peritoneum.akwamakin to glut, give or put too much. akwamakin amuunyu odia: to put too much salt in vegetables. akwangalu1 lightness; thinness. akwangalu2 to be thin; to be light; not to be heavy. akwangarar to waste away.akwangiar to become white. kinyek kes kokwangiaros: let them become white. akwangis to be white, grey, ashen, or pale. akwangus whiteness; brightness; paleness. akwang eong: I am white. kikwangak iso: we are white. aitakwang: to make white. akwangus to be white; to be grey or ashen, pale. akwanguun to be or become thin, become white, emaciated, waste away; to bleach, blanch. akwanguutu itunga kanuka etengei: the people have become thin on account of famine. akwanguu epaaba: the cotton has become white (has blossomed). akwaniar to become sharp. akwanikin to be sharp for; to cut sharp. ekwanikit ekileng akiring: the knife is sharp enough to cut meat. mam ekwanikit akojo: it is not sharp enough for cutting bones. akwanis to be sharp, keen, acute. ekwana: it is sharp . ekwaka akonye: sharp or eagle-eyed. ekwaka nges iwos: (of a boy) wearing shorts off very fast (literally, he has sharp buttocks). akwanus1 (of a cutting instrument) sharpness; keenness; cutting. akwanus2 (of a cutting instrument) to be sharp, keen, acute. ekwana: it is sharp . ekwana angajep: sharp-tongued; sarcastic; vitriolic. ekwana nges akituk: she/he has a sharp tongue.akwapin nuicanas : poor nations. akwapin nuepoloete : developing countries. akwapin nuabarak : developed, wealthy, or rich nations. ibore kakwap (noun neuter): sickness, smallpox, measles. ibore yen emamei ilope (noun neuter): public property. aberu kakwap : a prostitute; a public woman. akwapusinei the world; all countries. akwar sexual intercourse in animals; mating; copulation.ebiti: small spear; edomo, edobo: spear with a hook for spearing hippo. ituria: a small spear for boys. akwara nak’igirigiret: a pen-nib. ipejel: a spear like arrow.akware na: tonight. kiding kuare: midnight. akwasia to follow up (a person or animal into a secret spot in order to kill). akwat a forefoot (of an animal); a foreleg or front limb.akwatam alosit: to go about with a dirty, soiled, rough body. akwatamaar to go away unclean, unwashed. sirikikwatamaar osomero: don’t go to school unwashed and unkempt. akwatamikin to start off, go off with a dirty, unwashed body. akwatat1 a hundred. akwatat kere: all; a hundred per cent. ikar akwatat: a century. akwat akwat: hundreds and hundreds. akwatat2 a string of beads worn by women round their waists.akwe a corruption of akuwe: enlarged testicle (of men only). akweetet to have swollen testicles; (of ground) to be very dry. akweikin to roast fat for somebody. abu papa kokweik okokuke asyepai: the father roasted the fatty meat for his son. akweikwe to be white; to effloresce; to be fat (only of meat, not of living animals). ekweikwei epaaba lo: this cotton is quite white. ekweikwei akiring na: this meat is nice and fat. akweleu1 (singular noun F) paleness; anaemia. akweleu2 to be pale; to be anaemic. akwelianar to writhe (with pain); to twist the body about; to flounder. ikwelianar ngesi kanuka arieboke: she/he writhes (twists about) with pain.akwena to laugh. sirikwena: do not laugh. aitekwena etau: (to cause the heart to laugh) to console. akwenar to laugh at; to ridicule, make fun of, deride, mock. mam akoto ijo akwenar eong: I do not want you to ridicule me. akwenikin to laugh for. akweny birds. akwenyar to look away (in the distance); to turn eyes away. akwenyikin to look out for; to be watching; to be awake for. akwenyikit eong akoniswam: I have been looking at (observing) your work. akwenyun to wake up; to get up. etyono akwenyun elilim akwap: it is difficult to get up on a cold morning. akwerakin to scratch in a certain place or for. akwerar to scratch away. akweret a rake. akweretaar to scrape (meat and fat off a skin). akweretaar emukule: to scrape a skin, scrape off anything; to clean, take away all. kokwereta agar: scrape scales from the tilapia fish.akwerun to scratch this way. akwes heads; corn ears. aibil akwes: to count (heads of) people. akwesi to spread (as of potatoes, millet, etc); (of cloth) to dry. ekwesiete kesi inyamat: they spread foodstuff to dry. akwesikin to spread out for or somewhere. kokwesik igoen atiida: spread these clothes on the rock (to dry). akwetakin to call or beckon for somebody or to somewhere. abu papa kon kokwetak ijo epejonon: your father beckoned you to come to a visitor. akwetar1 to tick away; to mark as correct. akwetar2 to beckon away; to take away; to beckon to go. akwetar3 to pain; to hurt; to smart. kakweta eong akoik: my stomach hurts me. akweta naka akoik : stomach-ache. akweterer to be very skinny and short, or walk like a very skinny short person. ekweterete adekis: the skinny short people are going to the hospital. akweterikin to go or walk like a dwarf or a skinny person. akwetun to beckon to come, give one a dig. akweyiar to roast the fat meat, extract fat; to melt fat to flare up, to become suddenly angry, etc to melt (as of butter in the heat).akwi leaves. akwicakin to hang, suspend on, for or at (a place). ikwicanakinio itunga lueroko ojeera Luzira: bad people are hung in Luzira prison. to hang, suspend oneself on (a tree). kanukinyo akwicakinor ngesi?: why did he hang himself? akwicar to hang one in a place away from speaker. elosi ngesi akwicario Kampala: she/he is going to be hung at Kampala. akwidi to laugh slightly; to grin; to laugh forcibly.akwidiaros idwe kanuka alakar: the children shrieked with laughter.akwidiikin to laugh much at something; to cough excessively.akwongolol to waste away; to be thin, tall, emaciated, wasted (as of sick person or animal). ikwongolol akiteng ngin: that cow is emaciated.akyenanut1 (singular noun F) inclination to laugh. akyenanut2 to be inclined to laugh. akyenar to laugh at; to make fun of; to mock or to ridicule.
(in the Teso week) Sunday.alaanakin aur: child spacing. alaar to be spread out

to be wide spaced. alaaros amugog: the banana plantains have spread out. alabajang an edible grasshopper (long and green body); a cricket bat (in the game of einyure, made from eikiiki tree).alabira a mirror; a looking glass.alaborot a banana leaf.alacakin to set free from; to release from; to divorce from; to loosen from; to unfasten from; to untie from. alacakin angajep: to talk freely (literally, to release or loosen the tongue).alacakin akeju: let oneself go; to add on speed; to hurry (literally, to release or loosen the legs). alacakin amotoka: to add speed (literally, to release or unfasten the car). to loosen itself; to come loose, etc; to come free; to escape; to break loose. alacakinio (singular noun F) release from prison or custody; liberation; discharge; the letting go. alacar to loosen (screws or harness); to untie; to end (captivity or imprisonment); to stop (as of quarantine); to release (from quarantine); to open (box or bottle, door etc); to undo (as of a rope). alacar ajimi: to untie a bandage on a wound; to uncover a wound; to make a wound bigger by using wrong medicine, etc. to come loose; to be unlocked; to become bigger. alacet a hair comb.alacun egoe: to undress. alacun amuk: to loosen or remove shoes. alado a wild cat-like animal. aladot papyrus, Cyperus papyrus. alaga a roundabout way; a detour; diversion; deviation; a bypass.aomare alaga (asogol): to go the long way round. alaikin1 to give a slap on the ear hard. ailaikin akit: to give a slap on the ear; to strike somebody’s ear. alaikin2 (of things) to be spaced; to be wide apart; (of people) to be at loggerheads; to dislike each other; to hate one another. alaikinos itunga lu: these people are now enemies. alaire a vegetable resembling simsim plant, Sesamum; a mixture of groundnut sauce and leaves of the alilot plant.alait1 the fibre of a papyrus plant. alait2 to hate; to avoid; to have a grudge against somebody. alaita a ferry (water vehicle).alakar1 to spread out; to unroll (of cloth or skin); to loosen, disentangle. alakar etunganan: to set a man free; to redeem a debt to ransom. alakar2 to loosen itself; to free itself; to become loose or free (of things); (of man) to free oneself; to rejoice; to be glad, be cheerful, be jocund, convivial. kalakaros: let us be merry (happy, glad, cheerful). alakara (singular noun F) happiness; joy; gladness; beatitude; bonhomie. alakas a bundle of dry grass used for catching flying ants and as a torch alaket a hair comb.kolaku emukeeka, akoto aiboi: unroll the mat, I want to sit down. alakunet a deliverance; salvation; redemption.alalaar to be or become wide, spacious, broad. alalaar etogo ngol: that house is becoming spacious, i.e. the number of people or things in it is reducing. alalau1 (singular noun F) width; breadth. alalau2 to become broad; to become wide; to become spacious. aitalal: to make wide or widen; broaden, make spacious. elal erot: the road is wide . alamai a branch of elamai tree. alamaru a reed or sorghum-stem flute with four or six stops blown as a solo instrument by herdsmen or as accompaniment to akoogo dance; a fife; a clarinet; a recorder. alamat edible fruit of elamai tree; a ripe fruit, especially of a mango. alamulamu a mirror; ray bans or shades.kalangirikinit eong aswam na: this work weighs me down. kalangirikinit eong anyoun kane: it is hard for me to leave this place. kalangirikinit eong ekatau: I feel very sad, depressed, burdened. alangirior to become heavy; to become weighty; to become important. alangirior aswamuke: her/his work has become heavy, more important. alangiron a pregnant woman or animal; (anything) the heavy one. amoru alangiron: a heavy stone. alangiru1 (singular noun F) heaviness; weight; difficulty; gravity. alangiru2 to become heavy, difficult, weighty; to become pregnant (of woman or animal). alangiru kon etia ai?: how heavy are you? alangirioros (alangirioto) iboro lu: these things have become heavy. aberu ngin elangir akuwan: that woman is pregnant. alango a species of antelope.
Esabiiti alaanakin (of things) to space; to put or place wide apart
a word in the Langi language

a Langi woman or thing. Alangoi: the Langi women; the Langi language.alapak (of men only) to go or walk naked (literally, to dangle about). kolo sek alapakete Iteso: long ago the Iteso men walked naked. alapakaar (of a man) to go away naked; to become long. alapakaar auno: the rope has become long enough. alapakikin (of a man) to go about naked; to go naked, start off naked. ingai elapaki kangina?: who goes there naked? alapataar to become bare (as of place with no trees, as of table or house with nothing on or in); to become clear (as of compound). alapataar akalaro: my compound is clear, clean. alapatanar to be clean (of road, compound, of shaven head). alapatikin to be open; to be clear; to be bare of grass, of a table with nothing on, of hands with nothing in them. alapatu1 (singular noun F) emptiness, vacancy; open ground; an open plain; a compound; a firmament. alapatu2 to be bare; to be empty, vacant, destitute. elapat asaduku: the box is empty. abunit eong elapat akan: I have come empty-handed. alapodo a species of wide-mouthed fish (tilapia).alari a nape; the back of neck; the scruff of the neck. alarilar to be bare, clear; to be wide and open (like a sea or a plain or sky) , elarilari akwap, mam lolo edou etepi: it is all clear, it won’t rain today (there is no cloud). alaro a courtyard; a park; a compound. alaro nak’etogo: the floor of a house. alaro naka edege: an airfield or airport. alaro naka ere: a front-yard of a home. alarong to have a bald head. elarongi ngesi: she/he walks about with a bald head. alarongun: to come with a bald head. alarongokin: to go about bald-headed. alasiisi a license; a permit; letter of authorisation; letter of accreditation. alasilas to be nice or tasty; to be nice looking (of food or person or animal). elasilasi etelepat ngol: he is a nice, smartly dressed boy. alasit a little black tilapia fish. alatakin to fall; to apologize for. alatakin ngesi kwap: she/he has fallen down; she/he apologized for.alatar1 to throw down. to fall down; to apologize. ibusakinit ijo alatar neejai ngesi: it is imperative that you go and apologize to her/him.alatar2 to flop down, collapse, fall down, cave in, give way, crumble, disintegrate.
(singular noun F) the Latin language. alatun to drop

to come and apologize. to let fall. alatun etau: to accept an apology. alaun1 to disregard, not to heed; to disobey; to pay no attention to. sirikilau akakiro: do not disobey my instructions. to come away from. alaun emir awai epatana do aiyar: the rat has come out from its hiding place, it is now easy to kill it. alaun awai: to come away. alaun2 to become hateful; to avoid; to divorce or separate from. alaun3 to become clean, holy. alautu igoen: the clothes are clean. alaunanut1 (singular noun F) obstinacy; disobedience. elaunana etelepat lo: this boy is disobedient. alaunanut2 to be obstinate. alaunitor (prepositional verb) to disregard, pay no heed to. iswamai ijo ngun kanuka alaunitor akakiro: you do that in disregard of what I say. alean to be aflame; to be burning. eleani ekonitogo: your house is aflame. aleat a strip of meat of fish; a fish fillet. aleat naka akiring: a fillet. alecokin to punish for or somewhere. abu etengei kalecok eong Soroti: I was very hungry in Soroti (literally, hunger punished me in Soroti). alecor to trick; to con by being cunning to; to isolate and punish; to pain solely; to subdue; to infatuate. kaleco lolo eong etengei: I am very hungry today (literally, hunger is paining me today).alede a small striped brown garden lizard.aleega a brassier; a bra.alegetet to be clean, spotless, chaste, pure, beautiful, immaculate. ilegetet ngesi: ilegetetas kesi: she/he (they are) spotlessly clean. alegetu1 (singular noun F) cleanliness; chastity; beauty; justice. alegetu2 to be clean, chaste, beautiful, just. eleget nges ikeponesio: her/his manners are good; she/he is a clean living person. erai ngesi etelepat loleget: he is a clean boy aleikin to beat for somebody or somewhere. alejat1 an iron ring formerly worn in the lower lip. alejat2 the hammer or the tongue of a bell. alejekaar ki-a to become soft, weak. alejekek to be weak, puny, pathetic, fragile, scrawny, soft. alejeku1 weakness; softness; suppleness; pliability. alejeku2 to become weak, feeble, frail.alekakin ki-a to vomit on or to vomit in or at. kinyek alekakin togoka, kolot alekakin kinga: do not vomit in my house (room), go and vomit outside. alekan the vomit (of a person or an animal); puke. alekar to vomit away; to bring forth. kolot alekar ngina: go and vomit over there. alot aberu alekar adekis: the woman has gone to deliver in the hospital. alekun to vomit (this way); to say all one knows; to give birth or deliver to come out by itself (of food from stomach); to feel like vomiting. inyamat kere ekotos alekun: all the food wants to come out (from my stomach). alekun akiro: to say all one knows. alekun icel: to tell secrets; to speak insulting language. kinyek ber kalek eong ikacel: let me first reveal my secret things. alelakin to welcome; to appreciate; to enjoy. ejok alelakin epejonon: it is good to welcome a visitor. alelakinet appreciation; approval; admiration; positive reception; thanks; gratitude. alelasit pleasure; joy; happiness. alele1 a vegetable shrub, Oldenlandia.alele2 (singular noun F) effluent; waste matter; sewage; bilge water; overflow. alele3 to flow; to freewheel. eleleete akipi kosamai: the water flows in the swamp. aitelel: to make the water flow; to irrigate; to drain water. elelei ekume: the nose is (flowing) running. elelei ajimi: the sore is running. eleleete aimul: the saliva is flowing from the mouth. alelear to flow away; to float away. alelebo the merry-go-round; a seesaw. aleleikin to flow into. aleleikis akipi kai: the water has flowed into the house. aleleikis akipi togo: the water has flowed into the house. alelema a noisy, quarrelsome woman. aleleng1 hard stool or droppings of animals such as goats; goat dung. Aleleng2 (singular noun F) (the Jewish or Christian feast of) the Passover. aleleng3 to leave out; to leave untouched (as in weeding, not touching the main plant); to pass over or to omit. kalelengitoi eong kane bon: I was left out here alone (from the invitation).alelengikin to leave out; to pass by (a person when selecting); to ignore. kocap eduan bon kolelengik akimai: take out the weeds only, leave the millet (untouched). inyo bo kilelengitere ijo?: why are you ignored? alelengoor to leave out; to choose and take away. kolelengoo kwi, kolelengu nuwok bonik: leave out those, take ours only. alelengun to choose for oneself, select for oneself. kojep ikito lueroko, kolelengu luejokak: cut the bad trees and leave the good ones for us. aleles a ditch; a stream; a river; flowing water; a gutter; a current; an empty drain; a dry water course. aleleuro a mountain pigeon.
a pet name for a cow with brown and black stripes. aleliar to erode

to wear away; (of wealth or riches) to get wasted. alelio a fruit of ekalelyoi tree, Carissa edulis.alelot a vegetable used to give eboo vegetables the slimy feel.alem2 a plant, Leonotis nepetaefolia.alemar1 excepting; with the exception of; apart from. alemar2 to take away, or to abrogate; to subtract; to make free; to except; to take off. alemar na: besides. koge ber alemar lukon iboro: first take away your things. to be taken away; to be finished; to die out, abate. alemelem1 akeje to bewitch. kelemelem ecudan adaeka: the witch has bewitched my foot prints (i.e. she/he took the dust of my foot prints home and mixed the dust with medicine, cursed me who stepped on the above dust – causing pain on my legs). alemelem2 to steal; to pilfer; to bewitch. alemelemetoi iboro: to pilfer; to steal small things often pilferage. alemikin to pick for somebody (something); to pay for somebody (taxes, dowry, etc); to take up for somebody; to choose for somebody. alemikin akerit to get up and run away (off); to rush away; to vanish. alemikinos ikokolak akerit: the thieves ran off, vanished. alemilem to enchant, put a magic charm on; to bewitch. alemokin to pour out, into, too much (of any liquid). mam akoto ijo alemokin akile toma ocaai: do not pour too much milk into the tea. alemun to choose; to select; to pay (fine); to subtract. akoto alemun ber luka: I want to take out or choose my things; to pick up, abstract. alemun etau: to agree entirely. alemar etau: to cease to love or like, be indifferent. adau eong alemar etau kane ejai ngesi: I do not like her/him anymore. alemun eluk: to pay for adultery. to be chosen; to be paid, etc; to be picked; to come off. alemum epaaba kere: all the cotton has been picked. alemun apeesa: the button has come off (my shirt). alemunyang a donkey; zebra.alemura the only child (female) born to a woman.alemwoit a desert-rose bush, Adenium globosum. alenger (to walk or go) to be circumcised. alengerikin (of a circumcised person) to run off. alepon semen.alepor1 to pour out; to have diarrhoea. alepor eporododo: to suffer from very noisy diarrhoea. alepor esiric: to have uncontrollable diarrhoea. alepor aokot: to suffer from blood diarrhoea; to have dysentery. ekia loka alepor: medicine for dysentery. alepor2 to start and rush off. alepor je akurianaar ejie: the other guy has run off fearing a fight. alepun to jump out; to rise; to come up suddenly; to come to the surface; to spout out. alepun emir kotogoke: a rat jumped out of its hole. alepunos akipi kotoma atan: the water spouted up from a well. alero a blue gem worn on ears. aleru a large spear; a plant, Cucumis. alesi to stretch out (of mats, etc) (only used with noun object in plural: elesie ngesi imukuleneke: she/he is busy stretching her/his hides to dry). alesiar ki-o to lie down; to stretch oneself out (dead tired).kapas eong, akoto alesiar: I am tired, I want to stretch myself out. alet a small silver fish, Engraulicyprus argenteus. aletenyeny (of a vessel) to be shallow; to be flat (of buttocks). iletenyeny atiida mam ibwauni akipi: the hole in the rock is shallow, it does not hold much water. aletenyikin to make shallow (as of a pot). iletenyikina amoti ngun: those pots are shallow (flattish), not deep. aleun to tire out; to get by force of beating; to overcome.kaleu eong aswam na: this work has tired me out. to be very tired.Aleya1 (in the Teso week) Tuesday.erai kwana aleyakon: it is now your turn. ali? (interrogation, M) which? who? ali bo?: where is he? which one? ali bo ngesi?: where is he?aliagam (of a tall person or animal, bird) to move or walk. iliagami ijo alosit: you are very tall (you go, walk like a very tall man). aliagamikin (of a tall person or tree) to fall down. alian (of fire) to flame up; to be on fire; ablaze; to be burning. alian akim kokekwa kaje: there is a fire over that hill. alianata itogoi: the houses are on fire. alianakin to pour from for, somewhere; to pour little by little. to flow from. alianikin to kindle the fire (by blowing); to set ablaze; to stir the fire into a flame. to be on fire, aflame. alianiki ekatogo: my house is on fire. alianis to smell as of fresh milk, meat, fish, newly born baby; to be smelling like fresh milk, meat, fish, or a dog which has been in the rain. alianus to smell as of fresh milk, meat, fish, newly born baby; to be smelling like fresh milk, meat, fish, or a dog which has been in the rain.aliar1 to creep or crawl away (of a snake, an insect, etc). aliar2 to pour away (water, etc). koliaa ajon ngun nueroko: pour that bad beer away to be poured away (as of dirty water, etc); to be soft; to dissolve (like sugar or salt in water); to be watery. aliaros ajon: the beer was poured out, away (as useless). aliasit root (of a plant); the cause or origin of. aliasit naka emusaago: the cause of accusation. aliat to creep, or to crawl (of a snake, etc). eliat emun: the snake is crawling. aliatok flowing water; any creeping creatures. akoto aliatok: I want water.aliaton any creeping creature. erai emun aliaton: a snake is a creeping creature. aliaun to creep or crawl this way or towards the speaker (of a snake, an insect, etc) alibaanut1 greenness; verdure. alibaanut2 to be green, emerald, lime, jade, olive. elibaana ekitoi ngol: that tree is green. alibakin to feel or make cold, chilly. kalibakit eong aterot: I feel chilly, cold (literally, the wind makes me feel cold). alibat a bird - golden oriole. alibet a shoot (of a plant or a tree); bud. alibilib to grow or be very green, blue. elibilibete inya: the grass is verdant and lush. iporo ngesi elibilibiata inya: it is during the rainy season that the grass becomes emerald green. alibit a diving wild duck; a darter. aliborit a banana plantain or leaf, Musa paradisiaca. Its leaves and stems are used as fodder, thatch, fibre, and food wrapping, while the fruit is made into beer, banana juice and food.aliboro a species of bird - a redwing shrike. alibosit a shoot of potatoes that sprouts from the tuber itself.alibulibun to sprout; to become green. alibun to bud; to sprout; to shoot out; to become green; to develop; to revive (after dry season). alibutu inya bobo: the grass has sprouted out again. alibunet a shoot (of a plant or tree); a source (of river); a cause; a beginning; an origin (of a dispute). alibunet naka ekek: the beginning or origin of a clan. alibunet naka iboro: an element; a fundament; the origin of things. alicait white gravel; marble; flint-stone; mica; crystal. alidakin to fasten round for; to tighten to be too tight. alidakin akarokoba: my belt is too tight. alidar to take away, fastening tight; to catch hold of. alidioar to become unripe, undeveloped. alidioar emaido: the groundnuts are not seeded. alidioar ikoku: the child is premature. alidiou1 prematurity; rawness; freshness. alidiou2 to be unripe; to be premature; to be very young, fresh, raw. alidiou: premature; rawness; freshness. alidok (of a man or boy) to be naked or nude; to be in Adam’s suit; to have one’s penis dangling about.alidun to get hold of; to catch hold of. alidun akiro: to pay attention; to listen attentively; to mind what is being said. alidun iponesio: to take over habits; to catch, acquire habits. alies1 softness; liquidness; wateriness (of food). eli ekatau: I am upset. alies2 to be too soft, too watery, too wet. eli atap na: this millet bread is too soft. eliak acok ngun: those potatoes are too watery and soft. aliet a spout, etc for pouring out; a funnel. aligim to have or move about with a distended belly. aligimikin to poison the stomach so that it distends; to impregnate. aligimim (of stomach) to be distended; (of a woman) to be pregnant. aligirikin ki-a to distend; to impregnate. aligot a young pea (still in a pod); a young bean pod. aliik to have or to go with a large head. aliikik to be large-headed; to be fat-headed. aliikin to pour out; to instil; to pour into; to pour out for. koliikinai ajon keriik: pour out some beer for me to gulp. koyau eikopo kaliikinia ecaai: bring a cup I pour out some tea for you. aliit a plant used for rafter; a long straight pole.alili1 (singular noun F) jealousy; envy; covetousness. alili2 to pine for; to desire; to go on a journey; to be jealous of. elilito kesi ekagaali: they are jealous of my bicycle. aliliikin to be jealous or to be envious; to envy. aliliikit eong akoniswam: I envy your work. alilikin to do in excess; to overdo; to do too much. alilikin aimat ajon: to drink too much beer; to debauch; to indulge in. sirikililik aswam: do not work too hard. alilikin ainyam: to eat too much. alilimior to cool; to become cold; to become cool; to grow cold, cool. alilimioros akipi: the water has become cold. aliling to paint in different colours. alilio (singular noun F) jealousy; envy. alilit to desire to be envious of; to be jealous of. alilit eong akoniswam: I envy your work.alilot a plant used for making eboo vegetable sauce slimy; the slimy sauce made with alilot plant, Corchorus trilocularis.aliluar to emigrate; to go far away; to go and settle down far away; to go on a journey and stay for a long time. akoto aliluar Bulaya: I am going to Europe. alim iron sheet; corrugated iron sheet. asaduku alim: a metallic box. ibore yenilim: an iron thing. iboro lulim: iron things. alimokin to tell; to inform; to say to; to confess to; to announce; to report; to invite, mention, admonish, apprise. kolimokinai nuijeni: tell me what you know. alimokinet an order; a command, precept, advice, counsel. alimonokin to preach; to admonish; to keep telling, or saying to; to advice to meditate; to ponder over. alimonokinet an order, command, precept or teaching, advice, counsel. alimor to speak out; to report about; to confess; to betray another; to say, utter; to declaim, declare, aver; to prosecute. kolimo nuejaas otaukon: say what is on your mind (literally, say what is in your heart). alimoret an announcement; an advertisement; an ad. aipikakin alimoret oredio arai apapulai: to place an announcement in the radio or in the newspapers. ilimoreta ludidik: classified ads. alimun to confess; to speak out; to pronounce; to utter. alimun ekiror: to nominate somebody; to name; to say the name. Sirilim: (a pun, literally ‘Don’t say’) Slim (AIDS). alingakin to be early at; to be before time; to paint in a different colour once. akoto alingakin aswam: I want to start work early. elingakin ngesi alosit okeresia: she/he goes to the cathedral before time. alingar to go first; to go early. elingaros idwe ajo: the children go early to bed. alingiling to mark often (the body or anything); to put marks on; to paint in different colours. alingiling itunganan k’ebela: to mark a person with marks of beating. alinyo (singular noun F) baby lotion from simsim or sheanut butter; sheanut oil made from the seeds of ekungur tree.aliokokin akiro to tell lies about somebody; to calumniate; to slander. aliokokinet calumny; slander; denigration. iliokokinit ijo eong akiro: you calumniate me. aliokon (singular noun F) deceit; a lie; a fib; a hypocrisy. aliokonor to become a liar; to become deceitful. aliokonor etelepat ngol: that boy has become a liar. aliokonut to be fond of deceiving; to be deceitful. aliokono eong, iliokono ijo, kiliokoko oni, iliokoko yesi: I, you, we, you are deceitful/liars. aliokor to go and tell lies somewhere. kolioko ijo akonikiro nenice: go and tell your lies somewhere else. alior to be thin with protruding belly (to go with a thin body, etc). alipan a begging; the asking. alosi alipan: I go begging. alipong vagina; the external sex organs of a woman; private parts of a woman; female genitalia. ipon luka alipong: the genital labia (majora and minora). alir a very deaf woman; a total hearing-impaired female; a very dense or daft woman.aliriangang (abstract noun F) deafness; dumbness; foolishness; daftness.aliru a short stabbing spear with a large blade; an assegai.alitokin to make too long to be too long, too far. alitokin auno: to make the rope too long. alitokin ainyam: to eat before others; to eat before time. alitokin akiro: to say more than necessary; to say too much. alitokin ingaren: to go too far ahead. alitor akeje to make long strides to go too far ahead. kolito akeju ingaren: stretch the leg forward (making big strides). ilitor ijo ingaren, kobongu ber kau nepetai: you go too far ahead, come back a little. alitoro to be too far ahead, advanced. alitun to shoot out (of the ground, as of plants).aliyan fire flame. aloanakin akolong to dry things in the sun; to spread in the sun. aloboi ploughed field before crops are planted. alobot a furrow; a dug-up garden or ploughed field. aitwa aloboi: ailakilak aloboi: to clean the field (of grass and rubbish).aloet place for drying in the sun; a string for drying on. alogec to be bandy-legged; to be bow-legged. elogeci ngesi ore: she/he goes home bow-legged. aloger to put a spoke in the wheel; to trip a person (as in football) or an animal (by putting hand between legs when milking); to hamper. aloger akiro: to thwart a plan. aloger itunganan: to try to trip someone; to obstruct someone's progress. alogereun to trip this way. alogerikin to trip someone; to make a person angry; to embarrass; to thwart; to hinder. karai komam ijo alogerikin eong, ti kadum ajakaanut: had you not thwarted me, I would have been appointed to leadership. aloikin to air; to spread out to dry; to put in the sun. koloik igoen ngul: spread out those clothes to dry.
akalyo, akalelyoi alelioit the fruit of a hooked-thorn tree, Carissa edulis
(in the Teso week) Friday.alokar to trap and take away

to catch. akoto alokar akweny: I want to catch birds (with a trap and take away). Aloket1 (an Ateso reference to) a Karamojong tribeswoman. aloket2 a trap; a snare. aloketa nuka ajokit: the devil’s tricks or temptations. alokikin to put a trap for somebody or somewhere. kolokik eic nen: put the trap there. alokor to knock off, away; to extract tooth; to knock off (as of a piece of a pot or anything). alokot a place where teeth have been extracted or are missing.alokun to entice this way; to draw into a trap. alokun etunganan: to pay back in the same currency; to give tit for tat. to reach age of puberty (of boy). alokunet (singular noun F) puberty (of boys only). alolo to walk in a crouching way (as a thief or hunter); to slouch. ekamejan eloloi keanyu etyang: a hunter crouches when she/he sees a hunted animal. aloloar to go down (as of sun); to creep away; to sneak away (as of a thief); to go on a long journey. aloloa akolong: the sun has gone down. alolokin to creep towards. alosi eong alolokin akweny: I am going to creep towards a bird (to catch it). alolot to walk with a stoop; to go away secretly. elolot ekokolan: the thief walks with a stoop, secretly. alolotoi to keep sneaking round to do in an obscure way, sneaking way. elolotoi egole duc: the hawk flies low and shuns people. aloloun to creep this way; to slouch this way. alolouro a big pigeon; a mountain dove. alomakin to go into; to attack; to enter into; to start (work or anything); to invade. alosi alomakin akirokus: I am going into your case. kolomakisi aswam: start your work. to be started; to attack each other. alomar to enter a place or to go out (away from speaker); (of something sharp or pointed) to penetrate; (of sun) to go down, to set. alomar ataker: to embark, go in a boat; to go on board a boat. alomar akiro: to go into a case, examine a case, interfere, meddle. sirikiloma: no admittance. esineema ngol elomario aite atitai: that film is for free entry. alomarit to be connected with; to terminate in. erot lo elomarit orot loko Soroti: this road is connected with (terminates in) the Soroti road. alomun1 by chance. alomun2 to come outside; to come inside; to enter; to come towards; to appear above ground. ekoto epaaba alomun: the cotton is about to germinate (above the ground). alomutu aokot: the blood is oozing out. aitolomun akoik: to procure abortion. alomun akoik to have abortion. along (to do) simply; for nothing; just. acupa along: just a bottle only.aiboi along: to be alone; by oneself; to go naked. alonga a plant, Malvaceae. alongalong (to go somewhere) in vain; for nothing.alongorikin to run off with a thick deformed penis or big eyeballs. alongoror to have a thick penis or large eyeballs. alongwaanar to become lazy. alongwaanut1 (singular noun F) idleness; lethargy; indolence. alongwaanut2 to be very lazy, idle. alongwaana, ilongwaana I am, you are, lazy.alongwau (singular noun F) laziness; lethargy; indolence; awkwardness. alonyakin to miss a mark. abu eong kalonyak etyang kosamai: I missed (hitting) the animal in the swamp. aloorit a sandal made of a rubber tyre of a car. alopan a midwife. alope1 by herself; alone; the very one. iboyie ngesi alope bon: she lives by herself. ngesi ajakait alope: she is the boss herself (no other person). eong alope akituk: I am the owner of the cows. ijo alope: you yourself. alope2 the owner. alope akiro: the woman or female in question; the accuser. alope akwap: a female native or inhabitant of a region or country. ilope (neuter): the owner (general).alopolop to intertwine or plait (as of a mat); to strap (as of a belt, etc). alopolopit eong emukeeka: I plaited or weaved a mat. alopolop atenus: to string a drum; to plait strings on the side of a drum; to kick or punch one on his side. abu eong kalopolop emopiira kakeju: I kicked the ball. alos (singular noun F) threshed finger millet or sorghum grain (or flour from it) for the preparation of atap bread; millet and/or sorghum grain mixed with cassava and ground into flour for eating as atap. alosenen to go out repeatedly; to keep going to often. alosikin to approach; to intend; to go nearer somebody; to do intentionally; to do purposely; to go and attack. alosikinit eong ejakait ailip ibore: I approached the chief to beg. alosikinit eong ajon: I am on a drinking spree. alosikinet an intention; an objective, a goal; mission (the purpose for which one feels one was born). alosikinit to make up one’s mind; to intend; to do intentionally; to do purposely; to go and attack. alosikinit eong ejakait aibunga: my husband has intended to attack me (even when I have done no wrong). alosior to go towards. alosio ngesi okekwa je: she/he has gone to the other side (of the swamp). alosit1 a trip; itinerary. abu eong kalot alosito aare: I made two trips. alosit2 (singular noun F) journey; transport; travelling. aroniar alosit na: this journey is getting hazardous or fraught with hardship. alosi: I (shall) go/do; I am about to (go/do); I intend to; I shall soon. alosi eong ainyam: I am about to eat some food: I am going to have some food. alosit3 to go away; to depart, leave; to be about to do. alosit kwangin: to go naked or nude. alosi eong aswam ibore: I shall or will do something. alot1 (singular noun F) the goings; an affair or amorous relationship. aroniar alot na: this affair is going awry or sour. alot2 to go (seldom used as infinitive except as noun). alosi: I go . aloun to come out into the open; to appear outside. aloun ekokolan kinga: the thief has come out from her/his hiding place.aloyianar to sprawl; to loll about. aloyiar1 to take away; to spread out in the sun. aloyiar2 (of people, animals, birds) to be scattered; to spread out; to be dispersed. aloiaros angor komana ecapete: the women are scattered over the field weeding. aloiaros Iteso akwapin: the Iteso have spread over various countries. aloyio (passive verb) to be spread in the sun. ekaaso lo ekot aloyio: this cassock needs to be spread in the sun to dry.
Naikanyet alokanakin aki to pay attention; to listen carefully; to give ear to, attend to
an Indian woman, or a word in any Indian languages (Hindi, Sinhales, Tamil, etc). alugum to round

to blow out (as of stomach); to make corpulent. alugumum to be round (as of a pot, stomach, etc); to be corpulent. alugura to be bent like a bow; to stoop; to crouch down. alosi alugura otida: I am going to bend down beating the etida drum. alugurikin to bend (something like a bow) to be bent; to stoop itself. alugurur1 (singular noun F) curvature; twisting. alugurur2 to be bent. ilugurur ekaraman k’atenus: the drummer bends when beating the drum.

a woman native to Arua district; a word in Lugbara. Alugwaaran: the Lugbara women; the Lugbara language. aluikin to turn into an enemy. iluikit ijo opaperokon: you have become an enemy to your friend: you have turned your friend into an enemy. alujukuk to be weak, bendable, flexible, soft, limber, supple. alujukuk bala emun: lithe as a snake. lujuluj bala emun: lithe as a snake. alukakin to enclose; to go round something; to surround; to make round. kalukakisi ityang kiding: let us surround the animals (i.e. let us put the animals in the middle). alukar einer (of many people) to talk about a person present. inyo bo kilukariata yesi eong einer?: why have you besieged me with your gossip? (note: talking about absent person is aisiom).alukuj ki-a to go round something; to go round bends in road. ilukujai ngesi alosit mam itenarit erot: she/he goes round about, she/he does not keep to the road. alukujuj to be round. ilukujujos ikekitinyo: her/his cheeks are round. alukuluk ki-a to peck here and there (as of a bird). ilukuluki akokor alos: the hen pecks millet here and there. alukumet a circle. kiswama alukumet: make a circle. alukumet naka etogo: the circle of a house. alukun1 einer (of many people) to talk about a person present. inyo bo kilukuniata yesi eong einer?: what are you saying about me? (note: talking about an absent person is aisiom)alukun2 to surround, encompass; to encircle; to sit round (food or beer pot); to weave, centralize. kalukutu ikole: let us encircle the mudfish (to catch them by hand). kolukutu emukeeka: weave the mat (hem it).alukunet a circle; a loop; a ring; a circumference. alukuren a grass, Chloris. alulu to go far away; to vanish, clear off. eluluete kesi: they vanish. aluluar to go on a journey; to vanish; to clear off; to go far away. alulua ngesi acekwap: she/he has gone off to another country. alumangang to be hornless, handle-less, or round.alumangangat to be blunt; to be hornless; to be dull or stupid. ilumangangas itelepai lu kere: all these boys are dull. alumokin to dive for (saving) somebody or something; to dive after; to plunge into. alumor to dive and swim away. alumusus to be hornless. alung a piece, a cutting or chunk (of meat, food or soap). alungia nuka akiring: chunks of meat. alungakin to refuse to have food with; to refuse to take back a thing (because someone spoiled it); to refuse payment, etc (when dissatisfied) to do a thing in spite of anything; to pour out suddenly and quickly. alungakin ngesi akoko: she/he steals in spite of the consequences. alungaki papa okokuke inyamat: the father has refused to eat with his son alungar to go away angrily, shake the dust off one’s feet. alungar epejonon kane: the visitor went away in a bad mood. to pour out quickly. alungit (singular noun F) abhorrence; loathing; revulsion; repugnance. alungitoi to go very fast, tear along, or gravitate. alunguret an ear of grain; a lump of (bread or food); a crowd of (people or anything); a mass of anything; a team (of players); a bunch of bananas.alungurur to be round (as a ball, an orange or tree trunk).ilungurur: round shouldered; stooping. alunguur (singular noun F) roundness round and fat (as a bull). ilunguur emong ngol: that bull is fat and round, or plump. aluomod to eat something soft (in the form of porridge). aluor to change into; to discolour; to fly into a rage. aluoros ikeponesio: her/his manners have changed. aluonor: to change often. eluonor agougou: the chameleon often changes colour. alup earth; soil; land. alupok earth; soil; land.aluriluritoi to hang one’s head; to cower. alurokin to keep (working, etc); to be bent (on doing). alurokin alosit: to keep on walking. alurokin aisisia: to keep on, to be bent on learning. aluror to bend forward; to look down, droop, or bow. elurorete kesi kanuka ileic: they look down with shame. aluru a quail. alurugut a species of fish, Haplochromis. alurukene a bird - a black crake.alusumum (of a club) to be round-headed; (of a sheep, cow) to have a round head, be hornless. aluterer to have protruding frog-like eyes. alutukony a stick for stirring porridge or mingling atap (bread).
an Alur tribeswoman from the district of Nebbi and speaking a Luo dialect called Alur

a word in Alur language. Aluurun: the Alur women; the Alur language (a Luo dialect spoken in Nebbi). aluut a cow-horn or side-blown trumpet to warn people of danger (especially after Karimojong raiders have been sighted). alwak (singular noun F) a corruption of alwek: a swarm; a brood; a crowd. toto nak’alwak: mother of many children.alwanikin to be too far for. kalwanikit eong bukus: your home is too far away for me. alwanus1 distance; remoteness. alwanus2 to be far; to be distant. alwana eong: I am far off. kilwaka iso: we are far off. alwek (singular noun F) a swarm; a brood; a crowd. toto k’alwek: mother of many children.alyaar to crawl or creep or climb away. alyaat to creep, crawl; to be creeping. alyaikin to creep to; to twine round; to encircle. abu emun kolyaik ikoku: the snake twined round the child. amaapu a map; atlas; a chart. amaaran a rib (figurative) a wife. amabaati a corrugated iron or zinc sheet; a roof made of iron sheets.to become or be dislocated; to become or be sprained. amabuusu a prison; a jail. amacakin to tell lies about somebody. amacar to make a mark by beating or burning, or branding with a hot iron; to draw or write in a stylish way. amacigo a worm used as fishing bait. amadaala a ladder; steps; a rung; a hierarchy; a ranking.amadit1 (formerly) a small but courageous bantam hen imported from Java. Amadit2 a small stumpy woman; a dwarf; a Madi woman; a woman native to Moyo or Adjumani districts on the north-western tip of Uganda; a word in the Madi tongue. Amadi: the Madi women; the language of the Madi. amaduli a hat; a turban; a cap.amagaalit a farm wagon; ox wagon or cart; a trawler.Amagarait2 a Musoga or Mugwere woman or word. Amagara: Basoga, Bagwere women or their language. amagoro an uninhabited region; a desert; a wild forested area; the bush. iboiete ityang kamagoro: animals live in the bush. amagulusio tribulations; the ups and downs; the twists and turns of fate. amaikin ekiror to give name to; to call; to name. kamaikit eong ijo ekonikiror Petero: I call you, I give you the name of Peter.
a Luo dialect spoken in Nebbi

a word in Lumasaba – the language of the Bagisu people; a woman native to Bugisu, i.e. the present day Mbale and Sironko districts in eastern Uganda. Amaikoko: the language of the Bagisu or Bamasaba people; the Lumasaba language.amairo a mile (distance measure).amaisa (of a prison term) for life. aiwen amaisa: to imprison for life. awenio amaisa: life imprisonment. amajaani tea leaves. amajing to go like a deaf man. amajinging to be deaf. imajinging ijo: imajingingas yesi: you are deaf. amajingingaar to become deaf. amajokot an ox yoke; a harness.amakacac to be splay-footed.
a Muganda tribeswoman from the Baganda tribe – one of the Bantu-speaking tribes of central Uganda

a word in Luganda language; a woman native to Buganda – the present day Masaka, Mukono, Mpigi, Luwero, Kampala, etc districts. Amakada: Baganda women; the Luganda language.amakadi rock salt; salt lick (for livestock); sodium bicarbonate; Magadi salt.amakajan syphilitic swellings.
a woman from the Bakenye tribe (a Bantu-speaking fishing community mostly found at the shores of Teso lakes). amakereeda (in Pallisa) a tablet (of medicine)

a pill.amalan1 I greet you!; greetings! amalan2 ki-a to greet, salute, or to welcome; to thank; to congratulate. alosi amalan ejakait: I am going to pay my respects to the chief or to my husband, master, boss. amalayat a prostitute; a harlot; a whore; a sex worker. amaliongong to have a miserly, sickly look. amaluguguonor to undulate; to roll, ripple, or rise and fall; to heave or surge. amame to be absent, not to exist; not to have or possess. amamei eong (I am absent), emamei ngesi (she/he is not there), imamei ijo (you – singular - are absent), kimamei iso (we – exclusive – are absent), imameete yesi (you – plural – are not there). past: amameete (they were not there), imameete (you – plural – were absent), emamei eong aberu: I have no wife. emameete ileic: she/he is unashamed, barefaced, or shameless. amamean the absent one(s); absentee; absconder. akiro nuamameak: fiction. nuinera ijo eraas nuamameak: what you say is not there: is not true: it is fiction. amamear not to be there. amamearos kangina: there are none over there. amameikin to lack; to be without; not to have. kamameiki eong acoa: I am at a loss, I cannot decide. amameiki eong akine: I have no goat. imamekinete ijo inyamat: you will have no food. amameu (singular noun F) annihilation; absence; vacancy. kotoma amameu k'ejakait: in the absence of the chief.amameutu isirigin: there is no money. amameunos isirigin: there is no money.amamian the missing; an absentee. kideikis loamamian: leave something for the absent one. edar ngol da amamiak: I waited for him in vain.amamikit to need, be in want; to be without. kamamikit eong egoe: I am in need of cloth. amamus (singular noun F) absence; nothingness.amanaka: my garden.amanakin to go and find for; to go round something. komanakinai inyamat: go round and find me some food. to hide soon; to turn into a certain direction. ai bo amanaki akine na?: where has this goat gone to. ai bo ibu ijo komanak?: where did you hide yourself? amananakin to be going round and round; to be hidden; to keep hiding. amananut to be fond of roaming about a roaming spirit. amanar to pass, to go round something. amaneja a manageress.komanu lailo: come round this way. to find by going round. amanyaar (of a woman or girl) to get married away. amanyakin to pay dowry for somebody; to get married.amanyanakin to marry many women; to pay dowry for more than one woman (on behalf of or for somebody). amanyat a fiancée; a bride-to-be; a marriageable girl. amaragait a rib.amaran to tremble; to shake; to quake; to shiver; to be nervous; to be in a hurry to get off, thrill, vibrate. amaran aterot: to shiver with cold. emarani ngesi akuwan enyami: she/he is very greedy (literally, shaking with greed while eating). emarani akwap: there is an earthquake. imarani bo ai, eapie nen?: why such a hurry, that place is nearby? emarani ngesi bokobok (teletel): she/he trembles all over (her/his body).amaranaar to hurry away. amaranaar ngesi ore: she/he has hurried home. amaranun to begin to tremble or shake. amaratoit a brass armlet.amaria to scramble, rush for; to claim; to fight for, vie with; to grab, contest. amariamaria1 confusion, disorder; a mix up. amariamaria2 to keep grabbing; to rush (of water); to race; to contend. amariar (of many) to quickly finish; to vie, fight for. amariasi itunga akiring: people are fighting to buy a piece of meat. amariaros itunga togo: people have struggled to get into the house. amasabu soap. imasabu: a little soap; a piece of soap. amasabu nak’iloset: washing soap. amasabu nak’ilongis: toilet or bathing soap. atekat naka amasabu: a bar of soap. apeelet naka amasabu: a flake of soap. amasabu akiria: powder soap.amasakaliat a species of bird. amasikin to rust; to corrode; to stain (of teeth); to be dirty; to drink on behalf of someone. emasikito ikel: the teeth are stained. amasikin itunganan ekia: to recieve medication because of someone’s beating (the police will need a medical report of injuries incurred in order to prosecute someone for an assault case). amasiribut a moustache; a beard; sideburns. amataar to drink up; to empty out; to soak up; to drain. to have no strength left; to be near death; to feign death. amatabwino blotting paper; a fountain pen. amatagulat a roofing tile. amatapaalit a brick; a block. amateeka a book of basic religious teachings. amatenget the side of the head; the cheek; the temple. amatet a pub or public house. amatong to have a thin bony face with prominent jaws. amatongongoor to become thin-cheeked and bejawled. amatun1 akiro to investigate; to elicit. amatun2 akituk to pout, protrude lips on account of anger or sickness. amatuta a break-water; drainage; a dam; a small dyke; separation between gardens. amaukuk (literally) to be bigheaded; to have a big head.amaut a treasure; a gift. ameanakin to reciprocate. ameanakin einer arai aswam: to speak or do in turns. komeanakinos einer: speak in turns (not all together).amear from here on. amear kane aitodol osamai: from here on to the swamp. amearit from now onwards. amecat a shelter; a harbour. ameda a profit, gain, fruit, premium.amedel to be kind, gentle, merciful, clement, benign, gracious, or magnanimous. ebokorit lomedelit: the little finger. amedelanut (singular noun F) magnanimity; generosity. ameegi (singular noun F) (in Pallisa) yellow bananas (ripes).amegerer to be thin, emaciated; to be under-grown (of man, animals and plants). ameikin to drive (cattle or goats or prisoners to their stable or to prison); to stalk. ameikin aimany: to wait for elder brother to get married first. ameikin acok: to herd in turns; to pass on one’s turn of herding to someone else; to do in turns.amej to hunt; to persecute. amejai: I hunt. emejaete: they hunt.amejaar to hunt far away; to be hunting and take away; to kill and take away. amejal a red anthill. amejaun to surround in hunting, kill, and bring this way. ameje an abandoned home or village.amekek a pangolin or scaly ant-eater, Manis temminckii.
ekia, ekulony amakesit (school) marks; a correct tick; results; a grade
a woman from the Bakenye tribe, the fisher tribe of Bantu origin that lives near lakes in Teso

a word in the language spoken by the Bakenye. Amekenyin: the Bakenye women or their language. amekimek armlet or wristlet made from pieces of ostrich eggshell. amelejang a green grasshopper.idila amelo: there is plenty of new grass. ameme to spear; to aim at with a spear. amemei eong akingok nakokolan: I am aiming at a thieving dog (bitch) with a spear. abu eong kameme ekue: I speared a fox. amemeon one who hunts with spears. amen (usually said after a prayer) so be it; Amen.amenanut to be rebellious. dissatisfaction; rebelliousness; unruliness; insubordination. amengeranut1 (singular noun F) disobedience; defiance; rebelliousness; mutiny. amengeranut2 to be defiant; to be disobedient, insolent. amengerana eong, imengerana ijo, imengeraka yesi: I am/you are defiant, disobedient, insolent. amengerikin to disobey; to cause trouble or sorrow; to sabotage. kimengerik ijo eong kanuka airengiar ikakoku kosomero: you upset me by dismissing my child from school. amenit to disobey someone with authority; to have a dislike for; to have a grudge against; to be too little for. amenit eong ajon ngun: I consider that beer not worthwhile, it is too little for me. ameniton a rebel; a law-breaker. amenitonut (singular noun F) insolence; impudence; disrespect; cheek; audacity; impertinence; rudeness. ameonor to keep licking something (like a cat with its kittens). to keep licking itself like a cat or dog; to smack lips. ameor to lick off; to finish off.amera1 drunkenness; intoxication; rustiness. amera2 to be drunk; to be foolish on account of drinking too much. (lst person amera) . ameran a drunken person; a drunkard; a sot. ameranut to be in the habit of getting drunk. amerekek an ewe; a sheep.amerekekin a group of stars appearing between November and February.
alabajang amelo young grass after grass fire; green pasture
a pet name for a white and bluish flecked cow. amerianut (singular noun F) tarnish

stain. amerikin1 to be stained; to become rusty, tarnished. ameriki ekakileng: my knife is rusty. amerikin enyel: to become rusty. amerikin2 to become or be drunk or intoxicated. amerikinos kesi: they are drunk or inebriated. emerikinos kesi: they will become drunk. ametar to take all.ameun1 starting from; hence; since. ameun …aitodol: from … to. ameun eiditeuka: from or since my childhood. ameun2 to drive (cattle, etc) this way. amiam a small antelope, oribi, Ourebia ourebi. amidakin to eat by dipping finger into food or sugar, etc; to taste food by dipping finger into food and licking it. aisimidanakin ikoku inyamat: to feed a child with one’s fingers. amidilil to have small slit eyes; to be slit-eyed. imidililas akonye: imidiolitos akonye: having small slit eyes. amidiolit eye discharge or exudates.amiidi a tobacco or opium pipe. amiit to be wealthy; to have plenty of anything, especially food.amijiiri a small termite, different from amijimij.amijimij a small termite. amilimil to shine or glisten as of mica, or corrugated zinc sheets. amimiru1 (singular noun F) rancidity (of urine); staleness; rottenness (of butter). amimiru2 to become rancid. amin (singular noun F) love; liking; adoration; charity; kindness. amina to love, affect, or to care for; to be used to; to be fond of; to take a fancy to; to delight. eminas itunga epapaali: people like pawpaw fruit. emamei nges amin: she/he has no charity, kindness. amina itunganan: to be attached; to love someone. aminakin to take a fancy to; to like. aminaki etelepat esomero: the boy likes school. aminanar to love one another. kominanaros bonik: love one another. aminanut to be kind-hearted; to be charitable. aminar to captivate; to fancy; to tickle one’s fancy; to be amused. aminasi ngol akirokon: what you say has tickled his fancy, amuses him. aminat dear; beloved; dear one; popular; darling (used in opening or closing address, letters - translated as ‘yours dearly’). aming (collective noun F) small inedible termites.aminit a branch or wood from eminit tree; the place where iminito trees grow. aminun to fall in love with; to begin to like; to begin to like; to be in favour of. aminutu ijako nges: the chiefs like her/him. abu etelepat kominu apese: the boy fell in love with a girl. aminun: to be reconciled. aminyine1 a generic name for small inedible white ants. aminyine2 syphilitic lesions, Condylomata. amio (singular noun F) plenty; wealth; treasure (not of cows, etc but in food); high living. edumunit ngesi amio kakimai: she/he has got plenty of millet.amion1 a very small field mouse. amion2 one who is wealthy in food or crops.
apetar, amear ameturat ashes as blown up from grass fire or of a house on fire

a word in the Langi language.amisa a big stick; cudgel. to beat with a big stick. amisianakin to know well; to understand; to comprehend.amisianut1 shrewdness; astuteness; wisdom; intelligence; acumen. amisianut2 to be shrewd; to be observant; to be discerning amisiikin to know well; to understand thoroughly. amisiri a cultivated plot; a garden.amitirir to be small and thin, slender.
the Luganda or any Bantu language

any foreign language, i.e. any language that is not Ateso; non-Ateso women. amoar to go and look for; to go in search of. amocakin to crack a joke at somebody or something; to joke; to jest. amocanut1 (singular noun F) fondness of joking; jesting. amocanut2 to be fond of joking, teasing or wit-cracking. amocar to make fun of; to joke at the expense of somebody; to laugh at someone in an unkind way; to have a joke with; to make a farce of;
