to ridicule. mam akoto amocar eong: I don’t want you to make fun of me. sirikimocar akiro nuka ediini: do not ridicule religion. amodakin to cheat for somebody or somewhere.amodar to send astray; to deceive. kimodas ijo imo: the foreigners have conned you. amodet a deceit; cheating; a trick; a ruse. amodia to obtain bit by bit; to obtain one by one; to acquire slowly. akoto amodia isirigin agwelia egaali: I want to find money slowly sufficient to buy a bicycle. amodiaar to obtain and take away by cheating; to overcharge and take away someone’s money. amodianakin to find for. ape komodianakinai inyamat: go and find some food for me. amoding a wilderness; a hot desert; uninhabited country. amodingot a kind of snake (one cannot specify or identify). amodio- (prefix used with feminine nouns) some. akoto amodiocok: I want some sweet potatoes. amodiojon: a little beer.amodo a hollow reed or stick used as a case for keeping a beer tube.amodok1 thick beer before water is added. amodok2 to eat thick food or vegetables. abu bian eong kamodok emagira koreka: I ate thick peas pudding at home yesterday. amodokok (of clay or food or beer) to be thick; (of road or courtyard) to be dirty, muddy.amodomod to deceive, cheat repeatedly; to overcharge constantly. amodyalat a small swallow (bird) that builds its nest out of mud.amoeten an intestine or entrail (of a person or animal); a bicycle or motorcar tube; a rubber tube. amoeten nadidi: a small intestine. amoeten napolon: a colon; a gut. amogor to fold and push or press a long thing into narrow opening. abu eong kadum aberu emogori ibilenga toma amot: I found a woman folding and stuffing mudfish into the cooking pot. amogorikin to huddle or smuggle and push in or against (when too long) to hide oneself in a narrow opening. amoikin to search something for somebody. amoikin acoa: to give advice to; to plan for; to find a way of doing. amoit a female foreigner, especially of Bantu origin; a non-native; a foreign word (euphemism) a placenta or afterbirth.amoiten a corruption of amoeten: a gut; bowels. amojir to twist; to turn (a tap); to wring out; to wrench. amojir akiro: to twist words or a case. kamojir eong akoik: I have colic. kamojir eong etau: I feel like vomiting. kamojirata eong akiro ngun: I am sorry for that. amojir anaaga: to wind up a gramophone. amojir naka etau: a feeling of nausea. amojirit ekatau: I am very sorry. amojiraar to wrest away; to take by threats; to wrest, extract, wring; to take under duress. amojirikin to twist or turn or contort, once.amojirun to extort; to obtain by threat; to wrest, extract, wring; to obtain under duress. amojong1 an old woman above 66 years of age.amojong2 to become old old. amojong ngesi: she/he has become old or she/he is old. amojongaar to become old; to grow old; to age. amojonganut1 ageing or looking old fast. amojonganut2 to get old fast. amojongit to be old, elderly, mature or aged. amojongu (singular noun F) old age; maturity. amokodo a hollow reed or stick for keeping a beer drinking tube in.amolig a beehive; a hole in the tree (as bee-hive) (slang) the vagina (of a woman). aiwad amolig: to extract honeycombs from a beehive; (slang) to have illicit sexual intercourse. amolo a curved knife; a scythe.amongoriat a species of fish. amoni a thicket; a bush; an overgrown anthill; a forest where animals roam; a coppice. amonukuk to have a distended belly; to have a protruding belly. amonyakin to beseech; to ask for something.amonyo naka itaok (singular noun F) the yellow sticky droppings of a young calf. amonyukuk1 brittleness; frailty; fragility. amonyukuk2 (of bones)to be frail, fragile, brittle. amoorit a nerve; an artery; blood vessel; a tendon; a sinew or muscle. amoorit naka apokipok: a hamstring. amoori nuebutunitos: varicose veins. amoori nuka aokot: blood vessels. amoot to be looking for; to seek diligently; to search. amoot akiro: looking for trouble. imoot ijo akiro: you are trying to annoy me, to get me into a temper. amopiira a rubber tube; a plastic thing; a car or bicycle tyre; a rubber sheath or condom. amor a common duiker, Cephalophus grimmia.komoranaros: join up together; do not be enemies, make friends together , be of one mind. amorenen to share together always. komorenenete eperot: sleep together in the same dormitory. amoris an offence; an insult; an abuse.amorok a shaft of spear; a penholder; haft. amorokin to revile each other; to scold one another; to insult one another; to offend one another; to curse one another. amoromor to insult; to curse, scold, etc often or repeatedly. amoromor itunganan: to abuse or insult someone. amoromoroo naka apedorosio nuka itunga: human rights abuse. amoronor to grouse by oneself; to grumble; to utter threats; to fret. inyo bo imoronoror ijo?: what are you (grousing) growling, grumbling about? amoroonut to be fond of scolding. aimor: to scold, insult, etc amoror the wife of the maternal uncle. amorosit an offence, abuse, insult.amoru a stone; rock. amoru naka irieet: a grinding stone. amoru nainingere: a stone for weighing. a weight (for weighing). amosimos a waterbuck, Kobus ellipsiprymnus; a praise word for a man; a kind of vegetable plant. amosing a rhinoceros (animal), Diceros bicornis. amositoi to run fast, as of a motorcar or of water; to be impetuous, impulsive, bumptious; to be cursive in planning. abu amotoka ngin emositoi: that car came rushing on. amositoi inera: to be rash in speaking. amot an ordinary pot for carrying water or for cooking, made of clay; a crock. amot naka etaba: a pot of a tobacco pipe. imot: a little pot; a cruet. amot nak’ejaae: a hemp pipe. ejaas akipi amot: there is water in the pot. amotakin to dash at; to rush at or after; to fall upon. amotakin ikapa emir: the cat dashed at the rat. to do or work blindly at. amotar to dash off or run away; to rush headlong, roll down, move quickly aside, or move aside. amotaros itelepai amej: the boys dashed off to hunt. amotoka a motorcar; an automobile; a car. amotot a pool of deep water in the swamp. amotun to come quickly this way; to rush this way. amoun to look for and bring; to look for oneself. akoto amoun akile: I want to go and look for some milk. amoun etiai: to compute or estimate the price or value. amu twins.amuatonit a twin.amucaalat a lady; a wife; a mistress.

a woman native to Kigezi (the present day Uganda districts of Kabale and Kisoro), speaking a Bantu language called Rukiga; a word in Rukiga. Amuciga: the Bakiga women; the Rukiga language. amucogolot a species of bird, Bulbul.amudanakin to store up in something or gather and put into some container. amudang to walk or go with small ears; to have cuts in the ears (because of sickness or superstition). amudangang to have small ears; to have cuts in the ears (because of sickness or superstition). amudar to gather and take away (as of sweepings). amudar akeje: to bewitch foot prints or, rather, to bewitch a person by taking the dust of his foot prints. amudianar akonye to blind the eyes (as of sun); to dazzle. emudianari akolong akonye: the sun blinds the eyes. amudiaun akonye: to close someone’s eyelids (as of a dying person or a very hungry one). to close one’s eyes with pain, tiredness or hunger. amudiar to destroy, annihilate, or devastate; to rob or kill and take away; to play havoc with. amudiario (singular noun F) destruction; annihilation; devastation. amudokolo leaves or shoots of potatoes after the potatoes have been dug out.amudongong to have ears with small pinnae or crumpled backwards. amuduk to close the eyes by oneself; to shut the eyes. komuduk shut your eyes. amudukanar to become blind; to lose sight. amudukanut1 (singular noun F) blindness; sightlessness; loss of sight. amudukanut2 to be blind; to be sightless. amudukikin to shut the eyes for; to close the eyes; to endure. komudukik: close the eyes. amudukikin erot: to go or walk on steadily without resting. amudukikin adere: to go on drinking without stopping, with eyes closed. amudun to grasp by hand; to scoop up and bring this way (solid things); to collect and bring together by hand, take a handful (of anything solid). amudye to destroy; to ruin; to annihilate. amudyeikin to cover up completely for; to destroy utterly for or somewhere. (of many) to become dark; to get into trouble. amudyeikinos kesi omusaago: they all got into trouble. amudyeun to reflect sunshine on to somebody’s eyes with a mirror.amue a firefly; a glow worm. amuebe the leaf or wood from a mango tree. amug creeping plants producing gourds, Cucurbita maxima, Lagenaria vulgaris.

a woman native to Buganda (central and southern Uganda districts such as Kampala, Mukono, Masaka, Entebbe, Mpigi, etc); a word in Luganda (the language of the Baganda people). Amugaana: Baganda women; the Luganda language.Amuge1 a pet name for a dark brown (nearly black) cow; a common name for a woman. amuge2 a harmless brown centipede with a repulsive smell; also called totokamuge. amuget a topi antelope, Damaliscus korrigum.
a woman native of former Bugisu (the present day Mbale and Sironko districts)

a Mugisu woman; a word in the Lumasaba language. Amugis: the Bagisu or Bamasaba women; the Lumasaba language.amugit a creeper producing gourds, Cucurbita maxima, Lagenaria vulgaris. amugogot a banana plant; a banana leaf or banana fibre, Musa spp. Its leaves are used as thatch, fibre, wrappers, and fodder, and the fruit is made into banana beverage and food.amugolet a female initiate into a religion; a Roman Catholic nun; a bride (a woman to be wed). amugur to walk with stooping shoulders or back; to be hunched. amugurur1 a stoop; a bent back; a hunchback.
a woman native to Budaka and Kibuku counties of Pallisa district

a word in Lugwere language; a Mugwere tribeswoman. Amugwerio: the Bagwere women; the language of the Bagwere. amujaj sisal fibre. amujajut a woody herb with whorls of spiny leaves at ground level; a sisal plant, leaf or fibre, Agave sisalana. It is used for live fence, while its fibre is used for strong ropes, sacking, and mats. amujalal nakedness; nudity; state of undress; exposure. amujuulut a bird, Laurie. kiany amujuulut epodo, eanyunit emun: if you hear the amujuulut bird complaining, it has seen a snake (Ateso version of the saying: where there is smoke there must be fire). amukar to scoop away. amukat a leather sandal; a shoe; a boot. amukean (singular noun F) medical treatment; therapy; medication. amukebe a tin can.amuket dust-pan; a scoop; any instrument for scooping.amukono a roll of cloth in general; a sheet; a bed sheet.amukoro a hollow reed or stick for keeping a beer drinking tube in.amukun to scoop up; to pick up (of many together); to bring many together; to hold many to come together; to be scooped together; to be too many. amukunos itelepai osomero: too many boys have come to school. amukunet a syllable; a scoop.amukurat a gradient or slope; a steepness; an acclivity; a high rise; a hill. amula (of waves, froth, or anti-peristalsis in the stomach) to roll or to swell.
akebe amukeket a dried sliced sweet potato

a woman native to Ankole (the present day districts of Mbarara, Bushenyi, Ntungamo); a word in Runyankore. Amulaalo: the Banyankole women; the Runyankore language. amulangang to be hornless. amulaun (of anger or the contents of the stomach about to vomit) to come like a wave; to surge (like fits). amuleete a football made from rags or banana fibre and used by village children. amuleget a species of bird, African open-bill.
a Nubian woman native of Bombo, parts of West Nile, and Southern Sudan

a word in Nubian (the language of the Nubian people). Amulubin: the Nubian women or their language. amulukujut a crimson breasted shrike. amulut the mucous of the intestines; intestinal worm that attaches on the mucosa. amumu (singular noun F) lawlessness; violence; anarchy; chaos; disorder; mayhem; free-for-all fight. amumuikin to do or behave like a wild animal to somebody. kamumuikinit akiteng ngin eong: that cow is vicious to me. amumuor (of animals, seldom of man) to become violent. amumuor emong ngol: that bull is violent or has become wild. amumut (singular noun F) the smell of a baby’s excrements. amumutaar to smell like a baby’s excrements. amumwarat a horn (of an animal); a snuffbox made of horn. amumwarat naka ebeere: a tentacle of a grasshopper. amuna to lay waste; to ruin or spoil; to do harm to to brew beer; to ferment. alosi eong amuna ajon: I am going to brew beer.amunaar to spoil; to lay waste; to wipe out; to do harm to (of something away from speaker); to make dirty. sirikimunaa ikaboro: do not spoil my things. to get spoiled; to get dirty; to get ruined. amunaar ekatogo: my house is ruined. amunaaret a damage; a ruin; a wreckage; a devastation. amunaikin to brew beer for somebody or somewhere. amunan the one who makes the beer; a waiter (of beer only); sponsor of a beer party; the hostess at a beer party. amunaun to spoil; to corrupt; to waste; to mar, befoul. amunaun ekisil: to transgress. sirikimunau ekisil loka Lokasuban: do not sin. amunaun akoik: to abort; to miscarry. amunaun aiboi: to cause trouble at home; to disturb the peace (literally, to spoil the stay or sitting). to get spoiled or stained; to have premature birth (of woman or animal). amunaun aberu: the woman has had premature birth. amunaunet a damage; ruin; a miscarriage. amuno (singular noun F) hope; trust; expectation; assumption; confidence. amuno to hope; to trust; to expect; to be confident. emunos kesi adumun inyamat: they hope to get food. kamunos Lokasuban: let us trust in God. emunoi: it is hoped. amunokin1 to hope for; to put trust in; to wish to; to depend on. kamunokinit eong ijo angaleun atipet: I wish you a quick recover. amunokin2 to put one’s mind on doing something; to go on doing; to continue to pay attention to be confident; to be hopeful. emunokina itunga adumun akimai ipu okaru lo: people hope or expect to get a good (much) millet crop this year. amunor to wish good or bad to someone. kamunor eong ijo aijar namam edaun: I wish you eternal life. emameete nukajokak nukimunor ngesi ijo: she/he wishes you no good (things). amunot a trustworthy, dependable, reliable, or honest woman. amuny skin (of a person); a piece of leather of an animal; a cuticle; the bark of a tree; a strap of leather; a leather thong; a bootlaces. amuny naka eris: a strip of leopard skin (used as an amulet or talisman).amunyakin to break for or to break in to break off by itself (like a rotten twig). amunyakin etirir toma akeju: the etirir thorn has broken off inside the foot. amunyar to break off (as of a rotten twig, etc). sirikimunya atenu: do not break off the branch. amunyelet a skin used for sleeping on; a leather; a football game or leather ball; a shirt.amunyir (singular noun F) a kind of grass burnt to extract salt.amunyokin to patch up (a hole in a skin or in cloth).

a woman native to Bunyoro (the present day Uganda districts of Hoima, Masindi, and parts of Kibale and Mubende), speaking a Bantu language called Runyoro; a word in Runyoro. Amunyooro: the Banyoro women; the Runyoro language. amunyor to cut off (as of tail or ear of sheep); to break off (a piece of bar soap). amunyumuny to break to pieces (of stick or bar of soap); to transgress, break law. imunyumunyei ijo ikisila apaarasia kere: you are always breaking laws.amunyumunyet a scrap; a crumb; a fragment. amunyurur to have badly shaped ears (turned down). eitaabo loemunyuritoi: a dog-eared book. amuogo a cassava stem, leaf or cutting. amuokol ki-o to pull faces; to frown. amuokolikin to roll itself up (as of hedgehog). amuokoloor to pull sour face, turning the head away. imuokoloor apupu keanyu jo: the hedgehog rolls itself up when it sees you. amurake a home of an in-law. alot ngesi amurake: she/he has gone to (visit) his relatives in-law. amurakin to cover the millet to let it ripen quickly. amurakis akima: the cut millet was covered in order to ripen. amuraki akoik: dysentery has ceased. amurakin: (of millet flour) to be covered in one basket to ferment. amurakinos akiria kere toma obukit ediopet: all the flour due for fermenting has gone into one basket. amuran a sister-in-law; mother-in-law; the wife’s sister; all in-laws generally (male or female). amuranut1 (singular noun F) astringency; ascerbity; severity (of stomach). amuranut2 (of food when eaten) to be astringent, binding. amurat a basket or pot for fermenting beer dough; fermenting dough. amurenget anything tied together; a bundle; a parcel. amuriat (collective noun F) the swarming brown biting ants.amurok a wooden part of an arrow.amuron1 a centipede.amuron2 a traditional priestess or medicine woman (knowledgeable in herbal medicine or cure for witchcraft). amuron naka adekis: a female doctor (who administers western medicine). amuron nakokou: a traditional doctor (who administers herbs and potions). amuronot (singular noun F) beneficial witchcraft; the work of a traditional doctor (magic, healing, or prophesying, etc). amurut a small barn or granary; a decayed barn, washed away partly by rain. amurwo1 a thigh; hind leg. akewat: foreleg. amurwo2 to prophesy; to divine; to do the work of a traditional priest or doctor. emurwoi ngesi: she/he prophesies or divines. amurwon a traditional doctor or priestess; a health officer or woman doctor. amusala a grass, Pennisetum. amusaot a midwife. amuseit an old woman; an old lady; a dame.amusenu a hoe handle or shaft.amuseset a coly bird.
(singular noun F) Palm Sunday before Easter, commemorating Christ’s journey into Jerusalem.
a woman native to Busoga (present day districts of Jinja, Iganga, Kamuli, Mayuge and Bugiri)
a word in Lusoga language; a Musoga tribeswoman. Amusoga: the Basoga women; the Lusoga language.amusogot a palm leaf; a palm frond.
Amagarait: a Musoga or Mugwere tribeswoman

a word from a European language. akesa namusugut: a European woman. einer Amusugun: to speak a European language, especially English. amusumus1 (singular noun F) semi-darkness; twilight; late evening; penumbra. amusumus2 to be or to become half dark; to be twilight or dim. amusungut an injury; a harm; an accident; a mischief; a wound; a mishap.amutaru a truss; a heap (of something tied in a bundle). amuteete a headrest, cushion or pillow.amutojoj to be naked or nude; to be in Adam’s suit. amuton (singular noun F) darkness; night; gloom; obscurity. amutonoor to become dark; to become gloomy, mysterious, or sinister; to become overgrown.
akangas, aromwait amusus (singular noun F) smut; dirt; lewdness; rudeness; immorality

a woman native to Tooro (the present day western Uganda districts of Bundibugyo, Kabarole, Kyenjojo, Kamwenge and parts of Kibale and Kasese); a word in Rutooro (the language of the Batooro). Amutooro: the Batooro women; the Rutooro language. amutujuj to be dirty; to be black all over; to be dirty all over. imutujujos idwe etulia: the children are dirty all over with soot. amuturu a mature fresh sweet potato tuber just harvested; any freshly harvested tuber (potato, cassava, yam, etc). amuturur to be big, fat. imuturur akou: imuturur emorosing: fat or big-headed; thick-necked. amuulet an unmarried woman staying alone; a poor woman living in solitude; a widow.amuut a twin girlchild.amuya to take many together randomly (as of people, animals or anything); to uproot together (without segregation). emuyai ngesi eduan ka akimai da: she/he uproots the millet together with the weeds. amuya ejakait itunga ipu: the chief has taken many people. amuyonor to pout, sneer; to smile; to grin; to despise by turning head away (with mouth closed as one in a smoky or smelly place). amuyonor to grin; to smile broadly. amwalat spiral bracelet or earring; a bangle; a nose ring; an ankle chain; iron in general.amwalimu a school teacher; a tutor; a lecturer.amwangit Katoda: impiety, wickedness, transgression. amwaniar to become hot. amwaniar akolong: the sun has become hot. amwanikin to become hot for or somewhere; to become sick or feverish. kamwanikinit eong etogo: it has become too hot for me in the room. emwanikina ngesi akuwan: she/he is slightly indisposed; she/he has fever. amwanus heat; warmth; temperature. amwanus naka etau greediness; gluttony; stinginess. amwanuu nges etau: she/he has become greedy, stingy, closefisted. amwanuun to become hot; to be hot. amwakuutu akipi: the water has become or is hot amwaset anything to wipe or rub with. egoe lomwaset ereet: a handkerchief; a face mop. amwatar to expunge; to wipe away; to efface; to rub away or out; to brush away. komwata ekumekon: wipe your nose. amwatun akonye (formerly) a traditional ceremony performed by a son-in-law after looking by accident at his mother-in-law, ostensibly to cleanse his eyes. amwatun akonye to wipe the face amwe a bush, Lantana. amwekimwek to be polished like gold or copper; to shine; to be bright, dazzle, be iridescent..amwi a sister of one’s husband. amwika ngin: that is a sister of my husband. [note: a) sister-in-law is called akamuran by the sister’s husband. b) the young sister of one’s husband is called amwi nadidi by the wife. c) elder sister of the husband is called toto by wife]. amwiiko a trowel. amwokol (of a hedgehog or tortoise) to pull in or lower one’s head in anger; to draw in the head or hide the head (on account of fear); to introvert. aimwokolikin etau: to dishearten, discourage; to resent. amyedait old time iron neck rings; an iron necklace. amyedakin to strangle for or somewhere. to hang oneself; to commit suicide by hanging. amyedanar to belch; to retch; to feel like vomiting. amyedun akonye to stare with eyes bulging with astonishment; to ogle or eyeball. amyeedu a big rope for holding bulls or for anything else (6-10 plaits). amyetar1 iwos to have flat buttocks.amyetar2 to consume (of anything); to finish. amyetasi ipejok inyamat kere: the visitors have finished all the food.
apuserut amuunyu (uncountable noun F) table salt; common salt (sodium chloride)
a noun suffix denoting agency: ekelipan : one who asks, prays, begs for
ekaanyanaran : one who examines often; an examiner (ex professo)

suffix of quality verbs or adjectives denoting habit - ilipana: she/he is fond of prayer, asking, begging. enyamana: she/he eats a lot or is a glutton. epeipeyana emaido kamisiri: the groundnut crop is sparse in the garden. esilyana aberu ngin: that woman is dirty always.anaaga2 a shawl (as worn by Karimojong warriors), i.e. a sheet of cloth tied over the shoulder. anaaga3 the larger of the cog-wheels of a bicycle (where the pedals are attached).anaanar (reciprocal verb) to be comrades

to be friends; to be familiar to each other; to be devoted to each other. enaanara kesi noi: they are great friends. enaanaros kesi rwaru: they will be friends. anaanut1 (singular noun F) a habit; a routine; a practice; a tendency.anaana ngesi akoko: she/he has the habit of stealing. anaaror (prepositional verb) to get into a habit. ikoto ijo anaaror adoteu: you are getting into the habit of having multiple sexual partners. anaasit a nurse; a medical aid; a nursing sister anaikin to become used to; to become acquainted with; to become familiar with; to become accustomed to. anaiki aberu ekeere: the wife has got familiar with her home. kinaikina oni: we know each other. anaikinet a habit; a second nature; a practice.anaikinit to be used to; to be acquainted; to be familiar with; to be devoted to; to be accustomed to. anait to be inclined to; to be accustomed to; to be in the habit of. inait ijo apeg: you are inclined to argue. anakanar to suck often. anakanar akwena: to laugh often. anamo to press down something hollow; to close or to fold (as of book, lips or paper).anamoiki ngesi eitaabo: she/he has closed the book. anamusiga a metal that holds the tyre of motorcar or bicycle; the part of a bicycle holding spokes on the outer side of a wheel, i.e. the rim.anangakin to beat or give a punch for or somewhere. anangakin akou: to bang the head against. to collide, crash; to box each other; to come across; to meet unexpectedly; to meet by accident. abu eong kanangakin nges: I met him unexpectedly; I collided with him. anangakinet a collision; a crash; an accident; a confrontation. anangan a boxer; a pugilist. anangan eguumi: a boxer; a pugilist. anangan emopiira: a basketball player. ananganang to beat about with the fists; to beat at random with fists. ananganang atenus: to beat a large drum with the fists. anangar to knock down; to throw down. abu amotoka konanga ikoku korot: a motorcar knocked down a child on the road. anangar idowon: (euphemism) (of a person) to die. ananget a conclusion; a closure. anangirir to be thick, fat (as of a skin or bark of anything). inangirir emukule ngol, eroko epalal: that hide is very thick, it is not yet dry. anangit a small fish; a very small tilapia, Ngege haplochromis. anangun to knock out or up (like knocking one awake or out of bed). anapakin to dress for; to clothe for somebody; to give a lift (in a car or on a bicycle). anapar to give a lift on a vehicle; to take away anything with a vehicle. konaparai eong oidukai: give me a lift to the shops. to go together on a vehicle. anapet dress, cloth or skin with which to carry a child on the back. mam ikepi anapet eringa ikoku kidouno: (proverb) you do not make anapet before the baby is born – (Ateso equivalent of ‘do not count your chicks before they are hatched’. anapi a small drinking calabash or half gourd; a plastic bowl for scooping water. anapit to dress; to be dressed in; to wear. enapit ngesi igoen: she/he is dressed in cloth: she/he wears cloth. anapito clothes in general; apparel; attire; garb. apesur, konapete anapito namam eyauni ileic: girls, wear clothing that does not bring shame, embarrassment or ridicule. -anar a verbal suffix used with bi-syllabic –ar verbs to denote a repeated action away from the speaker. alemar: to remove or take away (once only); alemanar: to keep taking away (often). anyaraar: to call away (once only); anyaraanar: to keep calling away (often). anaranar to be shaking, springy, trembling; to thrill. anatar to remain quiet to go carefully through one by one, calling out names one after another, i.e. to call a roll; to keep quiet and yet hear and understand what is being said or what is happening. anatar ekaru kere: to go through the whole year, month after month. konatas ikiroria: call out names. aso yesi kere konatasi: keep quiet all of you. anear to push in or into; to push out; to intrude. koneata akwi ococot: push the grass or leaves into holes beside the anthill. to intrude; to push oneself forward; to project into. anebek to go or walk with a flexible body; to amble; to walk gracefully. anebekek to be flexible and soft, cosy, smooth. inebekek atenu ngin: that branch is soft and flexible. aneikin to push in (something into a hole or people into a house); to constrain (by force); to crush. koneik itunga togo: congest the people into the house. to push oneself into a crowd or a small space. aneitoi1 presumptiousness; temerity; audacity; impudence. aneitoi2 to presume, to brave (even if there is opposition). anemar to rise and go at once; to rise and go promptly; to go at once on command; to obey instantly. konemar toma aswamukon: go at once to your work.anemesaar to step quickly away; to run off quickly and quietly. anemesaaros itunga aitudeng akim: people have run quickly to extinguish the fire.anemesikin to dash at; to rush at; to jump at. anemesikin ikapa emir: the cat rushed at the rat. anemesun to come quickly and silently this way. anemitoi to be hasty; to be in a hurry; to rush about. enemitoi ngesi toma aswam namam erai nake: she/he rushes to do the work which is not hers/his. anemun to get up quickly and come.anepukuk to be soft; to be cosy, spongy, or downy. inepukukos igoen lu: these clothes are soft or downy. anerokin to wish somebody good or bad; to claim, choose, select for. kanerokit eong ijo ajakaanut: I wish you to get a leadership position. kanerokinit eong ijo arereng: I wish you good luck.aneror to claim and take away; to select and take away. anero ngesi akakokor: she/he claimed my hen and took it away. aneseikin to lead into trouble; to treat badly; to maltreat; to chase into the bush. eneseikit ngesi akeberu: he is always maltreating his wife. aneseikin akonye: to hate. eneseikinit ngesi akeberu akonye: he hates his wife, or he cannot stand the sight of his wife. aneseun to press upon; to crowd upon. to come in without permission; to come to attack, to rush to the attack. anesiar to enter without permission; to wander about; to go into; to scamper. aany eong nges enesiar okitui: I saw her/him running into the bush; I saw her/him scamper into the bush. anetokin to serve somebody with a big quantity of (solid) food; to deal a heavy blow for somebody or somewhere; to clobber for somebody; to serve somebody (in general). konetokinoi eong ekesa ngol: clobber that fellow for me, give her/him a hammering. aneun1 to compel; to force. kaneunit eong etengei ne: hunger has forced me this way. aneunos iponesio lueroko toma akwapuwok: bad customs have forced their way into our country. aneun2 to intrude oneself; to push in towards the speaker; (of eyes) to protrude. aneun akonye: to protrude eyes. angaar to open wide; to open or put back (a curtain). angaar ekek: to open the door; to answer the door. angaar akituk: to open the mouth.angaarany a gap in teeth resulting from unintentional or accidental removal of teeth; a notch. angaarwe a gland in the armpit, neck or groin; a lymph gland; a swelling in the groin. adeka naka angaarwei: east coast fever (a disease of cattle spread by ticks). angabar to go (as one with thin buttocks and wide hip-bones). angabararat: to be with thin buttocks and wide hip-bones; to run (as one with thin buttocks and wide hip-bones does). angabet the waist; the loin; the small of the back. angabinyaar to go away with one’s thin buttocks and bow-legs; to slip away swaying or in an excited manner. angabinyiny (of a small person) to have flat buttocks and bow legs. angabu to sprain or twist (somebody’s leg or arm); to dislocate. angabuikin to sprain somebody else’s leg or arm, etc; to contort.to be sprained, twisted or bruised. angabuor (of an ankle) to twist away from speaker. angac (in Karamoja) a venereal disease (in general). angacar (of a fat wide-hipped woman) to walk nude or naked; (of a fat wide-hipped woman) to be scantily dressed; (of a woman wearing see-through dress) to move about with no nickers on (in full view of many people).angaet a door-knob; the locking or opening mechanism of anything. angaikin to open for. angaikin erot: to allow to come or to go; to open the way. angaikin akiro: to open the conversation; to speak out; to open one’s heart.angajep a tongue (the taste organ in the mouth); language; dialect. angajep naka akwara: a pen nib. angajep kakim: a flame. kimyelu angajep: push out your tongue. ejai ngesi angajep: she/he has a tongue, i.e. she/he gives away secrets (by being talkative); she/he has a bad tongue (i.e. fond of using abusive or obscene language). angalakimak in the south; to the south; southerly; southern. angale to be well; to be healthy. angalei eong: I am well. ingaleete yesi?: are you well? eebo, kingalei: yes, we are well. angaleikin to get better health-wise; to be fat; to become fit; to become healthy, improve in health. angaleki akonijimi?: is your sore or wound better? angaleu (singular noun F) health; the state of health. edit angaleuke: her/his health is poor: she/he is in poor health. angaleun to recover from illness by oneself; (of a wound) to heal; to recuperate; to become better. angalom to have a gap (in the teeth). ingalomi ijo ai?: where are you going with your gaping teeth? angalomom to have few teeth left; to have a gap (between teeth or anything). ingalomom akonibwas: your fence has gaps. anganga to fuss about; to do in a hurry; to be too anxious; to like to do something and find it impossible. engangat ngesi alosit: she/he is anxious to go; she/he is in a hurry to go. angangaar to rush away or run away anxiously. angangakin to rush at blindly; to do blindly. angangakinos ingokwo amaria akoit: the dogs have rushed blindly to fight for the bone. angangamit gravel soil.anganganakin to try hard; (of food) to eat quickly; to gorge; to gourmandise (with ainyam). to be anxious to do or go; to do in a hurry. anganganakin eong agwel egoe, kwabo erono: I bought this cloth in a hurry, and found it is bad. angangat to be very anxious to do; to be eager to do, solicitous, try in vain the impossible. engangat ngesi alosit: she/he is very anxious to go. angangatoi to be over-zealous; to be over-anxious, bumptious, agog, avid, solicitous, or temerarious. engangatoi ngesi toma aswamusinei nuipu: she/he is anxious to try all kinds of work. angangatonut to be inclined to hurry. anganit a bunch of grain selected for seeds; choice seeds.anganyanar to lie, loll, sprawl carelessly while exposing the bottoms. anganyar to make a gap or opening; to lift something in order to look what is underneath; to remove, to push away and look for. konganya anya ngun, ejai emir toma: remove that sheaf of grass, there is a rat underneath. anganyar akeje: to kick into space (i.e. to miss the ball); to sit with legs spread out; to lift one’s foot or leg too high and reveal private parts. anganyit akonye to have eyes wide open; to stare; to look fierce; to threaten. anganyun to reveal; to find out; to discover a lost thing; to recover a thing lost somewhere; to unearth. abu eong kanganyu ekanusu: I found my shilling hidden within. to come out from a hiding place; to appear after a long absence. anganyun akiro: to reveal a secret. angar hatred; dislike; animosity. angar to hate; to dislike; to despise; to detest. engara ngesi akeberu: he hates and beats his wife. angarabab to have a complete set of teeth.angarany a gap (in the hedge or between teeth, etc). ejai ijo angarany: you have a gap between your teeth. to have a gap. ingaranyany ijo: you have a gap in your teeth. angarin a constellation also called the Plough. angaromit red stony soil; gravel. angasab to gorge food, eat quickly. angasabaar to bite off a big piece or lump. angasabaa ekingok akakiring: the dog bit off a large piece of my meat. angasabab to laugh with the mouth wide open, i.e. to laugh heartily. angasababat eong, engasababatos kesi: I am, they are laughing heartily. engasababat ngesi akwena: she/he laughs with open mouth; she/he is having a hearty laugh. angasianakin to try repeatedly, but ineffectually; to start again and again. angasiep a placenta; an afterbirth.angasikinos itelepai alosit ojie: the boys volunteered to go to war (without thinking of the risks they are putting themselves into). sirikingasikin aiwadik eitaabo komuno aikamun enyadu katipet: do not rush to write a book with the hope of getting rich quickly. angasingas to be very big; to be gigantic; to be awe-inspiring. angat to want; to like; to desire; to wish for. angata eong alosit ore: I want to go home. engatunit edou: it wants to rain; rain is threatening.angatar to rob and take away; to pillage; to raid. angatun to rob and bring; (of rain) to threaten. angatuny a lioness; a brave woman; a woman member of the Lionesses Club. angatunyoit (formerly) a bullet; a lead shot.to be admitted; to come out (of cows); to come in. angaunos akituk: the cows have broken out (from the kraal). angeberaar to go with a miniskirt or short trousers somewhere. angeberer (of dress, cloth, or trousers) to be short. angecel a natural gap between a person’s lower incisor teeth. angecer (of a thin wide-hipped person) to walk nude or naked; (of a slender woman) to be scantily dressed; to move about like a ghost.angecerer to be very thin (after illness) or (of a thin person) to be naked.adum eong ekatogo ingecerer: I found my hut not yet plastered. angeda (of rope or thread) to snap, break; (of a crowd) to break up. angedas itunga kotoma atenus: the people ran away from the (drum) dance. angeda eipaperone: the friendship is broken. angeda ekatau: my heart is broken.angedakin (of something chained, tied, or linked) to escape or to break loose. angedar to break off; to snatch away, disrupt, pull or tear apart. angeda ngesi atipeka: she/he snatched away my beads. angedengedeun (of anything sewn or stitched) to become worn out (by itself). angedengedeunos akamuk: my shoes are worn out (threads have snapped). angedun to break off this way. to separate oneself with difficulty. angedun eong kore: I tore myself away from home. angeemait the faecal remnants on the uncleaned anus; the anus. angeemem (of food) to be gritty. angejepanut1 (singular noun F) stammering; lisping; stuttering. angejepanut2 to lisp; to stammer; to stutter. epol nges angajepanut: she/he lisps or stammers very much. angelakin to cut off or break off a big piece (as of an earthenware pot, a ceramic utensil or bread). to fall off, break off (by itself). angelakin amot orot: a big piece of the pot broke off on the way. angelar to bite off (a piece of anything). angelejaar to bite off a big piece (as of half-ready mango); to make a wound bigger. abu ekingok kongeleja akakeju: the dog bit off a big lump of my leg. (of wound) to become very much bigger. angelengel to tell tall stories; to cut or bite into big pieces. angelun to break off and bring. angelun amot: a piece of the pot has come off. angengear to become rough, coarse, harsh. koyau apapula naengenge: bring some sandpaper. engenge etunganan ngol: that man is a ruffian, a barbarian. aitengengear: to make coarse, harsh, rough. angengeu1 roughness; coarseness; discourtesy; asperity; austerity. angengeu2 to be rough; to be coarse (like sandpaper). angereb ikel to make noise with teeth; to grind teeth. angereb: to crush hard food with teeth (as of dried potatoes or popcorn). angerep a kind of anthill from which white ants (called ingerepo) fly in the morning (about 7:00am). angerer to cut open fish; to cut into strips; to shred. angereriar to tear completely; to rip. to be completely torn. angereriar ekasaati: my shirt is completely torn. angerokin to refuse to somebody something or somewhere; to rebel against. to mortify oneself; to refuse one another; to separate (in marriage); to fall out with each other; to be at loggerheads.angeronut1 (singular noun F) fondness to refuse; stubbornly refusing; rebelliousness. angeronut2 to be used to objecting; to be stubbornly refusing or rebelling. angerun to cut (grass or hair) and bring; to mow. alosi eong angerun anya: I am going to cut some grass. angeruno to refuse to give. angeruno ngesi ekakalaamu: she/he refuses to return my pencil or she/he refuses to give me my pencil. angesan suddenness. adeka naka angesan: a sudden illness; epidemic. atwanare naka engeso: sudden death. angesanar to take often unawares; to surprise often. engesanari kwana atwanare itunga kobuku kangol: many people die suddenly these days in that county. angesar to surprise; to come upon unawares, take a thing before somebody has had a chance. abu eong kangesa ekokolan: I took the thief by surprise. abu eong kadum itunga kedautu angesar akimai: I arrived when the millet was sold. engesarit nges atwanare: she/he has died suddenly. angesa nges adeka: she/he fell ill suddenly. to die suddenly; to go early.angeset the end; a place where something happens suddenly. angesun to do all of a sudden; to befall on suddenly; to take by surprise; to surprise. kingesutu yesi eong: you have taken me by surprise. to arrive suddenly; to come suddenly; to happen unexpectedly, casually. angesun akiro: to say quickly; to say unexpectedly; to improvise. kongesu atipet: say it quickly. ngai angesu?: who said it so quickly? ngesi angesu: she/he said it. angetakin to complete for; to finish for; to finish off; to achieve. to come to an end; to be finished. angetakin akaswam: my work is finished; my work is over. angetet the end; the limit.esange: the extremity; the finish. ameun kageunet aitodol angetet: from the beginning to the end; from the first to the last. angeyaar to become worse; to flare up; to get excited. angeyaar akim: the fire flares up. angeyaar atap: the atap has become very thin. angeyaar ajimi: the wound has become very big. angeyaaros akiro: the case has become worse. angeyaar etauka: I am very annoyed.angianakin to face bravely; to bear bravely; to suffer bravely.angianar to show teeth often; to show teeth repeatedly.to show teeth as sign of indifference, carelessness. angiar to show; to disclose; to uncover. kongia ikonikel ngina: show your teeth the other way (not to me)(an insult). angibirir to run fast; to be fast; to run like mad. angibiriranut to be fast (in running); to be a fast runner. ingibirirana ijo: you run fast . angibiririt to be running very fast. angibiriruun to come running quickly. kongibiriruun lailo: run quickly this way. angicakin to find out for someone else, or to find, discover somewhere. koyanga kongicak kangina: take it and examine it closely over there. angican a spy; a detective; inspector; scrutiniser; searcher. angicar to discover and take away; to find and take away; to go and find out. angicun to find out for oneself, examine for oneself; to discover for oneself; to detect. angicun ediini: to learn religion well. kengicu ngesi ekediini: she/he knows her/his religion well (she/he learnt her/his religion well). angiikin to show teeth to; to pull faces (in pain); to grin and bear. kangiiki eong ekingok ikel: the dog bared me its teeth (a threat). abu eong kangiik ikacan: I gnashed and bore my troubles. angiingiit to keep showing teeth; to fawn on; to grin continuously. engiingiit apese kede ikiliok: the girl is smiling lecherously with men (as a loose woman does). angiingiitoi to grin; to go about laughing foolishly; to simper, smile in a silly way. inyo bo ingiingiitor ijo?: why this silly laughing? angiirit the gum (flesh around the teeth); the palate. angiit to grin, smile (usually in a silly manner). angimakin to cut a small piece or a little for somebody; to beat lightly. kongimakinai akiring: cut me a small piece of meat. angimar to cut off a small piece. angimun to cut a small piece for oneself; to nibble at. to come off in small pieces; to break off in small pieces; to crumble off. anginamam (of a person or animal) to have no teeth. anginga to rub the eyes because they are itching. kinyek anginga akonye: stop rubbing your eyes. angingaun to bring out from a hiding place (of anything); to take something out of the eye by rubbing. to come from a hiding place; to appear. angingaun do ngesi: she/he has made her/his appearance. angingiikin to be too blunt for (cutting something). angingiiki ekileng lo akiring na: this knife is too blunt to cut this meat. angingior (of a knife, axe, etc) to become blunt. angingioros aepei nu: these machetes have become blunt. angingitor to deride, gibe, or grin. angingiu1 (singular noun F) bluntness (of a knife, an axe, etc). angingiu2 (of a knife, an axe, etc) to be blunt angiol a woman with protruding teeth; anything protruding. angiolol (of teeth or anything) to be protruding; to have a harelip; to have protruding (teeth).angirabab (of teeth or of teeth of saw; of hoe or knife edge) to be chipped; (of teeth) to be broken. angiribib to have a set of small teeth; (of teeth) to be jagged. ingiribibas ikonikel: your teeth are short and small.angirijanakin to gnash the teeth (with pain). engirijanakini ngesi ikel kanuka ariebo: she/he gnashes her/his teeth with pain.angirikin to suffer bravely; to endure; to bear; to be patient with, be determined; to dare. angirikinit eong adeka na: I am enduring this sickness. angirikinet endurance; sufferance; staying power; stamina. angiriony a woman with a bruised face; a woman with broken teeth. angirionyikin to fall forward (of a person or animal); to throw headlong and break the teeth. to fall forward and injure the mouth; to bruise the face by falling forward. angirionyony (of face) to be bruised; (of teeth) to be broken. angirit a palate; gums of teeth. angironyor to fall forward; to die suddenly. angisibib (of a child) to laugh; to smile; to grin. engisibibit ikoku eanyuni totoke: the child grins on seeing its mother. angisolol to have protruding teeth (that do not allow the lips to close).angiun to show teeth; to rise or show light (of sun). to become visible; to appear; (of teeth) to be bare. angoanakin to mash often for; to become often angry with each other; to be often angry with. angobar to drink (thick food, etc making a slobbering noise). angobar: to drink at one go. angobun to sip little (something thick). angobun ajo: to sleep a little; to doze a little. angobun sarab: to drink noisily. angodial the left. left hand, leg, etc. akeju nangodial left foot. lok’ongodial the one on the left. longodial: a left-handed man; a southpaw. angodidi a Coucal bird. angoes a place or pot in which food is stirred; the implement (spoon, stick, ladle) with which to stir. angoet a stick for stirring (porridge, atap, etc); a paddle or an oar for rowing a boat or canoe.angoid to walk like a lion or king; to strut or walk proudly; to swagger or swank.angoikin to mingle atap for; to mash food for; to get angry with; to get cross with; to get annoyed with. to become enemies; to fall out with one another. angoikinos kesi: they have become enemies: they fell out with one another.angoit to be annoyed; to be vexed; to be angry. angokwaanut to be very poor. ainyam naka angokwaanut: to lead a dog’s life; to live from hand to mouth. Angole1 a pet name for a black cow with a white patch on its face. angole2 a head injury; a bald patch on the head; a scar on the head (after a blow). angole3 akide a species of eagle - a black crested eagle (looks to the east or west in response to a person’s call). angole4 angor a species of bird, wattle starling. angolemoru a mountain pigeon.angolengol to look around; to look from side to side. kinyek angolengol kokeresia: do not look around in the cathedral. angoleonut to have a bald patch (on the head) or a scar on the head after a blow. angoleun1 (of fruit) to become yellow; to ripen, be nearly ripe. angoleun2 to look this way; to eskew. kongoleutu lailo: look this way (plural). angoli to look; to glance; to beware; to look out (rarely used in infinitive and present indicative, instead say angoliar, angoleun, angolengol). angolianakin to look around constantly; to have a good look at; to keep looking at, glancing at often.to look at one another. angoliar to behold; to see; to look round at; to look away to behold or look at one another. angolikin to look at, glance at, look round at. kongolikinai eong: look at me. behold. angoliun to look this way; to glance this way. angolol a lake; a sea; a broad river; an ocean. angolop to take amiss; to take offence; to be annoyed. abu eong kebap ikoku, kongolopi totoke: I slapped the child and the mother took it amiss. angolopa1 (singular noun F) a disagreement; a quarrel; a verbal conflict (without physical fighting). epol angolopa kangina: there is a lot of quarrelling over there: they have many squabbles. angolopa tai: to bicker. angolopa naka angor: the squabbling of women (especially co-wives). angolopa2 to be quarrelling; to be squabbling; to find fault; to have a row; to altercate, contend. engolopas kesi apaarasia kere: they are always quarrelling. angolopanakin to be constantly quarrelling with one another. angolopanar to become quarrelsome; to be regular quarrellers. to quarrel with one another. angolopanut to be quarrelsome; to be fond of quarrelling, squabbling. angolopar to quarrel because; to squabble about; to have a row about. kinyekis angolopar ikakoku: stop arguing over my child. angolopikin to pick up a quarrel; to start a squabble, a row. ikoto ijo angolopikin ka eong: you want to start quarrelling with me. to get into a quarrel; to begin to quarrel. angoloror to have a cataract in the eye. ingoloror ngesi: she/he has a cataract in her/his eyes. angon to be proud; to strut; to walk like a lion; to have a high opinion of oneself; to walk slowly; to saunter. engonas itelepai lu: these boys walk like peacocks.angonakin to feel proud; to swagger; to realise one’s importance; to start to walk with a proud gait. angoobe a horn of a car or motor cycle. aicikakin angoobe: to press the horn. akutakin angoobe: to blow the horn.angooresia dried up drool, i.e. saliva around the mouth and cheeks during sleep.angopes a hiding place; a refuge; safe haven; sanctuary; asylum; bolt hole; harbour.angopikis kes akiro ngun: it was above their understanding; it was beyond them. to ambush; to lie in wait for; to waylay. abu engatuny kangopik eong: the lion laid an ambush for me. angopikinit itunganan: to do something and not tell someone; to go behind someone's back. angopikin aswam: to dodge work. angopis a hiding place; a refuge; safe haven; sanctuary; asylum; bolt hole; harbour.angopit dii di: to be completely hidden.angor women; females; wives. angorit (collective noun F) a crowd of women. angorokin to gorge food; to overeat.angorom ochre; yellowish-brown; orangey; tawny; orange colour. angorom (singular noun F) brown stony soil; murram; a place having yellowish-brown soil. angoronyony to be dirty (with earth, mud or road dust). ingoronyonyas idwe: the children are dirty (with dust). angoror to miss (food or anything); to happen in one’s absence; to be lost to. kangorosi eong inyamat: the food was finished during my absence (literally, the food missed me). angorot (singular noun F) old millet grain (from the previous harvest).angosibib1 (singular noun F) honour; glory; dignity; lustre; majesty; renown. epejonon lokangosibib: a male guest of honour. apejonon nakangosibib: a female guest of honour. angosibib2 to be honourable; to be glorious, look dignified; to be awe-inspiring. epol angosibib: eminent; estimable. ingosibibos ijaka ngul: those chiefs look dignified. angosobob to have protruding teeth; to be toothy. angosolol to have protruding teeth due to a harelip. angosoorot a branch or leaf of engosoorot tree. angoti (singular noun F) leprosy; skin cancer; chronic ulcer. angoti n’atom: nodular leprosy. angu a man-eating lion. angubokin to cut off a piece for somebody.angubonokin to cut off piece after piece for somebody. angubor to cut away a little. angubungubet a piece of something or anything; something incomplete. angubungubet naka acokit: a piece of a potato.anguc a bridle. angucoit a natural gap in the side teeth. cp atoet – natural upper; agilo: not natural lower. angularar to be maimed or crippled. angularikin to make too short (by cutting); to maim; to cripple. to become or be short; to be maimed or crippled. anguletait a piece cut off.angulor to cut off and take away.angulot a female leper; a maimed woman (with a limb or part of a limb cut off). angulungul to cut up into pieces; to amputate; to mangle; to dismember. angulutuny stump of hand; stump of foot. angung to grumble; to growl, grouse. angungakin to disagree with; to become enemies; to fall out with; to be angry with; to dissent. angungakinos aberu k’okilenike: the wife fell out with her husband. angurub to eat something hard; to crunch; to munch; to eat hard food. engurubi ngesi amukeke: she/he munches dried potatoes. angurubikin to crunch; to bite a hard object; to munch (once only). angurubub to have sores around the mouth. anguruc to munch something rubbery. enguruci ikoku amopiira kocupa lo akile: the child is biting the rubber teat of the feeding bottle. anguurian to complain; to be jealous of; to show dissatisfaction; to be discontent; to grumble. enguuriani ngesi ikenyamat: she/he is complaining about her/his food (too little or eaten by someone else). angwalit to be crippled; to be lame. angwalu (singular noun F) a permanent defect (as harelip, one eye, born blind, etc); lameness; being a cripple; deformity; disability. ani? interrogative relative pronoun feminine singular referring to feminine nouns: which one? where? aberu bo ani ibala ijo?: which woman do you mean? ani bo akine?: where is the goat?anibikik to be nice and soft to lay a hand on. inibikikos igoen lu: these clothes are nice and soft to touch. anibinib to look nice; to look beautiful; to look nice and green; to look fine. ejok aite akimai enibinibete: it is nice to look at the verdant (lush green) millet crop in the field. enibinibete akonikonye: you have a fine complexion (facial appearance). anicikik to be compact, finely woven; to be finely plaited (of cloth, mat, or rope); to be thick, as of mortar (a mixture of sand, cement or lime and water). anielet to smear on; to plaster. anielesi eong ekume arwatat: I am smearing mucous on the wall. enielesete kesi aoret orite: they are smearing cow-dung on the winnow. anieletikin to plaster or smear on or somewhere. tiki tiki, kinyek anieletikin ekume ogoe!: gosh, don’t smear mucous on the dress! aniemakin to go stealthily or on tiptoe to something; to stalk; to catch by surprise. kaniemakinos ber oni ekesa ngol: let us go quietly after that fellow (let us catch him by surprise).anieret to smear on; to plaster.anieretikin to plaster or smear on or somewhere.aniikin to dent or dint or pierce by pressure (as of foot by stepping on gravel); to hurt by pressing. kaniiki eong engarot akeju: a bit of gravel hurt my foot. aniikinet a dent; dint; a dimple; a damage; indentation; a hollow; a dip; an impression. animok (of a girl or woman with small buttocks and narrow hips) to move about naked and exposing one’s private parts; (of a narrow-hipped woman) to wear no nickers.animokok (of a woman or girl) to have small or tiny buttocks and narrow hips.anina to rub vigorously between hands (as one rubbing grains out of cob or fried/roasted groundnuts to remove husks); to have a rubdown of the body. akoto aninaanar akuwan: I want to have a rubdown. aninaanar to rub off dirt, etc; to unhusk fried groundnuts, etc. aninaar to rub off (once), as of fine shell from fried groundnuts. to rub oneself; to have a rubdown. aninaaret attrition, abrasion; a rubdown, massage, manipulation, reflexology. aninaikin to rub in (as of oil onto the skin). aninikaar to become tough, become hard. aninikaar etau: the heart has become brave, courageous, hardy. aitininik etau: to harden one’s heart. aitininik: to harden; to toughen. aniniku1 (singular noun F) toughness; hardiness; fortitude; endurance; constancy. aniniku2 to be tough. aniniku naka etau: hardheartedness. anionokin to dent repeatedly or make many dents. anionoki ngesi akamotoka: she/he badly dented my car. anior to push down (food stuck in the throat, being pushed down by drinking) or push back (a protruding object). to go down; to be pressed down. anior acokit na nan kamyedit eong: the potato, that choked me, has gone down. aniosit a dint; a dent; impression; indentation. anironut to have the property or quality of giving a satiating feeling (as of honey, fat or butter).
-on anaaga1 (a music instrument) a harmonium; accordeon; mouth organ
the land of the Banyankole people

the former kingdom ruled by the Omugabe (king); the present day Uganda districts of Mbarara, Bushenyi, Ntungamo. anoikin to make a dent; to press in; to cut into (as of narrow finger ring). to be pressed in; to be hollow (as of cheeks); to be falling in; to have a dip. enoikino nges ikitinyo: her/his cheeks are sunken. anokiar to burn out or down. anokiasi akito: the firewood has burnt out (without anything being done with the fire). anokit to be continually posing a threat on; to be harassing; to be near; to be close by (somebody or something). anomonor to keep scorching. kanomono eong akolong k’orot: the sun kept scorching me on the way. anomor to scorch; to burn; to build (a house); to pain; to be concerned about; to hurt (one cannot stand). enomorit nges aberu: he worries about his wife. kanomo eong akolong: the sun is scorching me. anomor etogo: to build a very nice house. kanomorit eong ikakoku ibungao: it hurts me to see my child being beaten.anomorit to keep hurting; to give pain; to pain one. kanomorit eong atwanare naka totoka: the death of my mother pains me very much. anomot a burnt out place or plain. anonok1 weakness; tenderness; ripeness, etc. anonok2 to be soft, tender; to be weak, flimsy, flexible, yielding, overripe, easy, limp. enonok akuwan: the body is weak. anonokaar to become soft, pliable, weak, flexible, languid, bendable; to yield, give in, stop trying to do something (because you are not strong enough, etc). anonokiar etau: to become obedient, pliable, amenable, docile. anonokaar akapet leje lej: the hide is now very soft. anoono to make many dents on; to dent repeatedly. inoonoit ijo akakopiira: you badly crumpled my hat. anoonokin to keep denting something; to keep pressing and hurting. kanoonokis eong ingaroi: the gravel keep hurting (my feet when I tread on them).anooti a banknote; paper money or currency note. anuikin to press on or against; to kiss; to osculate. abu Yuda konuik Yesu, kidupori nges: Judas betrayed Jesus by kissing Him. anuikinet a kiss; a peck. anuk1 a sty or a pen for goats or sheep.enukas kesi kotogo duc: they always stay inside the house. anuka to fold up or crumple (cloth, paper or anything); to eat something tough (like leather or tough meat). enukai ekingok emukule: the dog eats the tough hide. anukaikin to dent once; to crook; to crinkle up; to crunch; to fold together (as of mat); to bend over (as of nail when being hammered down). konukaik emukeeka ngol: roll up that mat. to bend, roll up itself. anukaikin ekameleku: my hoe has bent itself (after hitting something hard). kanukaiki eong amojongu kwap: I am stooped by old age. anukakin to bury somewhere; to fill a hole somewhere or for somebody. to stay somewhere for a long time (literally, to bury oneself). alot ngesi anukakin oidukai: she/he has gone to the shops and stayed there (literally, she/he has gone to bury herself/himself at the shops). anukar (prepositional verb) to stay with; to take and keep a thing for too long a time. inyo bo inukar ijo ekakalaamu?: why do you keep my pencil (borrowed from me)? anukio (singular noun F) a burial; interment; funeral. anukur to roll up; (of one’s statement) to bend or fold up; to twist, not to be straightforward. anukur akiro: to twist words. anukurikin to roll up; to fold up; to fold together. konukurik emukeeka ngol koyanga: fold up that mat and take it away. to roll up itself; to wind up itself; to coil up itself; to bend up; to cuddle. anukurikin etogo: to build a small round hut. anukurikin apupu: the hedgehog has rolled up itself.anumuk to eat something soft, floury, spongy (like a potato or cake). anumuki eong acokit: I am eating a nice soft potato. anunuk to fold or crumple up.anunuket a fold; a crease. anunukon a person who folds or creases. anunukonokin to entangle; to mix up; to twist (words). inunukonok ijo akapapulai: you have crumpled my papers. to be entangled; (of words) to be twisted; to be mixed up. anunukonokinos akirokon: your case is mixed up. anunut1 (singular noun F) silkiness (of complexion); softness (of skin); smoothness; velvetiness (of feel). anunut2 (of a person’s skin) to be smooth, even, velvetty, or silky. anupakin to listen to; to obey; to hearken; to believe. sirikinupak nuineras lukasabak: do not take any notice of what liers say. anwac (singular noun F) an enlarged spleen (malady). anwokorikin (of a person) to double up or fold up as if feeling pain in the stomach; to collapse or to crumple (as if in great pain). anwomok (of a toothless person) to eat; to eat like a toothless person anya grass (generally).anya anya (of things or crowds of people) uncountable; numerous; too many. ejaas itunga osokooni anya anya: there are too many people in the marketplace. anyaar to widen out; to unroll (of cloth, etc), dilate; to open wide as of a bag or mouth (not of door); to enlarge; to widen a circle. konyaa epuko: open the jute bag. konyaa akituk: open the mouth wide.anyadakak to have dirty teeth; to be dirty (in general). anyadakikin to put or throw something in a dirty place. sirikinyadakik ekagoe orit: do not (throw) put my cloth in the mud. anyaikin to make room for, open out for, stretch for. konyaikinai erot: make room for me. anyait a blade of grass.adak inya: to graze. edakas akituk (inya): the cows are grazing. anya nueokito: dry grass; hay.asokosin enyaitos: socks stretch themselves (when pulled). anyaka to chew; to munch; to masticate; to ruminate; to chew the cud. anyaka einer: speak at random; to stutter. enyakai: she/he chews. enyakaete: they masticate.anyakaanakin to chew for; to masticate for (as mother for child); to pretend to chew, moving jaws to the right and left (as of old people). anyakaet a jaw or a jawbone (as an instument for masticating).aijak anyakaeta: to be exhausted. anyakinyak the third stomach of a cow or grazing animal (a ruminant’s stomach); (slang) vagina. yeninyakinyakitoi: a tatterdemalion; one dressed in rags.
a woman coming from the north

a northerner; a Nordic. ebunit ngesi konyakoi: she/he comes from the north. Nyakoi nako Uganda – Acholi, Lango kede Karamoja: northern Uganda. Nyakoi naka Africa: north Africa – Egypt, Libya, Tunisia, Algeria and Morocco. Nyakoi nako Bulaya: northern Europe – Norway, Sweden, Finland and Russia. anyala to uproot enmasse; to pull suddenly (of bandage, of plants out of ground or of something caught or stuck on). konyalaa anya: pull out the grass. anyalaar to pull and take away enmasse; to uproot. to widen (as of sore); to spread (as of fire); to flare up (as of a quarrelling person). anyalaun to pull up or out enmasse; to uproot (of things stuck, or of plants). to rise quickly and run this way; to get up quickly and come running. konyalaun: rise quickly and come running; pull yourself up and run this way. anyalikik to be very soft; to be unpleasantly soft as of atap or the skin of an old person; to be downy like the fur of a cat. anyalikikin to be unpleasant for somebody to taste; unpleasant to the touch. kanyalikikit eong akiring ngin: I do not like that meat, it is tasteless, not properly cooked. anyamaanut1 (singular noun F) gluttony; gourmand. anyamaanut2 to be gluttonous, greedy. anyamia to eat with; to take advantage of. enyamia ngesi lucetunga: she/he takes advantage of other people; she/he exploits other people for selfish gain. anyamaar to go out to eat; to eat all of something. lolo alosi anyamaar orekon: today I am going to have food at yours. anyamaar ibore: not to return a thing borrowed. anyamun to get consumed or worn out, used up; to quarrel violently; to fight. anyamunos aberu k’okilenike: the husband and wife are quarrelling. anyamunor to cheat. kinyamunor ijo eong: you have cheated me.
a pet name for a brown cow.
a derisive reference (by the Bantu tribes) to any of the tribes of northern Uganda after 1986

(an insult) a northerner (Ugandan) or any person who is tall and dark-complexioned. anyanyaar to fester (of wound); to become bigger (of a sore); to spread (of fire); to flare up; to expand (of power). anyanyaar akajimi: my wound has become bigger. anyanyaar akim: the fire has spread. anyanyaar ecelet: the quarrel has become serious. anyanyaaros akiro: the matter has become grave. anyanyaar je: he has flared up. anyara to call, summon, or to invite by name (call often or many). anyaraar to call away; to ask someone to something. ingai kinyaraarit ijo?: who called you away? anyarao to be called; to be known as; to be named as. enyarao: she/he shall be called thus; they shall be known as. kinyarao: you shall be called thus. kanyarao: I shall be called thus. anyaraun to call this way; to summon here; to invite. anyaraun itunganan: to invite someone to a place, happening, etc. konyarau etelepat: call the boy. to be called, be invited, or summoned. anyaraunos itunga ipu: many people have been called. anyarit to be calling; to be summoning; to be calling a name. inyarit ijo nges ngai?: what, whom do you call her/him?

a woman native to Kisoro district at the extreme south-west of Uganda and the Republic of Rwanda; a word in Kinyarwanda (the language of the Rwandese people). Anyarwaada: the Rwandese women; the Kinyarwanda language. anyaun to make way for oneself; to bend this way. konyau erot: make way for me or for us. anyaun erot: the road is open; the road is clear. anyaun erot: to fight to clear the way from enemies or bandits. anyidik to go in crowds; to be many. enyidikete ikur kaikec: the worms are going in crowds into their house. anyidikaar to go away in crowds. anyidikik (of armyworms or maggots) to be numerous. inyidikikas ikur kotoma akiring: there are too many maggots in the meat. anyidikun to come in crowds, swarms or throngs. anyidok a kind of plant - a sedge. anyigolit a tumour or tonsil at the back of the tongue. anyilakin to give a little (of something to somebody). konyilakinai adikiring: give me a little meat; to give too little; to give short weight. kanyilakis eong Ilugai esukaali: the Indians gave me too little sugar. to be given little or short weight; to be thrifty. kanyilakin eong esukaali: they gave me too little sugar. anyilakinos akipi toma amot: a little water has been poured into the pot. anyilar to take away a little; to tear off. sirikinyila ikakoku: do not tear off (the arm of) my child (by lifting it roughly). anyilil to be torn; to be worn. enyilil ekagoe: my cloth is torn. anyilinyil to tear to pieces. anyilinyila to be torn; to be worn out; to be spoiled (by tearing). anyilun to tear off (once); to tear off or break of a little piece once. anyilunun to keep tearing off; to use carefully; to use sparingly; to be thrifty with. konyilununei ikonisirigin: use your money sparingly. to come off little by little. enyilununos akipi toma ajon nu: too little water is poured into this beer. anyiporit a White Nile sparrow. anyodokok (of teeth) to be dirty with tartar. anyoikin to rise for; to rise (to do something); to rise and start. kanyoiki eong aberu: my wife went away and left me alone. kanyoikisi alosit: let us rise and go; let us start our journey. anyongait a stalk of sorghum eaten like sugarcane. anyongirir to be thick; to be difficult to please; to frown. anyoor to rise and go away from here. konyoo ngina: rise and go away. anyoridid to be dirty; to be filthy (of the body or shoes, plates, cloth); (of room) not swept; sour-faced; grim. inyorididas igoen lu: these clothes are dirty. Anyoun1 the Exodus (one of the books in the Old Testament in the Bible). anyoun2 to get up, to rise up; to depart; to go away; to stand up (as of child) anyou akaberu: my wife has left me. anyounet a departure; an exit; an exodus; the going away. anyul a hammer; anvil.to come out easily. anyuluk to take off easily (like well-cooked meat from a bone). to be soft, easy to pluck out, easy to take off. anyunyu to be unlucky; to have bad luck; to be unsuccessful, unskilful, inapt. anyunyu eong kotoma amej: I am unlucky in hunting. enyunyu eong akan: enyunyu eong ereet: I am unlucky. anyunyura1 (singular noun F) anger; annoyance; fury; irritation. anyunyura2 to be angry; to be annoyed; to be hot-tempered; to be irritated. aitunyunyur: to make angry; to annoy; to upset; to vex, provoke. anyunyuranut1 irritability; tetchiness; bad temper. anyunyuranut2 to be short-tempered; to be inclined to become angry; to be irritable; to be touchy; to be hot-tempered anyunyurikin to be angry with; to flare at; to be annoyed with or on account of to become angry; to become annoyed; to become offended. anyura to pull up (something fixed, like roots); to uproot many. enyurai ngesi eduan: she/he pulls up weeds. anyuraar to pull away (grass, hair, feathers, etc); to disrupt. anyuraun to uproot; to pull out (something soft). anyusa to eat (meat, bread, etc) in mouthfuls. anyusa akiring: to chew meat in mouthfuls (like a cow eats grass). ao (singular noun F) honey bee(s).aog to swagger; to bluster; to strut with defiant air; to be proud.aogakin to become proud, arrogant, or defiant; to show off. aogar to go away proudly (prepositional verb) to pride oneself on. eogatar kesi ekecegaali: they pride themselves on their bicycle. aojaar to become tall; to become long; to become high. iojaar ijo: you have become tall. aojat a kind of grasshopper. aojau1 length; height; tallness; altitude. aojau kuju na angolol: height above sea level.aojau2 to be tall, long, high. aojau akan: to be a thief (literally, to have a long hand). eoj nges akan: she/he is a thief; she/he has a long hand. lo eoj akan: a thief . aoji to twist, or to spin; to twine or to interlace. eojie ngesi auno: she/he is making a rope. eojie ngesi akiro: she/he is twisting words; she/he exaggerates. aojikin to twist, spin for. koojikinoi auno: make or twist a rope for me.aojior to make longer; to twist away. aoke a branch or leaf of eoke tree. aokit a vessel for drawing water or for measuring commercial beer (ajon or ekamule). aokor to scoop away.aokikisi akipi kotoma atan: the well has dried up. aokosit (collective noun F) a great quantity of blood. abu ngesi koii aokosit: she/he lost a great quantity of blood. aokot1 devil's yam, Smilax anceps. aokot2 (uncountable noun F) blood. aiyat aokot: to give blood by transfusion. aokun to ladle, draw water from a well. aol1 the skin underneath the throat; the dewlap. aol2 to do the big; to boast; to be proud; to feel very strong, big, important. eola ngesi: she/he is proud. aola1 (uncountable noun F) a cough; a boast, a brag, or a swank. aola2 to cough; to boast. eolas kesi ebe kitelekaarete oni: they boast that they will beat us (at a football game, etc). aolaun to become adolescent (literally, to cough); to become proud; to become strong again, get courage again. aoli to get lost; to perish; to roam about; to disappear. aolio ebarenitika: my razor blade is lost. eoliete akituk kosamai: the cows will get lost in the swamp: they roam about. aoliosi akituk: the cows are lost. aolikin to lose; to forget; to lose sight of, not to remember. to fail to recognise each other. to be beyond one; to be difficult for one. kaolikitos eong nulimuno: I am at a loss what to say. aolior to disappear; to get lost; to escape, go astray, or be missing. aoliosi akamerekekin: my sheep are lost. aolit1 (singular noun F) ignorance; not knowing. epol aolitekon: your ignorance is great. aolit2 to be ignorant, not to know. aolit eong Ateso: I do not know Ateso. kanu iolitor ijo nu, nges etiokototor: because you do not know this, therefore it is difficult. aoliun to stray this way; to get lost here. aolobob to brag, vaunt, boast, or bluster. aolobobot to boast; to brag; to bluster. eolobobot etelepat lo tai: this boy is a braggart for nothing. aolokok1 light emptiness; hollowness. aolokokor: to become empty, vainglorious. aolokok2 to be hollow; to be empty (of anything); to be vainglorious. aolokonyoi eggshell. aolong to do the big; to be too optimistic about, pretend to be able to. aolongikin to try to do the impossible; to pretend to be able; to do in a hurry. aolongikin ngesi agwel amotoka: she/he has hurried to buy a motorcar. aomaar to sign, take a deep breath. aomaar etau: to take a deep breath; to sigh. aomare to fetch, go and fetch; to indent, order for goods. aomiar erot to go the long way round. aomikin to fetch for or somewhere; to measure or make too big. to become or to be too big. aomikin etogo lo: this house is (measured) too big. aomikin erot: to go the long way round (not taking short cut); to circumnavigate. aomisioit a thought; a conjecture; a concept; a consideration. aomit (singular noun F) a conjecture; inference; a guess; imagination; supposition; assumption; speculation. aomit to have in mind; to think, be of opinion, consider. aomoom to think over; to consider; to discuss in one’s mind; to ponder over; to meditate, or cogitate; to deem,; to imagine. aomoom ketau: to consider; to meditate; to ponder over in one’s heart. aomun to come and fetch; to come and call; to come and take away. (note: koom: go and fetch. koom: come and fetch. koomunoi: come and fetch me; call for me). aongakin to yawn for or on account off. aonganar akiro to drawl, pronounce, inflect, intone, enunciate, or brogue. aongon (the number) four. lokiwongonet M the fourth. aiwongonikin: to do a fourth time; to make four. kiwongonik itunga: add a fourth man, bring their number to four. Aongor1 a pet name for a dirty-brown cow. aongor2 a wading bird with a dirty brown colour, Hammer-head. aongor3 to make purple-brown; to make dark-brown. aongoraar to become dark or purple brown. aongoranut1 dark or purple brown colour. aongoranut2 to be dark or purple brown. aongoriat a species of bird, Hoopoe. aonikin to dry up; to shrivel up; to evaporate. aoniki esamai: the swamp has dried up. aonit to be dry, shrivelled; to be withered. eonit nges akuwan: she/he is shrivelled, has withered (by age or illness). eonit nges akan: she/he is poor: her/his hand dry. eonit nges akituk: she/he is hungry. eonit nges etau: she/he is thirsty, parched. eonit nges akou: she/he is thick-headed. eonit nges egur: she/he is very thin, bony. eonit ngesi kotoma Amusugun: she/he speaks English very well. kane eonit: on the dry land. aonon the dry one. aonore to become dry. aono ngesi: she/he/it is dry. aoko: they are dry, arid, thin. aokoto: they have become dry, slender, thin. aono ngesi de de: she/he/it is very dry, thin-bodied. aono atan: the well has dried up. aono eong etau: I am thirsty. aono nges akan: she/he has become poor, she/he is empty-handed. eringa egoe keono: the dress is not yet dry. eringa akwap eonit: the land is still dry. aoret (singular noun F) cow-dung.amonyo: the dung of a calf. aorikin to neglect, leave alone; to wean; to let go; to let free. aorikin aswam: to resign.aorokonyit phlegm in the throat. akakanyaar aorokonyit: to clear the throat. aoror to be hollow; to be open; to be split; to be cracked, empty, or devoid of. eorori arwatat na: this wall is cracked or the wall is hollow. eorori akoik: the stomach is empty. eorori akekituk: she/he talks a lot; she/he reveals secrets; to talk a lot. aoror swo swo: to be very hollow. aororikin (of a person’s voice) to become hoarse. aororikit (of person) to speak hoarsely; (of voice) to be hoarse. eororikitos kesi: they are hoarse, they speak hoarsely. aosianut1 (singular noun F) menorrhagia in animals or women. aosianut2 to have menorrhagia. aosiar (said of woman or animals) to take a long time without producing. eosiarit aberu na: this woman has been a long time without conceiving. aosikin to give permission; to let go; to resign; to set free or liberate; to stop doing or saying. aosikin erot: to get out of the way. aosinoit the vagina and the rectum of a big animal such as a cow. aosomit elephant-snout fish, Carcusenius. aote ki-o to work for wages; to loiter; to go and stop at somebody’s or somewhere often. akoto apaanakin neijai ijo: I want always to stop where you are. apaar to go astray or to diverge; to err; to make a mistake; to become bad; to turn aside; to go off the road; to be tasteless. epaarit akiring na: this meat is tasteless. apaar awai: to go aside; to go off the touch-line (in football). apaar naka akituk: abu akakituk kopaa: I had a slip of the tongue. epaarit akakituk: I have no taste. epaarit eong akituk kanyam eitola kasodi aimat ajon: I have no taste for beer after eating sugarcane. apaaran a day; daylight; a date. apaarasia kere: always. apaarasia nu: nowadays.apaaran kere: all day; the whole day. kapaarasia: from time to time. nace paaran: the following day.acepaaran: another time. inyamat lukapaaran: daytime food or meals; lunch. apaarasia nuka aburun: hard times. apaarasia nuka Rogasio: Rogation Days (the three days before Ascension Day). apaarit a day (24 hours); a date. acepaarit: another day; another time. apacanar to make slips (of the tongue) often; to err often; to make mistakes often. epacanar akakituk: I often make slips of the tongue; I say often the wrong thing; I often make mistakes. apacar1 to burst open; to shell; to unhusk. to be peeled, unhusked, shelled. apacar2 to go off the beaten track; to take another way; (of a missile) to ricochet, to divert. abu eong kapacar: I went off the right road; I took the side road or path. apacar awai: to deflect away (of a blow); to graze. apacara unhusked; shelled; peeled. apacet a husk, peelings, rind, the bark; a shell; a hull. apacetait a husk; a shell; a hull; bark. apaceta nuka emaido: groundnut-shells. apacolol to have a bald (hairless) or scarred head. apacoloor to become bald (hairless) or scarred on the head. apacun to take off, shell; to unhusk. to come off (as of shell or bark of tree).apadalal to be flat (of foot or head; of stool). apadalu flatness; evenness; smoothness. apadinganut1 enmity; hostility; unfriendliness. apadinganut2 to be enemies; to be unfriendly. apae a female friend; a female lover.apagal (of a situation) to be clumsy or awkward; to be difficult, awkward to handle. apagalal to become clumsy, awkward. apagalikin to be awkward for, clumsy for. kapagalikinit eong ainyam kakediany: I find it awkward to eat with the left hand. apagalu (singular noun F) awkwardness; clumsiness; difficulty. apaikin to halt; to stop; to wait; to stay; to abide (used in narrative form and infinitive) kopaikini and then; after that. apaipo a pipe; a tube; a cylinder; a conduit; a pipeline. apajangang to have a flat head; to be flat-headed. apak space; room; time; period of time; opportunity; turn; duration. apak naabunio: when I come. apak naka ailok: the time for trapping or catching (animals); time for removing teeth. apak alopet: the right time; the exact time. apak naewoj: a long time; at long intervals; for a long time. apak na kere: all this time. apakio nukolo: far distant times (in the past); a long time ago; in olden times. apakapak to break into pieces; to separate; to give strong blows; to break down (a wall). apakar to take off a piece; to break off; to separate (of things usually joined). to break off (as of a clod of earth, piece of potato, etc); to separate. apakasit a female labourer; a porter; a maid-servant. apaket a packet (of cigarettes, tobacco etc). apaketait a (broken off) part of something.
enyoodo anyulaun to pluck out (weeds); to pull out (feathers)

Ipalaasan ineras Apalaasan: the French speak French. apalakac tough meat. apalalu1 (singular noun F) dampness; wetness; moistness. apalalu2 to become fresh; to become damp; to become wet, moist, or clammy. apalanut1 (singular noun F) capitulation; surrendering; forfeiting.apalanut2 to give up or concede easily. apalapalat to go round shyly; to be shy, bashful; to be perplexed; to be disappointed. abu ikoku kobu epalapalat: the child came round shyly, bashfully. apalapalat tai: to go about aimlessly.apalapiano a frying pan. apalar to stop doing, using, or eating something; to give up something; to be quiet, motionless, restful; to stop by oneself. epalarito akipi: the water is calm, motionless. epalarit etauka: nothing worries me; I am at peace. apalaret a deadlock (in a tug-of-war). apale a woman’s skirt or petticoat.apalikin to neglect; to desert; to leave alone, sacrifice to; to refuse to press a debtor. apalikin aibois: to give up a seat or place for somebody. apalikin inyamat: to sacrifice one’s share of food to someone else who does not have. apalikin etau: to procrastinate. apalikin aswam: to give up work for someone else. apalisi a mattress (in general); a wire or sponge mattress: apalisi naka asinin. apalisionor to become a procrastinator, a foot-dragger, etc apalisionut1 (singular noun F) humble, polite; procrastination; delaying action. apalisionut2 to be humble, polite;
