to give up; to back out. apalunit eong aswam na: I dislike this work; I do not care for this work. apalu ngesi akeberu: he has deserted or neglected his wife. apalun akiro: to let well alone; to put aside bad blood. apalun2 to become obsolete; to become neglected, abandoned; to take away worries. apalun esomero ngol: that school has been neglected. epalunit ekatau: I am not worried about it, leaves me at ease. to be put at ease. apalunanut1 (singular noun F) level-headedness; equanimity; self-control; restraint. apalunanut2 to be level-headed, restrained, or not easily disturbed, disciplined, detached, calm. apama a (brick or mud) wall.apanamu (singular noun F) scarcity; shortage. inyamat lukapanamu: last-resort food; relief food; giffen goods. apanasiait a cluster of banana fruits, i.e. a part of a bunch. apanyait a potato mound; a potato heap. aibok acok: to dig potato heaps; to plant potatoes; (slang) (during the Teso insurgency of 1987-1991) to dig one’s own grave before being killed. apapan to try in vain; to hum and haw; to bustle.apapangu1 astringency; sourness like half-ripe bananas. apapangu2 (of fruit) to be sweet-sour; to be astringent, sour, acerbic. apapu (singular noun F) nothing; a wraith; a phantom; obesity around the waist. aparipar to be very shiny; to dazzle. eparipari angolol ya: that lake dazzles or gleams. aparis a branch, leaf or fibre of eparis tree. ajon nuka aparis: beer given to those who bring the dowry (named so because cows are beaten with the aparis branch on the way). apason (singular noun F) tiredness; fatigue; weariness; exhaustion. aara nges apason: she/he is very tired (literally, she/he died of weariness).apatakak to be very fat, obese. apatanikin to be convenient to; to be easy for. kapatanikit eong aimar: mathematics or arithmetics is easy for me. apatanu1 tameness; ease; gentleness; convenience; affability. apatanu2 to become easy, convenient, tame, cheap, or gentle. apaun to reroute oneself hither; to divert and come towards. apaup a female companion or friend; one of a pair of female things. ape1 (of an action) taking a long time. iswamai ngesi ape: she/he works slowly. iboyie ngesi kore ape: she/he sits all the time at home. inera ngesi ape: she/he talks for a long time. ape2 (imperative) expression, ‘go’; to have a leak. apedonor to be almighty. Edeke Lokapedor kere: God the Almighty; the all powerful; the omnipotent. mam eong apedonori nuetia nen: I cannot be bothered about all those things; I am unable to do so much. apedor1 ability; legal right; competence; power; permission; admittance; capacity. adumun apedor aswam ibore: to get permission to do something. apedorosio nukidwe (kwape nat aisiom, aidario ejok): child rights (such as the right to education and protection). apedorosio nukitunga: human or peoples’ rights. apedorosio nukidwe (kwape nat aisiom, aidario ejok): child rights (such as the right to education and protection). apedorosio nukitunga: human or peoples’ rights. apedor2 to be able, be competent, or to have power over; to manage; to get permission, admit. adumu ngesi apedor: she/he has got permission. koge ber adumun apedor: first go and get permission. apedori eong: I can. apedorit aswam ibore: to be able to do something. apedor3 to pierce through. abu eong kapedo ebileng: I pierced the mudfish. apedorit (singular noun F) ability; competence; capacity. apedosit a hole (in a substance); a fissure; a puncture; an aperture. apedot a hole (in a substance); a gap; a crevice; an aperture. apedot naka ekume: the nostril. apedot kotoma arwatat: a chink; a crevice. apedun to dig (for water) to come out; to appear this way. ebunit lokabokan atanin apedun akipi: the well-driller has come to dig for water. apedunos akipi: the water has gushed out (has spurted out). apeduro a kind of cactus plant, Euphorbia laterophylia. apedurot the fruit of epeduru tree, used as a flavouring for some vegetables and atap, and also placed in the gourd with the millet seeds just before planting the millet (to bless the millet crop). apeduru a branch or leaf of epeduru tree. apeelet a slice or a flake (of anything, especially of bar soap). apeero a grassy plain (i.e. grassland); a sod (i.e. grass); a sward (i.e. meadow or pasture). apeesa a (cloth) button. apeesan money; cash; cloth buttons. apeeti a woman’s silk underwear resembling a skirt, often with ornamentation at the fringes; a petticoat; underskirt; a slip. apega1 argument; discussion. apega2 to argue; to bargain; to discuss. epegas itunga ka Ilugai: people bargain with the Indians. apega eong : I (they) deny it; I (they) disbelieve. apegakin to quarrel with; to contradict; to disagree with; to answer back. mam ejok apegakin emuronikon: it is not good to contradict your doctor. apegakinet an objection; a protest; abnegation; a rebuttal. apegan one who contradicts; a debater; one who objects.apeganar to deny everything; to refuse to own up; to refuse to confess. siripeganari akiro: do not refuse to own up or to confess (the truth). apeganut1 protestation; contradiction; objection. apeganut2 to be inclined to argue, to contradict, deny, or discuss. apege a female pig; a sow; a woman wallowing in filth. apeikin to run away from somebody. kapeiki eong akingok: the bitch ran away from me. to roast, brand, scorch for somebody. apeipeyanut to be scarce; to do seldom, be difficult to get; to do occasionally. epeipeyana ngesi abunenen ne: she/he comes here seldom.apeis abore napeis: a gridiron. apejo (singular noun F) a visit; a call on; a stopover; a trip; a vacation. apejonon a female guest; a female visitor; a female caller; a female tourist. apekipok a hamstring i.e. a tendon at the back of the knee: amoorit naka apekipok.apel armlet or arm band (of ivory, bone or wood carving) formerly worn by men above the elbow, especially when dancing or getting initiated to elders. apele (followed by infinitive) to do badly, openly, on purpose, deliberately; to resolve; to do intentionally. ibu ijo kopele ainom nges: you beat her/him deliberately.apeleanut initiative; inventiveness; enterprise; creativity. apeleikin to intend; to mean to do something; to do on purpose, intentionally, or deliberately; to resolve to do. apeleikinet a strategic goal; an objective; an intention; an initiative; a programme; a plan; a scheme; a project; a proposal. apeleun to start something new; to improvise; to invent, extemporise. to start by itself; to go with a protruding stomach (as of children or small men, not of big fat man). apemerer to have or having a protruding stomach. apengo (of time in the past) long ago. kolo apengo: very long ago. apenyakin to do at once; to do immediately, rashly, in a hurry. (in narrative tense) ‘and then; immediately, forthwith.’apenyun to appear suddenly and head for the speaker. abu emir kopenyun kotoma anya: the rat came out of the grass. apeor to brand, scorch; to roast (a little), parch. to be roasted, scorched, branded, burnt, parched. apeoros inya: the grass is scorched (by the sun). apepeanut to be quick in deciding; to be impatient. apepeu1 (singular noun F) sensitiveness; susceptibility; guilt-conscience. apepeu2 (used with etau) to be impatient, easily influenced, vulnerable, easily moved, easily affected, irritable, or edgy. aper to lie down; to sleep, or to spend the night; to inhabit; to dwell; to stay. eperete kesi togo ngol: they are sleeping in that house. aper nen! it is over!; it is finished!; kaput! kalas! aperiat a bride’s escorts to the new home after the marriage ceremony. aperikin to do the whole night. aperikis kesi atenus: they danced to the drums all night.aperis bedding; bed; a place for sleeping; sleeping hut; abode.aperit1 bedding; a bed; a place for sleeping; a sleeping hut; an abode.aperit2 to have slept; to pass the night. iperit biai? (the morning greeting): how did you sleep? did you have a good night?aperoi good millet beer (four or five days old). acok nuperoi: potato mounds prepared for the following year. aperonor to sleep away from home often; to sleep over. alot ngesi aperor ngina: she/he went to sleep over there. eperorit akim koreke: the fire kept burning all night at her/his home. eperorit akakoik: I slept with a full stomach. aperosi akiro ngun bobo: that case was again deferred or left undecided. aperosit (singular noun F) remnants of food kept overnight. koyau aperosit, kariebi eong etengei: bring me last evening’s food leftover, I am hungry. aperun to lie in wait for; to lurk; to ambush. akoto aperun ekesa ngol aibunga: I want to ambush that fellow to give him a beating. apese an unmarried girl of 18–26 years of age; a spinster; a maiden; a damsel.apesen a debt; a loan; a mortgage; an advance; an obligation. ejai eong apesen kajo: I have a debt with you. apesiaar to open out; to spread out, increase. apesiar to open out; to spread (as of a mat), increase. apesikin to spread out. apesikin ejamu: to make the bed. apesikin akiro: to discuss; to talk things over; to go into details; to try to come to an agreement. apesikinet a structure (the way in which the parts of a thing are arranged or organised); topography; the lie.apetakin icetunga akiro: to discuss, explain for; to kick each other. kipetok ijo eong emopiira akongu: you hit my eye with the ball. apetonut1 skilled at kicking (football, karate, etc); fondness of kicking. apetonut2 to be skilled at kicking. apetor to kick off; to kick away; to leave alone; to reject; to abandon (as of hen kicking away her chicks). apeto akiteng elepit: the cow has kicked over the milking can. to refuse to pay a debt. ekopaarit ngesi akapeesan, konye apeto: she/he borrowed some money but she/he has refused to pay back. apetun to kick this way; to make to bulge out; togive a full account of an event. apetun epur: to stoop. apetun ngesi togo: she/he forced or kicked open the door; she/he entered by kicking the door open. api a small shallow basket. apiar to carry away all, rob all; to sweep away; to finish all. apiasi ikokolak ikaboro: the robbers have swept away all my belongings. apiar akan: to become poor; (of hands) to become empty; to be all finished. apiar eong akan: I have become poor. apie leftovers of food on the table; to see through; to comprehend; to follow (with the mind); to grasp; to fathom. ipirianik ijo akiro nu?: do you grasp these issues? apiirianut1 (singular noun F) expertise; insight; experience; sharpness (of intellect); slenderness; smallness (in stature). apiitit2 (of a person or an animal) to be slight, slender, or under-developed. apiku (in the Teso game of aibic) a small flat and round stone for hitting a nut outside the hole as chosen by the opponent (hitting that nut alone means you win all the nuts; hitting more than one nut means you lose your turn and the chance goes to the opponent; nuts entering the hole belong to the person who threw them in; apiku entering the hole having nuts means that player will lose those nuts i.e. the nuts continue in play). apinat (collective noun F) fowl fleas; chicken lice.apinyait a grass, Echinochloa pyramidalis.Apio(t) name of the first born girl twin. [note: the second born girl is Adong(ot)] apipa a barrel; a plastic tank or drum for storing liquids. apipilikin to be painful to; to be hurtful; to hurt; to sympathize with; to be attached to. kapipilikit eong ebela: the idea of being beaten frightens me. epipilikit nges ainyekin ere: the idea of leaving home is painful to her/him. (note: kariebi akou: my head is aching). epipilikit nges aberuke: he is attached to his wife.apipilu1 (singular noun F) pain; soreness; hurt. apipilu2 to become painful to; to become sore; to be a sore point to. epipil ngesi inusio: she/he is mean with her/his money. apiripir (of a lake or a road mirage) to glitter; to dazzle; to shine. epiripiri ecor: epiripirete akipi: the lake glitters in the sun. epiripiri akekou: her/his head is shines (because it is clean-shaven). apirit a plant formerly used for extracting salt, Cyperus distans; one of the two 'thighs' of the cycle or an ox plough where the wheel (hub) is fixed. apiriun to become clever. apiriutu kesi: they have become clever. apiupiu (singular noun F) the grapevine; rumours. akiro nu aarere ngesi mam ecaete, konye apiupiu naenerasi itunga ice nges abala ebe amariao apese: the reason why he was murdered is not clear, but rumour has it that it was rivalry over a girl. apiyai money; cash; currency. apoar to pull away (as of bark of a tree); to pull the skin off; to strip off, peel off; to pull off and take. kopoa akopit koyanga: pull off a few fibres and take them away. apod to grouse; to complain; to grumble; to lament; to be in distress; to worry; to care; to deplore, be anxious, or to mind. inyo bo ipodo ijo?: what are you worried about? apodo eong: I mind very much. apodo eong etengei: I am complaining of hunger. epodo ngesi ejose: she/he pretends to be vexed: she/he worries about nothing: she/he has no reason to worry. mam nges epodo: she/he is carefree or unperturbed. apodokinit (singular noun F) concern; worry; grouse; complaint. apodonokin to be constantly worried or concerned about something or somebody. epodonokinos kesi kanuka inyamat: they are complaining about food. apodonut to be fond of worrying, grousing, complaining. apodor to complain about something. epodotor kesi ikecekoku inyamat: they are worried about the food for their child. apog to swagger; to strut about; to boast; to be proud; to walk proudly; to put on airs; to flaunt. apogakin to swagger about; to be arrogant for or to. apoganut1 vanity; pride; conceit; arrogance. apoganut2 to be inclined to be haughty, proud, arrogant. apogot armlet; wristlet; bangle; bracelet. apokare (of many) to come. agiroto kesi apokare: agiroto kesi aponere: they have refused to come. apokipok the back of the knee-joint; (formerly) a rifle; a gun. amoorit naka apokipok: a hamstring; tendons holding the femur and the tibia at the posterior end. apokirir to be fat (of anything). apokokin1 (of a big person) to do a work which is too trifling, or fit for little ones; to be too big, not to fit in. apokokin ejakait toma abolia naka idwe: the chief took part in a children’s game. apokokin icetunganan akonye: to stare at someone. ipokokino ijo aitiji ikoku ngin: you are too big to fight that child. epokokino ngesi aiboi kosomero: she/he is too big or too old to be resident at school. apokokin2 to give somebody a big piece or lump or share of something apokonut1 greediness taking big morsels; ravenousness. apokonut2 to be greedy or ravenous by taking big morsels. apokopok1 to beat on the head, ankles, or elbows; to conk. apokopok2 to eat something hard or raw (as of raw potatoes, cassava, etc). apokor to take away something big. apokor akwena: to have a big laugh, to guffaw. apokor etyang: to kill a big animal. apokor euga: to take a big lump of posho. apokot the ear of grain; the head of millet. apokun akonye to bulge out the eyes; to ogle. apolisit a policewoman; a woman constable.apolo1 growth; development; progress; advance. apolo2 to grow; to become big; to develop; to expand. epoloi ngesi: she/he is growing. apolokin1 to grow up (somewhere or for or in); to be brought up at. epolokit ngesi Busia: she/he was brought up at Busia; she/he leads Busia. kapolokit eong aswam na: I cannot manage this work (because it is much). apolok eong toma aswam na: I have grown up doing this work. apolokin2 to be bigger than; to be too big for; to lead or be in charge of. kipolokit ijo eong: you are bigger than me: you are my senior. epolokit nges akoik: she/he has a very big stomach; she is in her last stages of pregnancy (can hardly move about). apolokin eicolong: to be chairman; to preside (at meeting). apolokiniton controller; manager; organiser; the in charge; commander; leader. apolokiniton ajakaanuto kodistrikt: the chief administrative officer in a district. apolokit to control, to manage, to organise; to be in charge of; to have power over; to be in command of; to lead. apolon a respected man in the age range 42–66 years; a master or a boss; a principal. apolon kateker a clan leader or elder. apoloor to develop; to grow bigger; to become important; to increase in size; to accrue.
(formerly) a name given to a girl-child passed through the roof to prevent its premature death (after the preceding child has died)

a woman’s name common in Teso.ikar luka apolou: age; a lifespan. apolounon one who has just grown up; an adult. etiai kalukapolok: the adult population. apomor to be corpulent around the stomach. apomoror to be corpulent around the waist or belly. ipomoror nges akoik: she/he is corpulent around the belly.aponere to come. abuni: I will come. kiponi: we shall come. epote: they will come. kopotu come. ekot ngesi abunere, ekotos kesi apokare: she/he, they want to come. Past tense: abu : I (we) came. aponi nges kinomai: she/he was beaten or shot. aponi kebungai eong: I was beaten. apongorut a lump of soil or clay; a clod. apongosos to have fat buttocks; to be fat, corpulent around the buttocks. aponikin to befall; to overcome (used with plural noun). kaponikis eong ican: problems have befallen me. Apoo1 a woman’s name. apoo2 a scrub hare, Lepus saxatilis; a rabbit (its droppings are believed to heal fire burns if smeared on the affected part). apoopi a bicycle pump.apoopo to tear off big chunks repeatedly. epoopoi ngesi akiring: she/he tears off meat (with her/his teeth). apoore a scar; a mark on the skin or in the soul; a cicatrix. apoore namam elemar: an eternal scar. apopir to twist a rope, etc between fingers; to roll cigarettes; to spin. apopirikin: to roll up for. kopopirikinai eong esigala: roll me a cigar. apopong a branch of euphorbia plant (figurative) a gun; a bazooka; a rifle. aporitoi to fly about; to be in flight or airborne. aporoc to fling with a catapult; to sling; to dart. aporocaar to sling away; to loosen the sling; to dart away, fling away, or to project to go too far; to run forward. aporocet a catapult; a sling (for throwing a dart or a stone).abu Daudi koporocik Goliasi amoru akou: David slung a stone at Goliath’s head. aporogot a tilapia fish; ngege fish.abu akokor koporok odula: the hen flew on top of the granary. aporor to fly away; to disappear quickly, take to flight; to get away quickly. aipor akeje: to go fast, run away. apotu asigirian eporete akeje karab karab: the donkeys are coming along galloping. aporosi akipi ngun: that water went the wrong way, i.e. went in the wind pipe, did not pass through the throat (hence, causing someone to cough). aporun to fly out (from the nest, tree or of white ants from the anthill). aporo ekongot: the white ant has flown away.aposik to be heavy, grave, difficult. eposik ngesi; eposik kesi: she/he is (they are) heavy. eposik aswam kon: you job is difficult.aposikikin to be too heavy for. kaposikikit eong epuko lo: this sack is too heavy for me. akirot naeposik: a serious matter; an important matter; a hopeless task. apoti (of a woman or animal) to be pregnant. epotie aberu ngin: that woman is pregnant (a verb to mean pregnancy of animals is aiwacun). apotikik (of porridge, beer, sauce, etc) to be thick; (of a person) to be dense, stupid, or obese. apotikin to make pregnant; to fertilise; to impregnate. apotionut1 fertility (of women). apotionut2 (of a woman) to be conceiving fast. epotiyono aberu ngin: that woman is fertile. apotipot a ferry (a water vehicle).aberu napotion : a pregnant woman. apotiun to conceive. apotiu apese ngin: that girl has conceived or has become pregnant. apotokok (of clay, food, beer, etc) to be thick; (of road, compound) to be dirty, muddy.apoun to strip, peel off for oneself. apua (singular noun F) dust; power or vim (to do something). apucet a peace offering. apuconut1 peacefulness; conciliation. apuconut2 to be peaceful; to be inclined to non-violence. apucun to educate; to polish up; to furbish. apudokin to go out early for somebody or something or somewhere. kopudok aswam: go out early for work.ipudorete itunga aswam: people go out early to work. epudosi kesi amat: they have gone out early to booze. apugan administration; governance; the regime. erono apuganike: her/his regime or government is bad. apugan nakotem: sub-county administration. apugan naka ikulepek akwap: the local government. apugan nakedaran: an interim government; a protectorate government. apugur to have a bent back; to go with a bent back; to be stooping. ai bo ipuguri ijo?: where are you off to with your hunchback? apugurikin to be bent (of a person’s back). epugurikina ngesi: she/he is hunched. apuikin to kill for (intentionally); to slaughter for. apotu kesi kapuikis eong emong: they killed a healthy bull for me. apujan a marshy lakeshore; a big dried-up swamp with trees. apukenit a clay lid of a granary. apuket a bottle or tin opener apukokin to open for; to uncover (as of a box). apukokinio (singular noun F) a revelation; a disclosure. Apukokinio: the Book of Revelations (according to St. John). apukor to open; to reveal; to uncover; to take off the lid or cover; to denude. apukor aki: to listen; to pay attention. apukor akonye: to open eyes; to see. apukun to discover; to open or uncover; to expose. apulakikin to rust; to boil down, be well cooked, well done. apulakiki edia: the vegetables are well done, well cooked. apulakiki ekileng: my knife has rusted or is rusty. apulasita an adhesive plaster or bandage for wounds; plaster of Paris. apuleeje a furrow, gutter; a ditch; a rut (in the road). apuleera (in the Catholic church) a brotherhood; a vicariate; a monastery.apuneke a wild cat hunted for its meat, Felis silvestris. apungure a log (of wood); a tree stump; a chump. keguiki eong apungure: I have stumbled my foot against a tree stump. ajo bala apungure: to lie or sleep like a log (heavy and without turning). apunuka a digestive stomach of a cow or hoofed animals; the abomasum. apuny to kill for sacrifice at a funeral feast. apunya1 (singular noun F) the last funeral rites ceremony. apunya2 to sack, rob, or plunder; to perform the last funeral rites to the dead (by killing bulls and drinking brew for the purpose). apunya lokatwan: to kill an animal for a funeral feast. apunyai the wakes; an annual feast for the departed. apuor to escape; to break out (of prisoner); to go beyond limit; to degenerate. apuor etau: insatiable, libertine.apupa to rub grain between hands; to grate. epupaete kesi imare: they are rubbing the peas (to take off the husks).apupaar to rub off (as of husks of peas, etc).apupet something to hear with; an ear; a hearing aid; a newspaper.apupetait something to hear with; an ear; a hearing aid; a newspaper.apupio naka emusaago: court hearing of a case. apupo to be rumoured. akiro nuepupos: rumours. apupokin to listen in; to attend to or listen with care; to wait a little before acting; to be patient. kopupok ber: first listen (to what I have to say). apupokin ber esimu: to attend to the telephone first. apupokinit: to pay attention; to listen or look with care. apuponut1 listening; attentiveness; compliance; submission. apuponut2 to be obedient; to be ready to listen; to hear apupu a hedgehog, Atelerix frontalis.etyono apupun akiro ecelasi itunga: it is difficult to hear when people are shouting. apurasas to be fat, corpulent, or obese; to be fat all over.apuri to be smoking; to evaporate. epurie etogo: the house is smoking. eur etogo lo apuru: this house smells of smoke. apurikin to be dusty, covered with dust or flour, brown with dust. ipurikit ijo: you are ashen or dusty. (only used of persons: of table, etc. say ileleba apua omeesa: the table is covered with dust). apuriki nges akekuwan: her/his body is dirty, filthy with age. apuriongong to be whitish, pale, ashen (with dust or ash). apurior (of gas) to effervesce, fizz, or to bubble. apurokin to plead for; to reply (in court); to intercede for, make peace with; to pacify. apuru (singular noun F) smoke; vapour; gas. apurukuc a knee-cap; a patella. apurus to have diarrhoea; to impale many.
Opolot apolou (singular noun F) importance; greatness; meaning; age; explanation; extent; size; rank; magnitude
a pet name for a bluish-grey cow. apusa to beat somebody or something big

to break a big thing; to throw over something full of liquids; eat a juicy or fat thing. epusaete Imugis ikur: the Bagisu eat fat caterpillars. adau ikoku yen apusa akamoti kere: this child has broken all my pots. (used with a plural object). apusaanar to fall down, throw oneself down repeatedly (as Ateso women do in mourning). apusaar (used with singular and plural object) to knock down; to break. apusaa etelepat ekatuo: the boy has broken my gourd. apusakin to throw (of something big); to kill for; to knock down something big somewhere (of persons and large objects) to fall down with a thud. apusaun etau (of heart) to beat suddenly or quickly. apusaun eong etau: my heart has missed a beat (a sign of bad omen).apuserut1 a kind of grass. apuserut2 a widow. apusianar to become purple-grey. apusianut to be purple-grey; to have purple-grey spots. apusit to be like; to have the appearance or to resemble. epusit ngesi ngai?: whom does she/he resemble? (note: not used of things; of things use: ikoni ai? or ikoni bo ai?) ikoni egoe lo ai?: what does this cloth look like?aput an image; a resemblance; a likeness; a picture; a photo. kinom aputoka: take my photograph. aputiot a muscle or tendon; a gut.aputokinos ngesi ka etyang: she/he is like a brute (an animal). aputonor to resemble each other. eputonoro kesi: they resemble each other. aputoor to resemble; to be like; to act like. aputoo ngesi Emusugut: she/he acts like a European. aputot a muscle or tendon; a gut.apuuga an unmarried hard-to-control girl; a miss.apuun to be spoiled, degenerated; to be alone; to come out, break through. apuun akoniberu: your wife has run this way for protection. apuuta a carnivorous fish - Nile Perch.apuworo to have a wild longing for (usually used with etau). apuyapuyat a crumb. apuyapuyan nuka emugaati: bread crumbs. apuyapuyaun to disintegrate; to decay. apuyat a crumb. apuyan nuka emugaati: bread crumbs.apuyere igoen luka Obore: they robbed Obore’s clothes. apuyo ngesi ikaboro: she/he ran off with my property. apwakanut to have the initiative. apwasaar to fall with a splash. apwasakin to smash something against. apwasakin etwo kwap: the gourd was smashed on the ground and is broken completely. apwasakisi ikokolak engarot lo ti okek: the thieves have smashed a huge stone against the door (so as to force the door open). apwatar to polish off; to dust, mop. apwatun to make clean; to clean, wipe, cleanse. to become clean, polished, cleansed. apwosok (of groundnut shells) to be empty; (of a person) to be without strength; (of a person) to be without guts or courage. epwosok emaido: the groundnuts shells are empty (no nuts inside). epwosok eketau: she/he has no guts. apyakiar to become stale. (used with noun in plural). elosete ajon nu apyakiar: this beer is becoming tasteless (due to water having been poured many times). apyaniar to become tasteless, stale (used with noun in singular). apyanikin to be tasteless, stale to; to be distasteful to. kapyanikis eong ajon ngun: that beer is tasteless to me: I find that beer tasteless. apyanus1 (singular noun F) tastelessness; staleness; insipidness. apyanus2 to be tasteless, to be stale, insipid. ajon nu ekotos apyakus: this beer tends to tastelessness. apyanuun to become tasteless, stale. apyakuut ajon: the beer has become tasteless . apyeede a nightjar (bird). apyetun ki-a to devour; to polish off. apyeun to sweep out; to take out (as of what remains in a granary). ikoto ijo apyeun edula kere?: do you want to empty the whole granary (leaving nothing inside)? -ar verbal suffix denoting a repeated act: aanyanar: to check repeatedly; to re-inspect; to re-examine. -ar verbal suffix denoting action away from speaker or acquisition of quality: akodar: to drag away. amear: to chase off, to rustle away. (Present tense prefix and suffix: i-ete. Perfect tense suffixes: -a , -asi) araakit1 an old woman (beyond reproductive or child-bearing age).araanut1 fertility, fruitfulness, fecundity (of trees, not of animals and human beings). araanut2 (of trees)to bear much fruit; to be prolific. araba a rubber eraser. arabal a women's skirt of skin.arabo (of plural objects) to clasp tightly (as when riding pillion); to get hold of; to press many things together; to rumple or crumple things in the hand; to fold (as of leaves); to fold or crumple hard things noisily. eraboete idwe apapulai: the children crumple papers. araboikin (used with plural or singular object) to crumple, rumple. iraboikit ijo ekaitaabo: you have crumpled my book. to be crumpled, folded, creased, rumpled, or pressed together. aracakin (of fluid or semi-fluid) to throw on; to spill on. sirikiracak eong erit: don't throw mud at me to fall on, drop on. aracakin acece ogoeneka: the sauce has stained (fallen on) my clothes. aracanakin to pelt somebody with mud or semi-liquids. aracar to throw away; to spatter (of liquids, or semi-liquids). aracasi idwe akima: the children have splattered the porridge about. araet a fruit (in general); an offspring. aragoit a stubble or stump of burnt grass. arai1 or; if; whether. arai...arai: whether...or. arai ebuni, arai da mam ebuni: whether she/he comes or not. karaida: although; even if. dimarai: unless; except. nabarai or naarai seeing that; because. nabarai edit apak mam abuni: I shall not come because I have no time. arai bo: probably; maybe. arai2 da although; even if.arai3 present indicative of araus (to be) followed by noun or pronoun. arai: I am; irai: you are (singular); erai: she/he/it is; kirai: we are; eraas: they are. erai ngesi ejakait: he is a chief.araikiliokit a small red and blue fish. araikin to bear fruit for. araitoit a fruit (in general). arakakin (of women and animals) to become barren, be barren, or sterile. erakakit aberu ngin: that woman is barren. arakan a barren female (person or animal).arakirak (of eyes) to be watery, running; (of an egg) to be watery, half cooked; (in general) to look like phlegm; to be phlegmatic. erakirakete je akonye bala epoon ewaragi: that guy has watery eyes like a crude alcohol distiller. aramakin to beat on, for (of drum). koramak atenus: beat the drum. aramet a stick for beating a drum; a stick for threshing grain.erangani ekesa ngol enyami: that fellow eats greedily or shakes with greed when eating. aranganet appetite; eagerness; keenness; enthusiasm; excitement; fervour; impatience. arany a leather or fabric with four straps (used by women to carry a child on the back). aranyet a saddle. arapaitelait a game bird - black ibis, Abdims stork (usually moving in great flocks and eat locusts).arapakin to cover up or over, put on lid or cork to be covered, be concealed; to lurk. arapakinet a cover; a lid.arapanar to screen, cover and keep taking away. araparap: to keep covering many things. arapar to cover up, hide away, screen off, shelter, or to envelop to be covered, screened off. arapetait a cover; a lid; a top.araping a grass, Echinochloa pyramidalis. arapud to build flat-roofed or low-roofed houses. erapudete Ilugai itogoi: the Indians build flat-roofed houses (note: plural object used, itogoi). arapudud (of house) to be low, dwarfish, short. irapududos itogoi ngul: those houses are low.arara1 a cheetah, Acinonyx jubatus.erarai ngesi akito: she/he collects firewood. eraraete akiyo: they are shedding tears. arara akiro: to jabber, talk much; to rattle off words. araraasi ikito akwi: the trees have shed their leaves. araraaros akwi: the leaves have fallen. arara akolong akwi: the sun has made the leaves drop. araraar akwi: to shed leaves. araraanar to strew on (as of soil or leaves); to spill on. araraar to shed (as of feathers or leaves); to clean (as of table). araraasi ikito akecekwi: the trees have shed their leaves. ararap to grope, feel one’s way (as of a blind person or one in the dark). ararapaar to feel around (as of a person in the dark or a blind person). ararapun to take without bargaining; to get blindly. ai bo kirarapunia ijo egoe ngol?: where did you buy such a bad cloth? were you blind when you bought such cloth? ararapun aswam: to take any job offered (good or indifferent). ararasit a waste piece; a remnant; crumbs; scrap. kotukonokis ararasia nuka emugaati: gather the breadcrumbs. araratoi to have the habit of shaking off, of shedding; to crumble off. eraratoi ekitoi akekwi: the tree sheds its leaves regularly. eraratos alup kwap: the plaster of the wall is crumbling away. araraun to let fall, drop (of fruits from tree or of tears, or spittle). to fall down, drop (fruits). araraunos araito kwap: the fruits have fallen (from the tree). ararum the back of body (of man or animal). arasaasit a bullet; a buckshot; a cartridge; a lead shot. arasai two days old millet or sorghum brew - follows ewinyiwiny (or ebibisi), precedes abeitok, then aperoi: well fermented or good beer.arasakin to start at once. korasak einer alimun akonikiro: say at once what you have to say. arasar to go right on, straight forward; to be quick. arata to do simultaneously; to do together. erataete kesi aida: they beat simultaneously. erataete einer: they talk simultaneously.arataikin to reach at the same time, supervene, coincide. arataikinos imopiiran aipany: the balls fell into the hole simultaneously. aratakin to insult one another. arataun (used with infinitive of verb) to do together, coincide. aratun to call names (once), insult, abuse (once). araun to become; to be; to be in a condition. araunos idwe ikiliok: children have become men. tetere araun(or) inyo?: so as to become what? araus to become; to be (followed by noun or pronoun), exist, be in a condition.Conjugation of araus: erai (she/he/it is); irai (you are - singular); kirai (we are); iraas (you are – plural); eraas (they are). araut to become; to be (followed by noun or pronoun), exist, be in a condition. Conjugation of araut: erai (she/he/it is); irai (you are - singular); kirai (we are); iraas (you are – plural); eraas (they are).areanar to keep pushing away or aside (as when making way through a crowd or high grass.arear to lead away; to push away, urge on or away. arebi (used with a plural object) to rob, take by force. abu nges korebi ikaboro: she/he robbed me of my belongings. arebiar to cheat and take away; to rob (of one or many). arecekek (of ground) to be muddy, slippery (after rain), clammy. arege to force; to intrude. arege akiro: to make excuses. eregeitoi: to interlope; to intrude. aregem dregs or remnants of groundnut paste. aregemem to be thin with a protruding tummy. aregerego a flour or a grain mill. areikin to allege or attribute something to someone; to impute.areit to have a dislike for; to persecute; to come to hate; to avenge, detest, or hate; to be spiteful or harsh on; to be odious. kireit ijo eong: you hate me.arem to fight (of animals); to push each other. eremos imongin: the bulls are fighting. aremerem to pierce repeatedly; to riddle (with knife or spear wounds). karemeremeto eong ikukwa: the thorns pricked me. aremetoit a puncture, hole; a spear wound; thorn wound. kitodikinai aremeto: show me the spear wounds. aremit ki-o to incite, urge on. aremo (singular noun F) a bull-fight; fencing. aremo naka imongin. aremokin1 to push into; to force to do. koremok itaok togo: push the calf into the stable. aremokin2 to spear for or somewhere; to thrust spear at. aremok eong ekingok ekokolan togo: I speared the thieving dog in the house. aremor to push away, or to push over; to upset; to exclude, propel, rebut, throw at, or to fling at; to extrude; (of spear) to hurl. aremor edeke: to offer a sacrifice to the god of calamity (in case of an epidemic, crop failure, etc). aremo ikapa akile: the cat upset the milk pot. sirikibirok ekingok amor: do not throw stones at the dog. aremot a puncture; a wound (caused by a spear or thorn).aremunun to keep pushing out one by one (of water, blood) to gush. eremununos akipi komoru: the water is gushing from the mountain. arengaanut1 redness; glow; rosiness; flush. arengaanut2 to be red, crimson.
a pet name for a red-brown cow. arengekok a superb starling (bird). arengeun to become red

to redden. arengiar to become red; to redden. arengus (singular noun F) redness; ruddiness; rosiness; flushness; blush; glow. arepenyeny to be dwarfish, short. arereng1 luck; boon; benediction; chance. kakotor eong ijo arereng: kanerokit eong ijo arereng: I wish you good luck. abolia naka arereng: gambling; gaming; luck-game. arereng naronon: bad luck; adversity; misfortune. arereng1 to be lucky, or fortunate; to be blessed. irereng ijo (irereng yesi): you are lucky. arereng arereng: by accident; by chance. arerengikin to be lucky in or with; to favour; to bring luck to. karerengikinit lolo eong ecor: I was lucky today in fishing (literally, the lake favoured me today). arerengikin adumun: to find or discover accidentally. arerengikin ibore: to take advantage of something. abu eong ketaswam arereng naepuwakatar agwelak iboro agweluna amuk: I took advantage of the sales to buy myself some shoes.. arerengonut to be always lucky, fortunate, or blessed. arerengoor to become lucky, fortunate, or blessed. areret a feather of a pelican (used as a mouthpiece of a drinking tube); a quill of a feather. arereu to be rancid; to have the smell of human urine. ares a stripe (as on cloth, animals, or shaven head); tonsure. aresia nuka akou: patches on the person’s head (natural or shaven). aresi (of baby) to yell; (of lighting, rain) to thunder; (of person) to shout in anger. ireta edou: the rain thunders. aresiait the eyebrow.aresianar to keep shouting in anger. aresiar to shout; to flare up, scream. abu ngesi koresiar nepe abuni eong: she/he flared up when I came. aretokin to hit against; to clash with; to crash on; to rattle teeth; to jar; to slam on; to collide with; to shoot with a lead shot. abu ikoku koretok ekek: the child banged the door. to knock oneself against somebody or something; to clash with. aretokinet a collision; a crash; a conflict. aretonokin to keep knocking one against another. to rattle, clash one against another; (of teeth) to rattle. aretonokinos amotokan: the motorcars collided. areun to push back (not of things); to lead this way (as of goats, cattle, etc). koreu akituk lailo: drive the cattle this way. ari general direction. aloto kesi ari nanyoin?: in what direction did they go? aloto ari nakokide: they went to the east. aria to crack, split open. arias amor: the rocks split open. ariacet a crack; a fissure; a cleave. ariak to be equal, alike, the same; to be similar (in size). iriaka iso: we are equal, alike, the same size or same age. iriakas yesi: you (plural) are equal, alike, the same. iriakas kesi: they are equal, alike, the same.kiriaka iso kajo: we and you (singular) are equal. ariakat a kind of white beads. ariako a species of grasshopper. arian1 equality (in size); flat or level; horizontal. arian2 to be equal, be alike, be the same (size). arianakin to become equal, become the same (size). erianakinos ikito ngul: those trees are of the same height; coincide. ariang a garden from where a millet crop has just been harvested; a stubble of millet crop; stumps left after reaping millet; (in Karamoja) the government (or its agencies, such as the police, the councils, etc). ariap (to be startled) very suddenly; startlingly.ariar to split once. koria akitoi ngin: split that stick or wood. ariariatoi ki-a to go about aimlessly; to wander about. ariasit a crack; a split; a rift; a fissure. aribik to be pitch black aribirib to be pitch black, shining black; (of night) to be pitch dark. aribokin (of sunlight) to become dark, dull, momentarily. ariboki akwap: it is dark, cloudy, overcast. aribokinit penumbra; darkness; gloom or shade. aribor to become dark, throw a shadow, become dull. aricakin to keep in custody for. to stick together, be inseparable friends. aricar to get hold of and take away. aricun to get hold of and bring home. arida to beat with a big thing. aridakin to squeeze or grip; to press upon; to fasten between clips; to clasp, constrict, or clamp. kikunya, kiridak ijo eong: extend, you are squeezing me. to be squeezed between, pressed, or clasped. karidaki eong ekek: the door squeezed me. aridakina ibokor okek: the fingers were squeezed in the door. aridar to squeeze into or through (narrow opening); to clasp between pincers and take away. korida epaabaka: take my little cotton with yours. to pass through a narrow opening, squeeze oneself through, infiltrate. abu eong keteleka, konye arai aridar: I won, but it was just squeezing through. aridat narrow space or passage, gate, pass (between rocks or in bushes). aridet pincers; clasp. aridi a narrow gate or passage; a corridor; a railed off passage for animals between the kraal and the grazing grounds. aridirida to be squeezed together; to crowd together; to be crowded. aridunet pincers; clasp; tong. arieba to feel pain; to feel anxious; to be aching for. arieba eong abunere nekon: I am anxious to come to see you. ariebakin to get sick, suffer pain, feel pain in. ariebakin eong akou: I have a pain in my head. ariebo (singular noun F) pain; ache; suffering; hurt; ailment; sickness; disease.ariengaki nges emuudu: the gunshot startled her/him ariengun to be startle; to be thrilled; to get a shock, get excited; to be frightened, be altogether surprised, be flabbergasted; to shudder; to be disturbed; to stand aghast. abu nges korieng nepe eduor emuudu: she/he was startled when the gun went off. arietait a crack; a split (in a pot or anything). arigirigi a one-stringed tube fiddle played to accompany a human voice; an African violin.ariikin to put crosswise, obstruct. to obstruct. iriikino ikukwa orot: thorns obstruct the road. eriikis kesi akitoi orot: they have put a wooden barrier across the road. ariim to be thin; to be slender. ariimim slimness; slenderness; skinniness. ariit a crossbeam (in a building); the milky-way (in astronomy). arikodod to be thin, wasted (after illness). irikododas itunga luedekas esilim: AIDS patients are thin or wasted. arikokin to lead for or somewhere; (of material things) to link; (of premises) to connect to power or water supply. arikokin akanin: to link arms. arikokin akim naka eipyei: to connect electricity to (a building). arikomom to be long (of body); to be tall. arikor to lead away (by the rope or hand) to go away hand-in-hand. arikosit a link; a bond; a chain. arima to go often, go frequently, or go everyday; to frequent. erimaete kesi oreka duc: they frequent my home. erimaete itunga toma aswam: people go daily to their work. arimaanut1 (singular noun F) faithfulness; dutifulness; obedience; docility; amenability; fealty; allegiance. arimaanut2 to be faithful, obedient, dutiful, amenable. arimaar to obey; to be amenable, be faithful to. erimaarit ikoku totoke: the child obeys its mother. arimaarit fidelity; obedience. arimakin to believe, obey, follow, be docile, be polite to; to take somebody's word. esabi ngol, mam irimakini akiroke: he is telling lies, do not take his word. arinyor to begin to shrivel, wrinkle, fade, wilt (from drought); to get thin. arinyo eong kanuka adeka: I am thin on account of my illness. arinyoret a wrinkle (on face or body); a crinkle (due to withering). arinyot an old potato garden or plot. ario obstacle; barrier; impediment. ariodik ki-a to bend the knee, curtsy, genuflect. ariodikikin1 a curtsy; a genuflection. ariodikikin2 to bend the knee (for); to kneel on one knee; to curtsy to genuflect. eriodikikinos itunga kokelesia: people genuflect in the cathedral.Ariokot1 (formerly) a name given to a girl-child passed through the roof to prevent its premature death (after preceding child has died). ariokot2 a species of grasshopper. ariong a peace-maker of old. kolo karionga long ago. kolo karionga, ariongitos itunga abotei; konye kwana, edakitos itunga imuudun: in the olden days, people carried their clubs about; but nowadays, people carry guns. ariongakin to carry for or on shoulder. eriongakinit ngesi ebela okeper: she/he carries a stick on her/his shoulders. to be carried on shoulder (as of a child, big enough to be carried on shoulders). arior1 to die (literally, to stretch one’s body in death). arior2 to stretch; to put straight; to straighten; to correct (a person making a mistake); to draw out. arior akiro: to settle a difficulty. arior akeje: to stretch one’s legs. arior emukeeka: to unfold a mat. korior kodai: lie down and be beaten. aripad (used with plural objective) to hammer down, beat with a big club; (of houses) to build low or flat. itunga luko Misiri eripadete itogoikec: the Egyptians build flat houses. aripaduun to make low, flat; to flatten. aripaduun akai: to build a low house (for oneself). to fall down slowly, come down slowly, be low (as of house, etc). aripakin to look at through an eye-hole; to go one behind another. aripar to accompany, follow after, or go together. eriparos kesi oiduka: they are going together to the shops.aripidid (of a man or boy) to have small buttocks and narrow hips.aripiny self-seeded groundnuts. aripirip ki-a (of the sea) to flicker, glimmer or shimmer in a dull way.aripooti a report (about class perfomance); a testimony. arira (of a fire) to burn away (without being used); to blaze away. ariri (singular noun F) a shore; a river bank; a brim; the edge; a vicinity; a place near to; the beach. ariri nak’ecor: the shore of the lake; the river bank. ariri naka akonye: near the eye. apero ariri naka akim: to sleep near the fire. aririet a splinter or chip of wood. aririp ki-o (of sky) to be overcast; to be cool.aririu2 to smell like fish or urine; to be rancid. eriri ebilaangit ekulam: the blanket smells of urine. emekenyit eriri agaria: a Mukenye fisherman smells of fish. arita a bundle; a parcel; a load; (number) thousand. aritai: thousands. aritikik to be very fat, thick and with knock-knees; to be huge and knock-kneed. iritikikos imongin ngul: those bulls are very fat and knock-kneed. aro a large uninhabited zone; wild savannah; a large wild plain. aroa to look at one another; to spoon. eroas akokoroi, apolouke epote lolo ipejok: the chickens are sizing each other, it means we shall have visitors today. aroanakin to look at oneself (in mirror or otherwise). aroanar to oversee. aroar to go to visit. arobat a woman’s laced skin-skirt; strips of leather to support the girdle; a belt.arobeikin to rob or take by force. arobi to take somebody else’s thing (along with one’s own); to cheat or hoodwink. arobiar to take away somebody’s things (as if by mistake); to take by force; to confiscate.arobiikin to rob, take away by force.aroboota a bale (of cotton, or an assortment of used clothing). arocakin to tie to to be lassoed, tied to. arocet a lasso; a rope to catch animals with. arocun to trip (an animal with a rope); to lay by the heel to be lassoed. arodakin to cheat one another; to be deceived; (of chess board pebbles) to get mixed up. arodakinos amor: the pebbles (used in the game of aile) are mixed up. arodiar to take by deceitful means; to defraud; to usurp. arodia ngesi ajakaanut: she/he has usurped power. karodi eong: I have been cheated.
(in the Teso week) Saturday.aroikin1 to examine for

to inspect for; to taste (vegetables or beer) for somebody. aroikin2 to make narrow, cause to shrink. aroikin aki: to close ears to; to turn a deaf ear to. aroikin3 to oppress; to compress; to rule firmly; to govern severely; to rule with an iron hand; to pinch. eroikit ejakait ngol iketunga: that ruler oppresses his people. to fall in (as of cheeks of old people). aroikinos ikekitinyo: she/his cheeks have fallen in. to cower. aroikinet a dictatorship; a tyranny; oppression. aroikinon a despot; a tyrant; a dictator; an oppressor. arok a gulf; a bay; a recess. arok naka acer: the milky way. arok naka akou: arok naka ereet: a receding forehead. arokoba a belt; a strap; a girdle; cincture.arokodet a species of bird. arokodod (of body) to be very thin due to sickness.arokonut to be fond or apt to acquire or contract good or bad habits. arokotot to be rough, uneven (as of bad road, skin or board, etc). arokun to adapt or copy; to derive. arokun ibore: to adapt or copy something. aromait an injury; a beaten or hurt spot; a bruise; swelling of or inflamation of the throat.aromococ to be knock-kneed. aromwait an injury; a beaten or hurt spot; a bruise.arongokin to gorge, take a bite at or in. aronianakin ki-a to be frequently bad for, not to agree with; to disagree with often. karonianakini eong emugaati: the bread nauseates me. aroniar ki-a to become bad, evil, spoiled, nasty, depraved, or deteriorated. arokiaros: they have become bad. erokiaros: they will become bad. arokiata: they have become bad. aronikin to be bad for, etc aronus1 (abstract noun F) sin; evil; badness; wickedness. aronus2 to be bad, evil, spoiled; to be wicked, or sinful. erono: she/he/it is bad, wicked, etc. irono jo: you (singular) are bad, depraved, etc. kiroko oni: we are bad, evil, etc. iroko yesi: you (plural) are bad, dirty, etc. aropetait a wage; emolument; a reward; a recompense; an award; a premium; a merit; a remuneration.aropi to elongate by adding; to join end to end. aropiar to make longer by adding; to continue from where someone else stopped. aropikin to join onto or to join for; to go together. aropior to make longer by adding; to continue from where the speaker stopped; to join; to extend. arorokanut1 greed; avarice (involving grabbing from others). arorokanut2 to be avaricious, grasping arorwai a gap; a lapse in security or defences; a passage in a fence, forest, mountains, etc.arotakin to spy for; to spy somewhere. arotongong to have a deformed brick-shaped head, with a narrow thin face. aroun to see for oneself; to find out for oneself. arowot1 an iron collar (as worn by Iteso in the past). arowot2 a calabash; a vessel made of calabash.arubakis akile: the milk is congealing.aijaanakin arubangat: to worship an idol; idolatry. arucetait a knot; a joint; a connection. arucokin to join, connect, or put (wire, rope) together; to tie (wire, rope); to knot together; to link (of chain) or join (anything); to fit. arucokiniton a coordinator; a link. arucosit a knot; a link. arudangang to be narrow-headed; to have a narrow head.arugamat a hunch-back, i.e. a deformation of the backbone.arugamo a hunch-back, i.e. a deformation of the backbone. arugut a fictitious hyena-like ogre; a child-eating ogre in Teso fables.aruikin2 to spit at or somewhere; to spout at or into. abu emun karuik eong akeimula: the snake spat its venom at me. aruja a basket for trapping fish or birds; a no-return trap or a snare made of wire mesh or withies (generally used for birds and rats); a cage for transporting birds to the market.arujakin akeje: to stand to attention. arujanut1 (of medicine on wound) astringency. arujanut2 (of embrocation) to be binding, astringent. arujuruj ki-a (of lips or buttocks) to contract or compress, become hard. arujuruj akituk: to compress lips (as in great pain). aruk a hump (on the back) as on African Zebu cattle; a hunch. arukan a whip; a leather thong. arukio to pursue; to chase. arukit a pestle or a pounding stick made from the wood of epuuton, ekungur, or ekisim. ingai ikoku eoj adepar totoke? arukit: (a riddle) what child is taller than its mother? a pestle (being longer than the mortar). arukokin to chase away for; to expel for, dismiss for to run after somebody and try to catch them. arukor to crush in a mortar. arukoria (prepositional verb) to drive away; to chase away, or to expel. korukoria ekingok: chase away the dog. arukudikin to bend up, fold up (as of back or body). arukudikin ikoku: to bend the little child (when carrying it on the back) (not used for other things).irukududas kesi: they have bent backs. arukumuikep a bird, ostrich pebble-roller. arumonor to finish one after the other; to complete one after the other; to consume one after the other; to terminate one after the other. arumor to finish, terminate, kill, consume. arumosi kesi inyamat: they have finished the food. to die; to be completed, terminated, or consumed; to expire. aruo1 a great talker; an orator. eruo ngesi tai: she/he is simply a talker and does nothing. aruo2 (singular noun F) a thunder; a sound; a boom. aruo3 to sound, make a noise; to roar, low, bellow, hoot; (of a drum) to sound, (of gun) to go off; to clack. eruo ngesi tai: she/he just talks or roars but does no harm. aruonut1 (singular noun F) sounding; thundering; lowing; roaring; growling; croaking; crowing. inyukutan lukaruok: inyukutan lueruos: vowel letters: a, e, i, o, u. aruonut2 to be sonorous, noisy, etc. aruopokok (of a receptacle, a pod, a tyre, etc) to be empty. aruopokok naka akoik: the hungry state (stomach empty); the fast (abstention from food). iruopokok eong akoik: I am hungry. iruopokok emopiira: the football is deflated. iruopokokos itunga apaarasia nuka Ailung: people are hungry during Lent.aruor to spit out. aruun: to spit this way.arupaada a catapult.arupepe a side-blown trumpet for summoning people; a bugle; a megaphone. aikut arupepe: to blow a trumpet. imulokolen luka arupepe: trumpet-blowing Christian sects who go about preaching in the street with megaphones. arupiya (formerly) a rupee (Indian money); (any) money. aruput strips of dried fatty meat.aruruak1 (singular noun F) solid fat for smearing or other external use. akile nueruruakito: congealed milk. aruruak naka ao: beeswax.aruruak2 to begin to congeal (of fat or milk). aruruakata acec nuasiepai: the fatty soup has begun to congeal. aruruaket naka akile: the cream of milk. aruruakikin (of fat or milk) to congeal. aruruk to catch up, run for something, or to try and be in time to. koruruk abaasi ekoto anyoun: catch the bus before it leaves. korurukai eong: (an SOS) come quickly to my rescue. arurukaar to go quickly; to hurry away. arurukit agiriaun isirigin luebaga nges eyaununei akangasia nuimotokan angeset naka ekaru: the drivers’ greed to rip profit during Christmas time is the cause of many car accident at the year end. arurukanut1 (singular noun F) disaster preparedness; swift-reacting; swift response. arurukanut2 to always respond swiftly. arurukikin to bring early to (before anybody). arrive early, come early. korurukikinos aitac isirigin luka aiwadikaun: pay registration fees early. arurukuun to come quickly; to come early; to hasten to come; to return in a hurry. arurut1 slipperiness; slime; grease. erurut erot: the road is slippery or smooth. arurut2 to be slippery, slimy, smooth (of anything), clever, or slick. arurutaar to become slippery, smooth or slimy. arurutikin to be slippery for. arurwak (singular noun F) lard used for smearing spear shafts; soap.arutor to uproot, throw away, eradicate (as of vice or weeds), dislodge; to stretch out (limbs). koruto iponesio lueroko: eradicate bad habits or bad manners. arutuk to beat simultaneously, hammer all together, stamp the ground simultaneously (as when making a mud floor or in a military drill). arutun to pull up, uproot, eradicate, or dislodge. aruturut akuwan to exercise the body; to take physical exercise; to have physical training. aruun1 to sound, clang (as of a bell).aruun2 to spit out. arwaar to stretch (especially of rope); to draw out, draw up (as of a line of soldiers). arwadak to go about covered with dirt. arwadakak (of anything) to be dirty, covered with dirt. arwait to be wearing across the shoulder. arwaitos kolo Iteso ibilaangin: the Iteso of the past wore blankets over their shoulders. arwarwa to crack, crackle (as of finger joints, or maize roasting in hot stove). arwatat a wall; a partition; a barrier.arwaun ikoku kotoma aperit: the child jumped up suddenly from its cot. arwetar to tear off or away; to snatch or pull away. arwetun to pull out; to get off, take off (as of a patch on wound, or handle from tool) to come off (by itself). arwopokok (of stomach, tyre, or football) to be empty. aryengun to be startled. aryengun riaka riak: to be very startled or frightened. asaajait a pack-saddle. asaanit a plate; a dish. ejaas inyamat asaanit: there is food in the plate.asaar to go along slowly; to go late alone; to go later than others unhurriedly. asaara (of people, especially children) to be well-behaved or neat; to be gentle and good. esaara akiro ngun: that issue is settled. asaara akiro kore?: is all well at home? esaara akiro ejok?: is everything ok? esaara erekon?: is everything ok at your home? esaara akuwan?: are you alright? asaasaat a palm leaf; a palm frond. asaati a blouse or a top (for women).
Naemukaaga aroet a mirror; a looking glass

the Sabbath. asabakin to tell lies about somebody; to slander or libel; to malign; to give too much (of anything) to.asabakinet a slander, defamation, misrepresentation, scandal, calumny. asaban a witchdoctor; a liar; a charlatan. asabunet a lie; slander; calumny; a draught (of water, etc); an amount of anything taken up at once. asabuuni soap. isabuuni: a little soap; a piece of soap. asabuuni nakiloset: washing soap. asabuuni nakilongis: toilet or bathing soap. atekat naka asabuuni: a bar of soap. apeelet naka asabuuni: a flake of soap. asabuuni n’akiria: powder soap.isabuunyu: a little soap; a piece of soap. asabuunyu nakiloset: washing soap. asabuunyu nakilongis: toilet or bathing soap. atekat naka asabuunyu: a bar of soap. apeelet naka asabuunyu: a flake of soap. asabuunyu n’akiria: powder soap.asacanut2 (of parents of their children, birds and their eggs) to avoid, shun, or shirk. asacar to shirk or avoid. asaduku a box; a suitcase; a coffin. asaet a nursery (for children); orphanage; a maternity home. asagarar (of hair) to be uncombed; to be rough, be bare (as of a leafless tree), be spread out (as of fingers). asakasak to stroll about; to have a walk; to take a stroll. esakasakai: she/he is strolling about. esakasakaete: they are strolling about. isakasakae: you are strolling about. asakasakae: I am strolling about.asakat a strong and nasty smell, especially of traditional tobacco. asakat naka emakole: the nasty smell of tobacco smoke. asaket a smell (good or bad). asakunun to glean or gather (what reapers left). asalabait a scab on an ulcer; an incrustation; a dried-up eye exudate. asalakin to remain over, stay behind. asalakis idwe ore: the children stayed at home (nothing remains to be done) except. asalaki do alosit ore: there is nothing left but to go home. asalanakin: asalenen: to stay away, remain behind often or always. asalang a grass, Brachiaria kotschiana. asalanut1 absenteeism; bunking off; skiving. asalanut2 to be inclined or in the habit of staying behind asalun to remain here; to come to an end; (of plan) to come to nothing, be frustrated. asamukuk to have long hair. isamukukos angor ngun akwes: those ladies have long braided hair. asangad1 (singular noun F) a dance; a prance. asangad2 to dance, or to jig. asangal the simsim stalks left in the garden after harvest.asangalal (of wasps) to be ready to sting; (of dog, cat, etc baring teeth or claws) to be ready to attack.asangan to tremble, shake with excitement; to be eager, on the alert, do greedily. esangani ikoku akuwan enyami: the child eats greedily (with the body trembling).asanget the end; the finish; the cessation; acme; conclusion; abrogation.asangir to dishevel, ruffle hair or feathers. asangirir (of hair) to be dishevelled; (of hair) to stand on end; (of hair of cat or dog when attacking) to stand up. isangiriros ajul: the fur or feathers stand on end. asangironokin (of birds) to preen feathers. asanyakak to be shabby, decrepit, ragged. asanyirir to have bristling hair (of dog or cat when afraid). asanyisany the third stomach of a cow, abomasum; (slang) the genitalia or vagina of a woman.asaot a kind of plant (with edible fruit). asapan1 (singular noun F) the initiation ceremony for adolescents and adult men to senior age groups; initiation to elderhood.asapan2 to initiate a man to a senior age group. asapatu a rubber slipper (shoe or sandal).asarab to drink noisily (as of thick hot porridge). angobun akima sarab: to drink porridge noisily. asarabaar to drink noisily; to drink something thick. sirikisarabaa akima kere: do not drink all the porridge (noisily).asaran (of fire) to glow; to smoulder; to be fiery; to be red hot. esarani akim: the fire is red hot. esaranete akonyeke bala akim: her/his/its eyes are red like a flame.asaranun to become red hot, glow, blaze up. asasam to be sour (as of vinegar). (note: it is used of eggs and meat only to mean ‘nice’). akiring na esasam noi: this meat is very nice or delicious. inyami ijo neesasam: you are alright, you get nice food. atap naesasam: millet bread cooked with sour (fermented) milk or apedur fruit. akile nuesasam: sour or fermented milk. ajon nuesasam: millet brew that has gone bad (bitter to the taste). asasamaar to turn sour. akile nu asasamaaros: this milk has gone sour. asasamunet a flavour (a sour or bitter taste). asasiai a fruit or sand-fly often sucking beer, ripe fruit, etc.asasit a bullet; a cartridge; a lead shot.asaun to come late; to come in style. asaunun akiro: to articulate issues. asaunet (singular noun F) a nice smell; a fragrance; an aroma. asear to pick and take away; to select and take away; to choose and take away.
a woman native to former Sebei (the present day Kapchorwa district)
a Sabiny woman; a word in the Sebei language. Asebei: the Sabiny women; the Kupsabiny language. asebot the top end of the spinal cord; the medulla oblongata. asedenyeny to be shallow, not deep.
women from Serere county in Soroti district
the Serere dialect of Ateso language that take ‘gw’ for ‘bw’, for example, Aseera say aigwot instead of aibwot, aigwang instead of aibwang, aigworo instead of aibworo.
a woman from Serere in Soroti district

a word from the Serere dialect of Ateso language. aseg to be clean, neat, spotless, unstained; to be holy, perfect, immaculate. asega (singular noun F) cleanliness, neatness; hygiene. asegakin ainyam to eat without having done any work.asegis (singular noun F) cleanliness; neatness; spotlessness; perfection; holiness. aseikin to choose for; to select for. koseikinai eong egoe loejok: select a strong, nice cloth for me. aseit a peg used for pegging out skins and hides to dry; a polling station, booth. asekar to pick and take out, away. asekun: to choose, pick, select. asekeny to go through the high grass. asekenyeny (of a garden, homestead, etc) to be overgrown; (of a house) to look untidy. asekenyu desolation; untidiness. asekisek to choose several times; to pick out many things; to make a choice. asekunun to pick up one after the other (like a hen or bird).aselel (of anything, especially of the skin) to be smooth. eselel emong: the skin of the bull is smooth. aselelu (singular noun F) smoothness (of skin , etc); sheen; gloss. asenesen to beat heavily many times. asenon one who deals a blow. asenyit to be thin, lean, emaciated; to be withered. aseo (singular noun F) elections; voting; sampling. aseor to stretch out, draw out, fetter, make tense, spread out to stretch oneself out. aseor aibwo: to stand at attention; to stand straight and still. (euphemism) to die.asepeo a bowler hat.asereseeti a fork (cutlery).aserun to vomit; to eject liquid. asesen to gaze at; to stare at; to watch for; to look at closely; to examine closely; to behold.asesena to look at one another; to stare at, gaze at, or behold one another. aseun to elect; to select; to choose; to pick out; to sort out, reserve; to vote. asiat a tilapia fish, Tilapia variabilis. asibilian a civilian; a woman who is not a member of the armed forces or the police force. asid a string of beads round a woman’s or baby’s waist; acid (battery acid, etc). asidak (singular noun F) dregs of beer or any dry sediment. asiepai (singular noun F) lard; fats. asigiria an ass; a female donkey; mule; a jennet; a burro. asigirikolong a burrowing viper; a stinging centipede.asigirir (of hair) to stand upright. asiigiri (singular noun F) a charcoal stove. asiikin to escape notice; to evade; to foil; to do secretly. asiiki eong ewenat: the prisoner has eluded me. asiilyanut1 filth; uncleanness; repulsiveness; dirt. inera ngesi nuka asiilyanut: she/he speaks filthy language. asiilyanut2 to be very dirty, unclean, obscene, filthy, repulsive, horrible, abominable. asiinit a rafter or stick for building roof.asiira a variety of sweet potatoes. asiiriany a vole (a small animal like a rat with a tail of a squirrel), Claviglis murinus. asiirikin ki-a to inform; to communicate. kesiirikit eong ijo ebe, abuni moi: I inform you that I shall come tomorrow. asikaat a woman’s skirt.asiles1 emptiness; desolation; loneliness; ugliness. asiles2 to be unbecoming, unseemly, displeasing to, ugly, or evil. esil eong aswam ya: that work is unbecoming to me. esil kes ener ngun: it is unbecoming of them to say such. asiles3 to be empty, lonely, deserted, desolate, solitary or uninhabited. asilikin to be lonely somewhere; to be too solitary for; to be too desolate for. kasilikinit eong ere ngol: it is too lonely for me in that home. asilipat a slipper (shoe or sandal).asima (singular noun F) face; likeness or the look; photograph; picture.. yenik’asimake: her/his double or likeness. asimasim a creeper used in rain dance. asimokok a spider; a network or a web. asinge (uncountable noun F) sand; a grain of sand; (figurative) crystal sugar.asinit nakarengan: a copper wire. asinit naka ikec: a barbed wire. asiniya a metallic or plastic tray.asiomakin to read out to or for; to backbite somewhere. asioman reading; education. asiomet a reading book; a reading, i.e. chapter and verse in the bible or scriptures. asionor to keep thumping on the back. to have constant great pain; to have colic. asior to give a heavy blow; to cause great pain; to clobber. to have great pain; to have colic. asiorotot (of anything) to be tall, long, straight, without bends. isiorotot ekitoi ngol: that tree is tall and straight. asip germinated grain destined for beer-making. asipisip asip: to drink beer ravenously. asipat unground germinated grain destined for beer-making.asipet a foundation of a building. asipet naka akwara: the spike of a spear. asipetait foundation of a house; a base on which something stands (as of candlestick). asipirit (singular noun F) methylated spirit (fuel). asipo to stand upright, straight; to rest firm; to stand up steady; to keep your balance. esipos amoti kokek: the pots are standing near the door. asipokin to erect; to set up; to establish (a home); to pitch (tent) or to put up (a house); to put on end; to set up or institute. alosi asipokin ere loitet: I am going to erect a new home to stand straight; to be erected; to calm down (as of waves); to stand up; to settle down (as of weather or anger). asiponokin atek: to stand poles in the ground. asipokina: to stay steady; to keep your balance. asipokinet a base; bottom; foundation; basement; substructure.
ainyam ekulukulu aseganut to be inclined to or fond of being neat, dainty or clean

a word from the Koran. asirikaalet a woman soldier; a female security guard; a woman sentry. ipu kwana asirikaalei da kajore: there are also many women in the armed forces nowadays.asirimim the bridge of nose; nose-bridge. asiriomom (of child's face) to be dirty. asirit a row of things or men; a line of people; a list of things. alosit asirit: to go in Indian file. asisi to get burned, get charred (of food only). asisiooto acok: the potatoes are burning. asisi akiring: the meat is getting burnt. akimai nuasisiooto: burnt millet.asisiet the remains of burnt food or anything. asisinit (collective noun F) hyperrhenia grass whose growth in a place is a favourable guide that the soil is good for crops, Hyperrhenia filipendula. asisit a peg used for drying skins or hides.asisiun (of a boy or girl) to reach manhood or womanhood; (of a person or animal) to give out the odour or smell akin to a billy goat; to smell like cotton aphids or greenfly. asitaani a devil; an evil thing or person. asitaapu a postage stamp; a seal, engraving or ink stamp. asitoopu a kerosene stove. asiun to come stealthily; to escape this way. asiun ebong: to come secretly in the evening. aso have it; now then; well then; get on with it; come on. aso kolot: hey, go. aso konye: there you are! asoaso-aswam a bird (believed to sing the words meaning, ‘get on with your work’, when it sees people standing idle in the garden), a Red-crested cuckoo. asodit to be first; to initiate; to originate something. asodokin to start for; to show somebody how to do something. asodore to start; to do first. esodete moi kace atemar ebe mam eong akoto kes: they might in future say that I don’t like them. asog to swagger; to swank, bluster, boast noisily. esoga ngesi ebe ebarit ere kec: she/he swanks that their family is well off . esogas itelepai ngul: those boys are swaggering. asogakin to swagger somewhere, or in presence of; to swank in the presence of or somewhere; to boast to or somewhere. asogakin do je ebe egogong kanupe ebungaa ikoku: he now swaggers that he is strong after beating a child. asoganut1 vanity; pride; swaggering; bluster; in-fashion. asoganut2 to be inclined to pride, vanity; to swagger; to be inclined to bluster; to be inclined to swank asogimim to be awe-inspiring, grisly; to be dreadful, horrifying, repulsive, terrifying, fearsome. akirot naisogimim: a wonderful story; something wonderful.asogol1 a roundabout way; detour; circuit; a story; a legend. awomaar asogol: to go or do in a roundabout way. abu ngesi kowomik asogol elosi oduka: she/he went to the shops in a roundabout way. awomaar einer: awomikin einer: to tell in a roundabout way; to beat about the bush. asogol2 (of horns, teeth, or anything) to be protruding, projecting; to talk in a circumlocutory manner or beat about the bush. asogolol (of anything) to be protruding or projecting. asogomior to grow or become ugly. asogomom (of a person) to be awkwardly tall and thin. asogoror to be awkward, unhandy, clumsy, cumbersome, ungraceful. isogoror etelepat ngol engoi atap: that boy is ungraceful in mingling millet bread. asogot a corruption of amusogot: a phoenix palm, Phoenix reclinata. asokodod (of stick, beak, nose, etc) to be hooked, curved or bent; to have the back of the head protruding. isokodod ekabela: my walking stick is bent or hooked at the head. asokosit a sock (a fabric covering the foot and ankle, worn inside the shoe). asola to pull out things secretly. asolaun1 to pull out of a hiding place. asolaun2 to come out of hiding, bush suddenly and try to escape. asolit (archaic) ammunition; a bullet.asomakin to jump at; to jump on; to bounce on or to. asoman1 (archaic) reading; education. asoman2 ki-a (archaic) to read.asomar to jump away; to bounce away. asomeroit a school girl; a student; a school-goer. asomet (formerly) a discotheque.asongol to pretend to; to talk in vain; to travel for nothing; to go or do in vain. asongolaar to feign; to pretend. asongolaar ngesi apero, ebala ebe edeka: she/he went to bed, pretending to be sick. asonya1 of very long ago; during ancient times. kolo kasonya: once upon a time; very long ago; in the olden days. asonya2 very long ago; ancient times. asonyok a tail of sheep; (jocular) the behind; the buttocks. asoogot a deep pit; an abyss; a deep valley; a deep hole. asoorian1 (singular noun F) submission; surprise; sulkiness. asoorian2 to look subdued; to look gloomy, shocked; to sulk. esoorianete idwe kiretakin: children are sulky when reprimanded.asoridid1 (singular noun F) dirt; obscenity; filth; squalor. asoridid2 (of anything) to be dirty or filthy. asorony large intestine; colon.asot a word of admiration or praise, ‘nice fellow’, ‘good fellow’. abu asot ya: there she comes (used for anything). asoto a roof of a granary; a hood; an umbrella; a hat; a cupola. asuat an iron bar; a metal bar; an iron ornament; a bracelet; an anklet. asubakin to make or create for; to displace; to sacrifice to; to mould or form for; to finish off; to give the finishing touch to; to immolate. to shift (a setting, standing) once; to move once; to be displaced. sirikisubakin!: do not move! (as when taking a photo or being put at gunpoint). kosubak epelukon: finish off your task. asubanakin to worship, sacrifice to; to keep creating; to make often for (as of pots); to sacrifice often. esubanakini ngesi eong amoti: she/he makes pots for me. Edeke Lokasuban esubanakini oni inyamat: God the Creator provides food for us. to keep shifting from one to the other; to turn oneself about; to keep moving about (when sitting or lying or standing). asubanit the ceremonial throwing away of the vigil ashes after the death of a person (- it marks the end of the formal mourning and it is the time when the property of the deceased is allocated); a funeral rite; a ritual; a sacrificial victim; a sacrificial ceremony. asubakin asuban: to offer sacrifice. asubanit naka emisa: the sacrament of Mass. asubia (prepositional verb infinitive) to create with; to make (pots) with. ekoto ngesi elupe asubia amoti: she/he wants clay to make pots. elupe ngesi esubere amoti: clay is used to make pots. asubun to make for oneself; to create, mould, form for oneself. asubunet nature; creation; instinct. asudenyeny to be small or dwarfed. asudokin to add to; to mix with. kosudok emaido odia: mix the groundnuts paste in the vegetables. asudonokin to be adding to; to go on mixing. asueny to walk away proudly and slowly; to swank. asuenyikin (of a short person) to walk away with short and fast paces; to swank. asujak ki-a to eat leafy vegetables without salt or groundnut paste; to eat boiled ecomai leaves before they are pounded; to chew emairungi leaves. asuketait a fold; a crease; a knee joint or elbow joint. asukitoit a grass, Eragrostis turgida. asukokin1 to bend up; to warp; to fold up, or crumple. asukokin akungin: to draw up the knees. asukokin asoto: to close an umbrella. asukokin epateit: to have cramps from sitting with drawn legs. asukokin angajep: to trip somebody in words. asukokinos amunyin: the skin is wrinkled. asukokin: to bend for, fold for. asukokin akan: to fold one’s sleeves. asukokin ebokorit: to bend finger; to crook the index finger (as a sign of contempt). asukokin akeje: to sit with drawn legs asukokin2 to wince, cringe, flinch, or recoil. asukonor to lope; to gallop or leap. asukor to scurry; to rush away; to dash off. asukor akeje: to draw up legs. asukusuk1 a wood wind instrument in the trumpet family (made of a long hollow stick ending in a hollowed gourd to provide a baritone like the sound of esukusuk to the sound created by the vibrations of the lips of the blower), used in ajosi dance. asukusuk2 to crease; to rumple; to crinkle. asulaj to have a beard; to wear a beard; to be hairy (of a man or anything). asulajaj to be hairy (as of beard); to be bushy, overgrown; to be full of weeds.asulyany (singular noun F) a blessing; good luck; benediction; prosperity; good fortune; boon. akipi nuka asulyany: holy (blessed) water. ainakin asulyany: to give a blessing to; to bless. asulyanyanut1 (singular noun F) luck; blessedness; fortune; beatitude. asulyanyanut2 to be lucky; to be blessed, fortunate, prosperous.asumet (singular noun F) bone marrow. asupaada a catapult.asupaanut2 to be medium-sized. asuponut1 a dog’s cleverness in tracking people or game through smell. asuponut2 (of dog) to be a good tracker asupor (of dog) to smell out, or find out. asupun (of a dog) to follow its own track; to scent, trace, or track down. esupuni ekingok ekelos: the dog scents its own track or follows its own track. asuretait a bamboo leaf, stick or pole. asuritomei a grey plantain-eater, (a bird believed to scatter elephants by its honks). asurokin to attack; to assault, or to fall upon unexpectedly; to ambush, maraud, or assail. asurokinet an aggression; an assault; an attack. asuror to scatter, disperse. asuroros idwe: the children have dispersed. asurubeeti a music band or troupe. asurup enmity; hostility; feud; animosity. ejai oni asurup: kirai oni lukasurup: we are enemies. asusujai rubbish; trash. asutor to claim and take away. abunit eong asutor emong kaujo kon: I have come to claim and take a bull from your kraal. asutukees a suitcase; a trunk. asutun (of many) to come to the rescue of; to come in a crowd (to demand something). kosututu: kopotu: come here (plural). asuuka a shawl; a bedsheet. asuulyany a nightjar (a bird believed to bring good luck to the beholder); a goat-sucker.
apolisit asirimait a stalk of maize, sugarcane or sorghum

Kiswahili language; a Swahili woman; a Swahili word. aswalar to give a painful blow; to refuse (as a reprisal); to give a painful feeling; to smart; to be attracted (by love); to fascinate, charm, infatuate. abu apese koswala etelepat etau: the girl fascinated (attracted) the boy. aswalun to make nice and tasty sauce from vegetables (especially emalakany or eboo or anything); to draw a beautiful picture or portrait; to get a clear snap or photograph. aswam1 acts; actions; conduct; deed; performance. Aswam (in the Teso week) Monday.aswam3 ki-a to work; to act; to labour to do; to make, fabricate, fashion, or form. eswama ngesi nen tir: she/he has worked there all day. educoki ngol epelu ke: that man has persisted on his task on a daily basis. iswamai: working; in action. mam iswamai: not working; out of action.
Naebalaasa aswam2 work; business; task; duty; use; occupation; employment; job; office; action
Acts (of the Apostles) – a book in the Bible. aswamisioit a deed

an accomplishment; a feat. aswarajikin to put a dirty thing somewhere. aswarun1 to come or run out in numbers or swarms. aswarun2 to cause to run out in swarms.asweenyeny to be small in stature; (of person) to be short, dwarfed. aswei a kind of anthill on which small edible mushrooms, called eswei, grow. aswetun to cut a small piece for oneself. aswongolol (of clothes) not to fit. asworony the large intestine (of a person or animals); the colon. amoeteka nuapolok: the colon asyanikin to be kind, generous, liberal, hospitable, merciful to. asyanus (singular noun F) kindness; generosity; liberality; mercifulness. asyanut1 to be kind, generous, liberal, hospitable, or merciful.asyarasiara crumbs; remnants; little bits. -at suffix denoting zeal, expertise in, dexterity at, ingenuity in doing something. ekeswamat : a zealous worker; workaholic. ekadanyat : a mass killer, murderer. -ata suffix of 2nd and 3rd person plural in past and imperative and subject persons. kiswamaata : work! konyamata!: eat! kibungaata!: beat her/him/it! ataaba an underground rock; base rock. ataadalo an open air wooden or metallic (plate) rack for drying utensils in the sun. ataagi a water or oil tank; a big metallic or plastic water reservoir. ataagoroit a root of tree; taproot. ataakit a young female animal; a heifer.ataamu a division of the school or academic year; a semester; a school term. ataan to shout; to howl; to roar; to cry out; to bewail; to din. etaanete idwe ke: her/his children are shouting. ataanikin to shout at or for; to cry out to or somewhere; to mourn for. ataayi a cravat; a necktie; a neckerchief. atabalait a large-mouthed earthenware pot for water or for vegetables. atabo a small cooking pot, more bowl-like in shape, mainly used for vegetables.atabok a piece of broken pot; a potsherd; a shard. atabonyony (of a person) to have small buttocks. atacakin to pay to or for; to reward for; to expiate for; to refund for; to remunerate; to dance for or somewhere; to reimburse. atacanar to pay all debts;
