to pay everybody. adau ngesi atacanar apeseninike: she/he has finished paying her/his debts. atacaret a paying off (of monies, debts, etc); instalment (part-payment). atacit a trap for big animals, consisting of a hole dug in the game track, a ring of etirir thorns over the hole and a rope tied on a log, with the noose of the rope over the thorns. atado a small bowl for food; a can.atagoroit a root (of a tree or anything).atai (to do something) in vain; for nothing; gratis; banal.atakan clarity; aspect; visibility. atakan to appear; to be seen; to be prominent or clear; to be visible. etakani noi: conspicuous. etoil mam etakani: a wraith or ghost is invisible. atakanikin to come in sight; appear to. atakanikinet an appearance; an apparition; a sight; a vision; an occurrence.atakar1 (of animals) to gallop; to run or buck; to race; to jump with all four feet; to canter. atakar2 to break down (a house); to chip. atakar3 (of body) to peel off; to take off; to copy; to blister (of wound) to break open; (of enamel off plate) to come off or peel off; to come off (as patch from rubber tube or tyre). atakarikin to jump away from (as in play); to run away (as of cow from bull). atakasit a blister. atakatak to copy often or many times; to beat on ears; to keep copying; to take off (something fixed). ataker a canoe; a boat; a craft; a launch; a big wooden trough for watering cattle.atakorit mucous dysentery (of man or animal); faecal slime. atakun to pull off; to tear off; to take off; to break down by oneself (of house). atakun akiro: to copy words or text. atakunet a copy; a duplicate; a photocopy.atakwa a large, tall cooking pot with wide opening and used for cooking atap; a basin.atalanta (singular noun F) talent; a special or innate skill, aptitude or ability, especially for art, music, etc; expertise. ataliiba a crowbar; a pick axe. atamakin to try for a short time; to test for a short time. to try each other; to fight each other; to dare each other; to wrestle.atamakinet an experiment; a test; a trial; an examination. atamit to be trying; to endeavour; I am a bit okay (in reply to a greeting, ‘ijai biai?’). atan a water or oil well; a stream; a waterhole. alosit atan: to go to well; to go for water at the well. atanu (singular noun F) a heap of bricks arranged for firing (burning). ainapakin atanu: to pile up raw bricks for burning. atanya earthen ware; crockery; vessels. ataok a heifer; a female calf.atap cooked millet meal.atapakin to dab on; to infect; to dip lightly into; to touch lightly; to mop up. atapakin edeke: to infect with disease (through contact). atapakin akiro: to get someone into trouble. atapakinet infection (process); a light-touch; a dab or light dip. atapar1 a pond; a water reservoir; a drinking place (for livestock); a dam. atapar2 to become plentiful; to abound.ataparac the early morning (before 11:00am).atapen the smaller of the two grinding stones (held in hand by women when grinding).atapeng a guinea fowl (a wild hen). atapikin to be common to; to be plentiful; to be seen commonly. atapikitos eong ipejok: I get visitors often (the visitors frequent my place). atapikis ikapa imirio: the cat gets plenty of rats (literally, rats are plentiful for the cat). atapit to be common, ordinary, usual, or banal. etapit ngesi asalenen ore: she/he usually stays at home; atapon leprosy; a severe skin and nervous disease which can be passed from one person to another, and which causes serious and permanent damage to the body, including loss of fingers, limbs, etc affected.etapunit ngesi atapon: she/he has contracted leprosy. atar deep waters; the deep part of a dam or swimming pool. atarion to be fatty and juicy (of meat); to be greasy (of anything). atarionor to become fat, juicy, or greasy. akiring naetaryono: akiring nacokom: fatty or juicy meat (not lean meat). atarukot a vulture, Neophron percnopterus (a scavenging bird of prey). ikoloror akou kon bala naka atarukot: you are as bald as a vulture. kolimokinai ikabore ‘akongu Kenya’? atarukot: (a riddle) what is it that sees as far as Kenya? A vulture (because it can detect a dead prey thousands of kilometres away!)atata to forge iron; to shape metal. ekatatan etatai isiman: the smith forges the little bells (strapped on legs for dancing). atataet smithy; a forge.atatas the hammer and the anvil. atatinyo the inside of heel, i.e. the soft section.etau loka akeju: the instep or the insole. ataulo a towel. ataulo nakilongis: a bath towel. ataulo naka akan: a hand towel. ataulo naka ereet: a face towel. ataulo naka asaanin: a plate towel. ataus to be (attributive) ata: I am; ita: you are (singular); eta: she/he/it is; kita: we are; itaas: you are (plural); etaas: they are. ataus ba: to be hard. ataus ti: to be silent or invincible; to be very heavy. ataus ci: to be cold. ataus do: to be nice or sweet. ataus du: to be very red or crimson. ataus kia: to be white or ashen. ataus lyo: to be deserted or empty. ataus ria: be bitter or sour. ataus pe: to be hot. ataus tul: to be pungent, rank or smelly. etaas doo do: they are very sweet, tasty or delicious. atear ki-a a corruption of atemar (to say; to speak). atedokin to make marks or incisions on. atedokin ekia akuwan: to incise a part of the body and put an embrocation. atedun to make a cut in for oneself; to cut off for oneself. atedun akiro: to pronounce distinctly; to utter once but clearly. ateele (formerly) a piece of skin dress worn by women, just to cover the pubic area (while the rest of the body would be naked). ategerioit a door post; a doorframe; a pillar; a main support; a mainstay; a jamb. atego a clap trap.ategum to walk with a big fat stomach. etegumete ijaka ngul kedautu aiju ajon: those gentlemen walk away with their distended bellies after quaffing a lot of booze. ategumum (of a person or an animal) to have a big stomach. ateikin to carry loose on the head without holding; to poise; to balance a load on the head. eteikinit aberu akemot: the woman carries her pot on her head without holding it. atek bars (of soap); balks; timber; tie-beams of a roof. atek nuka asabuuni: akito nuka asabuuni: bars of soap. atekat a bar; balk; timber; a pole for building. atekat naka asabuuni: akitoi naka asabuuni: a bar of soap. ateker a clan; a family (from common ancestor); a generation; a tribe.
a name of a Teso clan.atelepanut1 boyhood

adolescence; youth. atelepanut2 ki-a to be young or adolescent. atelor to go away by oneself and forget something behind; to travel by oneself. atelun1 to have one child only; to count one by one; to bring one only (instead of many of anything). etelunit akweny abeet: the bird laid only one egg. atelun2 to come alone; to come by oneself. atemar to say; to speak; to mean or suggest; to speak out. ngesi atemar ai?: what does it mean or imply? atemasi kesi ai?: what did they say?; what have they said? ngesi atemar ebe: that is to say…. atemel (of a person) to have a good figure or body shape; to have a nice figure; to be pretty, comely, elegant. atemele a woman with a good figure or body shape; the pretty, comely, or elegant one; a beauty queen. atemelel1 (singular noun F) good-looking; faultlessness; perfection. atemelel2 to be well-proportioned in build; to be good-looking; to be handsome; to be erect, beautiful, pretty, or a beau. atemonon a mother nursing her newly-born baby; a confined woman (after childbirth); an ayah (a wet nurse).atenak times; days. abu eong kaper ngina atenak aare: I slept there two nights (or twice). atenit to be steady; to be straight. etenit ekitoi: the tree is straight. etenit ere ke: her/his home is steady (peaceful). atenu a branch (of a tree or an organisation); a bough. atenus a drum (musical instrument); a dance to the sound of drums. airam atenus: to beat the drum; to hold a dance. ananganang atenus: to beat the drum (with the hand).atenyar (with a singular or plural object) (of anything) to touch a sore or wound (so that it hurts) to hurt; to be touched and ache. atepakin to rain on; to fall on (of rain) to rain somewhere. atepaki edou ikaraan: it rained on my crops. etepakit itunganan edou: it has rained on somebody, i.e. somebody is tipsy or drunk. atepetepet a wild duck.atepor to go at once. kotepor: go at once.atepurait a typewriter; a keyboard of a computer. ateran a bride.aterar to stretch out; (of umbrella) to open, spread out; to deploy. aterar akanin: to stretch out arms. atere to tell openly; to tell in the face; to confess openly, boldly. atereikin to tell somebody openly in the face; to come face to face; to be challenged. atereikinet a challenge; an obstacle. atereun1 akiro to speak out; to confess openly. atereunit eong alimun nukabeit: I have confessed the truth. atereun2 (of someone or something that should be in hiding) to come openly; to walk openly towards speaker. aterit a penis; a phallus.aterot (singular noun F) cold; chill; fresh air; cold wind. ketingit eong aterot: I feel cold or chilly. ededeng aterot: it (the weather) is very cold. akoto adumun aterot: I want fresh air. ejai aterot: epol aterot: it is cold. ebisi aterot: it is very cold.aterun to stretch out this way. aterun auno: to stretch out rope (this way). ates a grave; a corpse (in the grave); a tomb. atese to break brittle things. atesear to break (as of glass, egg or small brittle things). ateseikin to break (glass and the like) somewhere. ngai bo keteseikini asaanit ne?: who broke this plate here? atesek to be brittle or crisp, frail, fragile, breakable. atesin a graveyard; a cemetery. alosi eong atesin: I'm going to the graveyard or cemetery.
Ikatekok atela the only child (produced by a particular woman)
the language of the Iteso people

the women from Teso; the vocabulary or words in the language of Iteso. kalimonoki lolo je eong Ateso: he told me off; he used hard words on me. Ateso Atororo the dialect of Ateso language spoken by Iteso from Tororo and Kenya, characterised by the heavy use of letter k in verbs and nouns with prefixes ai- or ei-. aipany: a hole, becomes akipany. eicolong: a chair, becomes ekicolong. ainyam: to eat, becomes akinyam.

a Teso word. ateten the right (not left). akan nakoteten : the right hand. akediany: lefthand. atetiot metal rings or clips on ears, lips, nose or tongue; a brooch, ear-pin. ateyaar (of solids or crystals) to dissolve or disperse. ateyaar esukaali kakipi: the sugar has dissolved in water. ati big; important; whole; complete; large; huge; enormous. aberu ati: a huge woman. amoni ati: a large bush. apungurei nutiok: big logs.atiar to say (used before reported speech). ngesi atiar: that means; that is to say. etiarete kesi ai?: what will they say? atiasi kesi nen: they have said so/thus.atiaus to amount to (quantitatively – i.e. volume or level); to be so (in shape, quantity). etia: she/he/it is this/that much. etiaas: they are that/this much. etia ngesi ai?: how big is she/he/it? etia nen: she/he/it is so big, so much. etiaas nen: they are so big; there are so many. (note: for quality, use araus).atibar (of a fat person) to walk with a heavy stride. atibara a fat big woman (literally, a big shit). atibiba nakokwap bedrock; basement; substructure. atibo a food bowl or a dish made of clay.atibok naka amot: a potsherd.atibolok a potsherd; the remains of a broken pot, gourd or calabash. atibong evening; dusk; nightfall; sundown.atibonga the evenings. atica a school teacher; a tutor; a lecturer.atidok a piece of broken earthenware pot; a potsherd.atigo a vegetable plant whose leaves are used to give slipperiness to eboo sauce, Corchorus trilocularis. atiiba a jutting granite rock (a physical feature).atikat a quagmire; a swamp; a mire; a fen; a bog; a marshland; a morass. atiket a crossbar (used for barring doors or windows). atiketait a delay; a hindrance; an obstruction.atikijij to have abnormally fat cheeks.atikir to gallop; to jump for joy; (of cattle) to stampede. apotu akituk kotikiroto: the cattle stampeded. atikisimu (singular noun F) catechism (a book or a series of questions and answers about Christianity, used to instruct confirmation candidates).atikokin1 any traditional ceremony held to bless new property. atikokin akinyet : a traditional fertility and initiation ceremony where a newly married woman spends a night with her husband without bathing off the ghee and esas shavings she was smeared with on her introduction. atikokin2 to hold down; to press down; to curb. atikokin etau: to hold one’s heart (wants and desires). atikokin eiyengane: to hold one’s breath. atikokin etogo: (of a man) to initiate a newly built house by spending a night with a woman in it. atikokin ekirakira: (by two groups of leap-dancers) to stop the dance with one thunderous throb of the feet hitting the ground. atikokinet an obstruction; a delay; a hindrance; a dissuasion; a rebuff; a ban. atikonut1 (singular noun F) continence (control over one’s appetites and passions, or over one’s bowels and bladder); decency. atikonut2 to have self-control over one’s appetites and passions; to have the ability to control one’s bowels and bladder. atikor to push over by knocking against; to overpower; to jostle; to overwhelm; to overthrow. sirikitiko ekitwi: don’t run into the bush in fear. atikum a rubber stamp.atikun to fall or collapse this way. atilas (of a fat person) to walk or move about naked; to walk with nothing around the waist. atilasas (of a fat person) to be naked; to be nude; to have nothing round the waist. atilo a plant from which salt is extracted, Hygrophila spinosa; a traditional salt. atilon (singular noun F) an abyss; a depth. atingatinga a tractor (especially a farm tractor or a road grader); a bulldozer.atinot an ear of grain; a small head of millet. ationikin to be hard or difficult for; to be awkward or arduous for. ationis a difficulty; an awkwardness; arduousness; a mystery; a drawback; a hardship.ationoor to become difficult, hard, or not easy; to become awkward; to become arduous. ationore to be fully grown; to become ripe; to be ready for use; to be hard; to mature. atyoko acok: the potatoes are mature. atyono emaido: the groundnuts are mature. atyoko ikoku akojo: the child’s bones have become hard (are mature, fully grown). ationus a difficulty; an awkwardness; arduousness; a mystery; a drawback; a hardship.atipei a plant, Emilia sagittata. atipet1 once; at once; forthwith; in a flash; immediately; suddenly; presently; very quickly. atipet noi: very soon; immediately; at once; quickly, etc atipet2 a bead.atiraja a plant from which salt is extracted, Ageratum conyzoides. atirikiki an antelope, Klipspringer oreotragus. atirit a penis (generally).atirokin to touch, feel, finger for to touch one another. atiron speed of racing; swiftness atironor to become fast or speedy; to run fast; to run quickly. atiror to touch once; to affect; to feel; to handle; to finger. sirikitiro nges: don’t touch her/him/it. atiroret (singular noun F) a touch; contact; a feel. atisaar ki-a to melt. to dissolve. atitai (to do) in vain; gratis; free; for nothing; without reason.atitibat a heel (the back of the foot).atiting1 (singular noun F) courage; boldness; bravery; endurance; intrepidity. ainakin atiting: to embolden. atiting2 to dare; to brave; to challenge; to defy to be impervious; to pain; to hold out; to be long suffering; to be brave. atitingikin to endure for; to bear with; to suffer on; to hold out; to hold on; to dare. atitingoor to endure; to persevere; to be brave. atitingoor ngesi: she/he has endured, persevered, or stuck to it. atitiny (singular noun F) a corruption of atiting: courage; bravery; endurance; intrepidity. atitinyikin a corruption of atitingikin: to endure for; to bear with; to suffer on; to hold out; to hold on; to dare. atitipu an anthill; a heap. (slang) a big woman who just lies in bed without taking part in intercourse. toto katitipu: a queen ant. atitir to be insipid, bland, flat, or tasteless; to satiate; sweet like sugar. atitirikin to become too sweet for; to pall on; to become insipid to. katitiriki eong emaido: groundnuts have become bland or tasteless to me. atitot a calabash or pot for straining or extracting salt from ashes of burnt plants; a salt filter. atiya to break down; to pull down; to kill (a big man or animal); to cause to crumble; to break to pieces (as of house, anthill, etc); to destroy; to collapse. to fall down; to crumble away; to fall to pieces; to collapse. atiyaar to pull down (wall or house); to demolish. akoto atiyaar ekatogo: I want to break down my house. abu edeke kotiyaa ekamong: rinderpest killed my bull. atiyakin to break down for. kotiyak ekonitogo: break down your house to fall down; to fall in (of house); to collapse; to sink down or in. atiyanakin to collapse repetitively; to crumble. atiyatiyaun to crumble away entirely; to fall to pieces; to disintegrate; to fall to bits; to crumble to powder; to be dilapidated; to moulder. atiyaun to pull down (wall or house) to fall down. atoba a heifer.atodonor (of a bird) to keep pecking and taking away. atodor (of a bird) to peck once and take away something. atodotod (of birds) to keep pecking. atodunun (of birds) to keep pecking. atoet a natural gap between upper centre incisor teeth.atokit to have hemmed; to finish off; to put finishing touches to. itokit ijo emukeeka?: have you hemmed the mat? atokitoit a hem; a rim (of basket or granary); the edge (of a basket, blanket, mat, etc). atokosit a hem; a rim; a braid; an edge (as of basket, blanket, or mat, etc). atola to shed tears in torrents. atola akiyo: to shed tears in big drops; to weep incessantly.atolong the simsim chaff after threshing.atom (in Karamoja) a rifle; a gun.aton (from fear or cold) to cringe; to truckle (to submit or give in passively or weakly); to slouch. etonos ipakasin kaneejai ejakait: the workmen cringe in front of their employer. atongolol to be handsome, beautiful; to be nice-looking. itongololos kesi: they are handsome or nice-looking (of anything).atongora a plant, Honekenya ficifolia. atonokin to be humble; to be self-effacing; to cringe; to crouch with servility; to fawn; to be devoted to. atoogan to complain; to grumble; atoot a big ditch or gutter between two riverbanks; a passage between rocks or tors. atoris a head band; a ribbon round the head; a head ornament of beads.aitosom atorob adumunia ibore: to use force to obtain something. atorokin to tie a band round head, waist, etc; to gird. kotorok egoe kon karokoba: tie your clothes with a belt to gird oneself; to be tied round; to gird. atorom a trunk of tree; a bole of tree; the trunk or torso (of a person). atosa to enjoy something tasty, nice and juicy (of anything); to munch or crunch. atosai eong emaido loiwowatai kamuunyu: I am enjoying the taste of groundnuts fried with salt. atosatosa to keep enjoying; to enjoy always (something soft and nice); to eat something nice and soft; to pluck nice and soft vegetables. etosatosaete idwe eitola: the children are enjoying sugarcane. atosatosai eong akiring na: I enjoy this nice tender meat. atotoet a white-breasted stork (bird), Abdim's stork. atotol nukamor coal. atotolet1 charcoal; coal; embers; cinders; dry cells or battery. atotolet2 (singular noun F, slang) a guy; a buster (a form of greeting or praise for a man or boy). atuba a rough wooden dish; a manger; a trough. atubarar (of person) to be maimed or crippled; (of body) to be mutilated; (of limb) to be without toes or fingers. atubetait a cut; a portion; a fragment; a share. atubokin to cut or judge for. atubokin akiro: to give judgement on; to give a sharp reprimand; to tell off; to adjudge. atubokin egelit: to impose a fine. atubokin aitisilaario: to condemn to or give punishment. atubokin akile: (of the milker) to stop milking (leaving the remainder - called esurup - for the calf). atubokinio akiro: a conviction; to be found guilty of wrongdoing or crime. atubokin atwanare: to sentence to death; to put on death row. atubokin awenio amaisa: to sentence to life imprisonment. atubon a judge; an arbiter; a cutter; a referee; an umpire; a magistrate; a butcher. atubon akituk: a butcher of cows. atubon imusaagon: a court judge. atubonokin to cut (meat) for many; to cut into many pieces for; to cut short or out repeatedly (as when milking or pouring out again and again). atubor1 to pass by; to go across; to take a shortcut; to go past. atuboros akiro: that is a thing of the past; that is past. ketuboros apaarasia nuipu: (in narratives) after many days. atubor kojokan: to fare well. kotubor kojokan: farewell! atubor erono: to fare badly. atubor2 to cut off. atubor atenu: to cut off a branch atubor akou: to behead. atubor akan arai akeju: to amputate the arm or the leg. atubosit a cut; a rip; a cleft; a dissection. atubun to cut this way; to cut for oneself to come this way; to cut across this way; to arrive (as of unexpected visitors); to drop in. atubutub to cut up into pieces; to divide; to analyse. atubutubonokin to apportion; to cut into pieces and put into (as tomatoes into sauce). atudakin to plant in little groups here and there. kotudak akimai: make or plant a small plot of millet. atudek to dance, prancing like a hare; to jump about; to caper; to jig.atudo a female duck; a goose.itujomomos itelepai: the boys have not bathed (they have dirty bodies). atukalaar to go with fat cheeks like one with yaws. atukalal to have broad cheeks; to have protruding cheeks. itukalal ngesi: she/he is broad-cheeked or puff cheeked. atukalikin to go about with puffed, round, or protruding cheeks. atukalun to come with fat cheeks. atukaret a draught (of liquid); a gulp; a mouthful of liquid. atukit to keep or hold liquids or solids in the mouth. atukituk any big machine that is run by an engine.atukokin to gather together somewhere; to collect for; to heap up; to assemble together somewhere; to compose; to amass to gather; to assemble; to congregate; to crowd together; to come together; to cluster; to conglomerate. atukokinos itunga: many people have come together. atukonokin to accumulate; (of certain Christian sects) to assemble for seasonal prayers. atukos a place of assembly or meeting or crowding together; a classroom. Atukot1 (in the Teso week) Thursday.atukot naka anya: a heap or sheaf of grass. atukucel a hamerkop (bird). atukunyu a civet cat, Civettictis civetta.atukurur to be small and short in stature; to be stumpy; to be short (in height). Atular1 (singular noun F) sudden death; anthrax (in cattle). atular2 to kill suddenly by poison; to murder suddenly; to poison; to bewitch; to be fatal to. etularit nges atwanare: she/he died a sudden death to die suddenly (by poison); to be poisoned; to be bewitched; to go bad; to wither. ailel nakikoto atular: ecstasy. atulerer (of eyes) to bulge; to be staring (of eyes). itulereras nges akonye: her/his eyes bulge. itulerer ngesi: she/he has bulging eyes. atumaanakin to disobey; to be obstinate to. atumaanut1 obstinacy; disobedience; unwillingness; stubbornness. atumaanut2 to be contumacious or contumely; to be presumptuous, conceited, or arrogant; to be disobedient, stubborn, obstinate, or unwilling atumes (singular noun F) fatness; corpulence; thickness; obesity; heaviness. atumit to have gained weight; to be obese; to be fat. etumit nges akeju: she/he has fat legs (elephantiasis of the legs is implied). atumun1 puberty; adolescence. atumun2 to develop at puberty; to become stout; to become fat. atumunan a young girl or boy of 14–16 years; an adolescent. atun a bundle of grain; a package; a parcel (of anything); ten. atunakin to embrace (somewhere); to hold; to put hands or arms round (something). atunaki toto ikekoku atorob: the mother pressed her child to her bosom. etuni ikoku totoke: the child embraces its mother. atunu a bundle; a packet; a parcel. atunuru the woodwork of a house roof; principles of roofing; roof timbers; frame of roof; a cupola.atunyany rough furrows; roughly cultivated field. atunyeny rubbish from vegetation. atunyuru roof timbers of a house; wooden roof-work; a dome.atunyurur to be blunt and rounded. itunyurur akwap: the world is round like a ball (implying that fortunes in the world keep changing, and thus the lucky ones today can become unlucky tomorrow). atupakin to follow somebody; to come or go after; to succeed (as leader or ruler). atupakin akiro: to obey. atupakinit: to emulate. etupakini: next; following that; after that. atupar to go and follow after. atupit to emulate; to follow. atupit acoa ka: to emulate me. atupit itunganan arai ibore: to be after or follow someone or something; to hunt or want someone or something. atupiton a follower; a disciple; an apostle; a recruit; a partisan; a proselyte; a pupil; a believer. atupun to follow after (this way); to arrive after. atupuruc (singular noun F) the morning; dawn; sunrise; daybreak. atur1 an age-set; a generation; one's age mates. atur2 a plumage; a feather-ornament. aturasas1 to have fat buttocks. aturasas2 (singular noun F) fatness (of buttocks). aturiaar to go to a place accidentally or by chance. aturiaikin to encounter; to meet by chance; to meet unexpectedly; to discover; to bump against; to come across unexpectedly; to stumble into; to light upon. aturiaikin eong amuran kosokooni: I stumbled into my mother-in-law at the market. abu eong katuriaikin ebe ekokitos inyamat: I chanced that food was ready. aturiatoi to keep getting lost; to stumble about; to grope; to drift. aturiaun to come by chance; to arrive unexpectedly; to come suddenly upon. aturio generations; age groups. aturo to flower; to bloom; to blossom. eturoete kwana ikito: the trees are now blooming or flowering. aturokin to cut big pieces of meat for. aturor to cut away big lumps; to take away big pieces or lumps. aturot a flower; a blossom. aturukana small intestines in animals. amoeteka nudidik: small intestines.atusaar to break a pot or gourd.atuta a ridge made across a path to prevent erosion; a dam; a dyke; a mole.atuteanut1 (singular noun F) frivolity; thoughtlessness. atuteanut2 ki-a to be frivolous, or light-hearted atutubet a cut; a part or a fraction; a half; a portion; a share; a fragment; a syllable; a paragraph. atutuben: odds and ends. atuule a thumb piano.atwaar to wipe; to brush off. atwaar apua: to dust. atwakare (of many) to die; (of fire) to go out. atwakiar (plural) to lose; to suffer loss of; to forfeit; to be bereft of. atwakiasi idwe lu totokec, arautu ikokiok: these children were bereft of their mother, they have become orphans. atwakikin (of many) to die for; to die somewhere; to die on, in, or at. atwakikis itunga orot: people have died on the way (through an accident, perhaps). atwakun to work very hard; to work to death. etwakunit nges akaswam: she/he is working herself/himself to death for me. atwalanakin ki-a to mark; to stain; to paint anyhow. atwamakin to improvise. atwamitoi to be rash or mindless. atwana dead; finished; extinct. atwanare1 (singular noun F) death; fate. atwanare2 to die; (of fire) to go out. atwana: I am dead. itwana: you (singular) are dead. atwana: she/he/it is dead. kitwaka: we are dead. itwaka: you (plural) are dead. atwaka: they are dead. atwanare etengei: to die of hunger; to starve. kotwana eong akuwan: I was stunned. abu ekatau kotwana: I felt down-hearted; I was sick at heart. atwanare akwena: to burst out laughing; to laugh for long (literally, to die of laughter). erai ibore atwanare ka aijar: it is a matter of life and death. atwaniar to lose; to suffer loss of; to forfeit; to be bereft of. atwania ikoku yen totoke, arau ikoki: this child has lost its mother, it has become an orphan. atwaniaret an expense; a loss; a forfeiture. atwaniaret akos: a total loss (in insurance). atwaniaret adios: a partial loss. atwaniaret naepol: a big loss. itimitoi ikalia luatwakiasi luminan kec: condolences to those who have lost their beloved ones. atwanikin (of one) to die for; to die somewhere; to die on, in, or at. atwaniki esapat ajore: the boy died in the army atwario (singular noun F) discharge (of a patient from hospital); a farewell (of a departing person). atwaun to pluck (fruit); to knock down (fruit). atwaun iturutur: to knock down hornets or wasps. atwenyitwenyit a spark; a brand (live coal); a glow. atyak to separate; to part; to dissever. eraasi kesi ipapero lumam etyakas: they are inseparable friends. atyakakin to give a part to to part from one another; to separate from one another. atyakanakin to divide, dole out, deal, apportion, or parcel out amongst. atyakanar to take shares; to divide into parts; to divide into portions. atyakar to separate; to segregate; to divide and take away; to part; to keep separate; to seclude; to dissociate to part from one another; to say goodbye; to keep separate; to be a hermit; to live in seclusion. atyakat a boundary; a partition; a distinction; a difference; a part; a division; a crack; a split.atyakatyak to cut up; to distinguish; to dismember; to divide into many parts or many portions; to disintegrate. atyakatyaka to be divided, disunited, separated, or cut up, etc atyaketait a difference; a distinction; a dissimilarity; a disagreement; a boundary; a border. atyakun to divide, cut a portion and bring. atyonore to become mature; to mature; to ripen; to become hard. atyokoto imomwa: the sorghum is mature. atyonus1 difficulty; awkwardness; hardness; inflexibility; austerity; stiffness; rigidity; acerbity. atyonus2 to be difficult; to be hard; to be awkward or unbecoming. auj a cattle kraal; a stable; a cowshed; (formerly) a military school for initiates to elders in asapan. ipu akituk kauj: there are many cows in the kraal. aujo a species of tsetsefly, Tabanus species.aukede genital ulcers; syphilis.koukokinai esaduku lo: carry this big box for me. aukor to remove a big thing. kouko ekitoi lo korot: remove this big tree from the road. aukot a corruption of aokot: an edible yam. aukun to take up a heavy load. aulaar (of a fat or big person) to hasten away; to dash off; to hurry away. auleru a flute.aumeno1 (singular noun F) a groan; a grouse; a moan.aumeno2 to be groaning or grumbling; to bemoan. eumenos idwe kotogo: the children are groaning with pain in the house.apotu kesi koumokis amotoka: they were surprised at seeing a motorcar. aumokina to be wonderful; to be astonishing or surprising; to be amazing. aumokinet a wonder; a miracle; an exclamation mark (!). aumosit a miracle; an exclamation (mark). auno a rope; a string; a cord; a snare (made of rope) for catching animals or people. aunoi: cordage. auny to hiss with anger (like an injured bull). apotu itunga luaunyasi kobilutu ekokolan kawenis nako polis kosodete aibunga aidyak aiyar: an angry mob broke into police cells and got a suspected thief whom they beat to near death.aup1 a buddy; comrade; friend; an associate; a companion. aup2 to be in the company of; to be often with; to go about with. akoto aup kajo: I want to be in your company: I want to accompany you. aupakin ka to go together with; to go in the company of. kaupakinos: let us go together. aupakin a corruption of ayupakin: to thread onto; to string on; to plant in the ground (a pole, a knife, a stick, etc). koupak atipet ngin da: string that bead also. aupan to roast things. eupani ngesi acok: she/he roasts potatoes. aupanikin to roast for. koupanikinai eong acok: roast some potatoes for me.aupar to accompany; to go away with; to go in the company of; to go away together. aupar kede icetunganan: to accompany someone. kouparos ore: go home together. alosi ne nan kiupara iso: I am going to where we went together. auparat a tortoise living in rocks. aupaupan matured brew, 4 - 5 days old. aupet a string (of beads, fish, or anything); a female companion, aide, or escort. aupet naka agaria: a string of fish. aupet naka atip: a string of beads. aupit to feel tired; to feel satiated or fed up (with food, drink, work). eupitos ikagoen elos: my clothes are full of dirt. aupuli (singular noun F) a plague. aupun to come with; to fall down with; to come together. aupunos ngesi katenu: she/he fell down together with the branch. kiupun eong ka nges: I will together with him/her. aupwal a Turkana shield.aur to bring forth; to give birth to; to lay eggs; to bear. euriete ikweny abeei: birds lay eggs. aurakin to go to bed hungry. auramam to have a protruding stomach; to have a portly belly. aures1 a smell (good or bad); odour; scent. aures2 to smell of. aur eong ajon: I smell of beer. eurok kesi ajon: they smell of booze. eur saa: she/he/it smells nicely or smells sweetly (aromatic, spicy). auri ebu (singular noun F) rainfall showering while the sun shines; sun shower (literally, the hyena has brought forth). aurian (of cattle or chickens only) to rest; to lie down. euriakete akituk: the cattle are resting. ekotos akituk auriak: the cows want to rest. aurianakin to bear or produce for; (of a man) to be impregnating a woman often. aurianar to become short, stumpy, or low. aurianikin to be too short or too low for. kaurianiki eong ekek lo: this doorway is too low for me. aurianun to become short. aurianu auno ngin: that rope has become short. aurianut1 (singular noun F) shortness; brevity; abbreviation; fertility (of women). aurianut2 to be short or low; (of woman) to be fertile auries uterus. aurikin (of a woman by a man) to impregnate. auriki ngesi apese: he has impregnated a girl. aurio (singular noun F) birth; nativity. Aurio naka Kristo: the birth of Christ; the Nativity. apaarit naka aurioka: my birthday. auriun ikoku to give birth to a child; to bring forth a child. aurokin to give one a smell of something; to smell (good or bad). kauroki eong esigala: I smell a cigarette. auruma to crouch; to stoop low. euruma akokor kotoma abeei ke: the hen is sitting on its eggs. aurumikin to crouch down on or somewhere; to stoop low on something. aurup (used with plural objects) to snatch away things. aurupikin to snatch for or from. kourupikinoi asaduku kotoma akim: snatch my box from the inferno. aurupoor to snatch away from speaker. abu etoori kourupoo imiyot: an eagle snatched away a chick. aurupuun to snatch for oneself; to save or to deliver from danger by snatching. auruun to begin to smell badly; to begin to fester; to begin to go bad; to begin to corrupt; to begin to decay. auryanet a place where cattle rest; a courtyard where people sit and talk; a meeting-place; a council hall. auryaunun (of breath) to often become short or shallow. euryaunene eong etau kanuka etengei: my breath often becomes short on account of hunger, i.e. I am very hungry. auselel to have large prominent buttocks; (of a person) to have large or big buttocks. ausi a belt made of cloth; a ribbon; a cord.
women from Usuk county or sub-county in Katakwi district
Ateso dialect spoken in Usuk county, with elision of letter ‘k’ in words such as akipi, akituk, ekicolong, etc.
a woman from Usuk county in Katakwi district

a word from Ateso usually spoken in Usuk county (example: iidai: yes; itotoka: Oh my; aipi: water; iyo: you; aituk: mouth, cows) ausumoit an elephant snout fish; Marcusenius. ausur (of a person) to be rather big; to be rather fat. ausurikin to prepare or serve much food for somebody. kausurikit eong atap na: you served rather a big mound of food for me. ausurur (of body) to be fat. auta to struggle; to wrestle; to wriggle; to do or attempt. eutasi kesi: they are wrestling. autakin to wrestle with or for; to be doing or attempting. autakinos itelepai: the boys are wrestling with each other. autanut to be fond of or clever at wrestling; to have wrestlemania. auto cooking oil; vegetable oil. autokin akerit to get up and run away; to escape by taking off. autor to pull away; to take out and away. kouto epir ngol: pull out that pole. auto nges ariebo: sickness has overcome her/him. autotorot a flower of Hibiscus sabdariffa. autun to pull out; to extract. kout ekakelai: extract my tooth. aututu a green dove. autuutu a wooden trumpet with a gourd attached as a resonator.auya new grain.ewaanete itunga kanuka lokatwan: people are mourning for a dead man.awaanikin to begin to cry for; to howl or sing together in low tones. awaar (of sky or anything) to look pale or ashen. awaarit1 anaemia; paleness. awaarit2 to be pale, wan, pallid, anaemic or cadaverous; to remain pale; to turn pale. ewaarit ngesi: she/he has turned pale or light. awadet something for scraping or scooping; a scraper; a dredging tool. awadun to scoop up something thick with the hand. awai aside; away. kolot awai: go aside. awaikin to crack a joke; to jest with; to tell a pleasant experience; to tell news from elsewhere. awaitin the sides. awakai the back of the house.awakakin to give in big lumps or in big pieces (of a woman’s breasts or a cow’s udder) to grow big.awakar to break off something big; to knock out (as of teeth). awakawak to take in large lumps; to cut into large pieces; to beat repeatedly. ewakawakaenenei akiring: she/he always takes meat in big pieces. awakun emuogo: to eat or break cassava in big a chunk. awaket the udder of cow, goat, etc. awalaj to cut in big pieces; to vomit (in big chunks); to puke. awanasit a wound; a gash.awanawan to wound all over the body; to rip open in several places. awanawanaun to get wounded all over the body; to be injured all over. ewanawanauna Ecibu kakangas naka emotoka: Ecibu got injured all over in a car accident. awaragat a story; a fable; a parable; a riddle; an allegory. inera ngesi kotoma awaragasia: she/he speaks in parables. awarikin to become dark on somebody or somewhere; to spend the whole day until dark. kawariki eong akwap orot: darkness overtook me on the way. aitawar akwap: to make it dark, i.e. to do until dark.awariwar to loom; to be transparent; to be pellucid. ewariwari : it is (they are) transparent, whitish, grey. awasia1 at the side; at the end; the extreme or the furthest. ibokorit yenikawasia: the little finger; the little toe. ingai iboyie kawasia?: who is sitting at the end or at the side? awasia2 the end (of the world – as predicted in the Holy Bible). awatan to roast by putting near heat; to fry slightly. awatan akiring: to roast meat over the fire. awate bodies (flesh, bones and blood). awawaat to hover about; (of a person) to wait on the sidelines for a chance to take action.awear to scatter; to broadcast seeds, grain, news, etc at random. aswam ka Radio Uganda, Butebo, nges awear iyemuto luka apugan kide nako Uganda: the work of Radio Uganda, Butebo Channel is to broadcast state news to the eastern part of Uganda. aweet a planting time; a sowing period. aweikin to sow, disperse or broadcast for or somewhere. aweikin ekia: to throw poison at; to bewitch. aweikis amalayan esilim Teso: prostitutes have spread HIV/AIDS in Teso. awenan a jailer; a prison officer; a guard; a warder; a warden.awenis a jail, prison, or detention centre; a gaol.kawiinyikit eong ekaajo: I find sugarcane nice and sweet. awiinyu1 (singular noun F) sweetness; sugariness. awiinyu2 to become sweet awinar a corruption of ayunar: to slip through an opening. awoere to sing (a song or hymn); to talk often; to tell often. awoga to be proud (in the way one walks – swaggering, with arms held away from the body). ewogas kesi: they are proud. awogakin to be proud of. awogakin ngesi kanuka aswamuke: she/he is proud because of her/his job; to become proud of. awogar to walk about proudly. awoikin1 to sing for; to sing to; to talk often to; to tell often to; to drip into, onto; to leak somewhere. kowoikinoi: sing for me. ai bo ewoi kataagi?: where is the tank leaking? awoikin2 to help to put a load on the head. kowoikinoi asaduku na: help me to put this box on my head. awoisioit an anthem; a hymn; a song. awojat a species of grasshopper. awoji to spin a rope or thread; to make rope; to twine. ewojiete isomero aunoi: the schoolboys are making ropes.awojior to ravel; to twist (rope). awokit a vessel for drawing water, beer, etc. awokokin to draw water for; to fetch water for. awokokin akipi, ajon, akiria: to draw or scoop water, beer, or flour. awokor to draw (water, beer, flour) and take away.awolanet a bomb blast; an explosion; pent-up anger (causing aol to swell).ewoliete akituk kosamai: the cows are lost in the swamp (cannot find their way home). awolit eong nualosi einer: I am at a loss what to say. awolior to get lost; to be lost. awoliosi akituk: the cows are lost. awolit to be ignorant; to be at a loss. iwolito yesi akiro nu?: do you not know these issues? iwolitos yesi akiro ngun?: don't you know that? awoliun to stray this way; to be lost near here. awolobobot to be loud-mouthed or outspoken on trivial issues; to vainly speak of oneself; to be vainglorious or magniloquent. awolokok1 emptiness; vanity; hollowness.awolokok2 to be empty; to be hollow. awolokonyoit a shell (of egg or anything).awolong to act big. awomikin to fetch for or somewhere; to go and fetch from. kowomikinai akipi: go and fetch me some water. awomowom to think over; to ponder; to meditate; to consider. kowomowomaata ber nuilosete aswam: first consider what you are going to do. awomun to come and fetch. awongor a dark-brown wading bird.awonore to dry; to wither; to fade. awono ngesi : she/he/it has (they have) dried up. awook (of weight) to be light; to be buoyant. ewook kesi: they are light (not heavy).awookaar to become lightweight; to become buoyant. awoong to yawn; to gape. awoonor to leak; to pass through a sieve or filter. ewoonorete akipi kamot: the water leaks from the pot. awoore to sing; to be singing. ewoi she/he/it is (they are) singing. awoot a mark left by something moving on the ground; a spoor; a rut of a car; a trace; a trail or track made by a crawling animal. nakinyo awoot ngin? erai ngin awoot naka emun: what trail is that? It is the trail of a snake. aworet (singular noun F) a corruption of aoret: cow-dung; manure; (jocular) huge human faeces. aworonokin alup to scoop up earth (and fill a hole, etc). aworor to be hollow; to have a hole; to leak; to be perforated. eworori amot: the pot has a leak. awororikin to become or be hoarse or husky; to be empty for. kawororiki eong: I am hoarse. awororikinit (of voice) to be husky, hoarse, or raucous. awosan ki-a to sue; to accuse; to plead a case; to state a case in court. iwosaete kesi akiro: they are pleading their cause. alosi awosan: I am going to plead my case. awosianut1 (singular noun F) slowness in conceiving. awosianut2 to be slow in conceiving. ewosyana aberuka: my wife is slow in conceiving. awosikin to let go; to set free; to release; to give permission; to emancipate. kowosik akaakan: let go off my arm. kowosik amotoka kotubor: let the motorcar pass. awotoun to lift and put down once (off fire or off someone’s head). awoun a corruption of abwoun: to testify against; to resist. awoun1 to begin a song; to drip or leak just once.awoun2 to take or lift down a load from the head. kowounoi ajerikan na: please, take down this jerry-can off my head: help me to unload this jerry-can. awowa to rub lightly; to stroke or caress. ewowai ngesi ekapa: she/he strokes the tomcat (more than once). awowaar to stroke (just once); to rub off gently. bia kowowaarai eong: please, come and rub me gently. awu (singular noun F) a honey-bee. awudet a bicycle pump.awuikin to pass wind on or somewhere; to fart for. awuj a kraal; a cowshed. awulaar (of a fat person) to be off in a hurry; to hasten away; hurry away. ai bo iwulaar ijo?: where are you off to in such a hurry? awulak (of a fat woman) to waddle. awulanet dynamite; an explosive. epol awulanet: explosive. awumokin to wonder at. awunene a ground harp consisting of a taut string tied to a flexible stick at one end and a calabash buried in the ground on the other end, and strummed with fingers. awuno a rope; a string; a cord; a snare (made of rope) for catching animals or people.awuny to hiss with anger (like an injured bull). apotu itunga luawunyasi kobilutu ekokolan kawenis naka polis kosodete aibunga aidyak aiyar: an angry mob broke into police cells and got a suspected thief whom they beat to near death.awupakin to string on or somewhere. awupet a string of beads, fish, or anything. awures1 to smell after; to stink. awures2 (singular noun F) a smell (good or bad); a stench; an aroma; an odour. loewur ejok, loewur erono: good and bad smelling. ewur ejok: (of a smell) pleasant, balmy.awuri (of man or animal) to give birth to; to bring forth; to bear. awurikin to impregnate to have been impregnated. awurikinos apesur ngun kore: these girls have been impregnated at home (before marriage). awuris uterus. awuruget a small species of ngege (tilapia). awurup to snatch (many things); to grab (things). awurupoor (used with singular or plural object) to snatch away; to grab. awuryaanut to be short; to be stumpy, dwarfish, brief, curt, or abrupt. shortness; abruptness; curtness. awuryanet a children’s park; a courtyard. awuryanut to be prolific, fertile, fruitful fertility; fruitfulness. awutun to pull out this way; to dislodge. awututu1 a hooting instrument or thing. awututu2 a plant, Aframomum. awuya newly harvested grain. ayaar to take away; to lead away; to rule; to govern; to translate into. ayaar aberu: to marry. ayaar aberu kitunganan: to take away someone’s wife. koya elepa kon ngina: stop your impudence.ayaara bon to be independent. eyaara ngesi bon: she/he is independent. ayait to rule; to direct; to reign; to contain; to hold; to manage; to represent; to control. ayangaar to take away; to carry off; to abduct; to assume; to accept. ayangaar aberu: to marry (by taking a woman away from her parents).ayangaun to bring this way; to fetch; to transport this.ayanyanar (Serere) to oversee; to inspect; to monitor. ayanyun (Serere) to see; to perceive. kaloto ayanyun: let us go and see. ayanyun ican: to suffer hardships or poverty (literally, to see trouble). ayapiar (Serere) to go near to; to approach. nepe eyapiarete ore, kotwani papakec: no sooner had they come near home than their father died. ayapiu (singular noun F) (Serere) nearness; vicinity; proximity; approximation. ayapiun (Serere) to be near here; to become nearer. ayapu (Serere) to be near. eyapie: she/he/it is near. eyapiete: they are near.ayaun to bring hither; to cause; to engender; to adduce; to afford. koyau nges ne: bring her/him/it here. ayaun ejie: to cause or bring fighting or war. ayaun adeka: to bring or cause disease. akataasa naeyaunere inyamat: a tray. ayaun ekisil: to enact a law. ayedakin (Serere) to press or crush; to touch or wink at somebody (to draw attention or give a clue); to press on (as between fingers when killing lice); to kill between fingers. koyedak elacit: kill the louse (between fingers). ayedanakin akonye: to keep blinking the eyes; to peer through half-closed eyelids.ayekar (Serere) to go far; to be gone (away); to have departed; to do well, become an important person. ayekeret a prostitute; a sex worker.koyeku lailo: come this way. ayelo (Serere) (of a person) to have intercourse; to commit adultery or fornication. eyeloi ngesi : she/she is (they are) having illicit sexual intercourse.koyenik akine oloit: tie the goat to the peg.ayeyait (Serere) a niece (as referred by the aunt).ayiara (Serere) to be safe. eyiara ikaboro: my property is secure/safe. ayiikin to submit, defend; to guard for someone; to protect for. koyiikinai ikakoku kinyekinai ainomonom atitai: shield my child from being beaten for nothing. ayikokin ki-o to become calm; to calm down; to settle down (as of a vagabond). adau ekwam ayikokin: the wind has calmed down.ayikomo a thick brass or copper armlet; a bangle.ayikong a short wooden hammer (mallet) for pounding pottery clay, or for hammering out barkcloth; a threshing stick. ayikuro a peninsula; a cape; an isthmus.ayilarar ki-a (Serere) (of a tall bare-headed person or bird) to have a long neck. ayile1 (Serere) a big clay pot. ayile2 (singular noun F) (Serere) the irritating hairs of plants.aiyilit akonye: to be very curious; to look around often (curiously).eyiliyili ates: the corpse looks horrible.eyinanakinos kesi aswam ngin: they do that work in turns. ayines (singular noun F) (Serere) stinginess; close-fistedness; avarice. ayinit (Serere) to be stingy; to be closefisted or avaricious; to be niggardly. eyinitos itunga lu: these people are stingy ayinyakin (Serere) to tell off; to deride; to mock at, reprimand. ayinyanakin1 (Serere) to ridicule; to laugh at the poverty of somebody. inyo bo kiyinyanakina ijo ngol lokican?: why do you make fun of (ridicule) that poor man? ayinyanakin2 (Serere) to tell off often; to keep telling off (in one’s face). ayipan to chip off; to chisel; to cut off. ayipanar to cut off or chisel off a piece of wood, etc many times to make it sharp or pointed. ayipar to cut off or chisel off a piece of wood, etc once only. ayipilil (of bottom of gourd, etc) to be protruding or visible; to be pointed. iyipilil akituk kon bala naka ebilicoro: your lips are pointed like the beak of the buffalo-weaver (an insult). ayirang (of a person) to have a big fat head. ayirangang (of a person) to have a big fat head. iyirangang ijo: you have a big, fat head. ayiriyir (of eyes, water, glass, polished things) to glitter, shine. eyiriyirete akonyeke naarai edekas: her/his eyes are glazed because they are inflamed. ayis (Serere) a jungle; uninhabited bush; the high-grass.ayisang (Serere) to go or walk about with a big head; to have a big head. eyisangi ngesi: she/he has a big head. ayiset a water spring, fountain, source (of water or any liquid). ayisomom ki-a (of people only) to be tall; (of a person) to be higher. ayitakin to sharpen, point for somebody; to drip or trickle on to something. ayitakinet a drop; a point; a spot; a dot. ayitanut1 to be fond of sharpening. ayitanut2 habit of sharpening or pointing. ayitar (causative verb) to make pointed, sharp. koyita ekalaamu lo: sharpen this pencil. ayites spikiness; sharpness; tapering. ayitunet a drop of liquid; a trickle. ayiyara ki-a (Serere) to be safe; to be protected. ayogan (singular noun F) a greeting; a welcome. ayoit pain (after a knife-cut); soreness (after cut); a knife-cut; a minnow (a species of small fish). ayonganut1 timidity; fearfulness; veneration. ayonganut2 to be timid; to be timorous or inclined to fear ayonge the residue in salt-making after draining brine. ayonget apprehension; fear; awe. ayongikin to be afraid of; to stand in awe of. ayongit to be in constant fear of; to be afraid of; to be in reverence. eyongit ikoku ngin itunga: that child is afraid of or respects people. ayoore (Serere) to sing (a song or hymn). ayooya a cycle rim (without the tyre and spokes).ayoroi (Serere) a branch, a twig, or leaf of eyoroi tree. ayuara (singular noun F) a protection; shelter; fortification; security. ayuaret a defence; an explanation in support of; a plea. ayunar to go through a narrow opening; to slip through; to escape through a narrow opening. abu emir koyunar kapedot: the rat escaped through a narrow opening. ayunun to enter quickly; to slip in. ayupakin to string on something. ayupet a string of beads, fish, or anything. ayupit (Serere) to be tired; to be fed up.ayuunan a rescuer; a saviour; a liberator; a redeemer.ayuunet a guarantee; a bail; a bond. ayuunio (singular noun F) a rescue; a redemption; salvation; liberation; emancipation. ayuwara (singular noun F) a corruption of ayuara: protection; security; shelter; fortification.

(noun neuter) the second letter of the Ateso alphabet. ba1 (of strength, tightness, hardness) very. egogong ba: she/he is very strong, hard. koyen ba: tie firmly. ataus ba: to be hard. eta amoru na ba: this rock is very hard.ajai eong ba!: indeed I am here. bia ba!: in fact, do come (singular). ijo ba lo: you here: I mean you (singular M).baa ba (of strength, tightness, hardness) very. egogong baa ba: she/he/it is very strong, hard. itenara akimat baa ba: the old woman is very rigid (bodily, perhaps due to her age). ataus baa ba: to be very hard. eta amoru na ba: this rock is very hard. bala about

approximate; as; like; nearly. epogana bala ajokit: she/he is as proud as the devil. erai bala; ikoni bala; esubit bala: it is as if; it is as though; in a way that makes you think something. elosi ngesi kosubite bala edeka: she/he walks as if she/he were sick. etia bala: as…as (used with uncountable things). ipu/ikidioko bala: as many/few as. edolete itunga bala itomon kwangin: there are approximately ten people. bangal (of soft and fat things, down fall) floppily. abu emun lokatuman kibirun kokitoi bangal: a fat snake fell from a tree with a flop. bangar (of big things, fall with a) flop. adoo acokit kwap bangar: the (cooked) potato flopped down. bas ok then; that is it. batabat (of a duck or a fat and short person running) waddling; wobbling. ikeri ijo batabat: you run heavily like a duck. batisimu (noun neuter) baptism; induction into a faith or religion; initiation ceremony (especially into Christianity). be1 (of colour red) very; extremely. ereng abebe akituk be: an antelope’s mouth is very red. arengeu emukaro be: the kiln is red hot. be2 no; nay. be, mam eong acamuni nepecep da!: nay, I will not accept it in the least!bec (to fit, do, or go) exactly, punctually. erai isaawan itomon bec: it is exactly 4:00 o’clock.erai isaawan ikany-kape becebec: it is exactly 12:00 noon (or 12:00 midnight). bee (emphatic) very red. bekebek (imitative) like the sound of a bird pecking nutshells or eggshells. beket no; nay. beket, esabet ngol inera ijo: no, that is a lie you are now telling. ber first of all; so far; before; yet. koge ber aswam: (you) first begin to work. kobia ber: (you) come first. mam ber: not yet. bia (singular imperative) come! come hither!biai? (interrogation) how? ijai biai?: how are you? (singular greeting). ijaasi biai?: how are you? (plural) bian yesterday; last night.
baa ba ba2 indeed; in fact; certainly
(suffix, adjective) (of a pot, gourd, or person) narrow-mouthed. bir (of a flame or fire) roaring

flaring; flaming; blazing. egasi akim bir, apolou ke ebe ejaas ipejok orot abunore: when a wood-fire blazes noisily, it means guests are on the way coming. biribir (of a flame or fire) roaring; flaring; flaming; blazing. enokiete airiirin biribir: twigs are flaring on fire. bisaali yellow (in colour like curry); creamy. bisali bisaali very yellow or creamy. emunatai ajon bisali bisaali: the brew is creamy (the colour is like curry, hence well-made). bo perhaps; then. inyo bo?: what is it then (do you want?). ai bo?: where then? do bo jo?: what about you? aso bo do: very well then; there you are! boat a corruption of bo nat: anyway; by the way; at all. ingai boat ijo?: who are you at all?(a challenge)bobo bobo: again and again. lu bobo: again these. mam bobo: never again. moi bobo: tomorrow again. bokobok (to tremble; to shiver) all over, very much. amaran bokobok: to shiver terribly. amaran teletel: to shudder terribly. bon (used after singular reflexive verbs and personal pronouns) alone; by oneself; mere. eong bon: I alone; by myself; I solely. iso bon: we alone, ourselves; by ourselves. bonik (used after plural reflexive verbs and personal pronouns) one another; by themselves; each other; mere. oni bonik: we alone; by ourselves. iso bonik: we alone, ourselves; by ourselves. boo (to rain) heavily; incessantly. etepi edou boo: it is raining heavily. bu1 (of red) very. bu2 Oh! Oh my!
the land of the Baganda people of central Uganda (districts such as Kampala, Mukono, Masaka, Mpigi, Luwero, etc)
the pre-colonial kingdom of Buganda governed by the Kabaka (king).
Europe (misinterpreted nowadays to mean the United Kingdom)
the pre-colonial kingdom of Bunyoro governed by Omukama - king (the present-day Uganda districts of Hoima, Masindi, and parts of Kibaale and Mubende)
the land of the Banyoro people.
the land of the Basoga people governed by Isebantu - king

the present day districts of Jinja, Iganga, Kamuli, Mayuge and Bugiri. butubut (of the sound of water being poured from a narrow-mouthed vessel, especially a gourd) gurgling; gushing. buu! Oh! Alas!merrr: the sound of a sheep. buua2 (noun neuter) (to a child) a cow. bwang (to be finished) completely; utterly; totally. adaun bwang: to finish completely. adaunos bwang: erikaros bwang: they are completely finished.emwaka akeje bwangabwang: the feet are burning like they are on fire.
bu! buua1 (of the sound of a cow) moo; the lowing of a cow
(noun neuter) the third letter of the Ateso alphabet

(a mark indicating) the third highest grade or quality. ca (as a sign of impoliteness, with bo) well! indeed. eeca! yes, indeed; ay, aye. mam ca!: no, of course not. aso cabo! well, if you like! right! eong ca: it is I. caat perhaps; it may be so; well now. arai caat: perhaps.cani just awhile; a moment. koyau cani kaany: just let me have a look. caricar (to do something) for nothing; idly; in vain. aiboi carirar: to sit idly.
ca nat; arai ca nat cakaya cakaya imitation of the rattle of a railway train as it chugs away
(suffix or infix of adjective & pronominal) another

other; some. ece- (M): another one; someone else. ace- (F): another; someone else; some more. aceparit: another day. icekoku: another child. lokacekwap M or nakacekwap F: a stranger. eceipone: a different manner; differently. loce (M): the other companion; so-and-so. nace (F): the other companion; so-and-so. ceger (of a tall thing or person falling or jumping) gently, quietly, softly. ebala ekapa esomun kwap ceger: a cat jumped down lightly (not with a thud). cekicek (of rainfall) incessant; non-stop. atep lolo edou cekicek: it has been raining incessantly today. cep not in the least. mam nepecep da: not at all.ataus ci: to be very cold or chilly. eta akipi nu ci: this water is very cold. cii ci: very (awfully) cold.

immature; young; a little (thing). nediocici: a little while. ediocici: a little. akoto epaaba ediocici bon: I want only a little cotton wool. abuni nediocici: I’ll come in a little while, soon, now. cii ci (of coldness or chilliness) very; awful. elilim abaraapu cii ci: ice cream is very cold. cikil (of something falling into a liquid and sinking) plop; plonk. codok (to jump) over. cogor (of a long thing or person falling, moving or jumping) awkwardly, inelegantly, clumsily. ebala egoro elosi cogor cogor: a heron walks awkwardly (with long thin legs) cuc very; absolutely; extremely (black or dark). iryono etogo lo cuc: this house is pitch dark. emutono akware na cuc: it is pitch dark tonight. egoe loribik erurut kiryono cuc: an alpaca is a very dark smooth cloth. cut (of intensity, quality, or degree) very; utterly; completely; entirely; quite; really; indeed; verily; truly. ka cut: especially. cuticut: certainly; exactly. cuticut certainly; exactly; indeed; definitely; surely. konye cuticut atwana toto?: but surely mother is dead? cwa with a lot of confused noise; with a din; in commotion cwi (to hold) firmly; strongly; (to tie) fast; tightly. aikamun cwi: to hold firmly, tightly, with the hand.
(noun neuter) the fourth letter of the Ateso alphabet. da also

not even. ajai ngesi da: she/he/it was also there. mam da: not even. mam ediopet da: not even one. iida: yes. daang all; altogether; entire. atwaka akinei daang: all the goats are dead. atwaka kesi daang: they are all dead.dalac (of a long soft thing unwinding and falling) flop softly. adacun emun kwap dalac: a snake fell down flop.daladal (of a long thing) hanging listlessly. edeka emong ngol omulat, ebala amulat daladal: the bull is suffering from bovine pleuro-pneumonia, its mouth is drooling with saliva. dau dau (of something that can be felt or touched) glossy; silky; soft or smooth (to the touch). abu ekoroi ebala dau dau: the he-goat has come with a nice soft skin. enapit lolo ejakait nebala dau dau: the chief is dressed in silks today. ekuye asabuuni dau dau: the soap is foaming nicely. de very, completely (dry, desicated, arid); also; too. aono akwap de: the earth is completely dry; there is a great drought. akoto eong de akinyam: I also want to eat. dee de very, completely (dry, desicated, arid). aokoto nges ipon dee de: her/his lips are completely dry (due to thirst or hunger).aingop dii di: to hide carefully. abu je kidat di keanyu ijaka luka esolo: the other guy hid himself completely when he saw graduated tax collectors.

(diminutive infix, put between nominal or verbal prefix and noun or verb). akoto adijon: I want a little beer. alosi adipejo: I am going on a short visit.diala dial (of somethind attached loosely) dangling
hanging; floppy. ebala emaradaadi loka atip kogoe diala dial: the decorative beads on the cloth are dangling loosely. diat perhaps; probably.

a few. koinakinai ijon idicar: give me a little beer. akoto eong emuogo edicar: I want a little cassava. koyau akile adicar: bring a little milk. (note: only prefix e-, a-, i- changes for masculine, feminine, and diminutive to match the noun).
suffix very small. koyau imeleku yenididi: bring a very small hoe. die (to, from) nearby place

next to. alosi eong die nepene: I am going just near here. abuni eong kodie: I came from nearby. die ka: near me. die!: (when commanding draft-oxen) to the right! Turn nearby. dii (of people or animals moving) Indian file; one behind another. elosete imukunyo eriga dii: the ants are going hunting Indian file. dii di (to hide or get lost) entirely; completely. dikidik throb frequently; thud often; pulse repeatedly, etc. ebala abus dikidik: the boil throbs (says dikidik). dikila well done! fine! (mostly used by children in songs) dimarai except; unless; before. mam ikukonokin idekesio ice, dimarai Eong bon: do not worship any other gods, except Me alone.dimicaat perhaps if; except if; unless; if not; provided. abonguni eong, dimicaat kelomut acekiro: I shall come back unless something prevents me. dimikito except; unless. mam inyami aperosit ngin, dimikito kalimok eong ijo: do not eat that food leftover of yesterday unless I have told you to.dimito a corruption of dimikito: except; unless.ding (of size) very big; gigantic. epol ngesi ding: she/he is very big.

a little (of something). ediomoro: some other day. kookokinoi adisikipi: fetch me a little water. (note: -dio follows the prefixes e-, a-, i- and precedes the noun without the prefix). diolo diol (of wet ground or slimy vegetable) very, extremely polished, slippery, or smooth. ebala eboo diolo diol, esubit bala ekwamakina atigo toma: the eboo vegetable is very slimy, it looks like too much atigo condiment was put. erurut erot diolo diol: the road is very slippery.
(an infix denoting) a few. adisikinei: a few goats. idisitunga: a few people. (note: dis follows a prefix and precedes a noun
it is also used as an adjective following a noun). itunga idis: a few people. adisikipi: adisikile: a little water, milk.

a little. akoto eong akile aditai: I want a little milk. diye (to, from) nearby place; hereabouts. alosi eong diye nepene: I am going just near here. abuni eong kodiye: I came from nearby. diye ka: near me. diye!: (when commanding draft-oxen to) the right! Turn nearby.do nat sooner; later on. adau ngesi aibunga eong, doot ijo: she/he has already beaten me and now he is going to beat you. do1 (of sweetness) intense; very. ejijim esukaali do: the sugar is very sweet.do ijo: now you! inyo bo do?: what then? doot aikonakin ai?: what can we do then? what can be done then? or what is to be done then? doine a corruption of do konye: after which; so that. ejai ijo adolun ne moi, doine idumuni epale: you have to come here tomorrow if you want to get the trousers.dolodol1 (of something long and hanging) loosely; dangling sideways. ebakasi ekoroi itou dolodol: the he-goat’s testicles are swinging loosely. dolodol2 in a lazy manner; idly; sluggishly; lazily; indolently. iswamai ijo dolodol: you work sluggishly. doo very; too (sweet, syrupy, sugary). ejijim esukaali doo: sugar is very sweet. eta doo; ebala doo; ejijim doo doo: it is very sweet. doot a corruption of do nat: later on; sooner. adau ngesi aibunga eong, doot ijo: she/he has already beaten me and now he is going to beat you. dotini a corruption of do konye: and then; so that. koloto ber yesi dotini eong da aswam nuka: you better go so that I may do my work.du1 (of red or crimson) very. arengeun du: (of a solid object on fire, of the fire place itself) to become red hot, very hot, or very red. akinyeta nuebulucete emukule iterengeunete ijo du: bleaching creams make you very red. du2 (to hide, to get lost, or to disappear) entirely; altogether; completely. aingop duu du: to hide completely. aolio ngesi du: she/he/it is lost altogether.duc always; all the time; everyday; usually; daily. akoto eong ijo kobunenei duc: I want you to come always. ducuduc always; all the time; continually; usually; repeatedly; very often. akoto eong ijo kobunenei ducuduc: I want you to come very often. dukum (of a fruit, cooked food) soft; ripe; tender. akokoto acok dukum, ebucitos aipisiar: the sweet potatoes got very soft in cooking, it nearly turned watery. dupuk (of a clap-trap, to go off with a) thud; crash or bang. agwetakin akuluma dupuk: the clap-trap went off with a thud, crash. motoko eic da kitilim akiro, konye akuluma dupuk dupuk: the string trap allows you to squeak, but a clap-trap kills you outright (said at a meeting of Rats - in a children song). dus (imitative of a sound of a hard object falling on a resounding surface) thud; thump; bump; (of a heartbeat) throbbing; pounding. ebala akou edoi kwap dus: his head fell down with a thud. ebala etauka dus del: my heart is throbbing madly (like it wants to fall off its strings). dusuk (of something cooked) very soft; completely or totally soft. duu du (to hide, to get lost, or to disappear) entirely; altogether; completely. aingop duu du: to hide completely. aolio ngesi duu du: she/he/it is lost altogether. arengeun duu du: (of a solid object on fire, of the fire place itself) to become red hot, very hot, or very red. akinyeta nuebulucete emukule iterengeunete ijo duu du: bleaching creams make you very red.
(noun neuter) the fifth letter of the Ateso alphabet

a vowel letter as in ‘jet’. e- a prefix denoting: a) masculine nouns. etelepat: a boy b) large objects. emoru: a big stone or a mountain. c) adjectives. etunganan lo ejok: a good man. d) third person of ko-verbs. eduki ngesi: she/he builds. e) first person of ki-verbs. eswamai eong: I work.

the Sebei country. aite oalei: to die (some Teso clans bury their dead with graves facing east – the direction of Mt. Elgon from Teso).oiduka loeapie: at the adjacent shop. eapie2 soon; nearly. eapie ngesi abunere: she/he/it is nearly coming. eapikit ngesi atwanare: she/he/it is nearly dead. eapie oni adolore ngina: we are nearly there.
Eyale eapie1 being a short distance away; near; adjacent; approximate; contiguous
an Arab.The bark is poison, hence the 'ordeal tree'. The tree provides shade, firewood, and timber. eari fatal

deadly; lethal; incurable; terminal; mortal; serious; grave; critical. ebaado (formerly) a variety of maize with big cobs and seeds. orwa! abures ikel bala ebaado ngina: go away with your big teeth! (an insult to a toothy person).epuakata eong ibaajai noi: I am heavily in debt. ebaale a mushroom (in general). ebwangunit ebaale katitipu kangin: mushrooms have sprouted on that anthill. ebaba the last person (in class or in athletics race); a shrub, Rhus incana. ebabu a poor man; a beggar. irai ijo ebabu: irai ijo loka ibabu: you are a beggar.ebac an evergreen tree, Rauvolfia caffra. The roots and bark are medicine (abac) for hypertension, and the wood is used for poles, beehives and firewood. ebaga Christmas feast, celebration, festivity, rejoicing, or banquet; Noël tide.kiding ebai at dawn, about 4:00 am.
eyarabut earamor Sasswood or Ordeal tree, Erythrophleum suaveolens

the Bible, i.e. the sacred writings of the Christian Church, consisting of the Old and New Testaments. ebaibuli: a copy of the Bible. ebaibuli: a highly-detailed book, regarded as an authority. ebajeret a foreign made bracelet. ebajet a budget

a financial forecast; any plan, especially for a particular period of time, showing how money coming in will be spent. ebakat a man with feet full of jiggers; a man with very dirty feet; one who walks with difficulty (riadariad) with toes spread out. ibakatat: (you are) dirty! ibakatatas: (they are) dirty!(a term of reproach or abuse) ebakedo avocado pear or tree, Persea americana. Its fruit is used as food or cosmetic, oil is extracted from the seed, while the tree provides shade and firewood. ebakuli a vegetable bowl. ebalangit a tree, Protea paveta crassipes. ebalasa a verandah; a porch; a balcony; a loggia; a portico.ebalua a letter; mail; a memo. ibaluan: mail. aiwadikakin ebalua: to write a letter to. ebalua loilipit aswam: a job application letter. ebalua loilipit aibois: an application for a vacancy. ebalua loacamakinio aiboisit: an admission letter. ebang a fool; an idiot; a dumb person; a mad person; a duffer; a buffoon; a twin boy-child. isusit ebang aoret otimake: the madman has smeared cow-dung on his hair. ebangaana stupid; mad; dumb; daft; dull; foolish; deaf; silly; dense; absurd. ebangit a male twin-child.ebanyet a razor blade.ebar (formerly) a cleared space outside the village (used for ebar dance); a dance at night without drums; faeces (human or animal); solid excreta (of people). ebarakis a barracks. ebarara numerous; abundant; copious; profuse; many. ebarenit a razor for shaving; a razorblade.ebasang a slave.ebata a Sirris tree or red and white nongo - Albizia zygia, Albizia glaberrima (a tree in etekwa family). Its leaves and bark are used for soap (foaming lather), leaves are fodder, extract from flowers, bark and seed are medicinal. ebatalion a battalion (a number of companies). ebatiira elephantiasis of the feet.ebe thus; that, “……”; quite; like this. (Used with direct quotation) abala eong ebe, ‘mam akoto’: I say (thus), ‘I don’t want.’ (used before indirect or reported speech, meaning that 'he says.' ebala ngesi ebe ebuni moi: he says he will come tomorrow. (without ebe: ebala ngesi ebuni moi). ebebele an edible mole rat with a white-tipped tail.ebeei (singular noun M) a price; the cost of on a good or service.ebeele a fight as a result of double dealing; wrong information given by rumour-spreader; mischief-making. ayaun ebeele: to cause a disturbance. ebeere a grasshopper in general. ebega a detective; a spy; a sleuth.ebego a pedigree; a select or choice seed; a variety or stock (ancestry).ibecokino aipit ebego loka akokoroi: it is advisable to rear farm breeds of chicken. ebekubeku a variety of red-headed edible mushroom growing in sandy plains.ebelat a variety of cowpeas.ebelat a person to be wounded on the head (with stick.) ebele affair; an issue; a matter; a concern; a problem. inyoika ibelesio kus kane?: what is your business here? (what are you doing here?) ebelekinyom a variety of small white edible mushroom, Sarcocephalus esculentus ebelekuma a vegetable, Commelina. ebelel (it is) split, cracked, bashed in (as of a head using ebela - stick). ebeli (singular noun M) famine; starvation.ebeliodole a shrub, Sarcocephalus latifolius. Its root extracts are a good treatment for early leprosy. The fruit is eaten as food while the leaves and fruit are fodder for livestock. ebelo (rare) profit. emamei ebelo kotoma agwelanar kon: there is no profit in your business or trade.ebenen (of weight, work, movement) light, easy, brisk; agile or simple. ebenen amot na: this pot is light. ebenet a bayonet, i.e. a knife attached to the barrel of a rifle.ebenot a plant that grows near water, Ricinodendron heudelotii; It is a thorny leguminous shrub with yellow flowers with cork wood often used for rafts and corks. ebenyana harsh; vicious; quarrelsome; malevolent; cruel. ebenyo a tree, Acacia mellifera. eberiang excited; animated; lively; bubbly. eberu a very big woman; a virago; an amazon. ebeuna truthful; affirmative; right; direct or straightforward. ebia spear grass, Imperata cylindrica. Its presence in the soil means the soil is good for growing crops. ebiasara for-profit business; trade; economic activity. ebibiru the top of the inside of the house; the apex; a tower; a minaret. ebibisi sweet brew (two days old, after which it is called arasai).eiswamae lo ebicupuli: a phoney manner of working or doing business. isirigin lu ebicupuli: counterfeit currency. ebidio a video; a VCR player.ebilaep a tree - the root of which is used as medicine for wounds, Acacia macrothyrsa. ebilat a long chair (that can be folded together); a deck chair. ebileng mudfish; lungfish, Protopterus.aremor ebili: to cast off a spell or a curse.ebilibila (of a woman or girl) bashful; pretend to be shy or embarrassed; (of anything) broken many times. ebilicoro a buffalo weaverbird.ebilil broken; bent; crumpled; creased; folded; conquered. ebilionit a billion; a thousand million. ibilionin ka ibilionin: billions upon billions.ebilo a flute with 2-6 holes. ebinika a kettle; a tea-pot. ebino wine, i.e. an alcoholic drink made from the fermented juice of fruits such as grapes, passion fruits, tangerines, etc ebinu an unusually shaped pot with no neck, tall in relation to its width, tapering to a fairly small aperture.ebirinyaanya an eggplant; the aubergine fruit.ebitet the stem of a smoker’s pipe; the sharp end of a spear. ebiti a small spear. ebiya factory or industrial beer or brew; a lager.ebobore a fig tree in the ebule and ebyong family, Ficus sycomorus. This tree has sacred or religious significance and is not cut in anger. The tree bears edible fruits, and the wood is good for carving troughs as well as for timber or firewood. aisieb ebobore: to deny any wrong-doing by cutting or piercing ebobore, hence wishing the accuser death (if the accused is guilty, the death wish boomeranges on his family). ebocit an impotent man. ebocit: a man dressing and behaving like a woman.ebodaboda a pay cycle, i.e. a commercial bicycle or motorcycle. icaki ngesi ebodaboda: she/he carries passengers on a cycle (for money).ebogoya a variety of banana plant bearing long big fruits eaten yellow.eboi a fishnet; a web.eboikinon aingito: one who sits for exams or tests; an examination candidate. eboit (formerly) servant (from English ‘boy servant’); ploughing oxen. ebok (a reference among friends) a guy; a fellow; a mature man.eboket a tool for digging; a crow-bar.ebokoi the first part of a song. ebokolinga a red-necked lizard.ebokorit a finger; a toe of man or animals. ebokorit loka akeju: a toe. ebokorit lokapolon: a thumb. ebokorit lokokiding: a middle finger. ebokorit lomedelit or imedelit: a little finger or toe. ebokorit losodit: index finger. ibokorit yenikawasia: the little finger or toe. ebokorit lokepeta: a ring finger. adeka nakibokor: onychia (fungal infection affecting the skin between toes or fingers). ebokot (of anything) rough; misshapen; ill-formed. ebokot amot na: this pot is roughly done. ebol a swelling on the knee (due to too much kneeling), Bursitis juxta articular nodules.ebole a pact; a wager; a bet; a recompense; a promise; a testament, law; agreement. aiar ebole: to breach a contract.ebolet playing field.eboli a young Bagrus fish. eboliana playful; sporting; sportive; frivolous. ebolibol a tree, Ficus ovata. ebolo a shrub, Sarcocephalus latifolius. Its root extracts are a good treatment for early leprosy. The fruit is eaten as food while the leaves and fruit are fodder for livestock. eboloca a tree, Grewia mollis. eboluk a fat man (especially one with a double chin) (an insult). ebomibom (singular noun M) a variety of orange tree bearing big fruits.ebonet a swelling on the skin; a growth on a knee. ebong in the evening; afternoon; at dusk. ebonge (singular noun M) the time of return, going back, retiring. ebongut a barkcloth fig tree, Ficus natalensis. Its bark is used for making barkcloth, while the leaf extract is medicine for dysentery and sore throat. ebonibonit the ear lobe. ebonot1 beads of metal cylinders strung together (formerly used as an apron, a ring, or a crown). ebonot2 (of a person or animal) smooth; well fed; quite well developed (physically); most beautiful; unpretentious, considerate, nice; (of manners being) meek; elegant; well-mannered, easy. ebonot etelepat ngol: that boy is nice, quiet, humble, serious, etc eboo1 leaves of peas, Vigna; a common vegetable from pea leaves.ebood a board, especially of directors; an official group of people controlling or managing an organisation, etc., or examining or interviewing candidates. ebood loka idairekitan: a board of directors. ebood loka aingito: an examinations board. eboole work in exchange for beer in future; a communal feast held after millet harvest prepared for those who helped in the harvesting.ebooma a town (especially an administrative headquarters of a district).eboomu a bomb-shell; a grenade.eborosit (singular noun M) (disapprovingly) a lot of things; a heap of things; a conglomeration of things; a cluster of things. ebosana (of anything) liable to become rotten quickly. ebosino a male child surviving after the death of other children born before him; a soldier who survives in a battlefield. ebotet a club; a big stick; a cudgel. ebu a hyena (spotted – Crocuta crocuta; striped – Hyena hyena); a greedy person or glutton who eats anything and in large amounts. eicolong-ebu: a praying mantis. kinyami ebu kolek: you are so disgusting (literally, even the hyena will vomit on eating you). ebubaani frankincense; incense. ebukit1 a large reed basket.emuret: a basket for mixing and fermenting flour. eisowa: basket work for gourds. ebukit2 a herbaceous plant, Acalypha. ebuku a county; a skin or hide shield; a dwelling place; abode; armour. obukon bo ai?: obukon ne?: where do you come from? is this your home area? buka: my home. obuka: at my home. obuka: my home area. obukec: their home area. obukui: in (to) the countries abroad, overseas. obukusio kere: everywhere; the world over.ebulaayat a European man. ebule a tree in the ebobore and ebyong family, Ficus platyphylla. Its latex is medicine for ringworms. The latex is also the source of Niger Gutta gum. The tree is good for soil improvement and conservation because of its fruit that attracts birds. ebuleesut a man slave; a man servant. ebulit grease stains around mouth (a sign that one has eaten oily or fatty food). ebulolo chicken flea; chicken louse.ebuloni (singular noun M) a morass; a bog or quagmire.ebulukucwa a species of bird named after the sound it makes, Crimson breasted shrike.ebulumuka at random, haphazardly, or indiscriminately. apotu ipolisin kibungaata itunga luediiyaete korot ebulumuka: the riot police beat demonstrators indiscriminately. ebune the sterile head of sorghum or millet (with black fungal spores). ebuni a castor oil plant, Cussonia arbore.ebur1 big, huge, plump. eburok acok: the potatoes are big. eburok ipon: she/he is big-lipped or thick-lippedebur2 a river bank; deep water, a fissure or deep hole in the rock; the deepest part of the lake, hole, pit, or crevice. ebura (singular noun M) claiming of a debt; debt-collection. ebure1 (singular noun M) (formerly) a variety of sorghum. ebure2 (singular noun M) a method or manner of covering, sheathing or binding (of book, a sword, spear, etc). eburiged a brigade (a number of battalions). eburoit a grass, Eragrostis chalcantha. eburu a boring bee. eburuka a plant, Euphorbia.eburukunyu a large grasshopper; a mushroom (when first emerging). eburwoi a drop (of water or any liquid).eburwoit a swollen scar; a keloid. aiger iburwo: to make tribal marks, engravings, tattoos, or incisions. ebus a blue monkey, Centropithecus mitis stuhlmannii. ebusi (of beings, spirits) immortal; eternal. ebusiat a male slave; a male servant; one who stays with a chief to get food or clothes (a parasitic person); a draught ox (that pulls carts or ploughs). ebusibus a tree, Steganotaenia araliacea.
