Its root extract is used as a liniment for rheumatism or sciatica. ebutono (of a living thing, especially a person) eternal; living for long. ebutot a young mudfish; a young ebileng (mudfish) ebutuura a fruit-eating bird resembling a parrot (with a slightly curved beak) with red and black feathers. ebuu a shrub, Ficus sur. ebuubuu1 (of an animal) spotted or dappled brown (like a hyena). ebuubuu2 a shrub, Allophylus subceriaceus. ebuune shame; embarrassment. ebuune lokakou: swelling of the head on account of shame; blushing. abu nges akou kobutu nealimokinia eong nges akiro ngun: she/he blushed when I told her/him that. ebuunit (of a gland or anything) swollen; bloated; enlarged; engorged; inflated. ebuyat spear grass, Imperata cylindrica. ebuyu a mole rat; a honey badger, Mellivora capensis. ebwaade a large bird of prey in the eagle family; a male prostitute; a man who is always going about looking for food; a loafer.ebwacit a barren man; an impotent man; a homosexual; a gay. araus ebwacit: (of a man) to be impotent or homosexual. araun ebwacit: (of a man) to become gay, barren or homosexual. ebwaet a bracket; a fence; a hedge. ebwalaana (of a person) slow; negligent. ebwalai a tree of ebule family, Gymnosporia senegalensis & gracilipes. ebwanaterak (formerly) a variety of sweet quick-maturing cassava (a famine crop for newly married women).ebwiino ink. ebwikinitai compulsory. ebwolo a custard apple bush, Annona senegalensis. Its root is a deadly poison for eyes, the fruit is edible, and the liquid from the pounded and boiled roots is a dressing for septic wounds (in livestock) and snake bites. The bark is a dye. ebwolococo a tree, Lannea barteri. ebwonor (formerly) a variety of cassava. ebworon a mourner; the bereaved; a fierce person or animal. ebwos a multi-mammate mouse (literally, a rat which eats the abwo of old women).ebyong a tree resembling ebobore and ebule and whose bark is used for fibre and the wood for charcoal burning -Ficus glumosa. ecaai (singular noun M) tea (beverage). ecaai lo atibong: evening tea. ecaalo the village; upcountry; the rural area. ecaalo kosi ejai Katakwi: our village is in Katakwi district. iponesio lukocaalo: village mannerisms. ecaaman a chairman. ecabicabi (of a water body or sky) cloudless; clear. ecaboi a vegetable whose root extracts are drank to stimulate childbirth, Gynandropsis pentaphylla.ecak-eupa a greedy man or boy who searches for food after feeling the hearth warm with the foot.(A nickname given to a man or boy who tests whether ashes are warm to find out whether anything has been cooked. This kind of person always searches a house for food if he discovers that the hearth is warm). ecamuna acceptable, agreeable, compliant. ecamusana a bribe, a kickback; bribery. ecanit grief; trouble, misery, poverty; adversity; affliction; sorrow. kakotos eong ican ka Okula aiyar: I am in great poverty or misery (comparable only to a dog – Okula). lok’ican : poor man. aanyun ican: to get in trouble or misery. aanyunit eong ican: I am in great misery. ianyunit ican: well well, you have got problems. ecar a traditional heart-shaped hoe used for weeding a finger millet crop.ecawoit a plant, Alpima mutica. ece- (masculine adverbial prefix) some; another; more. ecekaru another year. ecekiliokit: another man. ecebore something; another thing.ececelu gland in the groin; the groin. eceelet a small elevation or hill; a protrusion. eceeret a species of black bird; ox-pecker, Buphagos. ecegere fork of a tree; a traditional three-legged stool; a lamp stand.ecekana ekesa ngol: that guy is very hairy. ecekem (of ground, vegetables, bed) thoroughly wet, soaking wet. ecekereng (Ateso Ateso) a tree in the acacia family, Acacia hockii. ecelana noisy; irritable; excitable; quarrelsome. ecelana aberu kon: your wife is quarrelsome. ecelet noise; a clamour; a quarrel; a shout; a row; an uproar; tumult; conflict; discord. ejai ecelet ore lo: there is a row in this home. ecen a nephew on sister’s side (from the point of view of the woman’s brother). (note: on brother’s side these are called okoku: son).ecepa a fork-tailed drongo, Dicrurus spp. ecepe insignia; stars or diamonds as signs of rank in the armed forces; shoulder epaulettes. eceroono striped; hooped; lined; banded.ecetunganan (indefinite pronoun M) someone; somebody.eceu (singular noun M) a guinea-worm, Dracunculus. ecici (singular noun M) a grass used for making idula (mud-and-grass granaries), Laudelia simplex; a climbing plant. Rhoicissus erithrodes. ecicikwa a small wild creeping sisal plant, Aloe vera. Its juice is used in the manufacture of modern cosmetics. Traditionally, the leaves are roasted and the liquid squeezed is smeared on the itching foot as a remedy. ecigwa a plant, Solanum dudiflorum. ecii1 a fungus on crops. ecii2 a species of grasshopper. eciidait a hookworm; a tapeworm.eciirit one of the bells tied on the leg and worn by men for dancing. ecilaboi a grass that grows in swamps and used for making brooms, Sporobolus indica. ecilet1 a stream; a rivulet; a swamp or marsh joining two water masses. ecilet2 a thong for fastening child on back. eciletait one of the four leather thongs of anapet. ecilikiki a double-edged knife resembling a spear (about 15 centimetres in length). ecilil1 torn; split. loecilil eponoi: a man with a hare-lip. ecilil2 an oryx, Beisa Oryx. ecirit a dancing pellet-bell tied on the lower leg.eco clever, cute, shrewd, cautious; (of chicken) grown up. ecoa a morass; a swamp; a bog or quagmire.ecobe clever; wise; adroit; intelligent; astute; shrewd. ecobe etelepat ngol: that boy is intelligent. ecoc a porcupine, Atherurus africanus. Its quill is mixed in a gourd with grain bound for planting as a ‘blessing’ to the grain.ecoco a misanthrope; a hater of people. ecocoot (of man or animal) rather clever, timid, timorous, shy; (of a chicken) rather big. ecocoot ekingok: the dog is timid, or afraid to be beaten. ecocoot eculot ngol, kikamutu kotuboi: that cockerel is rather big, catch it for slaughter. ecocot a hole in an anthill; a small hole in the anthill, an air passage for anthills. ecocote a misanthrope; a hater of men. ecododo a cripple.ecoe loka epiu: gall-bladder. ekot ejakait ecoe loka inusio: the chief wants a bag of money. ecoe loka ekulam: a urine bag; a urinary bladder.ecoget a strut; forked stick; pillar; prop.ecoitono prudent; careful; cautious; discreet; wise. acoitono eong atubitoi kokitwi: I am careful when making shortcuts through the bushes (wary of snakes). ecoka school chalk; lime. ecoke a tree, Ficus sp. ecokikinon one who herds (cattle, etc) for somebody; a hireling. ecokit a seed (in general); a kernel; a nut. ecokolet (singular noun M) chocolate. ecokolinga a red-necked lizard.ecokoliro a cock’s comb. ecokolokipi a mushroom growing in the swamp. ecokom (especially of meat) nice, juicy and tasty. ecokopita (singular noun M) cooked ecaboi or esukumawiki vegetable dish. ecolibe a coucal or bottle bird, Centropus senegalense. ecolooni a pit latrine.The foliage (ecomai) is vegetables in Usuk county during the dry season, edible oil is extracted from its seeds, the wood is termite resistant, crushed fruit and bark extract is used to purify water since it kills snails and waterfleas (cyclops) that carry bilharzia and guinea worms respectively. ecooga a he-goat paid to a fiancée’s father before dowry.

a man native to Gulu, Kitgum or Pader districts of northern Uganda. Icoolin: the Acholi people.ecooro a lung disease of fowls, Coccidiosis. ecoot careful; clever; wary. ecooto an engine; the core, the heart of a machine or automobile. ecopile a kind of grass. ecopot a pupil of the eye; the eyeball. aitocoun icop: to look wise. ecor a lake; a well; a river.angolol: sea. ecorai a variety of edible mushrooms. ecoro a water plant, Pistia. ecoroko (singular noun M) green grams.ecounet a sense (of sight, hearing, etc). ecucukwa aloe plant. ecucut a (house) fly. ecucut lomelomelo: a bluebottle (fly). ingai iirana inyamat? ecucut: (a riddle) who always likes tasting food? a housefly. ecudet harmful witchcraft; any eccentric or abnormal behaviour in people; a charm; cannibalism; night-dancing. ecue a bag; bladder; urinary bladder. ecuet wine-press or a press in general; a squeezer (for lemons, etc); a wringer (for clothes). ecugasa a plant, Solanum nudiflorum. ecugur high shouldered; hunched back; stooping. ecukat a draft ox. iso icukai lukane: we are the draft-oxen of this place i.e. doing the heavy work. ecuke the act of encouraging animosity between others; intrigue, mischief. kocoite etunganan ngol, iswamai ngesi nuka ecuke: beware of that man, he is an intriguer. ecukean a person who encourages others to start a fight; an inciter; an instigator. ecukia a flower, Leonotis. eculetait a spot of dirt; a stain on anything or on character. egoe lo ileleba iculeta: this cloth is full of stains.eculokina stained, tainted, blemished, or marked; out of place; intruding or interfering. eculokinet a spot of dirt; a stain on anything or on character. egoe lo ileleba iculokineta: this cloth is full of stripes. eculuculo chequered; spotted. eris erai etyang loeculuculo emukule: a leopard is a spotted animal. ecumacuma a plant that encourages lactation. ecupa a bottle. inyo ibore yenimam enyami, kodiding akituk, kopol akoik? ecupa: (riddle) what is it that does not eat, yet has a small mouth and a big stomach? a bottle. ecur a hawk. ecura a toilet cleaner; a night soil man. ecuramol (singular noun M) (slang) dry gin; crude distilled alcohol named after a bitter anti-malarial trademark drug (curamol).ecurukileng a kind of edible root. ecus a vagina (human).ecuude a tuft of hair left on the head of human beings (especially small children, or on women who have once born twins) at the time of shaving; a crest (of feathers) on heads of birds. ecuuma an iron tool; a spanner; a factory; a ginnery. ecuuma loka epaaba: a cotton ginnery. ecuuma loesukaali: a sugar mill. ecuuma loigoen: a textile factory. ecuwe a bird, lily-trotter.ecwarenit a bed-bug. ecwataarat a mongrel; a man with Somali features or origin; a half-cast or mulatto. ecwenene (singular noun M) an edible grasshopper.ecwi a metallic necklace. ecwilil an oryx, Beisa oryx.edakiika a minute. idakiikan akais akany kape ejaas osaawa ediope: sixty minutes are in an hour. edal a bird, yellow widow. edalac a tree, Ficus glumosa. The ripe figs are edible, while the wood is for charcoal burning. edaladalakisin an inedible wild cucumber plant, Cucubitaceae. edamok empty; having nothing inside.edangala (formerly) a variety of cassava. edanyot a sheanut; the seed of ekungur.edapaic a woman’s undergarment; a tampon; a rag.edapal flat; level; even. edapal akekou: her/his head is flat. edasit a whip; a scourge; a lash or whip made of plaited cowhide, used at asapan initiation ceremony.edauna complete; absolute; finished. abeit naedauna: an absolute truth. ejaas ajon osokooni? mam, edauna: is there beer in the market? no, it is finished. eringa edauna: not yet finished or it is not yet complete.edaunit ample; sufficient.edawoi a castrated bull; an ox.ededeng fierce; bellicose; strict; cruel; severe; furious; harsh; wild; malignant; unkind; hard; difficult; barbaric; savage. etyang loededeng: a fierce animal. edeet (singular noun M) trypanosomiasis in cattle; nagana; sleeping sickness in animals caused by tsetse flies. edege an aeroplane; an aircraft. kede edege: by air; by plane; in an aeroplane.edeidei1 (formerly) a red variety of sorghum. edeidei2 a pustule. ejai eong edeidei: ideideit eong akuwan: I have pustules. edeideit a grass, Perotis indica. edek1 a grass, Cynodon plectostachion. edek2 a sauce made of crushed beans or peas cooked in amakadi. edeke1 a deity of calamity; syphilis; gonorrhoea; a pestilence; rinderpest; a plague; a spirit or god of calamity. ejai edeke toma akituk: there is rinderpest amongst the cattle. aidede naka edeke: show signs of infestation with flukes.Edeke2 (singular noun M) God (to an Anglican Protestant Christian). Edeke Lokapedor kere: God the Omnipotent. Edeke Lokalaunan: God the holy one. ejai Edeke toma akuj: God is in heaven. edel pride; obstinacy; fractitiousness. mam akoto edel kus: I do not like your obstinacy, pride. edengerot a grass for covering roofs (thatching), Hyparrheni. edep a swarm; a big crowd of offspring (locusts, bees, children). shoal of fish. ijo bo naejai edep: you with your swarm of children (women-to-women insult). edep loka agaria: a shoal of fish.edeparit beyond; exceedingly; very; more than, better than, more, etc. ideparit ijo eong kapolou: you are older than me. edepidepit a flea. edere a big calabash used to protect children’s heads against the sun and rain. ederepa a driver (of a car). ederit a bushbuck, Tragelaphus scriptus.edes gonorrhoea. edetekewai a kind of bush with the adetekewa berries, Rhus glaucescens. edia vegetables in general; relishes. ediasit (singular noun M) relishes; different types of vegetables. edideo a hoopoe, Nile- kakelaar. ediding narrow; slender. ediding akonye: narrow-eyed. ediding ekek: the door is narrow. ediding ijo aomisio: you are narrow-minded. edidiot a species of bird, Helmet shrike. edidit a grass, Perotis indica eragrostis. edie die face-to-face; vis-à-vis; closely; at close range; at short distance. korem etyang edie die: spear the animal at close range. edieranakinan a donor; a distributor; a generous (liberal) person. ediguri a university degree award. adumunit eong ekadiguri loka agwelanar ko Makerere Yunibasite, edipoloma da Makerere Yunibasite: I obtained my commerce degree in Makerere University, and the diploma also at Makerere.ediiga a ram; a male sheep.ediiro a lobby, a passage, or a lounge of a house. ediisi (formerly) a DC - district commissioner (a representative of the central government administration in a district). ediit a tsetse fly; a short-sighted person. edijerane (singular noun M) a kind of eruption, rash or herpes around the mouth after a fever. edikait a milk curd. ediket a leech. edikisyonari a dictionary; a glossary; a lexicon. edikonit an Anglican Church deacon. edila (singular noun M) a common vegetable of wild pea leaves.edilidilit a growth on the earlobe or on the little finger; ear-rings; keloids on face. ediliwas a kind of poisonous snake.ediloi (singular noun M) the spinal cord.edimasita a headmaster; a head teacher.edingana ngesi: she/he is very hostile. edinget hatred; enmity; misunderstanding; contention. edino a penis; a male sexual organ.edinyot a grass, Panicum maximum. edio- prefix preceding a masculine noun, denoting a few; a little of; some. koinakinai idisinyamat: give me a little food. koinunai ediogoe: bring me some cloth. ediobore (indefinite pronoun M) anything; a scrap (of something). ediocici just a little. ediokasilon very little.edioli a vegetable eaten during the dry season, Maerua angolensis. ediolidioli slippery; smooth. ediolidioli etogo loka abikiran: the floor of the nuns’ house is smooth and slippery. ediope diope M (numeral adverb, used with singular masculine nouns) one by one; one after another; singly. aidome emaido ediope diope: to eat groundnuts one at a time. kolomanasi ediope diope: go in one by one. kopotu ediope diope: come one by one, singly. ediopet M (numeral adjective) one. ediopet emong: one bull. ekoroi ediopet: one billy goat. ediotai a little; some; a bit. koinakinai edia ediotai: give me just a little sauce. ediotitai a little; some. koinakinai esukaali ediotitai: give me some sugar. ediotunganan (indefinite pronoun M) any man.edipal1 stumpy; dwarfish. akiteng adipal: a dwarfish cow. mam akoto adipal ngin: I don’t want that dwarf (cow or woman). edipal2 a dwarf (or anything stunted in growth) edipoloma a college or university diploma certificate award.ikosimwalimun luipu ejaatar idipoloman luka aisisianakin luko Ngeta, Nagongera, Kyambogo arai bo Kamuli: most of our teachers have their teaching diploma certificates from Ngeta, Nagongera, Kyambogo or perhaps Kamuli national teachers colleges. edipor beeswax; saliva of mudfish, with which it protects itself by clouding clear water. edir a species of bird, Yellow-backed pytilia.edira communal labour in return for beer in future.edirikori a long-tailed bird - Coly edirikwap (formerly) a deep rooting variety of sweet potatoes. edirio a species of bird - Paradise whydah. edirisa a window (in general). idirisa: a small window. ediro a small antelope, dik-dik, Rhynchotragus kirkii.erai Katakwi da edistrikt loka Uganda: Katakwi is also a district of Uganda. edit (predicative adjective) little; tiny; modest; small; trivial; unimportant; childish. idisiak yesi: you are small; you are childish. not very; barely; hardly. (pronoun) not much. edit: loedit: (plural) luedisiak. akoto luedisiak arai nuedisiak: I want the small ones. apesur nuedisiak: the small girls.aikidiokut: fewness. edita1 (formerly) a variety of bananas. edita2 a big reed basket.edita3 an editor of a newspaper or a book, etc. editiana childish; silly; immature. edoan weeds in general; a grass that prefers unfertile soil, Rhynchelytrum repens. edobo a big fishing hook.edodet the index finger; a signpost; an instrument for pointing out, like a speedometer needle on a car or motor cycle. ebokorit lododet: index finger. edodoi a sausage tree, Kigelia africana.Its fruit is believed to increase sweet-potato yield if buried in the garden, and the leaves are applied as a liniment for mumps. Dye can be got from its cut and boiled sausage fruit. edodor quick; easy; hasty; quick to learn; liable to; quick tempered; easily heated; early-ripening. edodor amot na: this cooking pot heats up quickly. edodot the vagina.edoel slender; emaciated. edoi a whip made of rope or grass and used to drive locusts away, or for youths lashing each other. eleas itunga k’idoyan: people lash each other with whips. edoket1 an immaturely harvested groundnut seed when dry; wrinkled and sterile groundnuts removed from choice seeds in shelling (usually eaten raw). edoket2 a bridge; a harbour; a landing site; a ford. edokita a male doctor (who administers western medicine).edokole epiglottis (a flap that prevents food from entering the windpipe).edokolet a vervet monkey, Cercopithecus aethiops. edokomuny a serval cat, Leptailurus serval. edokor a thin person. edola1 a chronic topical (skin) ulcer on the leg or other part of the body; incurable wound.edola2 a dollar (currency of the USA). edolit enough; adequate; sufficient.edome a gum tree of which the fruit juice is used as gum, Cordia sinensis; the fruit of this tree. The leaves are used as sandpaper, the fruit is edible and also produces glue. The wood is good for making bows.
Enyakoit: a man from the north

(formerly) Sunday. edomo1 a hook or harpoon for hippo hunting.edomo2 (singular noun M) tertiary yaws.edonga (singular noun M) a kind of dance (originating from Karamoja but popular in Adacar, Ngariam and Magoro sub-counties in Katakwi district) involving leaping high up and down, in which no musical instrument is used apart from hand-clapping by the chorus

a leap; a jump.edongana persevering; persistent; insisting; determined; in the habit of pinching. edongana ekesa ngol: that guy is very persistent/determined/fond of pinching. edonge a castrated animal; an ox; a bullock; a eunuch; impotent man.edongodongot a cow bell. edongol akonye hollow-eyed. edongororot the elbow.edonyis a sewing needle.edonyony sewn; stitched; patched; embroidered. edoodoo1 a big variety of mango fruit or plant.edoomelu an edible mole or cane rat with a white-tipped tail.edoos (of a person or animal) slightly built; weak. etelepat loedoos: a poorly-built boy; a weakling. edoot a grey salty anthill. ikocete akituk edoot: cows lick and eat the grey anthill clay (as a kind of salt). edo-piric a little bird that lands with a lot of hullabaloo. Robin chat. edopudopu a boring beetle; the powder ejected by the boring beetle. edoret an enemy.edoronyit a dog's vomit; cat's vomit; anything repulsive through the mouth. (fingurative) dirty talk. koyangaa ekonidoronyit ngina: go away with your nonsense! take your obscenity elsewhere. adum eong kesi ineras nukidorony: I got them talking their obscenity, dirty talk, shameful talk.edos egg yolk; (of animals) first milk after birth – colostrum.edosoono yellow. edote an adulterer; a fornicator.edoteana loose loving; immoral; adulterous; lecherous. aberu naedote: a loose-living woman. edou a cloud; rain; thunder. etepi edou loepol: there is a lot of rain. aberu naka Okiru erai edou: Okiru’s wife is of a bitter scolding disposition (she is a thunderbolt). anangar idowon (euphemism): (of a person) to die (literally, to penetrate the clouds). edou lodaset or akiru nadaset: early rains for breaking new ground or clearing the fields. edu a sheanut tree, Butyrospermum paradoxum.edude2 (Kaberamaido) the buttock; the butt; the bums; the arse. edudu a species of bird, Bell cuckoo-shrike or Plantain eater. edudumak (formerly) DDT insecticide spray for termites. edudumeri a very small dove or pigeon with black head. edudut1 a bush, Cassia mimu soides. edudut2 the Bakenye (a fisher tribe on the shores of lakes Kyoga and Bisina) (an insult); the bird which goes and ducks into the water for fish.eduele a dwarf mouse, Leggada bella. eduidui a species of small bird, Cordon bleu.eduke style of building, constructing. ejokuna eduke kec Iusuko: the building or thatching style of people from Usuk is good (thatching ascends in rows up to the peak). edukokina married. eraas kesi luedukokina: they are married people. etogo loedukokina ne: a house built here. edukono fast or clever at building or architectural work. erai ngesi loedukono: he is a fast builder. edukudukut African fan palm, Borassus aethiopium. Its hollowed boles are used for beehives, the seed and fruit are edible, the fibre is used for making ekodo (beer sieves), and the leaves are a thatch. edukuru a small hut as for calves or sick people; a camp; a booth; a cottage.edula a big non-movable grass, mud and cow-dung granary, built up and shaped like a huge water pot on a base of timber, which rests on posts or stones as protection against termites; a food store.edulagol a guinea fowl-like eagle. edulo a tree, Ficus sur. Its leaves are used as goodluck amulets, the wood is for carving mortars and troughs, and the shade is used in ceremonies. edulukait a tree, Acacia mildbraedii. edunyana indefatigable; exacting; zealous; industrious; persevering. edunyaka apesur ngun: those girls are very zealous. edupuk soft (as of cloth); loose (as of sand, dust, flour); fine (as of flour). edupuk apuna: the apuna grass is soft (to the touch). asinge nadupuk: loose sand. eduro (formerly) a variety of millet. edurukoi Apple-ring acacia tree, Acacia albida. The tree is a good ceremonial shade and nitrogen fixer, the leaves and pods are good fodder, and the wood is for firewood. edusuku (formerly) a variety of short sorghum.edusutau (singular noun M) a love potion to stimulate love; an aphrodisiac.etunganan loerai ekadutan iboro: a generous man (generous with things). edutat a gift; contribution; endowment; a present, reward. eduwan (singular noun M) weeds.edwalaana lazy; lax (in cleaning teeth or in anything) (an insult of a big-bodied weakling).edwaliro a hospital; a clinic. odwaliro: at or to the hospital. edwar1 a kind of grass. edwar2 bitter; biting; sour; pungent; acrid; sarcastic; sharp and harsh cutting. edwar ekia ria ria: the drug is very bitter. edwar akitukuke: she/he is sarcastic in her/his speech (i.e. she/he makes biting remarks). edwar Eloket etau, kipedori aicum: the Karimojong rustler is quick tempered, he may spear you any time. edwar: to be in the act of, to be occupied. edwar nges ainyam: she/he is eating. edwarai a bush from which salt is extracted, Vernonia grantii. edwaramany a kind of fish (with bitter liver?). edwasi a disease, Haematuria bilharzia. edweet (in a bad sense) a crowd of children.edweli a kind of tree (with edible fruit). edwesisit (in a bad sense) a crowd of children.edwokai (singular noun F) vanity; self-importance; affectedness; snobbishness; pretentiousness. edyamakou (formerly) a variety of sorghum.edyera (formerly) a variety of finger millet (eleusin) or sorghum with long scattered ears. ee yes.eebo yes; aye; yes indeed. eeburan a claimant (of debt, etc); a debt collector.eebusianan a drudge; one who works hard for little pay. eebwalaan an enticer; one who keeps another from working; a negligent and slow-working person. eebwanan a laureate. eebwanyan a gatecrasher; an intruder into parties; an uninvited guest; a parasite. eebwokan a porter who carries things for others; a carrier. eeca yes indeed. eeca bo: yes, of course. eeciran a milker; a milkman.eecodon a person who limps; a cripple.eecokon akituk: a herdsman; eecokon amerekekin: a sheperd.eecololon a hypocrite; a fraud; a charlatan. ekecololon ijo: you are a hypocrite. eecoran a counsel; an adviser; a counsellor; a guru. eecukon a welder; a hot iron brander; an inciter (to a quarrel or a fight). eedaan a man who buries; grave digger; a mourner; an undertaker. eedaran a watchman; a guardian; a keeper; a protector; a waiter; a curator; a foster-parent.eede pretending; under pretext; seemingly; with deceit or sham under pretence of. abu ngesi neajai eong ican eede: she/he came to me pretending to cry of poverty. sirikilip eede: do not act as if you were praying; do not pretend to pray.eegangan an ally, a pleader, a lawyer, an advocate. eeja aunt. eejaka: my aunt.eejaanakinan a constant or regular attendant or protégée. eejerukon an unmanageable, disobedient, unruly, defiant, disloyal, or seditious man. eejo look! hear! eejo nges: look at him; hear him!. eejo eejo: hear, hear! eejodon a sycophant; toady; flatterer.eekaan a hunter, a seeker; a persecutor, a tormentor, a bully, a tyrant, an oppressor, or an intimidator.eekeon a carpenter; a carver; an engraver; an etcher. eekoban a transcriber; one who copies; one who transmits or passes on. eelaman a curser; a high-jumper (in athletics). eelipan a beggar; one who prays, begs, or asks. eelipat a habitual beggar; a tramp. eelu a tree bearing edible round black fruit called aelut or akarukwait, Markhamia platycalix. eema1 truly; yes indeed; so it is. eema, ilim ijo ejok: yes, you are right.eema2 a tent; a tarpaulin; canvas.eemanimanan inspector, examiner, checker, superintendent, overseer, assessor, supervisor. eemorikikinan a mediator; a reconciler.eemukean medical staff; a nurse (male or female). eemunonan one who conceals; an obscurantist; a doctrinaire; an obfuscator. eemut news; rumours; a report. kolimokinai iyemuto luka akwapukus: tell me the news of your country.eenat a prisoner; the one to be tied. eenen tied up; bound up; fastened; packed. eeneran a speaker (the person, not the machine); an orator; a lecturer; a presenter; a narrator; a spokesman. eenet a prison; a lock; a thing for tying. eengadan a treasurer; a keeper (of things in a store). eengalan a liar; a pretender; a con artist; a fraudster. eengarakinan a helper; an assistant; an accomplice (to a crime). eengarenikinon a leader; a guide; a director; a manager. eengarenon a leader; a director; an organizer; a manager. eengitan a questioner; an inquirer; an examiner like Uganda National Examinations Board. eengomingomon a gobbler; a greedy person. eenyagan a robber; a bandit; an organized thief or thug.eenyamiton an escort; an aide; a guide; a body guard.eenyoolan a driver of a motorcar. eepitan a livestock breeder; one who rears (animals or people) to maturity. eepitak ibaren: livestock breeders. eepoon a cook; a chef.eepugan a ruler; a governor; a head of state; a monarch; a sovereign. eeputan amuk a shoe-shiner. eeraban a speaker (in an assembly); a judge, a lawyer; a talkative man; a pleader, or a barrister. eereere a tree, Trema orientalis. Uses: the fruit is edible; leaves, pods, seeds are used as fodder; black dye is made from bark, brown dye from leaves; oil is extracted from seeds; the leaves are used as an antidote for poison; leaves are also medicine for deworming and cough; and the tree's shedding of leaves is an indicator of the planting time for finger millet. eerimon a tramp; a vagabond; a rover; a vagrant; a hobo; a hawker. eerionokinan a pessimist; a naysayer; a cynic; a person who throws cold water on everything good; a wet blanket. eerumunan a heir; an inheritor; a successor; progeny; a catcher-up (in a race). eerurwon a raider; a robber; a plunderer; an organized cattle rustler.eerut a edible wild plant root, Courbonia virgata. eeryonon an African; a Black person.
(adjectival suffix) bluish-grey. eeseana of bluish-grey appearance or colour. eesiaan a beginner

a novice; a starter; a learner; an innovator. eesicatan a supporter; a backer; a sponsor. eesidikon an inciter; an agitator; an instigator; a mastermind; an organizer. eesidounon a mid-man; a midwife.eesisian a student; a learner; a pupil. eesisianakinan a teacher; a schoolmaster; a professor. eesisiaunan a man or boy who has just acquired knowledge; a learner; a pupil; a novice. eesomesan (archaic) a man who teaches reading and writing; a teacher for lower primary school. eesupan a wooer; a campaigner; an amorous man; an intriguer. eeswaman a workman; worker; an agent; an employee. eetajaran a saviour; a rescuer; a reviver.eetanan a feeder; a nurse. eetelemunan one who causes something to be removed. eetelemunan esolo: a tax-collector; a tax assessor. eeteleman epaaba: a supervisor or headman of cotton sorters or pickers. eetelemunan eluk: one who causes payment of a fine by another committing adultery. eeteon a guardian; one who looks after; a spectator; an onlooker. eetimon a merciful or forgiving person. eetisian one who aids another to escape. eetisilan a confessor (in penance). eetobwoan one who makes somebody to stand up, i.e. an accuser. eetumunon one who promises or pledges. eewadikan a writer; a journalist; an author; a secretary. eeworon a talkative person; a loud caller; a taxi or bus broker or tout.eeyuunan a believer; one who agrees; one of the faithful. egaala vegetables cooked without groundnut paste. ainyam egaala: to be poor (unable to afford groundnuts). egaali a bicycle. alosi eong ka egaali: I go on bicycle. egaaso a big refugee camp; a settlement for the poor or the internally displaced people. egaat (formerly) a variety of arid-cultivated sorghum used for making beer; a grass, Sorghum verticilliflorum. egada a species of elephant grass used as reeds for building, Gennisetum purpureum. egagarikina disruptive; obstrusive; awkward; obstructive; unhelpful; obstreperous. egagarikina ngesi ne: she/he/it is too big for this place. igagarikina ijo toma aswam ngin: you are too big for that (small) task. egala a shrub, Lannea stuhlmannii. egalala vegetables cooked in water only i.e. without appetisers or flavourings. egalunak a mob; a rabble; crowd of rioters. egamira a camel.egaraama an expense; a cost; a charge; a hazard or a difficulty.igaraaman luiyatakina: additional costs. egarai a small tree, Lannea schweinfurthii subsp. stuhlmannii. Its fruit is edible, the roots, bark and leaves have medicinal properties. The wood is used for firewood, timber and charcoal burning. egaraji a garage, i.e. where cars are kept, or a place where cars are bought, sold, or repaired. egasia a tree, Senna spectabilis. A tree used for bee forage, firewood and shade. egasit cursing someone on an anthill; wishing someone ill-luck or misfortune. aicum epuu: to curse someone by sticking a sewing needle in epuu stem. egecit a small spur of birds; a small bone behind hoof of cattle.araito nuegeget: half-ripe or astringent fruits. egeget2 cashewnut tree.egego the shoulder or wing of a bird killed for food.egeit antecedent; previous; preceding; earlier; prior; before. egela a stranger; a different person; an alien. abu eong kadum etunganan egela: I met a stranger. differently; variously. ibunit ijo egela: you have come differently or for quite a different reason different.egelara different, diverse, altered, changed, unlike, dissimilar, unrelated; extraneous; strange, odd, bizarre, weird, extraordinary, eccentric, unfamiliar; alien, Martian, inappropriate, off the point, unconnected. egelegela varied; unlike; dissimilar; of many different kinds; different, not the same. egelegela iponesio luka itunga: people’s characters, customs, or manners are different. egelit a debt; a fine; obligation, liability; compensation, recompense, reward, damages, costs, reparation, or reimbursement. egerec a species of frog.

an Anglican Christian (man). egereger a monitor lizard, Varanus nilotica. egereset an embrocation; a massage. egeu a blue monkey, Cercopithecus mitis.egeye1 a black and white colobus monkey, Colobus polykomos.egigit a kind of euphorbia plant.egiilo a borehole pump (named after a pioneer driller in Teso in the 1940s, S. Gill). egilaasi a beaker; a tumbler; a wineglass; a cup; a chalice.egiligilet a tobacco case made of a cow horn. egilut a ring (on nose or ear of animal). egingilyici a grass, Branchiaria brizantha. egirigiran a clerk; a scribe. egirigirio a species of bird, Great spotted cuckoo. egirigiroi a tree, Acacia campylacantha. egirikoca bone cancer; stomach or cervical cancer (often causing haemorrhage in women). egiro a grass, Echinochloa pyramidalis. egirone (singular noun M) divorce; separation; split of marriage.egita2 a water shrimp. egitara different; unlike. egitigita different; unknown; separate; dissimilar. egita ibore ngin: that thing is unknown. egitu a plant, Echinops amplexicaulis. egoe a cloth; clothing; a dress; a garment; a costume.egogong strong; energetic; hardy; severe; strict; hard; firm; difficult; burly. egogong akirokus: your case is difficult. egogong akonye: barefaced; brazen; shameless; blatant; bold; unashamed. egogong akituk argumentative; quarrelsome; confrontational; belligerent; aggressive; challenging; irascible; hard to give in; contrary. egogong akou stubborn; obstinate; inflexible; wilful; mulish; hard-headed; obdurate; intractable. egogot intestinal worm.egole an African white-spotted harrier hawk, Polyboroides radiatus.egoleono grey-spotted. egoliam a tall thin person. egolis a door; anything for shutting or locking the door or window; a shutter; a screen or blind. egologolot a goat bell made from a hollowed coconut kernel.egolokino barred; impenetrable; shut; locked; blocked up; choked up; clogged up; jammed. egolol shut; locked; closed; blocked. egolol erot: the way is blocked (no thoroughfare). egoloro excluded or exclusive; barred; disqualified; debarred; expelled; restricted; limited; select. egolu a gaff or a big metal fishhook attached to a string.egoluno included or inclusive; built-in; incorporated; integrated; all-encompassing. egomas a cassock-like polyester or silk dress for women; a tunic.egongakina contiguous; close; nearby; adjacent; adjoining; proximate; neighbouring; leaning on. egongor a large green mantis with thin legs.egoolo a goal (post or score in a football game). egooro uvula; epiglottis. egoreara hidden, concealed, out of sight, veiled, secluded; remote, isolated, tucked away. egoria root of water lily. egorigor (singular noun M) whooping cough; bronchitis.egorogoro a feeble person; an invalid; a weak person. egoromoit (formerly) a variety of groundnuts that creep and bears more than three big grey seeds in a pod, harvested by digging up with a hoe. egoroopa a double or multi-storeyed house. egudugudwi a plant, Acalypha. egulugulut expanded sides of stomach (as of goat after feeding). egunia a gunny bag; a sack.egura the spine; the backbone; the upper part of a book; a midrib of leaves; veins of leaf; a keel of a boat. ogura: on the back; on the spine. kenomata kesi eong ogura toma: they have hit me exactly on the spine. egureedi a grade; a quality; a category. egurum a garden or field mouse, Arvicanthis.eguruupu a group; a gang; a clique; a set. eguruupu lok’isekan: a select group. eguti a kind of edible mushroom. egutit a small grasshopper. eguudo a highway; a main road; a street. egwaigwai eczema; mange. egwali a grass, Chloris virgate.egwang a wild cat that catches chicken, Felis silvestris.egwangira (singular noun M) a bitter vegetable, the wild cousin to emalakany, whose leaf is rubbed on the cheeks of a person due for tooth extraction, Hibiscus cannabinus. egwapet1 a tree, Steganotaenia araliacea. Its root has medicinal properties. egwapet2 an eland, Taurotragus oryx. egwari a kind of thorn-bush. egwaunana aggressive; violent; provocative; antagonistic; hostile; bellicose. egwegwet1 a flea; chicken louse.egwegwet2 a very poisonous and dangerous tree snake, Green mamba.egwei (singular noun M) indigestion; dyspepsia; flatulence. eijer egwei: to belch on account of indigestion. egwele a species of eagle, Bateleur eagle. egweleke a grass, Commersoni. egwelet1 a bush, Hoslundia opposita. egwelet2 a price; a value; a sale. egwelet loka epaaba ekaru lo ejok: the price of cotton is very high this year. egwelit a bribe; bribery (by buying favours).
a man from Gweri sub-county in Soroti county. Igweritok: people from Gweri sub-county in Soroti. egworon a mourner

the bereaved. eibel1 greed; lust; craving; gluttony; extreme hunger. eibel2 pimples or a rash around the head after hair-cut, or due to measles, chicken pox, etc healing up after a week. eibelit scale of fish, crocodile, or snake. eibibia (singular noun M) a sickness which makes the body brown, makes it swell and feel unwell. eibidaet fishing hook.eibidas a fishing hook.eibobo a house lizard.eibuga a city; a town (of Kampala’s size).eibulesene (singular noun M) slavery; serfdom. eibutone (singular noun M) a gift from an uncle towards marriage dowry of the nephew. eibwanyane intruding into drinking parties; gate-crashing. eibwong (singular noun M) applause; acclamation; incantation. eibworone (singular noun M) (formerly) an initiation ceremony for youths and adult men to senior age groups (especially to married life).eic a string snare for catching rats; a trap. musi eici da kitilim akiro, konye akuluma dupuk-dupuk: perhaps the string trap may make you shout, but the stone trap kills you right away. eicegera a fork of a tree; a traditional three-legged stool; a lamp stand.eico a large pot, tall, with a fairly small neck, used mainly for storing liquids. eicod (singular noun M) limping; hobbling; hopping. eicodet a crutch. eicolong a chair; a traditional bobbin stool; any seat. eicolong-ebu a praying mantis. eicorakina commandment; a rule; a mandate; a ban; a behest. eicum (singular noun M) a duel or fight with spears. eicur (singular noun M) leaping or jumping; playing or dancing; jubilation. eicweane (singular noun M) a heart-burn. eidada poison given in food (makes the stomach swell); bane; a disease following poisoning. iidadasia: various kinds of poisons.eidedia (of anything) lying face up; lying on the back. eideng a sickness causing sores on arms, legs or fingers. eidenyet food for a journey.eidiko a cricket game or ball.eidil (singular noun M) abundance; profusion; concentration; plenty.eidilo cricket game or ball. eidiny (singular noun M) a groan; a sigh; a grunt; groaning.eidodikinet a pointer; an arrow road sign eidodo a wall or house lizard.eidon (singular noun M) ceaseless rain; (of rain or a leak in roof, etc) dropping.eiduka a shop; a kiosk; a stall. eiduka loepol: emporium; a supermarket; a booth. eidukula a kind of fishing basket or fishing trap.eiduma (in parts of Teso bordering Bantu-speaking areas) a maize plant or cob maize.eiduny neighbourhood; neighbourliness; proximity; nearness; closeness. toma oidunyete kon ejai loejeni aitemonokin igaalin: in your neighbourhood there is one who repairs bicycles. eidunyet a neighbour; the one near; a vicinity; neighbourhood; abutment. itunga luka eidunyete kon eroko: the people in your neighbourhood are bad. erai ngesi lokidunya ka eong: he is my neighbour. eiduporo a martyr; a sacrificial victim; a victim. eiduporo losodit kobaibuli nges Stepano Lokalaunan: the first martyr in the Bible was St. Stephen. eidyaset a gourd in which churned milk is kept.eidyatet a gourd in which churned milk is kept. eigang (singular noun M) an alliance; a coalition, mutual help or assistance; a detente.eiges (singular noun M) a staggering gait. eigoliro a load; a burden, kit. erai aswam na eigoliro: this work is a burden. eigoo a trading centre; a settlement (with a central market).eigwerane (singular noun M) herpes zoster lessions.eigworone (singular noun M) (a Serere version of eibworone) the initiation ceremony for youths and adult men to senior age groups.amotika ejai eiise loepol: my pot has a bad leak. eiit a granary made of twigs.eijaanakine (singular noun M) service; way of serving. mam akoto eijaanakine kooteeri kangol: I do not like the service in that hotel. eijaikina an offer, gift, present, contribution, reward, bequest, donation, endowment, or souvenir. eijaloga a plant, Acalypha. eijang1 a plant, Acalypha ornata. eijang2 a scoop fishing basket resembling a manger. eijang3 ki-a to shake; to rock; to move to and fro; to oscillate. eijek ki-o to be dangling. eijekelut a cockroach.eijer ki-a to belch. eijerane (singular noun M) belching; burping; letting out air through the mouth.eijiij dropsy (an abnormal accumulation of fluid in any part of the body). eijiliet a strainer; a filter; a sieve.eijin a motor engine.
(singular noun M) the Gospel (any of the New Testament books of Matthew, Mark, Luke and John)

the life and teachings of Christ. eijulauna a boy child delivered (born) with the legs coming out first – such a person is believed to have natural powers to paralyse the ‘enemy’ if he buried reptiles on enemy soil before a cattle raid.eijuluna a child surviving after others have died. cp eipolyauna eikaajo a sugarcane. aigit eikaajo: to eat sugarcane.eikep a hammer or round stone to roughen a grinding stone, or to pound dry potatoes, etc eikiiki a deciduous tree, Prosopis africana. Its dry fruit is used as a rattle and the sticks are used in making cricket bats in the game of eidiko. The timber is very hard. The fruit and bark are used in making tannin and dye. eikit a grass used for making carrying pads.eikito food leftover from the night before, used for breakfast. eikoi a kind of white cloth (ekikoi) with red stripes at both ends. eikong a hammer; a mallet. eikopo a cup; a chalice; a cruet. eikoru a frontier; a boundary; a dividing line; a periphery. eilat a stroll, walk, hike. alot ngesi eilat: she/he has gone for a visit, or for a stroll. eiliili scary; intimidating; frightening. eiliilete akaninika: my hands are very dirty. eiliili emun: a snake is frightening, strikes fear into one. eiliili akouke: she/he is swollen-headed; she/he is proud. eiliili ates: the corpse is very scary. eiliketait a fishing hook.eililinga in silence; silently; noiselessly. eilip ki-a (only used in infinitive) the begging; the act of begging. epol eilip kane kocaalo: there a lot of begging here in the village. epol eilip loka esigala: there is a lot of begging for cigarettes. eilipe way of begging, asking, praying. eilit a path made by mice and rats; a burrow.eilongis a bathroom. eilopakina inherited or passed on property. ibore ngin ngesi eilopakinaka: that is my property by inheritance. eimae (singular noun M) the way to make porridge. eimaret something for counting; an abacus. eitaabo lokimaret: an arithmetic book. eimidi (singular noun M) fever; malaria; (of a person having) a high temperature.eimonit a tsetse fly (a vector for nagana or sleeping sickness); cattle fly.imyela eong etau akiring: I long for meat: ejai eong eimyel loka etau ainyam akiring. einakina1 (of a person) dedicated; devoted; determined; resolute. einakina2 a gift; a grant; a gratuity; an award; a reward. einer a limb or upper part of the body; any of the four parts of a dissected bird. iinerin luka akokor: the four parts of a chicken. einere a mode or way of talking; a dialect; a nuance. einere loko Serere: the dialect of Serere. iineresinei: a group of dialects; speeches. epol einere loko Usuk kodikisyonari kalo: the Usuk dialect of Ateso is prevalent in this dictionary. eingarenikine manner of leadership; management style. eingite (singular noun M) the way or manner of asking, or of setting exams. eingokit acne; a pimple.eingony2 (singular noun M) illicit sexual intercourse; sexual relationship between near relatives; incest; free-for-all sexual relationship in the neigbourhood, i.e. men and women are loose (like in the biblical Sodom and Gomorrah). einik black; dirty. egoe lo erai einik noi: this cloth is very black or dirty. igoen luinikino: dirty clothes. eining (singular noun M) wrestling; grappling; tussling. einyakit a rag; a worn out piece of cloth. einyangane revenge; vengeance; reprisal; retaliation; retribution. einyure the game of cricket.eipajane (singular noun M) relationship; connection; affiliation; association. eipapane (singular noun M) fatherhood. eipaperone (singular noun M) friendship; amity; attachment. eipara telepathy; second sight; a feeling that something is wrong or is going to be amiss. eipiane (singular noun M) the itch.eipiret a stick (often with a head shaped like a bowl or tripod) for stirring sauce (especially peas); a hole or thread drilling machine. eipise (singular noun M) a method of breeding or rearing animals. aise ibegoi luka ibaren luejokuka nges kwana eipise itojokiaritos ipiiriotin luka ibaren: selective breeding of livestock is a method of animal breeding advocated for by livestock experts.agolit ikweny ajoora, arai bo alacakinit kilatos tai – ali bo eipite akokoroi ejok adepar?: keeping birds within a wire mesh, or leaving them to roam about – which method of rearing chicken is better?eipoe (singular noun M) a way of cooking; cuisine; gastronomy. eipois a kitchen; a place for cooking. amot nak’ipois: a cooking pot.eipone a kind; a habit; a manner; a method or methodology; a character; a sort; a behaviour; a custom; a bearing; a category; know-how. eipone edio kere: in any way.eipongut a lump of unthreshed millet left in the granary; a knot in the wood or on the mud wall; a clod of earth. eipud (singular noun M) a need; a desire; attachment; liking; preference; aspirations. eipugae (singular noun M) the method of ruling or governing. eipugae loaronon: bad governance; misrule. eipyei (singular noun M) lightning (static energy in the sky); a flash of lightning. iretuni eipyei: it will thunder. imilia lolo eipyei: it is lightning or flashing today. ireta lolo eipyei: it is thundering today. abu eipyei kicwe ekatogo: lightning struck my home. abu eipyei kipumupum akiteng: the lightning struck a cow (but the cow was not killed).eirab (singular noun M) a discussion; a debate. kilosi iso eirab: we are going to discuss or to have a long talk. eirabo offertory at church or burial. eires (singular noun M) roaring; a roar; the thunder; the roaring; a flare.eires lokedou: thunder. eiriairia a whirlwind; a stroll. aiiriairia naka akipi: a whirlpool. aiiriairia naka ekwam: a whirlwind. eiris (singular noun M) an amulet chiefly worn by children round the neck; a charm. eirotane (singular noun M) polygamy; bigamy. eiruk (singular noun M) a dance; a song; a motto or maxim.eirumane (singular noun M) cohabitation; living together without marriage; concubinage; inheriting a woman from the clan. eirumuna an inheritance. aberu nakirumuna: an inherited wife (i.e. a wife given to a man by his clan after the death of her husband). iboro lukirumuna: inherited property (whose original owner has died). eiruru guilt. anyam ngol eiruru: he is guilty. aitanyam eiruru: to find someone guilty. eis (singular noun M) (the ceremony of) paying of dowry, or the showing of dowry. alosi eong ois ke inacika: I am going to the ceremony at which my sister’s dowry will be paid. eisaawe a playground; a field. eisaawe lokidegei: airfield, airport, aerodrome, helipad. eisaawe lokemopiira: football field. eisigane (singular noun M) a hiccup. kerumit eong eisigane: I have hiccup. eisiilooret an anaesthetic. eisiisa a brake of car or bicycle. mam iisiisan iswamaete: the brakes have failed. eisiitunet a memento; a memorial; a reminder; a remembrance; a sign (to remember with). eisil (singular noun M) a hiss; a whistling; a declaration not to. eisinye (singular noun M) greed; stinginess; selfishness; gluttony; avarice; cupidity (craving, desire, passion, eagerness, lust, or acquisitiveness). eisiret an ornament, adornment, or accessory; a decoration, an embellishment, ornamentation, or beautification. eisirwa a grasshopper, Zonocerous veriegatus. eisiwa a stink greenish-yellow giant grasshopper.eisolet a granary made of twigs or reeds.eisongot a ball in the hip; a nodule on the hip or elbow; juxta-articular nodule; a knot in wood. eisupane (singular noun M) courtship; illicit love affair; an affair; a liaison; a tryst; a flirtation. eisuwa a species of big yellow-green grasshopper, Zonocercus variegatus. eiswaget a toothbrush; a thing for scrubbing or polishing with; a sponge or steel wool to clean with.eiswamae (singular noun M) the manner or method of work, acting or conducting business. eit sharp; pointed. eitak ikilenga lu: these knives are sharp. eitaabala a handkerchief; a hankie; a neckerchief; a scarf; a headband; a table cloth. eitaabo a book; a register; a ledger; a log (book); a roster; an account. eitaabo loisirigin: a financial or bank account. iitaaboi luisirigin: books of financial or bank accounts. eitaada a bed - a camp bed, crib, cradle, bunk bed, double bed, single bed, etc. eitabira an offering; a sacrifice.eitai (singular noun M) communal work for reward (usually for beer); a reward; payment for work; salary; work for beer; task or work. eitane (the ceremony of) paying of dowry, or the showing of dowry; the method of nurturing or aitan. alosi eong oitane ka inacika: I am going to the ceremony at which my sister’s dowry will be paid. ainyam aperosit erai eitane idwe lomam ejok: eating the previous night’s leftover food is not a good way of bringing up children.ikisin ka akiteng kangin egolol iitana kec: the openings of the teats of that cow’s udder are blocked.eitarane (formerly) marriage of children in advance of maturity; a form of marriage whereby the parents of a boy-child approached the parents of a girl-child they hoped to be future wife of their son and married her in childhood. The girl-child was tied an arm band to signify she is married, until her maturity when she would join her husband. eitebwone (singular noun M) a swelling of stomach; flatulence; constipation.eitei (singular noun M) face-to-face; the look; the aspect. eiteikec: their look.eiteitei a dress with a blouse and skirt joined as one (made of the same fabric); a frock; a gown. eitekerane (singular noun M) tribalism; a tribal or ethnic manner of doing things – not on merit.eitekere a sub-clan; a family (from common ancestor); a sub-tribe.eitela2 an area of land clearly defined by natural swamp or valley boundaries. eitelepane (singular noun M) boyhood; adolescence; youth.eitemes weighing scales; a measure. eitemet a corruption of eitemes: weighing scales; a measure. eitena (done or spoken in a) straightforward or frank manner. einer eitena: to talk in a frank and simple manner. eitetere a fishing basket.eiteunet a prototype; a model; archetype.aibap eitinyo: to slap on the cheek.eitodikina (singular noun M) a command; a law; a commandment.eitola a sugarcane. kobilak eong da iisongen iuni luka eitola: break for me three nodes of sugarcane.eitolima a riverbank; a beach; a lakeshore. eitotone (singular noun M) motherhood. eitubuset an ornament; an adornment; a decoration. eitule (singular noun M) a swelling and reddening of the vulva (the pudenda); cancer of the female genitals. eituli a tyre puncture or leak.eitunet an island. eitunganane (singular noun M) humanity; mankind; human nature. eituritono a praiseworthy person; a hero. eitutu the breast of a fowl.eituudu a piece; a cigarillo; a stub of smoked cigarette. eituutooret an instruction booklet or manual; a training manual. eiwiny to be whistling with the lips; to whistle (singular noun M) whistling (with the lips). eiwiny (singular noun M) whistling with one’s lips. eiya (of grinding, work) evenly; equally; all sides. kiswama alaro kon eiya: level your courtyard. eiyara safe; protected; defended; secure; guarded; shielded. eiyara ngesi: she/he is safe. eiyas ki-a to increase, multiply, grow. isirigin luko toma aingadis elosete eiyas/iyatas: money in the savings bank accrues interest. abu keyat: I added. apotu kiyatata: they added. eong eyata: I grow/increase. kesi iyatas: they grow bigger/increase. abu eong keyatakin: I grew up or became big. kiyat! kiyatak! (singular imperative of eiyas): add! Increase! kiyatakin (singular imperative): (you) grow! (you) increase! kiyatakinos : (you) reproduce!eiyek (singular noun M) hanging; dangling.ebos eiyenganeke: she/his breath is vile. eiyengane (singular noun M) breathing; panting; respiration. eiyinyejaajalo (singular noun M) (in Pallisa) bean seeds or plants.ejaapu a wild creeper with edible leaves cooked with ecadoi, emoros, egwangira, and elwata, Commicarpus plumbagineus. ejaaye (singular noun M) Indian hemp; bhang; hashish. emasi ngesi ejaaye: she/he smokes hemp. ejae a state (of things); a station in life; being; state of being.ejago a tomato-like fruit. ejai real; actual; it, she, he is present. ejai edia amot: sauce is in the earthenware pot. ejaas itunga ogaago: people are in the shed. ejai eong aswam: I have to do; I have work. ejakaana well off; real chief. ijakaana ijo: you are well off, you are a real chief. ejakait mister; sir; master; chief; gentleman; principal; director; husband or owner of house. naka ejakait (mutan): (used in addressing a man) to Mr (so and so). Ejakaitiwok: Our Master (Jesus Christ); Our Lord. ejaket a jacket.ejakuna released; saved; be on holiday.erai etunganan lo ejala, mam ekoto aswam: this man is a layabout, he does not want to work. ejalakinio admissible; permissible. ejalakitai free; divorced; left alone; remaining. ejalana free with; ready to give a lot of something. ejalakuwan a reckless, wild, irresponsible person; a hero, idol. ejalal (to be) public property; accessible to all; (to be) free for all. ejalal araito nuka ekitoi kangol: the fruits of that tree are public property. ejalam (of liquids, etc) lukewarm; (of men) kind, good-hearted, generous. akipi nuejalam: lukewarm water. itunga luajalamak: kind, generous people, easy to approach. ejamu (formerly) a skin or hide for sleeping on (ijam, is now used to mean ‘beddings’). ayaunit eong ikajam: I have brought my bedding along. ejamut (of liquids, etc) lukewarm. akipi nuejamut: lukewarm water. ejanta enjoyment; pleasure; gratification. ainyam ejanta: to enjoy oneself.
a Jopadhola man (the Luo speakers of Tororo district). Ijapadola: the Jopadhola people (in general). ejarakina loose

slack; lax. ejaroto a slipknot. ejatoto (singular noun M) a vegetable plant, Asystasia schimperi. ejau a grass, Aristida adscendascienis. ejautene (singular noun M) a way of living; a state or station in life; a bearing; a quality; a climate. ejai ejautene kec erono: they live in misery. ejok ejautene: the conditions are good. isogoror ejautene: the situation is unpleasant. ejeburu an abandoned house or home. ejeburu ngesi ere loabwosere kotoma: a derelict home is one from which the people have shifted away.ejeet a piece of gourd or wood to smoothen a clay pot (before drying it in the sun). ejejait a nephew (called so by aunt). ejekelut a cockroach.ejelejele a grass, Paspalum commersoni. ejelel a tree, Acasia depanolobium.ejenio a celebrity; a famous person; a superstar; an icon; a public figure; a personage; a big shot. ejenunet a sign; a trademark; a mark; a token; a wonder; a miracle; an omen; a symbol; a musical note. ejepel a clitoris; a female’s urethra.ejepep maimed; cheated; cut down; felled. etunganan loejepep: a maimed person; a cheated person. ejese a colour; a hue; a tint or shade; a category of something.ejesi kia it is very white; (plural) they are very white. ejibat a domesticated pigeon; (slang) playboy; lover man. ijibai: deep lovers. ejie a fight; a contest; a contention; a war; a battle; a combat. ejiirit a cricket.ejijim yummy; sweet; appetising (of food or anything); delicious; enticing. ejijim doo do: ejijim laa la: very sweet; very delicious or luscious. ejijim dokodok: very sweet or very nice (to the taste). ejikai a tree, Sclerocarya birrea subsp. caffra. Its fruit is edible as food and fodder, the leaves are fodder, the bark and root are medicinal, while the wood is used as general-purpose timber and firewood. ainyam ejikai; aikony ejikai: (of someone staying far) to keep quiet for long. ejikit deaf. ijikitas aki: she/he is deaf. ijikitas akika: my ears are deaf. ejikooni a kitchen; a cooking place.ejinga a tree in the emidit family, but with adventitious roots - bark cloth tree, Ficus sycomorus.ejiono fond of fighting. ejioko kesi: they are fond of fighting. ejiose (formerly) a war dance; a battle dance.ejipai a drop of perspiration or of water or of milk, etcejiput scabies; mange; a mite. ejo stop; cease; leave off; you there; listen! ejo, kinyek!: you there, stop/leave!kijokis (in Kwapa –Ateso Atororo) all. akoto aswam kon kojok: I want your work to be good; let your work be good. kojok aswam kon : let your work be good. ti ejok: it would be good. ejok2 good; kind; just; nice; fair; beautiful; (of soil) fertile. ejokorot a short, strong tube for sucking beer made from a stem of a reed.(note: ejolot was a slave belonging to the family but of another tribe, not Etesot). ejon unripe; premature; immature; undercooked; raw; uncooked; fresh. sirikimat aokot ejonok: do not drink uncooked, raw blood. enyamete idwe araito nuejonok: children eat unripe fruits. atap na ejonit enyaritai ‘epule’: raw or poorly mingled millet/sorghum bread is known as epule. ejoreon a raider; a rustler. Ikaramoja eraas itunga luejoreok: the Karimojong are raiders. ejorit a fruit fly (likes sweet fruits).ejoroi a shrub, Teclea nobilis. Its leaf extract used as medicine for ear-aches. ejose1 pretending; under pretext; seemingly; with deceit or sham under pretence of. abu ngesi neajai eong ican ejose: she/he came to me pretending to cry of poverty. sirikilip ejose: do not act as if you were praying; do not pretend to pray.ejosi in the early afternoon. ejotono often asleep; sleepy; drowsy; lethargic; heavy-eyed; sluggish; tired. ijotono ijo: you are fond of sleeping or dreaming. ejuge (singular noun M) (slang) dry gin; crude distilled alcohol.ejuju a kind of plant with prickly purple flowers - a thistle.ejuka a plant, Solanum africanum. ejulai a corruption of ejutat: a cannibal; one who kills secretly; a witch or wizard.ejuliran a prosecution witness.ejungula a plant used for a hedge, Jatropha curoans. ainya ejungula: to be rich. anyaa ngol ejungula: that man has many wives, he has become rich.ejuput a corruption of ejiput: measles; rash; eczema.ejurusitoi (of a person) slick, polished, efficient, glossy, smooth, or professional; clever, witty, or brainy; (of a car) quick, rapid, fast, speedy, swift, or nippy. ejutat one who kills quietly or secretly; a cannibal; a serial killer.ejutet a razorblade.ejwele (of taste) insipid; dull; bland; wish-washy; characterless; colourless; stale; tame; unexciting. eka1 an acre. eka2- (prefix of agent in ko verbs) ‘one who...’ekalokan: one who traps; a trapper. ekatupan: one who follows; a follower. ekacudan: one who bewitches; a wizard; a witch. eka3 M (in salutation) my friend; my dear. ekatuan, eyalama aanyun: my friend, I am happy to see you. ekaabi a refugee camp; an internally displaced people’s camp; a laager.ekaajo a sugarcane. ekaalet the Flood age group. ekaame a shell formerly used as a spoon or a tool for weeding millet. ekaanyanaran a Church of Uganda bishop; inspector; overseer. ekaapuni a company; corporation; enterprise; a business; a theatre company; a troupe; touring company; a syndicate; an organization; a consortium; an association ekaaran a murderer; a killer; a serial killer. ekaaso a cassock; a long white robe. ekabadi a cupboard; a locker; a sideboard. ekabaka (any) king or monarch; a cultural leader of the Baganda tribe. ekabalagala a pancake. ekabaracaroi a tree, Vitex cuneatus. ekabaran a rich man; a wealthy man.ekabarit a plant, Crotalaria poly sperma. ekabeji an edible cabbage.ekabelit scale of fish, crocodile, or snake.ekabit (singular noun M) the kale plant or leaves (akin to cabbage without a head) eaten as vegetable.ekabokan a spy, tempter; a digger; one who digs. ekabokan atesia: a professional grave-digger.ekabolian a player; a jester; a joker; a sportsman or an athlete. ekabu a trench coat; an overcoat; a cloak; a big skin or hide formerly worn by chiefs and Nandi (a tribe in Kenya) and by Sabiny (a tribe native to Kapchorwa or Sebei in Uganda).ekabuoron a robber; a confiscator.ekaburon the fat or the thick one; the one who replaces another; a substitute. ekabut a trench coat; an overcoat; a cloak; a big skin or hide formerly worn by chiefs and Nandi (a tribe in Kenya) and by Sabiny (a tribe native to Kapchorwa or Sebei in Uganda).ekabwoan a sponsor; one who stands (bail, etc).ekabwoikiniton a sponsor or guarantor; a godparent; a delegate; one who stands and challenges another.ekaceeret a species of ox-pecker. ekacelan a shouter; a quarrelsome, irritable person.ekacelat a vowel letter, such as a, e, i, o, u. ekacoan a wise man; the maggi; a wise person, a clever person.ekacudan a witch; a wizard; a cannibal; a night dancer (figurative) (approvingly) a person who does things cleverly, in a clever way, like a juggler. ekaculon an arbiter; intermediary; arbitrator; a go-between. ekaculon mam ebelakinio angole: (an adage) a peace-maker is not to be molested (literally, a go-between should not be hit on the head). ekadakalu a water rat; an otter.ekadanyat a glutton; a great murderer; gourmand. ekadedengan a harsh, cruel, fierce, wild, severe man or animal. ekadekan a patient; a sick or ill man.ekademaran a grabber or snatcher; a robber; a plunderer.ekadepit a flea.ekadiekan a judge; a mediator; an arbitrator or arbiter. ekadilon an early riser or traveller. amina eong ikadilok: I like early risers. ekadinaali a Roman Catholic bishop or cardinal.ekadit not enough; inadequate; insufficient. ekadit ekwam: breathless.ekadongot a gong; a big church bell.ekadonyon a tailor; a dress-maker. ekadot a plantain-eating bird.ekadotean an adulterer; a fornicator; a prostitute; a sex worker.ekadukon a builder; an architect; a mason. erai ngesi lokadukon itogoi: he is a builder or architect. ekaduliai a kind of tree with edible fruit. ekaduot a marksman (of gun).ekadutan a generous or liberal person (in giving things). ekadwaran a prophet, foreseer, or a diviner; a bitter thing. amugogot nakadwaran: bitter banana for beer-making. ekadyekan an intercessor; an adjudicator; a separator; judge; an arbiter; a rescuer.ekaelon a bad friend; a lover; an intimate friend; fornicator; adulterer. aelo ijukanari ekaelon alosit aanyun akepese: a sudden sexual impulse prompts the lover to visit his girlfriend. ekaenan one who ties, binds, packs, imprisons, etc. koyautu ikaenak etogo: bring men to tie the grass on the roof of the hut. ekageretan one who massages, embrocates (sets a bone); a masseur; a physiotherapist. ekagogongon the strong, severe, hardy, difficult, strict one. lukagogongu: the mighty ones; the strong ones. ekagolon a doorkeeper; a prison guard; a loser; a failure.ekagwelan a buyer; a purchaser. ekajakunan a rescuer; a saviour; a redeemer; a liberator. ekajalan iboro a generous, liberal, open-handed, big-hearted, charitable, or munificent person.lukajarak ka lukatwak: the living and the dead.ekajean a potter; a person who moulds with clay, etc. ekajenan an eyewitness; a martyr; one who knows; a deponent. ekajengan a skinner; a person who removes the skin from a slaughtered animal. ekajepan a wood cutter; a lumberman; a cheat; a trickster. ekajikaj a fruit tree with sour fruit, Sclerocarya birrea subsp. caffra. ekajion a fighter, combatant, boxer, wrestler, pugilist, rebel; a warrior, soldier. ekakaa a tree the root which is used to speed up shea-nut butter (alinyo, akungurit) making or is planted near gardens to deter witchcraft on a grain crop (- the leaves of same tree are used in beer-making to prevent beer going bad or as a treatment for wounds), Lonchocarpus laxiflorus. ekakaas a banded mongoose, Mungos mungo.ekakale a castor oil shrub, Ricinus communis. The ricin in its seed coats is poisonous, while the seeds are used to extract castor oil which has medicinal value. ekakapiton a soldier in arms; a person in arms. ekakinangan one who hears but does not answer; a mute. ekakolon an adversary; an enemy; a contestant. ekakolot a great adversary; a vicious enemy; a serious contestant. ekakoran a distributor; a benefactor. ekakorion a farmer who cultivates land; a planter; a grower of crops. ekakwangan white; the white one; the bright one. akoto egoe ekakwangan: I want a white cloth. koyau ekakwangan: bring the white one.

a man native to parts of Arua district of Uganda west of the Nile. Ikakwa: the Kakwa people. ekakwenan one who laughs; a scoffer; a scorner. ekakwenaran one who ridicules; a derider or disdainer. ekal a marriage or compound of married people; a home; a family unit; a wife and her children; a basic social unit. ekalaamu a lead pencil. ekalaani a clerk; a secretary; amanuensis. ekalakunan a saviour; a redeemer. ekalany a lazy, indolent, idle, lethargic or sluggish person. ekalanyana lazy; idle; indolent. ekalaunan the clean man; the holy man or a male saint.ekalean one who beats or canes. ekaledi a tree used to fence kraals, Rhus incana. ekalees (in Karamoja) an ostrich, Struthio camelus.ekaleo a bush, Tiziphus mauritianus. ekalerut a plant, Cucurbitacaea; a cucumber-like creeper used as medicine for mange (emugege) in animals - Krotalario polysperma. ekalia a tree, Grewia mollis. ekaliagaman the tall, high one. ekalianan a baby (a newly born child). ekaliaton a creeper; a creeping thing (like a snake, worm). ekaliliton the jealous or envious one. ekalimonokinan a preacher, cleric, or reverend. ekalimoron a reporter; a betrayer, traitor, rebel, turncoat, defector, or a deserter; an announcer, presenter, telecaster, or a broadcaster; an informer. ekaliokon a liar; a hypocrite; a quack. ekalitiini a quarantine; an isolation of animals to prevent the spread of disease among livestock; a transit depot for animals. aigol ekalitiini: to enforce a quarantine. angaar ekalitiini: to open up a quarantine. ekalituusi eucalyptus or Blue-gum tree, Eucalyptus spp. ekalokan a man who ensnares; a man who traps; a man who sets traps. ekalokit a large brown sugar ant.ekalokunan an adolescent male. ekaloman an entrant; one who enters somewhere; an adulterer. ekaloman aberu adulterer.ekaloman kinga: a guard; a watchman; a witch.ekalomaran one who enters; an entrant; a recruit; a newcomer. ekaloton a pedestrian; a traveller, explorer, voyager, trekker, tourist; a passenger, or a commuter. ekalumon a swimmer; a diver. ekalungan one who refuses something (in anger). ekalyaton a creeping thing. ekalyoi a thorn tree with hooked thorns, the liquid from the pounded and boiled roots of which is used as a dressing for wounds in livestock, Securidaca ongipendulata.ekama (singular noun M) measles.ekamejan a hunter; a seeker. ekameran a sot; a drunkard; an alcoholic. ekamerat a perpetual drunkard; an alcohol addict. ekamesyana spotted; dotted; speckled; dappled; freckled. eris erai etyang loekamesyana: the leopard is a spotted animal. ekamet a kind of small tree. ekamodan a cheat; a conman; fraudster; swindler; one who cheats. ekamole pretending; feigning; seemingly. ejotoi ngesi ekamole: she/he is pretending to sleep.ekamonyan one who weeps; lachrymose. ekamule a millet or sorghum brew made for sale. ekamuran a father-in-law; a brother-in-law; the wife’s brother. ikamurak: all in-laws generally (female or male).ekamuriei a wild mulberry spiny shrub, Carissa edulis. The ripe fruit is edible, root extract is medicine, while crushed young fruits are used for seasoning vegetables such as ekipikipi, ecadoi, esukumawiki, etc. ekang M my friend; my dear; dear me. okwe ekang kolot, nukon nupe inerai: my dear friend go away, they are talking about (killing) you. (ekang used in a salutation or beginning a letter to a man: Dear Sir). ekangatan a robber, burglar, mugger, raider; a brigand, bandit, or thug. ekangatat one fond of robbing or raiding; a perpetual raider or bandit. ekangibiriran a fast runner.ekaniki black lustre (of cloth); alpaca; sheen; shine; patina; gleam. ekaninikan a tough one; the resilient; a diehard. ekanisa a Protestants church.ekanon an Anglican Church canon in charge of a parish. ekansila a local administrative council male representative. ekansulo a local administrative council. ekansulo lo ocaalo: a village council (LC-I). ekansulo lokoitela: a parish council (LC-II). ekansulo lokotem: a sub-county council (LC-III). ekansulo lokobuku: a county council (LC-IV). ekansulo lokodistrikt: a district council (LC-V). ekanyaman1 apese one who takes part of a girl’s dowry. ekanyaman2 itunga a cannibal; a man-eater (lion). engatuny lokanyaman itunga: a man-eating lion.
a man native to former Bugisu (the present day Mbale and Sironko districts)

a Mugisu man (because he is brown – enyangaana). Ikanyanga: the Bagisu or Bamasaba people (in general).ekanyumit a seed of simsim; a simsim plant, Sesanum idieum. ekao a kind of grass used as broom.ekaonon a thin or skinny person. ekapa a domestic cat; a tomcat.ekapakina ready to do; armed; in arms; prepared; equipped; organized; all set. inyo bo ekapakina itunga lu ejie?: what are these people armed for? ekapegan one who denies or argues; a debater; one who objects. ekapelimen (in Karamoja) a tree, Acacia nilotica subsp. subalata. Its pulpy pods are edible, the root extract is medicinal, the bark is used as a stimulant, tannin and dye.
a man from Kapel. ekapelyono (of animals, hills or anything) white-spotted

white patched; freckled; flecked; dappled. ekapetan akiro a lawyer; a pleader. ekapetan aperit a bed maker; a room attendant. ekapeton a kicker; one who kicks. ekapeton emopiira: a skilled football player. emopiira lopetot: a ball to be kicked, a football. ekapiira a cheap second-hand polyester garment.
a pagan (non-Christian), an atheist, a kaffir

a man from Kapir sub-county in Kumi district. ekapilan a wicked person; a wizard; one who bewitches by mere presence or passing by; one with evil eyes; the devil. ekapodon a man who worries, grouses; a grouser; a man who complains. ekapodot one who is fond of grousing, worrying, or complaining. ekapolon (formerly) a man who has been initiated to elderhood (through asapan ceremony); a great man; a principal; an important man. ekapucon one who prepares a feast to reconcile with another; a peace-maker; a reconciler; an arbiter.ekapupon one who is listening; a listener; a hearer. ikapupok: the audience. ekapurokinan one who replies or answers back; a pleader; a lawyer; an intercessor. ekaput (formerly) one cent piece. ikapun: money in general ekarac the bowlegged one; one with deformed legs. ecom erai etyang lokarac: a baboon is a bow-legged animal.ekaracunat a youthful warrior or raider. ekaramoto a plant from which salt is extracted, Achirantes aspera. ekaramwai (in Karamoja) white-galled acacia or whistling thorn, Acacia seyal. The bark is medicinal, exudes gum Arabic, and also used for tanning leather and for dyes. ekarata (singular noun M) a paper card game, played with 54 cards. etopoloosi kwana isapa abolia ekarata kotaun aibois naka akor: boys these days spend a lot of time in town playing cards instead of farming. ekare (singular noun M) (of women only) shouting and screaming for joy; ululation. ekaremon one who spears; one who punctures. ekarengan the red one; the red Indians. akoto iikopon lukarengak: I want the red mugs (cups).
lokapucon ekapuletenyit a cyst; a growth in the body; an ulcer; a sore; a carbuncle; a swelling

a man native to former Karamoja (the present day districts of Moroto, Kotido and Nakapiripirit). Ikarimojong: the Karimojong people generally. ekaromait a bush, Acacia seyal. ekaromata a tree, Euphorbia calycina. ekarotan a spy

a sleuth; a scout; a detective. ekarotan iyemuto: a journalist. ekarotan akiro: a spy or sleuth. ekaru1 a name given to a man who is born deformed (such as one who grows up without teeth, born lame, or is born deaf). ekaru2 a year. ekaru je: last year. ekaru ngol: next year. ekaru logeet: the starting year. ekaru loka asioman: the academic year. ekaru loka aurio: the year of birth. ekaru loka Ejakaitiwok: the year of our Lord (anno Domini – AD). ekarucon a fitter; a plumber; a linkman. ekarukwe a lily, Gloriosa varifolia. ekarukwei a Black plum tree, vitex doniana. Uses: it bears round edible fruits (black when ripe) called aelun or akarukwa; the tree provides shade; fuel is got from its firewood and charcoal; building materials from its poles and timber; its leaves, fruit, bark and roots have medicinal properties. ekaruwon a commander-in-chief of an army or any group. ekasaan a man servant. ekasaan ateker: a family or clan caretaker; an attendant; a servant. ekasaban a liar; fraudster; conman; a charlatan doctor. ekasabat a regular liar; one clever at lying. ekasekenyait a brown small hornet.ekasian one who escapes, i.e. an escapee; one who runs away; a fugitive; a deserter. ekasilon (indefinite pronoun) a little.nediokasilon: a little distance; a little while. akasilok: a small quantity of liquid. akiro akasilok: a few words. akipi adikasilok: a little water. ekasuban the maker; the creator; the moulder; the manufacturer; God the Creator. Daimler-Chrisler nges ekasuban imotokan luka Mercedes Benz: Daimler-Chrisler is the manufacturer of Mercedes Benz cars.ekasweet a drizzle; a little rain.ekateit a small termite egg (given to chicks).ekatereunan a confessor of bad doing; a rat (one who betrays a cause); a black leg; a sell-out. ekatetelit a gill of fish; a cockscomb. ekato an inoculation; a vaccine; vaccination; a booster; a jab; a shot; an injection.ekatubon a judge; an arbiter; a cutter; a referee; an umpire; a magistrate; a butcher. ekatubon akituk: a butcher of cows. ekatubon imusaagon: a court judge. ekatulikit a member of the Roman Catholic Christian faith. ekatumunan a young man 14 -16 years of age; a male youth; an adolescent boy. ekatupiton a follower; an attendant; a cohort; an aide; a servant; a henchman; a companion. ekatupiton Yesu: Christ’s disciple. ekatwan the mortal being; the dead one. ekauda (singular noun M) a grass, Chloris.ekaukau backwards. elosi ngesi ekaukau: she/he is going backwards or retreating. ekaulero a pepper plant. ekaulo afterwards; subsequently; then; next after (that); later than.ekaurian a parent; a producer (bearer); a begetter; a primogenitor; a progenitor; a forebear. ekaut a grass - Sporobolus pyramidalis.ekauton a castrator; an emasculator.ekawean a man who sows; a broadcaster (of news or seeds). ekawo the big peas.ekawokon akipi a water-drawer; a water-fetcher. ekawurian a parent.ekayaiton a ruler; a sovereign; a governor; a president; a monarch. ekayelon a man who has illicit sexual intercourse.ekayo a poison; a medicine; a drug; a remedy; tablets; an injection; a linctus; pills; medication; a toxin; a herbal cure.ekileng lo emameete ikayo: this knife is blunt (has no edge).akwanus. ekayuunan a rescuer; a saviour; a liberator; a redeemer. eke- (prefix for nouns, denoting agents of ki verbs). eke- (M); ake- (F); ike- (Dimin.) (note: ko verbs have eka- as prefix). ekeara puffed up; overblown; exaggerated; elevated; prominent.ekeburan claimant (of debt, etc); debt collector.ekebusianan a drudge; one who works hard for little pay. ekebwalaan an enticer; one who keeps another from working; a negligent and slow-working person. ekebwanyan a party intruder, a gate-crasher. ekebwokan a porter who carries things for others; a carrier. ekebwokot a regular porter (who helps to carry things on his back or on the head); a beast of burden. ekeciran a milker; a milkman.ekecit a spur (of a bird or horseman); a barb (of wire). asinit nak’ikec barbed wire. ekecodon a person who limps; a cripple. ekecokon a herdsman; a pastor. ekecokon akituk; a sheperd: ekecokon amerekekin. ekecololon a hypocrite; a fraud; a charlatan. ekecololon ijo: you are a hypocrite. ekecoran a counsel; an adviser; a counsellor; a guru. ekedaan a man who buries; grave digger; a mourner; an undertaker. ekedaran a guardian; a keeper; a watchman; a protector; a waiter; a curator; a foster-parent.ekedekede a species of bird, a red-billed hornbill. ekediany a southpaw or left-handed man – believed to have powers to bless rustlers whom he smears them with mud. ekedot brand marks or beauty marks on cattle or pottery. ekedyatan a treasurer; a collector; a compiler.ekeegere a bicycle bell.ekeeki a cake. ekeeyarit a soldier; an army man.ekejaanakinan a constant or regular attendant or protégée. ajaanakin duc: regular attendance or presence. ekejerukon an unmanageable, disobedient, unruly, defiant, disloyal, or seditious man. ekejodon a sycophant; toady; flatterer; a fawn.ekek a doorway, entry, or entrance; a family or tribal lineage of common ancestry; extended family. kogol ekek: close the doorway. ilomunit ijo kokek kangai?: to which family lineage do you belong? ekekaan a hunter, a seeker; a persecutor, a tormentor, a bully, a tyrant, an oppressor, or an intimidator.ekekemeran a happy-go-lucky man; one who chances upon something. ekekemoi (singular noun M) a loud laugh or cackle (especially by troublesome women in ekirakira dance). ejaikina oni ekekemoi loejok: we had a good laugh.ekekeon a carpenter; a carver; an engraver; an etcher. ekekes (physically) strong; powerful; obstinate; difficult. ekekes ijo etaukon: you are obstinate. ekekes etunganan ngol: he is a strong man. ekeket an iron tip of a spear casing.ekekwa the other side of the river or lake; the opposite bank. ekelai a tooth; a fang; a tusk; an incisor; a dagger; a cog. ainakin ikel: to make ridiculous. angiikin ikel: to show one’s teeth to (in anger). abu je kangiik eong ikel: he showed me his teeth, i.e. he threatened me. angiikin ikel: to set one’s teeth; to persevere when doing a difficult work or in great anger or pain. ekelai k’etom: an ivory; elephant tusk. ekelaman a curser; a high-jumper (in athletics). ekelapilapan aswam a work shirker or dodger; an idler; lazybones. ekelesia a Roman Catholic church (building).ekeli salivary glands. ekelijilijan a suckling (child, piglet, etc); a penetrator; a biter. ekelipan a beggar; a pleader; a petitioner; an appellant. ekemanimanan inspector, examiner, checker, superintendent, overseer, assessor, supervisor. ekemeran an albino. ekemerana albino; lacking pigment. ekemorikikinan a uniter; a mediator; a reconciler.ekemunonan one who conceals; an obscurantist; a doctrinaire; an obfuscator. ekenep a nettle with stinging leaves; a plant, a root of which is used as cough mixture. ainyam ekenep: to become daring and cruel. ekeneran a speaker (the person, not the machine); an orator; a lecturer; a presenter; a narrator; a spokesman. ekengadan a treasurer; a keeper (of things in a store). ekengalan a liar; a pretender; a con artist; a fraudster. ekengarakinan a helper; an assistant; an accomplice (to a crime). ekengarenikinon a leader; a guide; a director; a manager. ekengarenon a leader; a director; an organizer; a manager. ekengitan a questioner; an inquirer; an examiner like Uganda National Examinations Board. ekengomingomon a gobbler;
