a glutton or greedy person. ekenit a curse; blasphemy; profanity; sacrilege; wickedness; swearword; malediction.ekenyamiton an escort; an aide; a guide; a body guard.ekenyoolan a driver of a motorcar. ekeo a tree, Oxytenanthera abyssinica. ekeoron a talkative person; a loud caller; a taxi or bus broker or tout. ekepalisionon a procrastinator; a man who delays; a lazy, careless, negligent, slovenly, idle person. ekepep circumcised; (of a skin, finger or toe nails, etc) cut round. ikepep yesi: you are circumcised. ekeper a shoulder. ekepoon a cook; a chef.ekepugan a ruler; a governor; a head of state; a monarch; a sovereign. ekeraban a speaker (in an assembly); a judge, a lawyer; a talkative man; a pleader, or a barrister. ekere a plant - Harrisonia abyssinica - whose bitter red berry is not edible and its root is used for abortion and a treatment for eye cataract, and the twigs are used for making granaries; a portable granary made from these twigs and plastered with mud and cow-dung. ekerekeret a Nubian woodpecker.ekeresia a corruption of ekelesia: a Roman Catholic cathedral. ekeret a gourd churn for making butter when milk poured in it is jerked for some time.ekeriaut a sedge or grass growing in swamps, Cyperus. ekerimon a tramp; a vagabond; a wanderer; a nomad; a rover; a vagrant; a hobo; a hawker. ekerionokinan a pessimist; a naysayer; a cynic; a person who throws cold water on everything good; a wet blanket; a party pooper; a killjoy. ekeru a shelf; a ledge, sill, or outcropping; a bookshelf or mantelpiece. ekerumunan a heir; an inheritor; a successor; progeny. ekerurwot a great plunderer; a real raider (both clever at and used to it). ekeryonon an African; a Black person.ekesa a fellow; a man; a guy; a bloke; a chap; a member of an age group. ekesa ngol: that fellow over there. ikesa kwi: those fellows over there. ekesese a tall man; a giant. ekesiaan a beginner; a novice; a starter; a learner; an innovator. ekesicatan a supporter; a backer; a sponsor. ekesidikon an inciter; an agitator; an instigator; a mastermind; an organizer. ekesidounon a mid-man.ekesisianakinan a teacher; a schoolmaster; a professor. ekesisiat a clever student; a clever learner; a clever pupil; a bookworm. ekesisiaunan a man or boy who has just acquired knowledge; a learner; a pupil; a novice. ekesit a bundle (of grass, sticks, etc); a sheaf; a stack; a wad; a pile. ekesupan a wooer; a campaigner; an amorous man; an intriguer. ekeswaman a workman; worker; an agent; an employee. ekeswamat a good worker; a quick worker; a clever workman; an expert. eketajaran a saviour; a rescuer; a reviver.eketanan a feeder; a nurse. eketeon a guardian; a caretaker; a spectator; an onlooker; a witness. eketimon a merciful or forgiving person. eketisian one who aids another to escape. eketisilan a confessor (in penance). eketit an iron spike on the spear shaft. eketobwoan one who makes somebody to stand up i.e. an accuser. eketumunon one who promises or pledges. ekewadikan a writer; a journalist; an author; a secretary. ekeyuunan a believer; one who agrees; one of the faithful. ekia poison; curative medicine; charm; drug; linctus; medication; remedy. aingalakin ekia: to poison someone (through food). ekia loinyonyoikina akuwan: an embrocation. ekia lotudokina: an ointment (for eyes or ears). ekia lopedokino: injectable drug. ekia loilikoro: an oral medicine. ekia loikel: toothpaste. ekia loamuk: shoe polish. eitwasamae ekia lokaronon: drug abuse.ekiboko a corruption of eiboko: a whip; a lash. ekibui a big tree of the ficus family with edible fruits. ekicoi a shallow seasonal well; a waterhole; a burrow.ekicolong a chair; a traditional bobbin stool; any seat.ekidima a factory-made hoe with a metre-long haft (handle or amusenu). ekido an island; an atoll; an islet; an isle; a sudd; a floating island of vegetation. ekidon (singular noun M) ceaseless rain; el-nino.ekigimac a thorn tree, Alstonia boonei. A shade tree yielding firewood and timber. A decoction from its bark is used as a traditional remedy for venereal diseases.ekiiko a local administrative council meeting; a council hall. ejaas lolo ikiliok okiiko atubokinio esolo: today, men are at the council hall to be assessed graduated tax. ekiimit a small key-hole bee fond of picking earwax, Trigona. ekiira a plant, Achyranthos aspera. ekiitani a wedding ceremony; a marriage ceremony.alosi eong okiitani ka ejakait Omagor: I am going to the wedding of chief Omagor. ekiiwa the hub of a cycle (the centre of the wheel holding the spokes).ekiki (singular noun M) shouting by women at a certain dance called edonga. ekikopo a cup; a mug.ekile a husband; a mate; a male spouse; a man.ekilen a husband. iyalama ya aanyun okilenike: she is happy to see her husband.ekileng a 15-centimetre single-edged knife; a dagger; cutlery; a stiletto; a blade. ekilenyasit a joint (in the arm or leg or any part of the body).ekilikil squirming; wiggling; twisting; wriggling (of one wriggling through a crowd; a bird trying to escape from hand holding it; one in great sorrow; as one trying to escape). ekilimiiti1 a pigeon peas shrub, Cajanus cajan. Its root extract is used as a stomach-ache remedy as well as an aphrodisiac, while the seeds and pods are edible. It is a good nurse crop for tree seedlings. ekilimiiti2 epiglottis (a flap that prevents food from entering the windpipe).ekilingait a grass, Hyparrhenia variabilis. ekiliokit a full-grown man of 26–42 years of age; a male person or animal; a husband. ekiliokone (singular noun M) manliness; maleness; masculinity; manhood. ekiliokosisit (collective noun M) a crowd of men. ekiliton1 a scorpion.ekiliton2 (singular noun M) a vegetable, Sonchus bipontini.ekilomita a kilometre; 1,000 metres.ekimat1 a black large biting ant.ekimat2 an old man; a crone; a reverend (in the Anglican church); an elder. ekimat loka ekanisa: a parson.ekimeng a tree in the ekulony and ekwooro family, Combretum ghasalense. ekimia an animal like a squirrel; a field rat, Gertille taterona liadon dundasi.ekimidi (singular noun M) malaria fever; ague.ekimingana deaf; hard of hearing; unable to hear; hearing-impaired; she/he is (they are) deaf. ekinei a bird living with goats. ekinepes (singular noun M) mannerism; idiosyncrasy; characteristic; peculiarity. ekingok a male dog; a greyhound, Alsatian, or mongrel; a very poor man. ekingol1 a palm tree or a palm frond, Phoenix reclinata.ekingol2 fornication (of a married with an unmarried person); incest. ekinono a tradition; custom; practice; ritual; belief; institution; folklore; habit; convention.ekinyomit a choice seed for planting; (figurative) a sperm.ekiosik a kiosk; a stall.ekipikipi (singular noun M) a vegetable cooked without using magadi salt, such as ecadoi, esukumawiki, elwata, edila, etc. ekipoliauna a child who has survived after serious illness, or a child surviving after all others died.ekipyei (singular noun M) lightning; radio electric current. akim naka ekipyei: electricity.ekirakira (singular noun M) a national dance of the Iteso (in imitation of the crested crane – ewalu - and popular in Usuk county in Katakwi district) that involves two groups leaping high up and down in alternation, in which no drums are used but men wearing ankle-bells leap to the accompanying foot-stamping chorus of female singers.ekirebet scissors; shears; clippers; cutters; secateurs.Jethro Opolot nges kwana erai ekirigi loka atukot na imorikikinit Iteso kotoma oinono: Prof. Jethro Opolot is now the prime minister of the Iteso Cultural Union. ekirimat a variety of red sorghum seldom eaten by birds. ekirio a plant, Hippia adoensis. ekiriton a corruption of ekiliton: a scorpion. ekiror a name (person’s name, first name, Christian name, forename, given name, surname, family name, or middle name); appellation; a tag; a designation; a title; a label; a brand. kokiror ke: on his/her behalf; in the name of someone. kokiror ka: on behalf of someone; on my behalf; in my name. ekisel a third-born child in a birth and still alive.ekisil a negative command (prohibition); a law; a rule; a command; a commandment; a regulation; precept; an edict. aitutub ekisil: to enact a legislation. ayaun ekisil: to bring law and order; to stop anarchy. ekisim a thorn bush, Acacia hockii. It is used for twigs and medicinal purposes - the leaf extract is a gonorrhoeal wound remedy, and root extracts cure cough. ekisin a breast; an udder; a mammary gland.ekisoko (formerly) an agent or assistant to the parish chief.ekison an auction; a public sale; a cattle market; an open air market. ekisu a mortar for pounding grain, groundnuts, or maize, etc.ekitabala a handkerchief; a hankie; a neckerchief; a scarf; a headband; a table cloth. kokiror ka on behalf of; on someone's behalf ekitabo a book.ekitada a bed; a camp bed.ekitai (singular noun M) communal work for reward (usually for beer); a reward; payment for work; salary; work for beer; task or work. ekitanuna a foster-child; a step-child (with no biological mother to bring it up); an adopted child. ekitebwone (singular noun M) a swelling of stomach; flatulence; constipation.ekiteitei a dress with a blouse and skirt joined as one (made of the same fabric); a frock; a gown.
eturuturut, ekasekenyit ekasekenyit a brown small hornet
(singular noun M) the Iteso of Tororo, Kenya and Pallisa.ekitelek the armyworms (caterpillars that destroy finger millet crop).aibap ekitinyo: to slap on the cheek.ekitoi1 a medicine

a herb; a drug; a remedy; a linctus; a medication.ekitoi2 a tree; a bush. ejai ikwenyit okitoi: a bird is on the tree. ekitui high grass; a bush; a jungle. akwap naka ikituo: a bush country.alomar okitui: to join guerrilla fighting or rebellion against a government.ekituki a grass, Cymbopogon. ekitunet island; isle; islet; atoll. ekitwi a jungle; a bushy place; high grass. alot okitwi: she/he has gone to the toilet or latrine.ekiunione (singular noun M) trinity. ekiunione loagion: (in the Catholic faith) Holy Trinity - God the Father, the Son, and God the Holy Spirit. ekiyai firstborn boy child.ekiyot1 a potato variety identified by leaf type. ejok ekiyot lo: this potato variety is good. ekiyot asiira emini acokit naemiedana: the potato variety asiira yields a floury tuber that often chokes the consumers. ekiyot2 a bush; a shrub; a scrub. ekobet the outer rim of the ear or pinna. ekoboi a tree whose root extract is used as a gargle to reduce toothache, Terminalia torulosa ekobokobot edible cucumber fruit or plant.Gymnosporis buxifolia. ekoc (a reference among friends) a guy; a mature man.ekode a hooked stick; a walking stick; a hook. ekodeit a grass – a notorious weed - used as a favourable guide to soil fertility, Chloris gayana. ekodet a crowd; a mob; a gang; a club (of people); a category; a delegation; a Government department. ekodikod1 a network or web (of telecommunication lines, roads, etc). ekodikod2 a creeping plant; a climber. ekodo a plunge or scoop basket fish trap; a tiny sieve or filter attached to the bottom of a beer drinking tube called epii; a hamper; a basket. ekodoi (singular noun M) a deadly disease epidemic giving rise to rashes all over a person’s body, such as smallpox, chickenpox, or rinderpest. ekodokodoi a twining plant with thorny hooks. ekodokodwoi a thorny shrub, Acacia senegal. Its fruits are edible, while the root extract are medicinal, and seeds are used for dye.ekoduot a splendid glossy starling. ekoed a slender man. ekoile a grass with prickly hair; a tree - Berkheya spekeana. ekojo a small double-headed spear with 2-inch blades, usually twisted at the neck, used for stabbing fish (note that this spear has a religious and magical significance and is associated with rain-making); an arrow for use with a bow. ekojolo a grass - Hyparrhenia variabilis. ekoko (singular noun M) cocoa beans, tree or the drink made from processed seeds, Theobroma cacao. Uses: cocoa from the beans is used for chocolate, beverage is made from processed beans, and it contains a stimulant called theobromine. ekokoas a slender mongoose (a big rodent), Galerella sanguinea.ekokolana thieving; fond of stealing; kleptomaniac; sticky-fingered; light-fingered. ekokom a huge crested black eagle - a Batelleur eagle. ekokor a cock; a rooster; a male bird. etyang ka akokoroi - egwang: a wild cat. ekokoro a line (in a writing book or of growing plants); a verse (in the Bible chapter or a poem); a circle; a line of thatch or tie beams; a water wave; a longitude or latitude. ekokoro lok’akipi: a water wave. aira okokoron: to plant in rows. ekokot a red-beaked bird.ekokot1 concrete; bedrock.ekokota a seine net; a non-selective fishing net (catches small and large fish alike); a large marauding gang of armed cattle rustlers or raiders. ekokote1 cancer.ekokote kon nges kemiki eong adumun aswam: your jealousy prevented me from getting work. ekoleit a corruption of ekolia: a cat-fish.ekoleji a college; a further education college. Kaliro erai ekoleji loituutuonorere imwalimun lukosiniya ko Busoga: the National Teachers’ College Kaliro is a college for training secondary school teachers in Busoga region. ekoler insomniac; sleepless; wakeful. ekolera (singular noun M) cholera.ekoli a looped rope; a hook; a three-forked stick (to hang things on); a dipper; a long calabash with a handle. ekolia a lungfish; a mudfish; a cat-fish, Clarias.ekoliget a toothpaste; Colgate brand of toothpaste.ekolilit a cucumber seed. ekolimong a white-tailed mongoose, Ichneumia albicauda.ekolipana (of a person or an animal) sterile, barren or impotent. ekolo1 the soft stem of certain plants. ekolo loka amugogot: a stem (pith and xylem) of a banana plant; stem of papyrus. ekolo2 enmity; rivalry; antagonism; opposition; a contention; a quarrel; trouble; a feud; a dissention. ekolomiye a glossy starling (a bluish bird with red eyes, and eats red pepper). ekolono quarrelsome; troublesome; grumpy; grouchy; bad-tempered; tetchy; irritable; snappy; gruff; cranky. ekolor a bald man.ekomera a fence; a hedge; a barricade; a jail.ekomiiti a committee; a team; a working group; a panel. ekominiti1 the community; a group of people living in a particular locality. ekominiti2 seeta a community centre; a place where members of a community may meet for social, sporting or educational activities. ekomira finger euphorbia tree, Euphorbia tirucalli. Its latex is eye poison that can be neutralised by application of human milk. The plant can be used as a boundary marker or hedge. ekomision a commission (an official group); a working group or task force; a committee. ekomision loka aseo: an electoral commission. ekomisiona a commissioner (a member of a commission); an administrator. ekomisiona loka polis: a police commissioner (a high ranked police officer). arai kolo Stephen B. Akabway ekomisiona loka Ekomision Loedararoroi loka Aseo: Stephen B. Akabway was a commissioner in the Interim Electoral Commission. ekomol brown-spotted; having brown-spotted colours, as of goat, cow, python, cloth, a hyena, etc ekomoliana brown-spotted; having brown-spotted colours, as of goat, cow, python, cloth, a hyena, etc ekomyo a tree stump; poison (especially herbal, as used by witches).ekomyo kakirot: root of word, bottom of the truth, or of case. ekomyo loka emopiira: a strong man or a strong footballer, a football champion. ekone1 a big fish-hook.ekone2 a male friend (in Ngakarimojong); a male lover. ekongot a white ant (edible); a termite. ekonit1 (of fruit, food on fire) ripe; ready. ekonit2 akuwan dispirited; saddened. ekonokamu a grain ripening towards dry season, July-October; (formerly) a variety of sorghum, planted late and ripening in the dry season (kamu). ekontrakt a contract; a business deal. ejaiki eong edistrikt ekontrakt loka aiduk isomeroi: the district has awarded me a contract to build schools. ekontrakta a contractor; a supplier; a service provider. ekonyelet a dung-rolling beetle. ekonyokoit (singular noun M) a traditional ceremony (especially in Katakwi) of having a breastfeeding mother start eating beef with bone, and involves the killing of a bull supplied by the woman’s parents for the purpose, drinking of ajon, etc. (note: a breastfeeding woman is supposed to abstain from beef and vegetables cooked with amakadi or abalang - salt ash - in favour of offals such as small intestines and vegetables like emalakang that stimulate lactation).ekonyukoit a grass, Eragrostis turgida. ekoodakita a conductor; a man who collects fares from passengers on a bus, taxi, etc.ekoodo a door latch; a hook and eye; a press-stud. ekoodot an armed robber; a burglar; a bandit; a thug. ekoona a corner; an angle; a road junction or curvature. ekoosi a training course, curriculum, lessons, or classes. ekooti1 a coat.ekooti2 a law court; a magistrate’s court.ekopi a copy – reproduction, duplicate, replica, facsimile, print, carbon copy, photocopy, or a fake. ekopiton a tree whose bark is used for fibre, Dombeya goetzenii. ekor a species of animal – honey bear or ant-eater.
Iworopom ekitela an area of land clearly defined by natural swamp or valley boundaries

the holy bookof the Muslims.ekore a bush which if cut is believed to bring drought (no rain for long), Gardinia jovistonantis. ekori1 stinginess; miserliness.ekori2 a giraffe, Giraffa camelopardalis rothchildi; an okapi, Okapia johnstoni. isilo luka ekori armlet made of hair of giraffe’s tail or hair from the tail of any animal. ekori3 a line or a row of houses, plots, etc; a tail (of animal or of birds); buttocks; the stern of a boat.ekori6 k’ekunyuk a grass used as a broom, Eragrostis. ekori7 k’eris a grass (literally, a leopard’s tail), Setaria. ekori8 k’eris an insect like a bee that eats flies (literally, a leopard’s tail), Aristida ascensionis. ekorikitoi a giant rat that has a strange smell, Cricetonia gambianus.ekorikojwiny a bird with a long tail - a male weaver bird; widow-bird; a paradise fly-catcher (a polygamous bird) whose meat (used as a love potion) is believed to give a boy who eats it powers to attract many girls. ekorobe1 a line of plots (to be cultivated); a street. ekorobe loka itogoi: a line of houses or people; a street.ekorobwong an edible vegetable plant, Oxygonum atriplicifolium. ekoroi1 a male goat; a billy-goat; a he-goat. ekoroi2 a straggling shrub, Harrisonia abysinica, used for drying the afterbirth of animals (the afterbirth was formerly dried on that bush, smoked and eaten). ekorok a corruption of ekuruk: a pied crow.ekoroko a reed granary; (figurative) a prison.ekorokonyit slime; goo; gloop; gunk.ekoromait a tree in the acacia family, Acacia seyal. ekoromit a root of a waterlily; a waterlily; a floating yellow waterlily flower. inyo bo ingiitor ijo bala ikonyit ikorom?: why the display of teeth (anger) as if you have bitten the waterlily (said to be very bitter)? ekoropot (singular noun M) a creeping weed whose leaves are used as flavouring for certain vegetables, Commelina beniniense. ekorote a creeping shrub, Capparis.ekorubang an owl with no ear-like feathers; a barn owl.ekoruny an ankle.ekos immense; huge; gigantic. erai etom etyang ekos: an elephant is a huge animal. ekosile a grass whose root extract is a treatment for sore throat or to stimulate the expulsion of the placenta (afterbirth) in women, Eragrostis aspera. ekosimabu a grass, Chloris. ekosio a song; a chant; a hymn; a tune; a dance, bop, or boogie. ekosobwan a buffalo, Syncerus caffer. ekotono loving; affable. eong papa kon loakotono: I am your loving father. ngesi aberu kon naekotono: she is your loving wife. ekotonoro (of people) congenial, friendly, affable, amiable, pleasant, agreeable, good-natured, or hospitable. ekotot beloved; darling; dear. eong akoku kon naminat: I am your beloved daughter.ekristayot a Christian man. eku (in doing something) slowly; sluggishly; indolently. ipoi ijo ikoninyamat eku: you are late (you have been long in cooking your food). ilosi ijo eku: you walk slowly. iswamai ijo eku: you delay in your working. ekube a small eagle that hunts reptiles and can stay in the same spot in the air (by flapping its wings) while taking aim; a mouse buzzard.ekubui a tree with edible fruits, Ficus tonningii. akubui a leaf or branch of ekubui tree. ekucoi a corruption of ekicoi: a seasonal well, a waterhole, a burrow. ekude (singular noun M) animosity; hostility; hatred; loathing; ill-feeling; ill-will; enmity; bitterness; acrimony. ekudep a shrub, Teclea nobilis. Its leaves and roots are medicinal, while the sticks are used for firewood. ekudokina (as of cloth, road, rope, stick, etc) bent; crooked; folded. ekudulinga a big caterpillar. ekuetete froth; foam (of milk, soap or anything); suds. ekugulu a chequered woman’s dress, i.e. a dress having alternating patterns of squares or colours. ekuje (singular noun M) (euphemism) menstruation. edeka aberu ekuje: the woman is menstruating.ekujukuju (singular noun M) (formerly) a kind of tobacco used by Banyankole herdsmen in Teso. ekuku a species of bird, Lourie. ekukujo traditionally rolled tobacco (for smoking).ekukuny (of food) smell nice, pleasant, or enjoyable. akiring na ekukuny: this meat smells nice. ekukurana busy; industrious; hard working; zealous; diligent; active. ekukurut a black-biting ant. adeka naka ikukur: pimples caused by the bite of black biting ants.ekukut1 a tree stump; a broom stump. ekukut2 a footprint of man or animal. aibwapar ikukut: to follow footprints. ekukuye sternum. ekukwai a thorn; a spine; a prickle. ekulaac a clutch (a foot pedal of some cars that enables the driver to change gears). ekulac a creeping plant used as medicine against ticks, Strychnos innocua,. ekulam urine (generally) (of a person or animal).ecoe loka ekulam: urinary bladder. ekular a bald person; a bald head.ekulony a tree in the ekwooro and ekimeng family with smooth leaves and stems, Combretum collinum. Its root extract stops diarrhoea and vomiting, while the cut branches are used in fencing and building (atek); (euphemism) traditional or traditional medicine (herbs and roots, as administered by traditional medicine men).ekulu a jungle; high grass.ekulukulu a fish eagle; a turkey. ainyam ekulukulu: to eat without working for the food; to tramp about. enyami ngesi ekulukulu: she/he lives on the dole: she/he lives doing nothing.ekum an evergreen African ebony tree, Diospyros mespiliformis. Its wood is good for drum-making since it is fungus and termite resistant; fruit is edible, the bark and roots are medicinal. ekuma a cow-bell made of wood; an all-day dance without drums.
an Etesot man, so called by the Karimojong

a Kumam man (native of Kaberamaido district) who speaks a language akin to Luo and Ateso. ekumare a plant with edible leaves, Cassia tora.eyiete eong ikumes: I am bleeding through the nose. ekume kitaok a vegetable; (euphemism) butter or ghee (literally, a calf’s nose or a calf’s mucous). ekume kamerekek a kind of mushroom (literally, a sheep’s mucous). ikumes katitipu ‘nostrils’ (air-holes) of an anthill. ekume lokodos: an aquiline (or hooked) nose. ekume lobarany: a big flat nose (of a person). ekume locugur: a bent or curved nose. ekume k’auno: a noose. ekume lobatang a snub nose. ekumege a tree, Craibia laurentii. ekuna ordinary mist; light fog; haze. emuna: very thick mist or fog that greatly interferes with vision. ikunaikit akwap: it is foggy, misty, hazy.ekungin a weed, Brachiaria comata, Digitaria velutina urochooa panicoides. ekungur a shea-butter tree, Butyrospermum paradoxum subsp. niloticum.Used for timber and carving stools, high-quality charcoal; sheanut butter is extracted from roasted and pounded seeds mixed with water and boiled, and the fruit is edible when ripe.ekunia a poisonous medicine; a charm; a spell. emun loikuniai: a poisonous snake. abu ekunia kopia ikatunga: a charm or a poison killed all my people. ekunyuk1 a grass, Chloris. ekunyuk2 a ground squirrel, Xerus inauris.ekuolong the Uganda brown parrot.ekupup (of a person or an object) stubby; short, strong (of a stick or handle of a hoe). amusenu naekupup: a strong short handle of a hoe. ebela loekupup: a strong short stick. ekupuulu a lock; a padlock. ekuran a prickly shrub, Ptero lobium lacerans. ekurara yaws; syphilis. ekurara lourunet: congenital syphilis. ekuraut a tree growing near lakes, Acacia pennata. ekure a legendary plant, believed to stop rain from falling if touched by a person; a very long drought; a famine. ecai lolo ekure: there is a big drought these days. ejai ekure toma akwap: there is famine.ekuret1 a large fishing hook.ekuriei a timid man; a coward; a backslider. ekuron ash (remains of a wood fire).kidupok acokit okuruba: cast that potato into the heap of hot ashes.ekuruk1 (slang) an Anglican pastor (because of the white collar). ekuruk2 a pied crow (a bird in the raven family, but with a white ring of feathers on its neck); Cormorant. inyo kolo kisisianakini oni ainap ataayi? ekuruk: (a riddle) what taught us to wear a necktie? a pied-crow. ekurukuru an edible root. ekurungat an anklet. ekurunyon a man who melts lard for use in cooking. ekurupeta a 5-centimetre knife worn on the thumb for harvesting millet.ekurut1 a worm; a caterpillar; a maggot; a bacterium; a small insect; a virus; a germ. ededeng ekurut loka esilim: HIV is very fatal. ekurut2 an eagle coloured like a guinea-fowl.ekurwokina futile; in vain; impossible; unworkable. alosite kus erai naekurwokina: your journey is futile, in vain. ekurwokina akirot ngin aiirar: that is a mystery. ekus a pin; a needle; a point of spear; a prickle; axle (of the earth).ekusai naughtiness; cheek. ejai ijo ekusai: you are cheeky(you have cheek).ekuse (of meat) lean; bony; wiry; sinewy.ekusu a parrot.ekutukana (of a person) hot-tempered; rude; quarrelsome; harsh; unruly; strict. ekutukong an ant-bear; aardvark, Orycteropus afer. ekutukwap a short poisonous burrowing snake. ekutur a dwarf.ekuukuut a red and black bird living in swamps and makes such sound as it perches on a tree.ekuulit (singular noun M) snuff; (formerly) tobacco used by Karimojong, Nandi, Kipsigis, Masai, or Kikuyu. ekuulu an ostrich, Struthio camelus (the female ostrich is called aula, the male is otiira). ekuuruny the ankle. ekuurunyit the ankle.ekuwam1 (of face) rough (like unshaven); (of body) rough (like crocodile, lizard, etc. skin)ekuwam2 a rough bodied person or animal. ekuwe a fox; a black-backed jackal, Canis mesomelas.ekuyum (of biscuits) soft; (of dry soil) loose; (of boiled amukeke) soft and floury. ekwaaso a safety pin.ekwadakwada a water-beetle; a crab. ekwadoit1 (formerly) a variety of finger millet (Eleusin corocona). ekwakoit2 (formerly) a variety of big-seeded and thick testa maize.ekwalakwala a small evergreen tree, Garcinia buchananii. Its fruit wine is drank, the fruits are edible while the wood is for firewood and building. ekwalinga whitlow (on finger or sheep’s foot). ekwam wind, air; measles; smallpox. ikwamin: demons or evil spirits; weather. ekusi ekwam: the wind is blowing; it is windy. adeka naka ekwam: measles or smallpox outbreak. ekamutu apese ngin ikwamin: demons have possessed that girl. ejautene loikwamin: the state of weather (especially, winds). ekwana (of knife, poison, tongue) sharp; keen; acute. ekwana ekileng lo, ekwaka akwaras ngun adepar: this knife is sharp, those spears are sharper. ekwana akituk: quarrelsome ekwang white; pale; ashen. ekwang kia: very white. ekwanga1 a grey tree associated with cursing, Croton macrostachyus. ekwanga2 a plant with bright flowers and whose bark is used for fibre, Lachnophylis oppositifolia. ekwangal a light, thin (not heavy) person. ekwangale (formerly) a white variety of finger millet. ekwangan a sailor; a ferry-man; one who takes people across water in a canoe; a marine. ekwange (singular noun M) whiteness; white dust (of flour); brightness. elelebun ijo ekwange loka akiria: you are white with dust (after grinding grain or cassava). ekwaru a serval cat, Felis serval. ekwe a plant, Calotropis procera. ekwecit the spur of a cock-bird or of a python snake; the arm (arms) of an armchair. eicolong loka ikwec: the armchair. ebela loka ikwec: a forked stick. ekwee a jackal, Canis mesomelas; a fox (believed to portend death in the family when it barks in the vicinity).ekwele ngesi she/he is (they are) anaemic. ekweny a bird; an aircraft or plane.ekweru a kind of bush, root of which is used as medicine; medicine from ekweru bush. korukokinai ekweru kager akuwan: pound the ekweru root for me to incise in my body. ekwikwi1 a kind of mushroom. ekwikwi2 (singular noun M) a quiet laugh; asthma. ekwiniini quinine (drug for malaria). ekwinyikwiny epilepsy; fits; hysteria. ekwooro a small tree in the ekimeng and ekulony family, Combretum molle. The root extract is medicine for hookworms, snake bites, stomach-ache, fever, dysentery and leprosy. ekyala the hearth; one of the three traditional stones on which a cooking pot rests when on fire; a stove; a tripod. elaagano a competition; a contest.elaanakina spaced; having spaces in between. elaanakina epaaba: the cotton is planted apart. elabo cream (of milk).elabwata (singular noun M) a method of arresting or catching animals by throwing a rope round the neck or the legs. elacac loose; untied; unlocked; released; undone. elacamuk a large monitor lizard.elacara loose; untied; unlocked; released; undone. elace (singular noun M) the way or method of loosening, undoing, untying, opening, undressing, etc. elacet a key; a spanner (of a car, plough, etc). elacit a louse (a parasitic insect that lives in dirty clothes and hair). elado an arm-band of zebra tail hair; a fly whisk (switch) made of a zebra’s tail used in certain traditional dances (such as ajosi, ekirakira) as a costume tied above the elbow. elagagamit the collar-bone; clavicle. elagara a grass used for thatching and whose root extract is a remedy for measles, Hyparrhenia rufa. elago a cobweb; fluff; cream (of milk).elaisi an auction sale; a grand sale (prices are low). elakara joyful; happy; glad; cheerful. elakas a tree of which the branches are used to make a fence. elakit (singular noun M) divorce; separation; split of marriage.elala (singular noun M) alarm; warning; attention. apupunit eong elala: I heard the alarm.elamai a wild-grape fruit shrub or tree, Ximenia americana. Uses: its fruit juice is used to flavour or season atap and vegetables; oil used in lubrication and soap is extracted from its seeds; its sticks are used for fuel and building. elamit (singular noun M) a curse; a malediction; an anathema. elangir heavy; thick; difficult; weighty; burdensome; important. elangir epelu lo: this task is hard. elangir akirot na: this is a difficult case. (euphemism) (of a woman) pregnant. aberu naelangir: a pregnant woman. aitalangir: to burden.
eodo, elekumare ekume the nose; a road culvert; nostrils; mucous of nose; the front of a boat; a bridge
a Langi tribesman native to Apac or Lira districts of northern Uganda

a common Teso name.elap moon; month. elamu elap: new moon has risen. emaaraniki elap: first quarter. ekesaki elap: the moon is overhead. agonga elap: the moon is leaning to the west (three quarter moon). alumo elap: the moon has set. alosit olap: adeka elap: to have menstruation (literally, to go to the moon: to suffer from the moon). aica naka elap: moonbeam or moonlight. aige elap: to start a new month. atwana elap: the old moon has gone (literally, the moon has died). elap losodit: January; the first month. elap loiyareit: February; the second month. elap lokiuniet: March; the third month. elap loiwongonet: April; the fourth month. elap loikanyet: May; the fifth month. elap loikanyet-kape: June; the sixth month. elap loikanyet-kaare: July; the seventh month. elap loikanyet-kauni: August; the eighth month. elap loikanyet-kaongon: September; the ninth month. elap loitomonet: October; the tenth month. elap loitomonet-kalodiop: November; the eleventh month. elap loitomonet-kaluare: December; the twelfth month. elapada a kind of grass. elapat clear; open; bare. elapat erot: the road is clear, clean (no weeds, no people on it, no overhang). elarilar a common grey lizard, mostly staying on granaries.elaro a firmament; the sky; an international airport. elarwarwa a crackling of joints. elatiri a stone used in weighing scales; pound weight. elaunana disobedient; obstinate; neurotic. and v.i. eleana fond of beating or caning. elebeni a spirit-level.elecorai a tree, Crossoptery febrifuga. eleget (of character) clean; chaste; beautiful; just. elejek weak; flexible; soft. elekede (formerly) a variety of big red beans, Phaseolus vulgaris. elekek a gourd with a long neck. etwo lolekek: a gourd with a long neck. ikisin lulekekin breasts with long nipples. eleket mouth of river; bay, inlet. eleketete a creeping weed whose boiled pounded leaves are used as a disinfectant for livestock and a potion taken by breast-feeding mothers to stimulate the production of more milk, Portulaca sp. elekumare a vegetable shrub, Acacia sp.elelana fond of rejoicing; festive; jovial; celebratory; jolly. elele1 (of food, especially cassava in marshland) watery and likely to cause vomiting. elele2 a grass whose growth in a place indicates the soil is good for growing crops, and is also a remedy for wounds, Setaria sphacelata. elele3 a vegetable, Sesamum.elele4 a white faced tree-duck.elele5 (singular noun M) shame; ignominy.elele ka lo/na: shame upon him/her. elelebo1 a creeping clover. elelebo2 (singular noun M) a corruption of elelebwa: dizziness; vertigo.elelebwa (singular noun M) epilepsy; dizziness.elelekeja (singular noun M) a rain-dance. eleleku a grass, Eragrostis superba. elelemit a tadpole or larvae (in the water).eleli1 blithe; merry; happy-go-lucky; amiable; happy. eleli2 a striped mouse, Rhabdomys pumilio (a dormouse – believed to portend a beer party if it crosses one’s path). elem a bull, goat, etc without horns. lolem M, nalem F hornless. emong lolem hornless bull(s). elemana quick at, fond of picking or removing or stealing. elemelemet a tadpole or larvae (in the water).elemet allergic swellings caused by eating pork, ham or bacon when one has yaws.elemuni perhaps. elemuni alot: perhaps she/he/it has gone.elemunyang a legendary sickness or disease of dogs; a stye in the eye.elemura the only child (male) born to a woman.elemurang (singular noun M) (formerly) a variety of sorghum grown in the hot season.elemut a sheanut - the seed of ekungur; a kernel or seed of a fruit.elemwoono (of an animal) hornless. elepa (singular noun M) impudence; cheekiness; nonsense. koyanga ekonilepa ngina: go away, you impudent fellow! (literally, take your impudence away). elepit1 a bush, Mimusops fragrans. elepit2 a milking pail or jug. akile elepio k’elepit: milk is milked into a milk pot or pail.elepo a gerbil or desert rat; a rat burrowing in the sand, Taterillus emini. elepulepu an evergreen hardwood tree, Mimusops kummel. Its fruits (alepulepwo) are edible, and the wood is for timber and charcoal. elepunoit a boil.eles a tree or sun-squirrel, Heliosciurus cepapi.elet1 a grass, Eragrostis. elet2 a grassy plain along a river. eleuleu a tree growing in swamps, Melia azederach. eleuleut a water-lily, Gloriosa variifolia. eli a large pot, with a fairly narrow neck, in which beer is mixed and left to ferment for a few days; a large beer brewing pot. eliagam a tall man; a high tree, etc. iliagam ekitoi ngol: that tree is very tall. elibaana green; emerald; lime; jade; olive; verdant. elibibi milk cream.elibit verdant; lush; leafy; grassy. elicerai a tree used for building poles, Crossopteryx febrifuga. elidaana (of a person or rubber band) holding tight; relentless; revengeful, vindictive. elidana (of a glutton) picking big morsels of food; greedy. elidio unripe; premature; very young, fresh, raw. elidio acok: the potatoes are premature. eligim (qualitative verb) to be distended (of belly, on account of pregnancy or food). akoik naligim: akoik nailigimim: a distended stomach. eligoi a bush used for hedges, Euphorbia tirucalli; a gum tree with white latex. eliibo a graveyard; a cemetery; a funeral home.eliiro a kingfisher bird. elikidi1 (singular noun M) green grams (the plant or its seeds).elikot a small fishing hook.elilat a blind worm.elilim cool; cold; clammy; chilly. elilim akwap: it is cold. akoto akipi nuelilim: I want cold water. elilim cii ci: very cold; cool. elilim akuwan: to have no go, laid-back. elilim ngesi akuwan: she/he has no go in her/him. elilingan one who has the habit of keeping silent; a taciturn or introverted man. elilot1 a sesamum plant, Sesamum spp. elilot2 sauce made from groundnuts paste and elilot plant. elilyo a tree fibres of which are used for tying, Securidaca longipedunculata.Among its many uses are: the leaves are antidotes for snake bite and a cough mixture, powdered bark is an abortifacient, the root infusion is for tooth-ache, the roots are for soap, the seeds and flowers are for oil production, while the wood is used for firewood and poles. elimilim (singular noun M) a drizzle; drops of rain; a little rain. elingaana marked black and white or red and white. elinget a mark; a sign of anything, water or milk; a water mark; a boundary or limit in graduated instrument. elingo (of quality of cooking atap) bad, poor or unprofessional. ipoete kesi elingo: they cook badly; they do not allow water for mingling bread to boil, or they over-boil it.eliodo a small brown hornbill that nests in tree-holes.eliogot clean; pure; immaculate; holy; perfectly clean. Edeke ngesi emoyo loliogot: God is a holy or perfect spirit. eliokine a plant with plenty of sap, Lactuca capensis. elipilepo a small tree, Sapium ellipticum. Its roots and leaves are medicine for mumps, and the wood is for firewood and charcoal. elipongait a black stinging ant (believed to prefer biting genitals). elir a deaf man; a hearing-impaired male; a very stupid man. elir kapugan: a prize fool (literally, a government fool); a scapegoat.elira1 a small tree mostly grown in homesteads as a source of timber, Melia azedarach. Its seeds are poisonous and the leaf effusion is used as insecticide on vegetable gardens. elira lomoit: a neem tree, Azadirachta indica. The bark of a neem tree is medicinal, the root system keeps termites away, while the powdered leaves contain azadirachtin used as a fumigant/ insecticide for grain weevils. elira2 (singular noun M) rinderpest.eliri silk. enapit amucaalat egoe loliri: the lady is wearing a silk dress. elirira a deaf mute; a deaf and dumb man. elisina1 excessive wealth (in cattle). ejai ngesi elisina epol: she/he is rich in cattle.elisina2 (singular noun M) fog; mist.elisipata a small Spanish horse, Genetta stuhlmanni. elit a parasitic plant - mistletoe - Loranthus; an amulet; witchcraft (in general). elit etasuro: an amulet worn to frighten or terrorise an opponent. elit emakak: an amulet worn to immobilise or paralyse an opponent. elit edusutau: elit eramatau: a charm for causing someone to love you; a love potion. elitoto a variety of simsim grain used for oil extraction. eloa1 (singular noun M) a fungal infestation of the skin, Tinea versicolor; ringworms; a skin disease or ringworm of adult people, cattle and other animals.It's a hard wood tree for timber, the root and leaf extract are used as medicine for mental illnesses. eloba a hartebeest (a species of antelope), Tragelaphus oryx. elodot reeds, withes or osier twigs used as horizontal rafters to tie grass thatch or roof of traditional huts.elogec bandy-legged; bow-legged. elogook a tree, Acalypha villicante. elogoroto Adam’s apple; the slight lump, part of the thyroid gland, that projects from the front of a man’s neck. eloit a peg; a tether (to measure a house or to tie an animal). eloit lokaswam: occupation. kiyenikina iso oloit lokaswam: we are tied down by duty. kiyenikitai iso toma oloit loka aitumunet: we are bound by our promise. Eloket1 (an Ateso derogative reference to) a Karimojong tribesman (especially a cattle rustler or raider). eloket2 a Karimojong headdress or hair ornament. elokile a plant whose root is used as a purgative as well as an emetic, Sonchus bipontini.elokit loka etul: a pelvic joint. elokomacar the dorsum or root of the penis; the hinge of the penis. elolom (of a borehole or well) having few people; empty; vacant; unfilled; free. elolom lolo ecor, mam itunga emariaete akipi: the borehole is free today, people are not struggling to fetch water. elomabon (singular noun M) (in Karamoja) a cassava tuber or plant (literally, that which grows by itself).elomet entrance; exit; a club or spear (a thing to enter or come out at night with). alomet (for feminine things). elomocor a penis of a big animal, such as a he-goat or a bull. elomorut a trap or knot. elongot a (man’s or dog’s) penis. elongwaana (of a person) idle; lazy. elongwaut one who is from outside the clan; a stranger; an alien.elono a desert rose, Adenium globesum. A very poisonous shrub whose latex and root extract is medicine for boils and venereal diseases, the sap as arrow poison, and pounded roots are fish poison and rat bait. elooji a lodge; an inn. eloon a loan; a financial advance; credit. eloori a lorry; a truck. elooro a tertiary syphilis causing enlargement of groin, Alopecia.elopane accusation; blaming; finger pointing. elope1 by himself; alone; the very one. iboyie ngesi elope bon: he lives by himself. ijo elope: you yourself. ngesi ejakait elope: he is the chief himself (no other person). elope2 the owner. elope akwap: a male native or inhabitant of a region or country. eong elope akituk: I am the owner of the cows. ilope (neuter): the owner (general).elopodo a species of tilapia fish with a wide mouth. elore a beam of light of the sun, moon, etc.; a dazzle. elos dirt; filth (as in finger nails); dirt on body; a personal smell. erono ekonilos: you are hated or you are unfortunate (literally, your smell is bad). elose (singular noun M) a gait; a way of walking; a mode of transport. elotot an edible burrowing rat.elou a coat (worn by women); (formerly) an animal-skin shawl worn over one shoulder.kekamutu eong ilowun: I have become poor.eluatat one who urinates (in bed or anywhere) often. elubooni an earnest, i.e. a part-payment made in advance, especially to confirm an agreement; an advance, i.e. money paid to someone before payment is due; a deposit. elucat an amulet or talisman used superstitiously to prevent death of children. eluera whooping cough; bronchitis; disease of the chest or lungs.
emiroit; enyakoit: a man from the north
an Indian man. elugum (of the belly, etc) round, blown out. elugura sitting down with a bent back
stooping; hunched; arched. eluguras ilugai k’okekiakec: the Indians sit down at their door with bent backs.

a man native to Arua district. Ilugwaara: the Lugbara people of West Nile in Uganda. elujuk flexible; supple; soft; weak, not strong; lithe. auno naalujuk: a flexible rope. elujuk isapat ngin: that little boy is not strong. eluk adultery. aikamun etunganan eluk: to catch a person in adultery. alemun eluk: aigel eluk: to pay fine for adultery. aswam nuk’eluk: to commit adultery. ikamunitai ngesi eluk: he (she) was caught in adultery. abu ngesi kogel eluk: she/he paid fine for adultery.eluke a fast-flying green pigeon. elukumit a thousand. ilukumin ka ilukumin: thousands upon thousandselulu an alarm cry; hue and cry; warning. epurie elulu kokide, apotu Ilok: the alarm is sounding from the east, the Karimojong raiders have come. elumang (of a person) stupid; dull; (of an animal) hornless.elungung objectionable; repulsive; detestable; hateful; disgusting. elupe clay for bricks or pottery. elure a wild cat.elurun haggard; drooping; sagging; fatigued; very weak. abu kadum nges iluruna: I found her/him exhausted. elutaari an altar; a shrine.eluurut1 a tree insect - a cicada. Eluurut2 an Alur tribesman from the district of Nebbi and speaking a Luo dialect called Alur. Iluurun: the Alur people in general. eluwe (to swallow) whole; intact; complete (without masticating or chewing). ailik eluwe: to swallow like a dog; to gulp down solid food. eluworo desperate; anxious; treacherous; changed. elwala an olive baboon (a maize pest), Papio cynocephalus.elwana akwap: it is far.elwanalwanakina far apart; sparse; thinly populated (of a country). itunga luelwanalwanakina: people who live far apart. erai Moroto akwap naelwanalwanakina ireria: Moroto district is a place where homes are far apart. elwanalwanat rather far; not very far; rather soon. ebuni ngesi, konye eroko ber apak elwanalwanat: she/he is coming but not very soon. elwanikina aloof; unfriendly; distant; far off. elwata a plant whose leaves are used as seasoning for ecadoi, eodo, and emoros, Erythrococoa kirkii. elweera whooping cough; pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) - disease of the lungs with coughing; bronchitis. aingalakin etunganan elweera: to give somebody poison that causes bronchitis.ilyana ijo akile: you smell after fresh milk. ilyaka yesi agaria: you smell after fresh fish. elyaka akile ngun: the milk has a fresh (newly milked) smell. elyokono deceitful; deceiving; lying; false-hearted. etunganan loelyokono: a deceitful man. ema a ritual grass, Hyperrhenia themadra. It's used for building mock huts in swamps that are burnt during the purification ceremony for those who have committed incest. aicwe ema: to perform a purification ceremony for those who have committed incest (sexual intercourse between close relatives - considered wizardry in Teso culture). emaabo a kind of shrub used in the twin dances; a creeping plant. emaagalo pincers; a pair of pliers; forceps. emaagira (singular noun M) crushed peas cooked in the magadi salt and fried groundnut paste mixed with it – best eaten with fresh cooked sweet potatoes. emaala1 a dog tick. emaala2 a stye (a small swelling on the base of the eyelid).ejokuna aur da, ikonikoku eyauni emaali ore: it is also good to bear (and educate) children, they are a source of wealth to the home. emaara a huge strong bull; a male buck or deer (Uganda kob); a very strong man. emaaridi a nickname for Crested Crane brand of cigarettes, because of its aroma that lingers on the smoker’s path. emaaset a locust. ebunit emaase epol noi: there is a big swarm of locusts coming.emabaleo a fashion; a craze; a fad. emabuusut a prisoner; a detainee; an inmate; a jailbird; a convict.emabwor a red patas monkey, Erythrocebus patas.emacar1 a fishing spear.emacaret a kind of grass; a tool for beating, drawing, tattooing, branding, etc. emadak a bush, Annona chrysopholla. emadangit a tick; a mite.emaderait (formerly) a purple variety of sweet potatoes (popular in Madera in Soroti district).

a dwarf; a Madi tribeman; a man native to Moyo or Adjumani districts on the north-western tip of Uganda. Imadi: the Madi people in general. emadoit an armlet or wristlet. emaekeke pyorrhoea or dental caries (a disease that loosens teeth and swells gums). emaet (of a name) pertaining to flattery or praise. ekiror lomaet: a nickname; a pet name.
a man native of Busoga or Bugwere

a Musoga or Mugwere tribesman. Imagara: Basoga, Bagwere people.emagegerit a hoof (of a grass-eating animal); a claw.emagorot a wild sheep or goat. emaido groundnuts; a cashew-nut. emaidokoit a kidney-fruit tree; a cashew-nut tree or its nut, Anacardium occidentale. The liquid resin in a raw cashew-nut was traditionally used for tattooing people's bodies.The fruit and the roasted nuts are edible, while oil for varnishing and brake lining is extracted from the raw nuts. emaikina named; called. ekiror lomaikina ijo: the name given to you.

a man native of Bugisu, i.e. the present day Mbale and Sironko districts in eastern Uganda. Imaikoko: the Bagisu or Bamasaba people (in general).emairungi an evergreen shrub, Catha edulis. Its stalked leaves and shoots are chewed as a stimulant as well as medicine to treat asthma, cough, stomach-ache and chest pain. This tree grows in mountains in Karamoja, and its leaves are chewed by Somali people as a drug to prevent sleep. emait a corruption of ema: a kind of tall grass. emajaani an evergreen tea bush, the leaves of which tea is made, Camellia sinensis. emaji an eel-like fish, Mastacembalus victoria. emajing a deaf man.emakaasa a pair of scissors. emakada a tangerine, mandarin; a kind of orange tree or fruits, Citrus reticulata. The fruits are eaten.
a Muganda tribesman from the Baganda tribe – one of the Bantu-speaking tribes of central Uganda

a man native to Buganda – the present day Masaka, Mukono, Kampala, etc. Imakada: the Baganda people (in general).emakak (singular noun M) a paralysing charm; a spell. emakanika a mechanic (a person who repairs machines). emakaut a harveting knife.emakole hand-made foul-smelling cigars.emakuk a traditional two, three, or four-legged stool; a bobbin stool.emal a barbed arrow (shot with a bow). emal loebakere abus (formerly) an arrow for opening abscess. emalaika an angel; a seraph; a cherub. emalakang a sour vegetable good for breast-feeding mothers to eat to stimulate production of milk, Hibiscus sabdariffa.emalas a gourd for keeping unchurned milk; a churn (the milk is poured from the elepit - milking pail - into emalas). esosol bala emalas: pungent like (fermented milk in) a churn.emalayane prostitution; sex trade. emaler a shrub or tree, Vangueria apiculata. Uses: its hard fruit is edible; the poles for building; firewood and charcoal for fuel. emalera a red gown. ecamakinitai allowed; authorised; sanctioned; free to; allowed to do something that you want to do. emame absent; missing; not in attendance. emameotor without; lacking; free from. emaleria (singular noun M) malaria fever (from mosquito bites); (of a person) having a high temperature.emalit a lesser kudu, Tragelaphus imberbis - a species of antelope.emaneja a manager.emanerit katokon: your mother’s clitoris (an insult).emangor (singular noun M) a stew (a mixture of fresh sweet potatoes and peas/beans cooked together). emanikor a big garden; a cultivated farm.emaniman a climbing plant, Rhoicissus erytrodes; Clematis incisodentata. emanit a plant used for making beer tubes; a drinking tube made from this plant.emanukeret a bird in the thrush family. emany a liver (an organ). emanyata a manyatta; a Karimojong encampment or homestead.emanyit1 clotted blood (used for food); a blood clot (in the blood vessel can cause heart attack). aponi kibungai ekokolan toni aitelekun imanyin: the thief was beaten to near death (literally, beaten until he spat blood clots). emanyit2 a marriage ceremony where dowry or bride price is agreed on or paid. epu itunga alositos omanyit ke Arugai: there were many people who went to Arugai’s marriage party.emapeera a guava fruit or tree, Psidium guajava. The fruit is edible, and the wood is used for poles and firewood. emapule an iroko or Muvule hard wood tree famous for its heavy timber, Milicia excelsa.emaret a cowpea (in general) or a bean, Phaseolus tephrosia. emarooge a bean seed or plant, Phaseolus vulgaris.emasenik a choice bull or male of all herbivorous (i.e. grass-eating) animals. (jocular) a man; a big man. emaset a cup, a vessel for drinking; a little gourd used as a drinking cup; a cupping horn for sucking blood. emaswa a big man; a young bull. emata drinkable. akipi numam ematas: undrinkable water. ematakiro a small tree, Lannea schweinfurthii subsp. stuhlmannii. Its fruit is edible, the roots, bark and leaves have medicinal properties. The wood is used for firewood, timber and charcoal burning. ematata a swelling in the neck. ematerai a tree, Vangueria edulis.ematira an isolated traditional (small) hut.ematooke a variety of banana plant bearing bananas for cooking while green.ematun drinkable; (of liquid) can be drawn. akipi numam ematunos: undrinkable water. ematuuda a passion fruit or plant in general, Passiflora edulis. Its fruit is used as food, drink or wine. emaweeli bulrush millet. emedelit the little finger or toe. emeeba a member (of a club, an association, or committee); a representative. emeeba loka airabet: a member of parliament (MP). emeedera a banner; a standard; a streamer; a flag; an ensign; a pennant, pennon; colours; a bunting. emeesa a (dining) table. emeesa loejengere: (in a hospital) an operating table. ejai eitaabo omeesa: the book is on the table. emeimei (singular noun M) a skin disease which causes round scales on the scalp; a head ring worm.

a man from the Bakenye tribe - a fisher tribe of Bantu origin that lives near lakes in Teso. Imekenyin: the Bakenye people in general. emeketa (formerly) a variety of sweet potatoes. emelekede (singular noun M) a worm infestation of the human or animal gut.emeleku a hoe. emeleku loka imongin: an ox plough. emelemeloana shiny and brown-spotted, like a bluebottle (a large fly with a shiny blue body). emelemeloi a brown spotted fat edible grasshopper. emelet a swallow (bird). emelikin an evergreen tree in the ekum and emusya family, Craibia laurentii. emelut the head of a penis

meatus of the penis; the glans.emenana malcontent; rebellious; disobedient. emengerana disobedient; defiant; insolent. emenia a houe or fruit bat (in general), Eidolon helvum.emeo a grass with cutting leaves. emera drunk; inebriated; intoxicated; rusty; high; under the influence. emerana (of a person) habitually drunk or inclined to be drunk. emerekek1 a ram; a male sheep; an abnormally big or fat sheep. emerekek2 a water fly (running on top of the water); a dragonfly.emeret drunkenness (caused by alcohol); dizziness; light-headedness; wooziness; giddiness. epol lolo nges emeret: she/he is very drunk today. emeri striped (bluish colour). emeridian (noun neuter) longitude; an imaginary line on the earth’s surface passing through the poles at right angles to the equator (these lines run from north to south). emeridian 0o: longitude 0o. emerikol any striped animal; a spotted genet, Genetta genetta. emerimong a tribal division; a tree in the ekum family, Craibia laurentii.emerukwa a ploughing ox; a ploughing bull; a big bull; a draught ox; a man who does all the difficult work; a big strong man. mam eong arai ekonimerukwa: I am not your ploughing ox (I am not going to do your dirty, heavy work). emeswa a nest of a rat; rat hole. (figurative) a poor man’s home or house; a humble abode. alosi eong omeswaka: I am going to my humble home (abode).emidaalit a medal; a medallion; a pendant. emidet a point of an arrow or spear (the tip of any weapon); a teat (of breast); a peak (of a spire, turret, or of a mountain).emidil a man with slit dirty eyes. emidit a tree in the ebyong family, but with smaller leaves and fruit, Ficus capensis; a parasite, a leech. iramaana ijo bala emidit: you hang onto somebody like a leech: please, mind your own business. emidol (singular noun M) the sap from sweet potatoes. emiitono wealthy in crops; abounding in. emiitoko kesi inyamat: they are rich in food. emiliangole a Karimojong bull with a white spot on the forehead. emilimili shining; flashy. ecucut loemilimili: a bluebottle (fly). emilionit a million. imilionin ka imilionin: millions upon millions.emilisiat a militia man; a civilian fighting force used to supplement a regular army in emergencies. emimir (of butter) rancid, rotten, sour, or stale. emina sticky sap; resin; gum; glue; adhesive; latex. emina loka etaba: nicotine. eminaasi a coconut fruit. eminana amatory; affable; genial; pleasant; friendly; sociable; easy-going; jovial. eminanara compatible; congenial; like-minded; well-suited; agreeable. eminat dear; the beloved one or favourite one; dear one; popular; darling (used in letters, translated as ‘yours dearly’). Lokon eminat: Yours affectionately…(used by male writers). Nakon aminat: Yours affectionately (used by female writers). eminit a tree in the etirir and ekisim family, but with leaves darker than etirir but with fewer thorns, found growing near swamps, Acacia gerrardii.The bark has medicinal properties. emir a generic name for a rat. emira (singular noun M) an African tree used for its myrrh resin (i.e. a resin from an African tree used for medicine and perfume). emiria a hippopotamus, Hippopotamus amphibious. emiroit1 (formerly) a black variety of finger millet supposedly introduced from Lango.Emiroit2 a man native to Lango, i.e. of the districts of Lira and Apac; a Langi tribesman (one of the Luo-speaking peoples of northern Uganda).emisa the sacrament of Holy Mass. emisaani a weighing scale. emisikaut a plant, Sesbania. emision a Roman Catholic mission (a residence for priests and nuns). emisyana observant; discerning; shrewd; intelligent; wise. emita a distance measure of one metre; a metre rule. imitai 1,000 ejaas toma okilomita ediope: a thousand metres are in a kilometre.Its leaves have medicinal properties. emitina scabies; mange in animals and people.emiyono tending to be wealthy in crops. emocana fond of joking; playful. emocet a joke; badinage. koinakinai iso emocet: tell us a joke. emocet bon mere ejie: it is only joking not fighting. emod1 a hair-dress made of clay to fix in feathers. emod2 elephantiasis of the legs.emodana deceitful; cunning; sly; wily; devious; crafty; sneaky; shrewd; scheming. emodingoit a variety of finger millet.emodio- (prefix used with masculine nouns) some; a little of. akoto emodiodia: I want some sauce or vegetables. emodiodek: some peas pudding.emodit deception; eyewash; a ruse. emodo a civet cat, Viverra civetta. emodol (singular noun M) the burnt remnants from boiled sweet potatoes or cassava. emodu a scoop-shaped head of eipiret used for mashing cooked peas or sweet potatoes. emoit1 a male foreigner, especially of Bantu origin; a non-native; a Karimojong raider or rustler; a gentile. adeka naka imo: stomatitis (in babies at teething time).emoit2 an imported crop or grain (especially millet, maize, or potato variety).emojong an old man above 66 years of age (no longer paying graduated tax); a crock.emojongana inclined to look or grow old soon, especially of a woman. emokoda (singular noun M) fractiousness; faddiness; pickiness; peevishness; pettiness; fastidiousness; meticulousness, precision, or annoying care.emokol a big rat; a giant rat.emokoliait a traditional medicine man or doctor believed to have the art of making barren women fertile; a traditional bishop. emokorat a criminal person; a villain; one who acts against the law. emolojon an edible plant, Kleinia longiflorus. emolokony a hoof (of a person or an animal); a trotter (of pigs, etc).ikong luka emome: black edible flying ants. emomo a tree, Sporospermum campestre. emomwai sorghum vulgare. ajon nuka imomwa: beer made from sorghum.emon a grass, Harpachne schimperi. emonaki a monarchy; a kingdom. emong a bull; a motto or maxim. emong edonge: a castrated bull; an ox. emong emasenik: a choice bull for mating. eiruk lo Uganda ebala, ‘kanuka Edeke ka akakwap’: the Uganda motto says, ‘For God and my Country’. emongomongot a curd; a ball or cake of fried akiria (beer dough). emoni a plant, Crotalaria senecio discifolium. emono a field or food crop destined for a famine period; a food bank; a bank balance (money in the account to cater for emergencies); a child’s garden from which the harvest is not normally eaten unless the parents stock of food runs out. emonuk a well-fed person; a big bellied man.emopiira a ball; football; a big tyre. emopim a smelling plant used as flit against mosquitoes or to wash hands after burial or after eating smelly things like fish, Ocimum; a plant, Coleus aromatic. emor1 a food mixture; any combination. emor2 black remnants after the boiling of butter, eaten as food.
the Iteso cultural leader whose duties, among other things, is to revive, preserve and promote the Teso culture (including Ateso language literacy)

the chief executive of all Teso clans. emoringa a horse-radish tree, Moringa oleifera. A highly valued shrub - the fruits and young leaves are eaten, the leaves and fruits have medicinal properties, the seeds are used in oil extraction and water purification, and young roots are spices. emoro (singular noun M) (archaic) a day; a period of time. ecemoro: some day; another day. emoro lo: today. ediomoro: some day. ngolimoro always, every day. emorono abusive; obnoxious; insulting; rude. emoroko kesi: they are fond of insulting, scolding, etc emoros (singular noun M) a creeper used as a vegetable seasoning, Cissus adenocaulis. It removes the bad smell from ecadoi, ekabit, or eodo and gives the other vegetables a smooth feel. It is also used as a costume at rain-dances, or as a drug to procure abortion or rubbed on feet to treat sores caused by stepping on human faeces. emorosing a neck; the front of neck. ejai ngesi emorosing: she/he is stiff-necked; she/he is stubborn; she/he is proud; she/he is cheeky, insubordinate.emorotot a python. emoru a big stone; mountain; big rock. emorudoi a tree, Strychnos. emorukaalet a martial eagle, Polemaetus bellicosus; an eagle capable of killing an animal the size of a kid. emorumoru (formerly) a variety of finger millet; a plant species, Hibiscus lunarfolicos. emoto a grass whose presence indicates that the soil is not fertile, Strigacelosia havaya. emotoka a motorcar; an automobile; a car. emoyo the spirit; the soul. Emoyo Loagion: (in the Catholic faith) a Holy Spirit. Emoyo Lokalaunan: (in the Protestant faith) the Holy Spirit. emuatonit a twin.emuatonon a twin. emuceeri rice grain; a rice paddy field.

a man native to Kigezi (the present day Uganda districts of Kabale and Kisoro), speaking a Bantu language called Rukiga. Imuciga: the Bakiga people in general. emucuuga a sweet orange tree or fruit in general, Citrus sinensis. The fruits are eaten or drank as orangade while the peels, leaves, and flowers are used to extract citrus oil.emududu burnt sediment of food; burnt crust of food left in the cooking pan; burnt lumps of grain after making beer. ileleba akiria nu imudud: this flour is full of burnt crusts. emudukana blind; sightless; unsighted. emuduko (done) blindly; sightlessly; (to do) with eyes shut. ibu ijo kogwel egoe lo emuduko: you bought this dress without thinking (literally, with eyes closed). emuduku a hard wood tree (not easily eaten by ants), Bridelia sclero neuroides. emuduma (in Pallisa) maize or corn.emudumudu blindly; in the dark.emudunga a corruption of emuduma: cob maize or corn.emuebe an ordinary mango fruit or tree, Mangifera indica.
enimu emudang having small ears; having small cuts in ears

a man native to Buganda (central and southern Uganda districts such as Kampala, Mukono, Masaka, Entebbe, Mpigi, etc). Imugaana: the Baganda people of central Uganda.emugaati bread; a pancake; a doughnut; a bun.emuge2 (formerly) a strip of skin tied round the neck or arm of the widow/widower to distinguish the bereaved from other mourners; (nowadays) any attire that distinguishes the bereaved from other mourners (for instance, wearing of black clothing or a piece torn from the shroud). emugege a skin disease that removes hair, especially in goats; scabies in animals.emugeono brownish-purple or brownish-black. emugigi a catechism class. asiomi eong omugigi: I am learning the catechism.
a man native to former Bugisu (the present day Mbale and Sironko districts)
a Mugisu man. Imugis: the Bagisu or Bamasaba people.

an Indian from Goa in south-western India. emugogolit rough ground (like in a swamp) during dry season; little heaps of dry soil; a hunch, hump. emugolet an initiate into a religion; a bridegroom (a man going to wed). emugugut a bundle (of luggage); burdens; a shipment, consignment, or cargo; a load (of something heavy).emugur (one with) bent or stooping back or shoulders; (a) hunchback(ed).
a man native to Budaka and Kibuku counties of Pallisa district

a Mugwere tribesman. Imugwerio: the Bagwere people (in general). emuisa a tree, Protea. emujejel1 shortly; a little time; insufficiently; momentarily. aanyu eong nges emujejel: I saw her/him for only a (little) moment.emujejel2 a very little food; a very short time. emukaro a kiln; an oven; a furnace. emukeeka a raffia mat; matting.emukisa a good-luck charm; an amulet; a talisman. emukok a man who does things at dusk or evening. emukoki (of time of day) dusking or becoming evening; (of trees) leafy, overgrown. emukopit a peasant; a subordinate of a chief; a simple native or ordinary person; a commoner. emukule a hide; a skin (tanned or raw); a pelt; a dermis (skin of human body); a sleeping skin.emukuny a stinging black ant.

a man native to Ankole (the present day districts of Mbarara, Bushenyi, Ntungamo). Imulaalo: the Banyankole people of south-western Uganda. emulalu chilly sauce; chillies; pepper (red or green). emulang a hornless cow or animal. emuleera a red border round the neck and down the chest of a traditional gown. emulokolet a member of teetotalling Christian sects (especially sects having origins in the USA); a savedee or born-again.
a Nubian man native to Bombo, parts of West Nile, and Southern Sudan. Imulubin: the Nubian people (in general). emuluka a lay reader (an unordained person licensed to undertake some religious duties)

an Anglican Church pastor in charge of a sub-parish. emululut an unmarried man staying alone; a poor man living in solitude; a widower. amuulet: an unmarried woman; a widow.emumu itunga ngun: those people are rowdy or unruly. ekingok loemumu: a wild or rabid dog. emumwait (generic name) sorghum; guinea corn. ajon nuka imumwa: beer made from sorghum.imumwa k’ajele: a bush, Clerodendron myricoides. emun a snake (in general). aicak amun ekori: to get into trouble (literally, to tread on a snake’s tail). emuna1 a stew; a mixture of ghee or sheanut butter and roasted groundnuts paste. aigur emuna: to make emuna. emuna2 a very thick mist or fog, especially round hills or in swamps.emunaara spoiled; ruined. etogo loemunaara: a ruined house or a house in ruins. emunan (of beer) brewed; fermented. ajon nuemunan: brewed beer; beer ready to drink. emunet cheek; chutzpah; silliness; nuisance. emunokina hopeful; expectant; encouraged; positive; confident. emunoono fond of hoping; hopeful; reliable; trusting; trustworthy. emunot a trustworthy, dependable, reliable, or honest man.emunwoit2 an intestinal worm: askaris lumbricoides. emunyal a coloured clay used for dressing hair.
emuulut emumu violent, aggressive, brutal, fierce; unruly, vicious

a man native to Bunyoro (the present Uganda districts of Hoima, Masindi, and parts of Kibale and Mubende), speaking a Bantu language called Runyoro. Imunyooro: the Banyoro people native to Hoima, Masindi and parts of Kibale and Mubende districts of Uganda. emuogo a cassava tuber; the cassava plant; cassava flour; tapioca - Manihot utilisima emurana (of stomach) often astringent; constipated. emuret a basket used to ferment the beer-dough. emuria a creeping grass usually growing near or in kraals, Cynodon dactylon. emuria kolia. kolia!: (prayer at birth of a child in the clan) may the clan prosper. Let it flourish! (literally, may the creeper, emuria, flourish). emuriei a bush with edible fruit called amuriait; mulberry; a vine emuron a traditional priest or doctor knowledgeable in local herbs and cures and uses them for social good – such as foretelling the future, curing the sick, providing love potions, or bringing the rain; a doctor in general.emuron loka adekis: a western doctor (a clinical officer or any person who diagnoses and treats using modern methods). emurududu a crust of bread (at the bottom of a dry saucepan); a simmering.emurumuron a blind worm; a headless snake. emurusing a neck; the front of neck.emurwon a traditional doctor or priest; a health officer or doctor of western medicine. emurwon loka angaleu: a health officer.aitanyam emusaago: to decide in a law court that someone has done wrong. apetor emusaago: to defeat a case brought against one; to find innocent.emusaala salary; pay; reward; wage.emusaga a spitting cobra. emusalaba a cross; a crucifix. emuseit an old man.emusia a tree in the emelikin and ekum family whose root acted as a traditional lipstick and a ringworm remedy, and the leaf extract is used as a purgative, Mystroxylon aethiopium. emusibet a prisoner, convict, inmate, jailbird; a captive, detainee, hostage. emusika an heir, successor, legatee, beneficiary, inheritor. emusikiiti a mosque; a Mohammedan place of worship.
a man native to Busoga (present day districts of Jinja, Iganga, Kamuli, Mayuge and Bugiri)

a Musoga tribesman. Imusoga: the Basoga people (in general).emusogot a Mukindu or wild date palm tree, Phoenix reclinata. Its leaves are used as ornament and thatch, the fibre and leaves are used in basketry and mats, while the sticks are used in making traditional doors and roofing.
Emagarait: a Musoga or Mugwere tribesman
a European or a white man. emusumeeni a wood saw

a hacksaw.emusuuja (singular noun M) fever; malaria fever.emutojo a kind of grass; continuous headache, migraine. emutono (of time of day, manner, bush) dark; overgrown; gloomy; mysterious; sinister; shady; shadowy. emutono cucucuc: (of the night) extremely dark; very dark.

a man native to Tooro (the present day western Uganda district of Bundibugyo, Kabarole, Kyenjojo, Kamwenge and parts of Kibale and Kasese). Imutooro: the Batooro people in general. emutu a 12-centimetre needle for sewing cracks in a gourd; a punch.emutula a saltless sauce of groundnuts and sour milk eaten with pure millet bread by a breast-feeding woman; a traditional ceremony for initiating breast-feeding women into eating saltless food. emuturu a heartwood tree used for making pestles and threshing sticks, Ozoroa insignis subsp. reticulata. emutuugulu an onion.emuuja a jigger.emuulut a corruption of emululut: an unmarried man staying alone; a poor man living in solitude; a widower. amuulet: an unmarried woman; a widow. emuunu constipation; a poisoned stomach; a distended stomach.emuut a twin (person or animal).emwaanyi (singular noun M) a coffee tree or bush; coffee berry.emwalimu a school teacher; a tutor; a lecturer.emwana nges akuwan: she/he is quick, alert. emwana nges akuwan pe pe: she/he is ill; she/he has fever. emwana nges etau: emwana nges ekori: emwana nges aidoole: she/he is very greedy.akipi nuemwaka: hot water. akiro nuamwanak: akiro nuemwaka: a tight corner. agwaunit eong akiro nuemwaka: I am in a tight corner. emwane (singular noun M) gluttony; greediness. emweeso a razor for shaving; razorblade.omwika ngol: that is a brother of my husband. [note: a) brother-in-law is omuran by other in-laws, but is called ekamuran by the sister’s husband. b) the young brother of one’s husband is called okilenika locici by the wife. c) elder brother of the husband is called papa by the wife]. emyede a small brown hornbill nesting in tree-holes.emyelimyel only a little; a sip; only a moment; insufficiently. abu eong kaany nges imyelimyel: I saw her/him only a moment. anyam eong imyelimyel: I only ate a little, or I ate only a little. emyelot a hot-tempered person. emyetara (of body, buttocks) flat; plain; even (as of board). enaaba a number; a digit; a figure; numeral; integer; amount; quantity. enaabi a prophet; a foreseer; a diviner.enaabiya a love potion (believed to make the recipient fall in love with the giver); an aphrodisiac. enaanara commited, faithful, or devoted (to each other). enaanara kesi: eraas kesi luenaanara: they are devoted to each other. enaijeria a variety of cassava, origin Nigeria, whose tubers are not eaten raw because they are poisonous.enanaasi a pineapple fruit or plant. enange (singular noun M) abrogation; the end. enangiya cloth (general); apparel; attire.enasoro a common thing; a public property; a communal grain store. enebek (of cloth, skin) silky-smooth; glossy; soft and shiny. enebek egoe lo: this cloth is silky-smooth. enee compacted; squashed; crammed; condensed; compressed. eneko a corruption of enyeko: jealousy, envy, suspicion, resentment among co-wives. enema (in the Catholic church) sanctifying grace; poise; style; charm; elegance. enema loketwasaman: active grace. enema loketalaunan: sanctifying grace. -enen a verbal suffix denoting a repetitive or continued action either towards or away from the speaker. alosit: to go away (once only); alosenen: to keep going away (often). abunore: to come this way (once only); abunenen: to keep coming this way (often). akerit: to run off (once only); akerenen: to keep running away (often). enenwa a general name for a house or fruit bat, Tadarida limbada.enepes habit (in anything); peculiarity; idiosyncrasy. ejai nges enepes lokolo ka papake: she/he has the peculiarities of her/his father. ejai eipone lope ejaar: there is something queer or strange about him/her/it.eneran a talker; a speaker or an orator. enerat a talker; a chatterbox. aineraneratoi: always talking, babbling, chattering. engaano (singular noun M) wheat; wheat flour. engaara open; ajar; agape. engabwor an olive baboon (i.e. a kind of ape or monkey), Papio anubis.engadan a steward, treasurer or storekeeper.engaet a prop, support; a forked stick (to support the roof of a granary); door-handle or knob. engalan a liar; a deceiver, hypocrite.engalerut the pip of fruit; a wingless termite (after shedding wings). engalura a kidney. engalurat a kidney. engang (of a person, etc) very big; huge; giganticadum eong emun longang: I met a huge snake. akiro nungang: a big case; a tall story. engangatono bustling (with negative connotations); inclined to hurry about (but ending up delaying). engarana malignant; cruel; hateful; odious. engaranakinan a helper; an assistant; aide de camp. engarenikiton a leader; a guide; a director; a manager. engarenon a leader; a director; an organizer; a manager. engarot a pebble; gravel; grit; iron ore; murram. alosi eong aibe ingaroi: I am going to break up the ironstone. aitutu ingaroi orot: to stamp murram on the road. amatapaalin nuk’ingaroi: murram blocks. engas a prop or support; a forked stick to support the roof of a granary. engasingas a giant; a monster; a very big person, thing or animal. Maria angasingas ya eputos ka etop: Mary is very big; she is like the Morning Star. engasit plundering; robbery; raiding; rustling; pillaging, or looting. adau engasit ka Ikaramoja ko Teso ikar akais akany adepar: the Karimojong raiding in Teso has taken over fifty years. engatuny a lion, Panthera leo; a brave man; a male member of the Lions Club. engecer a person who is very thin (the thighs are far between) or walking naked.engeded (of rope or thread) broken, or torn. engedengeda iusio kosaatika: my shirt is torn. engedengeda (of cloth) torn in many places; (of rope) broken into many pieces. engejep one who stutters or stammers. engejepana stammering; stuttering; lisping. engelecomoit a contemptuous or despicable man; a coward; a traitor. engelerep a swift brownish venomous snake, Rhamphiophis. engeluna (of a piece of anything) broken off. engeluna atibok: a piece of pot has broken off. engenge rough; coarse (like sand); harsh; austere. engerebebe (singular noun M) a very severe kind of diarrhoea; dysentery; ulcer of the stomach. engerengerwai a bush whose roots are used as a liniment for wounds, Cassia singueana. engerepoit a white ant flying in the morning from an anthill called angerep. engeret a sickle.engerono obstinate; rebellious. engesana sudden; unforeseen. engeseb easily broken (of rope, cloth, pot etc); fragile; delicate; brittle; weak. engeseb etau: my heart is very tender; I am very susceptible to; easily affected by; (of rope) to be weak; (of cloth) easy to tear. engeseb erot: the road can easily be cut short.engeso a disaster; a sudden occurrence (such as premature birth, death, earthquake, etc). atiokisio nuka engeso: disasters. engesuna casual; unexpected; adventitious; unforeseen; unanticipated; unpredicted; surprising; startling; astonishing; sudden; out of the blue. engibirirana fast running; speedy; swift; rapid. ingibirirana ijo: you run fast. irai ijo ekangibiriran: you are a fast runner. engiet incisor tooth.enginam toothless; having no teeth. engingi blunt; not sharp. engingi ikilenga lu: these knives are blunt. enginyat a backbiter; a slanderer; a glutton. enginyot a small piece of cassava or potato (harvested prematurely); the two end parts of cassava or potatoes cut off first. engiol a man with protruding teeth; anything protruding. ikel lungiol: ikel luingiololas: protruding teeth. engirikino endured; sustained; borne bravely. ariebo nangirikino: pain borne bravely; endured pain. engiringirio a tree, Gymnosporia senegalensis.engiriony a man with a bruised face; a man with broken teeth. engiro the brown one; a mulatto or mongrel. engiroono brown; chocolate coloured; coffee coloured; tan; russet; brunette; auburn; tanned; sunburnt. engite a flowering shrub, Stereospermum kunthianum. Its sticks are used as toothbrushes and the root extract as a medicine for wounds, and the fruits chewed with salt is a remedy for cough. engiti a hand hoe with a heart-shaped blade.engole an animal with a scar or bare patch on the head; one with a white patch on the head. engoleit a large hornet with a white spot on the forehead. engoleono (of a person or an animal) having a bald patch or scar on the head (after an injury). engolet a man or animal with a scar on the head. engolopana (of a person) quarrelsome; contentious; cantankerous. engolor a man with a cataract in his eye. engomo a kind of plant with edible fruit. engoorit the lastborn boy child. kiwaliwal, eong engoorit: (an address to the cloudy or rainy weather by a boy) clear up, I am the last born.engorojojo half-cooked millet bread; half-ready millet bread or atap; badly cooked food; badly mingled and half-cooked atap. engorot1 old millet (not current year's harvest) or anything. engorot2 ancient; antique; prehistoric; primeval. engosob a man with protruding teeth. engosoorot a Ugandan coral, Red-hot-poker or lucky-bean tree bearing small black and red seeds, Erythrina abyssinica. Its crushed leaves treat skin diseases in livestock. The seeds can be used to make curios, the light wood is used as corks for fishnets and for carving beehives and utensils. engu a gravedigger; an undertaker.epol enguingui kane: there is a lot of grumbling here. enguleteny a stump (after cutting); a stub; a bump. engulot a male leper; a maimed man (with a limb or part of a limb cut off). engulul (of limbs or parts thereof) cut up into pieces, maimed. engulungul a part of the spine or backbone; a chop of meat from the animal’s neck or spine. engulungulut the nape; the back of neck at the junction with the spine; a chop of meat from the animal’s neck or spine. engunget controversy; discord; a disagreement; enmity; a quarrel; a squabble; grouse; friction. ejai iso engunget ka nges: we have a quarrel with her/him. engwalas a lame man; a cripple. engwaringwari of colour of fur) spotted; dappled; fluorescent. enibik (of cloth) nice and soft to feel. enibik egoe lo: this cloth is nice and soft to the fingers. enicik (of wet clay or fine strong cloth) thick; well kneaded. egoe loenicik: fine, strong and thick cloth. elupe loenicik: kneaded clay (for making pots or bricks). enikos (singular noun M) a chronic and incurable carbuncle or sore on a person’s foot (preventing the person from walking properly).(an insult)The fruit is used for lemonade drink and as a source of citric acid; lime oil, lemon oil, and cosmetics are extracted from peels. eninaet a thing to rub with, such as a towel, brush or India rubber. eninan oiled; (of medicine or oil onto the skin) rubbed in; (of fried groundnuts) unhusked. eninik (of meat) tough; (of wood) strong; elastic; (of person) resilient; (of character) inflexible; (of rubber) expandable; stretchy; (of millet or grain) moist. eninik akiring ngin: that meat is tough. akiring naeninik: tough meat. eninik etau: (of a person) brave, courageous, hearted. eninik akimai: the millet is moist, i.e. hard to grind because it is not well dried. to be hard-hearted;
