to be tight-fisted. eniniko a vegetable and weed - Justicia matanense. eniniku a kind of tree with an edible fruit. enino (singular noun M) simsim (and sometimes with groundnuts) seeds fried and ground into paste.enipono (of hunting dogs) good at sniffing and tracking game animals; (of person’s character) persistent, unrelenting. enirono (of food) satiating; nauseating; sickening. eniumoniya (singular noun M) pleuro-pneumonia in human beings.enokosa a swollen vesicle. enoman one who beats (another); a football kicker. enoman aputosia: a photographer; a picture drawer. enoman igoen: one who irons clothes as a trade. enoman epiki: a gambler. enomut a man from the Teso clan of bone-setters; a bone-setter; a physiotherapist. enon a caecum of a ruminant filled with select fatty meat, liver, small intestines, etc. spiced, sealed and cooked as a delicacy. enonok (of something) soft; (of character) weak; (of food, meat) tender; flimsy; flexible; languid. enoot a zero; nought; nil.enume the only child (born to a family).enusu a shilling; a currency unit. enyaanyaa a tomato plant or fruit.apaarasia nuka Kakungulu, adedeng inyaapalan aituduk itunga irotin: during the days of Kakungulu the roadworks overseers fiercely forced people to build roads. enyaapalane (singular noun M) overseeing; supervision; management; control. enyabwos a multi-mammate mouse, Mastomys couchae Ugandae. enyadak a man who is dirty. enyadak nges akuwan: (she/he is dirty) she/he has a dirty body. enyadu (singular noun M) blue swamp clay. (slang) money. enyagan a robber, raider, plunderer, a cheat. enyagirit a kind of bird. enyaiyon a man who is fastidious; a man who pretends aversion; a man who pretends to shirk food. enyaiyot a man given to extreme fastidiousness, meticulousness, precision or delicacy. enyakinyak a rag; a torn or worn out garment.enyakoit a man hailing from the north; a northerner; a Nordic. ebunit ngesi konyakoi: she/he comes from the north. enyakoka an edible plant, Hibiscus. enyakuka (formerly) a variety of sorghum. enyamana (of person, animal) gluttonous; guzzling; fond of eating; greedy; insatiable. enyamio (of food) edible; eatable; safe to be eaten; not poisonous. enyamio ityang lu ko Teso: eputir, amor, ekori, ekosobwan, etuko kede ice da: these animals are edible in Teso: a warthog, a duiker, a giraffe, a buffalo, a zebra among others. konye mam enyamio ebu, ekingok, edokolet, eris, eidodo, egereger, engatuny, kice da: but a hyena, a dog, a monkey, a leopard, a common lizard, a monitor lizard, a lion, etc are not eaten in Teso. enyamiton one who accompanies; an escort; aide de camp (ADC); a guide; a body guard.enyamukware a kind of plant. enyamun (of a thing) wearing off; (of food) consumable; (of an asset) depreciating. enyamuret a gatecrasher; a hanger on; a tramp; a destitute; one who eats at other people’s homes. enyang1 (of skin colour, fur) light brown; speckled; tan; yellowish-orange. akiteng anyang: a light brown cow. enyang2 (singular noun M) morning sun, i.e. sunshine between 7:00 am and 10:00 am. aipyer enyang: to warm oneself in the morning sun. alosi eong aipyer enyang: I am going to warm myself in the morning sun.enyang3 (singular noun M) a variety of sorghum grown during the dry season (requiring less rainfall).enyangaana (of colour or hue) light brown; yellowish-brown; tan; red-brown; auburn. edoso-nyang: canary colour. enyango (singular noun M) the morning sunshine (before 10:00 am, believed to be healthy).

a man native to Kisoro district at the extreme south-west of Uganda and the Republic of Rwanda. Inyarwaada: the Rwandese people in general. enyede (collective noun M) young locusts. enyege (singular noun M) bad luck (for being the last to come down a tree – causing a person to fall); misfortune; hard luck.enyeko envy, jealousy among co-wives. enyel rust; iron (ferrous) oxide. aikamun enyel: amasikin enyel: to be or become rusty. enyikibon (singular noun M) a weed, Bidens pilosa.enyilil (of something soft) torn; frayed; in shreds; ragged; tattered. enyimo a grass, Eragrostis tenuifolia. enyola a grass, Eragrostis aspera, enyolo rust; stain (on metal). enyongai1 a tree, Steganotaenia araliacea. Its roots have medicinal value. enyongai2 (singular noun M) a variety of sorghum plant whose stalk is eaten like sugarcane. enyoodo a hammer; a mallet; a tack hammer; a sledge hammer.enyoota a craving, lust, hankering; military insignia on the shoulder (in form of diamonds or stars). enyukunyuk a mole, Cryptomys leche. enyukuta a letter of the alphabet. enyukuta loapolon: a capital letter. inyukutan ludidik: small letters. enyuluk (of feathers) easy to pluck; (of rope) easily broken. enyunyinere a tree, Acasia senegal. enyunyurana inclined to anger; irritable; tetchy; short-tempered; hot-tempered; huffy. enyurinyur a short grass, Eragrostis ciliaris. enyuru an edible cane rat, Thrynomys harrisonia. enyutel insensate; numb; unfeeling; insensible; not sensitive. eodo (singular noun M) a green vegetable boiled without magadi salt. eodor a grass, Dioscorea bulbifera. eoj tall; high; long. ekitoi loeoj: a tall tree. eoj nges etau: she/he has a long breath (she/he can run or dive for a long time without breathing); she/he is greedy. eojakori a long-tailed bird, a Coly bird. eoke a kind of tree. eokito empty; dry; parched; dessicated; arid; waterless. eome a creeper with yellow flowers, Cucubitaceae. eomikina too big; very big; huge; arrogant. eomikina etelepat lo: this boy is too arrogant. eong (1st person singular pronoun) I; me. arai eong Apuda Egenatio: I am Apuda Ignatius. eong ma, onac: it is me, brother.iso: us, we. eongo (singular noun M) vainglory; self-seeking; self-complacency; self-conceit. eongor (of colour) dark-drown; purple-brown. eongoryana (of colour) blonde; flaxen; fair-haired; dark or purple brown. eonit dry; arid; poor; thin. eonokori a shrub, Sarcocephalus latifolius. Its root extracts are a good treatment for early leprosy. The fruit is eaten as food while the leaves and fruit are fodder for livestock. eorokonyit slime; goo; gloop; gunk.eosin the vagina (of women or animals); the birth canal.eosiyana (of a female animal or person) having long period between pregnancies.epaaba (singular noun M) the cotton plant; cotton yarn or fibre (fluffy down covering the cotton seed). epaabo a summons; a subpoena; court fees or legal charges. epaaran a fellow; a companion. opaaraka: my (male) friend (in a bad sense). apaaraka: (my) girlfriend; my lover (in bad sense). epaasi a flat-iron for smoothing creased clothes. epacol a man with a bald or scarred head. epadal flat; level or even; horizontal. epadic a male friend; a companion.epading an enemy; a foe. lokeding : an enemy.epaduk a neighbour. epadurat a bad male friend; a lover (an insult).epae a male lover; a male friend.epagal (of a situation) clumsy; inconvenient; awkward; difficult to handle. epaganga (singular noun M) a severe lung disease - phthisis; pulmonary tuberculosis; a whooping cough.etekeran edege nges epailot: one who flies an aircraft is a pilot. epajan a relative; a clansman; a kinsman. epajang (of a person) flat-headed. epaka a competition; a contest; rivalry. epakasit a male labourer; a porter; a man-servant.

fresh; damp; moist. epalal eong akan: I am rich; I am generous.epalana negligent; lax; ready to forego; ready to sacrifice; inclined to give in; inclined to be generous. epale a pair of trousers or shorts; pants; underwear.epalisi a big mattress; a wire mattress: epalisi lok’asinin. epalisyono lazy; negligent; idle; slovenly; lax; careless.epalo a pod of ekaikai tree, Prosopsis africana. epalunana level-headed; cool-headed; apathetic; not easily disturbed, cool, detached, calm, deliberate; dogged. ibusakinit engarenikiniton korai etunganan loepalunana: it is necessary that a leader be level-headed. epamor a man who shares in or who contributes to the same action; a member of a club; a shareholder of a company.epapaali a tree-like herb or papaya plant or a pawpaw fruit, Carica papaya. The ripe fruit is used as food, jam or drink, while the leaves are meat tenderisers when used as wrappers. epapai a decidious Camel's Foot leaf tree, Piliostigma thonningii. Its bark can be used as fibre or rope, and root extract is used as a remedy for scorpion and snake bites, rectal ulcers and genital syphilis. The pods are eaten as food, or roasted with seeds to make dye. The tree provides poles and firewood. epapait a grandchild; a great grandchild.ipapai k’ipapai: posterity; children of great grandchildren; descendants. epapang (of taste) astringent; sour. epapero a friend; a chum. epaperone (singular noun M) friendship; camaraderie; amity. epar a papyrus mat (for any purpose).eparian an equal (in age); a contemporary. kirai iso kere iparian: we are all age mates; we are all equal. eparis a small tree or shrub, Grewia mollis. Its strings of bark used for fibre, and smooth stick are used for spear hafts and walking sticks.
iinat eong akan: I am well to do

weary; fatigued; exhausted. epata a bald head; balding; hair loss.epataasi a chisel; a wood plane (carpenter’s tool). epatana easy; tame; cheap; gentle; self-evident; harmless; innocent. epate a political organisation or party. eridakit apugan naka e Movement ipatei; mam ecamakit kesi angaanar atenueik kokinga nako Kampala: the Movement government is oppressive to political parties; it has prevented them from opening branches outside Kampala. epateit the calf muscle (the muscle behind the lower leg). asukokin epateit: to have cramps in the leg. epaup a male chum; a male companion; a partner; a buddy; a male friend; one of a pair of male things; the other of two males. epaupaka: my friend. epaupane (singular noun M) friendship; partnership; association; camaraderie. epeded pierced; having a hole; perforated; punctured. epedel flat; shallow; thin (as of a flake of bar soap). abao napedel: flat board. epedel asabuunyu: there is little soap left; the soap is thin. asabuunyu napedel: a thin piece of soap. kotubokinai emugaati lopedel: cut me a thin slice of bread. epedele a tinker bird. epedet an instrument with which to make holes; a bore; a drill; a prick; a bradawl. epedokino pierced through; leaking. epedokino emopiira: the ball has a puncture. epedokino itiny: to have dimpled or hollow cheeks. epedor possible; able; competent; manageable; permissible; capacity. mam ngun epedoros: that is impossible. epedorio: she/he/it is possible. mam epedorio: it/she/he is impossible. epeduru the tamarind tree, Tamarindus indica, with the fruit (apedur) used to spice up atap, fruit pulp is eaten as food, the leaves are fodder as well as medicine. epeduru locici a cassia plant, Cassia negricans. Its cold leaf-infusion is used to expel intestinal worms in cattle and people. epeera a wage; a pay. epeero (singular noun M) a grass whose root is chewed to treat cough, Laudetia superba. epeet a hunting dog; a wild dog, Lycaon pictus. epeeti a woman’s silk underwear resembling a skirt, often with ornamentation at the fringes; a petticoat; a slip; underskirt. epegana fond of contradicting or answering back; obstinate; argumentative; belligerent. epege a male pig; a boar; a dirty man.epeget an argument; a controversy; a discussion; a debate; a dispute; a contest; a contention; a competition. epol epeget kangina: there is a great discussion going on over there. epeipeyana rare; sparse; (of plants) found scattered singly. epejal1 a platform outside the homestead for drying grain; a threshing floor.epejel a spear-like arrow for killing rats or birds. epejonon a male guest; a male visitor; a male caller; a male tourist. epejonon loapolon: a chief guest. epeket a falcon (small hawk with grey-spotted feathers).epeleboi a grass, Echinochloa pyramidalis. epelec a small silvery fish, Engraulicy pris argenteus.epeleikinitai intended; deliberate. epelekecoit a short stick (usually two) to beat a log of wood in order to attract white ants (emome – a dark variety of flying ants) to come outside (the sound of the log being beaten deceives the white ants as if raindrops). epelepelet a butterfly. epeleuna new; invented; improvised. epelu a task; a job; an assignment of work; a duty, office.iswamaete kesi epelu: ejaas kesi toma opelu: they are doing a task or a work. epem1 a platform or elevation of the floor used as sleeping place or bed; a dais; any little elevation or platform as in a law court (where judges sit).epem2 a rack made of twigs in the form of a huge wicker basket raised off the ground by four poles and used as a grain store. epene (in football) a spot kick or penalty. epeneesi a perennial evergreen shade tree producing jackfruit, Artocarpus heterophyllus. epenek a beard (on the lower jaw); the chin. epepe sensitive; guilt-conscious; susceptible epepe nges etau: she/he is very sensitive; she/he is very hot-tempered or very excitable; she/he is on edge. loepepe etau : a sensitive person. epepet a scapula; a shoulder blade.eperet (singular noun M) a parade; a march past; a procession; a display or pageant; a salute. ainom eperet: (of a soldier or policeman) to salute. alosit eperet: to walk in procession. aibwo eperet: to stand in a parade. eperit a pair; two together. eperit lok’amuk: a pair of shoes. eperot a sleeping place. etogo loperot: house for sleeping in; accommodation; a sleeping apartment. epesiara great; spread out; commodious. epesurone (singular noun M) girlhood; adolescence of girls. epeta a ring; a wedding; a washer (of a screw and bolt); a bolt and screw; a hinge (of a door). aiwen epeta: to marry in church; to wed. aberu naka epeta: a wedded wife, i.e. a woman married in church. epetet a tree, Ambatch. herminiera elaphroxylon. epetono fond of kicking; fond of playing football; good at playing football. epetuno convex; turned in; curved. epidaponi a tree, Hymenocardia acida. epiding gardens around the home; a back entrance to a traditional house; a small opening or gap in a fence (used as private entrance). epii a reed, Kecker opsis uniseta; a drinking tube for beer (made of epii reed).epii loka ekulam: the ureter or urethra (the urine tubes in general). epiibiro a kitchen; a cooking place.aitokony epiila: aitokony abalang: to let a woman taste salt for the first time after birth. epiirioit a clever person; an expert; an expatriate; one with insight or intelligence. epiiryana clever; sharp-witted; witty; cunning; wise. epiryana k’akanin: dexterous. epiiso a needle; an injection. adumun epiiso: aicum epiiso: to receive an injection. icumitai nges epiiso: she/he has received an injection. icumit ngesi epiiso: the needle has pricked her/him. epiit (singular noun M) a fig tree.epiki (singular noun M) speculation; betting; gaming; wager; gambling game. ainom epiki: to gamble, wager, or bet. enoman epiki: a gambler; a speculator. epikipik a motorcycle; a motorbike; a scrambler. epikisit the lower leg, i.e. the calf and the shin. epikoron a conqueror; a subjugator; a victor. epilias a snake, Chlorophis. epilili groundnut sauce; a relish. epilipili red pepper; chillies.epima a dagger; a sword; a rapier.epinipinit a small leakage; a puncture; the urethra; any duct in the body. epinot a cowbell.edongot: a big Ben or bell. epiokoit a self-seeded groundnuts.epiororo a flywheel of a cycle.
name of the first born boy twin (because it was the victor, i.e. aipior). (note: the second born boy twin is called Edongot or Odong because it remained behind, i.e. aidong). epipa a big barrel

a big metallic tank or drum for storing liquids. epipil painful; agonizing; excruciating; aching; hurting; sore. epipiot the ear-hole (auditory canal); ear-opening; a small hole (anywhere); a pore. kitoik epipiot: listen well (by approaching ear). epir a pole; a pillar; a post; a spoke of a wheel; a stay, buttress, or support; a leader; the big man. epir lok’aica: a ray of light. epir loegaali: a bicycle spoke. epir lok’akim: an electricity post or pole. epir lok’esimu: an telephone or telegraph post or pole.ingai ekusipir?: who is your leader or hero? epir lok’ere: the owner of a home; mainstay or support of a family. epiria (singular noun M) green moss (on top of the water or on rock or bark of trees); lichen; a shoal of fish. epirididi a severe diarrhoea onset.epirio1 (collective noun M) a flock of birds; a flight of birds; a bevy; a group (of anything raising dust); a caravan (of vehicles); a procession.epiro a grass, Loudetia superba. epirya (of colour) green; emerald; jade; lime colour.episikopi a Roman Catholic bishop.epit eong adeka, ti mam kidumak eong ore: if I had not been ill, you would not have found me at home.epit2 a habit; a custom. epiteni a habit; a custom; a kind; a sort. epitina (singular noun M) dislike; enmity; antipathy. kiinakit ijo eong epitina: kitokokolit ijo eong: you are my rival; you are against me; you have something against me. epitinan a misanthrope; an envious person. epiu1 a large crocodile; an alligator.epiu2 (singular noun M) bile; gall. ecoe loka epiu: gall-bladder. epinipinit loka epiu: bile duct. epiye a cedar tree, Terminalia brownii. Its leaves and bark are medicinal, the leaves are fodder and mulch, while wood can be used as firewood and charcoal. epodo East African yellow-wood tree, Podocarpus latifolius. It is used as a shade and an ornamental avenue tree, as well as providing timber and firewood. epodono fond of worrying, complaining, grousing, or grumbling. epogana (to be) inclined to swagger, brag, boast, etc epoget (singular noun M) pride; contumely; smugness; conceit; arrogance. epoison (singular noun M) poison. aingalakin epoison: to poison.epol big; ample; important; much; fundamental; burly. epol ecelet: there is much quarrelling or much noise. epol akoik: the stomach is big; she is pregnant. epola shame; disgrace; ignominy; embarrassment; indignity; dishonour. epoli a water-buck (a wild game). epolio (singular noun M) polio; poliomyelitis, i.e. a disease that causes crippling of limbs.epolokilokia a plant, Opilia celtidifolia. epolomuny (formerly) a variety of finger millet with a thick testa. epolon a man in the age range 42–66 years; an old man. epolopolot rather big, old, important, considerable. epolot a line of thatch in a traditional Usuk hut or granary. epone a kind; a habit; a manner; a method or methodology; a character; a sort; a behaviour; a custom; a bearing; a category; know-how. eroko iponesio kec: their manners are bad. ipoitoi inyamat luka iponesio kere: all kinds of food have been prepared. eponga a Barbary mouse, Arvicanthis abyssinicus. epongai a shrub whose root is an ingredient in a potion taken by women to accelerate the expulsion of the placenta (afterbirth) or a diarrhoeal remedy, Dombeya rotundifolia. eponoi a lip, i.e. the flesh forming the mouth or vaginal opening; the labium. epoode (of speech) flagrant; free; at liberty. inera ngol epoode: he is talking at liberty (without fearing any consequences). epopong euphorbia or cactus tree, Euphorbia candelabrum. Its copious milky sap is eye poison and also applied to swollen glands of cattle suffering from east-coast fever. The tree can be used as a live fence. The hollow wood is used for carving musical instruments like thumb pianos (akoogoi). epori (of bird, aeroplane, etc) flies; can be airborne. eporiporit a moth. eporiposi a plant, Asclepias semilunata, Clotalaria intermedia. eporitoi (of bird, aircraft, etc) in flight; in the skies; airborne. eporo elopement; flight of love-birds. eporokoca1 a swamp; blue clay from the swamp; a quagmire or bog. eporokoca2 a pickaxe.eporokot a swallow that carries mud in its mouth, Hironde semirufa gordoni. epororet an aeroplane; a thing to fly with. eporoto the throat; the voice (a say or influence); a melody or tune. adeka naka iporotoi throat infection; tonsilitis. eporoto loko kuju: high voice. eporoto loko kwap: low voice. eposita the post; the post office. eposok (of a part of a person, animal or plant) brittle; fragile; easily broken. epotoido a grass, Brachiaria. epotolo a military operation of cordon-and-search nature, involving the arrest of suspected wrongdoers such as tax defaulters, rebels, etc. epucit a feast; an initiation feast; a banquet.epucono inclined to be peaceful; peace-loving. epude1 a large cricket (insect).epuding pudding. epuesa (singular noun M) silver (a precious shiny grey metal widely used for making jewellery and coins).epujait a tree, Acacia seyal. epuko a sack; a bag; a gunny bag. epulaani a vest.epule1 (of quality of cooking) poor; bad. ingo ijo atap epule: you have served bread raw.epule2 half-cooked or poorly prepared millet bread (atap). ipoit ijo epule: you have cooked badly.epuleera (in the Catholic church) a brother; a vicar; a monk.epuluga a nicely prepared groundnut sauce.epungula a creeping plant tied on waists or head in a rain dance and from which salt is extracted, Coreopsis ugandiesis. epupono inclined to listen, to obey; obedient; docile; submissive. epura the back; the rear; the flipside; the reverse. epurakimat (formerly) a variety of sweet potatoes with rough tubers (literally, the old woman’s back). epureemu a frame or structure (of anything). epurie (of potatoes or cassava when well done) floury or dusty; (of the atmosphere) smoky, dusty, foggy, hazy, etc. epuripur a variety of high-yielding sorghum popular for making industrial beer. erai ‘Eagle Lager’ ajon nuka Epuripur: Eagle Lager is a beer made by Nile Breweries Ltd from Epuripur sorghum. epuroguram a programme; an agenda, plan or schedule; a series of planned projects to be undertaken.epus1 (of colour) purple grey. epus kakou: one with grey hair. epus2 (formerly) a variety of finger millet. epuserone (singular noun M) widowhood.epuserut a widower.epusupus (singular noun M) chickenpox. edekas idwe epusupus: the children have chickenpox. eputir a warthog, Phacochoerus aethiopicus.epuudit an artisan; a craftsman. epuudit loka amatapaalin: a bricklayer or mason. epuudit loka abaoi: a carpenter. epuuru measles. epuusa a jigger; chigoe; chigger.epuuti a pace; a stride; a foot measure. epuuton a tree, Pseudocedrela kotschyi. It grows on sandy plains and its wood is popular for making traditional stools, and the root extract is used to treat wounds caused by gonorrhoea, epuwai1 aside. kibwaik nges epuwai: put it aside.epuwai2 one side; the other side. epuwai ekwang, epuwai ereng: one side is white and (the other) one side is red. epuwal contents of stomach (of man or animals). epuyo1 (singular noun M) amniotic fluid in animals.epuyo2 (singular noun M) bluish swamp clay used for plastering houses, etc.Its branch is used as toothbrush, the fruit chewed with salt is medicine for cough; any toothbrush. epwatuna clean; polished; cleansed. epyana tasteless; bland; unsavoury; insipid; stale; unexciting. epyana nges akituk: she/he talks nonsense. epyaka akiro kon: there is nothing sensible in what you say. epyana akecebolia: their play is boring. eraada a hacksaw.eraagi a colour, dye, tint; a paint; a hue, tone, tinge, sort, type. eraakit a man from the Irarak clan; a cock or man with more than the normal number of fingers or toes. eraana fertile, productive, prolific, fruitful. eracakina splashed; fallen; spattered. aracakin akinyet kwap: the butter has spattered on the ground. eragwe a bush, Flueggea virosa. erai a grass, Hyperrhenia. eramatau a creeper used as a potion to stimulate love.erapakina covered; hidden; buried; veiled; concealed.erapara screened; covered.erapid (manner of shooting with a machine gun) rapid. ainom emuudu erapid: to shoot with bullets coming in quick succession. eratum a tree, acasia macrothyrsa. eraubei a plant, Indigo fera. ere a home; a village; a habitat; a homestead; an abode; a kraal; a residence; a palace. ore: at home; homewards. oreka: my home. kore: from home; at home. ejai nges ore: she/he is at home. iboie ngesi kore: she/he sits at home. ore: at home; in the home. ere lok’apugan: Government headquarters. -ere verb suffix forming passive infinitive of relative prepositional forms. esokoni ngesi aiboisit na earere ibaren: the butchery is the place where cattle are killed. erebeeni a spirit-level.erec a fiscal shrike. eredio a radio receiver; a wireless; a walkie-talkie. oredio: on the air; on radio. ereet a forehead; a front-face; a brow. lokoreet the one in front. oreet in front; in the face. oreeteka: in front of me; on my face. eregai a wait-a-bit shrub or thorn bush, Acacia mellifera. Its bark has medicinal properties. The plant is good for nitrogen fixation and soil conservation, and flowers are bee forage. erege a fishing net.ereit adverse; detesting; hating; unfriendly to. ereitos kesi idwekec: they are harsh on their children. erejesita a register; a list; a record. ereka a spy; a sleuth; a scout; a detective; one who reconnoitres.erelwe a railway; a railroad. eremokino pushed; pressed; hard-pressed. ereng (of colour) red; cherry; crimson. erengak ilugai lu America; konye luko India, enyangaaka: American Indians are red; but those of India are brown. ereng du very (red, crimson, or carmine). erengabor a Bateleur eagle. erengerenget (of colour) cherry; reddish; cerise. erepeny a dwarf; a midget; a pigmy. erere1 (of urine, anything) rancid; having the smell of urine. erere2 a grass, Hyparrhenia filipendula. ereret1 the big pelican; African saddle-billed stork, Balaeniceps rex. ereret2 a brim (of a vessel); an edge (of a container); a hem (of a cloth). ileleba eikopo aitodol oreret: the cup is full to the brim. ereret loka egoe: the hem of the cloth. eriago a bag; a pocket; a satchel. eriau (singular noun M) a grass that you cut today and the next day it has germinated, Digitaria volutina. eribik jet black; very black; pitch dark; shining black. eribit black cloth; alpaca; a rivet (a metal peg attaching or joining two metal parts together). eridakina (of clothes) tight; (of space) squeezed; stretched. erie awry; bent; curved. eriga a common game hunt; a hedge; a fence. koyangaasi akituk origa: take the cows into the fence. eriiga a sickle; a scythe.eriim kesi: they are thin. anyait naeriim: a thin blade of grass. eriketait a rope or chain or stick (to lead with). erikot a chain; a bond. ekosio erikot: dancing in circles; dancing hand-in-hand, with joined hands. erimaana docile; obedient; faithful; amenable; compliant; complaisant. eringa1 still; not yet. eringa iswamai: she/he is still working. not yet (used with relative prepositional forms). eringa kiswama: it has not yet been done. eringa ebuno: she/he has not yet come. eringa (by itself): not yet.eringa2 before. erinyin (of cloth, etc) hard (to the touch). erionget a group; a company; a flock; an army; a league; a crowd (not used for a football team). erionget lomam egongakina apugan: a non-governmental organisation. iriongeta luapolo: development agencies.erionoi a tree used for firewood, poles and charcoal, Margaritaria discoideus. erior ki-o to slander; to talk about somebody; to chat or to talk (in general).eripipi a wooden framework or structure for drying simsim stalks before extracting seeds; a statistical table. eripooti a report; information; details. eriribwas a sparrow-hawk. eririo a plant from which salt is extracted, Lippia adoensis. eris a leopard, Panthera pardus.eritanit a common earthworm. erite a winnowing tray made of woven withies (reeds) and smeared with cow-dung.erogec a kind of tree. erogoit (formerly) a variety of sweet potatoes. eroirwo (singular noun M) rust; mould; mildew. erojiroj elephantiasis of the legs or scrotum.akuwe: elephantiasis of the scrotum.erojo a moored trap made of netted strings with a noose that tightens behind the trapped animal as it enters deeper into the trap; a squirrel trap made from sisal or reeds. eroko1 still; meanwhile; not yet; ere, i.e. before (used with relative prepositional verbs to mean ‘not yet’). eroko ngesi iswamai: she/he is still working. eroko kiswama: mam iswamat: she/he has not yet done. eroko (by itself): not yet. abu ejakait? eroko: has the chief come? not yet. lueroko iitunitos: those who still remember. eroko2 bad; appalling; horrific; awful; terrible; dreadful. eroko kesi: they are bad. erokon a gouge or chisel; an adze; a small traditional hoe used for hollowing or smoothing out wood. erokono fond of adopting or copying vice or any habits. erokorokotoi a bush, Capparis tomentosa. Its root extract is very bitter and is used as a fever remedy. eromo a water-rat, Aethomya kaiseri. erongat a mountain range.erono bad; evil; offensive; odious; invalid; wicked; depraved; false; spoiled; dirty. erono noi: atrocious. erony (formerly) an administrative unit smaller than eitela (parish); a piece of land occupied by families of common lineage; a sub-parish; a communal grazing land; a sub-parish chief. eroodi a pair of trousers or slacks.eropit a salary; a pay; a reward; an emolument, etcerorokana avaricious; greedy; grasping. erot an avenue; a lane; a street; a path; a road; a way; a direction; a means, course. kaolikit eong erot lodumunet ibaren: I do not know how to get, or I have no means of getting, cattle or dowry. irotin luilogas: labyrinth; a maze. eroyet death; demise. aikony eroyet: to die. anyam nges eroyet: she/he died.erubit intact; whole; complete; full; untouched; unscathed. erujana (of an embrocation) binding; astringent. erukudo a murram or tarmac road; a highway.erumunan an heir; a successor. adeka naerumunan: an infectious or contagious disease.eruono noisy; sounding; sonorous; inclined to be noisy. erupe a malicious report. akiru naka erupe short-rains preceding the return of the wet season. erurwo (singular noun M) a plunder; a raid; a foray. erusurus (singular noun M) a soft and edible variety of mushroom.erwaara a corruption of erioro: tall; straight up. erwaitoi (of a person) excitable; neurotic. erwanit the multiplication sign X; multiplication. airwana: to multiply. airwanaar: to multiply; to forecast; to extrapolate. erwerweet a big black tit (bird). erwom (singular noun M) rumours; unverified news. Erwom ka Iteso: a defunct Ateso language newspaper during colonial times, i.e. the 1950s.erwopookot an edible plant whose pounded roots are used as a liniment. eryeco a tree, Bridelia sceleroneulioides. eryor ki-o to talk; to speak; to converse or discuss. eryor loka adotea erai loesil noi: the language of prostitutes is very obscene. esaabu gold (a soft yellow precious metal used for making jewellery, coins, etc).esaapa a papyrus mat (for any purpose).esaasaa a wild oil palm-tree, Elaeis guineensis. Its seeds are used in making palm oil, the oil is medicinal properties and also used in soap-making, while sap is for making palm wine. esaati a shirt (for men).esaawa a clock; an hour; a watch, chronometer; time. adolo isaawan idi?: what time is it? mam eong ajeni esaawa: I don't know the time. isaawan ikany luka tupuruc: eleven o’clock in the morning. esaawa ediope loka abong: seven o’clock in the evening. esaawa kere: all the time; always.esabana fond of telling lies; deceitful. esabet a lie; falsehood; lying; fibbing. esabibu (Biblical) a fig tree; vine. araito nuka esabibu: grapes. esabiiti a week. osabiiti ejaas apaarasia akany kaare: a week has seven days. apaarasia nuesabiiti: days of the week. Naesabiiti: Sunday. Naebalaasa: Monday. Naiyareit: Tuesday; the second. Nakiuniet: Wednesday; the third. Nakiongonet: Thursday; the fourth. Naikanyet: Friday; the fifth. Naemukaaga: Saturday. esabuli a psalm. Isabulin: the Book of Psalms (in the Old Testament of the Bible). esacana fond of forsaking; refraining from; abandoning; renouncing; rejecting, or avoiding.
(noun suffix): naesacit a woman who refuses a man. esacit ngesi ikiliok: she refrains from sexual intercourse with men. esae (singular noun M) (any kind of) perfume

fragrance; cologne; aroma; scent. esagaite an enclosure (made of reeds, sedge, etc) for bathing in; a (urinal) shelter. esagari (formerly) a variety of sweet potatoes. esairi barley cereal. esakale a grass, Sorghum arundinacea. esakarameetu a sacrament. esakarameetu loka oridini: the sacrament of priesthood. esalana inclined to be absent. esalir a bird’s crest; tuft of hair; a lion’s mane; forelock. esamai a swamp; a river; a marshland.
a Samaritan, one from (biblical) Samaria. esanga ivory

an elephant tusk.esange (singular noun M) the end; the limit; termination; boundary; bounds; abrogation. esange ngol: that is the end. esangisang a kind of climbing plant. esanyir bristling (of dog or cat when afraid).esao a handbag; bag; satchel; pocket; pouch. esapaali a journey; a safari; a travelling; a trip. (slang) a sexual round (one trip being equivalent to an orgasm). esapat a young man of 18–26 years of age; (formerly) an apprentice doing menial tasks for his sponsor befor initiation to a senior age group.esapanete isapa: the boys are getting initiated to full-grown men. esapir a man or boy with ruffled or unkempt hair; one who is unkempt. esapuli a rosary. esas (formerly) a stick carried by pregnant women (the number of those sticks representing the total pregnancies she has had to date). esasam (of fermented milk, beer, etc) sour. esasame a kind of tree with sweet fruit. esasedoti a corruption of esaseredooti: a priest. esaseredooti a Roman Catholic priest. esaseredootone (singular noun M) priesthood. esawe a goat paid by the brother of the bride to those who bring the dowry from the in-laws.
a man native to former Sebei (the present day Kapchorwa district)

a Sabiny man. Isebei: the Sabiny people (in general).esedeny (of a well, hole, pit) shallow, not deep; (of ideas) trite, frivolous, silly, trifling; (of actions) inconsequential, insignificant, superficial.
a man from Serere county in Soroti district. eseere a grass used as a charm, Sorghum rigidifolium. esega pure

clean; neat; dainty. esegana fond of cleanliness, neatness; fond of being dainty. esegaru (singular noun M) a plant, Polygonum. esege a water grass, Pennicetum; a plant, Sesbania. esegis a thing which is for personal care or hygiene; personal thing. iboro lusegis: personal effects. esegwa a pole for pushing or propelling a canoe into deep waters (so that the boat engine can be switched on, or for rowing to start). esekeloi (singular noun M) mockery; ridicule; sarcasm. esekeretariat a secretariat; the administrative department of any large organisation, its staff or premises. esel a big dress that sways about as the wearer walks. ailoli iselyo: to be uneasy.esele1 a large venomous arboreal snake. esele2 a secretary bird, Saggitarius serpentarius. eselel (of skin or surface) smooth; shined; glistened; glossed. eselotep (singular noun M) cellotape or adhesive sticker. eselotep erai amilimilit naiminai epuwai: cellotape is a synthetic tape that is sticky on one side. esemutuudu a Bagruss fish.esenot one to be beaten. eseny (singular noun M) AIDS (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome); a health condition transmitted by a virus which attacks a person’s immune system and leaving the person vulnerable, often emaciated and sickly.esenyit (of a person or animal) thin; lean; emaciated; withered. esepuria a saucepan; a metallic cooking pot. eseuna elected; sorted; chosen; picked; reserved. esiaale (formerly) a woman's pudendal fringe of beads.esiaduk (in children) cranial fissure (fontanelle); the top of the head. esial an end; the aim. esibilian a civilian; a man who is not a member of the armed forces or the police force. esicatan a support; a prop. erai ngesi esicatan loka totoke: he is the support of his mother. esidaani an injection; a needle for administering drugs.esidengideng the worm that cuts trees round the trunk till they fall; a fissure in palms of hand or foot. esidengideng lok’akit: sore on ear. esidepidep epiglottis; tonsil; uvula. esidokokot the protruding back of the head. esidongororot elbow joint.esiedan a Thomson’s gazelle, Gazella thomsoni. esiegot a reddish-brown roan antelope, Hippotragus equinus.

a Masai tribesman from Kenya or Tanzania (formerly a nomadic tribe, of Nilo-Hamitic origin).esiepit a tree from which they cut sticks used at ajosi dances, Grewia nyanze.esigala a cigarette. esigalikinan assistant

a helper.esigigir the spine or fins of fish. aisigigirit ajul: to make the hair stand on end (as of dog, a zebra, a donkey, cat or he-goat fighting). esigirait a cowrie shell. esigiria a male donkey; a jackass.esigirio a plant, Amaranthus spinosus. esigitan a nail splinter; a nail-fold. esiilyana filthy; lewd; very dirty; repulsive in appearance; unclean; loathsome; shocking. esiisa the brakes (of a bicycle or a motorcar).esik (singular noun M) honey. esik loka ao: bees honey. esik loka aamimit: small bees honey. akapet naka ao: honeycomb. esikarukaru a plant whose root extract is drank as a cure for a hydrocele (elephantiasis of the scrotum), Vitex doniana. esikitoit a grass, Eragrostis turgida. esil1 unbecoming; unseemly; illicit; displeasing; evil; bad; ugly; unlawful. esil ekonigoe: your dress in unbecoming (dirty or ill-fitting). akiro nuesiliok: bad, dirty, idle talk; nonsense. esil2 empty; uninhabited; solitary; lonely; desolate; deserted; dreary. esilang a bush or tree, Ziziphus abyssinica. Uses: the bushes can be used as live fence; its sticks provide fuel as firewood and charcoal; cinnamon-coloured dye is got from its bark. esilim (singular noun M) acquired immuno-deficiency syndrome (AIDS) or human immuno-deficiency virus (HIV) - a sexually transmitted disease, that is incurable at the moment, that is decimating the human population seriously.esiliot a dirty person (figurative) a hog. esilito a grass, Eragrostis superba. esiloewa a grass, Bothriochloa blabra.esilot1 a hair of cow’s tail; a hair of giraffe’s tail; a trap (made of string with a noose set from sticks put in the tracks of animals or birds) to catch small animals and birds; the stamen of flowers; a fibre (as in some fruits or root tubers). esilot loka acokit: shoot of potato (beginning of potato). esilot2 placenta; placental membrane (of human beings). esimamor a dwarf mouse, Leggada bella. esimat a bell worn by toddlers or by dancers on the ankles.esimato a certain bush plant. esimit (uncountable noun M) cement; concrete; mortar; plaster of Paris; epoxy. esimooni (formerly) a fifty cents piece. esimu (formerly) a telegraph; a telephone; telegram; cable. ainom esimu: to make a telephone call. abongokin esimu; alemun esimu: to answer the telephone; to pick up the telephone when it rings and speak to the person who is calling. esimu lok’akan: a handset; a mobile phone. esimu lok’arwatat: wall-mounted phone; a phone booth. esineema a cinema; a video film; a movie; a dramatisation. esingelelet a small black or brown sugar ant. esingingir a line on forehead. esingorot an elbow.esinyokit a white particle in beer i.e. poorly ground yeast. aituk isinyok: to drink millet or sorghum beer in a calabash. alosit aituk isinyok: to go to drink beer (ajon). esiomit gossip; backbiting; a little hollow near a well where women place their water pots whilst they gossip about their husbands). ‘koom esiomit’: said by emuron to the person consulting him about some misfortune, meaning that he wants the earth from the above pothole, with which he mixes his medicine. esiorot dead-straight; straight without a bend; straight as a die. esipaana a spanner or wrench (of a car, plough, etc).esipani a flock; a herd; a team; a crowd, or a host (of men or animals).esipiidi a speed; haste; a hurry. aibunyit amotoka esipiidi loetyono noi: to move a motorcar at high speed. esipiran (singular noun M) a wood weevil. epol esipiran kodula: there are a lot of weevils in the food store. esipo firm; rooted; established; steadfast; loyal. esipokina upright; straight; erect; standing. enyek eong ere esipokina: I left when the home was already established. esirapurap a skin on boiled milk; a membrane (as around bowels or in plants); a membrane in general. esire a wild cat. esirikaalet a soldier; a security guard; a sentry.esirut a mosquito. esisi1 stinking; smelling like a billy goat (he-goat) or a crushed bedbug. esisi2 a bedbug.ecwarenit. esisian a learner; a pupil; a disciple; an apprentice; a student.esisiarit crossroads; bifurcation; junction. esisiit (singular noun M) a weed, Bidens pilosa.esisio a grasshopper, Phimateus. esitaali a margin in a writing book; a line on an ironed cloth; a crease; a pleat; a fold.esiteseni a railway, radio or police station. esiyana (of a person or an animal) fond of escaping or deserting a place or a cause.esoda (singular noun M) soda – carbonated soft drink like Coke or Pepsi. esode commercial millet or sorghum brew.esogana vain; vainglorious; proud; swaggering, blustering; swanking. esogim awe-inspiring; dire; eerie; repulsive; dreadful; horrifying; fearsome; terrifying; ferocious. esogo a weaverbird, Reichenow’s weaver. esogol inconvenient; awkward; difficult. esogom a tall and thin man. esogomit intestinal roundworm; a kind of water beetle. esokoko a tree, Acasia senegalens. esokolet a worn out cloth (formerly used as underwear by women); a menstrual pad.esokooni a marketplace; a market (demand for a commodity or service). esokot a narrow path for walking people; a foot-path; a spoor; a lone game path. esokotan one who rolls tobacco. esokotan etaba: a tobacco roller. esolima a house rat (that often eats people’s feet), Rattus rattus.alemun esolo: to pay tax. aitelem esolo: to tax, i.e. to levy taxes (of any kind). esoman an employee; a worker.esomero a school (primary school, secondary school, or college). esomeroit a school boy; a student; a school-goer. esomesan (archaic) a literacy teacher.esooda a corner or angle of a house or an object. esorokan a young bull.esorom nasal discharge; mucus. esos a cone-flute or whistle made of goat horn and blown across the wider end of the cone. esosol (of badly brewed beer) stale; sour; (of fermented milk, etc) pungent. esosoloi self-conceit; hypocrisy; insincerity. esosot a tiny sieve or filter attached to the bottom of a beer drinking tube called epii.esot a word of admiration or praise, ‘nice big fellow’, ‘good fellow’. ee abu esot ngol: there he comes, the nice big fellow. esotoka rinderpest (a disease of cattle); meat of a cow that died of disease.esudeny1 (of hole, mind, etc) shallow; having little depth.esukaali sugar in general - cane sugar; blood sugar; beet sugar. adeka naka esukaali: diabetes. ecuuma loka esukaali: a sugar mill. ejai esukaali ocaai: there is sugar in the tea. esukaligulu (singular noun M) molasses; jaggery. emunaere esukaligulu ajon nuipois ewaragi: molasses are used for brewing crude dry gin. esukukurut a black biting ant; a thorny creeping plant. esukumawiki (singular noun M) a variety of kale closely resembling ekabit, but most popular in Kenya as a vegetable.esukusuk a big black African hornbill, believed to herald either rain season or dry season by its hoots (and a long spell of drought is believed to result if this bird is killed). esukut1 a species of grass, Eragrostis turgida. esukut2 a Bambara nut. esukuulu a school.esulianyana blessed; lucky; prosperous; fortunate.esululu a crowbar; a mattock or pickaxe. esulut a salute (by raising the hand to the side of the head, palm open, and then lowering it again – like soldiers greeting their superiors). esumaalit an iron nail; a srew; a door bolt; a man from Somalia. esumeredede (singular noun M) myalgia; numbness of the limbs; paralysis. esumuluso a key (a lock opener).esupaana medium-sized (usually of humans); (of length of anything) brief, curt, or laconic. esupono (of a dog) good at tracking by smell. esupuri zero; nought (from Kiswahili: sifuri: zero) esuretait a bamboo plant. It is believed in Teso that beating someone with a bamboo stick makes him/her thin, hence it is forbidden to cane children with bamboo. esurugia (singular noun M) hillocks in a swamp, home to eitiyo ants. esurukamu a grass, Hyperrhenia rufa; wild sorghum. esurulac (literally, the one that scatters lice) a plant whose root is used to make a potion for indigestion, Echinopsis amplexicaulis. esurup (singular noun M) milk left in the cow's udder by the milker for the calf to suckle. esusut a sod of grass; a turf; a sward; the root (of anything); a cassava or groundnut plant. akoto ajenun esusut loka akiro kangun: I want to know the origin of that matter.esutuwa a store; a storeroom; a warehouse (storehouse, depot, arsenal, repository). esuubusa a triangle-shaped pastry often filled with mincemeat, peas, beans or vegetables. esuubusit a trader; a merchant. esuujo a vegetable marrow; pumpkin.esuuku Gonorrhoea condylomata. esuula a chapter (in a book); a lesson.esuunyoit a large stinking biting black ant, Ponera.eswaagi a toothbrush.eswaat a tree, Cassia spp.

a Kiswahili speaker; a Swahili thing. eswam a poor person’s dwelling; a simple house or hut; a rat’s nest. esweeta a sweater; a jumper; a pullover.eswei (singular noun M) a variety of small mushroom growing on an aswei anthill; the mushroom sauce from eswei. eswi a little thatched house or hut. eswika: my little hut. eswii a point of roof; a pinnacle; a garret; a loft. eswiit a sweet; a bonbon; a candy. esworom mucus; nasal discharge.esyana liberal; generous; beneficent; kind; hospitable; accommodating; merciful; humane; affable; benign; charming. esyanana (always) kind, generous, etc.esyep a side; a flank; the coast; the edge. esyep lokecor: coast; beach; seaside; coastline. -et or –es suffix denoting instrument, or use made of the object or days of resting. adaket: a thing for carrying; a carrier; a bier. akoto aijiiko nanyamet: I want a spoon for eating. edoket: a landing site. etaala1 a hurricane lamp; a lighting device. etaala2 a sexually transmitted infection causing severe bleeding; genital syphilis; rectal ulcers or swellings (treated traditionally with herbal extracts from epapai, ekwooro and ekisim plants).etaba (singular noun M) tobacco plant, or its cured leaves; snuff tobacco. aimat etaba: to smoke traditionally rolled tobacco; to snuff tobacco powder (through the nose). etabaasa a hurricane lamp; a lighting device. etabaco a grass, Sida schimperiana. etabiranakulo a tabernacle; a platform for sacrifice; an altar. etabitaban a little child; a toddler. etacit payment; refund; reward; expiation; remuneration.etaget a banana fruit (cooked or uncooked). etajaran a saviour; a rescuer; a reviver.etajik tepid; lukewarm.etakalari an edible plant whose leaf is used as an embrocation to stimulate hair growth, Commicarpus plumbagineus. etakara blistered; copied; peeled. etakuna unpasted; unglued; clean.etal a clan ritual; a clan taboo; a clan custom; abstinence; a caste. etalakaaran a comforter; an entertainer; a comic. etalisit a courier; a postman; a mail-runner; a messenger. etaloka a rainbow; the iris (of the eye). etaluka a corruption of etaloka: a rainbow; the iris (of the eye). etamarukwa a greater bustard (bird). etamit (it/she/he is/I am) fine; okay; in good health; so-so (in reply to the greeting ‘Biai bo akuwan – how are you?’ or ‘Biai bo ngina – how is there?’). etamuro a second; a sixtieth of a minute.etangorobobo a cartilage.etaniboi a tonne boy; one who carries heavy luggage in a bus or truck.etanoka a grass, Setaria verticillata. etanunan a foster-father; step-father etany a large earthen bowl for serving food; a wooden three-legged stool with a round top for sitting on or used as a leg rest.etapa a hair-removing disease (hair falling out); a ringworm on the scalp.etapakon a kind of herb whose root was used for making cricket balls in Teso in the game of einyure.etapan (singular noun M) small ants (eating wood of a house).etapana inclined to become common, usual, or ordinary.etapipirio a whirlwind; a tornado; a cyclone; an eddy; a hurricane; a typhoon. etapo a minute; a sixtieth of an hour.etaroboboi gristle (cartilage, especially in meat); cartilage.etaryono akiring na: this meat is fatty and juicy. etaryono ekileng lo: this knife is greasy or oily (having been used for cutting fatty meat). etasuro a bad omen (especially feeling feverish before receiving bad news); a foreboding; a portend; a fright; an apprehension. etatai (singular noun M) a forge; a smithy. etatait a male grandchild; a descendant; a grandson. etatas the metal workshop; tool factory.etate a tree, Gymnosporia senegalensis. etau a heart; the mood; the centre or core (of anything); the bosom; greed. aibwaikin etau: to heed; to pay attention; to put the mind to; to be on guard; to take to heart. aomoom k’otau: to consider in one’s heart; to ponder or meditate. kariebi etau: my heart aches. erieba eong etau: I am anxious. etau k’akan: the palm of the hand. etau loka akeju: the sole or the instep of the foot. agir ekatau: I don’t want it. emwana nges etau: she/he is greedy. atikun etau: to search one’s heart. epapero lok’otau: a bossom friend. adeka naka etau: heart disease. ejaas ngesi k’etau: she/he is greedy.etaun a town; a municipality; a small city.etebakori a plant, Sida schimperiana. eteebe a plant, Emilia sagitta canna. eteede a female external genitalia - a clitoris.eteepelo a temple (house of worship). etegearan the author; the initiator; the starter. etekat a very large granary made of intertwined twigs or reeds.eteke (formerly) a variety of finger millet. etekit a spout of a wide-mouthed vessel. etekit loka aokit: the spout of a small calabash or any scooping vessel. etekwa a tree in the ebata family whose wood is used for carving big drums, the roots and bark are medicinal, while the leaves are used for ripening bananas; the incense tree and whose flowering is an indicator for the beginning of the planting period for finger millet, Albizia coriaria. etela the only child (produced by a particular woman).arai Yesu Kristo ikoku itela ka Edeke: Jesus Christ was God’s only child. etelebision a television (TV); a telly.etelepana young; youthful; adolescent; pubescent. etelepat a boy between the age of six and fourteen years; a young man who has not reached puberty; an adolescent; a male youth.eteluna the only child.etem an administrative unit equivalent to a sub-county; an age-group; the hearth or shrine (around which discussions were held in the past). ejakait Morunyang arai kolo loketem Katakwi: Mr. Morunyang was the sub-county chief of Katakwi.
(noun suffix) that which stiffens. adeka nak’etenaran meningitis

tetanus; any disease causing a stiff back or lockjaw. etengei (singular noun M) hunger; famine; appetite. mam etengei kariebi eong: I have no appetite; I am not hungry. aikany etengei: to fast; to suffer hunger. inyo ibore kidedengikini ijo noi ido komam ijo ipedori aanyun nges? etengei: (a riddle) what is it that harasses you very much yet you cannot see it? hunger. etenit straight; direct; peaceful; stable. eteran a bridegroom; an initiate or undergraduate in training (perhaps to become a university graduate, a bride, a confirmed Christian, etc). etereema (singular noun M) (formerly) a variety of red-seeded sorghum (not eaten by birds). eteregege (singular noun M) paralysis; meningitis. eteregu a tree, Hymenocardia acida. etereikina face-to-face; challenging (testing). Etesot1 a man or a native Katakwi, Soroti, Kumi, parts of Kaberamaido, Pallisa and Tororo districts of Uganda and Teso district in Western Kenya; a Teso tribesman. Iteso: the Teso people in general. Etesot obe: a true Etesot (by birth and character). etesot2 (singular noun M) a variety of groundnuts (with reddish seeds and a creeping plant) native to Teso. etesurut a grass, Panicum atrosanguineum.etetei a misnomer for ekerei (a reed granary for storing grain).etetiot a nose ornament; ring for ear, lip, or tongue. eti big; important; whole; complete; large; huge; enormous. ebeli eti: a severe famine. emoni eti: what a big bush.etia ai? (interrrogative pronoun) how big? how much?etiai ke : his/her/its (their) size; its price. etiai kosi: our number, as we are. etiang a corruption of etyang: an animal; a beast. etibang a big fool. etibar a fat big man (literally, a big shit). etibinet1 a plant, Veronia perottelli. etibinet2 a precious stone; a girdle of metal rolls (like beads) formerly worn by women round the waist; a jewel or ornament; tinsel. aiyup itibin: to string metal rolls. etica a school teacher; a tutor; a lecturer.etida1 a big healing drum; a dance for healing possessed people, consisting of a big drum (called etida) and a small high-pitched drum (itelele) played by the same person. airam etida: to beat the big drum to heal a person possessed by evil spirits. alosi eong otida: I am going to the etida dance (which heals hysterics). (the British colonial government used to forbid etida dance). erum nges etida: she/he has hysterics (on account of etida dance).aikerepikin, aibilerikin: to become mad; to become delirious. etida2 a spleen (a small organ lying near the stomach that purifies blood). etidot a sting (of bee, wasp, etc); a stinging hair of plants. etigo a variety of wild simsim. etiibi (singular noun M) pulmonary tuberculosis; a whooping cough; bronchitis.etiimu a team; a line-up; a squad of players. etikesa je that big fellow.: those big fellows. etil a Uganda kob (an animal whose picture is found on the Uganda Court-of-Arms, etc), Adenota kob thomasi. etilono (of anything) deep; abysmal. apak namam etilono: a shallow place (literally, not a deep place). etimat hair of the head; a hairdress (costume); a blood capillary. etimijako a very delicious (but black and ugly-looking) mushroom. etimon a merciful or forgiving person. etingunana having a retentive memory; powerful in recalling; mentally persistent. etipet a tree, Gymnosporia senegalensis. etirai1 a sickle bush whose presence is an indicator of overgrazing, Dichrostachys cinerea. Used as live fence, pounded leaves and roots are used to treat epilepsy. etirai2 a thorny shrub, Acacia glomerulata. etiri a tree, Acacia tortilis. etirikidait a molar tooth; a grinding tooth.etirir a long white-thorn tree, Acacia sieberiana. Its leaves are used as fodder, and the wood is firewood. etirono running fast; fast; speedy; quick. etit a tree in the palm family, Phoenix reclinata etiti a tree with a thick bark, Lannea barteri. Its fire-resistant wood is good for carving mortars, pestles and traditional stools. etiting courageous; enduring; manful; long suffering (pain); manly; intrepid; brave; daring; defying. etitiny a corruption of etiting courageous; enduring; manful; long suffering (pain); manly; intrepid; brave; daring; defying. etitir insipid; bland; satiating; not tasty; not nice.etitiyo silently; noiselessly; quietly; secretly. kolototo emanyit etitiyo: go for the marriage ceremony secretly. eto (formerly) the back of a house where goats sleep. etoba a young bull (not yet castrated); a cockerel.etoc a kind of bird. etodooma a candle lamp; a little kerosene lighting device made of an enclosed tin or bottle receptacle with a wick. etogo a house; a dwelling; a building; an abode. papa k’etogo: owner or proprietor of a house (the landlord). etogo loeperio: a house for sleeping. etogo loejengere itunga: (in a hospital) an operating theatre. etoil an image; a spirit of a dead person; a wraith; a ghost; a phantasm. etok a lesser bustard bird.etoke the seeds of emalakany or egwangira plants. etolim a shade (of tree, etc). ejaatar ekitoi etolim, konye itunganan ejaatar etoribe: a tree has a shade, but a person has a shadow.etolo bile-stained vomit. eleki ngesi etolo, etakani edeka eimidi: his/her vomit is bile-stained, it seems he/she has malaria fever. etolomunan the editor (of a newspaper or a book); producer or printer; the source (of data). etolut a Marabou stork (bird). etom an elephant (a huge animal that bears ivory or tusks), Loxodonta africana. angoti n’atom: nodular leprosy. etometomet a wart; a mole (on the skin). eton feeling cold; fearful; unctuous; cringing; deferential. etooci an electric torch; a flashlight. etoori an black eagle; an African kite. etop Venus; the morning star (a bright star that appears in the east at dawn) or evening star (a bright star that appears in the west just after sunset). Etop: a state-owned Ateso language newspaper founded in the early 1990s. itopion kwi kere mam eputosi kalo: the Venus of the yesteryears was not like this one. etopocon a cassava tuber; the cassava plant; cassava flour, Manihot utilisima
the Etesot from Tororo or Teso district of Kenya. etorube a corruption of etoribe: a shadow of anything

a shade of anything; a spirit of the dead.etotile an eye cataract; a stye in the eye. etotoyo a short beer-guzzling tube. etotule a corruption of etotile: eye cataract; nebula. etout a testicle; testis; the ‘balls’. etuan (colloquial of etunganan) a man; a human being; a bloke.etube (singular noun M) a method of cutting; a way of cutting; a way of judging; a judgement; a way of deciding. etube loka emusaago: the judgement of a court case. etube akiro: a decision; a judgement. mam ngesi iyuunit etubekon: she/he does not agree with your decision or judgement. etuboro past; bygone; archaic; prehistoric; history. etuborutu a plant in the etulelut family, Solanum torvum. etubuno unexpected; sudden; abrupt. etubusumeesa (formerly) a variety of sweet potatoes (with purple and white coloured tubers – hence the name etubusumeesa, ‘the beautifier of the table’).etuen (Serere - colloquial of etunganan) a man; a guy; a bloke.etuja a small simsim granary made of clay (elupe) and grass (ecici); a prison or a jail. aiwen otuja: to imprison; to incarcerate. etekat is a large reed granary. edula is a big version of etuja. etuke (in Karamoja) a parrot.etuko a zebra (a wild animal like horse or donkey with white and black stripes), Hippotigris quagga subsp. burchellii.etukuba a rosette disease in groundnuts (making leaves yellow and spotted).etukubai a tree, Spathodea campanulata. Its wood is good for carvings, firewood, and charcoal. etukumel an edible mole rat; hamster rat (with a white tail-tip).etukuri an owl (a night bird with big eyes and believed to portend bewitchment in the family if it perches and hoots on the hut at night – the effects of the witchcraft can only be averted by throwing a glowing firewood or acukumac at the owl to scare it away). etukuton an ant-bear.etul a hip bone; a hip. esonget loka etul: pelvic joint. etulari killing suddenly; fatal; lethal; deadly; mortal. etularut a swollen tick. etulelut1 a plant, Cucumis colcoynthis. etulelut2 a Sodom apples plant whose yellow fruit is believed to bring crop high yield when scattered over the grain field, and the stem is used to make ear drops, Solanum aculeastrum. etulia soot; smut; tar; carbon. alemar etulia: to decarbonise. etulubong a plant, Tephrosis. etulutulu (singular noun M) sulphuric acid; vitriol. etuma (singular noun M) mumps, i.e. a disease that causes the swelling of the ears. edeka ngesi etuma: she/he has mumps. etumaana disobedient; obstinate; stubborn; unwilling. etumit fat; burly; obese; thick. etumunan a corruption of atumunan: a young boy of 14 – 16 years; an adolescent boy. etumura (singular noun M) fermented cassava tubers used in the preparation of flour for beer-making or for atap.etungasisit (collective noun M) a mass, a crowd, or a mob of people. etungat (collective noun M) a mass, a crowd, or a mob of people. etunyuny (of a knife, etc.) blunted; unsharpened. etuo a gourd. aloma akolong otuo: the sun is setting (between 4:00–6:00 o'clock in the evening). etupanit a nipple (of breast or udder); a teat. etupitono a maxim; an example; a person worthy of emulation; a guideline. eraas itelepai lu itupitono: these are exemplary boys. eturubango a tree, Albizzia malacophylla.
a Turkana tribesman from north western Kenya
a Nilo-Hamitic tribe akin to the Masai, Karimojong and Iteso.

a man from Turkey. eturukuku a tree bearing hard orange-size fruits, Strychnos innocua pomegranata. Its stem is a remedy for caries (emaekeke) when used as toothbrush. The wood is used for hafts for traditional tools, and for firewood and charcoal. eturuturut a brown and white hornet; a black stinging wasp. etusuroi a grass, Eragrostis aspera. etut a heap (of anything); a rampart of a dam; a boundary mark; a milestone; a raised sleeping platform; an altar in a traditional shrine. etute always moving; restless; agitated; impatient. etutum (singular noun M) human flu - coryza; a runny nose - catarrh. etutumu a bush from which salt is extracted, Vernonia amygdalina. etuturumoi (singular noun M) trouble-causing; provocation; incitement; negative influence. etuugulu an onion.etwaat a colloquial of etunganan: a man; a human being. etwali iron shaft of a spear. etwan a corruption of etunganan: human being. etwat a corruption of etunganan: a man. etwo a gourd. aloma akolong otwo: the sun has set.etyakara secluded; discrete; apart; separated; segregated; divided; cut off, etcetyang an animal; a beast. etyangatyanga a climbing wild bean. etyono difficult; hard; awkward; arduous; unbecoming. etyono akoko: it is unbecoming to steal. etyono etelepat ngol: that boy is a difficult character. euduwudu a grass, Dactyloctenium. euga maize flour; posho. euji porridge made from posho or maize flour.eukarisita (singular noun M) the holy Eucharist. euko a lung. adeka naka iukoi: pleuro-pneumonia; any lung disease. eukot a big hill; a mountain range.inyami nat eul: you will be sorry for your obstinacy (literally, you will eat your disobedience). eula an arm-band of cow’s tail hair; a fly whisk (switch) made of a cow’s tail used in certain traditional dances as a costume tied to the upper arm. eulacom (formerly) a variety of sweet potatoes.
emutuugulu etuuru (singular noun M) fever and flu; sleeping sickness; coccidiosis (in chicken)

wonderful happenings; a wonder; a miracle. eunya hissing and sizzling with anger (like an injured bull). apotu itunga luaunyas kobilutu ekokolan kawenis kosodete aibunga aidyak aiyar: an angry mob broke into jail and got a suspected thief whom they beat to near death.eupa a fireplace; a heap of embers (as in a campfire); a pile of ashes. aicak eupa: to step on embers; to stir embers (i.e. looking for food). ecak-eupa a greedy person who searches for food after feeling the hearth warm with the foot. eupa loti: a bonfire. eupa loidopit: an inferno; Hell. eupanara accompanying; going together; relating to; associated with. eupanara aberu ngin kokilenike: that woman agrees with her husband (literally, that woman always goes together with her husband). apapulai nueupanara ka aitac esolo: tax related documents. eupet a male companion; an aide; an escort. eur to smell of. euri a fragrant plant, Ocimum. euria (singular noun M) steam; vapour; gas; breath. euriana short; stumpy; low; (of female animals, birds, or people) fertile, prolific, productive, or bearing many. euriat a native; an indigenous person; a born of somewhere; an aborigine. euriat loko Teso: a born of Teso. eurien a dwarf; a short person; a midget; a gnome; a pygmy; a homunculus; a Lilliputian; a manikin. euris a plant, Elaedendron cucchanani. eurukoroi a plant from which salt is extracted, Laggera alata. eusi a sewing thread; a spider’s web. eusuk a tree from which Usuk (county or sub-county) derives its name - Zanthoxylum chalybeum. Uses: its crushed seeds are used as spices in tea; its roots, berries and bark treat malaria (eimidi), stomach-ache (ariebo naka akoik), measles (ekwam), joint pain (obilibil), ekodoi (skin rashes caused by smallpox epidemics), eteregege (meningitis or paralysis), ekurara (yaws) and syphilis (esuuku), among other diseases.
a man from Usuk county or sub-county in Katakwi district. Iusuko: eusur (of a person) rather big

(of anything) somehow fat. eusur etelepat ngol: that boy is rather big. eutana fond of or clever at wrestling. eutudoole a shrub, Sarcocephalus latifolius. Its root extracts are a good treatment for early leprosy. The fruit is eaten as food while the leaves and fruit are fodder for livestock. eutune the spinal cord.ewadikan a writer; a clerk, a journalist. ewaet a joke; a jest. ewai the side; compass direction; a border; a margin; a page (of a book); a legacy; a portion; a part; one’s portion of inheritance. iwaitin kere: all over; in every part of a place. kolot awai: go to the side. ewalu a crowned or crested crane, Balearica regulorum. Uses: this beautiful bird is a national bird in Uganda; can be a good sentry at night against intruders to a home because it wails on seeing danger. ewangala (formerly) a variety of sweet potatoes. ewaragi dry gin; crude distilled alcohol variously called ejuge, ecuramol, etc. eware a grass, Simplex. ewaya a fencing wire; line (for hanging out clothes to dry); an overhead electric wire. ewayo a bush with sour fruits (used for preparation of atap when green), used as toothbrush.ewelu a black plum tree, also known as ekarukwei, Vitex madiensis. Uses: ripe black fruits are eaten; the bark, leaves, roots, and fruits are medicinal; tree provides shade; fuel from firewood and charcoal; building materials from its poles and timber. ewema a tent; a canvas material. ewenat a prisoner; a detainee. ewenet a thing for tying; a rope; a cord.ewiiny sweet; sugary; honeyed; saccharine. ewila a plant, Tephrosia barbigera. ewinyiwiny1 an ulcerated callosity.ewinyiwiny2 (singular noun M) sweet or raw brew (two days old, after which it is called arasai).ewoc a buzzard (a large eagle-like bird which hunts small animals for food); a black-shouldered kite. ewode (singular noun M) the manner or method of serving food. aijul ewode a balanced diet; to change the manner of serving food. ewoe1 (it is) leaking ewoe2 singing; a manner of singing; a totem. ewoe kec erono: their singing is bad or is wrong (at discord or out of tune). ewogor a kind of grass. ewoi a tree, Faidherbia albida. ewois1 a hymn book; a song book; a hymnal; a poetry anthology. ewois2 a song; a hymn; a chant; a poem; an ode. ewojakori a long-tailed Coly bird. ewokiwok a grass, Rotboellia exaltata. ewoliwol dropsy (i.e. abnormal accumulation of watery liquid in body cavities or tissues). ewom (collective noun M) a gang of labourers. ewongo a boast; a bombast; bragging; vaunting. ewoodi a ward; a building in a hospital with beds for patients. eworo (singular noun M) a call, a holler; an invitation. eworoworo a species of very poisonous snake. ewosin a corruption of eosin: a vagina. ewosit a buttock; the behind; a bum. ewosyana a corruption of eosiana: slow in conceiving. ewuko a corruption of euko: a lung. adeka naka iwukoi: pleuro-pneumonia; any lung disease. ewukot1 a hill; a mountain. ewukot2 a lung. ewul disobedience; obstinacy. ewula wristlet of cow's-tail hair; a tassel; a tress; a fly whisk. ewunyot one who lifts or raises (anything). ewunyot ekume: one who turns up his/her nose in contempt.ewupa the hearth; embers. ewuryaana short; stumpy; dwarfish; brief; curt; abrupt. ewuryana prolific; fertile; ewusi a sewing thread; a spider’s web.ewutune the spinal cord. eyaadi a yard (a British length measure); a parking yard (for trains or cars). eyaat a person of blessed trinity. iyaan iuni: the three persons of holy trinity, i.e. God the father, God the son, and God the Holy Spirit. eyakia a delegate; a messenger; a servant; an apostle; an emissary. eyakia lokibaluan: a mail-runner. eyakiton one who sends others on errands. eyala (singular noun M) conversation; pleasantry; trifle.

(singular noun M) Mt. Elgon (Masaba).aite oyale: to be dead or to die (literally, to face Mt. Elgon in the east – the direction the dead face during burial in certain Teso clans).atwanare: to die. eyapeesi an office
the place of work; an administrative centre; workplace. eyara (formerly) a variety of sorghum.

an Arab.eyelel (Serere) a thorn tree, Acacia deponolopium.apupunit eong eyemut ebe ededeng Kony ko Gulu: I heard news that Kony rebels have intensified attacks in Gulu. eyepamoni (Serere) a bird with orange-coloured feathers, black and white striped wings and fan-like fethers on top of its head, Crested hoopoe. eyeriyeri see-through

transparent; translucent.eyeyait (Serere) a nephew (as called by the aunt).eyeyis (Serere) song-book; hymn book; a hymnal. eyileyile a plant used together with etulelut (sodom apple) for aipolia (prevent witchcraft or evil eye on) a potato garden or emukaro (to thwart an evil eye that would prevent the kiln getting red-hot or roasting potatoes well), and from which salt is extracted, Trichodesma zeylanicum. eyokobiyat a worn out cloth (formerly used as underwear by women); a menstrual pad.eyongana timid; timorous; fearful. eyoroi (Serere) a tree the leaf extract of which is used as medicine for ear-aches, Teclea nobilis.eyosi (Serere) in or during the afternoon.
Earabut eyati a grass, Chloris virgate
a Jew (a person from Judea). eyunibasiti a university
campus; institution of higher education. erai Makerere eyunibasite lokapolon ko Uganda kere: Makerere University is the biggest university in Uganda.
esomero, ekolej eyuunan a believer; a follower; a devotee
(noun neuter) the sixth letter of the Ateso alphabet. gabumenti (noun neuter) (formerly) the government.
(singular noun neuter) (biblical) Hell (the place of eternal fire and suffering)

the abode of Satan.gulugul sound of rumbling or rattling of stomach. gwai rather; quite; somewhat; slightly; to a certain extent. gwok gwok (noun neuter) (of a dog, to) bark; the sound of a dog; (to a child) a dog.merrr: the sound of a sheep.
Jeana genger (sound imitation of an object falling without bouncing much, like a fully-inflated football or a bag of cotton well-filled, or of a stumpy, well built person) thud; thump; bump
(noun neuter) the seventh letter of the Ateso alphabet

a vowel letter as in ‘ink’. i- a) prefix of neutral and diminutive nouns - itunganan: a person in general. ikoku: a child. ikitoi: a small piece of wood. b) plural prefix of masculine and diminutive nouns - ekiliokit: a man - (plural) ikiliok: men. ikoku: child - (plural) idwe: children. c) pronominal prefix of second person singular and plural of all verbs and weak adjectives - iduki, idukete: you (singular, plural) build. ilipi, ilipete: you pray. d) pronominal prefix of third person singular and plural of all ki verbs - ilipi: he/you pray or ask. ilipete: (plural) you/they pray or ask. e) prefix of masculine plural numerals - ikany: five. f) prefix of second person singular and first person plural of present indicative of verbs - iduki: you build (singular). kiduki: we build. ilipi: you pray (singular); ilipete: they pray or you pray (plural).

suffix of relative prepositional form of verb: akan naanyamia eong: the hand with which I eat. akoto asaanit anyamia: I want a plate to eat with. iare (noun neuter/Dimin.) two. lokiareit the 2nd. nakiareit (singular noun F) Tuesday

(ordinal number) the 2nd. yenikiareit the 2nd. ibabu shame; moral poverty; shamefulness; obscenity; bad language. inera ngesi nuk'ibabu: she/he talks obscenity. lok’ibabu; lok’ileic - a shameful man: one who is ashamed; a poor man.ibakanyany amot ngin akituk: that pot has a wide mouth. ibakanyanyas itunga akitukes akwena: people are wide-mouthed with laughter. ibakor poverty; misery.ibalel fungus, toadstool, mould, mildew, yeast; mushrooms. ibalua (noun Dimin.) a chit; a note. ibalusus (of stomach) fat; gigantic; enormous; huge. ibamarar (of a person, an animal, or an object) fat, thick, paunchy. koany etuan lobamar akoik ewadi alosit korot: look at a man with a fat belly waddling on the road.ibang (noun Dimin.) a little blockhead; a dense child. ikoku yenibang egolenenei katukot: a stupid child/pupil comes last in class. ibangarar huge; gigantic; large.ibaranyany (of a gourd, pot, or a person’s waist) broad; wide. ibarasit (noun neuter) a cow (as riches). ibaren (noun neuter) cattle; livestock. ibatalal (of a vessel or an instrument) broad, wide, large. amot na ibatalal akituk: this pot has a wide mouth. ibatalalas je akeje: that guy has wide fat feet (or webbed feet like a goose) (term of abuse) ibatangang (of lips, nose) thick and fat. ibatangangas ipon: thick lipped. ekume lobatang: snub nose (Term of abuse) ibecokino accurate; exact; congruous. ibeeleana mischievous; vicious; belligerent. ibeketet (of a person’s feet, hands) having long and dirty nails; dirty; rough. ibelesio business; occupation. ibeliyana greedy; insatiable (food-wise); gluttonous, etc iberu (noun Dimin.) a very small woman (an insult to a petite woman) ibiler delirium tremens; hysteria.) a swift (a small fast-flying insect-eating bird similar to a swallow but with longer wings and a shorter tail).ibilibilikaalet (noun Diminutive) a swift (bird). ibityono stingy; greedy; selfish; miserly; egoistic. ibokonyony having a big lower jaw. (an insult) ibokoror (of skin, bark, or wood) rough. emukule loibokoror: rough skin. ibokorwa east coast fever; a disease causing skin warts.ibomoror (of body) large; (of stomach) fat. (an insult) ibonotot (of physique) quite well developed; most beautiful, considerate, nice; (of manners) elegant; well-mannered. ibore (noun Dimin.) a thing; an object; something. ejai ngesi ibore: she/he/it is at such a place (not now remembered). ore k’obore: at so-and-so’s home. ibotolol eponoi having a fat or thick lip. ibucelel (of lips) red (due to lip cancer or lipstick). ibulucuc (of body) without skin; (of face) browless (i.e. without eye-brows). ibulucucas nges akonye: he/she has no eye-brows. ibululu blue ibulurur (of the ear) swollen (from fitting earring). ibus (of a person or anything) beautiful; handsome; right; lawful; (of weather) warm. ibusiak itogoi ngul: those houses are beautiful. ibus lolo akwap: it is warm today. ibusakinit apt; pertinent; appropriate; suitable; proper. ibusakinit oni aswam kagogong: it is necessary that we work hard. ibuturur1 (of person) gloomy; sulking; angry-faced; purse-lipped; mooching or moping. ibuturur2 (of cutting edge) blunt; rounded. ibwanyana (of a beer-drinker) intrusive; fond of gate-crashing. ibwenyi bweny a reply of people cursing a thief. icana poor; badly off; lowly; destitute. icangang (of dry potatoes, cassava, etc) pounded; crushed. icawaana (of person) backbiting; detractive. ice- (diminutive or neutral adverbial prefix) some. icebore another thing; something. icetunganan: another person; someone. icebore (indefinite pronoun) something.icelelee (of a hill, elevation) sticking up; lofty; protruding. icenion posterity; nephews. icetunganan (indefinite pronoun) somebody; someone.icidikik (of breasts) tiny; small.icikik (of contents, flour) compacted; pressed together; compressed; squeezed together. icikik akiria nuatap opuko: flour is compacted in the sack. icipip (of rope, lace, hair, etc) plaited; woven, knitted. icira (of a milking cow) tame; easy. akiteng naicira: a milk cow. akiteng na mam icira: this cow is difficult to be milked. icodio fore-runners of a swarm of locusts.icodongong (of people, things and animals) tall. icodongongas yesi: you are tall. icogoror (of person's limbs) awkward; ill-shaped. icok-ajele a bush with edible berry the doves feed on, Hoslundia opposita. icolibib (of beak of a bird, of nose, finger-nail, spear, pencil) pointed; sharp. icolirir (of person with long neck, etc) tall. icolisis (of person with long finger-nails, limbs, etc) long; pointed.icoperer (of ears, leaves) pointed. ekingok loicopereros aki: a dog with pointed ears.ekingok loicopiriros aki: a dog with pointed ears.iculul (of container) congested; heaped; amassed. iculurur (of things) in a heap; heaped; gathered. icumum (of anything) speared; pierced; impaled. icunyetait (noun Dimin.) a small mark; a dot; a full stop; a speck. icupa (noun Dimin.) a cruet; a vial. icuro (of a kid) frantic; bouncy; full of life; lively; (of cassava, potatoes being pounced in a mortar) hard and bouncy. icurono (of youths, kids) playful; joyful. icuroko apesur ngun: those girls are very playful. icwa (noun neuter) a bird that makes such sound, Black-headed heron.idaakak (of person) bossy-headed.
ileic ibakanyany (of an opening, mouth, entrance) large, wide

Iteso people from Adacar in Usuk county in Katakwi district. Adacarait: a woman from Adacar. Edacarait: a man from Adacar. idaidait (noun Dimin.) a little drum. idalakak (of a female) having fallen breasts. idalakak aberu ngin: that woman has fallen breasts (a fallen-breasted woman). idamokok (of bag, breasts, football or any receptacle) empty

unfilled. idapokok (of person) having flat small buttocks, i.e. not protruding.idaukuk (of head, skin) woolly; like wool; fluffy. ideke (noun Dimin.) an idol; a carved god; a false god. idekerer (of person, animal, stick) thin; emaciated. idelana (of a snob) showy, flashy, ostentatious; (of a child) petulant; huffy; having fits of tantrums. idelana ikoku ngin: that child is obstinate (does not want to be pacified, shows a fit of tantrums); to go into a tantrums. idelelee (of anything) protruding; conspicuous; visible; standing out; prominent, evident, exposed. akiro ace nuedeleleutu: emerging issues. ideleleete akiro ngun: those things are very obvious. idepidepana (of person) jabbering; babbling; talkative. idepidepana ijo: you are a chatter-box, a tale-teller. idepio a brood, young ones of locusts, fleas, spiders; off-spring (an insult when used to refer to someone’s children). koyanga idepio kon ngina: depart with your brood.iderakina (of homes) sparse, (of plants) far apart, few in-between. iderakina emaido loelomit: only a few groundnuts have germinated. ideridera (of plants, homes, people) scanty; few; sparse. ideridera akimai komanaka: the millet is sparse in my garden. idetetait (noun Dimin.) a small drum used (together with a long drum – emidiri) at twin-dances.ideuna (of anything) spare; left over. emameete nuideuna: there are none to spare. emameete bobo eong nuideuna: I have said all I had to say. Idi1 (singular noun neuter) the ninth month of the Muslim year, during which Muslims fast between sunrise and sunset.idi2 (interrogative pronoun) M, Dimin.&neuter plural: how many? idi: how many (are they)? yesi idi?: how many are you? idicic (of flour, groundnuts, etc) ground fine; pulverised. idicic akiria nu: this flour is well ground. ididi (noun Dimin.) a species of small birds - Waxbill. ididiit (noun Dimin.) a small bird, Yellow-backed pytilia.idiimim (of body, stick, etc) thin; emaciated; (of grain) underdeveloped; stunted in growth. idiimimas akimai nu akwes: this millet has underdeveloped ears (is stunted in its growth). idik (of liquids) thick; viscous; gooey. idila (of anything) plentiful; rampant; copious; widespread. idiobore (indefinite pronoun) anything; a scrap (of something). idiope diope (adverb used with plural masculine, neuter or diminutive nouns) one by one; one after another. kolomanasi togo idiope diope: go in the house one by one. singly; one by one. kopotu ore idiope diope: come home one by one, singly. itunga idiope diope: one person after another. iboro idiope diope: one thing after another. idiopet (numeral adjective)(used with Dimin. & neutral nouns) one. idiopet itaok: one calf. ikalel adiopet: one kid. ikoku idiopet: one child. idiopetait (noun Dimin.) any of the digit numbers; a unit. idiopeta ikany: five units. idiotai a little; some; a bit. koinakinai ikiring idiotai: give me just a little meat. idiotunganan (indefinite pronoun) anyone; anybody.idipalalas itunga luko Kasese: the people of Kasese (the Bakonzo) are dwarfish, stumpy. idipanyany (of house, person) short; low. idipanyany etogo ngol: that house is low. idipolol (of person's buttocks) small; tiny.idisidisin a few; a minority. apugan naka itunga idisidisin: a minority government; a government by a few. ido moreover; also; then; and; again. kolot ber Katakwi, ido konye Kapujan: first go to Katakwi and then to Kapujan. ido bobo da and besides; and again; and more than that; further still. ejokuka apese ngin iponesio, ido bobo da kitemelel: that girl has good manners, moreover she is beautiful. idodomat (of a road) endless, too long;
