(of a mango fruit) very ripe. idoelel (of belly) slender; sunken. idokidokono (of person) having a good memory; vengeful. idokorian (noun neuter) a plodder; a persistent or persevering person. idolidola (of person) lacking energy; (of rope, etc) long and coiled. erai ngesi etunganan loidolidola: he is a lazy man. cp loelongwaana, loekalanyana: a lazy person (but with strength). idolit (noun Dimin.) a child born with umbilical cord round the neck. idolol (of rope, clothes, snake, etc) folded; coiled. abu eong kadum egoe idolol: I found the cloth folded. idomococ (of body) dripping wet; drenched; (of cooked potato, cassava) soft and watery. idomococas ikagoen kere: my clothes are full of perspiration (or thoroughly wet). idongoror (of plant) heavily laden with fruit. idongororas imucuugai ekaru lo: this year the orange trees are laden with fruit. idoponyony (of a person, animal) one-eyed. idoudout azure; sky-blue. idukulet (noun Dimin.) a small bead; a small round pond; a circle. idukulul concave; hollow. idukulul akaale: a spoon is concave. idukumum (of cooked food) mellow; soft; tender; (of fruit) ripe. idul (of hole) deep. idulok icileta lu: these rivers are deep. idul ajimikon: your wounds are deep. idungulul (of limb, fingers, toes) short; maimed; amputated. idunya (of things) adjacent; near; close together. itogoi luidunyas: neighbouring houses.idupukuk (of cloth, flour, cat's fur) fine to touch; soft. idupukuk apalisi naepaaba: a cotton mattress is soft. idusukuk (of cooked vegetables) tender; mellow; (of person) stout. idwe (noun neuter) children. idwomen (derogatively) food; edibles; eatables.koinakinai eong edia loidwomococ: give me nice vegetables. idwomokok (of pod, any receptacle) empty; unfilled. idyakalal (of anything) soft and watery. idyakalalas acok idoritoi: the potatoes have been cooked very soft and watery. idyamakak (of wet sticks) soft and bendable, pliable. idyatuna (of anything) accumulated; collected. idyeletet (of floor, road surface, etc) smooth; slippery. idyeletet erot lo: this road is slippery (plural) idyeletetas irotin lu.igabuna (noun neuter) (formerly, during the colonial era or the reign of Idi Amin Dada) a regional governor; (derogatory) a tramp (eats without working). igalal (of liquid) strained; skimmed. akile nuigalal: skimmed milk. igaluna (of tasks, resources) shared out; pooled; gathered; joint. kesi inyamat luigaluna: this is pooled food. igangit (of actions) collateral; supportive; helpful; sympathetic; encouraging. igarigara (of space) commodious; roomy; spacious; vast. igasiana (of homestead, etc) dirty; unclean; filthy; mucky. igasiana ekonire: your home is always dirty. igayoono holy; saintly. igeriat (noun Dimin.) a small seed-eating songbird, Hooded finch. igetemem (of person) having a distended belly (an insult) koyanga akonigetemem ngina!: off with your distended stomach! kingalakin ikoku ekia, igetemem do tai: somebody gave the child poison, now its stomach is swollen. igetet (of potato or cassava tubers) sliced and dried. acok nuigetet: sliced dried potatoes. igole-idodo (noun neuter) a lizard buzzard.igolemir (noun neuter) a mouse buzzard.
a Teso clan of Builders or Masons. igoromom (of girth) big, distended
near full pregnancy; (of a tree) heavily laden with fruit. igungurur (of person) small and mature. Zakayo arai etunganan loigungurur: Zacchaeus was a man small in stature.
people from Agu (a swampy place in Serere county). igurumum (of person, pot) rounded and fat-bellied. igwaamam (of surface, skin) rough
(of manners) uncouth. igwaramam (of surface, skin) rough, scaly.

goods. ileleba igwelanara oiduka ngol: that shop is full of merchandise. ii yes, of course; yes (an answer in response to a call); naturally; indeed; surely. iicudan (noun Dimin.) (euphemism) a penis (literally, a little wizard).iikinyiny (of face of person with aching tooth or ear) puffy, swollen, or bloated; fat-cheeked (due to diseased ear or swollen tooth). iikong (noun Dimin.) a small wooden mallet. iisineret (noun Dimin.) inverted commas. iitaabo (noun Dimin.) a booklet; a brochure. iiyengunet (noun Dimin.) a short rest; a comma. ijaa (noun neuter) aunt; the sister of one’s mother or father. ijaaka: my aunt.ijamakak (of belly) fleshy, plump, fat, obese, corpulent. ijamakak epege lo: this pig is very fat. etelepat loijamakak: a fat boy. ijamakakas akeje: kija eong kakejeka nuijamakakas: I have soft, supple feet. ijangijanga (of anything) shaky, insecure, unstable; rocking; unsteady, wavering, vacillating. ijangijanga aduko kec: their marriage, relationship, friendship is shaky, unsteady. ijarijara (of rope, belt, etc) loose; slack. epale ngol ijarijara: those trousers are too big or loose. ijauna acceptable; receivable. ijegejege (noun neuter) (formerly) a 5 cents coin; coin money (in general). ijejait (noun neuter) a nephew or niece (called so by aunt).ijekokino auno ya: that rope is too short. ijerer (of behaviour, branch, or rope) twisted, warped, or perverted. ijeruko (of bull, etc) rebellious; unmanageable. ijesuna (of price, measure, level, etc) lowered down; slipped down. aijesun etau: to lose courage.ijieta weapons; arms; military hardware. ijikitit (of person) deaf. ijip scabies. ijo (personal pronoun second person singular subjunctive form) you; thou. ai bo ilosi ijo?: where are you going? (note: objective and dative form isyo). ingai kinomi jo?: (singular) who beat you? ijo ba na: (singular F) you here. ijo ba je: (singular M) you there. ijo ba lo: (singular M) you here. ijo bo je: (singular M) you there. ijokoinet (noun Dimin.) a brown wagtail - a little bird that moves with grazing animals in order to catch grasshoppers. ijokot (noun Dimin.) a small bird that follows cows to catch ticks or grasshoppers. ijopijopo (of many heights, lengths, etc) unequal, uneven, lopsided, irregular, or disparate. ijopokino (two heights, lengths, etc) unequal, uneven; disproportionate. ijopokino akitoi na ka ya: this piece of wood is not equally as big or as long as that. ijopokino akonye: unequal eyes (one wider than the other); squinting or distorted sight. ijugume (noun Dimin.) a little drum used at twin-birth dance.ijukujukas itunga kagwelanaret: there are too many people at the market. ijukume (noun Dimin.) a small drum used for twin-birth-dance.ijulul (of sides) converse; opposite; reverse; opposed. ijululue (of something hanging) head down; slanting; diagonal; leaning. ikaalei kids; young goats. ikabinin worthless sorghum grain.ikadet (noun Dimin.) a small seed-eating bird. ikaidu (noun Dimin.) a man’s favourite wife (especially the latest and possibly the youngest) among many. (It is believed a husband sleeps, bathes and eats frequently at ikaidu’s house and he loves her most – to the chagrin of other wives). ikajaran (noun neuter) a living thing.ikalelo afloat; buoyant. ikalol (noun neuter/Dimin.) a kid; a young goat.okwe ikang konyou, nukon nupe inerai: my dear friend go away, they are talking about (killing) you. (ikang used in a salutation or beginning a letter to everybody: Dear Sir/Madam). ikangasana (of equipment, activity, etc) fatal, deadly, lethal; hazardous, dangerous, harmful; risky. ikangikanga (of cooking, grinding, etc) perfunctorily done; quickly and badly done; done in passing, hastily, hurriedly, superficially. ikangikanga alos na iryeitai: this flour was poorly ground. ikanyana (of person, animal) obstinate, pig-headed, inflexible, adamant, persistent; stubborn, intractable, obdurate, mulish. ikapa (noun neuter/Dimin.) a cat; a pussy cat.ikapan equipment; kit; apparatus; paraphernalia.
a major Teso clan (ateker) of rain-makers and from which warriors, hunters, and leaders of clans came

the Warrior clan. ikatanyany (of utensil, especially a bowl, basin or basket) having a broad opening at the top.ikatanyany ngesi akituk: she/he has protruding wide lips. ebukit loikatanyany: a big open basket.
a major Teso clan (ateker) - they do not eat the meat of a bushbuck (ederit)

the Thwarting or Restraining clan; the Pacifists.erai ekaki egoe lokatir: khaki is a tough cloth. ikatwan1 bad spelling of ikatunganan: my (little) friend ikatwan2 (noun neuter) the dead.ikaurian (noun neuter) a parent; a begetter; ancestor; a forebear. ikawoo shame; embarrassment; humiliation; disgrace; indignity; dishonour; infamy. kenyekikiniata eong ipejok ikawoo: the visitors left me in embarrassment or in shame because I had nothing to give them. aisamisam ikawoo: to savour shame.ikeara (of a person) arrogant, conceited, haughty, egotistical, proud, supercilious; stuck up; (of anything) high up; aloft. ikee medicine; drugs; poisons; medications. ikeeki (noun Dimin.) a wafer, cracker. ikela k’etom elephant tusks; ivory.) a chapel. ikerep lunacy; insanity; psychosis; mental illness; madness; mania, craze, or obsession. ikerep luka etyang: rabies. ikerepono crazy; fanatical; insane; maniacal. ikesa (noun Dimin.) a little fellow; a small guy; a chap; a member of a young age group. ikesa: a person. ikesa ngin: that little fellow over there. ikesisian (noun neuter) a student; a pupil; a scholar; a disciple.iketana (of person’s behaviour) hard; obstinate; dogged; inflexible. iketerer (of person, birds) skinny; bony; lean. iketerer ikokuka, engerit apoloor: my child is skinny, it does not grow. ikeuna prominent; outstanding; raised; elevated; hoisted; supported; propped up; shored up. ikiara lifted up; elevated, aloft, towering, sky-scraping, or tall; prominent, high up, high-flying.
Atekok ikatirir (of cloth, skin, etc) thick; tough; layered
natives of Kidetok in Serere county.

the eastern people.ikidioko angor: women are few. ikidioko ikiliok: the men are few. ikijit contents of bowels or entrails of animals.ikilarar akou (of person) big-headed and hairless. ikilarar nges akou: she/he is bigheaded and hairless.ikiliok men
husbands. ikingok (noun neuter/Dimin.) a puppy; a little dog; a despicably poor person (an insult).
people from Akisim. ikisin lulekekin breasts with long nipples.ikitinyo chaps

cheeks.) a seedling or small piece of wood. ikiyonit (noun Dimin.) a bud; small, young leaf. ikocolol (of person or animal) having hairless patches or bald patches on the head. ikodomom (of person) tall and round-shouldered; tall and hunched; tall and bent. ikoelel (of person or animal) big-eared; long-eared. ikoelel etom: the elephant has big ears. ikoi poorly ground beer yeast i.e. unground yeast radicles in millet beer or on fermenting beer. ikojoi lightning bolts; arrows; shots; bullets. ikoki (noun neuter/Dimin.) a little orphan. ekoki: an orphan boy. akoki: an orphan girl.
ikisin lucidik: breasts with short nipples

one of the four main divisions of the Teso tribe and native to Kaberamaido and parts of Soroti district – their language has a mixture of Ateso and Luo words. (These people prefer being called Kumam, not Ikokolemwo).ikokoteono nasty

jealous; envious. ikokoteoko itunga lu aitecel eong duc: these people are nasty, they always attack me verbally. ikoku (noun neuter) a small child (whether male or female) under six years; a baby; an infant. alot ikoku osomero: the child has gone to school. ikolededet (noun Dimin.) a small black cat-fish, Bagrus. ikolodong (noun Dimin.) a young tortoise; a Volkswagen Beetle car. ikolol (of liquid) congested with; brimming with. ikolol ajon ngun akipi: that beer is too watery.
Ingoratok, Iseera and Iteso (of Usuk county)
a major Teso clan that blessed others (but could also wish others bad luck if denied something)

the Spittle clan; people from Komolo - Wera in Katakwi district. ikopitoi tai (of disease or action) desultory; indiscriminate; infectious; contagious. ikoria breasts with long nipples.ikorococ (of head or ground) hard and bare. ikorococ akonikou: you are hard-headed; you are stupid.ikorodod (of a person, especially a woman who has borne many children) gassing or farting easily. ikorododas amojongik ngun: those old women fart at a slightest provocation. ikorwa he-goats; billy-goats. ikosobwa1 a variety of people’s hair resembling buffalo hair (soft, fluffy, curly and like for a mongrel or mulatto and greys very fast). Ikosobwa2 one of the clans in Teso. ikososoi (of anything standing) gigantic; huge; colossal; oversize. ikote ai? (interrogative pronoun) how are they? kikote nepenen: so be it; amen.ikote nen things are thus; well then; thus.

a Christian child. ikudelel (of platter, tray, etc) flat.ikuetet (of man or animals) having swollen testicles; (of soil) rocky, infertile and shallow. ikuetet : he, they have swollen testicles. ikuetet akwap, mam apedori akor: the ground is very dry, I cannot cultivate.ikulepek owners of; (used with plural of reflexive verb) themselves. lukangai ikulepek iboro lu?: who are the owners of these things? kesi ikulepek ejenete: they know it themselves. ikumemei (of anything lying down) huge; massive. ikungurur (of a person) pudgy i.e. short and thick; thick and fat. ikupa (of a garden) ready for gleaning. amisiri naikupa: a plot ready for gleaners, i.e. the owner has allowed others to gather leftover grain, etc from it. ikureana often feeling or causing thirst. ekureana: I am continually thirsty. ikureana: you are continually thirsty. ikureana: she/he/it is continually thirsty. kikureaka: we are continually thirsty. ikureaka: they are continually thirsty.
the Crow clan of Teso. ikusana (of person, animal, bird) playful

restless; fidgety; fussy; cheeky. ikusana ikoku ngin: that child is fidgety.ikuwamam (of surface, skin) rough, etc.ikwaamam (of skin, surface) coarse, rough. ikwangalal (of weight) light, thin.ikwareget (noun Dimin.) a species of small black birds.ikwatarar (of person, animal) rough bodied and thin. ikweje (noun Dimin.) a small quail-like weaverbird. ikweny birds in general; aircraft; planes. ikwenyit (noun neuter) a bird (in general). ikwes sheafs, bundles or loads of grass, fire-wood, etc. ikweta (noun neuter) the equator; latitude 0o; an imaginary line passing round the earth at an equal distance from north and south poles (this line runs from east to west). ikweterer (of a person, chicken) short and skinny. ikwii bushes; shrubbery. ikwiin (noun neuter) queen; empress; (also) jetliner.ikwijit the contents of the intestines of herbivorous animals.ikwongakina (of packing) mixed up; in disorder; topsy-turvy. ilabanyany (of opening of clothing, pot, door, etc) too wide; not fitting. ilabanyany ekasaati: my shirt is too wide. ilabilabana (of person) talkative; garrulous; loquacious. iladad (of a wall, surface) smeared; plastered. iladad arwatat na: this wall is plastered. ilajilaja (of something tied, a rope, a screw, etc) slack, loose. ilamam (of anything) cursed; accursed; jumped over. ilamitoi (of speech, activity, train of thought, etc) desultory; aimless; random; unfocused; haphazard.
the Langi people - one of the Luo-speaking tribes of northern Uganda

the natives of Lira and Apac districts.ilapadae (of herdsmen) wandering, nomadic, peripatetic, travelling, rootless, roving; (of speech) drifting, discursive, unpredictable, unreliable, inconsistent; (of movement) free, unrestricted, at liberty. ilararaara (of land, scalp, etc) bare, clear, open. ilarongong (of person, bird) bald-headed. ilatirir (of sheet metal, etc) dense; thick. ilebilebana (of person) talkative; loquacious. ileic shame; shyness; disgrace. aanyun ileic: adumun ileic: to be ashamed. abu eong kaany ileic kanukon: ibu ijo kitaany eong ileic: you made me ashamed. airum ileic: to be shy; to blush; to be ashamed. kerumitos eong ileic: I feel ashamed. aiturum ileic: aisurum ileic: to make ashamed; to humiliate. ileicono bashful; shy; coy. ileisit (noun neuter) one of the sixty-four beads in a board-game called aile (omweso) played by two people on 32 holes.ilekileka (of partly-eaten food) wasted. abu kadum atap ilekileka: I found food was being wasted (eaten at every point and yet unfinished). ileleba (of a container) replete; full; (of space) congested; (of anything) copious; prevalent. eleleba eong: I am full: I am satisfied. ilengerer (of a man) circumcised. ilengereras Imugis: ekepep Imugis: the Bagisu men are circumcised.ilepaana ngesi (ilepaaka kesi): she/he (they are) impudent. ilerara (of floor, ground, etc) hardened; dried. ilerara alup, mam apedori aibok: the soil is very hard, I cannot dig it up. ilererei (of anything visible) plain, obvious, clear. ilererei akirot ngin: that idea or statement is clear, obvious. ilerereete inyukutan: the words are legible. ilesiara (of person, animal, etc lying) spread-eagled; on the back and stretched out. ilesiara ngesi koitaadake: she/he lies stretched out on his bed. iletenyeny (of an excavation) shallow; flat. iliagamam (of a person, tree, etc) tall and thin; high and lanky, etc. iliagamam egoro noi: a heron is very tall. iliamamai (of surface) flashy, glitzy, garish, dazzling. ilidongong (of waist, body) narrowed like a wasp; slim, slender. iligerer (of neck in relation to big belly) elongated. iliikik (of head) large and unproportional to small body. ilikidyana (of person) greedy; miserly; stingy; close-fisted.ililingana (of person) taciturn; reticent; reserved; introverted. ilimia (slang) coin money; currency in general.ilimilimit (of surface) spotted; dotted; speckled; dappled; mottled; (of rain) having drizzled. iliogotot (of body, character) immaculate; unblemished; faultless. isapat yen iliogototas iponesioke: this boy’s manners are without blemish. ilipana (of person)fond of begging, praying. ilipet a petition; a small request. ayaunit eong ilipet: I have a little request. iliriangang (of person) deaf; hearing-impaired; unable to hear.ilisioror (of plant) tall and thin, slender. ilobob (of a garden) prepared; ploughed. ilobob amanaka: my plot was cultivated or ploughed again. ilociloco (of lengths, heights) different; unequal. ilociloco ibokor: the fingers are different in size. ilociloco apapulai: the papers are mixed up. ilocomom long-necked and big-bellied.ilogiloga (of passages, routes) labyrinthine; complicated; elaborate.

a Teso clan. iloja grain falling off from the heads of grain during drying. It is used for beer-making. (slang) beer from iloja. ajon nuka iloja: beer made from iloja.ilokiloko (of a pole, post, tooth, etc) loose

movable; shaky. ilokonyony (of dental formula) having missing teeth while others grow haphazardly. arai eong ekimat loilokonyony: I am an old man with missing teeth.ilolomono (of person, randy he-goat) cantankerous; noisy; raucous; boisterous. ilolony (singular noun neuter) exhaustion; fatigue; tiredness.ilolyana (of a child) touchy; playful; mischievous; naughty. ilolyana ijo: you are cheeky. ilope1 by itself; alone; the very one. ijo ilope: you yourself. ilope2 (noun neuter/Dimin.) the (little, despicable, or unspecified) owner. iboyie ngesi ilope bon: it stays by itself. ilope akiro: the unidentified accuser. ilope akwap: a native or inhabitant of a region or country. ilope (neuter): the owner (unidentified). ilopodot (noun Dimin.) a species of small birds. iloror (of a knot, ground) tight; rammed; hard. iloror akwap: the soil is very hard (no rain).ilosiikit (of a person’s body) dirty; grimy; filthy. ilosikino (of speech, action, amount, etc) apt; sufficient; appropriate. itunga lu kere mam ilosikinos togo lo: all these people cannot be accommodated in this house. ajon ngun mam ilosikinos itunga lu: that beer will not be sufficient for these people. ilotot (of body, clothes, etc) washed; cleaned out. inyekinit ijo asaanit mam ilotot: you left the plate unwashed. ilotuna (of a container, clothes, etc) well washed; cleaned out. ilotuna igoen lu: these clothes are washed, are clean. ilotuna ekatau neejai ijo: I like you very much.ilugumum (of bottle, belly, etc) very stout; tubby; portly; corpulent. ilugurur (of back, character, etc) hunched; bowed; crooked; criminal. ilujukuk weak, flexible. ilukumum (of vessel, pond, etc) round; circular. itogoi luka Iteso ilukumumas: the houses of the Iteso are round. ilukumuna (of huts, ponds, etc) detached; distinct. ilukumuna itogoi lu: these houses are detached.iluluono (of person) alarmist; panicky; jumpy. iluluono tai: sounding alarm for nothing. ilulwa1 (noun neuter) a fraction. oni da kidumuni ilulwa: we shall also receive a share. ilulwa2 (of anything) whole; unblemished; unscarred; perfectly smooth. ilulwas akiro ngun: that case has not been tried. ilumangang (of a person) stupid; daft; (of cow, sheep, etc) hornless; (of big object) rounded; without a protrusion.ilumudud (of wound) scabby; (of pot's contents) swollen up, orotund, etc. ilunguret (noun Dimin.) a pill; a tablet; a knob (of stick or anything). ilunguret yenika ekia: a table or a pill. ilungurur1 (of anything) rounded, round. ilungurur2 (of a leper's limbs) toe-less; finger-less; amputated; maimed. ilunyuny (of body, skin, etc) abraded; scratched. ilupudud (of nose, wound, etc) oozing; dripping. ilusumum (of a round thing, especially a head or club) smooth; rounded; (of cow, sheep, goat, etc) hornless. iluterer (of eyes) bulging; protruding. iluumum (of cow, etc) hornless; (of a club) round-headed.ilwatana (of person, animal) peeing often; urinating often; bedwetting always. ilwer (noun neuter) a lesser bushbaby (a small, furry, tree-living animal with big eyes and a long tail), Galago crassicaudatus. imadakak (of anything) very dirty; filthy; grimy; mucky; grubby; muddy; polluted. imadakakas ikonikel: your teeth are dirty. imadingana (of person) dangerous; desperate; atrocious. imagulul (of anything) bent; warped; crooked. imakacac (of person) splay-footed. imakacac etunganan naarai imakacacas akejeke: he is splay-footed, because his feet are turned outwards.imakakina (of anything) stuck to; fixed to; adhering to. imakakina eong eporoto: I am hoarse. imakio (in the Anglican church) the clergy; old men; aged men. imakucuc (of person) splay-footed.imalalana (of person) cheeky; rude; mischievous; disrespectful; naughty. imaliasas (of person) splay-footed.imanangit (noun neuter/Dimin.) a calf. imanangit (of a cow, an elephant) having a newly-born calf. imangara (of anything) knocked down or knocked over. imare cowpeas, Phaseolus tephrosia. imarimaret (noun Dimin.) something small for listing; a colon. imatamana (of person) stubborn, obdurate, mulish, bolshie. imatat (noun neuter) a beverage; a drink; a brew; a swill. ekia lomatat medicine for drinking. akipi numatan: drinking water. imaten (noun neuter) drinks; beverages. imatongong (of face) thin; mean. imaukuk (literally) big-headed. imedelana (of person's character) temperate; kind; merciful; clement; (of stature) tall and slender. imegerer (of person, plant) not growing well; skinny. imerekek a lamb; a young sheep; a small sheep (despicably). imidimida (of candlelight, voice) dim, weak, or muted. imilia (of lightning, surface) flashing; gleaming; glaring. iminai (of surface, glue, etc) sticky; gluey; adhesive. imir (noun Dimin.) (figurative) a small child; a baby (literally, a little rat). edeka ikamir kore: my little baby is ill at home. imirio: little kids or children.

a bastard; a street kid. imiroi duc emameotor alup nudukot: bastard children often have no land to build homes.imiyot (noun neuter/Dimin.) a chick; a young of a chicken.imodilil (of child) dirty; mucky; grubby; filthy. imodiobore (used with singular nouns) anything; something; nothing. emamei imodiobore einakitai nges: nothing has been given to him/her. imodioboro (used with plural nouns) anything; something; nothing. mam ikokolak apotu koyangaasi imodioboro kotogo: the thieves did not take anything from the house. imodo (noun Dimin.) a species of little birds. imokodana (of person) fastidious, finicky, hard to please, or peevish. imomot (of fruit) half-ripe or yellowish. imongot (noun Dimin.) a small fruit left after picking the big ones.imono (of person, animal, tyre, etc) satisfied; fulfilled; content; happy. imoriarit inclusive; comprehensive; wide-ranging; broad. imorikikina united; integrated; joined; married. imorimora varied; mixed; assorted. imoru (noun Dimin.) a pebble; a small stone. imoru yenetiai: a prize jewel. imorut (noun Dimin.) 1. one of the sixty-four beads or pebbles used in aile or omweso board-game; 2. the method of playing that game. ededeng ikemorut: his/her method of playing omweso always leads to winning.imu twins.imucakina (of passage, etc) closed up, filled up by itself. imudangang (of person, sheep) having small or cut ears. imudongong (of a person, animal) having little crumpled ears. imug gourd seeds, i.e. seeds of amugit. imugulul (of limb, stick, pole, etc) twisted; crooked; warped. imujalal (of a person) naked; nude; exposed. imujurono (of person) scowling, frowning, often.imukeru (noun neuter) a baby (girl or boy); a baby under two years of age, i.e. before it is weaned. ikoku yenimukeru: a little baby or infant child. imukerut babyish; infantile; puerile. eroko ngesi imukerut: she/he is still a baby. isirut yenimukerut: a mosquito larva. imukokit akwap evening time; dusky.imukoro (of anything) covered with cloth; (of people) uncivilised; primitive; (of development) delayed. iringa ijo imukoro: you are still uncivilised. sirikimukor, adoloto isaawan: do not delay, it is time. imukoro ateran kegoe: the bride is covered with a veil. imukurur steep; hilly. imulangang (of cow, etc) hornless.imunonoritai (of identity) concealed; kept secret. imunwo intestinal worms - ascaris; snakes (in general). imurwono forgetful; inclined to forget; scatterbrained. imusungana injurious, harmful, dangerous or risky. imuut (noun neuter) a twin (person or animal). imuyaayet (noun Dimin.) a street kid; an illegitimate child; a bastard. ipu imuyaayen ko Kampala: there are a lot of street children in Kampala city.imwaas ai? (interrogation) how many are they, you? imwace a colloquial form of moi kace: in future. imwaneono (of person) greedy; gluttonous; close-fisted; stingy. imwaneono ijo: you are close-fisted.imyela (of person, animal) hungry for; eager for; impatient for. imyelimyel (noun Dimin.) (Serere) a small grey house gecko; a newt; an eft.onaceka: my brother; my cousin brother. inacika: my sister; my cousin sister. inamana joking; fond of joking; fond of cracking jokes. inangai so-and-so; a woman that shall not be identified. abu inangai: so and so has come (in a despicable tone). inangei clothing (in general); apparel; attire.inapaara (of person, animal) polite; humble; gentle; well-mannered. etunganan loinapaara: a nice, polite, well mannered, or humble man. inapakina (of anything) calm; peaceful; quiet. mam ber akwap nako Teso inapakina: the Teso country is not yet peaceful. ainapakin akeje: to sit down with legs or thighs closed (as women do). inapap (of things) folded; arranged; organised; methodical; tidy; neat. inapat (noun neuter) clothes; clothing in general; apparel; attire; garb. emameete eong inapen: I have no clothes. inarurut (of the body) swollen from lashes or insect bites. inarurutos iwosike naarai edaitai: her/his buttocks are swollen because they were beaten or caned on. inepukuk (of fur, downs, mattress, pillow, etc) soft; spongy; fluffy; downy; cosy. egoe loinepukuk: a soft cloth. inepunit burning; ablaze; (of desire) enthusiastic. inepuuk a colloquial form of inepukuk: soft; spongy; fluffy; downy; cosy. apaliisi nainepuuk: a soft or spongy mattress. inerana loquacious; garrulous; talkative. ingaamam having many teeth; with a fuIl set of teeth.ingabarar (of a big bowlegged person) having fat buttocks and wide hip-bones. ingabinyiny (of a small person) to have flat buttocks and bow legs.ingadakina (of anything) hidden; preserved; kept in custody; put aside; saved up. isirigin luingadakina: money put aside, saved. ingadana fond of storing up (like bees or ants or people). ingai? (interrogative pronoun) who? whom? lokangai? (nakangai F) whose? ngai ma ngol (ngin F)?: by the way, who is that? ingai ijo?: who are you (singular)? ingai ekirorikon?: what is your name? lukangai ikusikiroria?: what are your names? ingalana fond of deceiving; dishonest; elusive; deceitful. ingalat having deceived; bogus; phony; sham. ingarakit supporting; beneficial; supplementary. ingaren forward; in front; the future; ahead.ingarenit (noun neuter) antecedent; precedent; guiding; standard.
Iteso people from Ngariam sub-county in Katakwi district. Angariamait: a woman from Ngariam. Engariamait: a man from Ngariam. ingarot (noun Dimin.) a pebble

a piece of grit. ingatan booty; spoils of war; plunder; pillage; the loot.ingatuna (noun neuter) the loot; booty; ill-gotten gains. iboro lungatuna: things robbed; the loot or booty. itunga lungatuna: captives after a raid. ingeberer (of dress, cloth, or trousers) short; brief; mini. ingecelikino (of anything) overlapping; unequal; going beyond. ingedeses (of hips) lopsided (one leg shorter than the other, or the hip-bone ill-formed. ingejingeja inarticulate; mumbling; faltering; tongue-tied. ingepesikina partly overlapping. ingeretenyit (of person) thin; emaciated. abongu ngesi kangina ingeretenyit: she/he came back from there very thin. ingesebeb (of rope, cloth, pot etc)easily broken; fragile; delicate; brittle; weak.inginamam (of person) toothless. inginyana (of person) fond of backbiting or slandering; gluttonous; (of cook) fond of mashing food. inginyiny (of food) crushed; mashed. akoto edia loinginyiny: I want mashed (or well-cooked) vegetables. ingiol (noun Dimin.) a person with protruding teeth. ingiolol (of a person) with teeth protruding; having a harelip. ingirabab (of teeth) broken or worn out. ingirababas ikonikel: you have got broken teeth. ingirionyony (of person) having a bruised face or broken teeth. ingisolol (of person) having protruding teeth or a harelip. ingitiyo (noun Dimin.) a little light grey house gecko; a newt; a gecko lizard.ingobelono desirous; covetous; longing; craving; pining; lusty. ingonyas (of networks) complicated; elaborate; (of people) hurly burly. ingoomom (of person, trees, etc) toothy; thorny; teeming, crowding. ingoomomas ikukwa korot kangol: there are plenty of thorns on that road. ingoomomas ikel: the mouth is full of teeth (no gaps); toothy.

one of the four main divisions of the Iteso people and natives of present day Kumi district counties of Ngora, Kumi and Bukedea. Their dialect of Ateso was formerly regarded by Christian missionaries stationed in Ngora as ‘standard’ Ateso which they recommended for use in written (as opposed to colloquial) Ateso.ingoriana (of a man) fond of women

womanising. ingosibib (approvingly) esteemed; estimable; (disapprovingly) awful; dreadful. ingosobob (of mouth) toothy. ingotolol (of face) disfigured; gnarled. ingotolol nges akuwan: her/his body is disfigured (having one eye, short leg, a dented face, etc). ingularar (of limbs) maimed; disfigured; mutilated. ipu itunga luingulararas kanuka ejie: many people are maimed due to war. ingulenyeny (of person) stumpy; dwarf. inicakina (of adjacent things) close together; compacted. yeninicakina : that, those that are compacted. inicanakina (of neighbouring things) close or closely fitted together. kibwaik kes kinicanakina: put them close together. inimokok (of buttocks) tiny and shrivelled. inokok on fire; (of food) well done, hot (literally, well cooked). inokok etaala: the lamp is lit. koyau akipi nuinokok: bring hot or boiled water. inokok acok ngun: those potatoes are well cooked.
a Teso clan of bone-setters and masseurs

the physiotherapists. inukusana (of person) fond of sleeping for too long or waking late. inusio coin money; mint.inyadakak (of mouth, teeth) dirty; unclean; grimy. inyaiyono (of person) fastidious; particular about things; hard to please; fussy. inyalal (of things) mixed; compounded; amalgamated; composite; multifaceted. inyalikik (of body, meat, etc) soft to touch; squashy; spongy like a dead cat. inyalinyala (of things) mixed; confused; assorted; varied. inyamat food; edibles; nourishment; meal. inyamen food (derogatively); edible things.inyeg worthless millet grain.inyekoono (of a co-wife) jealous; envious; green-eyed. inyikokinit (of a person, sickness, etc) continuing; earnest; serious; grave; sombre; stern-faced. inyo bo? (interrogation) what now?; what then? inyo? (interrogation) what? kanukinyo?: why? alosi ngesi kinyo?: how did she/he go? (on foot or on bicycle?) lonyoin? M, nanyoin? F which kind? what kind? (referring to colour or quality). inyoin ikoku? (itelepat arai ipese?): what sex is the child? (a boy or girl?) inyodokok (of mouth, teeth) unbrushed; dirty; grimy; unclean. inyogirir thick or (to be) difficult to please (of man). inyonyoikina the anointed; the smeared. inyorakina (of things, especially cooked food) mixed; added. inyamat luinyorakina acok ka imare: a mixture of potatoes and peas.inyoridid (of body) dirty. inyus (of dough, clay, mortar, food) thick; solid. -io suffix for present indirect and infinite of passive form. enyekinit eong etogo edukio: I left the house being built. ipa (noun neuter) (used in letters) sir; My Lord; Your Highness. ipa: papa (father).
(noun neuter) the Pope. ipajanas (of people, animals) consanguineous

related. ipak (noun Dimin.) a moment; a jiffy; a split second; an instant. ipaliyono obdurate; insolent; mulish; stubborn. ipaloror (of a head) bald; bare; clean-shaven. ipaperono (of person) friendly; sociable; welcoming; amiable. ipaset (noun Dimin.) a full-stop; a resting point./neuter) a piglet; a little pig; a little dirty child. ipegeta (formerly) arguments at initiation ceremonies. ipeket (noun Dimin.) a small grey hawk. ipelakina (of anything) precarious; unstable; in a falling position; shaky. ipemerer (of a child or a thin man) having a distended stomach. iperito beddings.) a female infant.ipicara (of something semi-liquid) crushed; quashed; flattened. ipidipidiara (of height) very far up; (of tree) very tall, high. ekitoi loipidipidiara: a very tall tree. ipiitit (of person) stunted, underdeveloped. ipinyana (of person) inclined to gorge, over-eat. ipiricara (of food, fruit, etc) crushed; squashed; pressed out. emucuuga loipiricara: a crushed orange. ipirisakina (of solids, crystals) dissolved; liquefied; thawed out. ipirit (of wood, dried potatoes, etc) weevil-eaten; rotten; decayed. ipisakina (of a container) absolutely full; full to the brim.ipokiriras itelepai lu: these boys are burly. ipongosos (of buttocks) huge.ipoo (noun neuter/Dimin.) a scrub hare, Lepus capensis; a rabbit. ipopanyatoi (of a rhino, bull, etc running) noisy and forceful, dangerous. ipopolana (of person) boisterous, rowdy. iporo during the wet season. eweyo ikinyom iporo: seeds are sown during the wet season. iporo in, during the wet or rainy season. ipu many; much; plenty. ipu akipi: water is much. ipu itunga: people are many. ipu agasia: rubbish is much. epol emaase: many locusts. epuata kesi: they have become many. ipucakina (of an opening) blocked, closed, plastered or fastened. ipudanara (of people) desirous of each other; loving one another. ipugurikina (of person) hunch-backed; stooped. ipugurur hunch-backed; hunched; arched; stooped. ipumu epilepsy; seizures; fits. ejaas ngol ipumu: erai ngesi lok’ipumu: he has epilepsy. lok’ipumu an epileptic. ipus (noun neuter) a pussy cat; a kitten.iput (noun neuter) a stunted child; a dwarf; a midget. ipuwak numerous; many. itunga luipuwak mam edumunete aswam: many people will not get work.iraat (noun neuter) a thing planted; a plant. iragag (of grain) poorly ground, coarse. irajakak (of body) flaccid; flabby; floppy. irajiraja (of anything) tied loosely.irangaana (of person) greedy; gluttonous. irangangai (of meat, wound, eyes, etc) very red. irapudud (of person, animal) short; dwarfish.

the Cheetah clan. iraruna a thing found or picked up. ikoku yenikiraruna: foundling; a stray child picked by someone who is not a relative. iregeget (noun Dimin.) a small black bird. iregemem (of a sick person) thin with small protruding belly. iregemit (of eyes) dirty. iregemitos akonye kon: you have dirty eyes (like groundnut dregs). iregwa (noun Dimin.) a small black bird. iremana (of a dog) good at barking. irengamoni (noun Dimin.) a little shrike. irengemany (noun Dimin.) a small fish with red-tipped fins. irengerenget (noun Dimin.) a robin (bird). irepenyeny (of animal, person) short, dwarfish. ikingok yenirepeny: a pug dog. irereono observant; watchful. ireria homes; villages; homesteads; abodes; kraals; residences. iriapongong (of a person) cock-eyed; squinting. iribikik (of cloth, the night, etc) jet black; very black; pitch dark; shining black (like alpaca cloth). iridet (noun Dimin.) a clip; a clamp. iriorono (of person) talkative; chatty. iripadad (of something big, a person) flat; low; depressed; stumpy. iritongong (of person) cock-eyed; squinting. irokodod (of head) pointed at the back. irokodod nges akou: she/he has a head protruding at the back: her/his head protrudes at the back. iromococ (of person) knock-kneed.irumuna (of wife, property, etc) inherited; innate; inborn; hereditary. iboro luirumuna: inherited property. aronus nairumuna: original sin. aberu nairumuna: an inherited woman (i.e. wife of a dead relative). irumunet (noun neuter) apostrophe; the sign (’). irumurumaara (of body, the face) bloated; swollen; distended. irupeana (of person) double-dealing; fond of reporting, duplicity, and being devious. iruruono (of gangs) fond of raiding, plundering, robbing. irwa (imperative) go away; get out of the way; be gone. irwa kane!: get out of here! vamoose! (plural) irwa yesi kane!irwa etom (singular noun M) a sensitive plant that folds up on being touched, Biophitum. rwaru in the far future; in the distant future.irwerweet (noun Dimin.) a tit (a small bird). irwopokok (of stomach, tyre, football, etc) empty; deflated. irwoporo (of a container, such as a rubber tube) empty, unfilled, etc. epesete itelepai emopiira loirwoporo: the boys are kicking a deflated football. iryono (of complexion, the night, etc) black; dark; dirty. iryono cucucuc: (of the night) very dark; (of anything) very dirty; very black. iryoro (of person, radio, telephone, etc) talking; speaking. iryoro ikoku katukot: the pupil is talking in class. iryorono (of person) talkative; garrulous; loquacious; chatty. iryorono emuluka loka ekanisa kangol: the pastor of that church is talkative. isagarar (of hair, dry grass, etc) rough, shaggy, shabby, or unkempt. isamukuk (of hair, head) overgrown; hairy; shaggy. isamukukos idwe akwes: the children have long hair. isamukuk eong akou, ekoto abarenio: my head is overgrown (hair too long), it needs a shave.isanyirir (of hair) bristling, bedraggled, shaggy. isapirir (of person’s hair) unkempt.isaseredootin the (Roman Catholic) clergy. isean the chosen ones; the elite; the elect. isedenyeny (of a hollow, pit, etc) shallow.
irocokok irotongong (of the head, an object) narrowed; squeezed

one of the four main divisions of the Iteso people and natives of present day Soroti district counties of Serere, Kasilo and Soroti, and Amuria and Kapelebyong counties in Katakwi. (Iseera speak a dialect of Ateso distinguished by their use of letters ‘gw’ instead of ‘bw’ in words such as aibwo, aibworo, Ikarebwok, etc.isekelono (of person) inclined to scoff at, ridiculing or laughing at. iselio poorly fitting large garments. ailoli iselio: aiil iselio: to be alarmed (literally, to sway with large garments). iselyo a corruption of iselio: big dresses (that swing about as the wearer walks). ailoli iselyo: to be uneasy.iseren (noun Dimin.) a butter fish, Shilbo. iseuna the elect; the chosen ones.isididiara (of tree, evil, etc) cannot be eliminated or eradicated; deep-rooted. isigala (noun Dimin.) a cigar; a cigarillo. isikakina (of passage, etc) blocked; clogged; jammed. isikakina eong eporoto: I am hoarse. isikik stamped; rammed; blocked; pumped up; beaten up. isilarit contrite; sorry; remorseful; repentant; apologetic; penitent. isimu yenikakan (noun Dimin.) a mobile phone; a hand-held phone. isinerit engaged to; affianced to; betrothed to. isineritai apese: the girl is betrothed or is wooed. isinyeono (of person) greedy, voracious. isiorotot (of tree, pillar, etc) dead-straight; straight without a bend. isiriamut (noun neuter/Dimin.) a Muslim in general; a little Mohammedan; a Muslim child or thing. isirigin money; currency; legal tender. isirigin luko Uganda edit egogong adepar luko Kenya arai Tanzania: the Ugandan currency has less value than that of Kenya or Tanzania. isiriomom (of face, etc) dirty. isirir adorned; decorated; festooned; bejewelled. isisiat (noun neuter) a lesson; a little teaching. iso (personal pronoun 1st person plural subject or object, but exclusive of the listener) we; us.isogoror (of a part, etc) sticking out; protruding; protuberant. isokodod (of handle of walking stick, beak of bird of prey, nose, etc) having a round bend; curved; hooked. isomelel (of an egg, sheanut fruit, etc) oval; stream-lined; elliptical. isoridid (of anything) sordid; dirty; filthy. isorididas kes awate: their bodies are filthy. isorodod (of anything) dirty; dingy; filthy; squalid; (of language) lewd; obscene.isoswa pretence; sham; feigning; make-believe; pretending. mam akoto ikonisoswa: I don’t want your pretence. isot (noun Dimin.) a word of admiration or praise, ‘nice little fellow’, ‘good little fellow’. ee abu isot ngin: there comes the good little fellow! isotia (noun M, Dimin.) (only used by close friends) heroes; guys. apotu isotia kwi or apotu asotia kwa: our heroes are come: our heroines are coming. isua (slang) coin money (currency).) a creature. isugurana (of person) phlegmatic; showing unwillingness or reluctance (by going slowly).isujakak (of head, body) hairy; shaggy; hirsute; bristly. isuk Bambara nuts (a variety of beans).
Iseera speak a dialect of Ateso distinguished by their use of letters ‘gw’ instead of ‘bw’ in words such as aibwo, aibworo, Ikarebwok, etc. cp. Ingoratok, Ikokolemwo. isekelono (plural isekeloko
Christmas time (period around 25th December). apaarit naka Isukukur Christmas (25th December).
ebaga isulajaj (of beard) hairy; hirsute; (of head) overgrown; (of garden) full of weeds
a Teso clan of denouncers and blasphemers (who kill by incantations and sacrificing at anthills)

people from Asuret in Soroti county or some other place of that name. iswagara (of utensils, floor, etc) clean; polished; scoured; scrubbed. iswamana (of person, animal) hardworking; industrious. iswapakak (of eyebrows, eyelashes) overgrown, long. isweenyeny (of a person) small, dwarfed, meagre, tiny, or of slight build. iswomodod (of nose, face) very dirty with dripping thick mucous; (of sex trade) iniquitous; lewd; obscene. iswongolol (of a person’s character) maladjusted; (of dress) not fitting. isyalakak (of hair) rastafarian; unkempt; (of clothes) in rags, pieces or strands. isyarasiara (of bread, etc) scattered; spread about; dispersed. isyo (personal pronoun, 1st person plural, subject or object - exclusive of listener) us; we. eong: I; me.edukit ngesi eketogo: she/he has built her/his house. elipit eong ijo: I ask or keep asking, begging you. itaditada (of pole, tooth, etc) infirm, unsteady, or shaky; (of teeth, etc) loose. ejaas eong ikel luitaditadas: I have loose teeth.itagitaga (of a pole) loose, rickety, or unsteady; (of any furniture) rickety, wobbly, or shaky. itagitagitoi: it/she/he is staggering on. itak (noun neuter/Dimin.) calves. italakana (of a person) consoling; condoling; cheering; heartening. itanaki (of a mother) breast-feeding. itangaleuni (of drug, etc) curative; remedial; healing; therapeutic. itaok (noun neuter/Dimin.) a calf. itaparin a grass, Andropogan. itapatani simplifies; makes easier. itasiono humble; repentant; sorrowful. itawono (of a person) greedy; selfish; egoistic.itebeikina congruent; appropriate; fitting; suitable; facing, in front of. itegelikina especial; unique; special; singular; different; peculiar. itegumum having a big belly or tummy. iteketeket (noun Dimin.) a second – one sixtieth of a minute; a jiffy. karai ejaas iteketeken akais akany-kape odakiika ediope, idi bo do iteketeken ejaas toma osaawa ediope?: if sixty seconds are in a minute, then how many seconds are in an hour? itela (noun neuter) the only child produced by a particular woman. itelele (noun Dimin.) a small drum (often beaten together with a big etida drum for curing a sick person). itemelel (of a lady) beautiful; good-looking; gorgeous. itemokino prepared; orderly; arranged; measured; justified. itemoro (of formatted text) justified; measured; exact in measure; (of dress, etc) fitting.itemwan sub-counties. itenakina lengthwise; straight; standing; upright. itenara upright; erect; straight; vertical. itengeana always hungry; ravenous.
iso -it suffix of verb active tense, present indicative, effective or continuous tense or result of completed action
a Teso clan. itenya sores on knuckles
arthritis of the knuckles. itepegit contra; hostile; opposed; anti. iteregeg stiff; paralysed; rigid.
natives of former Teso (present-day Katakwi, Kaberamaido, Soroti, and Kumi) and parts of Bukedi (current Pallisa and Tororo districts) in Uganda and Teso in western Kenya

a Nilo-Hamitic tribe in eastern Uganda and parts of western Kenya, numbering at least two million people – probably the third largest of Uganda’s 53 tribes - akin to Karimojong, Turkana and Masai; the people of original Usuk county in Katakwi district (the people who pride themselves as being from U.K – Usuk Katakwi) with a dialect characterised by elision of letter ‘k’ in certain nouns such as akipi, akituk, ekicolong which they pronounce as aipi, aituk and eicolong respectively.itesot1 of Teso or its people; pertaining to Iteso people, their language and culture. Itesot2 (noun Dimin.) a child or little person from Teso. (note that referring to an adult as itesot is an insult). itet new; fresh; young; recent; clean; unused; modern.itia for; instead of; in place of. koyau akine itia emerekekeka: bring a goat instead of my ram. itia nyo? (interrrogative pronoun) on account of what?) a female school teacher (especially in primary or nursery school).itiirianakina ikar kec: they are equal (in age); they are contemporaries. itilasas (of fat women) naked above the waist; half-naked. itilasasas aloke toni kwana: the Karimojong women are naked up to this day. itim hair on the head; a hairdress (made of human hair and worn during traditional dances as a costume); blood capillaries. itimaikinit (of an organ) having capillaries; (of scalp) hairy. itimono lenient; forgiving; merciful. itingatoi indisposed; reluctant; half-hearted. itinitina peevish; shy; finicky. itinitina ber apese egeunio aisup: a girl will be shy when courtship starts. itirajaj (of a woman) having huge rolling buttocks.ititimana fussy; vacillating; undecided; delaying. ito dear me! oh oh! alas! ito! kiyangaa bo jo ajon kere, ido bodo eong ka nyo?: alas! if you carry away all the beer, what will I remain with? itodikitai (auxiliary verb) I, you, etc must or should; you are dictated or commanded to (do something). itogo (noun Dimin.) a cottage; a hut; a little house. kotogo: indoors. itokokolit antagonistic; anti; opposing; competing with. itomon ten. irwana tomon: ten times. itunga itomon epote: ten people will be coming. itongolol (of man) handsome; praiseworthy; meritorious. itonokit causing to come near; causing to close on; firing up or keeping on fire. itopolono haughty; arrogant; self-important; conceited; inclined to be proud; stuck up. itoronana (of person) critical; eager to blame; nit-picking; captious; fault-finding. itoror (of a path, road) trampled down; trodden hard. itoror ijo aki: you are very deaf; you are hard of hearing; you cannot hear. itotoka dear me! oh my (mother)! alas! itotoka! adunge akim komukaro: oh my! the fire in the kiln has gone out. itotokang dear me! oh my (mother)! alas! itotokang! adunge akim komukaro: oh my! the fire in the kiln has gone out.) something small for cutting; a semicolon. itudot (noun neuter/Dimin.) a duckling; a gosling.itugai an armlet or bracelet made of plant roots or giraffe hair. itujomom (of a child) having a dirty body; having an unclean face. itukalal puffy or fat-cheeked; bloated.itunganan (noun neuter) a person (man or woman); a human being. itungasinei (collective noun plural) the people; the masses; mankind. iturasas (of a person) fat-buttocked; fat-arsed. ituria (noun Dimin.) a small spear used by children.ituro proud; arrogant; self-conceited. iturono fond of praising, approving, flattering; fond of exalting. itwala (noun Dimin.) a little pied (black-and-white) wagtail. ityangaikinit (of person) bestial; beastly; brutal; loathsome; wild; feral; untamed; abominable. iulana disobedient; stubborn; obstinate.
people from Usuk sub-county or county in Katakwi district. iwangana (of person) eating half-cooked food

greedy. iwolokok (of anything) hollow; empty; vain; inane. iwolokok asaduku: the box is empty. iwololo (noun Dimin.) a loud caller; a taxi or bus broker or tout.iwongono bombastic; high-flown; vainglorious; presumptuous; inclined to boast, brag or vaunt. iwonyana (only of walking) brisk; fast; quick; speedy. iwonyana ngesi: she/he is quick, walks fast.

Iteso from Tororo and Kenya distinguished by their heavy use of letter ‘k’ in Ateso nouns and verbs with prefixes ‘ai’ and ‘ei’ (for example: verbs aicum, aitep, aibunga become akicum, akitep, akibunga respectively; nouns eicolong, eitela, eitaada become ekicolong, ekitela, ekitaada respectively). iworoworo (rare) leaking; porous. iwulana a corruption of iulana: disobedient; insubordinate. iyakiana obedient; inclined to obey; dutiful; submissive. iyakitono obedient; submissive; subservient; dutiful; beneficial; useful; handy; versatile; serviceable. amot na erai nakiyakitono: this is a handy pot. ekiyakitono etunganan ngol: he is a useful or handy man.iyalana conversational; good at telling jokes; good-natured. iyamakina (of anything) peaceful; undisturbed; serene. iyamara (of manner, attitude) gentle; meek; mild; quiet. iyapono (of a person) inclined to swearing or to make vows. iyapununee (of user, spender) frugal; economical; thrifty; sparing. iyata (of amount, conflict, etc) rising; escalating; increasing; growing; mouting. iyatakina excessive; needless; unnecessary; extreme. iyeda (of belly) slender, slim. iyeyait (noun neuter) (Serere) a nephew or niece (called so by aunt).iyo (personal pronoun) (Serere) a corruption of second person singular personal pronoun ijo: you iyogiyoga (of teeth, poles, wall, etc) shaky; rickety; unsteady. iyuuna (of story, etc) credible; believable; plausible. iyuunana (of person) gullible; naive; credulous; easy to fool.
(noun neuter) the eighth letter of the Ateso alphabet. je (demonstrative pronoun masculine singular) that man (far away). koleje pac: recently. koleje in the recent past

previously; some time ago, not long ago. laije over there; that side. okekwa je: the other side (of the river or of the swamp). oitela je: at the next parish or village. olap je: the previous month. ekaru je: the previous year. je bo je: (emphatic) there he is.

the abode of Satan. jelijel very tasteless, insipid. epyana atap jelijel: the millet bread is very tasteless. ijelijelit ekatau aswam ngin: I am disgusted with that work.jepeje (demonstrative masculine pronoun singular) that one over there.jik completely; surely; absolutely. aidong jik: to stay put. agir je ainyam jik: he has refused to eat totally.kiting nges jokan: hold her/him/it very well.apaaran jui: the whole day; all day long.apaarit jui jui: the whole day; all day long. komat jui jui: drink completely.jukujuk (of people, an activity, etc) too much; congested; crowded; jam-packed. elosete kesi jukujuk: they are crowded together. juwai on the other side; across; on the other side of; over from one side to the other side of something. okekwa juwai: on the other side of the river, valley, forest, desert, etc. mam imwangi yenejai okekwa juwai: (proverb) respect the fellow who has crossed the river. juwai ketogo: on the other side of the house. jwele jwel (tasting) insipidly; dully; blandly. epyaka acuc jwele jwel: the ajon remnant is very tasteless.
(noun neuter) the ninth letter of the Ateso alphabet. -k suffix of plural nouns whose singular ends with '-on' or '-an': ekadukon (singular): ikadukok (plural)

ekelipan (singular): ikelipak (plural). k’ prepositional prefix of place meaning 'from' (followed by feminine noun of place or verbal noun or other feminine nouns). alemunit eong nges kasaduku: I took it from (out of) the box. abunit eong katapar: I came from the swamp. abunit kaira epaaba: I come from planting cotton.-k-1 infix forming plurals of adjectives which have root ending in 'n': ejokuna: good . k-1 prefix for conjugation of the far past, conditional and optative forms - abu eong kaduk: kaduk eong kolo sek: I built a long time ago. kadukoto ne: let us build here. kaduk eong ne: let me build here. -k-2 infix indicating plural form of verbs in '-n-': atwanare (singular): atwakare (plural): to die. atwana: she/he/it died. atwaka: they have died. k-2 prefix indicating objective personal pronoun of the 1st and 2nd person singular and plural prefixed to verbs. (note: objective pronoun, not subjective) kelipit eong ijo: I pray or ask you. kilipit ijo eong: you ask me. (plural): kilipitos yesi eong: you ask of me. k-3 pronominal prefix meaning 'when' or 'if'- kebu ejakait, kisiira eong: when the chief comes, let me hear from you, i.e. warn me. kalot eong Kampala, kejukakini agangat: if/when I go to Kampala, I shall send you help. kilot Soroti, sirikimurwok agwelun etabaasa: if you go to Soroti, do not forget to buy a lamp. -ka preposition 'of' denoting possessive case preceded by relative pronoun lo-, na-, yeni- : aberu naka Ojangole: the wife of Ojangole. angor nuka lteso: the women of the Iteso. ka1 conjunction and preposition 'and' used before proper nouns beginning with vowel A-, such as Aoja, Asuret, Arapai, etc: and; with; by means of; also used to form numerals above 5: ikany kape - 6. the 'a' of ka is elided before nouns beginning with a, except in proper nouns and pronouns. ijo ka eong: you and I. ibuni ka eong: you come with me. Oceger kikokuke: Oceger and/with his child (a of ka elided before I of ikoku). abu eong kaara ngesi kebela: I killed him by means of a stick (club). abuni ka Amuria: she/he came from Amuria. ka2 possessive pronoun of first person 'my' used adjectively: etogoka: my house (note: if used by self: M loka: mine; plural luka: mine. F naka: mine; plural nuka: mine. Dimin. yenika: mine; plural luka: mine). ka3 cut most especially. eroko isapa lu, ka cut Otoke: these boys are bad, most especially Otoke. kabeit truly; in truth; truthfully; really; in fact; actually; accurately; strictly. kabeit, emamei kwapekwana ngesi kane: she/he is not actually here at the moment. kabeit elimunit ngesi ngun?: did she/he actually say that? kace (F) in addition; and others. kace da: and so forth; et cetera. kadodi (singular noun F) a lively Kigisu circumcision dance with drums, rattles and ankle bells. kadoogo (noun neuter) (a despicable code-word during the 1987–1991 insurgency in Teso) a child soldier; a Uganda government soldier in the late 1980s. kai1 in, at, to the house; at home.kakai? kaina a corruption of kangina: over there. kakai? (interrogation) from where? kipote kakai?: where do you come from?kakeju with the foot; by foot. kakongu with the eye; from the eye. kakonye in future; in front; forward; with the eyes.
(adjectival suffix) (lokakwap M, nakakwap F, yenikakwap Dimin.): native

indigenous; rural. kama from. kama ejai from where; from where she/he/it is. abuni eong kamaejai ejakait: I come from the chief.kamoi goodbye till tomorrow; till tomorrow; farewell till tomorrow. kamu (done) in or during the dry season. kana demonstrative pronoun feminine singular: and, on, from this. kakan kana: kowai kalo: on this side. kane (demonstrative pronoun) from here; in this place; from this point. kolot kane: go from here. kane eonit: on dry land. kanewok: where we are; one of us. ingai kanewok?: which one of us? koge kane egeunia: begin from the beginning. koge aswam kane: start work here. kane ibunitor ijo: from where you have come. kaneka from me; from my home. ibunit ijo kaneka?: have you come from my home? abunit eong kaneka ejakait: I have come from the chief's place. kanekon: from you (singular). kaneke: from her/him/it. kanekosi: from us (excluding the person spoken to). kanewok: from us (including the person spoken to). kanekus: from you (plural). kanekec: from them. kanen and then; thereupon; so. kiroko iso kinyami kanen kobuni edou: as we were still eating the rain came. kanenice partly; from somewhere else; in other ways. kanenice ejok, ido kanenice erono: it is partly good and partly bad. ebunit ngesi kanenice: she/he/it comes from somewhere. kanepekanen there and then; instantly; here on the spot.kangina over there; from there.kangun demonstrative pronoun: therefore; for that reason; that is why; henceforth; and so. kangun, akoto alosit oreka: that is why (therefore) I want to go home. kanuka (possessive 1st person singular) for my sake; on my behalf; on my part. kanuka: on behalf of; because of; for. kanuka, alemunit eong emong ediope: on my part, I donate one bull. kanukon: for your sake. kanukon bon: of your own accord; without being asked. kanuke: on his behalf. kanukosi: on our behalf (excluding you). kanuwok: on our behalf (including you). kanukus: on your behalf (excluding me). kanukec: on their behalf. kanuka nu ad hoc; for this reason. kanukangun therefore; for that reason; consequently; as a result; so; hence. kanukangun, mam ipedori alosit: therefore, you cannot go. kanukinyo? (interrogation) why?

(numeral noun suffix) six together with. kara kar very, completely (dry, arid, desicated, or empty). aono akeit kara kar: the frying pan is completely empty. karaba karab (sound) like animals galloping

like soldiers goose-matching. karai if; when; in case. kibwokuna inyamat karai ilosi ocaalo: bring some foodstuff if you are going to the village. karai bo if perhaps; or perhaps. komanyai, karai bo kimina: marry me, if perhaps you love me.karaida even though; even if; although. karaida kigir ijo, eong alosit kwapekwangin: even though you refuse, I’ll go all the same. karaida…karaida: either…or.
(noun neuter) the land of the Karimojong people - the present day districts of Moroto, Kotido and Nakapiripirit in the north-eastern corner of Uganda. karibu welcome in

come in. karibu ore!: welcome home! (a reply to kodi!) karoba long ago (noun neuter) old times. kolo karoba: kolo kasonya: long ago. ikoto ijo ainyakunit karoba: you want to bring back old times, i.e. you are backward.abu ngesi kasesen eong kasoorian: she/he looked at me gloomily. katekisim (noun neuter) catechism. katipet at once; immediately; very fast

(noun neuter) (in the Roman Catholic church) God. katulik1 of, about, or belonging to the Roman Catholic church. Katulik2 (singular noun M) the Roman Catholic Christian faith, with the Pope as its head. katupeta respectively

in that order; correspondingly. apotu itunga iwongon kodumutu abootin 89, 46, 40 kede 15 katupeta: the four people got 89, 46, 40, and 15 votes respectively. katuputupeta respectively; in that order; correspondingly. kau at, to the back; behind. ai bo jo kau?: by the way, where do you come from (village)? kawai at the farthest side of; at the extreme end. kobwo kawai: stand on the far side, over there; stand aside.kawasia at the farthest side of; at the extreme end. kobwo kawasia: stand on the far side, over there.
(suffix or infix of possessive pronoun 3rd person singular) his

hers; its. aberuke: akeberu: his wife. okilenike: her husband. ikoku ka totoke: the child and its mother. ke- (pronominal prefix of verbs in 2nd person singular) if she/he/it; when she/he/it. kemataa ngesi ejuge, erai teni ededengu aibunga angor ke: when he takes alcohol, he really becomes violent in beating up his wives. kebuu ngesi, kolimok kobu oreka: if she/he comes, tell her/him to come to my home. kebil if; had …not; unless (with past tense or infinitive); perhaps; maybe. kebil ijo abunere: if you had not come. kebil alot nan ore: perhaps she/he has gone home. kebil ijo abunore, ti eong kalot bon: had you not come, I would have gone alone.-kec- suffix or infix possessive personal pronoun 3rd person plural: their; theirs. ikokukec: their child. lokec: lukec (theirs singular: plural M); nakec: nukec (theirs singular: plural F); yenikec: lukec (theirs singular: plural Dimin.). erai ngesi lokec: it/he is theirs. keceipone otherwise; by other means. kecerot by other means; by a different road. kede and; also; with; by; as well as; in addition to; along with. kede bobo: further more. eong kede ka jo: you and I. kede ka : with. kediany on the left; to the left. akan nakokediany : on the left. kedim had it not; if not (usually followed by verb in infinitive); but for; if you had not (followed by subject). except; excepting; but not. kedim ijo abunere, ti kalot eong apejo: if you had not come, I should have gone on a visit. kedim papaka adolun, ti eong kalot: if my father had not come, I would have gone.keeya of the army; belonging to the armed forces; in, to, for the military; of the Defence ministry. atuboros amotokan nuka keeya ibwokito ikeeyarin: army vehicles carrying soldiers have passed.eriata kwi apungure kekekek ba: they pulled at a log with all their strength, but to no avail. kemere good luck!; good fortune! kemere, ado akan!: Sweet fortune, I have chanced it! kepuwai partly; on the contrary; on one side; on the other hand. kere all; really; entirely; altogether. ai kere?: where on earth? where at all? itunga kere: all the people; everyone. ai kere ilosi?: where on earth are you going? inyo kere?: what on earth? inyo kere inera jo?: what on earth are you saying? abu kere papa: watch out, daddy has come. kokeri kere, aker onacekon: run, mind your brother is running. ikoto kere ijo apega nu ijeni?: you want really to deny what you do know? akwap kere kere: everywhere. kes personal pronoun 3rd person plural used as object: them. kesi (personal pronoun) they; them. (note: kesi is subject, kes is object)-ki- infix to all ordinal numbers above one. lokiareet: the second. lokiuniet: the third. ki- verbal prefix denoting: 1) first person plural in all tenses. kipou kabwoutu ber ko Getom agwela ibilenga: we stopped awhile in Getom to buy mudfish. 2) second person past tense in ki-verbs. kibungai ca bian je ebutuunitos akonye: it looks like the other one with swollen eyes was beaten yesterday. 3) imperative prefix of all verbs (infinitives and causatives). kiswama!: work! Do! 4) third person past tense. kinyamit iso: we have eaten. 5) second and 3rd person subjunctive. 6) a negative imperative of all ki-verbs. kinyekik kwangin!: stop it!; leave it there! 7) imperatives of all causative verbs. kitanyam idwe: feed the children! kia (of colour or lustre) shiny; very white. ejesi kia: it is very bright. ejesete kia: they are very white.kibwar kibwar sound imitation of a four-legged animal running quickly and heavily apace; swiftly; briskly; rapidly. kice da et cetera; and others. kidari goodbye; bye-bye; adieu; farewell; may God keep you. (abbreviation for) kidari Lokasuban: may God bless you. kide (noun neuter) the east. eastern; easterly. acila kide: dawn has broken; it is dawn. kokide: in/from the east. agiru edou kokide: the rain has thundered in the east. kidenyite (a saying meaning) on purpose, determinately, be prepared. kidenyite ibuni: be prepared when you come. iswamat ijo ngun kidenyite: you did that on purpose. kidim had (she/he/it) not; unless.kiding in the middle of; in the midst of; in the centre of; between; amidst; among; amongst; amid. kidding kus: amongst you. kokiding: in the middle; from the middle; from among. kiding ocor: to the middle of the lake. kiding paran: midday. kiding kuare: midnight. ebokorit lokokiding: middle finger. kiding ebai at (mid) dawn, about 4:00 am. kijokis (indefinite pronoun) all.kikir kikir sound of animals galloping very fast. atakarikisi imongin akerit kikir kikir: the bulls have galloped away very fast. kilar (of a bald-headed person falling) thump; crack; bump. ado etelepat osimit kilar: the boy has fallen heavily on the cement (the head touching the ground). kilar kilar (of a person, to go about) bald-headedly. elosi ngesi kilar kilar: she/he is walking bald-headedly. kilong (of sound of a bell) clang; clank. kimwa ai? (interrogation) how many are we? -kin1 a verbal or noun suffix to denote a repeated action or the acquisition of a characteristic. aiareikin: to do again. kiareik: do it again. kiuniik: do it a third time. aikingokikin (from ekingok: a dog) to become very poor; to behave like a dog; to become a vagabond, homeless. -kin2 verbal suffix forming dative or prepositional form of verb. kiswamanakini kesi ejok: we do good to them. kolot aiswamakin nges ngina: go and work for him over there. kinga outside; in the bush; exterior; abroad or overseas; afield. ejaas ityang kinga: animals are outside (in the bush). kinga ketogo: outside the house. kinga kakan: the back of the hand. nukokinga distractions; things outside. alosit kinga: to go to the toilet; to go overseas or abroad. aiboi kokinga: to live abroad; to stay outside (the house).kingaren (noun neuter) ahead before; in front. kingarenika: in front of me; ahead of me. kolot kingarenika: go in front of me. apak nakoingaren: in the future.kiokiot (to finish food from the pot) altogether; completely; entirely (imitates the scraping sound of a ladle against the bottom of an empty vessel). akitunos inyamat kiokiot: the food is totally finished.kire, ejulak eong akaomisio: actually, I have changed my mind. agir kire: she/he has truly denied or refused it. kire irai ijo Etesot?: truly, you are an Etesot?kito (if) at all. mam kito oni kicela da: we were not shouting or quarrelling at all. ngai kito kicelatatar kane?: with whom at all were you quarrelling here? arai kito: if at all. kiputo kito: we are the same. kiputo kito, inyo nat ejai ijo?: we are the same, what have you got more than I? arai kito kimina ijo eong, koinakinai akiteng: if at all you like me, give me a cow. kiton up to; till; as far as. kiton Ngariam: up to Ngariam sub-county in Katakwi. alosi apejo kiton Anyara: I am going for a visit up to or as far as (not further than) Anyara in Kalaki county – Kaberamaido district. kitoni as far as; until; straight on to. kitoni do kesi alosit: until they went. kitoni Nairobi: right on to Nairobi. kitoni bobo: then again. kiya the whole night through; all night long (pronounced as one syllable). aram bian Okolimo adeudeu kiya: Okolimo played the harp all night long. aikweny kiya: to be awake all night.eremas bian ingokwo akware kiya kiya: the dogs barked the whole night. aikweny kiya kiya: to be awake all night; to be sleepless or insomniac.ebunit ngesi kotogo: she/he comes from the house. iswamai ngesi koipois: she/he is working inside the kitchen. abonguni ngesi ko Bulaya: she/he just returned from Europe. abuni eong ko Usuk: I came from Usuk. ko-2 verbal pronominal prefix used: a) for imperative of ko-verbs: koduk: build . b) third person past tense of ko-verbs: abu ngesi koduk: she/he built. c) second and 3rd person subjunctive singular and plural: akoto ngesi koduk: let her/him build. kocoite (imperative) be careful; take precaution, be circumspect carefully, purposely. kolosi kocoite: go carefully. kodakite nges kocoite: carry it/him/her carefully, purposefully, intentionally. ibu ijo kolim ngun kocoite: you said that carefully. kodi may I come in? (the reply is, karibu: please do come in). kodoco truly; properly; as it should be. ibusakinit ijo aitodiar ijenuneta kon kodoco: it is desirable that you display your identifications properly. kojokan well; rightly; properly. kokau (of time) later; after; afterwards; at the back; behind. ebuni ngesi kokau: she/he is coming behind, after somebody else. abu ngesi kokau: she/he came late. kokau ka: at my back; behind me. iboie ngesi kokau ka: she/he is sitting behind me or stays in my boys-quarters. iboienene ngesi kokau ka: she/he sits always behind me.kokiding in, at, from the middle; in the amidst. kokinga from outside. kokokok (to finish) completely; altogether; entirely. amataas kesi ajon aikokoor kokokok: they drank and finished the beer completely. kokoliro koo (singular noun neuter) the sound of a rooster; cock-a-doodle-doo. kokuju from heaven; from above. ebunit kokuju: she/he comes from heaven, or from above. inera kokuju: she/he speaks from up there. koleje in the recent past; not long ago. kolo formerly; long ago; of old; in the past. kolo sek: long ago. kolongoe: lately. koleje: lately; in the recent past; previously. kolo karoba: kolo karionga: kolo kasonya: ngo kasonya: in the days of our forefathers or ancestors; once upon a time. kolo apengo: long ago. komam without. sirikilot komam eong: do not go without me. sirikilot komam inyamit: do not go without eating first.

suffix of certain nouns that have eka- prefix: ekadukon: a builder. ekaliokon: a liar. ekarokon: one who copies. -kon- suffix or infix of possessive pronouns in 2nd person singular. aberukon arai akoniberu: your wife. kongin a corruption of kwangin: in vain

like that. atyakatyak etengei ateker, abongu eong kongin kore kamamai: famine has divided the clan, I have come in vain from uncle’s home (without any food).konye bo: but then. kosodi konye: kosodi konyete: after that; and then. koyanga ebalua lo, kosodi konye alosit ore: take this letter, and then go home. kopirimasio (singular noun neuter) confirmation ceremony in the Roman Catholic church. koponesio by manner; by character; by category. ekodikod loirotin koponesio: road network by category, i.e. perennial and seasonal roads. kopuwai aside; apart; away. koroc koroc very (hard and bare). eonit akwap koroc koroc: the ground is very hard and bare. korododo noise of continuous diarrhoea. ebala amojong ebie korododo: korododo, thus farted an old woman.-kosi first person plural possessive pronoun infix or suffix, exclusive of person spoken to: our. erekosi: ekosire: our home (excluding you).kosodi1 (singular) and then. kosodete (plural) and then (used in the narrative form).kosodi ngesi abongor: and then they returned. kosodi konye: and then she/he/ it…; also; in addition. kosodete konye(te) (plural): and then they.kosodi2 and then (expression for narrative forms followed by infinitive verb). apotu kesi koloto ore, kosodete kesi ainyam, kosodete alosit apero: they went home, and then they ate, and then they went to bed.kotenan (to do, to speak) straight, correctly, justly, accurately, or well. kiswama erot lo kotenan: make this road straight. kotub akiro nu kotenan: settle this case justly. kikam nges kotenan: hold it well or hold her/him fast. kiner kotenan: speak accurately.koteten on, to the right (hand). akan nakoteten : the right hand to the right (side). kolot akan nakoteten: go to the right. lokoteten M, nakoteten F, yenikoteten neuter: the one to the right. koteten right. akan nakoteten: the right hand. kotogo from, at, in the house. kolem edia kotogo: get vegetables from the house. kotoma inside; within; amongst; from within. ejai loecudi kotoma kus: one amongst you is a witch. kwap toma: underneath.
Christ. luka Kristo Christians. kuju above

on top of; upstairs; in heaven. einer kuju: to speak aloud. kokuju kangun: in addition to that; above all; more than anything else. kuju kangin on top of that (one). ejai kuju: (it) she/he is above. elosi kuju: she/he (or it) goes to heaven or up. ejai eikopo kuju omeesa: the mug is on the table. kikea eporoto kuju: lift up your voice: speak loudly. ejai aberu kuju olap (euphemism): the woman is having menstruation (literally, the woman is up on the moon).kukur (low sound of a log or big stone being rolled once) bumpety-bump. ekokorior amoru kukur: the stone has been rolled down pumpety-bump. kukuru kukur (low sound as of a log or big stone being rolled many times) bumpety-bump. ikokorit ekingok ekisu kukuru kukur: the dog is rolling a mortar pumpety-bump (perhaps after licking it). kulu kulu (noun neuter) (of a turkey, to) chuckle; the sound of a male turkey; (to a child) a turkey.kutu kut: the sound of a breeding hen. kulut (noun neuter) a game of seek-and-hide (for boys and girls). kurub (sound of boots against hard surface or teeth grinding hard) crunch. icakete ikeeyarin eperet kurub kurub: the soldiers take their salute or parade with resounding steps. kuruc crunching sound. -kus- possessive pronoun, 2nd person plural suffix or infix. etogokus: ekusitogo: your house. kut kut kut (sound of a person calling chicken) cluck, tut, chuckle. kut kut kut, asosi inyamat lu: cluck cluck cluck, here is mash. kwa (demonstrative pronoun plural feminine) those far off; those far away.nu: (feminine plural) these. ngun (feminine plural) those. angor kwa: those (far off) women.kwa ka like this; similar to; as. kwa ka ya: like that feminine one (far off). kwa ka lo: like this one (masculine). kwapekwangin: like that. kwapekwana: just now. kwabo kwa: (of cows or women or feminine objects) there they are. kware at, in the night; during the night.abala lem eong ebe eco Oguti, kwabo mam: I always thought Oguti was clever, whereas he is not. kwabo nan: kwabo sek: whereas before. kwana1 (in demonstrating how something works) like this; in this way. kwanata: like this; thus. kwana2 now; nowadays; these days; at the moment; at present; in the present day. kwanata (in demonstrating how something works) like this; in this way; thus; as you will now read or hear; as follows. kwangal (imitative sound of a big metallic object falling on hard surface or a thin tall person falling awkwardly) clang; clank. kwangin (demonstrative pronoun) like that; thus; just so gratis; for nothing. kinyek kwangin: leave it just so, like that. kwapekwangin: like that. ape kwangin: (that is enough for you,) you can go now. aberu naka kwangin: an unmarried woman. alosit kwangin: to go naked; to go without. ainakin kwangin: to give for nothing. kwap down; below; underneath; beneath (followed by ka); on the ground or floor. ejai ngesi kwap ka emeesa: it is under or beneath the table. kokwap: on the ground; down there. mam ajeni nuiswamas kokwap kangina: I do not know what goes on down there. kwape how (followed by prepositional verb); like; as (in the job of). mam ajeni kwape iswamaere: I do not know how it is done. kiswama kwape ekotor ngesi: do as she/he wishes. mam ajeni kwape elosio: I do not know her/his travel plans (itinerary). kwape lem sek: as usual. kwape ka like; as. kwape kanu: like these ones. kwapekwa (demonstrative pronoun, feminine plural) those female things over there.kiwadik ebalua kwapekwana: write a letter just now. kwapekwangin like that; thus; just so. komat ijo da ajon kwapekwangin: you also take the beer as it is (without complaining). kwapuke underneath it; beneath it; below it. . yenikokwap: lokokwap: something below; somebody lower. kirai oni lukokwap kotoma aijen: our knowledge is of a low standard. elope akwap: an inhabitant; a native. kwatekwangin so much; that big; that much; that tall, etc. elwana kwatekwangin: is it that far? when it is that far!kwe kwe (I told you) again and again; (did I not tell you) now and again? kinyek akiro ngun kwe kwe: (I told you in vain to) stop those things. kweret nil; null; zero; nothing. kwi (demonstrative pronoun 3rd person plural masculine or diminutive) those yonder or over there; those far away. konyarau itelepai kwi kopotu: call those boys over there to come.elelebun amot kwic: the pot is very full; the pot is full to the brim.kwici kwic (to fill with a liquid, to block) completely, to the brim. elelebunos akipi opipa kwici kwic: the drum is completely full of water.kwii kwi (of a cough, breathing) noisy, wheezing. edeka ngol epaganga, ebala eola kwii kwi: that man has pulmonary tuberculosis, his cough wheezes.

(singular noun neuter) Quinquagesima (the Sunday before Lent). kwipekwi (demonstrative pronoun, masculine plural) those males over there. Iloke kwipekwi emeetos akituk: the Karimojong rustlers are just over there driving rustled cattle.
kwapekwa kyo kyot to finish completely; absolutely finished (used with adaun: to finish; airikar, anyamaar or amataar)
the tenth letter of the Ateso alphabet. laa extremely sweet
very delicious, nice. ejijim laa - very sweet ladalad (of movement of an invalid or a snake) wriggling; winding; snaky; twisting laije over there; that way.lali? (interrogative pronoun) where?
lailo lailo laije here and there; this way, that way
(noun neuter) the land of the Langi people

the present districts of Lira and Apac of northern Uganda. latak (the way a long soft thing or person falls) softly; soundlessly. abu emusaga kocakun kwap latak: the cobra fell down softly.lejelej (of cooked food) very soft; (of walking) very weakly; sluggish; without energy. akono akiring lejelej: the meat is thoroughly cooked. anapet naimanyimanyitai ejok ebala lejelej, mam iketerer: a well tanned hide used for carrying babies on the back is soft, it is not stiff. arai lem I wish she/he/it could; if only…(In wishes after arai, means only ‘would that’: arai lem kotep da: if only it rained: I wish it could rain) would; I wish that; I may that. lem eong kadum egaali da, ti ejok: I wish I could get a bicycle, it could be better. (note: lem is followed by subjunctive ‘kadum’) lem usually; hitherto; in the past. mam eroko ebuni, abunenenei lem sek: she/he does not come anymore, she/he used to come some time ago. mam lem enyamenenei, konye kwana enyami: she/he used not to eat, but now she/he eats. lengileng one only; one by itself; cut off; all alone; marooned. atwaka ikatunga kere, do eong bon ajai lengileng: all my people have died, I am left alone by myself. ler (of a pebble, to fall down or drop) once; singly.ebala akako lere ler edoenene kwap: one hears the rattling noise of hailstones falling.enokiete akimian kotaun lia lia: street lights shine bright in town. lis (of a spear or any pointed instrument piercing) through; from side to side; completely. aicum lis: to spear through. abu eong kecum etyang lis: I speared the animal through. litania (noun neuter) litany (a series of prayers or supplications with a response which is repeated several times by the congregation). lo1 (demonstrative masculine pronoun singular) this. lopelo (M): napena (F): this one. lokolo (M): nakolo (F): the one of old; the former one. lokolo kasonya (M): nakolo kasonya (F): the one of long ago. loti lo (M): nati na (F): this big one. lo2 (relative pronoun masculine) who; which.lo + noun: like. ekeri lotyang: she/he runs like an animal. lo + adjective: stands for definite article. akoto loepol: I want the big one. lo- prefix of derivative masculine nouns, implying ‘he who’; ‘that which’.loameton: he who drives animals. loangiirit: he who has gums. loatyonon: the difficult one. loameton a (cattle, livestock) driver. loangiirit a toothless man. loatyonon a difficult one; an awkward customer; the unbecoming one. lobonot a humble boy (man). loce (indefinite masculine pronoun) so and so.). loce ka (pronoun M) my companion; my comrade; my friend.loduc (used with masculine nouns) usual; ordinary; common. etunganan loduc: an ordinary man. ekingok loduc: a common village dog (that roams about). loebelel a person struck on the head with a stick. loebur a stout man; a plump, fat person or thing. loedakana a glutton. loekokolana thievish; kleptomaniac. loekupup a strong, able-bodied man. etelepat loekupup: an able-bodied boy. loemariana a grabber. loemenana a rebel; an insurgent; a mutineer; a radical; a revolutionary; a dissenter; a man who constantly disobeys. loemerana a drunkard;
