a sot. loemorono one who is fond of scolding, insulting, or offending others. loemudukana a blind one (man or animal).loengangatono one who is inclined to dally or waste time. loengolopana a man fond of quarrelling; a quarrelsome man. loeranga a gormandiser; a foodie; a glutton.loerurwon a raider; a rustler of livestock or other property; a robber. loesenyit a thin or emaciated man loesulyanyana the blessed or lucky one. loetirono a sprinter; a racer; a pacesetter. loetukuan one who makes another escape; a redeemer; a rescuer; a saviour. loetute one who is frivolous, restless, light-hearted, or thoughtless. loeworotoi (the invited) guest; the one who was invited or called. loewosikitai the one left over; a free man. loeyaara bon an independent person. loeyari deadly, mortal, lethal. aarenen: to kill continually; to kill often. logeet the first born; the one to begin with. kotoma akoik katotokos, Agwang Amoding nges akiyai, Apuda nges engoorit: Agwang Amoding is our mother’s eldest child, Apuda is the last-born.logela a stranger; a different person or thing; an alien.loibatisatai a baptised person.loicuma a man to be impaled (speared), pricked, stabbed, or injected. loicumum a man who is impaled (speared), pricked, stabbed, or inoculated. loideuna a leftover; the remnant.loiilonor a palsied man; a paralytic; one who keeps collapsing.loijoseono one who always pretends; a pretender; an impostor; a fraud; one who shams or is fond of shamming. ijoseono ekesa ngol adeka duc: that fellow always shams illness or pretends to be ill. loijunet (of a person, animals and plants) the barren; the degenerate; the sterile; to have very flat bums or buttocks. ikamomwa luijunetetas: my sorghum that is degenerate (no seeds, dried up, not pollinated). aberu ngin erai naijunet: that woman is barren. loikeara the arrogant, the conceited, the haughty, egotistical, proud; stuck up. loimono one who is satisfied. loimuuna one of the twins. loipinyana a man who is fond of overeating or gorging. loipoikino a married man (who they cook for). loiraruna a thing found or picked up; a foundling. loiryorono a garrulous man; one who talks much or chatters. loisinyeono a man who has the habit of being selfish, stingy, greedy, sensual, eager, or passionate. loisiorotot the straight one; the tall and slim one (person or tree). loiteregeg one with meningitis; a paralytic; a paraplegic. loitet the new one; the fresh one; the young one. koyau eikopo loitet: bring a new (clean) cup. papa loitetet: a new father of an asapan initiate. loiwangana a greedy man who eats food hot or half-cooked. loiwosatai a defendant; the accused. loka M of; naka F; yenika Dimin. . (possessive pronoun) loka, luka M: mine; naka, nuka F: mine; yenika, luka Dimin.: mine; lokon, lukon: yours (2nd person pronoun). Lokon obe: Yours sincerely; Yours truly. loke, luke M: his. lokosi, lukosi M: ours. lowok, luwok M: ours. lokus, lukus M: yours. lokec, lukec M: theirs. loka, loke M: with (adjective prefix for definite masculine article). loejok, lokajokan M: the good one. lokaanyiton superintendent; inspector. lokaaran a murderer; a killer. lokabeit the true one; one that is not fake or counterfeit. lokacekwap a stranger; an alien; a foreigner; outsider. lokacelan a shouter; a quarrelsome, irritable person.lokacoan a wise man; a wise person, a clever person.lokadakan a carrier; a porter; a carer (of children only).lokadedengan a severe, savage or cruel man or animal. lokadekan a patient; a sick or ill person, etclokadukon mason; builder; architect. lokadwaran a prophet; a soothsayer; a rainmaker; augur; clairvoyant. lokaelon a fornicator; an adulterer. aelo ijukanari lokaelon alosit aanyun akepese: a sudden sexual impulse prompts the lover to visit his girlfriend.lokagion (in the Roman Catholic church) a saint; a holy person; a perfect person; a paragon.lokagwelanaran merchant; seller; vendor; trader; dealer; broker; traitor; betrayer. lokajengan a butcher; a surgeon; a slaughterer; an operator. aijeng akoik: to have caesarean section; to have an abdominal operation. lokajokan the good one, etc lokajonon the unripe; the immature; the raw; the uncooked, etc. akiring na erai nakajonon, do bo akiring ya erai na ajono: this meat is raw but that meat is cooled (after cooking). lokalaunan the clean man; the holy man; a saint.lokalean one who beats; one who thrashes.lokaloton a pedestrian; a traveller, explorer, voyager, trekker, tourist; a passenger, or a commuter. lokamaranan a nervous person. lokamatan a drinker; the imbiber. lokamwanan a hot person or thing; a greedy man.lokapolon the big one; an adult; the important one; the master; the boss; the elder; the chief. lokapucon a peace-maker; a reconciler; a host; an arbiter. lokaraan (one) always bearing fruit; one who or which is prolific. lokasaban a liar; a fraud; a charlatan; a traditional healer with dubious methods. lokasalan abider; absentee truant; one who stays behind; one left behind; a remnant. lukasalak: remnants. lokasenyan a man or boy who is becoming thin; one whose body is wasting away; an AIDS sufferer or patient. lokasuat of iron; of steel; metallic. asaduku nakasuat: a metallic casket; a safe; a coffer; a strongbox. ibore yenikasuat: a thing made of iron, steel, or metal. lokasuban the creator; the maker; the manufacturer. Edeke Lokasuban: God the Creator. lokasurup an enemy; a foe; an adversary; an antagonist; an opponent; a disputant. ejai ngesi asurup ka je: there is a feud between her/him and the other man. akerit asurup: to escape vengeance (run away from enemies). lokatapon a leper; a man who has leprosy. lokateranet of honeymoon; nuptial; conjugal; marital. lokatitingon a brave man; a courageous man; a hero; a daredevil.lokatubon a judge; an arbiter; a cutter; a referee; an umpire; a magistrate; a butcher. lokatubon akiro: an arbiter; an umpire. lokatubon imusaagon: a magistrate; a judge. lokatwan the dead one. lukatwak: the dead. lokawoon the singer; a vocalist; a bard. loke (personal pronoun masculine used subjectively) his, hers, its. erai ngesi loke: it/he is hers/his (property). lokebeele spreader of rumours; rumour-monger; mischief-maker; one who causes strikes or blows. lokebit the greedy one, an avaricious man; an egoistic man. lokecanicanan a sinner; a transgressor; a destroyer. lokeciran the milker; a milkman.lokecokon a herdsman: lokecokon akituk; a sheperd: lokecokon amerekekin. lokeibel the greedy one, etc. lokekaan a game hunter, a seeker; a persecutor, a tormentor, a bully, an oppressor, or an intimidator. lokekolo an adversary; an opponent; a rival. lokelocon an interpreter; an exchanger. lokelocon apeesan: money changer. lokemunet a cheeky, foolish, or troublesome man. lokenyangan an avenger; a man who is spiteful; a retaliator; a nemesis. lokepitina an envious or jealous one. lokepoon a cook; a chef.lokepugan a ruler; a governor; a head of state; a monarch; a sovereign. lokepyedan a harbinger (of bad omen); a witch. lokeranga a gourmand; food-lover; glutton.lokesiecan one who exchanges; a money-changer. lokesigalikinan an assistant; a helper; an aide. lokesosoloi a hypocrite. loketatamanakinan a story-teller; a narrator; a novelist; a minstrel. lokewadikan a writer; a clerk, a scribe. lokewongo a boaster; a braggart; an attention-seeker or a vaunting man. lokewongon a boaster; a braggart; a spoilt brat. lokeworoton the host (the invitee). lokewosan a plaintiff; a petitioner; the accuser. loki- masculine prefix forming ordinal numbers greater than one (1); prefix of masculine derivative nouns formed from verbs, adjectives or other nouns, implying “one with” a specified characteristic. lokiareit: the second. lokiuniet: the third. lokibakor (formed from the noun ‘ibakor’ – poverty) one with poverty; a destitute man; a poor man; a beggar. lokibakor a destitute man; a poor man; a beggar. ateker naka Iteso arau nakibakor akaulo naka ejie lokokaru 1987 toni 2003: the Teso people have become impoverished as a result of the 1987-2003 wars. lokicaru a mad fellow; a fierce person. lokikerep a mad man; a lunatic; a maniac. lokiliokit male or like a man. lokiloset something for washing (like a basin or soap). akoto esabuuni lokiloset igoen: I want soap for washing clothes. lokitomonet (ordinal number) the tenth. elap lokitomonet: the tenth month; October. lokituritono a praiseworthy man. lokiyai the first born.lokokau the man behind; the latter thing. lokokitono a friend; a protégé; a prisoner (to be guarded well). lokolic a man having red or white spots on the skin. lokoputuke (in Karamoja) a species of bird, Fork-tailed drongo. lokori (cattle, cloth, a hen) striped; variegated. lokos very big; huge; enormous; gigantic; mammoth; immense. Elgon erai emoru lokos: Elgon is a massive mountain. etom erai etyang lokos: an elephant is a huge animal. edukit ngesi etogo lokos: she/he has built a very big house.lokou (in Karamoja) an epileptic. lokowai husband; the one at the side. nakowai: a wife. lokowaike her husband. lolenger a circumcised man. lolo today. lolong a good-for-nothing person; a beggar, a hobo, a vagabond, or a tramp. lolukum (of hut, bowl, etc) round; circular. etogo lolukum: a round hut. lominat the beloved one; the favourite one; the dear one. lomonuk a well-fed person; a big bellied man.longinam a man without teeth.longolong in the long past; once upon a time.lonyadak the dirty one. loongor (of colour of fur, feathers) dark brown. looreet the one in front. looreeteka: one in front of me. lope practically. lopelo (demonstrative masculine pronoun) this is he; this is the very man (spoken about); this is the one (you want).lopepitelo nges akoto eong: this is the very kind I want.lopeponelo this very kind, category or type.lopetai worthless; useless. etunganan lopetai: a useless man. lopeti M huge; very big; important; gigantic; enormous; colossal. erot lopeti: the highway; a long journey.lopus purple grey. lopus kakou: one with grey hair. loropat a hireling; a paid servant. lorudang one with a narrow head. loruped a man with small buttocks. loseny a grass, Rhynchelytrum repens. losiorot the straight one; the tall and slim one (person or tree).lotai commonplace; the ordinary. etelepat lotai: a useless boy. nepetai: at all; just a little; at least. lotesot of or pertaining to Teso, its culture and people. emaido lotesot: a Teso (variety of) groundnut. lotikaojan a giant; a tall man. lowai this side; this way.lu a) (demonstrative pronoun, masculine plural) these. itunga lu: these people; you people. kesi lu: these are the ones.na, ngun, kwa F b) lu forms numerals after multiples of ten. itomon kaluongon: fourteen. akaisaare kalukany M: twenty five (men). c) lu is relative pronoun, masculine plural. lukajokak: (those) who are good. luakapanakin equipment; tools; kit or utensils (for soldiers or a feast or journey, etc).ludeman the spoils; the loot; the booty. ludu lud (to block up, to seal, to fill) completely, to the brim.luedeunos those left over. luegituna things separated, kept apart or back, put aside. sirikiyanga iboro ngul luegituna: do not take away those things put aside. lukapan equipment; kit; gear; tools; utensils; apparatus; paraphernalia. lukateker relatives (both close and distant); extended family.lukatinenikwana the present generation. lukawook singers, a choir. lukecor fish (in general). lukiraa crops (in general).lumanyet dowry. ijaatar ijo kede ibaren lumanyet?: do you have cattle to give as dowry? lumiduna food (literally, those which are licked).

Lucifer.lwaru a corruption of rwaru: in future; in the distant future; some day far off. lyo (of a place or home) very desolate; empty; deserted. esil etogo lyo: the house is quite empty (nobody lives inside). esil ere lo lyo: this home is deserted completely.
(noun neuter) the eleventh letter of the Ateso alphabet. ma used to express a threat or astonishment

also used to express a request ‘please’. ngai ca ma etunganan lo?: by the way, who on earth is this man? bia ma jo: please, do come. maa (of a nice smell) aromatic; nice; spicy. eur edia maa: the vegetables smell nice, spicy. asabuunyu naeur maa: an aromatic soap. akinyet natuanaret naeur maa: this smearing oil has aromatic. maaba ka (noun neuter) my friend, companion, comrade. maaba, awar akwap kaloto: my friend, it is dark let us go. maaba! say; by the way. maaba! ai ilosi ijo?: I say, where are you going? madak (to step, sit, or do) dirtily or in a dirty way; with muck; filthily. abu ngesi kiboikin madak oicolongoka: she/he sat on my chair dirty as she/he was. mam no; not; nay. mam ajeni: I do not know. mam adis: not even a little. mam ca: of course not; not at all. mam bobo: never again; no longer; no more. mam nepecep da: not at all; not in the least; on no account; never. komame: and there was none. (note that mam is used with adjectives and verbs, but with nouns and adverbs, use mere; with imperative, use siri) mere ijo, mere ejakait: not you, not the chief. mere kwangin: not like that. sirikilip: do not beg.eebo, eeba. mam ber not yet.mama over there; towards; yonder. kolot mamaejai papakon: go to your father. koyanga nges mama: take it there. mamai maternal uncle; the brother of one’s mother; (an Ateso reference to) a Karimojong. (note: paternal uncle is papa).
(noun neuter) (archaic) Monday.mapekon just to you. abunit mapekon: I have come just to you (nowhere else). mati so far

as far as; perhaps. mati Ngora kibunio ijo: perhaps you came from Ngora? alosi eong mati Ngora: I am going far, as far as Ngora. mee (noun neuter) (of a goat, to) bleat; the sound of a goat; (to a child) a goat.merrr: the sound of a sheep. mere no; not; neither; it is not. Used: a) before nouns: mere ejakait ebunit: it is not the chief who has come. b) before pronouns: mere ijo: it is not you. c) before adverbs: mere kwangin: not like that. mere nat: not later. d) before subjunctive: mere kalot, mere kolot: let me (her/him) go. mere ber: wait a bit; a moment. mere noi: not at all; not much (words you say to someone who has just said "eyalama noi" - thank you very much).Also note: mam – not - is used for verbs and adjectives; siri – not - is used only in imperative and subjunctive: mam alosi: I shall not go. mam ejok: it is not good. sirikilot: do not go. merrr (noun neuter) (of a sheep, to) bleat; the bleating of a sheep; (to a child) a sheep.buua: the sound of a cow. miyot miyot (noun neuter) (of a chick, to) peep; cheep; the cry of a chick; (to a child) a chick.kutu kut: the sound of a breeding hen. moding in, from, at the wilderness; from the wild or bush. Mohamed ekadwaran Prophet Mohammed (the founder of Islam). moi tomorrow; soon; the near future. moi kace: the day after tomorrow; the near future. moolo in the distant future. abuni moolo: I shall come later on.mot slowly; softly; lightly. motimot: slowly; carefully; little by little. motimot slowly; carefully; little by little; bit by bit; fifty-fifty (in reply to a greeting ‘Ijai biai – how are you?’).ilosi ijo muliamulia: you walk like a lame person. emun elosi muliamulia: ebala emun muliamulia elosi: the snake moves in a wriggling manner.musi perhaps; suppose. musi bo je kobu, ikwaikini bo jo ai?: suppose he comes, what will you do? musi ebuni: perhaps she/he will come. musiki perhaps; suppose; maybe. musiki bo je kobu, ikwaikini bo jo ai?: suppose he comes, what will you do? musiki ebuni: maybe she/he will come. mutan (noun) so-and-so; somebody; someone (man or woman). mwadamwad (to do or to act) like a blind person. mwekemwek (to be) dazzling; twinkling; glittering. ebala angolol paran mwekemwek: the lake dazzles at noon.ebala aacerit mwemwe: the star is twinkling.
Naebalaasa mape mama just there; that place

adverbial prefix indicating time or place or relative clause ‘where’ or ‘when’. Where - mam ajeni neejai ngesi: I do not know where she/he is. When - neelosio ngesi: when she/he goes. n-2 prefix before feminine parts of speech: naberu: female or feminine

naejok: a good (woman) -n suffix of participles or agents (M or F) - ekajenan: a witness; lokajokan: a good one; ekamejan: a hunter. (note that in plural this -n changes into –k: ikamejak). n the twelfth letter of the Ateso alphabet. na feminine demonstrative pronoun singular, na: this. aberu na: this woman. natina: nasina: this (big or fat) one. It is also a suffix forming feminine nouns and adjectives of definite articles - aberu nakajokan: the good woman. aberu naejok: a good woman. Also forms the preposition ‘of’ for feminine nouns: aberu naka ejakait: the wife of the chief. -na- infix to verbs indicating repeated action or reciprocal action: ailipanakin: to beg or pray often for somebody else. eminanara: they love one another. (note that many verbs have –no- instead of –na- infix, adukonokin, ekotonoro: they like one another). naarai because; on account of; for that reason. irono ijo naarai ibitiono: you are bad because you are greedy. kanu naarai: because of; as a result of something. nabarai seeing that; considering that; since; because; on account of. nabarai imamei ijo, mam eong da abuni: because you are absent, I am also not coming. abunit eong kanuka emong, nabarai ijo kitumunit eong: I come for the bull, because you promised me.nabonot a humble girl. nadote a whore; a prostitute. naduc (used with feminine nouns) usual; ordinary; common. aberu naduc: an ordinary woman. akingok naduc: a common village bitch. naemanyany a married woman.naerimon a prostitute (mobile lover); a one night stand; a vagabond; a truant.loesidounon: midman; birth attendant. -nai a verbal suffix to change certain –un verbs to first person imperatives implying a request. adakun: to lift and put down; kodakunai: lift me off, please. alakun: to redeem; kolakunai: redeem me, please. naidedet a pustule. ekotos ajimi aidede kakuwanaka: my body is developing sores (or wounds). idedet eong akuwan: I have pustules. naideuna a leftover; the remaining.naitet the new one; the fresh one; the young one. koyau asaanit naitet: bring a new (clean) plate. toto naitetet: a new mother of an asapan initiate. nakaanyiton superintendent; inspector. nakagion (in the Roman Catholic church) a saint; a holy lady; a sanctified female thing.erai ngin akirot nakakwena: that is a funny statement (utterance). nakasaan a nursemaid; a maid servant. nakasaan idwe a baby-sitter. nakasenyan a woman or girl who is becoming thin; one whose body is wasting away; an AIDS sufferer or patient. nakatipet urgent; immediate; sudden; quick. atwanare nakatipet: a sudden death. abongokinet nakatipet: a quick answer; a retort.nakatumunan a young girl of 14–16 years; an adolescent girl. nake (possessive pronoun singular F) his, hers, its (used with feminine nouns). nakeburunan an adolescent girl (with breasts just developing). nakec (possessive pronoun singular F) theirs (used with feminine nouns) nakejaanakinan a maid servant; a waitress; a housegirl. nakekal a housewife. adumunit eong nakekal: I have got a wife or I am married. arai eong lokekal: I am married or I am a man with a family of my own. idumunit ijo ekal?: are you married? nukekal: connubial, marital, or conjugal issues. adeka nakekal: a hereditary or inherited disease. nakepoon a cook; a chef; cordon bleu. nakerimon a prostitute (mobile lover); a one night stand; a sex worker; a vagabond; a truant.naki- feminine prefix for ordinal numbers. nakiareit: the second; Tuesday.ateker naka Iteso arau nakibakor akaulo naka ejie lokokaru 1987: the Teso people have become impoverished as a result of the 1987 war. nakitoi wooden. amuka nukito: sandals; sabots; clogs. nakitomonet (ordinal number) the tenth. akiteng nakitomonet: the tenth cow. nakokal a house wife (literally, the woman of the home). nakokaleke: his wife. nakokaleka: my wife. nakokalekon: your wife. nakon (used in closing letter, possessive pronoun singular F) yours. nakon da reply to the greeting: yoga aswam: meaning ‘the same to you’, when replying to one person.(note: nakus da is used when replying to more than one person). nakowaike his wife (literally, the one on his side). nalangiron a pregnant woman or animal (literally, the heavy one). aberu nalangiron: a pregnant woman (literally, the heavy woman). nama a corruption of mama: over there. namaka: at my home; to me. namanam (of insects falling on) in a crowd; in swarms. apotu icuc namanam toma ajimi: the flies settled on the wound in swarms. naminat the beloved one or favourite one; the dear one. namiyot a darling; a dear heart; a sweetheart. nan a moment ago; a moment earlier; a while ago (3 or 4 hours ago, today); a short time ago. alot nan ngesi: she/he went off a short time ago.nan sek sometime ago; sometime earlier; earlier today; a short time ago. alot ngesi nan sek: she/he went off sometime ago.nangiirit a toothless woman. nape as soon as; no sooner…than. nape ekwenyuni toto kocalaar ikoku: no sooner had the mother woken up than the baby yelled. napena (demonstrative pronoun F) this very one. adolunike da ngesi napena: she/he has also just arrived. napus purple grey (used of females). napus kakou: a female with purple-grey hair. naranar (of the earth, underfoot) shaking; vibrating; quivering; shuddering; juddering; pulsating; throbbing; trembling. ebala akwap naranar ireta edou: the earth shakes when rain thunders.
suffix of certain verbs or nouns - atwanare: to die (verb, singular)

death . atwakare: to die (verb, plural). nasodit the first one. nat soon; soon after; later. idumuni nat: you will get it soon. nat kwana now. nat kwapekwana: just now; this minute. ajai ngesi ne nat kwapekwana: she/he was here just now. nat bo: afterwards. nat ebong: this evening or afternoon. nat kuare: tonight. nat sek sometime soon; sometime later. idumuni nat sek: you will get it later. nata this female here (emphatic); this one here. erai ngesi nata: it/she is this one here (no one else). naticokom (only said of meat) nice; juicy. akiring naticokom: a juicy piece of meat. natupat a precept; a rule; a guideline; an instruction; a principle. ne ka ngina here and there; about; to or in many places. ne here. neka: my place, home where I am; to me, my part.nekon: your place, your home, where you are; to you. alosi eong nekon: I am going to your home. ne lem the former place; the usual place; the ordinary place. alosi ne lem sek ajai: I am going to my usual abode or residence. abunit eong kane lem: I come from the usual place. ne syo ours; our (noun neuter) (euphemism) genitals (a term used by men only talking to women, or women only talking to men). edeka ngesi ne syo: she/he is having a problem with our bodies, or she/he has a genital infection (the listener is of opposite sex). ne oni ours; our (noun neuter) (euphemism) genitals (a term used by men only talking to men, or women only talking to women). edeka ngesi ne oni: she/he is having a problem with our bodies, or she/he has a genital infection (the listener is of opposite sex). ne oni nges ebunitor ngesi: she/he comes from ours (home) (inclusive of listener). nediat (singular noun neuter) (in a game of archery or marksmanship) a bull’s-eye; a targeted point. nedidio nearly; almost; a little. nedidio ti ketwana: she/he nearly died. nediocici nearby; close by; a little away; awhile. kinyamarai ber eong nediocici: accompany me a short distance. kopaik ber nediocici: stay awhile. nediokasilon (noun Dimin.) a little time or distance. neejaas where there are; where they are. neejai where there is; where she/he/it is. negwelanaret (singular noun neuter) a marketplace; a selling place; a shop; a bazaar. negwelet (singular noun neuter) a marketplace; a buying place; a shop; a bazaar.agola naisidoere angor: a labour room.neisidounet (singular noun F) a maternity; a labour ward; a delivery room.kibwaik nges nen: put it there. etia nen: it is as big as that; they are that many; it is like that. ikote nen: it is like that. ikote akiro nen: that is that; that is so. ekote nen: things were like that; they were thus or so; it was thus. nen ta there (you are); that is the place. nen nen: there there; it is here; over there. nenice elsewhere (noun neuter) alibi; a defence; explanation; excuse. kanenice: from somewhere else; from elsewhere. kanenice: and partly. kanenice inera ngesi Ateso, kanenice inera amo: he talks partly Ateso and partly a Bantu tongue. nenidio…ti almost; nearly. nenipe together; jointly. elosete kesi nenipe: they go together. nepe while (doing something); whilst; as soon as; where. nepe abala keswama: as I was about to do. nepe ilosi ijo kodoluni ngesi: as soon as you went she/he arrived. nepe kuare: during the night; at night. nepe sek: very early. nepecep: not in the least; not at all. itunganan yen ekalanyana mam edumuni isirigin ka nepecep da: a lazy person will not get my money, to say the least. nepe eroko ber: before. nepe eroko ber akwap iwalara: before dawn. nepe lem: at least. nepe lem aideun ajon adicar da: at least a little beer should have been left. nepecep da not in the least; not at all. mam ijo kitelekaari eong nepecep da: you will not defeat me, not in the least. nepene right here. kanepekane: here and now; forthwith; just now. konyam kanepekane: eat it here and now. nepenen right there; that very spot; that very point or place. kikote nepenen: let it be thus; so be it; Amen. kikote nepenen?: were they like that? kilipi ngun kere kokiror loka Yesu Kristo ekosijakait, kikote nepenen: we pray all that in the name of Jesus Christ our Lord, Amen. nepepe together (with); in one place. kere nepepe: all together; everyone or everything at the same time. nepepe ka: together with. kopotu Ikilai nepepe ka Ikiror: let Ikilai come together with Ikiror.nepetai slightly; lightly; nearly; only a little; a short while; approximately. nepetai ti eong kebiror: I nearly fell down; I almost failed exams. kinyek nepetai: wait a little. kebap ngesi eong nepetai: she/he hit me slightly. mam nepetai da: not at all; not in the least. nepetai: a little; not in the least. nepetai ti kikamun ijo ikokoi: you were almost caught red-handed stealing. nes1 that is why; that is where; that is how; therefore. nes alosio eong: that is why I go; therefore I go. Ngora nes abunitor eong: I come from Ngora (from nowhere else?). moi nes alosio eong: I will be going tomorrow. (note: nes is followed by a relative prepositional verb) nes2 (personal pronoun 3rd person singular, used as object) him; her; it. ajeni eong nes: I know him (her, it).nesi (personal pronoun third person singular, used as subject) the person spoken of: him, her, it (subjects). ejeni nesi nges: she/he knows her/him. nesi: it is she/he. nesi eong: I am (he is) the one.-net suffix of certain derived masculine and feminine nouns. acodunet: a temptation; a spike. epeleunet: a thing for starting, repeating or for initiating. neta here (emphatic); this place. ejai neta: it is here (nowhere else). neti nen that much; all that long; all that far. etia neti nen: it is that big. ngai epedori aswam naetia neti nen?: who can manage so big a task? ketemasi neti nen: and that is what they said. neti kolo ngina: it is a long time since. neti kolo kaanyunitor eong ijo ngina, eapie?: is it not a long time ago since I saw you? newois (singular noun neuter) a place for singing; a choir loft.

ng (noun neuter) the thirteenth letter of the Ateso alphabet. ngai? (interrogative pronoun) who? whom? lokangai? (nakangai F) whose? ngai ma ngol (ngin)?: by the way, who is that? ingai bo jo?: who are you? loce or olongai or inangai (indefinite pronoun) so-and-so

the aforesaid. ngalakimak (singular noun F) the south. ngany (to refuse) altogether, absolutely. agir ngesi abunere ngany: she/he refused to come absolutely. ngaoi a cry of a wild cat. ebala atawoi ngaoi ngaoi: the wild cat cries ngaoi, ngaoi. nges atemar that is (to say); 'id est'. nges (personal pronoun 3rd person singular used as an object) him; her; it. akoto eong nges: I like it/her/him.ngesi (personal pronoun 3rd person singular used as a subject) he; she; it. ebuni ngesi: she/he/it will come.ngil (of pain, to be) sharp, pricking. ebala akakoik ngil: I feel a sharp pain in my stomach. ngilingil (of pain, to be) acute, aching. ebala akeju ngilingil: my foot aches. ngin (demonstrative pronoun F and Dimin. singular) that one; whoever; every; each. nginiberu: every woman; each woman. mam akoto ngin: I do not want that (female) one. ngipengin: that very (female) one . kwangin: like that; therefore. kwapekwangin: like that; that is right. kwangin naked; without; just like that. elosi ngesi kwangin: she/he goes naked or nude. abu ngesi kwangin: she/he has come empty-handed. nginice: the other (female) one. nginiibois: everywhere; every place. nginitunganan: everybody (neuter). nginibore: everything. nginidiope: each one. nginipaarit: always; everyday. nginituan: everybody; everyone; each one. (note that ngin: every, is followed by the infix -i-, which stands for the noun prefixes e-, a-, i- in the three noun gender classes M, F, and neuter/Dimin. respectively). ngina over there; yonder. kolototo ngina abolia: go over there to play. ngio (to sleep) deeply; soundly. ajotoor ngesi ngio: she/he is sound asleep. ngipengin(used to refer to feminine, neuter, and diminutive pronouns) that very one. ngipengin: that (very female) one over there. ngipengina just over there; that very location. ngiuu a cry of a cat. ebala ikapa ngiuu: the cat wauls. ngo long ago nil. ngo kolo in the olden times. kolo apengo: once upon a time.ngo ngo very long ago. ngodial on to, towards, the left.ngol demonstrative adjective and pronoun, masculine singular: that; each; every. ngopengol: that very (male) one. ngolitunganan: each or every man. ngolimoro: every time; always; every day. ngolidiope: each (male) one. (note that ngol and ngin: each, are followed by the infix -i-: nginiberu, ngolitunganan, nginikoku). ngolimoro always; everyday.ngomongom (to eat or devour) greedily; voraciously; ravenously; quickly. enyami ekingok ngomongom: ebala ekingok enyami ngomongom: ebala ekingok ngomongom enyami: the dog eats quickly and greedily. ngoon yesterday but one. ngoon kace: the day before yesterday.ngopengol (masculine singular demonstrative adjective and pronoun) that very man; that is the man. ngorob (imitation of a dog eating something hard, but with the mouth open) crunch; chomp; munch. ebala ekingok iboiboi akoit ngorob ngorob: the dog crushes bones noisily.itunga ngul: those people not far away. (suffix) every; all (used with plural masculine nouns). ngulutunga: each group of people. ngupengul: those very men or males or groups.elosi ngesi ngularangular: she/he walks in a crippled manner (as a maimed person). ngun (demonstrative adjective and pronoun feminine plural) those. angor ngun: those women. (suffix) every (followed by a plural feminine noun). ngunupesur: every group or crowd of girls. kanukangun on account of that; that being so; for that reason; therefore. ngunu da: those also. ngupengul (demonstrative adverb and pronoun masculine plural) those (emphatic); those are the very ones. eraas ngupengul ikokolak: those are the very thieves, no other. ngupengun (demonstrative adverb and pronoun feminine plural) those (emphatic); those very ones. ngupengun F: those are the very ones. ngupengun edolitor ijo alosit: that is the very reason why you should go. ngurub (imitation of a person eating something hard, but with the mouth shut) crunch; chomp; munch. ejo, ipupete yesi Ilok ebakasi emuogo ngurub ngurub kokinga?: listen, do you hear the Karimojong thieves chomping fresh cassava tubers outside?

Noël tide. noi very much; extremely. noi noi: very, very much. kakoto ijo noi noi: I like or I want or I love you very much.-noi a verbal suffix to change certain –un verbs to first person imperatives implying a request (not an order). awoun: to put down a load from someone’s head; kowounoi: lift this load off my head, please. awomun: to come for; kowomunoi: come for me, please. -nokin a verbal suffix denoting a repetitive action away from the speaker. awotokin: to lift onto (once only); awotonokin: to keep lifting and loading onto (people’s heads – many times). aremokin: to push or plunge into (once only); aremonokin: to keep pushing or plunging into (often). nono nude; naked; undressed. alosit nono: to move about naked or undressed.
a suffix of certain verbs used with singular or plural nouns respectively – adau egoe aonore: the dress is dry

adautu igoen aokore: the clothes are dry. adau emuebe atyonore: the mango is mature; adautu araito atyokore: the fruits have matured. adau eupa ajonore: the fireplace is cold; adautu acok ajokore: the potatoes have cooled. adau epapaali akonore: the pawpaw is ripe; adautu ipapaalin akokore: the pawpaws have ripened. nu1 (demonstrative pronoun feminine plural of na) these. angor nu: these women. akinei nu: these goats. nu- (relative pronoun feminine plural of na) who; which. angor nuabala eong kesi nu: the women I talked about are these. nu nan: the aforesaid. nu2 (used with relative prepositional verbs to imply) the reason why. nuakotor eong alosit kes nu: the reason why I want to go is this. nuabekoi unconfirmed news; rumours. nuegeete preface; foreword. nuejaas toma table of contents; contents (of a book). nuelomunete consequences; results; outcomes; effects. nuelosikinitai objectives; aims; purposes; intentions. nueumokina wonders; miracles. nuibwaa mysteries; secrets; anonymity; hidden matters. nuitogogongete supporting evidence; corroborating evidence. nuka1 (1st person possessive feminine pronoun plural of naka) mine. akinei ngun eraas nuka: those goats are mine. nuka2 concerning; on account of; therefore; consequently. kanukinyo?: why? kanukangun: for that reason; consequently. kanuka akiro nuka bian: concerning yesterday’s matters. ekoto einer ka jo nuka aingito kon: she/he wants to talk to you about your exams. nuka3 (F plural of naka) of. angor nuka ejakait: the women of the chief. nuka- (prefix to feminine plural adjectives) angor nukapolok: the principal women; ladies. nukabe rumours. nuabe: rumours; nonsense. akiro nuabeak: the truth. nukabeit the truth. nuke (third person possessive feminine pronoun plural of nake) his/hers/its. akokoroi ngun eraas nuke: those chickens are his/hers. nukec (third person possessive feminine pronoun plural of nakec) theirs. apopongo ngun eraas nukec: those guns are theirs. nukisisianakina moral lesson; the teaching; instructional material; drills; tenets; philosophy. nukisisianakina nuka akelesia: the teachings of the Roman Catholic church (literally, the things taught by the Roman Catholic church). nukisuduno caprice; vagary; whimsical acts; impulsive actions. nukon (2nd person possessive feminine pronoun plural of nakon) yours. apungurei ngun eraas nukon: those logs are yours. nukos (1st person possessive feminine pronoun plural of nakos) ours (excluding the person addressed). aperito ngun eraas nukos: those beds are ours (you excluded). nukus (2nd person possessive feminine pronoun plural of nakus) yours. aperito ngun eraas nukus: those beds are yours. -nut a suffix of intransitive verbs and feminine verbal nouns implying tendencies. anyamanut: to be fond of eating all the time. akukuranut: (adjectival feminine noun from ekukurana) diligence; efficiency; hardwork. aipit: to breed animals or plants; aipitanut: to be fond of rearing animals. nutiok the big ones. koyau amor nutiok: bring big stones.nuwok (1st person possessive feminine pronoun plural of nawok) ours (including the person addressed). asaanin ngun eraas nuwok: those are our plates (those plates are for me and you). naka: (possessive pronoun feminine singular of nuka) mine. nakon, nake, nakec, nakus: yours, her/his/its, theirs, yours. naka: that; of (for feminine nouns) aberu naka Orena: Orena’s wife. nwom emptily; vacantly; vacuously. anyamaar nwom: to swallow at once (like nothing was ever put in the mouth).
ny (noun neuter) the fourteenth letter of the Ateso alphabet. nyakoi (noun neuter) the north in the north

northern; northerly. nyalanyal (of the skin sensations) creepily. ebala eong akiring nyalanyal: I have a creepy feeling; I feel my flesh creep.abu ikapa yen etwanit kodacun kwap nyilak: the dead cat fell down softly. nyong look! there!nyudunyud (of people or animals moving together, or of fire burning slowly) at close quarters; head to tail
rikirik, nyilak (of a soft or furry thing falling or getting cut) softly; soundlessly

o exclamation of wonder or disgust.o-1 prefix forming locative cases - ore: at home. okitoi: in or on the tree. osamai: in the swamp. o-2 prefix of prepositional nouns. ore: at home. osomero: at, to, in the school. otunga: in, among, towards people. oboro: in, among things o-3 prefix of some masculine proper names - Okinei : Mr. Goat. Opus : Mr. Purple-grey. Otaupe : Mr. Hot-heart the greedy one. Okurut : Mr. Maggot, Mr. Caterpillar, etc. Okiring: Mr. Meat, Beef, or Flesh. -o1 suffix of passive infinitives. adukio: to be built. -o2 suffix of verbs in -or singular, 3rd person singular, 1st person singular, plural indicative. kilimo ngesi ijo: she/he told on you

she/he reported you. -o3 suffix to some verbs and nouns in -kin, -kino: - adukokino: marriage. o the fifteenth letter of the Ateso alphabet; a vowel letter as in ‘owl’. obaet at dawn. obar to, at, from outside field or village. alosit obar: to go to the toilet. obe (indefinite pronoun) own; proper; sincerely; truly; true. eong lokon obe: (when ending letters) I am yours truly. aiboisit kon obe: your real or proper home address. obe the real one. ngesi obe: she/he/it herself/himself/itself. kesi obe: they themselves. akekiro obe: her/his actual words; verbatim. obebera (usually used with negative connotations) initiator; instigator; originator; one who hurries ahead of others. obeet (formerly) a variety of millet and potatoes. obilibil joint pain; mild arthritis. obonipe one who lives alone; childless person; hermit. obwabu a man as poor as a dog. ocailap (formerly) a variety of sweet potatoes.ocigicig gout (a disease of the blood that causes painful swelling of the joints); athlete’s foot. ocole (formerly) a variety of cassava. ocookonye a man with lustful eyes; enfant terrible; a very curious person, always looking about.
okwe, okwe toto, otukwi, ooi, u uu
September (literally, the month of plentiful cow urine used in butter-making).odiiri (formerly) a variety of cowpeas.odikisyonari in, to or from a dictionary

of a glossary; in, to or from a lexicon. odood (of a person’s movement) awkwardly; clumsily; (of sound of the beating of the jugular artery) throbbing; lub-dub. ekeri ngesi odood: ebala ngesi odood ekeri: she/he runs in an awkward way.oduk a tree in the ekimeng and ekulony family, Combretum molle, whose leaves or roots are a cough remedy. In Usuk it is known as ekwooro.
Otibar odidi a species of bird, black-faced waxbill, Cordon bleu
April (literally, the month of smouldering fires and cloudy skies, plentiful rains and flying ants – adunge). oduu (noun neuter) a scrub hare, Lepus saxatilis. odwaratau a hot-tempered man

a suicidal man; a suicide bomber (like the Palestinian or Iraqi resistance fighters). odwomen a glutton; gormandiser. ogangarakou one with a big head; a fat-head (as a term of abuse) ogaria a pigmy kingfisher; a large, fish-eating bird of prey with a brown back, and brown and white underparts, Osprey. ogeana (biblical) in, to, belonging to Hell. ogiegio a species of fish, Heterobranchus. ogogolo (formerly) a variety of big-seeded cowpeas.ogoloi (singular noun M) gonorrhoea or any disease of the urinary system. ogurememe a greedy person; a glutton; a foodie; a gastronome; a food-lover; a gourmand; a greedy-guts.oi exclamation of pain. oi to: oi toto!: exclamation of ‘dear me’. oidoolei a knicker; pants; underwear.oitolima on the river bank; on the lake-shore.

God the Good One. ojokokan a good rich man; a benefactor; a donor; the giver (good hand). ojokotau a kind-hearted man; a charity or aid organisation. ekorete iriongeta lukojokotau ikerai iperito kede inyamat kokaabin luko Teso: aid organisations (such as Action-Aid, Lutheran World Federation, Oxfam) distribute clothing and food to the internally displaced people in camps in Teso. okaleka at my house; in my family. enyamenenei ngesi kokaleka: she/he often eats at my home. okapet a grass, Brachiaria. okejukusa a bat-eared fox (believed to portend death in the family when it barks in the vicinity), Otocyon megalotis.okekwa the other side of river or valley. okekwa juwai: okekwa je: on the next hill; on the other side of the river. okelo a boy born after twins. okeper abreast; shoulder to shoulder; on, at the shoulder. okewas (singular noun M) black quarter – a disease of cattle akin to rinderpest. okidia the country to the east. okinei (formerly) a variety of reddish sorghum. okiru a bee-eating bird.okituk1 a grass, Bothriochloa glabra. okituk2 a big-mouthed man; a cantankerous person; a big liar. okitwi in the jungle; in the bush; in the high grass. alomar okitwi: to wage a guerrilla war. okok a species of fish - Bagruss.okoku a son; a male child. the son of (a person specified). okoku oduk: a son for posterity. okoku koduk (singular noun M) so-and-so; somebody; everybody. ayangaa okoku koduk ekagaali: somebody has taken my bicycle.okoku kojokotau son of a good-hearted father. okoku kalukojokotau: son of good-hearted parents. okoku oduk children of Teso; son for posterity; children of men (exclamation of praise for one providing for the future).okokuka my son. okoleji at, in, to the college. alomasi apesur aisiom okoleji: girls have gone to study in college.e. who has left boyhood for manhood. okori one who goes about to finish meal remnants from other people’s plates.okuk a species of fish, Bagruss.
a name of a man. okutukut an African black and white horn-bill.

March (literally, the month of the grey skin, because of dust from preparing fields and also due to the fact that food is getting scarce after the long dry season and the beginning planting season). okwangole (a nick-name for) a very thin man or animal. okwaras1 a shrub used for smallpox wounds, Acacia pennata. okwaras2 (singular noun M) a plant from which salt is extracted, Aspilia kotschyi. okwe (interjection of shock or entreaty) please

oh dear. okwe toto: oh dear mother. Okwe, katamata oni da aitopol angajepewok: please, let us also try to propagate our mother tongue. okwe lolo eong: oh dear me!okwenyu ainyam a very heavy cast-iron saucepan made at the blacksmithy (literally, wake up to eat – so because the saucepans are so heavy they last generations). okwii to or at the green bushes; to or at the shrubbery. kolot okwii kwi: go to yonder (those) green bushes. okwir a species of long-tailed gregarious ravens, making like sounds. olalaboi a glutton; Mr Wide Stomach.olangirikibwoko a person who always carries heavy loads. olap in, at, of, with the moon; in or during the month. abuni eong olap loitomonet: I will come in October. abu etunganan losodit kodo olap okaru 1968: the first man landed on the moon in 1968. oliborit a green plantain snake.
a pet name for a white cow.
October (literally, the month of hartebeests, ilobai).oloit a prison warder.
August (literally, the month when storing millet grain, iloja).olongalong one who likes to talk big or to boast
Mr. Bombastic. olongolong (of speech or movement) over-confident; expressing pride and big talk. ebala ngesi olongolong elosi: she/he walks proudly.
June (literally, the month of large white mushrooms, imaruk).omatet at a beer party

in or to a drinking spree or binge. omeena a tiny edible fish in the orugeny and ayoit family (a good remedy for measles). omelekes a tidy edible mole rat that sneaks into people’s homes and snatches domestic wares to store in its burrow in a dead anthill.omeleku a big swallow (bird).omilimil a bluebottle (fly).

July (literally, the month of the dirty or thick stirring stick, akingol). omoit a mouse-bird, Coleus-stratus. omolimol trypanosomiasis (a disease of cattle spread by tsetse flies), causing the animal to drool. omududu (formerly) a black variety of finger millet.
the title of former kings of Ankole (the present day Uganda districts of Mbarara, Bushenyi, Ntungamo)
the cultural leader of the Banyankole people.
February (literally, the month of shoes – amuk - because the sun is scorching hot, and also when trees grow new leaves, aimuk).
the title of former kings of Tooro or Bunyoro kingdoms

the cultural ruler of the Batooro or Banyoro people. omukeke a harmless black or brown sugar ant. omulat Trypanosomiasis (a disease of cattle spread by tsetse flies).omuran all male in-laws. omusaalatwo a clan leader as an unpaid agent of Government (literally, his wages are a gourd of beer).omusenu (singular noun M) a grass whose extract is used as a liniment in a guineaworm infection. omusikiiti at, in, to, from the mosque. omweso (singular noun M) a board game played with 32 holes and 64 peas (imor).onges a small scorpion with a very painful sting.oni (1st person pronoun plural of eong) we; us (inclusive of persons spoken to). (note: iso: we; us, exclusive of those spoken to). -onor a verbal suffix used with bi-syllabic '–or' verbs to denote a repeated action away from the speaker. aiwucor: to throw away (once only); aiwuconor: to keep throwing away (often). aremor: to topple over (once only); aremonor: to keep pushing over (often). onyamen a greedy man; a glutton; Mr Food.onyangairiare a short beer tube, ‘the Mill Compensater’. ooret a variety of edible mushroom (growing on cow-dung heaps). opaara a friend. opar on, to the papyrus mat.
May (literally, the month of hunger and slim stomachs, apedelel).opelec a small silvery fish, Engraulicy pris argenteus.
name of the first born boy twin (because it was the victor, i.e. aipior). (note: the second born boy twin is called Odong because it remained behind, i.e. aidong).
December (literally, the month of setting animal traps).
(formerly) a name given to a child passed through the roof to prevent its premature death (after preceding child has died).
a man’s name. opunuka a glutton

Mr Distended Stomach.opus (formerly) a variety of finger millet with purple-grey seeds. opyet! Finished! it is over! I stop there! -or a verbal suffix, indicating motion away or to become (in verbs in ki-o or class).
January (literally, the month when trees shed their leaves and women stock firewood, arara). ore at home

indoors. oria (imperative) clear out!; go away!oriatom a sensitive folding plant. oriimikuwan a nickname for a thin person or a little fellow. orima the faithful or obedient one. orinyo a plant, leaves of which are edible, Astrochlaena.
(formerly) a name given to a child passed through the roof to prevent its premature death (after preceding child has died).
(singular noun M) Holy Orders. esakarameeto lok’Orodiini: the Sacrament of Priesthood. orugeny a species of tiny (small) fish in the ayoit or omeena family

a National Resistance Army soldier (Uganda government army in the late 1980s), named so by the insurgents because of the general presence of child-soldiers in the army ranks. oruk a grasshopper with a ridge-back, Phymateus; a caterpillar with humps on the back; (formerly) a variety of groundnuts with red and white big seeds (often causing headache when eaten raw). orwa! (imperative) go away!; get out of the way! orwa ijo kane!: get out of here! vamoose! (plural) orwa yesi kane! osaapa on or to the papyrus mat. osarapune a greedy man or boy; a selfish man; Mr Hot Porridge; a glutton.
June (literally, the month of plentiful beer, asered).
October (literally, the month of drooping high grass, ema, heralding the beginning of the dry season).osuat a bishop bird.
November (literally, the month of the wakes or funeral rites, asuban). osyep on the side

at the side of something long; along; on the shore. kopaenene imotokan kosyep lokediany: always keep left when passing on-coming motorcars. otapasulyany the fortunate one; Mr Lucky One; the blessed one. otaupe a greedy person; a glutton; a stingy person; Mr Hot Heart.
(singular noun M) September (literally, the month of plenty to eat and drink, hence the month of big shit, feasting and dancing, ebar).otibok a grass, Urochloa panicoides.
(singular noun M) August (literally, the month of plenty to eat, hence the month of a big stomach, akoik).otitiro a herb whose root is believed to give virility to the men who chew it

traditional viagra or levitra plant. otitot a dragonfly.otogoro (singular noun M) electricity; electric power.otokwi (interjection of surprise, wonder, or of sudden pain) oh! oh! otolim in, at, towards the shade. alosi eong aiboi otolim: I am going to sit in the shade. otukwi oh oh! alas! expression of pain, hurt, or misery. otwele (singular noun M) (formerly) a variety of finger millet. oukoi (singular noun M) bovine pleuro-pneumonia; a fatal cattle disease that attacks the lungs, causing animals to foam in the mouth and die.owo a species of bird, Bittern exobrychus. oyapeesi at, in, from office; at, from the place of work; at the administrative centre. oyokiyok one who wears rattling ornaments; an ajosi dancer. oyunibasiti at, in, to the university. ikoku yenecobe esiomi toni oyunibasiti: a bright child studies upto university level.
(noun neuter) the sixteenth letter of the Ateso alphabet. -pa- infix indicating: being with, possessing. epaupa: my male friend

my male companion. epading: my male enemy. epae: a man friend. epadic: a male companion. eparian: a male equal; a male contemporary. epajen: a male relative. epaper: a male friend. pac recently; a short time ago. koleje pac: in the recent past. yenipac: the latest thing. nupac: the latest news. pamar (of a fat soft thing, to fall with a) thump; bump; thud. abu asirikaalet natuman kolatar koperet pamar aiilor: a fat female soldier collapsed and fell with a thud at the parade. papa one’s father (biological or otherwise); the brother of one’s father; the elder brother of one’s husband; the owner; the master; the superior; the boss. papa-odwe: the father of twins (literally, the father of many). papa k’ican: a very poor man; a pauper.papaa a grandfather; a brother of grandfather; a father of one’s husband. lukapaa: forefathers; ancestors. papakiye a man who causes trouble.papa-odwe father of twins. paran by day; during the day; at daytime. paran ecumere nges: it was during the day when she/he was stabbed. adol akolong kiding paran: the time or the sun has reached mid-day. pas (of fullness) very full; full to the brim; completely full. ileleba pas: it is very full.pasa pas (of fullness) very full; full to the brim; completely full. ileleba pasapas: it is very full. pe (of warmth or heat) very; extreme. ikoru ijo acok emwaka pe: you have served potatoes steaming hot. emwaka akipi pe: the water is very hot.-pe a suffix used in numerals to stand for ‘one’. epe M, ape F, ipe Dimin. (noun) one. akany kape : six (literally, five and one). ipeikoku: ikoku ipe: idiopekoku: one child. ediope: one; a single one. atipe: once. -pe- infix used with a demonstrative pronoun with an emphatic meaning: lopelo M: this very one. napena F: this very one. yepeyen Dimin.: this very one. lupelu (M plural): these very ones. nupenu (F plural): these very ones. jepeje M: that very one. kwipekwi (M plural): those very ones. kanepekanen: forthwith; immediately. nenipe: nepepe: all together; in one place. apenan: since time past. pee pe (of warmth or heat) very; extreme. inepit emukaro amwanus pee pe: the kiln is continuing to be very hot. amwana akolong pee pe: the sun is very hot. emwana akolong pee pe: the sun is very hot.pel (of a fire, a faggot) flaming, blazing. ekeritor aberu acukumac kuare pele pel: the woman runs with a blazing faggot at night.
(singular noun neuter) a sacrament of penance, atonement or apology
self-punishment. adumun penetesia: to receive penance.

(singular noun neuter) Pentecost (the seventh Sunday after Easter, commemorating the descent of the Holy Spirit on the apostles). apaarit naka Pentekosit: the day of Pentecost. petek (of an light or thin animal jumping or prancing) lightly, soundlessly. peu (of pain, heat) intense

severe; extreme. emwaka akima peu: the porridge is very hot.pii1 (of movement of body fluids) slowly; sluggishly. ebala akuwan pii: the body is sluggish. ebala eong akuwan pii: I am not feeling well; I do not feel well. pii1 (of something syrupy, flowing) slowly; thick. ebala esik pii: honey flows thick or is syrupy. pio (of something getting finished) completely; altogether; entirely. adaunos akipi pio: the water is completely finished. adaunos akipi kamot pio: the water is completely finished in the pot. piric (to squash, to crush) altogether; completely. ecak emotoka emucuuga piric: the car squashed the orange altogether. epiriciki emotoka eong elupe: the motorcar has squirted mud on me. piripir (of water, a reflection or a mirage) glittering; dazzling; shining.ecak egaali emuebe lokabosan piris: the bicycle crushed a rotten mango totally.pis (of extent of fullness of liquids or solids) very; brimming. aileleba pis: to be very full.aileleba pisi pis: to be very full.adaunos akipi pit: the water is completely finished.adaunos inyamat kosepuria piti pit: the food is completely finished from the sauce pan.ebiror ngesi po: she/he fell down with a thud. polis1 police; relating to the police force. igoen lukapolis: police clothes – police uniforms. ipolisin luenapete igoen lukaraya: plain clothes police (detectives).politiks (singular noun neuter) politics (the science or business of government); moves and manoeuvres concerned with the acquisition of power or getting one’s way. politiks lunyodok: dirty politics, involving slander, mudslinging, murders, etc.poo (of rain falling or a tree branch suddenly breaking) heavily; violently; powerfully. ebala edou etepi poo: the rain is falling heavily. abilun atenu poo: the tree branch has broken off suddenly. porododo noise of continuous diarrhoea. ebala je elepi porododo: porododo, thus goes the sound of his diarrhoea.

(noun neuter) (archaic) Friday.ileleba amot puc: the pot is brimful (with water or beer).pue (of spearing or knocking) right through pukupuk (sound imitation of the heart or a kerosene lamp) throbbing, beating, palpitating

fluttering, flickering, or sputtering. ebala ekatau pukupuk: my heart is throbbing, palpitating. elomarit ekwam otabaasa ngesi nen ebalar pukupuk: air has entered the lamp that is why it is flickering. pururu (sound of bird flying off) suddenly; swiftly. aporo ekweny pururu: the bird flew away very fast (making a purururu noise). purus (of a soft thing being speared or stabbed) right through; completely. aremi emerekek kakwara purus: a ram has been speared (impaled) right through.purus (of a spear or any sharp object piercing something soft) right through. aicum purus: airem purus: to spear right through.arem eong ekukwai akeju pus: a thorn has pierced my leg badly.ebir ikoku abaati kede engarot puu: the child has hit the iron roof boom with a stone. aduo eboomu kokide puu: a bomb has exploded massively in the east. pwa pwa (of a child bathing or splashing in water) noisily; loudly; carelessly. ilongi ikoku pwa pwa mam irigai akuwan da: the child is splashing water on its body without even scrubbing. pwe (of breaking of a soft thing, such as a rotten twig, a pot, a wet anthill) easily; effortlessly; noiselessly. abu ngesi kobwang amot pwe: she/he broke the pot noiselessly. pwos (of a hollow object falling and breaking) completely; utterly. adusaar etwo loka akipi pwos: a gourd of water has fallen and broken completely. pyana pyan (tasting) insipid; dully; blandly; characterless; unexcitingly. epyaka acuc pyana pyan: the ajon remnant is very tasteless. pyanga pyang (of an agitated liquid not full in a vessel being carried) shaking; unsteady; sloshing. ebala amot namam ileleba pyanga pyang kakou: a half empty pot of water shakes unsteadily as you carry it on the head. pyo (of something getting finished or exhausted) completely; totally. adaun edia pyo: the vegetables are finished completely.
Naikanyet puc (of fullness of vessels with liquids) entirely; brimful; full to the brim
(noun neuter) the seventeenth letter of the Ateso alphabet. rac (sound of mud, paste, or cow dung falling on hard surface) splash

splatter. adoo aoret kwap rac: the cowdung fell with a splash. -rai a verbal suffix to change certain –ar verbs to first person imperatives implying a request or repeated action. aninaar: to rub away; koninaarai: massage me, please. aitalakaar: to please or to amuse; kitalakaarai: amuse me, please.
(singular noun neuter) the ninth month of the Muslim year, during which Muslims fast between sunrise and sunset.rau (of red pepper, etc) hot

burning; searing. eta emulalu rau: the red pepper is hot to the taste. raya civilian; not relating to the armed forces or the police force. igoen lukaraya: civilian clothes – not uniforms of the army or policeeta ria: it is very bitter. edwar abalang ria ria: the traditional salt is very bitter. riak (to frighten, startle, scare) suddenly; abruptly. abu ngesi korieng riak: she/he was startled suddenly, got a sudden start, shock (on hearing or seeing something shocking). riaka riak very (startled, scared, shocked). asalaki ikoku ebala riaka riak akaulo ikapa asomakin nges: the child has remained startled after the cat jumped on him/her. riapa riap (of walking, gait) precariously; shakily; blindly; unsteadily; like a blind person. ebala emuduk riapa riap elosi: a blind man is unsteady while walking. rit1 (sound imitation of things falling, or soldiers’ feet when taking a salute) in unison; together; at once. rit2 (to be finished) completely; entirely; very; altogether.akoor: to scratch away; kokooroi: scratch my back, please. aipikor: to defeat or to overwhelm; kipikoroi: defeat me, if you can. -roroi a suffix after verbs and added to them, to mean 'to do ….meanwhile'. konyamaroroi ber ijo : you eat meanwhile (I do something else). rwa the sound of crackling joints. rwarwa (like the sound of a wild bush-fire on half-dry grass) crackling; rattling; clapping (of hands). aibap akanin rwarwa: to clap hands in unison. rwopo rwop (of or like a deflated stomach, tyre, or a football) emptily; vacuously. etapas ya egaali awuyonor, alomaki do aicak ngesi kobala amopiira rwopo rwop: the bicycle has disturbed that woman by getting deflated every now and again, she has decided to ride on with an empty tyre. rya very (bitter). eta rya: it is very bitter.
(noun neuter) the eighteenth letter of the Ateso alphabet. saa fragrantly
nicely; pleasantly. esaete ikonigoen: your (singular) clothes smell nicely.
(noun neuter) (archaic) Sunday.ebala akakuwan sangasang: my body is trembling. sarab (sound of drinking something thick) noisily.
(noun neuter) (archaic) Saturday.nan sek: earlier on today. kolo sek long ago

in the past. kolo sek kasonya: very long ago; in the far past. tupuruc sek: early in the morning. adilun sek: to rise early; to come early. sekisek very early. kobu sek (imperative) come early; come betimes. serena (singular noun M) (formerly) a variety of short and early ripening sorghum (developed from Serere research farm). serenat (singular noun M) a variety of purple groundnuts that is easily eaten by weevils (developed from Serere research farm). sereser (of a snake’s tongue) darting; flitting. ebala emun angajep sereser: the snake’s tongue is darting about. -si- an infix forming causatives in verbs with 'i' in the root (whether the infix should be –ti-, and not –si-will depend on the ease of vocalisation and the judgement of the speaker) aimik: to deny, refuse; aitimik: aisimik: to cause to refuse or fail, etc. sibilian civilian; not relating to the armed forces or the police force. igoen lukasibilian: civilian clothes – not uniforms of the army or policeaeniki emotoka esiisa sig nepenen: the car braked there and then. sigig (of something getting stuck or stopping) suddenly; at once; abruptly. aremokin emeleku okomyo sigig: the ox-plough has got firmly stuck on a tree stump. -sinei a suffix for generic plural of nouns. itunganan: a person; plural, itungasinei: people generally, tribes upon tribes, races. akwap: a country; plural, akwapusinei: the whole world. sinia at, in, to, from senior school. siri- a negative prefix, 'do not', followed by any form of verb. aarenen: to kill often; siriarenene: do not kill. adote: to fornicate; siridote: do not fornicate or commit adultery. akoko: to steal; sirikokoi: do not steal. siriki- a prefix for the negative imperative 'do not' or 'thou shall not'. (note that after siriki, all verbs are ki verbs). -sisi a suffix on adjective meaning 'grey' - losisi M, nasisi F, yenisisi Dimin. grey. -sodit a suffix implying 'the first'; 'the initial'; 'the original'. losodit (adjective M) the first. nasodit (adjective F) the first. yenisodit (adjective Dimin.) the first.
Naemukaaga sek before; ago; formerly; already; early; anterior

(proper noun) the old name of Soroti. sude (to upset, tip, turn or push over) completely. abu esirikaalet kisudeor sude: the soldier made a perfect somersault. sue (to fall over) awkwardly, clumsily. aido sue: to fall over. ado eong sue: I tumbled over.suenye sueny (of the manner of walking of a short person) with short brisk steps. ebala ngesi elosi suenye sueny: she/he walks with short brisk paces. swaraj (to put something somewhere) dirtily

offensively; foully. swe (to fall over) clumsily; awkwardly. ado eong swe: I tumbled over awkwardly. swee (sound of rain falling) in little drops, drizzles. etepi edou swee: the rain is drizzling. swi (of many things) teeming; plentiful; congested; crowded. swiswi snivelling sound (as of one with a bad cold or asthma). swoswo (to gape or be open) widely; broadly. eorori etogo swoswo: the house has a big opening or gap; the house is empty.
with vowel of root of verb, forms infix of causative verbs which are all ki-verbs and have the ki conjugation

the ‘ta te ti to tu’ infixes follow the verbal prefix a- or ai- and precede the root of the verb: ainyam (to eat): aitanyam (to feed, to cause to eat); aiten (to put to be straight): aiteten (to cause to be straight); ailip (to pray, to beg): aitilip (to cause to pray, to cause to beg); ailot (to wash): aitolot (to cause to wash); aidum (to get): aitudum (to cause to get or find). t (noun neuter) the nineteenth letter of the Ateso alphabet. -ta adverbial suffix, emphatic ‘this, that, etc very one’ after demonstrative pronouns: nata F or lota M: this very one; nuta F or luta M: these very ones; neta: just here, etc. -ta- infix of causative verbs with ‘a’ in root: ainyam: aitanyam; ainap: aitanap; aidak: aitadak
(noun neuter) (archaic) Thursday.imonyi ijo tai: you are crying for nothing. taitai1 very

too much; exceedingly; everywhere; all over the place. itaditos itunga itogoi okaabi taitai: people have built randomly at the refugee camp. taitai2 a corruption of atitai: (to do something) in vain; for nothing. aari etunganan ngol taitai: that man was killed for nothing (i.e. he had no fault).bia tani ne: come here a moment.taparac sek: very early in the morning (before sunrise). tapi from that; so that; consequently; therefore; forthwith; after which. tapi bo ijo abunere: after which you should have came. abu edou kotep apaarit ngin tapi bo naimecia ijo ne: it rained on that day so that you took shelter here.ebala abaati taratar ijangijanga akwap: the iron roof is vibrating noisily during the earth-quake.tata grandmother (either on father or mother’s side); the senior wife; the principal wife (called thus by concubines). -te- causative infix for verbs with 'e' in the root: aitep (to rain): aitetep (to cause to rain); aidem (to confiscate, grab): aitedem (to cause to confiscate, rob). tei (to break a small glass or brittle thing) into bits; completely. abwanga igilaasi tei: the glass tumbler has broken into bits.abila akan teketek: the hand is completely broken. teletel (to shake or tremble) very much; vigorously. amaran teletel: to tremble or shake extensively due to cold or fear. teni truly; really; verily; all right. teni bo: in fact, true indeed, or very much so. teni bo kabala eong yes: I’m definitely telling you. ejaas teni teni: they are at it for real; they are doing the actual thing. teong (exclamation of disapproval) don’t!; stop it; now now! look! You see! ter a sound of a wound spring falling or the splitting of glass slightly. ebala akilauri ter edea: the glass of a hurricane lamp split by itself.
Nakiongonet tai anyhow; in vain; for nothing
(singular noun neuter) Trinity. Sande na Teriniti: Trinity Sunday. tes sound of a brittle article breaking. aibwang tes: to break into pieces.
(singular noun neuter) (formerly) a district in eastern Uganda with the headquarters in Soroti town, native land of the Iteso people
a district in South Western Kenya occupied by Iteso of Kenya; the areas of Soroti, Kaberamaido, Katakwi, Kumi, Tororo and Pallisa occupied by the Teso tribe.
(suffix) of or pertaining to Teso, its people or its culture. teten to, at the right hand. akan nakoteten to, at the right hand.tetere in order that

so that. kiswamata tetere idumunete inyamatakus: work in order that you may get your meal. tetere mam: lest. korimaana tetere mam ijo kitisilaaro: be obedient lest you be punished. ti1 (of weight; of silence) very; absolute. ililingi amoru na ti, mam ipedori aijangakin da: this stone is very heavy, one cannot even move it a little. kidum itunganan kililing ti, adumu neenyamia: if a person suddenly keeps quiet (when she/he was previously noisy), that person has got something beneficial to do. aililing ti: to be quiet.ti kalot: I would (should, or might) have gone. abunar akokor ebe ti akokoar: to snatch a chicken with the intent of stealing it. -ti- causative infix of verbs with 'i' in root and preceding the verb: airim: to turn (vowel in root 'rim' is 'i' causative is ‘tirim’ or ‘sirim’) hence aitirim: to make (cause, let, force) to turn or rotate. ti3 enclitic after lo, na, yen, lu, nu, and other demonstrative pronouns: lo ti lo (also lo si lo): this one. tiarai should; might; could; would rather; preferably; she/he/you/I better do. tiarai ijo ilosi: it should have been you going. tiarai adukokin ekonitogo ne: you rather build your house here.tii ti (of weight; of silence) very; absolute. ililingi lokadekan tii ti, mam epedori bobo einer da: the patient is very quiet, cannot even talk a little. aililing tii ti: to be absolutely quiet; to be too heavy. kililingata tii ti: keep very silent; keep very quiet. tilikida hurrah! Bravo!; hooray! tilikidaa tilikida, ya: (said by a dance-leader morale boosting his/her fellow dancers) yeah hurray! tinenikwana (in reference to the past) at this time in the past; about this time in the past. tinenikwana kinyouni: we would be leaving at this moment (about this time yesterday). tipi such that; so that. iwalarit ca lolo erono, tipi idedeng ijo kwangin: you may have woken up badly such that you are irritable like that.eboi ngesi kane tir: she/he/it has stayed here all day.tiritir all day; constantly; always; often; many times; repeatedly; daily; continually. ebunenenei ngesi ne tiritir: she/he/it comes here very often (hence, I am tired of him/her/it).

(noun neuter) (archaic) Tuesday.togo in, within, at, from, towards the house. ejai ngesi togo: she/he is in the house. toi (to sting, bite, or peck once) badly. kakony eong elacit engabet toi: a louse has bitten me hard on the waist once. toi toi (to be stinging, biting, or pecking) very much

badly. kakony eong emukuny iwos toi toi: the black ant bit me several times on the buttocks painfully. -tok a noun suffix indicating people of a place (frequently used in place nouns beginning with consonants and ending in vowels): Ingoratok: people of Ngora county (in Kumi district); Imuriatok: people from Amuria county (in Katakwi district); Ikumetok: people from Kumi town or Kumi district. Igweritok: people from Gweri sub-county in Soroti. toma in; into; inside; through. ejai edia toma osepuria: vegetables are in the cooking pot. toni until; and so; and then; then; as far as; up to. aiboi toni tupuruc: to stay upto morning.too (noun neuter) west to, from, in the west; westerly. elomari akolong too: the sun sets to the west. tooka a corruption of totoka (my mother) or of togoka (my house).
Naiyareit -to- causative infix of verbs with 'o' in root and preceding the verb: aitor: to pass, vowel in root is 'o' and the causative is ‘totor’, hence aitotor: to let pass; to force to pass
(noun neuter) the land of the Batooro people

the pre-colonial western Uganda kingdom ruled by an Omukama (king). tope just awhile; a moment. bia tope ne: just come here a moment.toto mother; the elder sister of one’s husband; mama; a female parent; an elderly lady. totoka: my mother. toto-acelit: a snail. toto katitipu: a queen ant. toto k’ican: Mother of sorrows. totokiye: Mother Trouble. totowok: our mother. toto katitipu the queen ant. toto-akit the eardrum.. totokiye a woman who causes trouble; Mother Trouble (euphemism) the anus; the arsehole. toto-odwe the mother of twins.tototot (of a flood of liquid or tears from a person crying) bubbling incessantly; flooding unrestrained. -tu- a causative infix of verbs with 'u' in root and preceding the verb - aitub: to cut; vowel in root 'tub' is 'u', the causative is tutub hence aitutub: to make or cause to cut, or cause to pass (or cross). tuitui (of a person or animal walking about) heavily; with feet thumping the ground. ebakasi alotok korot kuare tuitui: the foot steps of those walking on the road at night can be heard. tul (to rot or decompose and smell) completely; altogether. ebos akitukuke tul: his/her mouth smells badly (has a very foul smell). aibos tul: to rot altogether or completely. eur etulutulu tul: sulphuric acid is very pungent. ebos emalas tulu tul: the milk churn smells nasty.ebos amot tulutul: the pot smells very badly (has a very bad smell). tupuruc in the morning; at dawn; at daybreak. tupuruc sek: very early in the morning. twar (of light being reflected) dazzling; flashing; beaming. ebala edou twar: there is lightning accompanying the rain. aimilia twar: to flash brightly.ebala edou twaratwar: there is a lightning storm. aimilia twaratwar: to keep flashing brightly. twilitwil (of something small) very or extremely small. edit ngesi twilitwil: she/he is very small.
(noun neuter) the twentieth letter of the Ateso alphabet

a vowel letter as in ‘woo’. u2 exclamation of wonder, painful surprise, or of entreaty - please; oh! u bia!: please do come here! u okwe papa!: oh, father! u toto abei lolo ai?: u ito, abei lolo ai?: oh, mother, where shall I go? woe upon me!-un verbal suffix indicating action towards the speaker: imperative singular -u, plural –utu: kobu (come) becomes kopotu; plural 2nd & 3rd person –unete: adolun (to arrive) becomes edolunete (they arrive); reflexive singular –un and plural –unos: emata (drinkable) – ematun (to absorb) becomes ematunos (to be absorbed) in plural reflexive. -uni suffix of cardinal number three (3) or thirty (30). angor auni: three women. itelepai akais-auni: thirty (ten times three) boys. akinei atomon-kanuuni: thirteen (ten and three) goats. -uniet suffix of ordinal number three (3): the third; Wednesday. lokiuniet M: the third. nakiuniet F: the third; Wednesday. -unun a verbal suffix denoting a repetitive action towards the speaker. awoun: to put down from someone’s head (once only); awounun: to keep lifting and putting down (from people’s heads – many times). aremun: to push down (once only); aremunun: to keep pushing down this way (often). us exclamation of contempt or of refusal: pooh. us, etumit ngol tai: gosh, he is fat for nothing (he is a useless fellow). uuss (sigh of disapproval) pooh; humph. uwokwe a corruption of u okwe: exclamation of horror or contempt.
u okwe: wu okwe: exclamation of horror, dismay or contempt
(noun neuter) the twenty-first letter of the Ateso alphabet

a semi-vowel sound. waa imitation of sound of a pressure lamp, radio atmospherics or drizzling rain. ebala eredio waa: the radio is not clear due to atmospherics. ebala edou waa: the rain is pelting the zinc roof hard. wailo this side, to this side. bia wailo: come to this side.waije to the other side of; across. kolot waije: go to the other side of.
juwai the other side; to the other side: okekwa je

(noun neuter) (archaic) Wednesday. Wenside nakekurwon: Ash Wednesday (the first day of Lent or the Christian fasting season).epipil akajimi wiliwil: my sore is very painful. winyiwiny (of itching, a sore) very (painfully sweet). -wok a suffix forming possessive pronoun 1st person plural of -ka: our (inclusive of audience). lowok M, nawok F, yeniwok Dimin.: ours. papawok: our father (mine and yours). ngesi lowok: that is ours (you inclusive). wori? (interrogation) when? ibuni ijo wori?: when will you come? wu exclamation of wonder or painful surprise or of entreaty, horror, or contempt. wu okwe kingarakinai!: oh, please help me! wu okwe papa!: oh dear, father! wu toto abei lolo ai!: oh, mother, woe betide me! wu okwe exclamation of painful surprise, horror or contempt.
Nakiuniet wiliwil (of pain, to hurt) very sharply or acutely
(noun neuter) the twenty-second letter of the Ateso alphabet

a semi-vowel sound. ya demonstrative of feminine singular nouns, meaning ‘the female far off’. apak ya: at that time. aberu ya: that far off woman. eyapeya: there she is.yakayak imitation of a cracking or rattling sound, as of dry leaves falling or being walked on. ebakas akwi nukaokok yakayak: dry leaves crackle when walked on.yapeya feminine demonstrative pronoun: ‘that very female’ we talked about; that far off woman (or feminine object). aberu yapeya: that very (female) one we know. yem like the sound of dry grass being shaken or disturbed. ebala ibore yem kokitwi: something is shaking the dry bushes. yen diminutive demonstrative pronoun: this. ikoku yen: this child. yen- prefix of relative pronoun of diminutive or neutral nouns: who; that. ikoku yenedeka: the child who is sick. yeti yen: this very (small) one. yepeyen (emphatic): this very (small) one. yenegei (noun neuter) the first (to do something or to be born).yenegei nges edumuni ainakinet: the first one will receive or get a gift. yenelingi (noun neuter) the one that comes first; the first born child.loelingi (M), naelingi (F): the first. loelingi nges edumuni ainakinet: the first one will receive a prize. yenemodomodoo (noun neuter/Dimin.) a dupe; one who is deceived. yenice indefinite diminutive pronoun: the other. komina yenicekoku: love your sibling. yenididi (noun Dimin.) the little or small one. yenikaronon (noun neuter) an evil or bad one (thing); a sinner (in general); a criminal. yenikatupan (noun neuter/Dimin.) a succeeding one (child); the child following another in the order of birth; a person following up something (an issue, a case, etc). yenikaurian (noun neuter.) a parent; a producer (bearer); a begetter; a primogenitor; a progenitor; a forebear. yeniki- a prefix of ordinal numbers in neuter or diminutive: the nth. yenikiareit: the 2nd one. yenikiuniet: the 3rd one. yenimeo (only of plants and animals) thin-bodied; willowy. yenisodit the first (one). yenitemeri intoxicating; causing drunkenness or dizziness. yes (personal pronoun 2nd person plural used as an object) you. ajeni yes: I know you. yesi (personal pronoun 2nd person plural used as a subject) you. ijenete yesi: you know.Yesu Kristo Jesus Christ (the founder of Christianity). yi a demonstrative diminutive pronoun: that far off little one. ikoku yi: that child over there. yitoyi (emphatic): that very little one over there. ikesa yi: that far off little fellow. yoo yo (of a knife, a razorblade, etc) very sharp. ekwana ekileng yoo yo: the knife is very sharp, it just slices through. yoga good day; greetings to you; how do you do? congratulations. yoga aswam: well done. yoga noi: many tidings (greetings). yoga do: bye-bye; bye for now.
